title: Beirut's Rightist Leader Asserts Reforms Can Only Follow Peace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31The head of the rightwing Phalangist Party today demanded the restoration of public order before there could any consideration of political reform of Lebanon's 32yearold system.

title: ExChief Appointed
description: MONROE, La., Dec. 31 (AP)Johnny Robinson, the former Kansas City Chief defensive back, was named today to John David Crow's new football coaching staff at Northeastern Louisiana.

title: N.F.L. Alumni Unit Backs Court Ruling
description: DETROIT, Dec. 31 (Al')The National Football League Alumni Association, made up of about 1,000 former players, said today it supported the Federal court decision yesterday that declared the Rozelle role to be in violation of the antitrust laws.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: 2 Appointed in U.S. Attorney's Office

title: State Is Assailed on Care Of Its Troubled Children
description: MONTCLAIR, Dec. 31An 18month study by the Citizen. Committee for Children of New Jersey has sharply criticized statesupervised longterm residential facilities for troubled children.

title: Met and Musicians Agree On Pact, Averting Strike
description: The Metropolitan an Opera reached agreement with its orchestra on a new twoyear contract last night, averting a strike that had been scheduled to begin at midnight.

title: MARY LOUISE KENNEDY
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 31Mary Louise Kennedy, a specialist on children's literature, died Monday of cancer. She was 51 years old.

title: For a National Urban Strategy
description: New York's fiscal crisis is far from over and the package put together by Gov. Hugh Carey needs nurture and good luck to succeed. But it is not too early to examine the deeper problems that occasioned the crisis, for they threaten nearly every major metropolis in the country. And unless there is a radical change in our national approach to this urban malaise there will be more New Yorks in the future of America's cities.

title: Boston High School Repairs Will Be Completed by Jan. 5
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Improvements ordered at South Boston High School by a Federal judge will be completed when students return from their holiday vacation Jan. 5.

title: Lafayette and Canarsie Look Like the Best
description: Basketball's busy Christmas season is over, and it produced some things to look forward to in the new year. At this point, Lafayette and Canarsie, both from Brooklyn. seem to have the best chances in the race for the Public Schools Athletic League title. Tolentine of the Bronx is proving itself the strength of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.

title: South Africa Calls on the West To Increase Its Role in Angola
description: JOHANNESBURG. South Africa, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Minister John Vorster urged tonight. that Western involvement in Angola he increased and said that all of Africa would face enslavement if the Angolans were allowed to he hounded into the Communist fold.

title: Sale of Slater Shares Set
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) Slater, Walker Securities Ltd. said its former chairman, James Slater, had arranged to sell his entire holding of 2 million ordinary shares to a private company owned by family interests of the current chairman. Jaill(i  Goldsmith, The price was 23 pence per share, or about .17 cents.

title: 2 Peas In a Pod In Cotton
description: DALLAS, Dec. 31 (UPI)The Georgia Bulldogs and the Arkansas Razorbacks look and play as if they were stamped from the same mold. The teams are so similar that even their names sound alike: The Dogs vs. the Hogs.

title: New Brunswick Warns City Workers Of Layoffs to Hold Down Realty Taxes
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 31 of this city's 550 employees received a layoff alert in their paycheck envelopes today as the city administration began looking for economies to prevent or curb further increases in the local property tax rate.

title: U.S. Steel Closes 3 Units In Gary on Clean Air Order
description: GARY, Ind., Dec. 31 (UPI) United States Steel has shut down three cokeproducing facilities at its Gary works. but comnany official says that the city's air quality will be scarcelyif at allimproved by the shutdown.

title: '75 Brought Carey Fame But Ended on a Sour Note
description: Hugh L. Carey, who began 1975 as a stranger to Albany and its intricacies, ended the year as a national figure, with more formal power than any Governor in the state's history, but enmeshed in controversy over his motives for trying to dismiss the special prosecutor he inherited from his Republican predecessors.

title: Blue Cross Rise Opposed
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 31 (AP) The National Treasury Employes Union filed suit today in United States District Court to cut in half an increase in Blue CrosBlue Shield health insurance premium for government workers and their families. The increase, due to take effect to. tomrrow, would raise premiums by 35.3 percent.

title: Chinese Puzzle
description: Even Moscow, it appears, was as totally unprepared as the rest of the world for Peking's decision to release three Soviet helicopter crewmen it had been holding as prisoners since March 1974, and even to suggest some regret over the incident and a desire to make partial amends. The Soviet Ambassador to China has said he is as mystified by it as anybody else, while Tass indicates that the Kremlin itself is puzzled. Inevitably, there is now widespread speculation about what it all means, if anything.

title: Ford Looks Back on 1975 As a Year of Achievement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 President Ford looked back today on what he said had been a year of personal accomplishment in domestic and foreign policy and said he was resolved in the New Year to achieve peace throughout the world, better economic conditions and the strengthening of individual freedom in this country.

title: Incentives in Soviet Industry inadequate for Speedy Growth
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31 On a wall above the workbenches of a Leningrad factory, there hangs a large electric counter that looks something like a basketball scoreboard. It is divided into two parts, each With a threedigit number formed by lights.

title: Amid the Revelry, a Hope for a Better Year
description: Typical 75, groaned John Miziack, ripping up his betting slip in the offtrack betting parlor on Times Square. That's the way I've been running all year.

title: Men at MidDecade: Elezance Revival
description: If in the seventies, fashion went out of style for women, all signs point to it coming back for men. Serious fashion, that is. No more bangles and beads: it's back to short hair, shirts and ties. Look for a revival of the man in the gray flannel suit or the one who looks as though he's got a gentleman's gentleman waiting in the wings.

title: W.H.A. Saints Play Without Pay
description: ST. PAUL. Dec. 31 (AP)The Minnesota Fighting Saints of the World Hockey Association failed to meet their $140,000 semimonthly payroll today. But the club avoided folding when its players voted to keep playing without pay while attempts to raise funds continued.

title: Contract Awards
description: American Bell International Inc. was awarded a $23 million Air Force contract to provide professlonal assistance for development of a plan for a national communications system for Iran.

title: BOY'S DEATH RULED A BEATING HOMICIDE
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 31 (UPI) Hudson County authorities ruled today that a 6yearold boy had been beaten to death on the day before he was reported missing by his mother last Nov. 13.

title: Spirit of 76' Flares in Massachusetts Over the Issue of Stamp in Pasadena
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass.. Dec. 31The Spirit of '76, the painting of the battered but defiant. fifer and drummers that have come to symbolize the American Revolution, hangs here in this seacoast town whose hardy mariners rowed Washington across the Delaware. Tomorrow. on the first day of the Bicentennial Year, a stamp reproducing the famous painting will he issued.

title: Spirit of76' Flares in Massachusetts Over the Issue of Stamp in Pasadena
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass.. Dec. 31The Spirit of 76, the painting of the battered but defiant. fifer and drummers that have come to symbolize the American Revolution hangs nere in tnis seacoast town whose hardy mariners rowed Washington across the Delaware. Tomorrow. on the first day of the Bicentennial Year, a stamp reproducing the famous painting will he issued.

title: City Death Rate Reported At a Record Low in 1975
description: The city's Health Department reported yesterday that the city's death rate9.6 per thousand populationwas the lowest since citywide statistics were first compiled in 1898.

title: SEVERAL AIRPORTS; SEALING LOCKERS
description: A number of major airports including Chicago's O'Hare, the nation's busiest, and Washington's National and Dulles closed lockers to the public yesterday. And in New York, similar security moves at airports intensified, with the sealing of lockers at both commuter bus terminals in Manhattan and the PATH railroad station in the World Trade Center.

title: Amid the Revelry, a Hope for a Better Year
description: The year of the nation's 200th birthday arrived last night much as 1975 did a year beforein pouring rain, with thousands of boisterous New Yorkers forgetting for a moment the problems that made them wish that the incoming year would be better than the last.

title: Truce Group Ends Laos Role
description: VIENTIANE, Laos Dec 31 (Agence FracePresse)  The International Cont ml Commis sion, set up 21 years ago in a vain attempt. lo bring peace In Indochina, ended its activities in tam today the explana tion that the 1951 Geneva agreement on Indochina, under which the commision was created. was no longer valid.

title: Market Place
description: Seven years agoon Jan. 2, 1969a leading institutional research organization published a 21page report about a billiondollar company that, in the research organization's judgment, was a giant learning to walk. The report said, however, that the company was on its knees. . . . This year [we] expect it to struggle to its feet and, by 1970, to begin moving forward.

title: Leafs Game Postponed
description: TORONTO, Dec. 31 (UPI)California's National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs was postponed tonight and rescheduled for tomorrow afternoon. The game was postponed so that Toronto fans could see the Soviet ArmyMontreal game on television.

title: MUSE UNIT SEEKS INQUIRY INTO F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) A select House Intelligence Committee investigator said today that there was evidence that the Federal Bureau of Investigation may be attempting to retaliate against or squelch an investigation of possible F.B.I. purchasing improprieties.

title: Trudeau Urges Canadians To Adopt New Lifestyle
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (AinPrime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau told Canadians in a message for the New Year that they must adopt a new lifestyle if they are to cope with economic difficulty.

title: STATE COURT VOIDS $800,000 IN LULUS
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31A State Supreme Court justice today declared illegal the Legislature's practice of paying allowances to Senators and Assemblymen during their own two year terms in office.

title: Study of Dr. King's Death Finds No Links to F.B.I.
description: This is the first of two articles on renewed questions about the assosinal ion of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It was written by John M. Crewdson and is based on reporting by Mr. Crewdson, Ben A. Franklin, Nicholas M. Horrock and Martin Waldron.

title: Notes on People
description: As the result of a recognized but previously urpublicized brain tumor. Dr. Karl A. Menninger is netirolog cally and medically seriously ill. his physc ians annoLinced yesterday. The 82yearold psycmatrist was hospitalized in Topeka earlier this month for surgery to drain fluid from the brain in the hope of relieving his dizzy spells and partial loss of hearing. Dr. Menninger. chairman of the Menninger Foundation. was in New York Nov. 1112 for a convocation marking the foundation's 50th anniversary. In late November he was hospitalized for 12 days of testing.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Moscow Denies Violating 1972 Strategic Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31  The Soviet Union today rejected charges by American critics that it had cheated on its arms agreements with the United States and hinted that it harbored its own doubts about American compliance.

title: Moving of Liberty Bell Opens Bicentennial
description: PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 31 For weeks officials here and in Washington have billed tonight's transfer of the Liberty Bell from Independence Hal to a new pavilion across the street as the first Bicentennial event of the new year.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Washington Star

title: Producers of Gas Are Split On End to Pipeline Loans
description: The end of the controversial advanced payments program to natural gas producers, though it came as no big surprise to the industry, brought a mixed reaction yesterday.

title: INDIAN LEADER GETS 4 YEARS FOR RIOTING
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 31 (AP)  Russell Means, the American Indian Movement leader, was sentenced to four years in prison today on a rioting charge.

title: A 116YearOld's Good Advice
description: At 116 years of age this New Year's Day, Dionisia Perez advises other people, with remarkable vivacity, to be happy. Most of her days, and some nights, she spends singing tunes of the 19thcentury Puerto Rico she remembers so well.

title: New Year: New Mess
description: Just when it appeared that everything had been tidily set in place for resuscitation of the state's battered anticorruption drive, Governor Carey scrambled things all over again by his jolting attack on Special Prosecutor Nadjari.

title: Bangladesh Envoy Arrives
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Deed 31 (Reuters)The first Bangladesh ambassador to Pakistan, AbduIlah Zaheeruddin, arrivedi today to an unusually warm ,welcome. His arrival formalized the establishment of diplomatic ,relations between Pakistan and its former eastern wing, which broke away in December 1971.

title: U.C.L.A. Gets 2d Chance
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP)The University of California, Los Angeles, has a sense of history when it tries tomorrow for an avenging, upsetting Rose Bowl football victory over topranked Ohio State.

title: BreakIn Effort Reported At Ford Campaign Office
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) A burglar alarm went off orly today at a suite occupied by President Ford's campaign Coramittee, but the police said the intruders apparently had not taken anything from the office.

title: Article 4  No Title
Top Mental Health Official In Connecticut Retire
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 31 (AP)Ernest Shepherd, Conecticut's top mental health official since, 1969, retired today and said he might return to work as clergyman.

title: SEA AREA NAMED FOR OIL LEASING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31The Department. of Interior announced today the selection of 1,172,796 acres on the Georges Bank, 50 to 200 miless, offshore from Nantucket Island, to be offered tor oil and gas leases. This is an area never before drilled.

title: Carey Appoints 2 Justices To Appellate Division Bench
description: Governor Carey yesterday designated Supreme Court Jusices Joseph H. Hawkins of Poughkeepsie and Vito J. Titone of Staten Island to serve on the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court for the Second Department.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Transit Authority announced that, starting today, 25 cent addaride transfers will be available for the first time between local routes of authority buses and lo.cal. buses operated by six privately owned lines. The private companies are the Triboro Coach Corporation, Green Bus Lines. Jamaica Buses Inc., Queens Transit Lines. and Steinway Transit Inc., all in Queens, and the Pioneer Bus Corporation in Brooklyn.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTO
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday ended the year in a bullish fashion in moderate trading.

title: TEENAGERS PLAY AIDS THE NEEDIEST; Another Donor Says. If We Don't Care, Who Will?
description: A twoact play, Son cf Claus, which was written and produced by a group of teenagers from the Youth Ministry of the Community Church of Douglaston, L.I., turned out to be an artistic an financial success. As a result the production benefited the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund by $85.

title: Massachusetts Vote Law Upheld by High State Court
description: BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP)The State Supreme Court upheld today a new law doing away with the election of delegates to national political conventions.

title: JOHN J. O'LEARY
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Dec. 31 (AP)John J. O'Leary. close friend and special agent for President John F. Kennedy, died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Physicists Find Support For Charmed Quark Idea
description: Physicists in the United States and Europe believe they have produced for the first time particles of matter displaying the elusive property known as charm.

title: Physicians Warned On Use of Solution In Eye Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that a problem may have developed with certain surgically implanted human eye lenses that could result in the loss of an eye.

title: 2 LEADERS CONFER ON SAHARA CONFLICT
description: RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 31 (UPI)President Moktar Daddah of Mauritania and King, H'assan II of Morocco met today to consider Algeria's increasing opposition to the annexation of Spanish Sahara,

title: LEFKOWITZ BALKS AT PLAN TO PLACE AIDE OVER NADJARI
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz who three days ago pledged to retain Maurice H. Nadjari as special state prosecutor for six more months, expressed doubt yesterday that he would go along with Governor Carey's new plan to appoint an interim special prosecutor.

title: SEOUL CONVICTS 3 AS REVOLUTIONARIES
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 31 (AP)The Seoul district court convicted two striking newsmen and a school lecturer today of plotting a Maoist revolution and sentenced two of them to prison terms of four years and the third to eight.

title: 70's Fashion: Sportswear at the Summit
description: Somewhere around 1970, fashion itself began going out of fashion. And no wonder: look what was happening:

title: Ring Out, Ring In
description: New years lose their luster, as a rule, a few days after their opening. No longer seen through a champagne glass brightly, the world appears once more to be the same old place, as full of problems and distress as ever. Nevertheless, there is still a point in celebrating New Year's Day for the perspective it periodically brings to the past and the hope it offershowever momentarilyfor the future.

title: Moscow Denies Violating 1972 Strategic Arms Pact
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 31  The Soviet Union today rejected; charges by American erities that it had cheated on its arms agreements with the United States and hinted that it harbored its own doubts about American compliance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: INSIDE MONTE CARLO. By Senley Jacsson. 278 pages. illustrated Stein & Day. $12.60.

title: Mexican President Bars Apology Over Country's Vote on Zionism
description: MEXICO CITY. Dec. 31 (UPI) President Luis Echeverria Alvarez says he would rather die than ask forgiveness for Mexico's antiZionist vote in the United Nations.

title: Notes on People
description: As the result of a 'Iong recogmzed but previously unpsublicized brain tumor, Dr. Kari A. Menninger Is neurologically and medically seriously ill. his physicians announced yesterday. The 82yearold psychiatrist was hospitalized in Topeka earlier this month for surgery to drain fluid from the brain, in the hope of relieving his dizzy spells and partial loss of hearing. Dr. Menninger, chairman of the Menninger Foundation. was in New York Nov. 1112 for a convocation marking the foundation's 50th anniversary. In late November he was hospitalized for 12 days of testing.

title: W.VirginiaTopsN.C.State,1310,in Peach Bowl
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 31 (AP)Dan Kendra threw touchdown passes of 39 yards to Arthur Owens and 50 yards to Scott MacDonald in leading West Virginia to a 1310 victory over North Carolina State today in the eighth annual Peach Bowl college football game.

title: FAR PRICES RISE IN 4WEEK SPAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  The Agriculture Departmeilt said today that prices farmers get for raw agricultural products rose 1 per cent from Nov 15 to Dec. 15 and averaged 5 per cent higher that at the close of 1974.

title: Just a Snow Job for Crazy Mike
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Dec 31Mike Brandt, the owner of West Mountain, maintains he was crazy to get into the ski business, but this mornmorning he was more ecstatic than crazy. A snowstorm that ended early this morning had deposited eight inches on his report's slopes and provided excellent conditions, the best here for the young season. The snowfall gave the mounrain depths up to 36 inches.

title: Carlos Said to Go to Libya In a Deal With Terrorists
description: LONDON, Dec, 31The elusive trrrist known as Carlos Martinez, who has been identified as the leader Of the gang that kidnapped Middl Eastern oil ministers from Vienna two weeks ago, has apparently left Algeria for Libya, according to police sources in Europe and the Middle East.

title: Petroleum Distillate Stocks Fall in Week
description: Stocks of distillate fuel in the United States fell significantly last week, reflecting cold weather in many parts of the country.

title: Harpsichordist And Violist Play Baroque Works
description: The billing for the concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was a little misleading. The big print was devoted to Sylvia Marlowe and Friends. It turned out that although this was the overall name of the series, Miss Marlowe actually had nothing to do with Tuesday's affair, other than lending her Dowd harpsichord to the harpsichordist of the night, a former pupil.

title: People in Sports
description: President Ford, a firststring center on the University of Michigan football team before his graduation in 1935, has a $2 bet with Senator Dewey F. Bartlett,  Republican of Oklahoma, on tonight's MichiganOklahoma game at the Orange Bowl. A week ago Senator Bartlett out a loyal $1 on Oklahoma. He doubled his bet with the President yesterday, notwithstanding the absence of O.U. running back Horace Ivory, as Bartlett put it. Ivory was suspended from the team last week for disciplinary reasons.

title: RHEINGOLD PLANT AGAIN IMPERILED
description: City officials met yesterday to preserve the hardwon and idelicate arrangement that has kept the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn in operation for the last two years.

title: Soviet Six Triumphs
description: MADISON, Wis., Dec. 31 (AP)Vladimir Kovin scored two goals yesterday as a touring Soviet Union hockey team defeated a United States Olympic squad, 84.

title: Washington Post Rejects Bid to Reopen Labor Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31A new committee of 100 labor union, religious, political and professional leaders sought unsuccessfully today to persuade The Washington Post to reopen negotiations with its striking pressmen.

title: Bridge:
description: The most successful New York player in the old year of 1975 was not, as it happens, a New Yorker. The winner of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Player of the Year title, based on a calendar year of New York tournaments, was Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J. This was a title she would have won in the past, hut until recently players living outside New York City and Long Island were ineligible.

title: Rice Output Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)  Strict controls on rice production in 1976 to help head off a rising surplus were announced today by the Agriculture Department. The controls include a sharply reduced acreage allotment.

title: About the Soviet Teams. ..
description: Vladimir Shadrin of the Soviet Wings was sent to a Pittsburgh dentist this week to repair five upper front teeth, all cracked in half by a blow from a Penguin in the corner during last Monday's game. . . The Russians drink hot tea with lemon and sugar between periods. . . Only a few of the Soviet players wear sweat socks. The others wear ordinary black street socks inside their skates. They say they can feel the skate blade better that way. . . The players rise at 7 o'clock each morning to do calisthenics in their rooms with television sets turned up full volume. Then they jog through the hallways to limber up.

title: BOND PRICES SLIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The bond market ended 1975 with a small decline in prices yesterday but many traders remained convinced that 1976 would bring a resumption of December's pronounced trend toward lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve once again pumped temporary reserves into the banking system, an action that reassured the bond market that the central bank is headed toward a somewhat easier monetary policy. Trading activity, preceding what for many is a fourday weekend, was almost at standstill.

title: Paterson Driver Is Charged In Crash Fatal to Woman
description: TOTOWA, Dec. 31 (AP)A young Paterson man was charged today with causing the death of a 99yearold woman in a twocar crash here that also injured six persons, the police said.

title: ARGENTINE COURT CLEARS MRS.PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 A federal judge has cleared President Isabel Martinez de Per& of criminal liability in the drawing of a $700,000 check from a public charity for deposit in the estate of her husband. Juan Domingo Pern

title: Britain Reports a Decrease in Strikes
description: LONDON. Dec. 31British workers, who have stormed out on strike often enough in recent. years to demolish a lot of notions about British civility. are settling down.

title: Udall Seeking to Outstrip Liberal Pack
description: SALEM, N. H.  For more than a year, Morris K. Udall has been touring the country, quietly telling groups of potential supporters that he does not really need the hassle of what he has been doing.

title: WALDHEIM URGES LONG VIEW ON U.N.
description: UNITED NATION, N.Y., Dec. 31  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, in a New Year's message, urged the 144 member countries today to view the obvious shortcomings and failures of the world organization from the longrange perspective that governments must still learn to use the very complex mechanism of the United Nations and also to cooperate with each other.

title: Hurled Stones Halt Train
description: LONGWOOD, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPI)  Youngsters throwing stones yesterday stopped an Amtrak train on its way from New York to Tampa. The police said that the windshield of the Champion was smashed, and that the engineer, A. O. Roberts was hit by splinters of glass. The train was halted for 15 minutes.

title: COOP CITY GROUP LOSES A COURT BID
description: Leaders of the resistance at Coop City to paying a 25 percent increase in monthly carrying charges lost another court suit yesterday when the full bench of the Appellate Division, First Department, ruled against them.

title: Physicians Warned On Use of Solution In Eye Operations
description: WASFIINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that a problem may have developed with certain surgically implanted human eye lenses that. could result in the loss of an eye.

title: Spanish Leader Predicts Laws Leading to Amnesty
description: MADRID, Dec. 31The head of Spain's national police said today that the Government would proclaim amnesty for prisoners, but only after making changes in the penal code and the antiterrorist law.

title: W. T. GRANT SEEKING BONUSES APPROVAL
description: The W. T, Grant Company aid yesterday it is seeking court approval of $2.3 million in bonuses for company supervisors and the Sam Nassi Company, supervisors of Grant's store liquidation program. Nassi holds a $6 million contract for the liquidation.

title: Albert A. Lowe, 83, Dies; Motion  Picture Salesman
description: Albert A. Lowe, a global motionpicture representative, died Monday in his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 83 years old and formerly lived in Rye. N. Y.

title: ULSTER PUB BLASTS KILL 2, INJURE 37
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Dec. 31 (AP) Terrorist bombs expioded among New Year's Eve drinkers in three bars in Ulster, killing two persons and iniuring. 37. nonce said.

title: Year of the Dragon Honors 5th Animal In Buddhist Cycle
description: TOKYO. Dec. 31 RIMDramatic ups and downs and pionty Of excitement may he in store in 1976the Year ot the Dragon on the Chinese calendar.

title: France Freeing Last African Area
description: PARIS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) France announced today that it Was granting independence to the territory of Mars and Issas, its last African posession,

title: Dividends
4 Die in Greek and Turkish Quakes
description: ANKARA, Turkey. Dec. 31 (Reuters)Three persons died and 14 were injured last, night when earth tremors struck parts of southeastern Turkey that were damaged by a major quake in September, the stateowned Turkish radio said today.

title: Landfill Issued Writ
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 31 (AP)A Superior Court judge yesterday ordered operators of a garbage dump in rural Sussex County to stop accepting chemical wastes pending a court hearing here on Jan. 16.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DENVER, Dec. 31 (AP) Denver officials have filed a $47,334 tax lien against the Denver Spurs of the World Hockey Association to recover part of the $80,000 the team owes the city for money collected under the city's 10 percent seat tax. A report by Auditor John Dee shows that the team owes $80,285 for the season as of Nov. 30, but the report includes no data for debts incurred in December.

title: Alabama SugarVictor Over Penn State, 136
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama knew exactly what he was doing when he suggested to Sugar Bowl officials that they invite Penn State to be the Crimson Tide's opponent in the 42d annual Sugal Bowl game tonight.

title: GULF REPORTS GIFT TO AIDE IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON. Dec. 31A Gulf Oil Corporation official has testified that his company paid $10,000 as a thank you present. to William .T. Flanagan the executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: Philadelphia Wins a Stay On RefuseDumping Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) A Supreme Court Justice today allowed Philadelphia to continue dumping garbage In New Jersey, pending a decision by the full Court on a wastedisposal dispute.

title: UKRAINE DISSIDENT GETS AN EXIT PERMIT
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) Exit permits have been signed by Soviet authorities for a dissident Ukrainian mathematician. Leonid Plyushch. and his, family. His wife, Tatyana, said today that they must leave by Jan 10.

title: Cuban Exiles Said to Join
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (AP)Cuban exiles in the United States are being signed up as mercenaries to fight against Cuban Communist troops in Angola, according to a recruiter. Jose Antonin Prat, a Bay of Pigs veteran.

title: Soviet Proposes to Ease Travel for Journalists
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today of fered to ease internal travel formalities for Western Jour. nalists, giving them the same privileges as diplomats.

title: Next Year, Perhaps a College Bowl
description: Not long after Woody Hayes arrived at the Rose Bowl for his fourth consecutive California visit, the 62yearold commander of Ohio State was asked to comment on the decisions of John McKay to transfer his 52yearold brain from the University of Southern California to the new Tampa Bay Bucanneers of the National Football League.

title: Open Interest
5000YearOld Temple Found in Soviet Armenia
description: MOSCOW Dec. 31 (UPI) Archaeologists have discovered a 5,000yearold temple in Armenia that they describe as the oldest architectural relic in the Soviet Union, the farm daily Selskaya Zhizn reports.

title: Penguins Set Back Kings, 51
World Events of 1975: A Review in Photographs
description: The end of American action in Vietnam came with evacuation of officials and employees, some by helicopter. Efforts to achieve peace and harmony in the Mideast continued, but in Portugal violence marked the rivalry of leftist and rightist elements in a power struggle. Three heads of state died, one at the hands of an assassin, and Hirohito, Sakharov and Mrs. Gandhi made news.

title: Reprieve for Yonkers
description: Yonkers, which had faced a 25 percent cut in municipal services and personnel today, has received a twoweek reprieve under a lastminute accord reached with its municipal unions. Page 35.

title: Rep. Randall Retiring
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 31 (UPI) Representative William J. Randall, Democrat of Missouri, has announced that he will not seek reelection next year to toe congressional seat tias held for 16 years. He said that he suffered front ?? last year, but

title: Nancy Carpenter Wed to David James
description: Nancy Joan Carpenter of San Diego, widow of Dr. John Rice Carpenter, was married in San Diego yesterday afternoon to David Alton James, president of the Richard A. Mills Insurance Company there. The Rev. David Laird Barclay performed the ceremony in St. Dunstan's Episcopal Church.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The first contributor to a campaign to raise $7 million to $10 mill:on for the city's cultural institutions lives in Dayton, Ohio. He is David Gilmore, a 28yearold veteran of the Vietnam war, who this week sent a check for $100 to Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Commission for Cultural Affairs.

title: Year of the Dragon Honors 5th Anunal In Buddhist Cycle
description: TOKYO. Dec. 31 (UPI)Dramatic ups and downs and plenty o excitement may he in store in 1976the Year of the Drlgon on the Chinese calendar.

title: Trudeau Urges Canadians To Adopt New Lifestyle
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 31 (AP)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau told Canadians in a message for the New Year that they must adopt a new lifestyle if they are to cope with economic difficulty.

title: Lenore Lucey Has Nuptials
description: Lenore M. Luccy. an associate of Vitto and Robinson, Architects, here, was married early last evening to Gary B. Vowels, corporate vice president of Edward Durell Stone Associates.

title: Market Closes Out 1975 Showing a Modest Gain
description: The stock market bade farewell yesterday to one of its best years in history by staging a modest advance in more active trading.

title: Thousands Reported to Lose Pension as Concerns Cut Back
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Thousands of workers are losing their pension plans as private companies terminate the coverage in unexpectedly high numbers, Representative Charles A. Vanik says.

title: Enchilada Sauce Recalled Over Contamination Fears
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) Nearly half a million cans of enchilada sauce are being recalled because of possible bacterial contamination, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

title: British Chrysler Workers Accepting Plan for Rescue
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) Workers at Linwood. Scotland, and some other plants of Chrysler United Kingdom Ltd., a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, today accepted the Government rescue. plan. which calls for a reduction of more than 8,000 in the company's workforce of 25,000.

title: Authority to Merge Upstate Branches Of Banks Begins
description: Statewide branching among banks in New York State becomes effective today. New York's banking enterprises have received authorization to merge their upstate branches into the parent banks in New York or other headquarters cities.

title: A Proposed New Symmetry in the basicconstituents of matter
$500,000 Fire in Montana
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Dec. 31 (UP)Fire swept through a half block of businesses in the downtown section yesterday, causing damage estimated at $500000. Six firemen and a woman were treated for smoke Inhalation.

title: Teheran to Execute 10 Rebels for Killing U.S.Officers,Others
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec, 31 (AP) An Iranian army tribunal has sentenced 10 guerrillas to deathl by a firing squad for the killing; or three American colonels, an Iranian employee of the United States Consulate and four other Iranians.

title: Ford Accepts Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)President Ford has accepted the resignation of Jacob Seidenberg as a member and chairman of the Federal Service impasses Panel. effective today. No successor was announced.

title: ARGENTINE COURT CLEARS MRS,PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 A federal judge has cleared President Isabel Martinez de Peroin of criminal liability in the drawing of a $700,000 check from a public charity for deposit in the estate of her husband, Juan Domingo Peron.

title: 3 in Philadelphia Plead Not Guilty on Gun Charges
description: PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 31 (UPI)Three of five men indicted on charges of illegally purchasing arms and smuggling !them to the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland pleaded not guilty in Federal Court today.

title: Same Flavor to New PrimeTime Shows
description: Although the networks are making substantial midseason changes in their programming, the flavor of prime time will not be altered by the effort similar in type to those being discarded. Of the canceled shows, seven, were actionadventure series and five were situation comedies. Among the replacements, six are adventure dramas, and six are situation comedies. Moreover, like the departed shows, the new comedies are in the bold tradition established by All in the Family, and the dramatic shows are largely concerned with police work.

title: Article 2  No Title
Sihanouk to Visit Cambodi
description: TOKYO, Dec. 31 (AP)Prince Norodom ?? Cambodia's chief of state, left Peking today by special plane for his second visit to his homeland since the Communist victory there eight months ago.

title: Reprieve for Yonkers
description: Yonkers, which had faced a 25 percent cut in municipal services and personnel today, has received a twoweek reprieve under a lastminute accord reached with its municipal unions. Page 35.

title: Rockwell Cites Payment Of $570,000 in 4 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Rockwell International Corporation has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it paid $570,000 to foreign government officials or employees in connection with sales in four countries.

title: Smith Bows In Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (UPI)  Stan Smith was eliminated from the $105,000 Australian open tennis championships today, making an allAustralian quarterfinal lineup.

title: New Year's Day
description: Today is New Year's Day. Following is a list of services that are affected:

title: Fine Nutcracker by Eglevsky on L.I.
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 31 The Nutcracker is more than just another ballet. It is easily the most popular ballet in any company's repertory. It is also likely to be the first ballet anyone sees and is a standby of the Christmas season throughout the country. The myriad mountings of the work vary widely from the spectacular glamour of the New York City Ballet's to minor local attempts that are best forgotten.

title: LEFKOWITZ BALKS AT PLAN TO PLACE AIDE OVER NADJARI
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who three days ago pledged to retain Maurice H. Nadjari as special state prosecutor for six more months, expressed doubt yesterday that he would go along with Governor Carey's new plan to appoint an interim special prosecutor.

title: Gulf Reports a Payment To Jersey Turnpike Aide
description: TRENTON, Dec. 31A Gulf Oil Corporation official has testified that his company paid $10,000 as a thank you present to William J. Flanagan, the executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: JOSEPH R. GARRY, 65, JOHN B. BROOKS, 84, INDIAN LEADER, DIES EXGENERAL, IS DEAD
description: SPOKANE. Dec. 31 (UPI)Joseph R. Garry of the Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, great grandson of Chief Spokane Garry and a national Indian leader, died, following a stroke in a local hospital yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: The Daily 50Cent Lottery Goes Out as Heavy Loser
description: NEWARK, Dec. 31The end came today for New Jersey's 50cent daily lottery ticketone of four choices that had been available to players in the state's lottery programand the consensus was: good riddance.

title: Social Security Tax Is Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)For American workers earning $15,300 a year or more, Social Security taxes increase 8.5 percent starting New Year's Day, taking a still bigger bite from the paychecks of middleincome workers in 1976.

title: Jobless Numbers
description: WASHINGTONEarly this month, the Labor Department announced its latest statistics on employment in the United States. The number of jobless dropped from S million in October to 7.7 million in November, causing the unemployment rate to decline from 8.6 percent to 8.3 percent (a good sign!). At the same time, the number of jobs decreased slightly, from 85.44 million to 85.28 million (not such a good sign!).

title: Jury in Hodge Murder Is Sequestered for Night
description: A State Supreme Court jury, unable to reach a verdict in the murder trial of Beverly Donna, Hodge, accused of plotting the murder of her husband, a rock, music arranger, was sequestered in a hotel last night.

title: Egypt $7 Billion in Debt For Nonmilitary Assistance
description: CAIRO, Dec. 31 (AP)Egypt bas disclosed that its nonmilitary debts to foreign countries total almost. $7 billion.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALTERNATIVES Today can be more than just an opportunity to visually grapple with 8 hours and 45 minutes of televised collegiate football. One can venture forth through town and view the city in one of its annual rare muted moments as the populous is generally engaged m resolve, recover and contemplation. Yet, somewhat abated, the New York pace continues.

title: World Events of 1975: A Review in Photographs
description: The end of American action in Vietnam came with evacuation of officials and employees, some by helicopter. Efforts to achieve peace and harmony in the Mideast continued, but in Portugal violence marked the rivalry of leftist and rightist elements in a power struggle. Three heads of state died, one at the hands of an assassin, and Hirohito, Sakharov and Mrs. Gandhi made news.

title: New Year's Day
description: Today is New Year's Day. (allowing is a $list of services lit are affected:

title: Udall Denies He Seeks Fannin's Senate Seat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI)Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, acted today to quash speculation that he planned to drop out of the Democratic Presidential race to run for Senator from Arizona.

title: Doubts and Anxiety for NATO Officials
description: BRUSSELS  Military commanders and civilian officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are increasingly anxious over what they view as weaknesses and imbalances Military Analysis threatening the alliance's credibility. They say that improvements in some areas are more than bal anced by obsolescent materiel, a lethargic pace toward standardization, sharp differences in the quality of frontline forces, political agitation in the French and Italian Armies and awkward and potentially dangerous deployment of troops and supplies.

title: Gulf Oil Puts Aside Tax Money for Angola
description: PITTSBURGH. Dec. 31 (Reuters)  The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it had placed estimated tax money due the Angolan government in a special account for the benefit of the state of Angola.

title: Joan Braden Gets State Department Post
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 31 The State Department announced today the appointment of Joan R. Braden. a friend of Vice President Rockefeller aid Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, to the newly created $37,800ayear job of coordinator of consumer affairs.

title: Chess:
description: Valery Chekhov won the 1975 World Junior Championship in Tjentiste, Yugoslavia, the fourth triumph for a Russian entrant since the series was initiated in 1951. Boris Spassky took it in 1955, Anatoly Karpov in 1969 and Alexander Beljavsky in 1973.

title: Armina Marshall Takes Stock of Stage
description: When Armina Marshall made her New York debut in 1922 in Paul Claudel's The Tidings Brought to Mary, her whole motive was to be in actress. And though she was a good one (an actress of uncommon abilities Brooks Atkinson of The New york Times wrote of her in Those We Love), she round herself drifting away from the footlights proper into becoming a playwright, a play adapter, a director of the Theater Guild, producer et the Theater Guild of the Jr and owner and operator of the Westport Country Playhouse.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Udall Seeking to Outstrip Liberal Pack
description: SALEM. N. H.  For more than a year, Morris K. Udall has been touring the country, quietly telling groups of potential supporters that he does not really need the hassle of what he has been doing.

title: SEVERAL AIRPORTS SEALING LOCKERS
description: A number of major airports including Chicago's O'Hare, the nation's busiest, and Washington's National and Dulles closed lockers to the public yesterday. And in New York similar security moves at airports intensified, with the sealing of lockers at both commuter bus terminals in Manhattan and the PATH railroad station in the World Trade Center.

title: Egyptians Enter Israeli Section To Construct Warning Outpost
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 31Egyptian jeeps,, supply trucks and bulldozers churned through Israelicontrolled territory in Sinai this morning to start the construction of an earlywarning station near the eastern end of the strategic Gidi Pass.

title: Occidental's Cost Of Nationalization Put at $19 Million
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 31 (Reuters)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that nationalization of its properties in Venezuela and Nigeria would reduce its net income in 1975 by $19 million.

title: City Bicentennial Body Denies It Will End Up in Red on July 1
description: The city's Bicentennial Corporation accused the office of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday of jeopardizing delicale funding negotiations by reporting pimaturely that the corporation would he $137,519 in the red by July 1.

title: Nancy Carpenter Wed to David James
description: Nancy Joan Carpenter of San Dicco, widow of Dr. John Rice Carpenter, was married in San Diego yesterday afternoon to David Alton James. president of the Richard A. Mills Insurance Company there The Rev David Laird Barclay performed the ceremony in St. Dunstan's Episcopal Church.

title: Too Young to Be Cited
description: GENEVA, Ohio (AP) Robert C. Coy has assured the Ashtabula County Juvenile Court that his son, Jeffrey, has not sneaked out in the family car despite the court's notice of a, traffic citation, Mr. Coy said tne court sent a letter telling him to appear in court with his seri ard ?? ?? license to answer the citation. Jeffrey was only two months

title: Deaths
Dark Horse Stocks Led the Way in Year's Advance
description: A year ago, if an investor had tried to pick the best stock market winners for 1975, what would have been his choices?

title: Spanish Leader Predicts Laws Leading to Amnesty
description: MADRID, Dec. 31The head of Spain's national police said today that the Government would proclaim amnesty for prisoners, but only after making changes in the penal code and the antiterrorist law.

title: Fishbach Takes Title
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 31Pete Fishbach, the topranking Eastern player from Great Neck, defeated unseeded Joel Ross of Hartsdale, NY.. 64, 63, and won the New York State men's in?? tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: History of Raiders: Losing, but to Best
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 31 The Oakland Raiders are looking at their game with the Steelers in Pittsburgh on Sunday, not unlike some highly proficient student with a long record of accomplishment entering a final exam that will produce an advanced degree, admission to the bar, or something equally crucial.

title: Rates on Letters Going Overseas Also Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP)The Postal Service said today that rates for overseas mail had also been increased in the latest postage rate rise.

title: BigBand Promise Not Fully Realized In Calloway's Show
description: The promise that seems to be implied by the appearance this week of Cab Calloway with his big band and his revue at the Riverboat is realized in only the most superficial manner.

title: Markets Idle Today
description: All securities, commodity. and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today for the Npw Year's holiday. Banks, businesses and Government offices will also be closed.

title: Egyptians to Vote This Year For President and Assembly
description: CAIRO, Dec. 31 (UPI)President Anwar elSadat has approved a timetable for elecdons late in 1976, according to an exchange of official letters made public today.

title: Portugal Raises the Price Of Gas 80 Cents a Gallon
description: LISBON, Dec. 31 (AP)The Government has raised the price of hightest gasoline from $2 a gallon to $2.80, making Portugal one of the most expensive countries to drive in.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Coop City Group Loses a Court Bid

title: Man Dies in Fall Off Bridge
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP)A New Orleans man stopped to help at the scene of a traffic accident early today, fell through a hole in a clamaged guard fail and plunged 200 feet to his death, the police said. He was Glen Brauer, 30 years old, who fell from a bridge that carries Interstate 10 over a canal and industrial area. A car and a large truck had collided on the bridge.

title: Oklahoma, Michigan: Ground Duel
description: MIAMI, Dec. 31 (UPI)The air is expected to be virtually free of passes tomorrow night when secondranked Oklahoma and fourthranked Michigan meet in the 42d annual Orange Bowl football game.

title: Former Executive Of Dairylea Fined In Sale of Milk
description: ALBANY, Dec. 31A former executive of the Dairylea. Cooperative Inc. has pleaded guilty to petit larceny here in the latest of the legal actions against the giant milk cooperative arising out of the sale of adulterated milk several years ago.

title: Manson Wins Final
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec 31 (UPI)Bruce Manson of Southern California won the Palm Springs collegiate tennis tournament today with a 64, 64 victory over Jon Eric Palm of Arizona state in the final.

title: Russians Tie Canacliens, 33
Article 3  No Title
Reuters Manager Retires
description: LONDON. Dec. 31 (Reuters), Brian Stockwell retired today, as general manager of Reuters, which he served for 38 of his 60 years. lie is succeeded by Michael Nelson, his deputy. Gerald Long, managing director, said: Brian Stockwell gave his life's work to Reuters, as did his father before him.

title: F. P. C. APPROVES A PRICE INCREASE FOR NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Federal Power Commission authorized today an increase of $500 million a year in natural gas prices that will be borne by households and other consumers. But in another decision, which represented a major policy change, it gave a victory to consumers that was a setback for large oil companies.

description: FOOTBALL

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Ford Looks Back on 1975 As a Year of Achievement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 President Ford looked hack today on what he said had beer a year of personal accomplishment in domestic and foreign policy and said he was resolved in the New Year to achieve peace throughout the world, better economic conditions and the strengthening of individual freedom in this country.

title: Miss Potter Triumphs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, I.I., 31  Barbara Potter of 'Woodbury, Conn., overcame Lydia Caporale of Brooklyn, 13, in the 18's final and Judy Braisted of Staten Island beat Martha Roberts of Greenwich, Conn., 75, 63, for the 16's title in the Eastam junior indoor tennis championships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: US. IBIS CHANGES FOR COAL LEASES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) New proposed regulations for nonproducing coal leases on Federal lands were announced today by the Department of the Interior.

title: Music; Students Give Concert ?? Carnegie Hall
description: For seven years now, Carnegie Hall and an organization known as New School Concerts have sponsored a holiday season training orchestra activity under the direction of Alexander Schneider. and each year the New York String ,Orchestra, as it is called, has played public concerts. The first is traditionally at midnight on Christmas Eve, and this year the second was on Tuesday night.

title: Physicists Find Support For Charmed Quark Idea
description: Physicists in the United Slates and Europe believe they have produced for the first time particles of matter displaying the elusive property known as charm.

title: Donna Laub Married To Jeffrey M. Kramer
description: Donna Lois Laub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Laub of Great Neck, I..I., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Mark Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kramer, also of Great. Neck.

title: Beame, Looking Ahead, Orders JobRecovery Program
description: At the close of a witheringly bad year, Mayor Beanie searched for fresh beginnings at City Hall yesterday by ordering a fiveyear jobrecovery program and swearing in a new first deputy and a new cityplanning chief.

title: Yonkers, Facing Cuts, Gets Reprieve
description: The city of Yonkers, which had faced a 25 percent cut in municipal services and personnel today, has received a twoweek reprieve under a lastminute agreement between the city and its municipal unions.

title: Dietz Crew Is Victor in 8Oar Event
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 31Jim Dietz. the national sculling champion. stroked the New York Athletic Club eight to a twolength victory over the Middletown, Conn.. Rowing Club today in the 20th annual New Year's Eve regatta of the New York Rowing Association.

title: D. Lawrence Jaffe, 62, Is Dead; Microwave Technology Pioneer
description: D. Lawrence Jaffe, an early developer of microwave electronic technology in World War II, died Monday in Kyoto, Japan, where he had been on vacation. He was 62 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla., and formerly lived in Great Neck, L. I.

title: POTATO FUTURES DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: In the at trading session of the year, commodity speculators were noticeably absent yesterday and trading volume was sharply below average on most exchanges. In fact, most exchanges had only a short session to allow members to leave early..

title: Who's in Charge?
description: BLOOMFIELD. N. J.It took many years for me to realize that I do not live alone.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Notes on People column in The New York Times of Nov 22 reported that George Whyle whose name was misspelled as White had helped Valery and Galia Panov, the ballet dancers to emigrate from the soviet Union To Israel and had lent them $60000 to buy a baller studio in Whyte says he did neither.

title: Con Ed Agrees to Sell Nuclear Plant to State
description: Under strong pressure from Governor Carey's office. Consolidated Edison agreed yesterday on the terms for sale of its Indian Point No. 3 nuclear power plant to the state.

title: Study of Dr. King's Death Finds No Links to F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31For nearly eight years the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has puzzled many private citizens and even some Government officials who were skeptical that James Earl Ray, an escaped exconvict with no obvious antipathy toward the black civil rights leader, had been the lone assassin, despite Mr. Ray's own admission of guilt in court.

title: Irish Train Crash Kills 5
description: GOREY. Ireland, Dec. 31 (AP) A passenger train jumped damaged tracks and crashed down an embankment today in southern Ireland, killing five persons and injuring 30, railroad officials reported.

title: Irish Spaniel Gains Honors Hard Way
description: For five years Mrs. Anne Snelling was looking for a good Irish water spaniel. When I finally located one, Naptandy's Annie Oaktrees, recalled the Canadian, I almost lost her. She managed to get out of her crate at LaGuardia Airport and for an hour and a half they pursued her When they finally caught her, the experience proved traumatic. She was terrified of everything. It was two years before we were able to bring her around.

title: U.S. Steel Closes 3 Units In Gary on Clean Air Order
description: GARY, Ind., Dec. 31 (UPDUnited States Steel has shut down three cokeproducing facilities at its Gary works, but company official says that the city's air quality will be scarcelyif at allimproved by the shutdown.

title: Flames Rout Rangers, 81, At Garden
description: Question: Is it possible for the New York Rangers to look more inept than they did Sunday night against the Soviet Army team?

title: The Gulf Scandal
description: The finding of a special review committee, headed by John J. McCloy, that Gulf Oil Corporation's clandestine political activities were shot through with illegality is a heavy blow to the corporation and its top executives. But, unfortunately, Gulf is not alone in having maintained a political slush fund, in doling out secret payments to politicians at home and abroad in exchange for favors. The McCloy report should serve as warning to all other corporation executives who by similar actions, have imperiled not only their own companies but respect for a free economic system and the democratic process itself.

title: Extinction by Red Tape
description: Compared to a Government bureau, the mills of the gods grind exceeding fast. In August 1973, the United States Senate ratified an international convention for the protection of endangered species of plants and animals. The Interior Department actively promoted the treaty and urged quick passage of a law for carrying out its provisions. !laving got everything it asked for, the Department has in effect sat on its hands ever since,

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Moving of Liberty Bell Opens Bicentennial
description: PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 31 For weeks officials here and in Washington have billed tonight's transfer of the Liberty Bell from Independence Hal to a new pavilion across the street as the first Bicentennial event of the new year.

title: Office Pool, 1976
description: WASHINGTONNew Year's tradition demands that this space be turned over to the Third Annual Office Pool, in which every reader becomes an instant pundit. The fallibility of the resident essayist is exposed, as an appetite for the coming years news budget is whetted.

Union to Israel and had lent them $60,000 to buy a ballet studio in Jerusalem Mr. Whyte says he did neither.

title: TWOCOUNTY GROUP BACKS FRED HARRIS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31 Former Senator Fred R. Harris was endorsed last night for his party's Presidential nomination by the New Democratic Coalition of Westchester and Putnam Counties, in a convention attended by about 130 of the oroun's almost 1.000 members.

title: GUN TESTS DELAYED IN68 KENNEDY DEATH
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 31 (UPIA county judge postponed at least three weeks today a decision on whether additional tests were needed to determine if more than one gun was fired during the Robert F. Kennedy assassination seven years ego.

title: NEW ORDERS FELL DURING NOVEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31Manufacturers new orders declined in November while inventories showed the second consecutive month of moderate Increase, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Article 1  No Title
GRACE DISPOSING OF ITS LEAF UNIT
description: The W. R. Grace and Company said yesterday that it has sold its Leaf Confectionery division for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes to a new company whose principal officers are former executives of the division. The division, which was bought by Grace in 1967, is based in Chiago. Grace at that time paid 280,000 shares of its stock then worth $49.25 a share, or a total of $13.79 million.

title: 1975: Start of Recovery, Easing of Inflation and U.S. Tax Cuts
description: The economy began to emerge from its recession in the late spring of 1975. An upturn in the gross national product and industrial production was evident in the summer months and early fall. Inflation began to OA falling , from doubledigit figures, at an annual rate, to 7 to 8 percent. Wholesale prices continued to climb during 1975, but, the rise, 4.3 percent, was modest in comparison with the 17 percent gain during 1974.

title: F. P. C. APPROVES A PRICE INCREASE FOR NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Federal Power Commission authorized today an increase of $500 million a year in natural gas prices that will be borne by households and other consumers. But in another decision, which represented a, major policy change, it gavel a victory to consumers that was a setback for large oil! companies.

title: Personal Finance: Tracking Deposits
description: Depositing funds in a checking account can be simple, but there are some complexities that ought to be understood by individuals with these accounts.

title: Mamie Eisenhower Taken to Hospital From Farm Home
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Mamie Eisenhower, 79 years old, was taken by ambulance today to Walter Reed Army Medical Center after she became ill at her Gettysburg, Pa., farm home.

title: The Dance: Le Spectre de la Ros;
description: His dancing is accomplished in that flowing line, without a break between poses and gestures, which is the despair of all novices and almost all other virtuosi. After a particularly difficult leap or toss of the legs or arms, it is a marvel to observe how, without an instant's pause to regain his poise, he rhythmically glides into the succeeding gesture.

title: Rhode Island Wins Suit
description: PROVIDENCE, Jan. 1 (AP)The state of Rhode Island was awarded a $5.06 million judgment against the Bethlehem Steel Company yesterday for remedial painting of Newport Bridge, which spans Narragansett Bay from Conanicut Island to Newport.

title: Sooners Victors in Orange, 146
description: MIAMI, Jan. 1  Three hours after the University of California, Los Angeles, had upset Ohio State, nation's No. 1 team. Oklahoma lifted itself back into contention for the top ranking by beating Michigan, 146, in the 42d annual Orange Bowl game before 80,307 fans.

title: Engineers Here Urge Prudence On Discouraging Use of Autos
description: A new report on automobile traffic in Manhattan contends that city and regional planners are on slippery ground and may be doing real damage to the economy in making decisions affecting automobile usage.

title: Guests at Holiday Fete Pay Extra to Thieves
description: A bunch of thieves mingled with thousands of celebrators at a marathon party at the New York Coliseum early yesterday and rang in the New Year with drinking, dancing and larceny.

title: RECORD REPORTED IN BANKRUPTCIES
description: A sharp rise M bankruptcies was noted yesterday in a comprehensive annual report on the Federal courts in the Second Circuit, covering New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: Revelers Go Home as Families Breeze In
description: There was only the briefest of pauses yesterday as the last horntooting reveler staggered away from the city and the families arrived.

title: DOCTORS ON COAST STAGE SLOWDOWN
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 (UPI)  A slowdown by doctors protesting soaring malpractive insurance rates led private hospitals today to begin turning away to county facilities accident cases that were not considered emergencies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver, 23, Killed in Crash
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, Jan. 1 (AP) A 23yearold Mays Landing man was killed today in a twocar headon collision on Route 40 here, the police said. They said the man, James Dorman, was dead on arrival at the mainland division of Atlantic City Medical Center. The police said the driver of the second car, John Catille of McKee City, suffered only minor injuries.

title: Bogus  Student Faces Inquiry at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Early fast fall, Bernard John Chu. bet 3d walked into the Tower Club, an eating club in one of the old fraternitylike buildings here. He was greeted as a quintessential member of the Ivy League.

title: Air Traffic Increase Slowed Daring 1975
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 1 (AP)Traffic on the world's scheduled airlines increased by only 2 percent in 1975 compared with 6 percent in 1974, the International Civil Aviation Organization has reported.

title: Finland's Hard Winter
description: The shotgun wedding that recently gave Finland a government of national emergency is a result of lagging economic recovery in West Europe, Finland's chief market. With the prospect of a much deeper depression this winter than had been expected, the Communist Party has been brought back into the Cabinet for only the second time since World War II.

title: 100,000 Gallons of Oil Foul the Hudson
description: One hundred thousand gallons of homeheating oil spilled into the Hudson River on Wednesday and yesterday after a barge rammed an abutment of the Tappan Zee Bridge. The accident left a narrow swath of oil running from Haverstraw, N. Y., to the George Washington Bridge.

title: Arkansas Wins, 3110, With Rally
description: DALLAS, Jan. 1 (UP)Arkansas accepted a gift of 10 points to tie the score at the half today and Scott Bull hit Freddie Douglas with a 35yard pass to set up the goahead touchdown in the fourth quarter as the Razorbacks scored a 3110 victory over Georgia in the Cotton Bowl.

title: STATE COURT BARS NEWSCAST IN FILM
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has granted a preliminary injunction requiring the removal of parts of a WCBSTV newscast from a New York manufacturer's promotion film. The decision, handed down Tuesday, affects only the film's distribution in New York State.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times Wednesday about a biography of William Loeb, it was incorrectly stated that Kevin Cash, the author, had written that Mr. Loeb told his wife that he drank raw alcohol to help him fail a physical examination for the draft in World War II. The Cash book states that Mr. Loeb told his wife merely that he intended to drink the alcohol.

title: Holiday Revelers Clash With Police In 3 Florida Cities
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI) Confrontations between policemen and New Year's revelers in three south Florida cities early yesterday resulted in at least 175 arrests and two dozen injuries, according to reports by the authorities.

title: Dumpson to Stay On As Search Widens For a Replacement
description: James R. Dumpson, who was expected to leave his post as City Human Resources Administrator and Social Services Commissioner yesterday, will stay on temporarily while city officials expand their search for a replacement on a national level.

title: About New York
description: Over the years it has gotten to Frank Manza, although he does not acknowledge it, and if you mentioned it he would not like it at all. Mr. Manza is a short man, built approximately like a fireplug with a paunch, and he could easily have done a walkon in On the Waterfront." Inside, however, he is a marshmallow. Mr. Manza loves animals.

title: ASPIN URGES INQUIRY INTO NORTHROP FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)Representative Les Aspin. Democrat of Wisconsin. called today for reopening of the Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into illegal campaign contributions by the Northrop Corporation.

title: Ballet Spotlight on Martine van Hamel
description: You wouldn't expect a young dancer who won a gold medal at the Varna international ballet competition in Bulgaria in 1966the same year Mikhail Baryshnikov won hisand who was a leading younger ballerina with the National Ballet of Canada to wind up in the corps de ballet of American Ballet Theater.

title: Monsieur Tocqueville! Oh, Get Some Water He's Fainted!
description: DETROITIn July 1831, Alexis de Tocqueville, the French social observer, arrived in Detroit in search of the extreme limits of European civilization. His was not a simple task. Although this country was only a halfcentury old, wild areas were disappearing. Forests were falling. Swamps were being drained. Settlements were expanding. Roads were being constructed. Where Tocqueville expected to find solitude, he found the sound of the axe and the tinkle of cow bells.

title: Queen Honors 32 With Knighthoods
description: LONDON, Jan. 1Thirtytwo British subjects received knighthoods in Queen Elizabeth's New Year's honors list, which was announced here today.

title: Books of The Times
description: I remember a bitter cold night in December 1971, when GoIda Meir went to New York to address a huge fundraising dinner in the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton. She had seen President Nixon at the White House that day, flown up during the afternoon and was now standing before an expectant audience of more than 3,000 people. Rather than make a formal speech, Mrs. Meir told storiesfunny stories, sad storiesin the intimate, conversational tone she has on the podium. As she talked, she transformed that cavernous, cold room into her own private world. The vast ballroom was dark except for a single spotlight focused on her face, and it was as though she were sitting in her living room, sharing her most intimate thoughts and fears with a handful of close friends. It was magic, and the audience, myself included, was transfixed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times Wednesday about a biography of William Loeb. it was ??meorrectly stated that Kevin Cash, the author, had written that Mr. Loeb told his wife that he drank raw alcohol to help him fail a physical examination for the draft in World War II. The Cash book states that Mr. Loeb told his wife merely that he intended to drink the alcohol.

title: The Nation in 1975, Seen Through the Camera's Eye
description: Unemployment, particularly in the construction industry, remained high. William O. Douglas resigned from the Supreme Court, and the President escaped two assassins. Patricia Hearst was caught, Congress made changes, and refugees came from Vietnam.

title: GWYN C. STEINBECK, EXWIFE OF WRITER
description: BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 1 (AP)  Gwyndolyn Conger Steinbeck, former wife of John Steinbeck, the late novelist, died Tuesday at a hospital here of cardiac and respiratory failure following an acute asthma attack. She was 58 years old.

title: Austrian Triumphs in Ski Jump
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 1 (AP)Toni Innauer, a 17yearold. Austrian, leaped to his second straight victory in the international FourHill ski jumping tournament today. He collected. 231.3 points with the day's longest jump of 95 meters and one of 89 meters. Karl Schnabl of Austria finished second with 229.66 points on leaps of 91.5 and 92 meters. Jochen Danneherg, a 22yearold East German soldier, had two leaps of 91 for 227.5 points and third place.

title: Mamie Eisenhower Gains In Treatment for a Virus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)Mamie Eisenhower is responding to treatment for a viral infection that hospitalized her at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, the hospital said today.

title: Doubts Rise on Wallace's 76 Strength; Some Pet Issues Have Lost Their Magic
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.A few months ago, it seemed that Gov, George Corley Wallace might be headed for his strongest run ever as a Presidential candidate.

title: Monsieur Daniel Bids Adieu to Le Chambertin
description: Le Chambertin, one of the best known of the small, familyowned French restaurants on the West Side, closed its doors unexpectedly after a final New Year's Eve dinner.

title: 4 Children and a Family of 4 Die in Fires
description: Four children in a Brooklyn family and a family of four in Norwalk, Conn., perished yesterday in fires.

title: Briton Slain Near Angola
description: OSHAKATI, SouthWest Africa, Jan. 1 (Reuters)A Briton and an African wornan working for him as a servant were shot to death by guerrilla raiders from Angola. the police in this northern border town reported today. They said about 10 guerrillas opened fire with machine guns on a trailer in which the Briton was living in the village of Oshandi, about four miles from the Angolan border.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Lion at St. Paul Zoo Dies After a Mauling
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 1 (AP)Doc, a former circus lion who had sired 25 litters of cubs and was recently mauled by two lionesses, died yesterday at the age of 11.

title: Ford Signs Bill Granting Money To City for Guarding Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 1President Ford on New Year's Eve signed into law 14 bills, including a measure that wil reimburse New York and other cities up to $3.5 million annually for the expenses of protecting foreign diplomats.

title: Head of Science Group Seeking to Broaden Its Sphere
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 1William D. McElroy, the biochemist who asumed today the presidency of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, plans a major reorganization of the group's prestigious journal Science, deeper. involvement of the organization in governmental and industrial affairs and a drive to Quadruple its membership.

title: Detroit's Homicide Toll Down 117 for 1975
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (UPI)Detroit, which set a record that earned it notoriety as Murder City one year ago, ended 1975 with its first decline in total homicides in 13 years.

title: We Hoped the Laws Were Flexible
description: Chances are the National Football League will take an appeal from the decision of Federal Judge Earl R. Larson that the league is operating an illegal monopoly. At least some club owners want to go all the way to the Supreme Court, if possible. This might postpone for as much as two years the day when they will have to start obeying the law.

title: U.S. Sells 51 F5's Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP): The Air Force has awarded the Northrop Corporation at $79.2 million contract for 51, F5F jet fighter planes for sale abroad28 for Iran. 20 for Saudi Arabia and three for Chile.

title: Crucial Time for Knicks
description: A crucial period is coming up for the Knicks. In the last three weeks they have gone from an 819 wonlost record, the second worst in the National Basketball Association, to the brink of respectability at 1620. But in winning their last six games and eight of their last nine, the Knicks have made up little ground on the Buffalo Braves, their immediate target if they are to make the playoffs for the 10th straight season.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The number of people riding subways and public buses in October, the second month of the 50cent fare, was 7.2 percent lower than in October 1974, according to Transit Authority officials. Buses, they said, accounted for most of the loss, despite a new system of bustobus transfers for 25 cents.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
VALENTINE A. BANGERT
description: Valentine A. Bangert, chauffeur for John D. Rockefeller Jr. for 42 years until his retirement in 1950, died Tuesday in Hudson, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Kinderhook, N.Y.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NICE AND SMOOTH. It's easy to relax at the Grenadier Restaurant (PL 32960), a popular place for cocktails and dining in the United Nations neighborhood at 863 First Avenue, on the corner of 48th Street. One of its attractions is the nightly enterinmant startine at 9 o'clock.

title: Kidnapped MotherinLaw Of Fiat Heiress Is Releaset
description: TURIN, Italy, Jan. 1 (UPI)Kidnappers freed the motherinlaw of a Fiat heiress today in exchange for a reported ransom of $975,000.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMENTHALRose. Jan. 2, 1958. Mother dearest Lovingly remernbered. Sad?? missed Always in my heart: ??

title: CINCINNATI POLICE CONDUCT PROTEST
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (UPI)Traffic violators, including those driving under the influence of alcohol, received warnings instead of tickets today from the police protesting the city's refusal to meet their wage demands.

title: Venezuela's Oil Industry Is Formally Nationalized
description: CARACAS, Venezuela Jan. 1 The Venezuelan Government today assumed formal control over the country's oil industry, the largest and most sophisticated petroleum complex in Latin America and the chief supplier of foreign oil to the United States.

title: Louis H. Dorman, 75, Dies: Cheese Concern Chairman
description: Louis H. Dorman, board chairman of N. Dorman & Company, cheese makers, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Little Neck, Queens.

title: Advertising
description: In case you haven't gotten wind of it. 1975 was a tremendous one in the fragrance business. There was a flood of new products; manufacturers broadened their horizons; there was more television advertising and, apparently. people bought.

title: NEW YEAR STARTS WITH TWO QUAKES
description: The new year began yesterday for the world's earthquake monitors with temblors in Greece and in Southern California, United Press International reported. On New Year's Eve, a quake measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale jolted the New Hebrides Islands in the South Pacific.

title: CareyNadjari Dispute: Main Figures Involved Give Different Versions
description: Governor Carey says he strongly doubted Maurice H. Nadjari's credibility as long ago as last spring hut did not seek to dismiss the special prosecutor until he had found a replacement.

title: DETECTIVE CHIEF IN QUEENS HEADS EXPLOSION INQUIRY
description: Deputy Chief Edwin T. Dreher, with a successful record as Queens chief of detectives, was shifted yesterday to take charge of the police arson explosion squad. concentrating on the La Guardia Airport bombing as the city administration's No. 1 police priority.

title: 500 DEMONSTRATE AT SPANISH PRISON WITH POLICE HELP
description: MADRID, Jan. 1One of Spain's most militant Roman Catholic priests led a parade of 500 people around Barcelona's main prison early this morning to demand amnesty and, in a highly unusual move for Spain, the police helped them.

description: Two thoughts provoked by Patti Smith's appearance last weekend at the Bottom Line:

title: Higher Rents Likely With Building Slump In Apartment Units
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 The new, affordable apartment, like the new, affordable house in the suburbs with picket fence, is becoming an endangered species in much of the nation.
