description: The Washington Star

title: 9 Held in Louisville Protest
description: LOUISVILLLE, Ky., Jan. 1 (UPI)Nine persons were arrested early today when the Jefferson County police broke up an antibusing demonstration in suburban Valley Station.

description: By Reuters

title: LONGER JAIL TERMS SOUGHT IN PASSAIC
description: PATERSON. Jan. 1 (UPI)The Passaic County Prosecutor, citing increased crime statistics, said today that his office would strengthen its procedures in the sentencing of convicted criminals.

Catskill Crisis
description: A disturbing quiet seems to have settled over the program for bringing some measure of landuse planning to the Catskill: In view of the project a history, it is hard to avoid an impression of conscious neglect.

description: Deputy Chief Edwin T. Dreher, with a successful record as Queens chief of detectives, was shifted yesterday to take charge of the police arson explosion squad. concentrating on the La Guardia Airport bombing as the city administration's No. 1 police priority.

title: Dardanelle Returns As Singing Pianist With a Relaxed Air
description: In the decade after World War II, a small but persuasive group of women jazz pianists began to be heard in New York, including Marian McPartland, Barbara Carroll, Jutta Hipp, Beryl Booker and a pianist who used only one name, Dardanelle. The Dardanelle Trio played the Hickory House and the Copa Lounge and recorded for RCA and Columbia.

title: C.I.A. Said to Train A Unit for Angola; U.S. Issues Denials
description: BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP)The Christian Science Monitor reports that about 150 Americans took refresher military training at Fort Benning, Ga., sponsored by the Central Intelligence Agency last week to prepare to join 300 other Americans the paper said were fighting in Angola.

title: Families Replace the Revelers
description: There was only the briefest of pauses yesterday as the last horntooting reveler staggered away from the city and the families arrived.

title: Bicentennial Is Roses Parade Theme
description: PASADENA, Calif.. Ian. 1 (UPI)With a salute to its heritage and a prayer for peace, the United States observed its yearlong 200th birthday celebration today with flowers, floats and pretty girls proclaiming, America, let's celebrate!

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Jobless Rate Dips in Part of State

title: TV: Will to Be Free
description: When you enter dogood territory in commercial television, the time must be somewhere between late morning and early afternoon, preferably on Sunday. For this weekend's instance, there is ABC's Directions series and The Will to Be Freer. Which will be broadcast at noon Sunday as part of a Bicentennial Conscience of America project. Written, produced and directed by Marc Siegel, the hour traces the Historical, religious and philosophical roots of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Events Today
description: Dance

title: Loan for Peru Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP)The Agency for International Development has announced an S11 million loan to finance progam for improved water and land use in the Sierra region of Peru. The announcement said Peru would match the loan with a minimum of $10 million to finance the balance of the $21 million project.

title: Ford Administration Deregulation Proposals Bring Increasing Opposition From Industry
description: WASHINGTON  President Ford has been winning a multitude of cheers from business audiences across the United States during the last few months by criticizing Federal bureaucrats and what he has characterized as their sometimes silly and wasteful ways.

title: Kirsten Bids Met Adieu at Gala Tosca
description: Dorothy Kirsten went out in a blaze of glory on New Year's Eve. Making her farewell appearance at the Metropolitan Opera after 30 years with the company in nothing but leading roles, she sang and acted the part of Tosca with the vocal control and dramatic acuity of a prima donna in midcareer.

title: Weekly Newspaper On Upper East Side Ceases Publication
description: Park East, a weekly newspaper that covered the Upper East Side for 12 years, has suspended publication indefinitely.

title: Abu Dhabi Oil Money Developing the Desert
description: ABU DHABI  Amulets against the evil eye are scarce now in the bazaars of the sheikdom of Dubai. The descendants of pirates in Ras al Khaimah are being given lowcost housing. The dusty counting houses of Abu Dhabi have been equipped with electronic calculators.

title: The New Year's Bowl Games
description: Ohio State went into the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., needing a victory to clinch the national championship, but it didn't get it: the University of California. Los Angeles, scored a 2310 upset.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Policy Backed As Ruling Party's Talks End
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 (Reuters)  A national convention of India's governing Congress Party ended today after calling for a continuation of the country's state of emergency, postponing general elections and hinting at sweeping constitutional changes.

title: The New Year's Bowl Games
description: Ohio State went into the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., needing a victory to clinch the national championship, but it didn't get it: the University of California, Los Angeles, scored a 2310 upset.

title: ACCOUNTING PLAN FOR BANKS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1The three Federal bank regulatory agencies have raised strong objections to new rules proposed by the accounting profession regarding treatment by banks of exchanges of municipal securities such as those involved in the recent restructuring of New York City's debt.

title: Plane Makers Start 76 Stalled on Commercial Sales
description: LOS ANGELES  On a windswept desert plateau about 50 miles from downtown Los Angeles, stand five 250foot L1011 jet airliners, each valued at more than $20 million, that no one seems to want.

title: Murder Jury Disagrees on Mrs. Hodge
description: A State Supreme Court jury here failed to reach agreement yesterday on a verdict in the case of Beverly Donna Hodge, who had been accused of plotting the murder of her husband, George Howard Hodge a rock music arranger.

title: New York in 76
description: Ringing down the curtain on the toughest time in the city's history, Mayor Beanie predicted in a yearend interview that 1976 could be one of the greatest years New York has ever had.

title: Rosewall, Edmondson Gain at Aussie Net
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (UPI)Ken Rosewall survived a scare from a highly touted high school student 24 years his junior today and reached the semifinals of the $100,000 Australian open tennis tournament.

title: Dumpson to Stay On As Search Widens For a Replacement
description: James R. Dumpson, who was expected to leave his post as City Human Resources Administrator and Social Services Commissioner yesterday, Will stay on temporarily while city officials expand their search for a replacement on a national level.

title: Suffolk Executive Fears Fiscal Cuts and Layoffs
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 1Warning that 1976 would be another financially severe year, John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive. today raised the possibility of layoffs and the necessity for sharp reductions in governmental spending here.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Dog Racing Track Opens Tonight
description: PLAINFIELD, Conn., Jan. 1 (AP)The Plainfield Greyhound Track, the state's first parimutuel betting facility, will open tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Developers expect a nightly handle of $300,000 to $400,000, which would mean $3.5 million for the state between now and June 30. The track will be open every night except Sunday. Although the General Assembly legalized gambling in 1971, the dog track will be the first facility in the state. Until now the only legalized gambling has been the lottery.

title: Substation and Office Damaged In Bomb Blasts in Seattle Area
description: SEATTLE Jan. 1 (UPI)An electrical substation was heavily damaged early today by a bomb that a group calling itself the George Jackson Brigade said it set off in protest against the power company.

title: Senator McGovern Leaves On Tour of 4 Asian Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) Senator George McGovern left today for three weeks in Asia during which he will visit Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and North Vietnam, his press secretary said.

title: Manhasset Yachtsman Is Leader
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 1 Randy Bartholomew of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, seeking his fifth straight Interclub Class championship in the 45th annual New Year's Regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club, moved into a comfortable lead today after the first six races.

title: NEWS INDEX
Fred Millet of Wesleyan Dies; Educator Assailed Censorship
description: Dr. Fred B. Millet, professor emeritus of English at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., literary critic and author, died yesterday in Brockton, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Whitman. Mass.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the most coveted awards in New York tournament play is the Spero trophy, awarded to the player with the best overall performance in team events during a calendar year. The 1975 winner was Matthew Granovetter, one of the youngest generation of experts. His Victories contributing to this win included the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams, the Reisinger Knockout Teams, and the Fall Swiss Teams. His remarkably successful year also included district qualification in the Grand National Teams and a dramatic defeat of the touring Lancia team of worldfamous stars.

title: Blaze in Christmas Tree Kills 6 in Indiana Family
description: GREENWOOD, Ind., Jan. 1 (UPI)A fire that started in a Christmas tree swept a frame home last night and killed a man, his wife and four children. A young woman who escaped by running through flames in her nightclothes was critically burned.

title: FREEING OF RAIDERS UPHELD IN ALGIERS
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 1 (Agence France  Presse)  Algeria freed the terrorists group that seized oil ministers in Vienna last month in order to respect the wishes of the governments involved in this affair, the Algiers newspaper El Moudjahid declared today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Leafs Defeat Seals, 5 to 1, On 2 Goals by McDonald
description: TORONTO, Jan. 1 (UPI)A pair of secondperiod goals and an assist by Lanny McDonald paced the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 51 victory today over the California Seals in a National Hockey League game.

title: Thais, in New Year Gesture, Reopen Border With Laos
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 1 (UPI)  In a New Year's gesture, Thailand today reopened its border with Laos.

title: Dr. Judith E.Woll, R. H .Bernard Wed
description: Dr. Judith Esther Woll of Rochester, director of the hematologymedical oncology unit of Highland Hospital there, was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald H. Bernard, a systems specialist on the corporate audit staff of the Xerox Corporation in Rochester. Brighton Town Justice James Morris performed the ceremony in the bride's home.

title: Weekly Newspaper On Upper East Side Ceases Publication
description: Park East, a weekly newspaper that covered the Upper East Side for 12 years, has suspended publication indefinitely.

title: Fire Kills Woman, Daughters
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP)  An 86yearold woman and her two daughters were killed early today as fire swept their twostory brick row house. The police identified the victims as Elizabeth Hawthorne and her daughters, Betty, 56, and Evelyn, 53.

title: Portuguese Troops Kill 3 and Hurt 15 As Leftists Demonstrate Outside Jail
description: LISBON, Jan. 1Three persons were killed and 15 wounded tonight in a leftist demonstration outside of the Prison of Custoias in the northern city of Oporto.

title: Todd Turned The Tide
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1The Sugar Bowl game turned on one play last night, as is often the case in such good defensive battles.

title: Article 3  No Title
Miss Rockwell Wins 3d Ski Trial in Row
description: CABLE, Wis., Jan. 1Martha Rockwell of Stratford, Vt., gained her third straight triumph today and remained undefeated in the Olympic women's crosscountry skiing trials at Mount Telemark.

title: The C.I.A. in Chile: A Question of Responsibility
description: WASHINGTONIn its staff report, Covert Action in Chile, 19631973, the Senate Intelligence Committee has provided the first detailed official account of the largescale secret efforts of the Central Intelligence Agency to manipulate and, if possible, control political events in that small and vulnerable country. A careful reader of this report is driven to the conclusion that the United States Government bears a major responsibility for the destruction of Chilean democracy.

title: Senior Cowboys Are Leading the Cheers
description: Lee Roy Jordan, one of the senior citizens of the Dallas Cowboys, refrained from roaring through a rousing New Year's Eve.

title: Mexico Opens New Drive To Halt Narcotics Flow
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 1 Mexico has launched a broad offensive against the narcotics traffic in apparent response to criticism in Washington that its efforts to curb the flow of heroin into the United States have been inadequate.

title: Socialist Group Hopes to Spur New Activism in U.S. Colleges
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 1The Young Socialist Alliance is finding signs of new life in the campus activism that many thought had died in the early 1970's. and hopes to make it grow.

title: PLAN FOR PARLEY ON DISABLED LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) A White House conference on the handicapped scheduled for 1976 is getting off to an unrealistic and ridiculous start because of inadequate planning arid funding, Jack Smith, the conference's executive director, said today.

title: IND RIDERS ROBBED, 11 YOUTHS SEIZED
Indian State Planninfi Compulsory Sterilization Effort
description: CHANDIGARH, India, Dec. 29The government of Punjab state is drawing up legislation to make sterilization compulsory after a family has had certain number of children, probably two or three.

title: ...But I.W.Y. Head Sees Mostly Gains
description: When she is asked if International Women's Year was a boom or bust, Helvi Sipila, secretarygeneral for the year, likes to show visitors color photographs of 2000. women from the Ivory Coast marching in a women's rights day parade last May in Abidjan.

title: Doubts Rise on Wallace's 76 Strength; Some Pet Issues Have Lost Their Magic
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.A few months ago, it seemed that Gov. George Corley Wallace might be headed for his strongest run ever as a Presidential candidate.

title: Suns Lose To Bullets, 114 to 103
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 1 (UPI)Len Robinson, a reserve, scored 21 points tonight to lead the Washington Bullets to a 114103 National Basketball Association victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: Columbus to Use Funds In Defiance of U.S. Directive
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1 (AP) The city says it will defy a! U. S. Labor Department ruling and use $1.4 million in Federal funds to rehire 338 laid off employees.

title: CITY TO ASK FUNDS TO REOPEN TOMBS
description: City and state officials will go to Washington next Monday to try to retrieve $11 million in unused Federal funds so that the city can reopen the Manhattan Men's House of Detention and set up nine new State Supreme Court parts to ease prison overcrowding.

title: Patient at Willowbrook Is Slain While on Leave
description: A 30yearold patient at the Willowbrook Developmental Center for the Retarded, who was in the process of making the transition to the outside community after 12 years of institutionalization, was bludgeoned to death early yesterday and a former patient at the facility was later charged with the murder, the police said.

title: NEW U.S. PROCEDURE ON DUTIES OUTLINED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1  The Government announced today procedures for adding new imported articles, or subtracting current ones, in the new system of preferential duties now in effect for hundreds of items imported from less developed countries.

title: 100,000 Gallons of Fuel Spill into the Hudson River
description: One hundred thousand gallons of hothe heating oil spilled into the Hudson River on Wednesday and yesterday after a barge rammed an abutment of the Tappan Zee Bridge. The accident left a narrow swath of oil running from Haverstraw, N.Y., to the George Washington Bridge here.

title: Exchanges Closed
description: All securities. commodity and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday for the New Year's holiday.

title: Hungary Raises Forint 3%
description: BUDAPEST, Jan. 1 (Reuters) Hungary raised the value of the forint for nonbusiness purposes by an average of 3 percent against Western currencies today. The change was the third Hungarian revaluation in 12 months, during which the forint has increased in value against most Western currencies by 13 percent.

title: BANGLADESH BEGINS TO CURB POPULATION
description: DACCA,, Bangladesh, Jan. 1 (UPI)The Bangladesh Government began a monthlong familyplanning program today and declared that overpopulation was the main problem of the nationone of the world's poorest and most densely populated.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: With Chiaese restaurants spotted multitudinoutfly the length and breadth of Manhattan Island, systematic coverage is impossible and a reviewer has to operate on the buckshot principle. Here are three we have hit recently. in geographical order from way uptown to way downtown east:

title: For Women, Gains and Losses in 75...
description: To its leaders, it was the best of years; to some feminists, it was the worst of years. But to most of the women who were somehow involved with it, it was better than nothing at all, the socalled International Women's Year, 1975.

title: Higher Rents Likely With Building Slump In Apartment Units
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1The new, affordable apartment, like the new, affordable house in the suburbs with picket fence, is becoming an endangered species in much of the nation.

title: Juvenile Corrections
description: A recent study conducted at the University of Michigan for the Justice Department suggests that public spending on juvenile justice throughout the nation reflects just the wrong priorities.

title: Terms for Upstate Teachers
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 1 (UPIA State Supreme Court justice yesterday set the dates for 12 leaders of the teachers union here to begin serving jail sentences for contempt convictions stemming from a twoweek strike in September. Justice William J. Crangle said they must go to jail for 10 days beginning at 2 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Miss Vogt Wins Speed Skating Races
description: INZELL, West Germany, Jan. I (UP1)Cathy Vogt and Gayla Gordon of Canada finished 1, 2 today in the women's 500 and 1,000 meter races during an invitation speed skating meet. Jos Valentin of the Netherlands also was a double winner, taking the men's 500 and 1,000 meter races.

title: Policeman, 2 Others Killed In Gun Battle in California
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)A policeman and two others were killed today in a shootoul. at a Long Beach home after two calls to ask that officers come to the house, the police said.

title: Waterbury Freezes Pay
description: WATERBURY, Conn. Jan. 1 (AP)Mayor Edward Bergin, who was sworn in today, said he anticipated a deficit of $9 million to $10 million this fiscal year and ordered all city workers wages frozen.

title: Frank Rand Jr., Sportsman, Published Santa Fe Paper
description: Frank C. Rand Jr., sportsman, former cattle rancher and newspaper publisher, died of a heart attack Monday night at his home in Santa Fe, N. M. He was 69 years old.

title: UTILITIES OPPOSE DISCLOSURE PUSH
description: Some of the nation's major electric companies that have been conducting private intercompany performancecomparison studies for more than 20 years have refused to share their information with utility regulators and customerinterest groups that contend the data would be invaluable in regulatory and ratemaking proceedings. The utilities refusal has triggered efforts to force disclosure of the data.

title: Rejection of a Brief From Bishop Urged In the Quinlan Case
description: MORRISTOWN. Jan. 1 (AP)The lawyer for Karen Anne Quinlan's doctors has asked the State Supreme Court not to accept a friendofthecourt brief outlining the Roman Catholic Church's position on the right to die case.

title: Mao Asks China to Avoid Sliding Into the Easy Life
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1Two new poems by Chairman Mao Tsetung, accompanied by a New Year's Day editorial defending the results of the Cultural Revolution, were published in Peking today in what appeared to be an attempt by the aging Chinese leader to insure that his revolutionary policies are not overtaken by the drive for economic growth.

title: Chilean Envoy to Britain Denies Torture Charges
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Chile's Ambassador to Britain has denied charges by a British woman surgeon that she had been tortured by the police for having treated a wounded leftist.

title: CITY TO ASK FUNDS TO REOPEN TOMBS
description: City and state officials will go to Washington next Monday to try to retrieve $11 million in unused Federal funds so that the city can reopen the Manhattan Men's House of Detention and set up nine new State Supreme Court parts to ease prison overcrowding.

title: CareyNadjari Dispute: Main Figures Involved Give Different Versions
description: Governor Carey says he strongly doubted Maurice H. Nadjari's credibility as long ago as last spring but did not seek to dismiss the special prosecutor until he had found a replacement.

title: Losers Night at Trotters; Aqueduct Reopens Today
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 1As the new year approached Roosevelt Raceway last night, a car lurched out of the parking lot at the end of the Program. One window opened and a shower of paper blew into the rain. No, it was not confetti. The driver wasn't celebrating. It was a swarm of tornup tickets. There was no holiday for losers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fish Are Attracted to Old Sunken Tires
description: Shreds of high, white clouds soften the bright blue of the sky and are reflected in the smooth lake. A towheaded lad of eight jumps out of his skiff and runs up the dock with a fishing rod in one hand and a bluegill in the other.

title: City Breathed Easier In Some Ways in 1975
description: The city's air was easier to breathe last year, according to the Environmental Protection Administration.

title: 15 Die in a Belgian Dance Hall In Blaze of Holiday Decorations
description: LA LOUVIERE, Belgium. Jan. 1 (UPI)A fire swept through a small dance hall here crowded with New Year's revelers, killing 15 people and injuring 37.

title: TAX FORMS TO AID REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1Nobody likes to see those income tax forms that arrived in the mail this week, but the leaders of 39,156 local governments have reason to hope that taxpayers will pay close attention to four little questions crammed into half an inch of space near the top of the new form.

title: Mao Asks China to Avoid Sliding Into the Easy Life
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 1Two new poems by Chairman Mao Tsetung, accompanied by New Year's Day editorial defending the results of the Cultural Revolution, were published in Peking today in what appeared to be an attempt by the aging Chinese leader to insure that his revolutionary policies are not overtaken by the drive for economic growth.

title: Elizabeth Mayor Plans Layoffs Of 75 Policemen and Firemen
description: ELIZABETH. Jan. 1 (UPI)Mayor Thomas G. Dunn announced plans today to lay off 75 policemen and fire fighters to reduce city expenditures. He said the layoffs were necessitated by the city's shrinking tax base, the winning of excessive wage and benefit demands by cops, firemen and teachers, and reduced state aid.

title: WESTGATE DISPUTE REPORTED SETTLED
description: An outofcourt settlement between the WestgateCalifornia Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that apparently averted bankruptcy for the financially troubled conglomerate was reported yesterday in San Diego.

title: PORT SAID BECOMES TAXFREE ENCLAVE
description: PORT SAID, Egypt, Jan. 1 (Reuters)This city at the Mediterranean end of the Suez Canal today became Egypt's first taxfree enclave.

title: Basic Commodity Prices Fell in 75
description: Prices of most basic commodities fell substantially Throughout most of 1975, ending the year well below the yearago levels, even though housewives can find little to cheer about at the retail level as the new year begins.

title: Connecticut Bars Miller Co. From Shipping Beer to State
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 1 (UPI)The State Liquor Control Commission has barred the Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee from shipping its own beer or German Lowenbrau beer into Connecticut, allegedly for having violated a cornmission order to supply five Connecticut beer wholesalers with Lowenbrau.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Passengers on two Brooklyn IND trains were harassed and at least three of them robbed last evening by a gang of youths, according to the Transit Authority police. One youth carried a pen gun"a smallcaliber weapon resembling a pen, the police said, and others wielded toy pistols.

title: French Reds Report Gain
description: PARIS, Jan. 1 (Reuters)The French Communist Party says that it signed up 93.875 new members in 1975, reportedly the highest increase for a single year since 1946.

title: About Real Estate
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  A Bergen County realestate broker was asked the other day whether he thought there was still a boom in office construction in the county.

title: Easy Actor's  Road Was Hard Riding
description: What do actors and schizophrenics have in common?

title: Theories on King Murder Tied by Common Threads
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 1Most of the theories of a conspiracy surrounding the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4, 19138, are bound by a common threadthe view that unnamed interests, Southern, reactionary and white, had sensed in Dr. King's increasingly militant stance a new economic and political threat that prompted his murder at their hands.

title: Bogus Student Faces Inquiry at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Early last fall, Bernard John Chubet 3d walked into the Tower Club, an eating club in one of the old fraternitylike buildings here. He was greeted as a quintessential member of the Ivy League.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Organ Concerto No. 13, Handel; Symphony in D, Arriaga; Rosamunde, lncidental Music, Schubert.

title: Madagascar Sets Amnesty
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Jan. 1 (Agence FrancePress)President Didier Ratsiraka ordered an amnesty today for an unspecified number of political prisoners to mark the New Year. The amnesty covers political crimes committed before Jan. 1, 1975.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners. Not all lifts operating.)

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST EXCEED S600,000
description: The 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $8,868.60 from 200 donors. The overall figure for the campaign now stands at $601,033.41.

title: Theories on King Murder Tied by Common Threads
description: This is the second of two articles written by John M. crewdson and based on reporting by Mr. Crewdson, Ben A. Franklin, Nicholas M. Horrock and Martin Waldron.

title: Connecticut Prosecutor
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 1 (AP)Connecticut's top state prosecutor said tonight that he had found no criminal wrongdoing after reviewing charges of billing and funds abuse by the director of Connecticut's Drug Advisory Council.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made pay. able to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Higher State Fees and Taxes Mark the Start of a New Year
description: TRENTON, Jan. 1 AP)Higher motorvehicle fees, fewer Medicaid services, bills for a new tax on unearned income and open public meetings come to New Jersey in the first month of the New Year.

title: Platform On a Snowy Day
description: STOWE, Vt., Jan. 1The more enthusiastic skiers have gone to the slopes and the house is quiet. Against the green of the pines outside, snow Swirls down endlessly, as if to interrupt the human din with a moment of serenity and blanket all things earthly in white.

title: Stockton, With 66, Leads Coast Golf
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)  Dave Stockton of Westlake, Calif. shot a fiveunderpar 66 today and took a onestroke lead after the first round to play in the $65,000 Lynx invitation proam golf tournament.

title: Article 4  No Title
Brown Quits Bengals
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (UPI) Paul Brown, whose football teams have posted more victories than those of any other coach, resigned tonight as head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: 500 DEMONSTRATE AT SPANISH PRISON WITH POLICE HELP
description: MADRID, Jan. 1One of Spain's most militant Roman Catholic priests led a parade of 500 people around Barcelona's main prison early this morning to demand amnesty and, in a highly unusual move for Spain, the police helped them.

title: Reference by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who has shown an increasing concern about birth control in the last couple of years. said in a political speech this week that the Government would have to promote family planning with some strong steps which may not be liked by all. She did not elaborate.

title: 10 YearOlds in the Kitchen: Will It Be Fun or a Kind of Punishment?
description: Give a child of 3 or 4 a cooking assignment  mush those eggs, squoosh that squashand he'll leap into it with his whole being. Who cares that it's going to turn into scrambled eggs (??yeccch) or mashed squash (unspeakably ugh)? The mushing and squooshing are fun.

title: 34 Debutantes Are Presented
description: Thirtyfour young women started the New Year last evening as debutantes of the 1976 season. Among them Was Tawny Elaine Godin, the current Miss America, who led the grand march for the presentation at the 54th Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball at the Plaza.

title: Nebraska Paper Sold
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 1 (AP) Stauffer Publications Inc. of Topeka has announced the purchase of the Beatrice (Neb.) Daily Sun from Robert S. and George P. Marvin. No purchase price was announced. The 11,000 circulation newspaper becomes Stauffer Publications third Nebraska daily newspaper.

title: The Nation in 1975, Seen Through the Camera's Eye
description: Unemployment, particularly in the construction industry, remained high. William O. Douglas resigned from the Supreme Court, and the President escaped two assassins. Patricia Hearst was caught, Congress made changes and refugees came from Vietnam.

title: Jurors for the Pulitzer Prizes Named
description: The appointment of 50 jurors for the Pulitzer Prize awards in journalism was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University.

title: The Screen
description: Miss Peterson's films, Rainbow Bridge (Parts One and Two), are a series of abstract, geometric designs constructed mostly of images of the sea and closeups of waves. The film maker uses these shots the way a nonrepresentational sculptor might use found objects, to create new images that are most beautiful when the original associations have been most effectively denied. It's not a labor for which I have particular sympathy.

title: U.C.L.A. Stuns Ohio State, 2310; Oklahoma Conquers Michigan
Market Place
description: Shareholders have long borne sales charges imposed by mutual funds.

title: Hugh Hutton. 78, Cartoonist For Philadelphia Inquirer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Hugh McMillen Hutton, editorial cartoonist for The Philadelphia Inquirer for 35 years, died today in a Philadelphia hospital. Mr. Hutton, who was 78 years old, never regained consciousness after suffering a stroke on Tuesday shortly after visiting his son in Alexandria, Va.

title: Frescoes Attributed To Michelangelo Found in Florence
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 2Art experts reported today the discovery of what they believe to be previously unknown frescoes by Michelangelo. if confirmed, the find would he the second discovery of a work attributed to the Rennissance master in two years.

title: Riessen Duo Advances
description: DALLAS, Jan. 2 (AP) Secondseeded Marty Riessen and Martina Navratilova defeated the brothersister team of Cliff Richey and Nancy Gunter, 62, 75, in the S80,000 world mixed doubles tennis tournament tonight.

title: Oklahoma Rated No. 1
description: The University of Oklahoma was named the nation's top college football team yes?? ?? ?? ?? Press's poll of sports writers and the United Press International poll of ?? Details on Page 13.

title: Glassmakers in the State Said to Be at Disadvantage
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2A study by the slate's Department of Labor and Industry says New Jersey's big glass is industry is suffering irons a substantial disadvantage in competing with other states at the region because of higher fuel costs and more stringent airpollution standards.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Seabrook Farms Unit to Close

title: Amex Is Adding 7 Options To Program This Month,
description: The chairman of the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that four new options classes would be added Jan. 6 and three more on Jan. 19, bringing to 51 the number of underlying securities in the exchange's options program.

title: Eastern Urges Air Fares Be Raised Over 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Reuters)  Eastern Airlines has proposed a sixmonth program of monthly increases in domestic passenger fares starting with a 1 percent increase on February ??

title: Treasury Bills Futures To Be Traded Tuesday
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (Reuters)Trading in Treasury bills futures begins Tuesday on the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Jetliner Mishap at Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 2 (AP)A DC10 jetliner, carrying 364 Turkish pilgrims from Mecca and 13 crew members, landed 20 feet short of the runway at Istanbul airport today. Two persons were reportedly slightly injured, including the American flight engineer, William Whitesell of South Carolina.

title: Rats and Looters Roam Charred Beirut
Carey Pressing Lefkowitz on Nadjari
description: Governor Carey, who has angrily disputed suggestions that he dismissed Maurice H. Nadjari because of political pressures, yesterday renewed his effort to win the cooperation of Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, in appointing a special deputy to investigate the allegations.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GARDEN GREENERY Ireland is providing the new year's first entertainment program salute to America's Bicentennial in a multimedia package of drama, music, dance and graphics today at 1:30 P.M.one performance only at Madison Square Garden. Heading the bill will be two estimable Irish stars well known to American audiences, Peter O'Toole and Siobhan McKenna. This will mark the first appearance on a New York stage by the actor, a fourtime Oscar nominee for his screen work, including his most famous portrayal, that of Lawrence of Arabia. Miss McKenna. who has been absent from the local stage in recent years, is best known here for The Playboy of the Western World and Saint Joan.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Seven policemen and two ?? who were to have been laid off by the city of New Rochelle have won a reprieve under the new $25.6 million budget adopted by the New Rochelle City Council early yesterday morning, &. The number of dismissals already made was incorrectly stated in The New York Times Yesterday. New Rochelle has now laid off 10 policeman, 16 fire fighters and 13 other. city employees. As of March 1, tie city will no longer provide free backyard collections, which v ill reduce the sanitation force by 32 men. But the city is offering residents an option to pay for backyard pickups, which may save the jobs of some sanitationmen.

title: Grudge Studied as AirportBlast Motive
description: Investigators of the fatal blast at La Guardia Airport last Monday were checking on the possibility that it might have been the work of a deranged person with a grudge against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Soviet Appears to Tighten Restriction on Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2The Soviet Union appears to have hardened its stand on emigration in the wake of the 1975 Helsinki declaration, which called in part for freer movement of people and ideas in Europe.

title: Concert
description: Zdenek Macal, a Czechoslovak conductor who was a winner of the 1966 Mitropoulos Conducting Competition here, is making his New York Philharmonic debut in the orchestra's concerts at Avery Fisher Hall this weekend. Mr. Macal, who is in his late 30's was appointed music director of the Cologne Radio Symphony Orchestra in 1970 after having been principal conductor of the Prague Symphony for several years.

title: The Complete Control of Paul Brown
description: Early in the week, Paul Brown took aside Al Heim, the Cincinnati Bengals public relations director.

title: Suspect Seized in Michigan Torture Case
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP)The Federal Government said today, that ii had arrested a Detroit'. man and accused him of taking part in the torturewounding of an informer who testifed at the recent briberyperjury trial of former Gov. John B. Swainson.

title: Chemical Bank Consents To Reduce Lawsuit Fees
description: The Chemical Bank of New York confirmed yesterday that it had signed a consent agreement covering refunds for fees charged to a total of 2,500 customers whose bank accounts had been subjected to legal actions by others.

title: Glenz Shoots 65, Ties for Golf Lead
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan 2 (UPI)David Glenz of Miami, Fla. posted a courserecord 65 today and tied Bob Risch of Diamond Bar, Calif., after 36 holes of the S65,000 Lynx invitational pro am golf tournament.

title: Happy Days For Rams, Cowboys
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2There appeared to be happy circumstances all around as the Los Angeles Rams prepared today to play the Dallas Cowboys for the National Football Conference championship on Sunday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Mathmates Device Teaches Two at a Time
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2A Columbia University professor has invented an instructional aid enabling pairs of students to teach each other. Called Mathmatcs, the device has been tested in four New York City school districts and brought consistently favorable results and comments.

title: Byrne Orders Cut of 5% In Jersey's Payroll Costs
New York Official Disputes Effects of Hudson Oil Spill
description: The New York Commissioner of Environmental Conservation sharply disputed Coast Guard statements yesterday that the more than 90.000 gallons of home heating oil had dissipated safely after spilling into the Hudson river from a barge that rammed a support of the Tarnan Zee Bridge.

title: Rheingold Foresess: $1.6 Million Saving By Moving of Plant
description: Officials of the financially troubled Rheingold Breweries said yesterday that plans to shut down the company's Brooklyn plant and shift itsoperations to Orange, N..J., could save nearly $1.6 million a year in electricity, water and server costs alone.

title: 11 Presidential Contenders Get First U.S. Funds for Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)The Treasury Department distributed $1.88 million to 11 Presidential contenders today, the nation's direct Federal campaign contributors.

title: Article 3  No Title
Egypt Ousts Ireland
description: CAIRO, Jan. 2 (UPI)Egypt swept the final two singles matches in Davis Cup play today and took the threeday quarterfinals from Ireland, 4 matches to 1. Abdel Ghany defeated Michael Hickey, 63, 62, 62, and Abdel Gawad beat Kevin Menton, 62, 62, 63.

title: Towaway Charges For Illegal Parking Will Rise to $65
description: The towaway fee for illegally parked cars in Manhattan will go up from $50 to $65 starting Monday. The fee is in addition to the customary $25 fine for illegal parking and $5 a day for storage of the impounded car.

title: DR. JOHN V. D'ANCELO
description: Dr. John V. D'Angelo, a former Bronx surgeon who had been on the staffs of Morrisania and Union Hospitals, died Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Article 8  No Title
News Summary and Index
description: Public demonstrations outside prisons in Oporto, in northern Portugal, were banned yesterday after incidents on New Year's Day in which three persons were killed and four gravely wounded by guards. One of the victims was identified as a 22yearold German student, (hinter Bruns, from Hamburg. An official communique said that he had been interferring in Portuguese politics and had links with various organizations. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Vermont, Clarkson Sixes Win at Garden
description: College hockey came to Madison Square Garden last night and came off reasonably well in comparison with the professional kind the Garden management has been selling lately.

title: Soviet Appears to Tighten Restriction on Emigration
FED REPORTS DROP IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: Another decline in the nation's money supplythe third in as many weekswas reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, confirming that the downward trend experienced early in December was not a statistical !aberration.

title: SAUL LASKY
description: Saul Lasky, a founder of the Masters Printers of Newark and Vicinity, now known as Printing Industries of New Jersey, died Wednesday in the Miami Heart Institute, Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and had formerly lived in Newark.

title: Notes on People
description: Was it Elliot L. Richardson's farewell address as Ambassador to Britain or the first speech of a renewed political career at home? Mr. Richardson told a London audience yesterday that many Americans, particularly IrishAmericans, misunderstand the background of the Northern Ireland question and think the British Army is there to suppress the Ulsterrnen rather than to protect the [Roman Catholic] minority. The former Boston lawyer said that, when he returns in two weeks to become Secretary of Commerce, he wants to give a better indication of what the situation really is.

title: City's blood Supply Is Low
description: The New York City blood supply was reported to be a the danger level yesterday, and donors were requested to come forward during the weekend A spokesman for the Greater New York Blood Bank asked donors to go to the Blood Cen ter at 310 East 67th Street be tween 10 A.M. and 5 P.M either today or tomorrow. Fur ther information can be ob tamed at hospitals or by tele phoning 7943158.

title: State Aide Dispute Effects of Oil Spill
description: The state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation sharply disputed Coast Guard statements yesterday that the more than 90.000 gallons of homeheating oil had dissipated safely after spilling into the Hudson River from a barge that rammed a support of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: REP. GREEN TO RUN FOR U.S. SENATE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2Representative William J. Green, whose late father was one of the country's most powerful political bosses, has decided to seek the Senate seat being vacated by Hugh Scott, the retiring Republican minority leader.

title: Files Show F.B.I. Got Reports On RosenbergLawyer Meetings
description: Files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation show that durHog and after the espionage trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, an informant reported to the bureau on talks, traditionally and protected, between the defendants and their attorney.

title: DANIEL R. NEWTON
description: Daniel R. Newton, director of the Bryant Library of Roslyn, L. I. since 1960, died of an ?? Thursday at Flushing Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: 2 Boys Are Killed As Shell Explodes At Camp Pendleton
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Two boys on a camping trip who wandered, into a Marine Corps training: area were killed yesterday by explosives they had apparently been playing with.

title: The Important People on Spains Costa del Sol Hope That Any Changes Won't Be Too Extensive
People and Business
description: Americans for Energy Independence, a group consisting of persons prominent in business, labor, science and the professions, is searching for a new leader.

title: Security Forces in Beirut Take Over From Gunmen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2 (AP)Security forces gradually took over Beirut's commercial center today, replacing Moslem and Christian gunmen at major intersections.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)Housing Secretary Carla Hills said today the interest ceiling on Governmentbacked home mortgages will drop to 8.75 percent on Monday, the first decline in nine months.

title: Max Robb, Was President Of City Stores Co., 195862
description: Max Robb, president of the City Stores Company, a national departmentstore chain, from 1958 to 1962, and since then chairman of the executive committee of the Bankers Securities Corporation in Philadelphia, parent company of City Stores, died Wednesday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 80 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Oklahoma Rated No. 1
description: The University of Oklahorna was named the nation's top college football team yes. ?? in both The Associated Press's poll of sports writers and the United Press Inter. national poll of coaches. Details on Page 13.

title: Phone Company Operators Put on 4Day Week on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, LI, Jan. 2 (UPI) The New York Telephone Company announced late today that about 600 of its switchhoard operators in Nassau and Suffolk Counties would be placed on a fourday work .week, effective Sunday.

title: HOTEL OFFICIAL,WIFE DEAD IN PLANE CRASH
description: Robert E. Kulka, director general of the InterContinental Hotel in Paris, and his wife, Micheline, were among the victims in a plane crash in the Saudi Arabian desert that killed all 82 persons aboard a Middle East Airlines jet Thursday, a spokesman for the InterContinental Hotels Corporation reported yesterday.

title: You dare to say we abuse our kids? Abuse No! We beat them hard only because they misbehave!
description: FRAMINGHAM. Mass.Last January, the Massachusetts Department of Social Services reported an alarming increase of childabuse cases during 1974 and predicted that they would keep on rising. By June, Jack Hagenhitch, the department's coordinator of protective services, was saying that cases had nearly tripled. In 1974 we were averaging 5S cases per month. This year it is more like 154, and still increasing.

title: Anne Foster Bride of Judge
description: The marriage of Anne Tolstoi Foster, a vice president of Cunningham Walsh Inc., the advertising agency to Judge Richard Wingard Wallach of the Civil Court of New York took place here yesterday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Budd Goodman performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Edward Tolstoi, father of the bride.

title: Village Gate Shut Down By Buildings Department
description: The Village Gate, the Greenwich Village night club that has had its share of legal tangles, lately, was closed, by the police last night on the basis of an order issued by the city's Department of Buildings.

title: Crewmen of Struck Ship Await Transport to Israel
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (UPI) The remaining crewmen of the strikestalled cargo ship, M. S. Niuta, under orders from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to leave the country as soon as possible, spent today ashore awaiting transportation back to Israel.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: ESCROW IS SOUGHT FOR POSTAGE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Lawyers for the bulk mailing industry petitioned the United States Court of Appeals here today to compel the United States Postal Service to place in escrow its revenue from this week's postagerate increase until the court rules on the legality of the increase.

title: Baker and Richardson Remove Names in Massachusetts Race
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)Two more Republicans have withdrawn their names from the state's March 2 Presidential primary ballot. They are Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee and the Secretary of Commercedesignate, Elliot L. Richardson.

title: No. Carolina Beaten By Wake Forest
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP)Wake Forest lost its junior star, Skip Brown, with an injured thigh early in the second period but went on to send thirdranked North Carolina to its first loss, 9583, in the first round of the Big Four tournament tonight.

title: INFLATION IN CITY BELOW U.S. FIGURE FOR SECOND YEAR
description: For the second consecutive year, the pace of inflation in 1975 was slower in the New York metropolitan area than it was in the nation as a whole7.8 percent here compared with 9.6 percent nationallyand this enhanced the competitiveness of the area's economy. the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Where Did We Put That Nuclear Reactor?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.One major problem of the nuclear age is how to prevent crazy people from making and exploding nuclear bombs. Recently, on a television program, a bright student said he had designed a bomb in five weeks. That does not mean it will work or that he can make one by himself. Moreover, there are other places in society where he can create havoc more easily.

title: Eisenhowers Go South
description: TOKYO. Jan. 2 (AP)David and Julie Nixon Eisenhower left Peking for a visit to southern China today, Hsinhua, the Chinese agency, reported.

title: Westinghouse Faces Suit By Holders Over Uranium
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 2 (UPI)The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that a stockholder class action suit, alleging damages in connection with longterm contracts for supplying uranium to utility customers, had been filed against the company and its independent auditors, Price Waterhouse & Company.

title: TRANSIT POLICE SEEK FULL FORCE
description: John Maye. head of the Tran sit Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday called for the restoring of 500 trarrsit police jobs LO bring the force hack to its level of 3,600 before the attrition and layoffs :of last summer.

title: GEORGE KELLY JR.
description: George Kelly Jr., assistant principal at Public School 75 in Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 30 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Taxes: The City Exodus Incentive

title: Article 1  No Title
Suffolk County Swears In First Democratic Majority
description: RIVER HEAD, L.I., Jan. 2To the sustained applause of their supporters, Suffolk Democrats today formally took control of the County Legislature for the first time in this traditionally Republican county. But before the applause had subsided, their G.O.P. rivals engaged them in a spirited confrontation over minor technical matters.

title: LEIF J. SVERDRUP
description: WASHINGTON, Mo., Jan. 2 (AP)Leif J. Sverdrup, Norwegian consul for Missouri Kansas and Oklahoma and chairman of the engineering. firm of Sverdrup &Parcel and Associates of St. Louis, died today after collapsing while on a hunting trip. He was 77 years: old.

title: WOMAN'S ABDUCTION ASCRIBED TO FRIEND
description: BARNSBORO, Jan. 2 (UPI)A Stafford Township man armed with a revolver abducted a woman he once apparently had dated, but the man was seized eight and a half hours later and the woman released unharmed, the police said.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The Commerce Department today estimated last week's retail sales at $11.9 billion, up 16 per cent from the yearearlier $10.3, billion. Last week's department store sales totaled $2,2 billion, up 36 per cent from $1.6 billion.,

title: Market Place
description: With the stock market embarked upon the uncertain course of another new year, the ranks of Wall Street analysts are filled with optimists, pessimists and others who simply are hedging their forecasts.

title: USED CAR DEALERS FACE F.T.C. ACTION TO BAR DECEPTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Federal Trade Commission proposed today a regulation requiring dealers in used cars and trucks to place a disclosure sticker on all used vehicles for sale.

title: California's Farming Profits Fell Last Year
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2In the vast, rich agricultural valleys of California, hundreds of acres of wine grape vines are being plowed under these days. But cotton growers, after a long period of slack sales and prices, are optimistically increasing their plantings.

title: P.S.C. Grants Con Edison A 9.6% Interim Gas Rise
USED CAR DEALERS FACE F.T.C. ACTION To BAR DECEPTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Federal Trade Commission proposed today a regulation requiring dealers in used cars and trucks to place a disclosure sticker on all used vehicles for sale.

title: Dr. George Milstein Dead A Specialist in Horticulture
description: Dr. George Milstein, a former dentist who for the last 12 years devoted himself to indoor horticulture, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Long Island City. Queens.

title: MISS MANDAC SINGS GRETEL AT THE MET
description: In the New Year's Day performance of Humperdinck's Hansel and Gretel given by the Metropolitan Opera, Evelyn Mandac took the part of Gretel for the first time with the company. A Philippine soprano, she made her Met debut this season.

title: Article 4  No Title
Decision Awaited on an Action to Bar Discharging of PCB's in Hudson River
description: By the end of the month, Prof. Abraham Sofaer of the Columbia Law School will try to decide if two General Electric capacitor plants have violated state water quality standards in the Hudson River as charged by the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner. Ogden R. Reid. Professor Solaer was the hearing officer at 10 days of sometimes bizarre sessions dealing with the allegations. and his decision in this case could trigger lengthy litigation. The basic reason is that Mr. Reid is taking the rare action of demanding not only that the company completely stop discharging a chlorineladen group of chemicals called PCB's inio the riverbut also that the company pay reparations to restore'the river, which Mr. Reid believes has been seriously damaged by the discharges.

title: Humphrey's 76 Stance: Willing, but Not Running
18 Major Satellite Launchings Are Set
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Ha.. Jan. 2 (UPI)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has scheduled IS major satellite launchings in 1976two from the western test range at Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif.. and 16 from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: PollSays 80% FeelRay Had Helpin Killing King
description: A national CBS News poll says 80 percent of those it asked think James Earl Ray was involved with others in the 1968 slaying of the Rev. Dr. Marlin Luther King Jr., The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Aide Won't Deny U.S. Trains Foreigners for War in Angola
Pocatello Official Becomes Idaho's First Black Mayor
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Jan. 2(AP)Thomas L. Purce, a 29yearold vocational education instructor, become Idaho's first black Mayor today.

title: TV: A Truman Crisis
description: In the questionable style of The Missiles of October, a dramatic reconstruction of President Kennedy's Cuban missile crisis, ABC Theater offers Collision Course, which uses President Truman's General MacArthur crisis during the Korean war. The twohour program can be seen on ABC tomorrow evening at 9.

title: STOCKS IN ADVANCE, ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday although volume slumped.

title: Nation Found Near Point Of No Unwanted Births
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The United States is approaching the point at which. statistically. all of its legitimate babies will he wanted at birth by their parents. according to an analytical study of national data published today.

title: DR. ARNOLD TREITMAN
description: Dr. Arnold Treitman, a cardiologist and an instructor in cardiology at Stony Brook Medical College, died of a hear attack Thursday at South Nassau Community Hospital in: Oceanside, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived at 164 East Rockaway Road, Hewlett.

title: Bill Widening Picket Rights Is Vetoed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) President Ford vetoed today a bill that would have expanded picketing rights for construction unions, declaring that the measure could lead to greater, not lesser, conflict in the construction industry.

title: Spurs Franchise Goes to Ottawa
Steelers Defense Is Ready
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 2The specter of Ted Hendricks may hang over the Cincinnti Bengals the rest of the winter, but the Pittsburgn Steelers don't believe in ghosts. Thy don't believe either that any moital linebacker, even if he is 6 feet 7 inches and is called the Mad Stork, will squash their Super Bowl plans.

title: New York in 1975: A Pictorial Review
description: The city received aid from the state, which had its own difficulties, in the fiscal crisis. There were disasters, a kidnapping, a theater strike, but for opera fans there was a happy eventBeverly Sills in her debut at the Met.

title: Frescoes Attributed To Michelangelo Found in Florence
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 2Art experts reported today the discovery of what they believ5 to be previously unknown. frescoes by Michelangelo. lf confirmed, the find would he the second discovery of a work attributed to the Renaissance master in two years.

title: Belgian Cafe Owner Held In Death of 15 in Explosion,
description: MONS, Belgium, Jan. 2 (Reuters)The police today placed manslaughter charges against the owner of a cafe where 15 New Year's revelers died in a fire and explosion.

title: Costs and Taxes Shrink City's Printing Industry
description: In the current flight of industry from New York City, a leader of the exodus has been the printing trade, a victim of high taxes, urban congestion and expensive labor.

title: Goodbye, Lulu
description: State Supreme Court lust ice Edward S. Conway has blown the whistle on a legislative action that is unconscionable even if it were constitutionalwhich the judge says it is not. That is the traditional practice of Albany lawmakers to vote themselves generous supplementslulusto their regular $23,500ayear salaries, plus 40aday expense allowances.

title: Wheat Futures Prices Climb, Reflecting Ordering Overseas
description: Buying by commercial firms, apparently to fill some recent orders by Korea and Peru, helped increase wheat futures prices yesterday enough to keep them unchanged or a penny a bushel higher.

title: At Site of In Flooded Mine, Pumps Work and Families Wait
description: DHANBAD, India, Jan. 2 A week ago tomorrow, as hundreds of men worked in two shafts 1,050 feet below ground at the Chasnala colliery, roofs above them gave way and poured millions of tons of water on them from an abandoned mine.

title: I.M.F. Set a Record on Aid To Member Nations in 75
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it had extended more balanceofpayments assistance to its member countries in 1975 than in any other year of the Fund's 30year history.

title: Antiques: Made by New York Craftsmen
description: Cabinetmakers of early New York have been overshadowed in recent years by those of Newport, Philadelphia and Boston.

title: Ship Aground Off Belize. 576 Passengers Removed
description: BELMOPAN. Belize. Jan. 2 (Reuters) All 576 passengers have been taken off the French liner Mermez, which ran aground off Belize, formerly British Honduras, New Year's Eve, shipping sources said today.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday.

title: Making The Law Of the Sea
The Ballet: Lucifer
description: When Martha Graham created the ballet Lucifer last summer, she was working for the first time with Rudolf Nureyev and, of course, working for the first time with a purely classical dancer. The result was stimulatingMr. Nureyev absorbed a great deal of the Graham style, and very easily assumed the Graham passion.

title: Wall Street Decision
description: A new world of competition is opening on Wall Street, where the hallowed traditions of past generations of brokers are giving way to modern technology and efficiency. Eventually, if the securities industry overhaul goes as intended, the small public shareholder will be better able to compete with insiders for stock market profits.

title: Marie de Bourbon's Nuptials Held
description: The marriage of Marie Blanche Louise Elizabeth de Bourbon to Jonathan Stone took place in Patterson, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, justice of the Peace George J. Pfahl performed the ceremony at the home of Anne de Bourbon, mother of the bride.

title: INFLATION IN CITY BELOW U.S FIGURE FOR SECOND YEAR
description: For the second consecutive year, the pace of inflation in 1975 was slower in the New York metropolitan area than it was in the nation as a whole7.8 percent here compared with 19.6 percent nationallyand this enhanced the competitiveness of the area's economy, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: CrossCountry Skiing Grows As Family Sport in Minnesota
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2Ski fever continues to run high in this flat upper Mississippi River country. It is estimated that last year about 55,000 new devotees were created within a 75mile radius of the Twin Cities. This seaSon, two storms Skiing in midNovember that produced IS inches of wet snow in Wisconsin and Minnesota provided the booster shot that kept the enthusiasm mounting. Today, this city was digging out of an 8inch overnight snowfall. It's small wonder ski shops across the upper Midwest have been running short of stock.

title: Final Results in Election Are Announced in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (Reuters)The final results of the Australian national eleclions for seats in the House of Representatives, held on Dec. 13 and announced today, are as follows:

title: Company Reports
description: For periods ended November 30

title: A Close Ally of Mrs. Gandhi Controls Indian News Chain
FRANK PARENTI
description: CHICAGO. Jan. 2 (UPI)  Frank Parenti, a former minor league infielder and manager in the Chicago White Sox system and longtime White Sox coach, died yesterday at the Bay Pines Veterans Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Josephine Waters Bennett Dies Scholar of English Renaissance
description: Josephine Waters Bennett. a scholar of the literature of the English Renaissance, who had taught at Hunter College from 1942 to 1968, died Wednesday in a Washington hotel. Mrs. Bennett. who was 75 years old, apparently died of a stroke in her sleep. She had been in Washington to do research at the Folger Shakespeare Library. Her home was in Sandwich, Ill.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Construction Spending Up In November After a Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Reuters)The value of new corrstruction put in place in November rose $4.1 billion to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $139.2 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Bargain Hunting Sends Stocks Ahead Broadly
description: The stock market greeted the new year enthusiastically yesterday as bargain hunting, especially in lowpriced issues, generated a broad advance in sluggish trading.

title: People in Sports
description: Al Conover apparently has run out of gimmicks to fire up the Rice University football team. After four seasons at the Houston school. Conover announced his resignation as coach and will go into business.

title: Files Show F.B.I. Got Reports On RosenbergLawyer Meetings
description: Files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation show that during and after the espionage trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, an informant reported to the bureau on talks, traditionally confidential and protected, between the defendants and their attorney.

title: Humphrey's '76 Stance: Willing, but Not Running
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Diffidence has never been an obvious political flaw in Hubert Horatio Humphrey. Even now, as a declared noncandidate for the Presidency after three futile tries, he remains an irrepressible and unabashed aspirant.

title: Canadian Chief's 45 Diary: Hiroshima Spared Whites
description: OTTAWA. Jan. 2The wartime Prime Minister of Canada. William Lyon Mackenzie King. expressed relief that the first atomic bomb used against humans was dropped on the Japanese rather than the white races of Europe, according to a 1945 diary.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
N.F.L. Competition
description: When Federal District Judge Earl Larson decided that the Rozelle rule violated the antitrust laws, he struck a blow against the fantasies with which owners of professional football teams have successfully cloaked their operations. He also shoved the National Football League toward acceptance of the plain facts that professional football is largescale business and that its employees have rights even if they are athletes.

title: Books of The Times
description: No matter how else we will be rated by the history books, we will surely be remembered for our insatiable interest in and probing into mental illness. We encourage revelation, we say, better to understand our fellow man and perhaps to remove the stigma that still attaches itself to those who are mentally disturbed. In art we search for theories that will explain the relationship between the artist's neurosis and the finished work. And we have turned the expression of the artist's illness around in such a way that what might have served to explain the work now becomes part of the subject matter.

title: Oklahoma Eleven Ranked No. 1 in WireServicePolls
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2The Oklahoma Sooners claimed they were No. 1 last night after, their 146 defeat of Michigan in the Orange Bowl, and today they got their hearts desire when both the United Press International and Associated Press polls named them the unofficial national college football champions.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Spring Arrives At Big A
description: If winter is here, can spring be far up the track? was how the late Col. John R. Stingo consoled actionstarved readers of his turf column back before the New York Racing Association and State Legislature thought of overTracks ruling nature, and proclaimed the sport of kings a yearround business.

title: Contract Award
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday receipt of a $44.8 million Navy contract for guidedmissile launcher systems.

title: Ban on Ocean Race Ended by Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 (Reuters  Brazil rescinded its ban on the CapetowntoRio yacht race tonight and announced it would allow entry to its ports.

title: Cummins Recalling Workers
description: COLUMBUS, Ind. Jan. 2 (Reuters)The Cummins Engine Company said today that as a result of an increase in demand for onhighway truck engines, it would recall about 350 production workers from layoff effective Jan. 19.

title: Confederate Widow. 100
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)Achsah T Hartman, widow of a Confederate soldier, died yesterday. She was 100 years old. Mrs. Hartman was married in 1902 to John P. Hartman who served in the Louisiana Cavalry in the Civil War at the age of 14. He died in 1933. Survivors include a daughter and four sons.

title: CON EDISON GETS A 9.6% GAS RISE
description: Most of the Consolidated Edison's 1.2 million gas customers will get a $1or 1 percentincrease in their monthly bilk under a ruling by the Public Servico Commission yeterday.

title: Farm Workers Maintain Lead Over Teamsters in Coast Vote
description: FRESNO. Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) California's new farmlabor election process was responsible for 376 labor elections on individual farms during its first four months of effectiveness, according to statistics compiled by The Associated Press.

title: He Helps Women Put Their Best Face Forward
description: Most women remember when George Masters turned Lynda Bird Johnson from a sparrow into a swan. And when AnnMargret fell and badly injured her face, it was Mr. Masters who was called in to make her up after the plastic surgery. Cutrently, he is working his miracles with makeup at the Bergdorf Goodman beauty salon, and a number of women who dream of looking like glamour girls are lining up for a chance to be transformed by him.

title: ROBERT M'GINNIS,65, A SOLO CLARINETIST
description: Robert E. McGinnis, a solo clarinetist with leading symphony orchestras, died of a heart attack Thursday at Syosset (L.I.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Huntington. L.I.

title: Live Shell Stolen as Lesson
description: OAKLAND, Calf., Jan. 2 (AP) Federal agents said today that a man telephoned a newspaper Wednesday night to say that he had stolen a live 70pound shell just to show how bad the security is at Port Chicago weapons depot. He gave the authorities directions to the street where he had hidden the shell. The guy really proved his point, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent said.

title: Scranton Likely to Aid Ford's Campaign
Rep. Cohen Decides Against a Campaign To Unseat Muskie
description: BANGOR. Me., Jan. 2United States Representative William S. Cohen, Republcian of Maine, announced here today that he would not challenge Democratic Senator EdMund S. Muskie, but would seek reelection from the Second Congressional District.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Jan. 2, 1976

title: Mountain Climbers Reach Top of Grand Teton Peak
description: GRAND TETON PARK, Wyo., Jan. 2 (UPI)Four members of Paul Petzoldt's mountaineering party, led by Tom Warren of Riverton. Wyo., climbed to the 13,776foot summit of Grand Teton Peak today in high winds and subzero temperatures.

title: Art: The American Idiom of Charles Shaw
description: It is not so much in fact as in fiction that we expect to come across someone like Charles Green Shaw (18921974). Gigantic in stature and a model to all in his manners, Mr. Shaw wrote, drew and painted at a professional level but was never known either to talk about what he was doing or in any way to draw attention to it. He was well born, he had a bit of money. He was asked out as often as he wanted to be, and he was in the middle of things without ever seeming to intrude.

title: 38 Officers Are Penalized for Greenburgh Protest
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 2 The Board of Police Commissioners has found 38 Greenburgh town policemen guilty of disorderly conduct, harassment, obstruction of traffic and other disciplinary charges: which resulted from a twohour demonstration at a major intersection six months ago, protesting unresolved police contract negotiations.

title: Ironsicle Van Lets the Handicapped Drive
U.S. SEEKS CHANGES IN INSURANCE LAW
description: The Ford Administration plans to seek changes in Federal laws that exempt the nation's fire and casualty insurers from Federal regulation and antitrust jurisdiction, Government and industry sources have disclosed.

title: Bridge:
description: Misfit hands regularly present problems in bidding, play and defense. If a partnership with a misfit has the highcard values for game, it will usually attempt three notrump, but the problems involved in trying to make nine tricks are often insoluble.

title: Teamsters Offer Reward To Help Find Hoffa's Body
Wanted: U. S. Africa Policy
description: LUSAKA, ZambiaZambia's President Kenneth Kaunda has impeccable credentials as a thirdworld statesman and nobody can complain he is insufficiently opposed to that contemporary bogeyman, the United States. A member of his Central Committee, equivalent to a politburo in Mr. Kaunda's oneparty system: recently spoke out against American imperialism in Havana.

title: T.W.A. Reports Agreement On Deferring Its Debts
description: Trans World Airlines has disclosed a debt deferral agreement with its institutional lenders through the first quarter of 1976. It also said it was negotiating a longer term agreement that may defer S86 million of sinking fund. payments that otherwise would fall due in 1976 and 1977.

title: PULPWOOD STRIKE STIRRING ANXIETY
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 2Concern over the prolonged strike of Canadian woodpulo and paper workers is spreading through the industry as stockpiles decline while mills remain closed by the labor strike.

title: CHESSIE'S EARNINGS UP 135% IN QUARTER
description: Chessie System, Inc., which owns the Chesapeake & Ohio and Baltimore & Ohio as well as a number of affiliated railroads, reported yesterday a 135 percent gain in its fourthquarter earnings. Net income in the period was $40 million, or $2.16 a share, compared with $17 million, or 95 cents a share, in the like quarter of 1974.

title: Article 7  No Title
JUDGE WILLIAM GOODWIN
description: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 2 (UPI) United States District Judge William N. Goodwin, chief judge of Washington State's Western judicial district. died Wednesday while playing tennis here. He was 66 years old.

title: A Date to Remember
description: When historians look back on the events of 1975, one day in particular will stand out as a turning point in the nation's affairs. On April 29, President Ford announced: The evacuation [of all Americans from South Vietnam] has been completed.... This action closes a chapter in the American experience. I ask all Americans to close ranks, to avoid recrimination about the past, to look ahead to the many goals we share...

title: ACCOUNTING RULES CALLED TENTATIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  A leading executive in the accounting profession emphasized today that proposed accounting rules affecting treatment by banks of exchanges of municipal securities, such as those involved in the effort by New York City to avert a formal default were only a task force draft proposal and had not yet been adopted by the profession.

title: Ruffels Beats Roche Newcombe Is Victor
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (AP)Twelfthseeded Ray Ruffels of Australia upset thirdseeded Tony Roche today in the quarterfinals of the Australian open tennis championships.

title: Priorities for Portugal
description: Portugal enters 1976 shorn of last year's early hopes for easy passage to a flourishing new democratic society, but with far better prospects for survival in freedom than seemed possible only six weeks ago. The crushing, with a minimum of bloodshed, of the attempt by the far leftmasterminded at the outset by the Communists and backed by rebels in the armed forcesto seize control of the Government in late November has given democracy a fresh chance in Lisbon.

title: LINUS HOARD WALKER
description: Linus Hoard Walker, legal counsel of the United States organization of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, died Wednesday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)Andy Hinson, Bethune  Cookman's first smallcollege AllAmerican in 1953, was named today the school's football coach. Hinson replaces Wesley Moore, who was dismissed.

title: Article 2  No Title

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today it was conducting an industry  wide investigation of advertising and marketing of individual retirement accounts and annuities to see if the practices violate Federal law.

description: Susanne C. Mayer. daughter of Mrs. Robert Mayer of Ludwigsburg. West Germany, and the late Mr. Mayer, was married in Sharon. Conn., yesterday morning to Otto A. Kaletsch, president of Panta Inc., a corporate planning and management services company here. Justice of the Peace Joan Bianchet performed the ceremony in the Sharon Town Hall.

description: PEKING. Jan. 2 (Reuters)China's First Deputy Prime Minister, Tong Hsiaoping. today lectured 12 American Congresswomen on the dangers of United StatesSoviet dtente.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The United States is approaching. the point at which, statistically, all of its legitimate babies will be wanted at birth by their parents, according to an analytical study of national data published today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Senator Frank Church said tonight, in the aftermath of the assassination of Richard S. Welch, the Central Intelligence Agency representative in Athens, that those who reveal the names of agents active in the field are playing reckless games with human lives.
