title: Could Raises Dividend
description: Gould Inc. directors yesterday voted an increase in the quarterly dividend to 30 cents. a share from 30 cents, payable March 15 to holders of record March 1. The diversified producer of electricalelectronic products raised the quarterly dividend from 27., cents a share on the common stock last February.

title: Dividends
Group Claims Denver Blast
description: DENVER. Jan. 2 (AP)A weekly newspaper here has received a letter signed Continental Army claiming responsibility fur a Dec. 23 bombing at a downtown Federal building near offices of United States military recruiters. Ron Wolf. editor of The Straight Creek journal. said he found the letter yesterday, retyped the text and turned it over the police. There were no injuries in the bombing.

title: CHARLES N. SHIRA
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 2 (UPI) Charles. N. Shira, Mississippi State athletic director, died this evening of a stroke he suffered New Year's Eve at his home in Starkville. He was 49 years old.

title: HOWARDH.BATTIN, ARCHITECT, DEAD
description: Howard H. Battin. a leading Westchester architect, who designed the Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial Library at Hyde Park, N. Y., died Wednesday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 80 years old and lived at 9 Northminster Drive, White Plains.

title: McGovern Visits Lisbon
description: LISBON, Jan. 2 (Reuters)Senator George McGovern met 3rime Minister Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo here today. The South Dakota Democrat is in the first stage of a threeweek tour that will lake him on to Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and North Vietman

title: A King Plot? Still No Hard Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Justice Department is now midway through what will almost certainly be its final investigation into the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and law. yers there are still no closer to con. cluding that un, punished individu. als were involved in the murder than they were the moment James Earl Ray pleaded guilty to the crime.

title: BISHOPS PLAN DRIVE TO BAN ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI A draft of a proposed pastoral letter to be issued by Roman Catholic bishoPs seeking the cooperation of all Americans in amending the Constitution to prohibit abor tion is being circulated among the bishops.

title: CLASH IN PORTUGAL BRINGS A NEW CURB
description: LISBON, Jan. 2Public demonstrations outside prisons were banned today in the northern city of Oporto after incidents last night during which three persons were shot dead and four gravely wounded by guards.

description: In Trinity English Lutheran Church in Fort Wayne, Ind., last evening Karen Joan Andrews was married to David Rees Gilliatt by the Rev. Dr. Richard Frazier.

description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday a seat sale at $44,000, unchanged from the prior sale on Monday. Memberships are now quoted at $36,000 bid, $49,0001 offered.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The Energy Research and Development Administration plans to proceed with research and development on the controversial liquid metal fast breeder reactor.

description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Jan. 2 (UPI)A fire killed a composer and music professor and five other persons yesterday, although a firehouse wal only 100 yards from the burning home.

The sunken blackandwhite squared dance floor of the midtown discotheque is jammed with welltailored young men and with women in slinky jersey dresses and swirly calflength skirts. In each other's arms, couples move to the beat of records spinning in a glassenclosed booth in the corner.

title: 11 FIRS AT A SITE FOUND IN 3 WEEKS
description: A series of small suspicious fires has plagued the 39story officehotel building that is the newest addition to the United Nations complex on First .Avenue.

title: Endpaper
description: Our country's one and only official Bicentennial symbol is a white star suggested by red, white and blue arches and circled by the words American Revolution Bicentennial 17761976. It is the right of the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration alone to license this symbol for use by organizations and products it feels are in keeping with the spirit of this Bicentennial

title: Legislature Meets Wednesday With Many Holdover Problems
description: The Senate and the Assembly !reconvene in Albany Wednesday for the start of the 1976 legislative session, confronted with a variety of issues that are depressingly familiar to the members who endured the sixweeklong special session that ended barely two weeks ago.

title: 65 Injured in a 52Vehicle Accident in Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 3 (AP)Fiftytwo vehicles piled up yesterday in a chainreaction accident on an icy highway, injuring 65 persons, the city police said.

title: SEC's Chief Grapples With Disclosure Rules, Among Many Problems
description: WASHINGTON  The way Roderick Maltman Hills looks at it, the Securities and Exchange Commission greets the new year with a cacophony of jangling problems that demand at least the outlilies of a solution fairly soon.

title: Veteran Truck Driver Gets a Special Funeral
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 3 (AP)  Reached by citizen band radio, nine truck drivers ro.,ecl out and drove by the burial service of one of their fellow truckers to pay their final respects.

title: Miss Cochrane, M. E. Pulitzer Jr. Have Nuptials
description: Ramelle Frost Cochrane, a graduate student in politics at Brandeis University, was married yesterday to Michael E. Pulitzer Jr., a video consultant and greatgrandson of Joseph Pulitzer, publisher of The St. Louis PostDispatch and founder of The Exening World in New York.

title: Labor Goal Portends Strikes
description: Organized labor enters 1976 with two paramount goals: big wage gains in a crowded collective bargaining calendar and an unprecedented massing of union strength for the Presidential election, in sharp contrast to the neutralist role that proved so helpful to President Richard M. Nixon in 1972.

title: In Midwest, A Cautious Air
description: C HICAGO  Through the natiorf's middle, which includes some of the world's richest farmland and some of its heaviest industry, the economy last year was like a prairie jackrabbit  sometimes leaping forward, sometimes dropping back into the nearest hiding place.

title: Layoffs Nag Rutgers Faculty
Cricket Fates, S. K. Scovil 3d Married on L.I.
description: Janet MacLaren Fates, daughter of Harold Leighton Fates of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Winhall, Vt., and the late Mrs. Fates, was married yesterday to Samuel Kingston Scovil 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scovil of Gates Mills. Ohio.

title: Miss Eisemann Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Eisemann of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Anne Eisemann, to Richard Sonkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sonkin of Hauppauge L. I. Miss Eisemann, president of Eisemann & Associates Marketing Consultants Inc., and her fianc, a lawyer with the New York firm of Shearman & Sterling, plan to he married in May.

title: A U.S. Judge Defends Young Lawyer's
Blue Cross Granted Rate Rise of 3.9%
description: The State Insurance Department announced yesterday that it had granted Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York permission to raise rates for four million policyholders in New York City and 12 downstate counties.

title: SOVIET ACCUSED OF AFRICA BRIBE
description: LONDON, Jan. 3  A British political leader has stirred up a diplomatic storm with his charge that the Soviet Union has paid a $50 million bribe to an African leader in return for recognition of a Marxist group that has set up a government in Angola.

title: Cynthia Hicks Is Bride Of Peter Walter Niles
description: Cynthia Montgomery Hicks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Hicks 3d of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Walter Niles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymore Mansfield Niles of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Chandler W. Gilbert performed the ceremony in the Trinitarian Congregational Church in Concord Mass.

title: Between Street Peddlers and Police, a Ritual Confrontation

title: College Soccer Coaches Kick About Corner They're Put In

With the economy as its biggest weapon, the N.C.A.A. will hold a special convention in St. Louis later this month to vote on legislation that if passed, coaches feel, would be detrimental to the sport.

title: The Man Behind Abilities, Inc.

title: The Art of Winning Foundation Grants
description: The Art of Winning Foundation Grants does not deal with such irrelevancies as the quality of your research, the seriousness of your enterrise, its contemporary urgency or whether it will genuinely improve the human condition. Rather it goes right to the heart of the matter and tells you in what format to submit your application, how to write a title page, how to get taxexempt status (if you are an organization) and how to write a thankyou letter (including thankyou letters for rejections to leave the door open since policies, personnel and haonenstance may change").

This is a mild type of material that is applied trees, fruit trees, berry crops and ornamental shrubbery when there are no leaves on the plants and when there is an excellent possibility of good coverage. The materials ars harmless to the environment generally miscible oils, oil emulsions, lime sulfur or dinitros.

The joint contract board of the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association put into effect a special $3.28 surcharge on local tonnage assessments levied to pay for such contractual obligations as the guaranteed annual income and pensions, and health and welfare services.

title: Washington Hopes Mobutu Will Be a Key to Africa's Future

With that, the flow of United States funds into the huge, potentially rich, but still disorganized Central African country grew larger and larger, The Americans were not alone. The Japanese, the French and the Belgians also sank funds into joint ventures with the Zairois, hoping finally tap the mineral riches and commercial possibilities of the country.

Kissinger, has been appointed to the newly created S37,800 a year position of coordinator of consumer affairs in the State Department. It was one of Walter's favorite operas, and it was with Fidelio that he made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Feb. 14, 1941. His leading singers were Rend Maison, Kirsten Flagstad, Alexander Kipnis and Herbert Janssen: pretty.close to an allstar cast.

description: Is there a man's world and a woman's world? Has woman been judged, in lbsen's words, in practical life according to man's laws, as if she were not a woman but a man"? Precisely what constraint does our biological heritage place on our motivations and actions? It is to these central and endlessly recurring questions that sociologists Lionel Tiger and Joseph Shepher address themselves in their study of some Israeli kibbutzim.

Feigen of Ne,w York, and James Corcoran of Los Angeles. Retail sales in the last full shopping week before Christmas increased 17 percent over the level of sales in the corresponding week in 1974. . . . Residential build. lyz contracts, according to F. W. Dodge, rose 29 percnt In value in November compared with November of 1974, but the rise was offset by contrct value declines in other types of construction. Totl value of contracts in the month amounted o $5.57 billion, down 6 percent.

title: Music Notes: A Massenet Spectacular
description: Massenet is the coming revival, and it's going to happen in New York, Randolph Mickelson predicts confidently. If it does, it will he partly due to the enthusiasm of this musicologist, who specializes in the intricacies of the bel canto style and has for years worked closely with such singers as Montserrat Cabelie and Joan Sutherland In preparing ornamentation and cadenzas for rarely sung scores. (He edited the edition of Rossini's Siege of Corinth for the 1969 La Scala production in which Beverly Sills and Marilyn Horne made their debuts, a version on which the current Met performances are biased.) tavIng become fascinated with the unknown sacred scores of wellknown secular composers, Mickelson has founded the Sacred Music Society of America, which makes its bow on Jan. 7 at Avery Fisher Hall with Jules Nlassenet's sacred drama Marie Magdeleine, performed for the first time in America.

title: Bull, Bear and Mr. In Between

title: Who invented the clothespin?By Shaker Hands
description: Several national magazines advertise kits for building your own Shaker furniture. Young America listens to Judy Collins singing the beautiful Shaker folk song, 'Tis a Gift to Be Simple. And Middle America delights feels its romantic rootsin listening to Aaron Copland's Appalachian Spring, which is based upon a Shaker song. The household broom, the circular saw, even the ordinary wooden clothespin, all are inventions of Shaker communal villages, and all touch our lives with a practical regularity.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS TO BACK DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  President Ford said today that he would not abandon his support for dtente with the Russians and that any Presidential candidate who urges such a change in policy will be the loser in the long run.

title: John Simon on stage
description: It is common knowledge that American culture has produced at least two John Simons: John Simon the Good who makes his living in publishing, giving editorial support and encouragement to creative people, not to be confused with John Simon the Bad who makes his living in criticism. giving other sorts of creative people bilious attacks and nervous disorders. After reading through these two collections of theater essays and reviews, I have become convinced that the critical John Simon is composed of divided personae as well. which, for convenience sake, we'll call the good, the bad and the ugly.

title: STAGE VIEW; Can a 1915 Musical Sound Fresh? Yes
description: I began enjoying Very Good Eddie during the, overture, and do you know why? Didn't recognize a single tune in it. Now that is undoubtedly remiss of me, because even if this early Jerome Kern score (1915) has never been among his most celebrated I certainly ought to have heard hummed, and never forgotten, as enchantingly plaintive a duet as Babes in the Wood. (I guess I thought the phrase lost in the wood belonged exclusively to Ira Gcrshwin, whose use of it in Someone to Watch Over Me I had not forgotten, and so became addled somewhere along the lamentable line). I think, too, that some kind soul might, over the years, have directed my attention to a bit of music called I've Got to Dance, which is much more than an early form of maxixe and even more fun than its sudden and impertinent banjo accompaniment. It's got a strange modulation in itlisten, listenthat can make your skin prickle in the same way that the opening phrases of the more recent Cabaret did.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Courmayeur fly to Milan or Geneva, then rent a car. Train or bus connections from these cities are difficult. The village is about 140 miles from Milan and 180 from Geneva. For room reservations write to the Office of Tourism and Travel. Viale Monte Bianco, 100, Courmayeur, Italy. To go to Lech fly to Zurich, then take an express train to Langen; from Langen there is a local bus or taxi. An alternate route: bus from the Zurich airport to St. Anton (three and a half hours), and then a local bus to Lech. The distance from Zurich is about 120 miles. For room reservations write to the Lech Tourist Office, Lech, Austria. Be certain to specify that you want rooms in the center of town where every. thing is nearby. Ask about offseason reductions, which can range up to 20 percent.

title: A Totally Secure Airport: Impossible
description: LOS ANGELES  Three years ago tomorrow, the United States inaugurated the most extensive system of routine air travel surveillance and searches in the country's history. Under White House orders, the nation's airlines and more than 530 airports were ordered to inspect every purse, briefcase, parcel and other item carried aboard airliners. The passengers themselves were to be inspected by metal detectors.

title: Yugoslavia's New System

The manager of a new multistory department store says he gets his merchandising ideas all the way from GUM in Moscow to NeimanMarcus in Texas. The traffic jams are as solid as in many Western cities. with the car becoming a necessity.

title: Garage Sales Facing South Jersey Curbs
description: COLLINGSWOODGarage sales, the homeowner's traditional method of getting paid for disposing of accumulated tousehold junk, are coming under regulation in a growing number of South Jersey municipalities.

title: Sharp Rise in Profits Expected for 1976
description: Dollar profits of America's corporations this year are expected to rise sharply  perhaps twice as far as they dropped in 1975  according to several leading economists. So abrupt a reversal would bring profits to their highest total in American history.

It's called New Yorkers for Tourism Excellence and Expansion (that's NYFTEE, pronounced nifty"), and if it accomplishes nothing else; it should spur everyone in the travel industry to make a New Year's resolution to swear off abbreviations.

description: The employment rate in New York City continued to decline in November, compared with November 1974, according to the State Department of Labor. State economists worry because the rate of job losses in the city is steeper now than at any other period for which data exist.

title: What do we learn when apes smoke cigarettes?; Animal Liberation
description: Peter Singer is as far from a philosopher's philosopher as one can get  a young Australian philosophy teacher with the highest philosophical pedigrees who willfully avoids the more arcane and technical issues that concern most of his colleagues in the Englishspeaking world. Not only has he argued for the necessity of getting philosophy back into the marketplace, but he has provided paradigms of how this can be done, writing on fields as diverse as famine and civil disobedience, in journals as different as Analysis and The New York Times Magazine.

title: Lebanese Attack Jail, Free Criminals
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3A band of more than 400 armed men assaulted a prison north of Tripoli early today and, after a 90minute battle with guards, freed 100 criminals, police sources reported.

title: What's Doing in NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: THE SETTINGThis is a state without a sales or income tax but with a balanced surplus budget. Nothing serves better to illustrate the lifestyle of the New Hampshire native: Live within your means; make do with the fruits of your labor. On the other hand, while New Hampshirites may frown on New York's fiscal woes and call Massachusetts Taxachusetts, they welcome freespending outofstaters with open arms. Their $400million annual partonage of New Hampshire's yearround recreation facilities is crucial to the state's economy. No sooner have the last foliage watchers departed in October with the final falling leaf than the mountain resorts gear up for winter sports. Winter usually comes early to New Hampshire and stays late. Snowfall averages 150 inches in the northern region and makes possible some of the best skiing available from December to April in the Northeast. One of the cardinal attractions of a New Hampshire winter is that all it offers can be enjoyed far from the madding crowds who fight for elbow room in more fashionable surroundings.

title: Merrick Is Prepared for Bicentennial
description: MERRICK  Residents of this community have been preparing since 1972 for the nation's Bicentennial and the 333d anniversary of the Merricks.

He said that he believed the inquiry would find millions of dollars of waste and fat in government noshow and nonessential political jobs.

title: Veterinarians Start Program For Curtailing Dog Population
description: With the dog population explosion causing a big problem, the Veterinary Medical Association of New York City has taken steps to do something about it. The organization's executive board has voted to put imo action a plan to provide lowcost neutering surgery for pets of New York residents financially unable to pay the normal veterinary fees.

title: Airline Strike Count Today
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3 (UPI)Ballots will be counted tomorrow in a poll that will determine whether the 1,200 flight attendants of National Airlines will continue a strike that has kept the carrier grounded since Sept. 1. The attendants have been voting on the question in recent days, and if they decide to return. National hopes to begin flying its 55 jets on Tuesday

title: The Replay' Issue
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 3Sooner or later, a critical National Football League game, perhaps the Super Bowl, perhaps one of tomorrow's conference championships, will be decided by a glaringly wrong call by one of the six officials. Glaringly wrong means, for example, a pass ruled complete even though it is clear on the TV replay that the receiver was out of bounds. When a game is decided or influenced by a glaringly wrong call the nation will know that the wrong team won. The credibility of the N.F.L. will be as weak as its antitrust arguments. The shame Is that the possibility of the wrong team winning can be avoided. All the N.F.L. has to do is what the nation doeslook at the replay.

title: Hanoi Hopeful on Rail Line
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)The 1,060mile rail link between Hanoi and Saigon should be fully back in service by the end of 1976 after repair work on extensive war damage, the North Vietnamese Communist party newspaper, Nhan Dan, reports. Parts of the line are already open to traffic in South Vietnam.

title: The PostModern' Choreography of Trisha Brown
description: In a famous sequence from the film Royal Wedding, Fred Astaire seems to dance up one wall of a room, across the ceiling, and back down another wall without ever missing a single tap. Choreographer Trisha Brown, a leading exemplar of what might be called postmodern dance, goes him one better; or perhaps I should say six better. In her performance event entitled Walking on the Wall, which was presented at the Whitney Museum four years ago. Brown and five of her dancers walked, trotted and sometimes ran along two adjacent walls.

title: Tears Take No Holiday On the Soaps
description: If you, too, have been battered by the barrage of fake togetherness that assaults us every holiday seasonthat prime time for suicide, crime and marital discordyou may be cheered to know there is .a way to see the Christmas traumas dramatized in their true terror each year. If you need to be reassured that you're not the only one who gets migraine from jingle bells, just tune into the soap operas. The muchmaligned daytime dramas are the one place you'll find acknowledgment that lots of people have a hard time with the holidays. I have found that the best therapy for the crunch of Christmas is to buy a six pack of beer, a couple of pastrami sandwiches, and sit back and watch the soaps on the day before Christmas.

title: A New Role for Radio Star of Old
description: MURRAY HILL  When members or St. Andrew's Episcopal Church attend the 11 A.M. service on Sundays, they are aware that the soloist has some decidedly unecclesiastic ways. She insists on counting the house and she sings facing the audience.

title: The Stein gut and Blumenthal Cases Again Raise Constitutional Issues
description: His proudest accomplishment, the prosecutor told a group of lawyers at a private lunch not long ago, was not the impressive string of important cases brought and won by his office, but the fact that no leaks concerning grand juries had come from that office.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 (AP)Armed forces in the South Vietnamese province of Darlac are on a mission to destroy troops still loyal to the former Saigon regime, according to a Hanoi radio broadcast monitored here.

title: The Ballet: Peter Darrell's Operatic Tales of Hoffmann'
description: In recent years British choreographers seem to have created a special form of what might be called the operatic ballet  a ballet closely based on an opera. and sometimes, although not usually, using that opera's music. The late John Cranko's

title: Newark Man Slain; Police Here Study Tie to Muslim Feud
description: An employee of the Newark Board of Education was found slain here yesterday, authorities said, and investigators were attempting to establish whether the man had been a victim of the long. bloody feuding between rival Muslim factions in Newark.

title: Before the Pipes Can Freeze
description: When a house that Is located in an area where freezing temperatures are a possibility is left unoccupied for more than a day or two, it is always advisable to leave the heating system on  at least at its minimum setting of 45 or 50 degrees. This insures against the interior of the house developing condensation that eventually leads to mildew and musty odors and, even more important, it will protect the plumbing system against dangerous freezing and possible bursting (which almost always leads to very expensive repairs  especially if the pipes thaw out and flood parts of the house before the owner returns).

title: Yiddish Humor The Adventures Of the Fabulous Shlemiel
description: In Love and Death Woody Allen, a shlemiel passing as a Russian soldier in the Napoleonic wars, meets a Spanish countess of dazzling ugliness and addresses her, gallantly, as Your mieskeyt. In Blazing Saddles Mel Brooks's Indian chief bursts into a harangue of pure Yiddishfrom Sioux to nu. In Funny Lady Barbra Streisand, playing (more or less) Fanny Brice, and James Caan, fumbling as Billy Rose, trot out a threeword Yiddish vocabulary, all with excretory associations happily beyond the grasp of most American audiences.

title: Democrats to Push State Income Tax
description: TRENTONDespite a series of taxreform defeats over the last two years, the new Democratic leadership in the Senate will again press for the enactment of a bropcibase levy this year, almost certainly a graduated state income tax. Although the new Democratic leaders in the Assembly are intent upon reserving their options, they, too, regard an income tax as the fairest revenue source to meet New Jersey's fiscal crisis.

title: In Boston, Ripple of New York's Hard Times
description: BOSTON  The Christmas lights that normally gloriously swathe Boston Commoneven in defiance of the great energy crisis of two seasons were noticeably thin last month. There was considerable difficulty in raising the contributions from the downtown merchants that have decked the Common in years past.

title: Politics Thwart Consumer Forces
description: WASHINGTON  The constmier movement has never been adroit at straightforward electoral politics. Nonpartisanship has been an instinctive strategy, and its priorities have been outside politics. But political reality has hurt the movement in the last few years, and it's apt to hurt even more in 1976.

title: CASE IS OPTIMISTIC ON TRANSIT PLANS
description: Senator Clifford P. Case, Re:publican of New Jersey, said yesterday that the Federal relection of funds for the extension of the PATH rapidtransit :line in New Jersey could open the way for a new era in coordinated transit planning.

description: Mr. and Mrs. James Rush James Jr. of St. Louis and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Handley James, to Worthington Johnson Jr., son of Mr. Johnson of Fairfield, Conn., and Mrs. Drayton Cochran of Oyster Bay. L. I.

title: LETTERS
description: In an article on the new editorial policies at Art forum magazine ["Muddled Marxism Replaces Criticism at Artforam, Dec. 21], Hilton Kramer stated that a tendentious sociopolitical analysis of all artistic events, deeply suspicious of all esthetic claims, has now routed all but the last traces of [the] formalist criticism . . . in what was, until quite recently, our leading modernist art journal. Herewith, replies from the editors of Artforum and others:

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the DaySection 1

title: TV VIEW
description: One of the more intriguing possibilities for this new year was reported in a recent edition of The Media Report, a biweekly newsletter: Consumerist Ralph Nader may be preparing to bite the media hand that's fed him over the years. Nader has been telling some of our sources that he has been keeping a close eye on television network news programs. Specifically, we're told he has been:watching all of the network television panel shows' to see what kind of news comes out of them. A staffer is studying how politicians use these forums as a device to duck the tough questions' and propagandize the audiences. Also . . looking at the conduct of the correspondents to see if they are as probing as they should be. Television is a matter of growing concern' to Nader.

title: The Tuition Spiral
description: The inexorable rise of tuition charges at the nation's independent colleges is a matter of deep concern not only to these institutions' current and prospective students but to all those who believe in diversity higher education. An informal polling of leading independent universities across the country shows that the average tuition level among that group will be $4,200 in the coming academic year.

title: The Nation
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, appears to have made it certain that school busing to achieve desegregation will be an issue in the 1976 campaign. He has proposed legislation that would restrict judicial busing orders.

title: Politics vs. Art In CostaGavras And Wertmuller
description: Constantin Costa Gavras and Lina Wertmuller currently share the title of Europe's preeminent political moviemaker. They have been equally honored; their political outlooks are close, both identified with the European Left; and they agree on the central place that politics holds in their respective works. From the moment you try to show society, a movie becomes political, says CostaGavras. And Wertmuller says, Everything is political. Yet their visions are in truth worlds apart and their films have something to tell us about the uses of politics in works of the imagination.

title: TwoMile Relay To Molloy in 7:58.3
description: Archbishop Molloy High School of Queens posted an outstanding earlyseason time of 7 minutes 58.3 seconds in the twomile relay yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association novice indoor track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Varied Backing Seen for Soviet in Angola; Moscow Asks End to Armed Intervention
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 3A number of African leaders and journalists who are not Soviet sympathizers are publicly condoning Moscow's assistance to Angola's Popular Movement while condemning the smallerscale and less blatant support given by the United States to two other nationalist factions in Angola.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: My roof Is covered with white asphalt shingles. Along the front of the house there are a number of tree branches that overhang the roof and because of the sap and debris falling from these branches the roof has discolored and is turning black, giving it a shabby looking appearance. Can anything be done to restore the whiteness to the roof without damaging the shingles? Heavy rains have not washed the dirt away.  E.A.I., Rockaway, N.J.

J., of the ,engagement of their daughter, Eileen Louise Boerner, to James Harold Patch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Patch of Saugus and Eastham, Mass. title: STAMPS

title: A Realistic Generation' of Youth Turns to Business
description: A few years ago Martha Reed considered the world of business and finance something to be shunned, or more ideally, to be attacked. She was majoring in art his. tory at Vassar College ana planning a career in that field.

title: If Bette Davis Can Be Alec Guinness's Mother. . .
description: My eye was caught recently by an item in one of the Hollywood gossip' columns. Right after the latest news about Cher's most recent annulment from Greg Allman (I think the grounds this time were irreconcilable hairdo's) was the following dispatch: Michael Caine goes next into Hollywood and Vine' playing Jackie Gleason's son. Michael Caine as Jackie Gleason's son? Isn't Michael Caine the rather thin and pasty Cockney actor who portrayed Alfie, and isn't Jackie Gleason the rather corpulent and robust AllAmerican comic who gave us Ralph Kramden? Who's going to play Mrs. Gleason? Twiggy?

title: 2 in Miami Seeking Cubans For Angola; F.B.I. Plans Inquiry

title: Monetary policy: A Shifting Target

title: Frames: Fancy, Funny and Fine
description: Need a frame? Whereas custommade frames tend to be quite expensive, old ones can frequently be bought for a pittance at antique shops. flea markets and garage sales  or even be obtained free from the attics or basements of friends. These old frames often need only a bit of touching up to restore them to their original beauty  and this is exactly what thousands of hobbyists enjoy doing.

Gill of Manhasset, L, I.. and Scottsdale, Ariz., to Bruce Chambers Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. Stevens of Ponce, Puerto Rico, formerly of Galveston, Tex.

title: Cincinnati Talks Go On
description: CINCIN IATI, Jan. 3 (AP)  Policemen and firemen involved in a contract dispute with the city plan to take their case to the City Council on Monday, while 3,800 nonuniformed workers continued talks today.

title: Carol Waters Has Nuptials
description: Carol Lynn Waters and Thomas Hayward Torrey were married yesterday evening in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N. Y., by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Dudley J. Stroup.

title: PUBLISHER, EDITOR HEADING FOR JAIL
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3A millionaire publisher of erotica and an editor of one of his books are to begin serving prison sentences Monday for converting a Presidential commission's report on pornography into a bestseller in 1970 by adding 546 illustrations to a condensed version of the official text.

title: Skier's Dream Come True: Italy and Austria Back to Back
description: E VER since I first slithered down an Icecaked ski slope studded with clusters of cunningly hidden tree stumpsa condition known in the jargon of some ski area operators In the American Northeast as packed powder, goodtoexcellent skiing"I have wanted to ski in Europe. There, according to the brochures and ski movies, powder reaches the kneecaps, the sun shines like one of those brilliant aureoles in a Piero de Franceschi paintIng, and the skiers and instructors, shop. keepers and hoteliers greet each day without a care.

title: Gov. Askew Orders Inquiry On New Year's Eve Arrests
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP)  Gov. Reubin Askew has ordered a state investigation of the New Year's Eve disturbance here in which 110 persons were arrested after policemen unleashed billy clubs and turned fire hoses on revelers.

title: Toonerville Sets Calder Turf Mark
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP)Toonerville broke his second Calder Race Course record in two starts, upsetting the favored Royal Glint today in the $93,000 McKnight Handicap.

title: Police Rate Radio Car Response Times
description: A police survey in a Brooklyn precinct has found that the average time it takes for a radio car to reach the scene of a reported crime or emergency is 3.8 minutes  much faster than had been widely believed by most law enforcement experts.

title: Liberals and Conservatives Join to Exert Negative Power
description: WASHINGTONThe growing controversy over what the United States should do to develop new sources of energy has created an unusual alliance economic conservatives, environmentalists, oil state representatives and some of the more liberal members of the House and Senate.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article on the Soviet Circus  In Russia, the Circus Is an Art Form, Dec. 14  was written by David Shipler, not Christopher Wren.

title: New Airport in Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali, Jan. 3 (Agence France Presse)  Mali President Moussa Traore has opened an International Airport 10 miles from the center of the capital.

title: AILEEN V. EPPLER
description: Aileen Vaughan Eppler, widow of William E. Eppler, railroad financial consultant, died Friday in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Mendham, N..J.

title: Late TV Listings
For young readers
description: The Magic Cauldron is an intriguing study, yet it seems somewhat rushed, not quite in kilter, possibly too ambitious. One of those books that should have been longer or shorter. Certainly Margaret F. O'Connell's axial theme is valid and important: that the witch, particularly during early Christian times, served as a kind of apothecary. It wasn't all bat wing and toad kidney in trie stereotypical cauldron: digitalis, salicylic acid (that first Bayer aspirin made from willow bark), belladonna, henbane were also available without prescription. Witches could cure and relieve; they were useful to the woebegone peasant whose lord provided no Blue Cross coverage. This makes excellent sense: witches couldn't have hung out their clandestine shingles for so long unless they had run up a decent track record. What witches have done for the good of mankind has been glossed over and mostly forgotten. Or misunderstood; misunderstood probably by the witches themthat.

title: Four Lives Of Judy
description: When I was about 7. I had a friend named Judalein. We used to play at her grandmother's house. In it there was a big closet filled with wonderful grownup, makebelieve clothes we loved to wear. Sometimes Judalein's aunt, to whom the clothes belonged, would unexpectedly drop by. The grandmother would tell us to stay in the quiet corners of the house and be good. I was afraid of the aunt because she received such special treatment, as if there might be something wrong with her. One day, to my horror, she asked to see me. I presented myself in the living room. She stood with her back to me. then abruptly turned around and said, I understand you're moving to New York. I nodded. It's too bad you have to leavebut you'll like it there, really you will, she said, earnestly. I nodded again. I believed her. And, she added, looking most tenderly Into my face. you will grow up and be very beautiful.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: N o More than six months ago, it was prophesied in this .:olurrin that 57th Street would assert itself.as the most rewarding single concentration of art galleries in Manhattan. It has competition !imp Madison Avenue and SoHo, but the fall season backed up the claim. By general consent. the two most beautiful displays of pure painting were those of Richard Diebenkorn (at Marlborough. 40 West 57th Street) and Helen Frankenthaler (at Emmerich. 41 East 57th Street). The transplanted Kennedy Galleries (40 West 57th Street) are a prime source of Americana fOr those who know how to pick and choose. At 20 West 57th Street, Jill Kornblee and Brooke Alexander took to their new addresses the way migrant geese take to a particularly rewarding pond. The bolas Gallery at. 52 East, 57th Street humanizes an intimidating office building at street level. Terry Dintenfass opens at 50 West.57th Street in March. There is even a street magazine, The 57th Street Review, which covers the current shows 10 times a year and can be purchased from Jock Truman, 24 West 57th Street, for $10.00 a year. (Contributors to the current issue include John Ashbery, David Shapiro and John Bernard Myers.)

title: Answers/Questions
description: A ANTHUMUIVIS (Dec. 14)  Three years ago, Mrs. A.W.P., Douglaston, N. Y., purchased an anthurium and although she  transplanted it.twice to larger pots, it never bloomed. She asked why. Mrs. D. H. Griffin, a New York State reader, explains, Anthuriums need to be pot bound or only foliage will grow. Any surface roots need only to be lightly covered with sphagnum moss and kept damp. Mist the plants daily and feed every two weeks with a plant food high in phosphorus. With good light, if no sun, the antburiums should bud as mine have. Constance PrOcott, a New York City reader, adds this, A good potting mixture for anthuriums is equal parts of peat moss and ostliunda fiber or perlite. I feed them once a month with fish, emulsion and 153015 water soluble fertilizer at onegullter strength.

title: Trivia into myth
description: If Anais Nin is not recognized as one of America's best writers today it is because we are always so slow to recognize prophets in our own country; and perhaps because of an amalgam of other incidentals the careful reader will find in this book. A wonderful book. One I wish had been called An Artist Speaks or A Humanitarian Speaks or even An American Speaks, for what comes through is hr articulate insightfulness about the interior processes of the artist, the deep love for people and life which both she and all of her work possess, and something that have been touting for a few years now, her originality, her inventivenessthe fact that she has created a form of writing which was never there before. Of course, I do not mean people never wrote diaries before, or journals. But that she has done something especially American, and especially 20th century, in taking an old form, something that was conceived of as unimportant, because it is personal, and turned it into a rich public art form. As with most innovators, it is hard to imagine what the world was really like before she changed it.

title: Will Sondheim Succeed In Being Genuinely Japanese?

As we begin our talk in his East Side apartment, the composer  lyricist removes the ice cubes his Japanese manservant Eno has inadvertently dropped into a glass of white wine and observes, Whether or not the show bombs, and regardless of whether you love it or loathe it, it's certainly the most bizarre and unusual musical ever to be seen in a commercial setting, How much do you know about it?

title: Twyla Tharp's new kick
description: Twyia Tharp clumps back into the studio whore she's been re. hearsing all morning with her company, staggering slightly under the burden of her coat and a huge, shapeless, overloaded bag that has the legs of a pair of jeans protruding from it. She's wearing typical multilayered Tharp rehearsal attire: Ileshcolored leotard and tights, a striped Tshirt, a pair of royal blut wool tights and a pair of red wool tights rolled up to knee level. She stands theresmall, dark and intenserapping out a few lastminute instructions to the dancers; she's on her way to American Ballet Theatre (A.B.T.) to work on her new ballet for that company. Suddenly she stops in mid' sentence', frowns down at her feet. says accusingly, THESE AREN'T MY SHOES! and retreats to the dressing room with a whoop laughter, her straight, choppedoff hair swinging. The other dancers look pleased and proud, as if she were going off to win the Golden Gloves for them. They down their yogurt and get back to work without her. Tharp never does get her jeans on.

The father smiled and gently pushed the boy toward the tall, somber stranger saying, Go on, he'll shake your hand.

title: Scrubber Success
description: Only a year ago some major power companies were conducting an allout campaign against the coal scrubber, a system for removing harmful sulfur oxides before they floated out through the chimneys of a power plant. The scrubber, they insisted, was unproved, unreliable and expensive. Better to stripmine the lowsulfur coal of the West; until that could be obtained in sufficient quantity, they would settle for tall stacks, which would disperse damaging emissions over a wide area. The theory was that the solution to pollution is dilution.

title: CHESS
description: Amazing, isn't it, how vengeful, chess positions can be if not handled in accordance with the correct strategy. One would think offhand that, in a favorable position, something less than the most forcing continuation should still suffice to draw, even if it does dissipate winning chances. But it doesn't always work that way.

title: New Mint Mailing Policy
description: With multitudinous offerings of special Bicentennial coins and medals, last year was probably the busiest in the history of the U.S. Mint; consequently the number of customer complaints about slow delivery or no delivery probably reached an alltime high. From personal experience this column can attest that the Mint's staff made strenuous efforts to answer  and solve  every complaint, but apparently the sheer weight of numbers put that goal out of reach. Some angry customers would not accept any apologies but continued cling to the understandable but mistaken belief that they were being ripped off by a branch of the Government bureaucracy.

title: Map to Tell Story Of Passaic's Past

title: SUDDENLY, ANGOLA
description: HUAMBO, Angola. It is a hig land. twice the size of Texas, a mosaic of high plateau, broad rangeland, craggy mountains, stretches of desert, and rain forest with elephant grass standing tall along the riverbanks. For centuries, the land lay in colonial slumber, largely ignored by its absentee landlords in Lisbon, who were interested in Angola only as a source of slaves for Brazil, though a few investors talked shrewdly of the territory's untapped wealth in coffee, diamonds and oil. When the stave trade was outlawed, the land became nothing more than a penal colony for Portuguese convicts. It was not until 1912 that the Portuguese subdued the last tribal revolts. It was not until after World War II that the Salazar Government turned its energy to the develop:nem and colonization of Angola.

title: Article 14  No Title

Design

Originally the house was built for a bachelor, but three years ago it was bought by a married couple to use as a summer home.

Nonetheless, the heads of two Congressional committees said the service had to end because amounted to unfair competition to private photocopy businesses by a Federal agency.

The 33yearold salesman from Cleveland, in Manhattan for a business meeting, had a reservation to return home the next daybut he'd changed his mind. He wanted to stay in New York an extra day, to shop, to visit relatives. The United agent was reassuring: No problem, there were plenty of flights, plenty of seats. Maeroff said he'd call back when he'd made up his mind which Sunday flight he'd take.

Hamilton Jordon, his campaign coordinator, said that Mr. Carter's son, Chip, and his wife, Caron, would fill in for Mr. Carter at scheduled appearances.

Four climbers reached the summit Friday and a group of five made it to the top yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 38yearold city corrections officer was shot to death during a holdup of a bar and grill in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police reported. Authorities said the officer, Charles Hill of 1577 Carroll Street in the Crown Heights section, had finished work at the Rikers Island Hospital and was at the Moulin Rouge Lounge at 344 Sumner Avenue when three armed men entered. According the police, the officer may have been shot by one of the men even before the holdup was announced.

An undetermined number of persons were evacuated from a square mile area around the Dorchester Gas Company refinery.

title: MRS. CARMEN LOMBARDO
description: Florence Lombardo, widow of Carmen Lombardo, cofounder with his brother Guy of the Royal Canadians dance band, died Saturday in Miami, where she had lived since her bus' band's death in 1972. She was 94 years old.

title: 7 WILD WOOD STORES DAMAGED BY A FIRE
description: WILDWOOD, Jan. 4 (AP)A fire that police officials said was apparently started by an arsonist did more than $1 million worth of damage to seven Boardwalk stores here today.

title: Man Using an Alias Is Listed Among 62 eeking Presidency
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 4 (AP)As a Presidential candidate, Paul T. Lanyhow is just a face in the crowd, and nobody knows which one. He is running under an assumed name.

title: TRANSIT SERVICE FOR NEEDY CLOSES
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4  A threeyearold program that provided free transportation to elderly and sick persons in rural areas of 21 counties in western and southwestern Pennsylvania ended at the close of 1975.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We have received recently by mail several basic lessons in chemistry, a subject that has never interested us much in an academic sense. We flunked chemistry in high school, and our mastery of the subject runs to the knowledge that water is sometimes referred to as attchtwooh, a thought that has never given us much comfort.

title: Put Your Dreams Away: The Sinatra Connection
description: In a recent essay about the way Senators Frank Church and John Tower were trying to conceal a connection between the Kennedy White House and the Mafia mobsters assigned to kill Fidel Castro, I concluded:

title: Assembly Will Act Today On Supplement to Budget
description: TRENTON, Jan. 4The New Jersey Assembly convenes here tomorrow in a final effort to approve a $37 million supplemental budget appropriation. The funds would head off scheduled cutbacks in the state's Medicaid and commuter railand bussubsidy programs.

title: Planning: I
description: WASHINGTONThe United States is well on the way to a planned economy. Over the next decade, questions of economic growth, income distribution, price and employment levels and the use of scarce natural resources will become more and more subject to explicit political decision. The key questions are not whether we will plan, but how and for whose benefit.

title: Waitress Who Refused To Shave Back on Job
description: SOMERS, Conn., Jan. 4 (UPI)Judith Quist returns to her waitresses job at the Plaza Restaurant tomorrow wearing opaque stockings almost two years after being dismissed for not shaving her legs.

title: Jackson Supporters Stage a Blitz for Delegates Here
description: The 1976 Presidential campaign in New York began to take shape yesterday in 40 motel meeting rooms and political clubhouses, where supporters of Henry M. Jackson gathered to suggest candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: A CHURCH HELPS CLERGY FIND JOBS
description: The clergydeployment office of the Episcopal Church has contracted with Snelling and Snelling, a worldwide employment agency, to help clergymen find jobs outside the church.

title: F.B.I. Accused of 69 Bid to Exploit Blacks'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4The Federal Bureau of Investigation attempted to capitalize on the violent and sometimes fatal battling between two West Coast black militant groups in 1969, according to memorandums in the files of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Science Drives to Expand Nature's Nitrogen Output
description: Scientists in many nations are sharply expanding efforts to harness tiny organisms, widely distributed in nature, in order to reduce agriculture's dependence on artificial fertilizers for meeting vast new food requirements in the next quarter century.

title: Concorde Is Facing A Decisive Hearing
description: The issue of whether the 1,350mile.anhour Concorde should be allowed to fly regular .passenger runs into the United States will enter the decisive stage today in Washington when Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. presides over a one.day hearing.

title: Stephanie Saland Dances Nutcracker
description: The Nutcracker jingled tunefully away over the weekend, leaving in its train holiday memories and a glimpse at a promising new Sugar Plum Fairy. Stephanie Saland danced the role Saturday afternoon with Daniel DueII as her cavalier in New York City Ballet's sumptuous production.

title: IRVING KAUFMAN, SINGER, 85, DEAD
description: INDIO, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP) Irving Kaufman, a singer and an early radio and recording artist, died yesterday of heart complications at Indio Community Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: TV: Upstairs, Downstairs Reflects Social Change
description: About midway through its last 13 episodes, Upstairs, Downstairs went distressingly bad. Props turned noticeably shabby, performances became strained. The British series seemed to have expired rather abruptly and not without a touch of embarrassment. But the next batch of episodes, which began on public television last night initially suggest that Upstairs, Downstairs may be that rare broadcasting phenomenon that recovers nicely after apparent disaster

title: FIRE WRECKS CENTER OF TOWN FOR 3D TIME
description: BEAVERDALE, Pa., Jan. 41 (UPI)For the third time since loll, fire ravaged the center of this tiny mining community today, destroying its business district and causing more than SI million damage.

title: Ford's Backing in Illinois Is Reported to Be Fading
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 President Ford's campaign aides have pictured the Illinois primary on March 16 as the perfect place to recoup from difficult early rounds in New Hampshire arid Florida in the struggle with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination. But the latest soundings from Illinois are not encouraging.

title: Jackson Supporters Stage a Blitz for Delegates Here
description: The 1976 Presidential campaign in New York began to take shape yesterday in 40 motel meeting rooms and political clubhouses, where supporters of Henry M. Jackson gathered to suggest candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Charmed Quarks
description: Basic to science is the assumption that ultimately the universe is not only orderly but in a sense simple as well. Particle physiciststhe researchers concerned with trying to understand the ultimate nature and construction of matterhave been plagued for many years, however, by a plethora of particles ranging from simple electrons to protons, muons, kaons, neutrinos, pions.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A malfunctioning furnace was blamed yesterday for asphyxiating a 2yearold boy and felling his parents in Green Township in Sussex County. The state police at Newton said they were called to the home of Thomas and Chris King in the Lake Tranquility section of the township early Saturday. Troopers said the house was filled with fumes from a faulty furnace. The parents were unconscious and their son, Timmy, was pronounced dead on arrival at Hackettstown Community Hospital, the police said. The Kings were in good condition at the Hackettstown Hospital.

title: U. S. PLANS TO ASK SOVIET TO EXPLAIN ITS ANGOLA POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4The United States plans to ask the Soviet Union whether an ambiguously worded article in Pravda was meant to indicate that Moscow was now ready to work toward ending all foreign interference in Angolan affairs, a senior Administration official said today.

title: An Englishwoman Leads Tourists Through Guatemalan Ruins
description: TIKAL, GuatemalaThree years ago Patricia Marshall, a slight young woman rrom near Stonehenge in England, ventured into the thick jungle here to have a look at the ruins of one of the greatest Mayan cities.

title: Sabres Trounce Soviet Wings, 126
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 4With an unmerciful attack, the Buffalo Sabres routed the Wings of the Soviet today, 126, and registered the first victory for the National Hockey League in the eightgame series with two Russian teams. The N.H.L. now has one victory, two losses and one tie.

title: Books of The Times
description: The ambiguous position of a poet in the Soviet Union in recent times would seem to me to suggest some choice ironies. If is difficult enough to write poetry under ideal conditions, imagine what it must be like with the censoror the secret police reading over your shoulder. How much can a Soviet poet get away with? Is the poem itself a form of political asylum? Is the poet at the live center of his culture, or a merely marginal figure, someone who talks aloud to himself in the street?

title: German Leading In Jump
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 4 (AP)  Jochen Danneberg of East Germany won the skijumping contest on the Olympic run today and took the overall lead from Toni Innauer of Austria. who had a bad first jump, on the third day of the fourhill tournament.

title: Pearson's Prize: A Return to Bowl
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4The lockers in the visitors' dressing room in the Los Angeles Coliseum consist of twoman cubicles, with swinging metal doors, and not more than half a dozen people can squeeze into one at time, especially if some are carrying cameras and microphones and one is still wearing his shoulder pads.

title: Steelers Win, 1610, Reach Super Bowl With Cowboys, 3 77 Victors Over Rams
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4Is it possible for a team to play a perfect game of football? Some say yes, some no.

title: Suspect in Murder of 2 Women Has SexCrime Record
description: RAHWAYState and Federal law enforcement officials say they have identified a prime suspect in the murders of two Bergen County women last fall and that the man is a model graduate of the sexoffender treatment program at the state prison here.

title: Hank Jones Gives Jazz Piano Tunes Sense of Tradition
description: Hank Jones, the jazz pianist, is, at 58 years old, less widely known than his two younger brothers, Thad, the trumpeter and fliigelhornist, 52, and Elvin, the drummer, 49, both of whom have led their own groups for many years. For most of the last two decades, Hank Jones has worked in the relative anonymity of television and recording studios, highly admired by his fellow musicians but relatively unknown to the public.

title: Six States in South Move To Ease Prison Crowding
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 4  Faced with severe overcrowding and a prison population that is growing faster than new prisons can be built, six Southern states have adopted formal or informal programs to ease crowding by releasing inmates early or by accelerating parole.

title: Damaged QE2 in Norfolk With Cruise Passengers
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 4 (AP) The cruise ship Queen Elizabeth 2, her bow slightly damaged after apparently hitting submerged coral, arrived tonight to unload passengers and prepare for an inspection.

title: Josephine Forrestal Dead; Defense Secretary's Widow
description: Josephine Ogden Forrestal, widow of James V. Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense, died Saturday in Newport (R.I.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Newport.

title: 1,300 Form Human Chain To Mark the Bicentennial
description: CHERRY HILL. N. J., Jan. 4Their hands linked. some 1.300 people formed segments of a Bicentennial chain here today.

title: CORRECTIONS

Actually, Mr. Tierno Galvn gave that description of Mr. Fraga.

title: Kings Stop Loss Streak At 11 With 9886 Victory

description: BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 4 (AP) Policemen waved nightsticks and parked jeeps in the path of 5,500 demonstrators today to prevent their petitioning the civil governor for amnesty for Spanish political prisoners.

description: Striking flight attendants at National Airlines overwhelmingly accepted a 46month contract yesterday, ending one of the longest shutdowns in domestic aviation history.

title: State Democratic Chiefs Like Jackson and Humphrey
description: Senators Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota are clearly the most acceptable Democratic Presidential candidates to the New York Democratic establishment despite the current neutral stance of almost all leading New York Democrats from Governor Carey down. The neutrality is designed to buy time so that the New Yorkers can determine how strong Senator Jackson runs in various primary elections, including this state's April 6 Presidential primary.

title: Anderson Wins Tokle Ski Jump
15,000 Mummers Parade
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (UPI)  More than 15,000 plumbers, waiters, policemen, firemen, students and schoolteachers marched today in the city's 75th annual mummers parade, twice postponed because of bad weather. Thousands of cold but smiling onlookers lined South Broad Street to watch them.

title: Clarkson Six Wins Final, 105
description: Clarkson College won its fourth Eastern College Athletic Conference Hockey Festival by crushing the University of Vermont. 105, in the final yesterday before a small but demonstrative crowd of 4,950 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Personal Finance
description: Few aspects of making a will are as important as the naming of an executor. Yet this decision is frequently an afterthoughtmade at the end, rather than at the beginning, of the planning process.

description: Stella F. Rapaport of Scarsdale, widow of Irving S. Rapaport, a lawyer, was married yesterday at her home to Stanley H. Fuld of New York, former Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Gerson D. Cohen and Sheldon Zimmerman.

description: The Newspaper Guild and The New York Post negotiated through the evening and into the early morning in an effort to reach a contract settlement before the union's strike deadline of 6 A.M. today.

title: Ogilvy &
description: As a step toward beefing up its marketing effort, the United States Trust Company of New York, a major force in money management, has retained Ogilvy & Mather as its advertising agency. The business had been at Donald G. Weiss & Company.

description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 4 (AP) Prime Minister Zaid alRifai of Jordan paid a surprise visit to Syria today to press Jordan's moderate stance in Arab strategy talks for the Jan. 12 Mideast debate at the United Nations.

description: The Pittsburgh Steelers and thy Dallas Cowboys won their conference championships yesterday and advanced to the Super Bowl, to he played in Miami on Jan. 18,

description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble, a twoyearold group with venturesome ambitions, moved up from its normal Hudson Street location Saturday night for a concert, eccentrically priced (25 cents a ticket), but mostly enjoyable, in Alice Tully Hall.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4 (UPI)  A new wave of shooting, kidnapping and looting swept Beirut's streets today. After a relatively calm afternoon snipers wounded six persons and gunfire and enplosions ripped through Beirut's eastern suburbs as Moslem and Christian militiamen traded rocket and machinegun fire, the police said.

description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 Neither ice nor subzero weather nor a crunching Oakland defense could stop the Pittsburgh Steelers from their march to the Super Bowl today.

description: AMSTERDAMSylvla G.In cherished and brloved memory of Ma whom I miss very men and will love and remember/always Grandson. John.

title: Bicentennial Law Lectures
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) The Justice Department will sponsor a series of eight Bicentennial lectures on the law and criminal justice through 1976, Atorney General Edward H. Levi announced today. Senior Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals for the second circuit in New York will deliver the first lecture Jan. 29 at Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia.

title: Red Smith
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4John Stallworth is a tall young citizen of Tuscaloosa, Ala., whose second season as a wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers was divided between sick bay and tie job of backing up the more celebrated Lynn Swann. Injuries took him out of the lineup from time to time but he got in often enough to catch four touchdown passes, and one of them was instrumental in putting the Steelers in the American Football Conference championship game here today. It was a 20yard pitch from Terry Bradshaw that Stallworth caught running flag patterndown and in and then out toward the cornerin the eighth game of the year. It beat the Houston Oilers, 2417, with 38 seconds to play, and without that victory Pittsburgh couldn't have finished with 122 record at the top of the A.F.C.'s Central Division. So now it was the fourth quarter of the Steelers match with Oakland for a place in Super Bowl X two weeks hence. Pittsburgh was leading, 107, when Jack Lambert, the Steelers linebacker, recovered 6ne of Oakland's many fumbles, on the Raiders 25yard line. Mr Pittsburgh offensive unit took the field with Stallworth in for Swann, who had taken a knock on the head and was through for the day, at least.

title: Kennedy's Mother Recalls Pledge He Wouldn't Run
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Rose Kennedy has said in a published interview that she extracted a promise from her last surviving son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, that he would not run for President this year.

description: Edward Acevado is a plumber and electrician.

title: Norwegian Is Winner
description: OSLO, Norway. Jan. 4 Oddvar Braa or Norway edged Alexander Jurasov of the Soviet Union by 1 second today in winning the 16.2.kilometer Monolithe cros3country race. Braa was clocked in 50.01 minutes and Jurasov in 50.02.

title: Mike Wilson Wins Run
description: The Wilson twins, Mike and Marvin of the New York Pioneer Club, finished first and third, respectively, yesterday in the Patrick winter sixmile roadrunner series at Central Park. Mike won the event in 30 minutes and I second. Tim Weaver of Fordham was second in 30:04.

description: Doormen shivered at curbs and policemen huddled in doorways. Deckhands on the Staten Island ferry clenched their teeth. Ice skaters in Rockefeller Center and victoria cab drivers in Central Park tried to keep moving. Times Square pretzel venders and massage  parlor leafleteers stomped their feet and swung their arms.

description: Julie Ann Kaufman, a research account executive with Norman, Craig & Kummel Inc., advertising agency, was married at noon yesterday to Walter Niemasik Jr., an antitrust litigator in the Washington office of Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine. New York law firm. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Niemasik of Storrs, Conn.

title: New Zealand Golfer Wins
description: TAURANGA, New Zealand, Jan. 4 (Reuters)John Lister of New Zealand overcame a fivestroke deficit today, then won the New Zealand professional golfers association tournament in a suddendeath playoff with Billy Brask Jr. of the United States. They finished with 17underpar totals of 263.

description: The New Jersey Food Council has predicted that shoppers in 1976 will refrain from buying many frill foods and will instead he sticking to basicsmuch as they did in 1975.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4Until 1830, when the Depot of Charts and Instruments was established here, American seamen navigated their vessels more by instinct and a knowledge of the stars than by the navigational tools that might have been on board.

title: CAREY MAY WIN POINT ON NADJARI
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, indicated to aides yesterday that he would probably appoint the special investigator asked for by Governor Carey to look into allegations that the Governor had moved to dismiss Maurice H. Nadjari because of political pressures.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, which is scheduled to finish its work by Feb. 29, may seek more time to complete drafting legislative guidelines to limit the domestic intelligence activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 4 (UPI)At least 100 guards called in sick or stayed off their jobs at state prisons today, one day before nearly 9,000 state employees were scheduled to stage a job action to press a demand for costofliving bonuses.

title: About New York
description: Caitriona Yeats and her harp were in Carnegie Hall the other day, appearing in something called The Best of Ireland. Nevertheless, Miss Yeats now lives in Brookline, Mass., which is a better place for a harpist to live than Dublin, though not so good a place as New York. For the time being, however, Miss Yeats cannot live in New York. She says it makes her nervous.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)  Senator Roman L. Hruska, Republican of Nebraska, was admitted to Walter Reed Hospital today for surgery scheduled for tomorrow, aides said.. A spokesman for Mr. Hruska said the surgery was not serious.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP)The Christian Science Monitor said in its Monday editions that recruiting and training of Americans in the United States to serve as mercenaries in Angola had come to an abrupt halt.

title: Spain Lets Sick Woman Cross Gibraltar Border
description: GIBRALTAR, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Spain opened its border with Gibraltar last night for the first time in six years to enable a sick West German vacationer to be flown home to Cologne.

description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 4 (Reuters) Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, the heart transplant pioneer, has refined his twinheart operation by introducing a double pacemaker that prevents the two hearts from beating at the same time, he said in a newspaper interview today.

title: ... to Old Problems
description: It is the task of political leadership to define the nation's problems and to offer programs, both immediate and longer range, to cope with those problems. On some issues such as the management of foreign policy, it obviously not possible for Presidential candidates to do more than make clear the trend of their thinking because difficult future choices cannot be made responsibly until the specifics of each situation are known.

title: Latins Threaten to Quit Rights Group
description: The Hispanic member organization of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a multiethnic coalition that has strongly influenced civil rights legislation in recent years, has threatened to quit the leadership conference over what it calls a hypocritical, absurd and inexcusable disregard for Hispanic issues and problems. In a recent letter to Roy Wilkins and Marvin Caplan, the coalition's chairman and executive director, respectively, the National Congress of Hispanic American CitizensEl Congresosaid that if the Hispanic community was not given a full voice in all the affairs and decisions of the conference, it would resign after Jan. 30.

title: Edmondson Wins From Newcombe
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 4 (AP)Unseeded Mark Edmondson of Australia, who was working as a janitor three months ago, defeated the defending champion, John Newcombe, 67, 63, 76, 61, today and, won the men's singles title at the $100,000 Australian open In one of the greatest upsets in tennis history.

title: BISHOP PRAISES CHURCH MERGER

title: Water Spaniel judged Best at Specialty Show
description: The Irish water spaniel is frequently called the clown of the spaniel family. But there was no clowning yesterday, as far as Ch. Oaktree's Irishtocrat was concerned. He was all business when he stood before Clark Thompson, along with 10 other contestants for the title of best at the American Spaniel Club's specialty.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BIG FREEZE The 36th edition of the Ice Capades is due at 7:30 o'clock tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, sailing across the rink for 20 performances through Jan. 18.

title: Quadruplets, All Boys, Born To a Mother of 3 Daughters
description: QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 4 (AP)Quadruplets, all boys, were born late last night to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Kuhn of Ursa, Ill.

title: The Future of SEEK
description: Ever since the City University launched SEEK (Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge) under an enabling act of the State Legislature in 1966, the program has suffered in almost equal measure from the hostility of conservative academic opponents and from the excessive claims of its supporters.

title: Tax Cheats in India Get Amnesty, Pay Up
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 4Indian movie stars, doctors. architects and businessmen stood in long lines before internal revenue offices last week to disclose concealed income and pay up taxes.

title: Steelers 7Point Pick
description: LAS VEGAS, Jan. 4 (UPI)  Oddsmakers made the Pittsburgh Steelers a sevenpoint favorite over the Dallas Cowboys in the Super Bowl X game at Miami Jan. 18 after the Cowboy victory today over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Beanie Scores Court Stay Keeping Village Gate Open
description: Mayor Beame questioned the wisdom and legality yesterday of a decision Saturday by Supreme Court Justice Leonard H. Sandler to stay a Building Department order for the Village Gate cabaret to vacate its premises.

title: Madden Went for Field Goal One Play Late, Davis Says
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 4In the quiet of the Oakland Raiders locker room. Al Davis secondguessed Coach John Madden's strategy that resulted in a 41yard field goal on third down with 17 seconds remaining today in their 1610 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers for the American Football Conference championship.

title: Science Drives to Expand Nature's Nitrogen Output
description: Scientists in many nations are sharply expanding efforts to harness tiny organisms, widely distributed in nature, in order to reduce agriculture's dependence on artificial fertilizers for meeting vast new food requirements in the next quarter century.

title: Rev. Leslie Weatherhead Dies; ExHead of Britain's Methodists
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI)  The Rev. Dr. Leslie D. Weatherhead, one of Britain's leading Methodist preachers, died yesterday at his home in Bexhill, England. He was 82 years old.

title: Slowdown Hits Coast Hospitals Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (UPI) The full impact of a slowdown by Southern California doctors protesting higher malpractice insurance rates was expected to be felt in hospital emergency rooms tomorrow.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Call for Realism at Economists'
description: DALLAS Robert Aaron Gordon has spent most of his life sniping at his fellow economists for one sin or another. But last week, in his address as outgoing president of the American Economic Association, the crusty professor from the University of California at Berkeley attracted his largest audience of the academic lite.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Spain Looking With New Hope to Europe
description: MADRID, Jan. 1  The magic word in Spain now is Europe. It is the goal, the test and the goad, the way national hopes, national politics, even national ego are measured.

title: Explosion Rips a FuelOil Tank On South Brooklyn Waterfront
description: An explosion ripped through an underground fuel tank on the South Brooklyn waterfront last night, touching off a raging fire and spilling thousands of gallons of oil into Gowanus Canal.

title: Potholes in the American Way of Giving
description: The truth of the old saying that money is the source of all evil is not lost on philanthropists. Since the number of those who seek grants greatly exceeds those who get them, the disgruntled outnumber the satisfied, and the disbursement process is a natural target for attack. Yet even after discounting its proclivity to attract criticism, a process that involves an annual distribution of some $26 billion is too important to the nation's social and economic health to be left without close scrutiny.

title: Grain Futures Prices Rise in Heavy Buying
description: Wheat, corn and soybean prices rose sharply yesterday in the first full postholiday session of the new year, following a slow session last Friday as many traders took a fourday weekend.

title: BUJONES'S DANCING LIFTS SHADOWPLAY'
description: The ordinary process of the species is toward a higher form of sentient life, but Antony Tudor suggests that man :nu) ape, rather than the reverse, is also a possibility. The balletIs is elusive Shadowplay. and it was given a powerful reading on Sunday by Fernando Bujones of American Ballet Theater.

title: Otto Herz, Professor of Music And Concert Pianist, Dies at 81
description: Otto Herz, a professor at the Manhattan School of Music and veteran of nearly 5.000 concerts here and throughout Europe, died yesterday at his home, 302 West 79th Street. He turned 81 on New Year's Eve and had remained active at the school until the holiday recess as a coach for vocal literature, preparing young Singers for their debuts.

title: All Is Moss And Confusion
description: Periodically, the conspiracy of lawyers which is government compels ma to think about taxes. I resent this. It is an unjust imposition on my time, energy and such meager intellectual provender as I still have husbanded away in the mental vaults.

title: Carey Meets With Foes of Stock Tax
description: The possibility that Governor Carey will seek the repeal of New York City taxes on both stock and bond transfers has prompted at least one Wall Street brokerage house to hold off serious plans to move out of the city, wellplaced industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
