description: Why on earth should an ambitious young player adopt the stodgy CaroKann defense?

title: State Closing Fish Hatchery
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5 (AP)The Johnstown Fish Hatchery, the smallest of 16 hatcheries operated by the slate, with an annual budget of $35,000, will be closed this month in an economy move by the Department of Environmental Conservation. A spokesman said today that the 100,000 brown and brook trout being raised by the Johnstown facility would be moved to other state hatcheries.

title: SETTLEMENT SET ON VILLAGE GATE
description: City officials and the owners of. the Village Gate reached an agreement yesterday that will permit the Greenwich Village nightclub to remain open while a number of alleged Building Code violations are removed by the management.

title: South African TV Makes Debut;Vorster Is Wary of Its Dangers
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 5 (AP)South Africa joined the television age tonight with its first full nationwide broadcasts after more than a decade of controversy, over the possible corrupting influence of the medium.

title: Office for Aging Gets Head
description: Mrs. Lou Glasse, director of the Dutchess County Office for the Aging, was appointed director of the state Office for the Aging by Governor Carey yesterday. Mrs. Glasse, who is 48 years old and lives in Poughkeepsie. will succeed the acting director. Warren G. Billings, who will return to his position as deputy director. The director salary is $43,050 a year.

title: Soviet Aide Details Plans To Aid Hanoi on Big Scale
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UPI)The Soviet Union plans to grant extensive economic assistance to North Vietnam during the next five years, including cooperation on 40 major construction projects, a Soviet offiCial has said.

title: BOND PRICES RISE ON ACTION BY FED
description: The credit markets moved toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday afternoon, prompted partly by the Federal Reserve's decision to inject money into the banking system. Fixedincome markets opened with prices down slightly from their levels last Friday, began to recover about midday and closed higher. The turnabout took place on moderate trading volume. Traders cited the Fed's decision to negotiate twoday repurchase agreements. an action that pumped reserves into the banking system for a short time. and they also asserted that all the factors that pushed the bond market higher in December were still present.

title: SUMMONS FOUGHT BY CUNNINGHAM IN NADJARI CASE
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, yesterday challenged a subpoena issued by a special state grand jury by asserting that Maurice H. Nadjari had been ousted as the special state prosecutor investigating political and judicial corruption.

title: Chileans Assail Reports That Doctor Was Tortured
description: LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters)Chile characterized a5 completely unfounded and malicious today British charges that Dr. Sheila Cassidy had been torlured or otherwise mistreated while he was detained by Chilean security police in Santiago on Nov. I.

title: Amateur Baseball Has World Unit
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5 (AP)  A new international amateur baseball association, which puts the United States and Cuba in the same league, was created today in the hope or making the sport more popular throughout the world.

title: FORD BARS CUTOFF OF GRAIN TO SOVIET IN ANGOLA DISPUTE
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5President Ford warned again today that continued Soviet intervention in Angola would damage Moscow's broader relations with the United States, but ruled out any withholding of American grain shipments as a retaliatory weapon against the Russians.

title: Two in Symbionese Group Ask Damages
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit on behalf of William and Emily Harris today, demanding $30 million in damages from 24 law enforcement officials who the Harrises say systematically leaked to the news media prejudicial information designed to deny the couple a fair trial.

description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 5The Indian Parliament opened its session today with the Opposition condemning the repression of political rights under the state of emergency and the Government hailing a dramatic effect on the health of the nation.

title: Reagan Opens Campaign For New Hampshire Vote
description: MOULTONBOROUGH, N.H., Jan. 5The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign got under way in earnest today as Ronald Reagan formally opened his attempt to wrest the Republican nomination from President Ford.

description: Every time a magazine with aspirations to true literary merit is born, one is inclined to wince at its probable future and then to wish it well.

description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: A Second Explosion Fans FuelOil Fire in Brooklyn
description: A second explosion erupted yesterday at a series of underground fuel tanks on the South Brooklyn waterfront, injuringi eight firemen and two employees of the Exxon Corporation. The explosion further fanned flames of a fire that had been burning for 18 hours, but with diminishing force, as a result of an explosion Sunday night.

title: Home Sweet Homer Closes
description: Home Sweet Homer, the musical comedy based on Homer's The Odyssey, gave its first and final performance at the Palace Theater on Sunday night. Formerly known as Odyssey, the show starred Yul Brynner.

title: Kissinger Resignation Urged By a Republican Legislator
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (Reu ters)A senior Republican Rep. resentative said today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had lost the confidence of Congress and should resign for the good of the country.

title: Fashion Talent Thrives Outside Mainstream
description: Not all women who enter the fashion arena head for Seventh Avenue. Many are content to carve out a career on the fringes, seeking a means of selfexpression as well as fulfilling a need to work. Besides satisfying their creative drives, they also emlarge the scope of fashion. Gray eyes focus intensely. Black hair waves softly around piquant features, and black cotton smock stops just above the ankles. Legs clad in black stockings are slipped into black flatheel anklestrap shoes.

title: Exodus of Leading Executives Worries Directors of City Hospitals Corporation
description: Directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation have expressed growing concern about top management's leaving the corporation and the apparent difficulty in getting replacements.

title: Either Way It Comes Out Quagmire
description: Gerald Ford and other backers of American intervention in Angola insist that the situation there should be judged on its own merits, and not by reference to what happened in Vietnam. Either way it comes out quagmire.

title: 994 More Job Cuts Proposed by Police
description: The New York City Police Department yesterday proposed cutting an additional 994 jobs next year, the second year of a city austerity drive that already has eliminated 4,211 police jobs.

title: Body of Lord HawHaw To Be Moved to Ireland
description: LONDON, Jan. 5 The Irish authorities have given Heather: Joyce, daughter of William Joyce, who was hanged in 1946 for wartime treason, permission to rebury her father's body in Ireland.

title: I.B.M. Wins Antitrust Suit
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Jan. 5 (Reuters)The International Business Machines Corporation said today that the United States District Court or northern California had ruled in its favor in an antitrust suit brought by Symbolic Control Inc., and awarded I.B.M. its costs. The court said that Symbolic Control, which filed the suit in November 1971, had not been injured.

description: The state's Department of Taxation and Finance moved yesterday to put parirnutueltax funds into interestearning accounts immediately after they are received.

description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 5The Pittsburgh Board of Public Education asked today that the striking teachers union be immediately fined $25,000. plus $19,000 a day for each day it: continues its walkout and $100 a clay for each member oft the union negotiating committee.

title: Public TV Outlook
description: The 252 public television stations in the country are assured of greater independence because President Ford has signed into law a bill that promises Federal funding for the next five years. Although the Public Broadcasting Financing Act will still require periodic appropriations. its passage gives a basis for longterm planning of programs and the development of communications technology for improved dissemination of educational TV and radio broadcasts.

description: LISBON, Jan. 6Parry leadera have reached general agreement on changes in PortugaI's coalition Cabinet after nearly a month of difficult negotiations.

title: Dow Average Up 19.12
description: Stock prices showed their best gains in more than four months yesterday as the Dow Jones industrials raced ahead 19.12 points to finish at 877.83. Trading was heavy. Analysts credited the cessation of taxloss selling for 1975 as one factor behind the advance. Page 43.

title: Essex Prosecutor Is Pressing Inquiry In Biz zrre Slaying
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5The Essex County Prosecutor's office reported today that it was making progress in solving the murder of a Newark man whose dismembered torso was found yesterday in Elizabeth. The head and limbs had been found the day before at two places in Manhattan.

title: Closing of Copper Mines Protested by Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 5 (AP)Almost 5,000 tourists were trapped in the Red Sea resort of Elath today by strikers protesting the closing of copper mines.

description: WASHINGTON  Guaranteed employment and stabilized prices of basic necessities should be two major goals of economic planning. Not only are they important in themselves, but they are needed to create a foundation for solving other national problems.

description: A family tradition going back for generations is kept alive by many of the generous people who annually donate to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. From Marjorie Zimmern of Manhattan came a check for $15 with this covering letter:

title: SEYMOUR GANG, 50, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Seymour Gang, who as principal of public schools in Harlem won recognition a decade ago for carrying out his conviction that all children. could be taught to read at the accepted level for their grade, died Saturday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 50 years old.

description: An ecumenical group of 21 Boston area theologians, teachers and laymen released yesterday a sweeping theological statement that attacks what the group sees as escapist tendencies in recent religious thought and calls on Christians to recognize God's active concerns for the world.

title: Volume of Cars Up 29.8% for 10Day Span
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5The United States automobile industry reported today it sold 189,826 cars in the Dec. 1120 period, up 29.8 percent from the corresponding period of 1974.

title: State Orders Warning On Aerosol Dangers
description: ALBANY, Jan. 5 (AP)Beginning next January, your favorite spray perfume, deodorant or household cleanser may carry a label saying its use could harm the environment.

title: City Reacts to Three Subway Incidents And Reassigns 100 Officers to Evenings
description: The city shifted more than 100 Transit Authority policemen to late evening hours yesterday in reaction to three incidents in a little more than a Week in which subway passengers were terrorized and harassed.

title: CasalsStockton Take Mixed Doubles Crown
description: DALLAS. Jan. 5 (UPI)The team of Dick Stockton and Rosemary Casals took advantage of poor serving by Mark Cox to down the Britisher and his countrywoman virginia Wade, to?? 64, 63. 63, and win the world mixed doubles ??

title: Books of The Times
description: It was almost sufficient to be themselves, but not quite. Like the lions in Trafalgar Square, the great English titles, for the last 100 years, have possessed the lineaments of nobility without the functions. Except, at best, that of representing things that fewer and fewer people cared about.

title: Gunmen in Manila Yield After Holding, Airliner 10 Hours
description: MANILA, Tuesday, Jan. 6A Japan Air Lines plane with 201 passengers was seized yesterday at Manila International Airport by two armed men who surrendered early today after 10 and a half hours.

title: AUBREY RINGLING HALEY
description: SHEPHERD, Mont., Jan. 5 (AP)Aubrey Barlow Ringling Haley, wife of Representative James A. Haley, Democrat of Florida, died Saturday. She was 81 years old.

description: The James Van DerZee Insitute, including about 100000 photographs, negatives and plates by the 89yearold Harlem photographer for whom it is named, will be housed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: John A. Costello Dead; Ireland Prime Minister
description: John A. Costello, who twice served as Prime Minister of Ireland, died yesterday of cancer in a Dublin hospital. He was 84 years old and had been retired from active politics since 1959.

title: MILTON GOODFRIEND, OBSTETRICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Milton Goodfriend, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist who was a past president and chairman of the Bronx County Medical Society, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 65 East 76th Street.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Bowing to high operational costs, the Whitney Museum of American Art will be closed on Mondays beginning Jan. 12. As of next Tuesday, it will also raise its weekday admission fee from $1 to $1.50, the same fee now in effect on weekends.

title: Civil Liberties Union Elects
description: The election of Donald D. Schack. a 47yearold lawyer, as chairman of the board of directors of the New York Civil Liberties Union was announced yesterday. Mr. Schack, a graduate of Williams College and Harvard Law School, has been vice chairman of the civil rights group for nearly 10 yaws, lie succeeds Sheldon Ackley, who served as hoard chairman for 10 years.

Bingham, the fugitive radical attorney, cooperated with law enforcement agents ordered to set up George Jackson.

description: ALBANY, Jan. 5The Governor's office today released details of the 2,590 layoffs that heads of state departments have been ordered to make by next month.

title: New Plan Studied in Elevator Strike
description: Union and management negotiators agreed yesterday to recommend to their members tomorrow a mediator's contract proposals that would end the 11weekold strike by 1,300 electricians who maintain and repair elevators in the metropolitan area.

title: Owners, Players Seek To Settle N.B.A. Suit
description: A toplevel meeting will be held tomorrow in New York in an attempt to reach an outofcourt settlement of the Oscar Robertson law suit. The suit was instituted in 1970 by Robertson on behalf of the National Basketball Association players. It contends that the common draft, the option clause and the N.B.A. equivalent of football's Rozelle rule, which compensates the team a player has left to sign with another, violate antitrust laws. The suit is scheduled to go to trial June 1.

title: Alcoa to Raise Prices On Its Container Stock
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, yesterday announced price increases on the rigid aluminum container stock that is used for beverage cans.

title: STATUTES STUDIED IN LEAK ON C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  The Central Intelligence Agency has asked the Justice Department to determine whether Federal laws were violated in the publication of the identity of Richard S. Welch, the C.I.A. chief of station in Athens who was murdered by gunmen there last month.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Fight Begins Over a Wilkins Successor
description: The expected retirement of Roy Wilkins at the end of this year as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has already touched off a fight within the board of directors over naming his successor.

description: On the first day of business of the Beam administration's third year, two new commissioners were sworn in.

title: JACQUES BISSAT
description: Jacques Bissat, president of the House of Travel Inc., a travel agency, died here Thursday of a heart attack. He was 44 years old and lived at 212 East 48th Street.

title: Soviet Delaying Release Of Ukrainian Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (AP)The release of a Ukrainian dissident mathematician, Leonid Plyushch. from a psychiatric prison hospital has been delayed, dissident sources said today.

This remains the official position of the Organization of African Unityat least until its summit meeting begins in Ethiopia Saturdayand it was also reiterated yesterday by President William R. Tolbert at his inauguration for a new term in Liberia.

title: LOU SHAINMARK, EXHEARST EDITOR
description: Lou Shainmark, a former executive on Hearst newspapers, died yesterday at his home, 2686 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx He was 75 years old.

title: MRS. D. WARREN FISHER
description: C. Elizabeth Pugh Fisher, widow of D. Warren Fisher, la writer, died Sunday at her home, 1075 Park Avenue. She was 87 years old. Mrs. Fisher was married first to Ethan A. Dennison, an architect.

description: BRASILIA, Jan. 5 (UPI)Brazil's militarybacked Government removed two legislators from office today, allegedly for having links with the Communist Party.

title: One of Quadruplets Dies
description: QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 5 (AP)One of the four sons born last Saturday night to Mrs. Eugene Kuhn died early today, a hospital spokesman said. The remaining three boys were reported in good condition. The babies were two months premature. The fant who died, Colin, was the last born and largest of the quadruplets, weighing four pounds 10 ounces at birth. The other boys are Craig, Christopher and Curtis.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday on military personnel and state income taxes, it was erroneously reported that Gen. David C. Jones, the Air Force Chief of Staff, maintains legal residence in South Dakota, which has no state income tax. General Jones, a native of South Dakota, maintains his legal residence in North Dakota, where he paid state taxes on his 1974 income.

title: 2 U.S. Milers to Run for Other Nations
description: Marcel Philippe and Ron Speirs were born and raised in the United States and became athletes devoted to the task of trying to beat other athletes in the mile run. As such both have their minds on the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal.

title: Favorable Economic News Stirs Price Rises on Amex and OT C
description: Favorable economic news and the end of taxloss selling for 1975 helped propel prices upward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in accelerated trading.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: A KEY MONEY BILL LOSES IN TRENTON
Diplomats in Moscow Express Doubt About a Shift on Angola
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 5The Soviet Union has not given any clear public indication that it is willing to reduce its military involvernent in Angola despite hopes in Washington that a commentary in the newspaper Pravda had signaled a softening in position.

title: Stockbroker Gets Pat on the Back
description: Peter Forsythe and Alisabeth E. Jergens Forsythe like their stockbroker, so they did the natural thingthey took ads in four publications to tell the world about him.

title: Cry for Hyman Kaplan
description: When Leo Rosten in 1937 published The Education of H*y*m*a*n K*a*p*l*a*n, the inside story of adult night school classes for immigrants, he created more than a classic of American humor. The hilarious situation cornedy of middleaged newcomers trying to enter the mainstream of society via the schoolbench only sharpened the poignancy of a peculiarly American struggle.

title: Lorraine Franks Is Dead at 58; Director of Boston Opera Guild
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Jan. 5Lorraine Lois Leavitt Franks, a civic leader and trustee of NewtonWellesley Hospital, died here today at the age of 58. She was the wife of Thomas E. Franks, a management consultant in Boston.

title: Bulls Top Rockets On Marin's Basket
JUDGE RESCINDS NEW GAG ORDER
description: NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Jan. 5 (AP)A judge reversed himself today and opened to the press and public jury selection proceedings in a murder trial in which a press gag order has already caused much controversy.

title: Food Labeling Is Tightened
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 5 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that all foods containing fats or oils would have to list on the label exactly what kind of oil or fat was involved.

title: New Riots in Ecuador Halt Transportation in 2 Cities
description: QUITO, Ecuador,  Jan. 5 (Reuters)  Student riots in protest against higher bus fares paralyzed public transportation today in the Ecuadorean capital and in Guayaquil, the country's main port.

title: Indiana Five Victor Over Northwestern
Business Briefs
description: LISBON, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Portugal has sold four metric tons of gold as an experimental measure, the Finance Ministry disclosed today. It was the first time since the overthrow of the old rightwing regime in April, 1974, that Portugal has officially admitted having sold gold.

title: French Decide Hot Dog' Won't Cut the Mustard
description: PARIS, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The Government announced today that beginning in 1977 most foreign words would be barred from advertisements, work contracts, guarantees and other documents under state control.

title: Stormy Days for N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athetic Association will undoubtedly survive what promises to be a stormy convention in St. Louis next week de.spite recent threats to its existence from such men as Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama, Barry Switzer of Oklahoma, Don Canham of Michigan and the 98 coaches in the 1C4A, the major Eastern college track group.

title: London Doubts Angola Bribery Charge
description: LONDON, Jan. 5The British Foreign Office said today that it attaches no credence to allegations by the head of the Liberal Party that Moscow had bribed one or more African leaders to recognize the government set up by Angolan Marxists.

title: Byrne to Honor Jerome Hines
description: The Metropolitan Opera said last night that Governor Byrne had proclaimed today Jerome Hines Day in New Jersey, in honor of the 30th anniversary of Mr. Hines's debut at the Met. Tonight Governor Byrne will present Mr. Hines with a copy of the proclamation, Mr. Hines and his family are residents of South Orange.

title: D. BARNEY. LEFFERTS, MAGAZINE WRITER, 53
description: D. Barney Lefferts, a deskman of The New York Times Magazine from 1956 to 1967 and a magazine writer, died of cancer Sunday in Washington. He was 53 years old.

title: L.I.Youth in Coma Is Ordered Shifted To Nursing Home
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Jan. 5The administration of Southside Hospital today rejected a request by the family of a Long Island youth who has been in a coma for more than a year that he be given continuing intensive care.

title: Helping New York
description: Theodore Roosevelt Jones, known to his colleagues as Teddy, was a common figure in the Times Square area. He had been in and out of prisons. He was continually drunk. And he was, to understate the fact, not very presentablelooking.

title: Weekly Steel Production Climbs to 2,005,000 Tons
description: Steel production rose for the week ended Jan. 3 to 2,005,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with the 1,896,000 tons poured in the preceding week but was down from the 2,451,000 tons produced in the week ended Jan. 3, 1975.

title: A.M.C. Fined $4.2 Million On California Smog Code
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5California fined the American Mottors Corporation $4.2 million today because the company allegedly submitted totally false test reports to the state and unlawfully sold cars that exceeded California's strict automotive pollution control standards.

title: Lebanese Prime Minister Sees a Delay in Election
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that lawlessness would force postponement of parliamentary elections due to be held this spring. He suggested that the mandate of the sitting Parliament be extended.

title: The Northeast Rails
description: Despite the general deterioration in relations between the White House and Congress, a welcome, lastditch effort is being made to reach an accommodation on terms of the Northeast railroad reorganization bill. Though the bill has already cleared both houses, the aim is to head off an otherwise certain veto through advance agreement to amend disputed sections.

title: U.S. Clears Japan of TV Export Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 5 (UPI)The Japanese Government is not subsidizing exports of televisions, radios and other electronics sold in the United States, Assistant Treasury Secretary David R. Macdonald said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Jersey Assembly Defeats a Bill Aimed at Forestalling Cutbacks
description: TRENTON. Jan. 5A lastminute supplemental budget appropriation to forestall cutbacks in Nev Jersey's Medicaid and commuter bus and rail subsidy programs was decisively defeated in the Assembly this evening.

title: FORD WOULD EASE ESTATE TAX RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Ford said today that he would ask Congress to change the tax laws to make it easier to continue family ownership of small and middlesized farms and businesses.

title: New Jersey Adds 100 Days of Racing
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5A bill allowing harness and thoroughbred racing in New Jersey an additional 100 days of racing annually was approved tonight by the State Assembly.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A bank teller who had been dismissed after $300 was discovered missing from a vault charged that the First National State Bank discriminated against minorities by administering liedetector tests. Jacinta Humphrey, 20 years old, of Newark, the only black teller at the bank's Springfield Avenue Branch in Newark, said in a suit filed in Federal Court that it unlawfully administered truth verification tests only to black and minority employees.

title: Fire Damages Textile Plant
description: A textile factory in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn was heavily damaged yesterday by a twoalarm fire. Fire officials. said the ceiling of a building at 429 Third Avenue near Eighth Street collapsed before the blaze could be brought under control. There were no reported injuries and the cause of the blaze was not immediately determined.

title: A Second Explosion Fans FuelOil Fire in Brooklyn
description: A second explosion erupted yesterday at a series of underground fuel tanks on the South Brooklyn waterfront, injuring eight firemen and two employees of the Exxon Corporation. The explosion further fanned flames of a fire that had been burning for 18 hours, but with diminishing force, as a result of an explosion Sunday night.

title: U.S. BANK IS ASKED TO HELP THE STATE
description: With the monthly threat of default by state agencies waxing once again, Governor Carey and other state leaders met yesterday with Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a renewed attempt to obtain Federal credit assistance for the state.

title: No Progress Is Reported In Washington Post Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)  Bargaining between The Washington Post and striking pressmen resumed today, but there was no progress reported. The Post rejected a revised contract demand from the union.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest energy supplier, petitioned the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners for rate increases that would raise its annual revenues $447 million, or 24.71 percent. A board spokesman said that the rate request was the largest ever. It follows three separate approved increases in 1974 and 1975 that totaled $217.8 million.

title: Weather Forecasting Is More Than a Matter of Degree
description: It's 25, said the meteorologist reading the Central Park thermometer needle.

title: Anne Armstrong, a Top Aide to Nixon, Expected to Be Named London Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Ford intends to nominate Anne L. Armstrong, a former White House counselor, to replace Elliot L. Richardson as Ambassador to Britain, a wellplaced Administration official said today.

title: Safety Inspections Rise
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 5 (UPI) The Occupational Safety and Health Administration conducted 2,430 more workplace inspections in October 1975 than in September, the Department of labor said yesterday. There were 6,933 inspections in September and 9,363 in October.

title: Con Ed to Study Brewery Bill
description: Consolidated Edison experts will begin a study of the Rheingold brewery's Brooklyn plant today in an effort to find ways to trim the company's $1.3 million annual electric bill. The bill has been cited as a major factor in Rheingold's plans to consolidate operations at its plant in Orange, N. J.

title: Hawkins Announces Race For Pastore Seat in Senate
description: CRANSTON, R.I, Jan. 5 (AP)  The State Senate majority lender, John P. Hawkins, has announced his candidacy for he United States Senate seat being vacated by John 0. Pasture.

title: Old Lyons Remodels To Cheers and Jeers
description: LYONS, France  While Paris and other major European cities ponder their futures  debating concrete versus green spacethis metropolis in southeastern France is boldly and swiftly ellanging its face with a profusion of towers, tunnels and overpasses, as well as a subway that may or may not be necessary.

title: People in Sports
description: Saying my love for the game is gone, Joe Bugner announced yesterday his retirement from boxing at the age of 25. The former British and European heavyweight champion has not fought since losing a 15round decision to Muhammad Ali in a title fight in Kuala Lumpur in July. He also lost to Ali in a nontitle fight in 1973.

title: FORD WOULD EASE ESTATE TAX RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5President Ford said today that he would ask Congress to change the tax laws to make it easier to continue family ownership of small and middlesized farms and businesses.

title: LILCO RATE PLAN PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: The Federal Energy Adrninis tration proposed yesterday that: the Public Service Commission set up a rate schedule under, which consumers would pay less for electricity used at offpeak periods and penalties for use at peak periods.

title: Cambodia Says New Charter, Hailed by Sihanouk, Is in Effect
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 (Reuters)A new Constitution went into effect in Cambodia today and the country, under Communist rule since last' April, will officially be called Democratic Cambodia, the Phnom Penh radio reported.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: A.C.L.U. FEARS SNAGS IN CURBING SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI)  The American Civil Liberties Union said today that it would be more difficult to control the nation's intelligence agencies than it was to get Richard M. Nixon out of the White House.

title: Turcotte, Cordero Win 4 Each
description: Before the ninth race at Aqueduct yesterday. Ron Turcotte said to Angel Cordero, You win this race. Angel. and you and me will sweup the card. Cordero went out and won the race but Turcotte was slightly off on his calculationsit was a virtual sweep for the pair of talented jockeys. Each had four winners on the ninerace card.

title: MARION H. MILLER, OLYMPIC OFFICER, 71
description: Marion Hellam Miller, the director of procurement for the United States Olympic Committee since 1965, died last Wednesday in New Paltz, N. Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Rizzo Is Silent at 2d Inaugural on Holdiag Tax Line
SovietBacked Force in Angola Reports Seizing a Rival Capital
description: JOHANNESBURG. South Africa, Jan. 5 (Reuters)A major gain in the Angolan civil wail was claimed may by tile nationalist movement that is supported by the Soviet Union.

title: State Employees Protest Cuts With Work Stoppage
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5  Several hundred state employees stayed away from work today to dramatize their demands for restoration of $8 million in salary increments and bonuses cut from the current state budget for reasons of economy.

title: FORD BARS CUTOFF OF GRAIN TO SOVIET IN ANGOLA DISPUTE
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5President Ford warned again today that continued Soviet intervention in Angola would damage Moscow's broader relations with the United States, but ruled out any withholding of American grain shipments as a retaliatory weapon against the Russians.

title: Quake in New Mexico
description: FARMINGTON, N. M., Jan. 5 (AP)An earthquake shook an area in northwest New Mexico, causing minor damage but no injuries, officials said. The Mational Earthquake Information Service of the United States Geological Survey at Golden, Colo., reported that the quake, measuring roughly about 5.0 on the Richter Scale occurred yesterday at 11:23 P.M. about 40 miles southeast or here.

title: Byrd of West Virginia Nears Bid for White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia is getting ready to announce a Democratic Presidential campaign that will concentrate on his home state, but could win him enough delegates to put him in the brokers circle at a closely divided convention.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: 10 Protestants Are Slain As Ulster Violence Grows
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 5Ten Protestant workmen were shot dead tonight southwest of here in an area where five Roman Catholics were killed last night.

title: Windward Passage Leads Race
description: HOBART, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP)The American yacht Windward Passage maintained the lead after two days in a 1,517mile ocean race from here to Auckland, New Zealand. According to a radio message today, the 72footer was 387 miles east of Tasman Island and 11 miles ahead of her rival United States yacht, Kialoa.

title: Reagan Opens Campaign For New Hampshire Vote
description: MOULTONBOROUGH, N.H., Jan. 5The New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign got under way in earnest today as Ronald Reagan formally opened his attempt to wrest the Republican nomination from President Ford.

title: BUJONES'S DANCING LIFTS SHADOWPLAY'
description: The ordinary process of the species is toward a higher form of sentient life. but Antony Tudor suggests that man into ape. rather than the reverse, is also a possibility. The ballet is his elusive Shadowpiay, and it was given a powerful reading on Sunday by Fernando Bujones of American Ballet Theater.

title: Seabrook Farms Plan to End Processing Of Vegetables Is Termed a Disaster'
description: SEABROOK, Jan. 5Farmers, laborers had political leaders said today that the decision by Seabrook Farms to end processing of fresh vegetables here was a disaster for Cumberland County, already suffering from a 17 percent unemployment rate.

title: POLICE IN CHICAGO GET RACIAL QUOTA
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5A Federal judge, in a longawaited action, ordered the Chicago Police Department today to set up racial quotas in the future hiring of police officers.

title: NEW ROCHELLE MAN IS CALLED ART THIEF
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5A New Rochelle man has been indicted on a charge of criminal possession of four of seven paintings valued at more than $500,000 that were stolen from a New York gallery six years ago.

title: Debate Lingers After Beaux Arts Show
description: Few events in the architectural community have excited as much talk as the exhibition The Architecture of the Ecole des Beaux Arts, which was on view until last weekend at the Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition is now dismantled, but the debate it unleashed seems likely to last for some time.

title: Man Is Accused of Using Fire Alarms as Harassment
description: Fire marshal's arrested a 2carold Manhattan man early yesterday and accused him of harassing a former friend. whose identity was withheld, through false alarms that sent fire engines wailing to her home, the Fire Department repoted.

title: 994 MORE JOB CUTS OFFERED BY POLICE
description: The Police Department yesterday proposed cutting an additional 994 jobs next year, the second year of a city austerity drive that already has eliminated 4,211 police jobs.

title: Sears, Roebuck Sets Math for Four Weeks
description: The nation's leading chain store organizations registered sizable sales gains for December, reflecting a resurgence of consumer spending.

title: MAYOR, POLICE CHIEF INDICTED IN MORRIS
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 5Mayor Robert J. Rooney of Mount Arlington, and Police Chief Edmund Secula were indicted here by a Morris County grand jury today on charges that they conspired to cover up the confession of the Mayor's 23yearold son that he set fire to six buildings from December 1973 to June 1974, causing damages estimated at $100,000.

title: C.I.A. Rebuffs Request in Trial For Data on a Hughes Burglary
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5The Central Intelligence Agency refused today to produce in court any information regarding the mysterious burglary of Howard R. Hughes's headquarters in 1974.

title: Advertising
description: For the Buckingham Corporation, importers of Cutty Sark Scotch, Lois, Holland, Callaway created a cute little campaign based on the whiskey's name and label with the theme Don't Give Up the Ship.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday on military personnel and state income taxes, it was erroneously reported that Gen. David C. Jones, the Air Force Chief of Staff, maintains legel residence in South Dakota, which has no state income tax. ?? ?? Jones, a native of South ?? maintains his legal residence in North Dakota, where he paid state taxes on his 1974 income.

title: Notes on People
description: In Boston's Faneuil Hall, Mayor Kevin H. White, inaugurated for his third term, proposed that the city's fivemember school committeecurrently all white and all opposed to busing  be elected from community districts rather than atlarge districts. He characterized some of the antibusing tactics as adolescent temper tantrums.

title: Cousy Is Rehired As Soccer Head
description: Bob Cousy's contract as commissioner of the American Sorter League has been extended, Al Sclavounos, the A. S. L. president, announced yesterday.

title: FOOD STAMP FUNDS FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5Auditors from the Department of Agriculture and Federal and state law enforcement officials are investigating the possible misuse of Federal food stamp money by thousands of credit unions, banks, checkcashing concerns and other establishments that sell food stamps to the public.

title: A Once Lavish Yacht Is Honored On Millionth Mile of Vital Research
description: Although she began her career as the epitome of idle luxurya sailing yacht lavishly furnished with gold faucets. marbletrimmed fireplaces and oriental rugs  the Vema, now completing her millionth mile as a research ship. may have added more to knowledge of the ocean basins than any vessel in history.

title: Rangers Davidson Sidelined 6 Weeks
description: The abyss between the Rangers and Islanders grows. Though both of New York's National Hockey League teams lost Sunday night, the manner in which they lost, the Rangers injury jinx and the Islanders esprit de corps indicate the gap will continue to widen.

title: More Suppression Of Trial Evidence Alleged by Carter
description: Defense lawyers for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artists said yesterday that they had uncovered additional materials supporting their claim that evidence had been suppressed at a triplemurder trial nine years ago.

title: 10 Protestants Are Slain As Ulster Violence Grows
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 5Ten Protestant workmen were shot dead tonight southwest of here in an area where five Roman Catholics were killed last night.

title: Strike at Post Is Averted; Kheel to Draft Settlement
description: A strike threatened at The New York Post was averted yesterday when negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and the paper agreed to have Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator, recommend the best procedures for achieving a settlement.

title: 3 ARE INDICTED HERE IN VISA CONSPIRACY
description: Two Manhattan lawyers and the owner of a midtown employment agency were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of submitting false jobqualification documents to the Immigration and Naturalization Service in an alleged conspiracy to win aliens permanent resident visas.

title: Helping New York
description: Theodore Roosevelt Jones, known to his colleagues as Teddy, was a common figure in the Times Square area. He had been in and out of prisons. He was continually drunk. And he was, to understate the fact, not very presentable looking.

title: TapedOver Shows Get CBS Disclaimer
description: A few years ago, the author of a new book was called for an interview with Mike Wallace on the CBS Radio network and found himself taping answers to questions posed by staff reporter. On the broadcast, however, Mr. Wallace's voice was patched in so that he seemed to be conducting the !interview.

title: Ulster Group Declares It Murdered 10 In Retaliation for Slaying of Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Jan. 6  A group calling itself the South Armagh Republican Action Force claimed responsibility for the machinegunning to death of 10 Protestants last night, saying it was in retaliation for the murder of five Roman Catholic men in two separate incidents in the same Dart of Ulster the night before.

title: MAN IS SOUGHT IN BOMB INQUIRY
description: The police are seeking to question a man in connection with the investigation into the La Guardia Airport bombing who had been interrogatedbut never chargedin bombing inquiries in the 1960's.

title: U.S. Gives Burma Quake Aid
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 6 (UPI)The United States Government has donated $10,000 for repairs to ancient pagodas and shrines damaged by earthqukes in the old capital of Pagan in central Burma. The .donation was handed over to the Burmese Government by ambassador David L. Osborn.

title: The 9 Questioned Deaths
description: Following are the nine patients at Riverdell Hospital whose deaths are the focus of the investigation reopened by Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor:

title: Store Cuts Cuisin art Price But Can't Replenish Stock
description: The Cuisinart food processor is one of the hottest selling home appliances in New York, and most people are paying the manufacturer's suggested retail price of $190.

title: LEON C STOWELL, BUSINESS LEADER
description: Leon C. Stowell, an early leader in the business equipment industry, died Monday evoning in Nev.. Rochelle. N.Y., Hospital, wheic he had undergone surgery a few days learlier. He was 84 years old and lived at 23 Bonnie Briar Lane in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: SOME RULES END FOR OIL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Federal Energy Administration began . peeling away today some of the layers of price regulations imposed on the oil  industry in the last three years. However, with respect to crude oil prices, more complicated regulations have been mandated by Congress.

title: Elizabeth G. Augustus Is Wed To John S. Knight in Florida
description: John S. Knight of Akron. Ohio, and Miami, editorial chairman of the KnightRidder Newspapers. and Elizabeth Good Augustus of Willoughby, Ohio, and Charlottesville, Va., were married yesterday afternoon in Bal Harbour, Fla. The Rev. John Lawrence Yenches performed the ceremony in the Church by the Sea, Congregational.

title: RESTAURATEUR DIES IN A RESCUE EFFORT
description: DELAND, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) A woman who was a coowner of the Ginger Man restaurant in New York was killed yesterday in a futile attempt to pull her 4yearold daughter from the path of an onrushing train.

title: For Angolan Refugees, a Harsh Winter
description: LISBON, Jan. 6  The winter has been cold in Portugal, with near freezing temperatures, but for the refugees from Angola it has seemed even colder.

title: Article 8  No Title
Police Chief Reprieves Flag Patch on Uniform
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6 (AP)  The American flag patches on 600 clty police uniforms won't be stripped off this Bicentennial year as ordered earlier, according to Police Chief Earl Burden.

title: East German Aide in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The East German Foreign Minister, Oskar Fischer, arrived here today on a twoday official visit. He is the highest East German official to visit France since the creation of the Communist state after World War II. France recognized East Germany in February 1973.

title: MOSCOW REBUTS FORD ON ANGOLA
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6The Soviet Government newspaper lzvestia issued a toughly worded rejection today of the recent attacks on its Angola involvement by President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Ohio Tracks Settle Dispute
Trucks Ambush Revives Beirut Fighting
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon. Jan. 6Christian gunmen today ambushed two trucks carrying flour into the blockaded Palestinian refugee camp of Tell Zaatar and surrounding Moslem shantytowns, sparldng sharp clashes in the eastern suburbs of Beirut.

title: Jerome Hines Marks 30 Years at Met
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Jan. 6When neighbors on South Wyoming Avenue look out. their windows and sec Jerome Hines careening along on his bicycle despite the snow, they seldom bother with a second glance.

title: Ice Capades Breezes In
description: With the weather serving as a frosty advance man, the 36th edition of the Ice Capades slid into Madison Square Garden last night, to flash its blades through Jan. 18.

title: Rosenberg Sons Say F.B.I. Bars Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI)  The sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg have charged the Federal Bureau of Investigation with holding back thousands of pages of the Rosenberg spy case records in a willful violation of a court order that most of them be made public, court records showed today.

title: Scholar Is Fined $10,000 In Fraud on Nixon Papers
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 6  Ralph G Newman, a literary appraiser and prominent Lincoln scholar, was fined $10,000 today for his role in backdating Richard M. Nixon's personal papers, giving the then President a $450,000 illegal income tax deduction. with Mr. Newman and tried last October in a separate action in Los Angeles. But the charges against him were dismissed by United States District Judge Warren J. Ferguson on the ground that the conduct of Jay Horowitz, the special Watergate prosecutor who also Served as prosecutor in the Newman trial, had deprived Mr. DeMarco of a fair trial. The Government has appealed.

title: Austrian, 17 Is First in Ski Jumping
description: BISCHOFSHOFEN, Austria,.. Jan. 6 (AP) Toni Innauer,. Austria's main hope for the Winter Olympics next month, won the final event today: of the fourhill ski jumplilg: tournament, but Jochen Dan neberg of East Germany tookoverall honors.

title: YONKERS CHARGED $500,000 BY STATE
description: YONKERS, Jan. 6  State Comptroller Arthur Levitt has surprised and annoyed Yonkers officials by demanding more than $500,000 in interest for $10 million in revenuesharing funds advanced to the city on Nov. 14.

title: 3 Premature Boys Fine
description: QUINCY. Ill., Jan. 6 (AP)  The three remaining quadruplets born here over the weekend were reported in good condition today and are expected to be fed for the first time through the mouth. The boy's mother, Mrs. Eugene Kuhn. 27 years old, of Ursa, was expected to go home tomorrow. Her three premature sons will remain hospitalized at least a month. A fourth son died early yesterday.

title: U.S. Cancels Cuban Baseball Telecast
description: An exhibition baseball series in Havana between allstar teams of the United States and Cuba, which was to have been financed by the sale of television rights to a network, has been called off by the State Department because of Cuba's military involvement in the Angolan civil war against proWestern forces.

title: Nadjari Calls Cunningham A Salesman of Judgeships
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, charged yesterday that Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, was at the center of the corrupt marketplace of judgeships in the Bronx and specifically accused him of selling judgeships, accepting bribes and fixing at least one criminal case.

title: What Can It Make?; SALMON PATE
description: 2 cups cooked, boneless, skinless salmon, (see note)

title: Evidence of Curare Sought in 9 Deaths
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 6The Bergen County Prosecutor has reopened an investigation into whether nine or more patients, including a 4yearold girl and a woman who had just given birth, were murdered over a 10month period in a small osteopathic hospital in Oradell nearly a decade ago.

title: William Blakley of Dallas Dies; Twice Appointed to the Senate
Dr. Bruce P. Webster Dead at 74; ExMedical Director of Time Inc.
description: Dr. Bruce P. Webster, former medical director of Time Inc., died Monday in his home at the age of 74. He lived at 14 Sutton Place South.

title: SEOUL DISCOVERY OF OIL IS REPORTED
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 6 Oil has been found underneath the land area near the Gulf of Yongil on the southeastern coast of South Korea, knowledgeable sources said today.

title: New Law on Divorce In Effect in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP) Hundreds of people have been lining up at special information counters to take advantage of a new divorce law.

title: 4 in Watergate Appeal Say Sirica Barred a Fair Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Lawyers for the four former Nixon Administration officials convicted last year in the Watergate coverup case told the United States Court of Appeals here today that Federal District Judge John J. Sirica had failed in numerous ways to give the defendants a fair trial.

title: Red Smith
description: The flower of American letters, also known as the Baseball Writers Association of America, is engrossed its annual exercise in taxidermy, stuffing and mounting obsolete baseball players for the Hall of Fame, The B.B.W.A.A. membership considers only players who were active during the period from 1956 through 1970. Candidates for immortality who packed it in more than 20 years ago are considered by a committee of old crocks who meet around the end of this month. For the nationwide vote, screening committee has reduced the field to 32 eligibles who are trustworthy. loyal. courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty. brave, clean and reverent, served at least 10 years in the major leagues and have not recently been convicted of any ax murders. Even with those qualifications, no entry gets his niche in Cooperstown unless his name appears on 75 percent of the ballots. No such strict guidelines inhibit the codgers. They are free to exhume fossils by whim, and sometimes they do.

title: Mayor of Utica Scores A Point on Water Bill
Reagan Defends His Plan to Cut Budget
description: LITTLETON, N.H., Jan. 6 (AP)  Questions concerning a plan to cut the Federal budget by 1$90 billion continued to haunt Ronald Reagan today.

title: Wm. &
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6A sophomore forward, Frank Sowinski, scored 22 points and Princeton overwhelmed William and Mary, 6443, in college basketball tonight.

title: Hundreds Line Up To Buy New Stamps At U.S. Post Offices
description: Some walked in and walked back ut again. Others reluctantly joined a linue. Throughout the city yesterday, post offices were crowded with people complaining about the wait for stamps.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made pay. able to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Stage: Verbal ReCreation of Dickens
description: Although Emlyn Williams as Charles Dickens, which opened at Town Hall last night for a sixperformance run through Saturday, is not new to these parts, Mr. Williams's series of reading remains as fresh and as refreshing as if it were being done for the first time. Indeed, what the eminent Welsh playwright, actor and author does is less, a reading than a verbal recreation before our very eyes of a whole cluster of Dickensian characters, some grotesque, some caricatures, soine athletic, some repellent, but all full of life, of gusto.

title: To Lift Midwinter Spirits, a Note of Fun in New Designs
description: Pleated culottes to stroll down the street in.

title: Coal Study in Montana Scored; Conflict of Interest Is Charged
Pittsburgh Classes End as Teachers Defy Court Order
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Board of Education canceled classes indefinitely for 62,000 students.today because of the refusal of 4,400 striking teachers and aides to obey a backtowork court order.

title: Jacobsen Trial Is Delayed On Double Jeopardy Plea
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., Jan. (UPI)  A state district judge delayed today until March 22 the theft trial of Jake Jacobsen, a former lobbyist for Associated Milk Producers Inc.

title: ELEPHANT'S MEMORY IN A CHANGE OF PACE
description: Elephant's Memory, a group that formerly attained notoriety as a backup band for John Lennon after the Beatles broke up, appeared on Monday at The Other End club, 149 Bleecker Street, with fewer members and much broader musical horizons.

title: THAIS END DISPUTE ON RICE PRICE RISE
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj today abandoned plans to raise the price of rice, ending a confrontation with Thailand's trade unions.

title: Church Plans to Enter Primary in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.. Jan. 6 (Reutefn)  Senator Frank Church of Idaho, moving a step closer to entering the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that he planned to enter the June 8 California primary.

title: Stock Prices Soar
description: Stock prices soared yesterday for the second consecutive session in one of the heaviest trading days in history. The Dow Jones industrials climbed 12.99 points to 890.82 on a volume of 31.27 million shares. Page 55.

title: CLASH IS NEARING O I.M.F. LENDING
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 6 A new clash between the ,demands of the world's poorer countries and those of industrial countries over the future lending policy, of the International Monetary Fund shaped up today as the key issue on I the eve of a meeting here of ;20 finance ministers representing all the member countries of the fund.

title: Canadian Education Circles Worry About Ottawa's BudgetCutting Mood
description: OTTAWA, June 6  With the Government in an austerity mood, Canadian educational circles are deeply concerned over the financing of increasingly expensive higher education in the economically critical months ahead.

title: BONDLOSS ACTION SEEN FROM S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission probably will recommend shortly that banking enterprises not be required to write down their holdings of municipal securities against earnings to reflect reduced market values due to the distress of New York City and other municipalities.

title: When Money Talks but Doesn't Shout
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, when Representative John B. Anderson (Illinois Republican) and I introduced a bill in the House of Representatives limiting to $1,000 any contribution to a candidate for Federal office, and providing for matching public funding, I had no thought of running for the Democratic Presidential nomination. That bill became law, the Clean Elections Act of 1974,. and in the last twelve months I have been made acutely aware of its impact.

title: Italian Workers Are Paid to Improve Education
description: ROME, Jan. 6  Two years ago, numerous public schools throughout Italy opened their doors several evenings a week to an musual form of adult education. The students were factory workers and they were being paid to go to school on company time.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Transport of New Jersey has asked a State Superior Court in Newark for permission to increase student bus fares immediately. The bus line petitioned the court block a hearing for Friday by the State Board of public Utility Commissioners.

title: 4, Including Inmate, Held In Murder of Newark Man
description: NEWARK, Jan. 6Four persons, including a convicted murderer who had been on holiday furlough from Rahway State Prison, were arrested today and charged with the slaying of a Newark man whose dismembered body was found in Manhattan and in Elizabeth last weekend. A fifth person was held as a material witness.

title: Reporters Refuse to Enter Courtroom in Nebraska
description: NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Jan. 6 (UPI)  Reporters covering the murder trial of Erwin Charles Simants refused to attend today's court session and avoided making a prior agreement to withhold information developed in the courtroom.

title: Knicks Trounce Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 6 For the first time since Election Night, 1972, after six straight defeats, the New York Knicks won a basketball game at Memorial Coliseum, beating the Portland Trail Blazers, 11297, tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Jailed Chinese Jesuits Said to Get Short Leaves
description: ROME, Jan. 6 (UPI)  Over 120 Chinese Jesuits are believed still living in China, but the Society of Jesus has had definite news of only three of them, according to the Vatican radio.

title: Odds 5050 On Opening Of Olympics
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (UPI)  The Quebec minister in charge of the 1976 Summer Olympics site said today there was a 5050 chance facilities would be ready in time for the July 17 opening day. But he said the odds were improving every week.

title: Soviet Ships Reported Bound for Angola, But Purpose of Mission Is Unclear to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6An informed United States Government source said tonight that a Soviet destroyer, an oiler and a ship for landing tanks were headed in the direction of Angola.

title: Recording Executive Abducted in Paris
description: PARIS, Jan. 6Which one is Mr. Hazan? one of six armed intruders demanded on New Year's Eve, beginning a mysterious kidnapping in which $3.5 million in ransom money went unclaimed for five days.

title: Swiss Bank Reports Accord With S.E.C.
description: GENEVA. Jan. 6 The Swiss Credit Bank said today that it had found a Way nut of its dispute with a Washington Federal court over its refusal to place in the court's custody assets estimated at $150 million to $200 million on deposit with it.

title: C.I.A. IS REPORTED TO GIVE ANTIREDS IN ITALY $6 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Central Intelligence Agency has funneled at least 86 million in secret cash payments to individual antiCommunist political leaders in Italy since Dec. 8 in an effort to prevent further Communist Party gains in national elections there, wellinformed sources said today.

title: Bankers Uncertain OnNewJerseyBonds
description: Investment bankers preparing to bid for $50 million of New Jersey bonds scheduled for sale this morning were not certain last night that they would actually offer to buy the securities today. They were still unsatisfied Credit Credit that the state would disclose as much information they wanted.

title: Islanders Win, 81; 3 Goals for Drouin
JOHN E. ALLEN
description: John E. Allen, who for many years operated a motionpicture film library, died of a heart ailment Friday at his home in Park Ridge, N. J. He was 65 years old.

title: A.C.L.U. Challenges Assertion in Clemency Board's Report That Ford's Amnesty Program Was a Success
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6  The American Civil Liberties Union made public today a copy of the final report of the Presidential Clemency Board for Vietnam war resisters and imme diately challenged the document's assertion that the program had been a success.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY ANGOLAN LEFTISTS WON KEY VICTORY; Northern Drive Is Termed Significant Gain Against One of Rival Factions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Highranking American officials said today that the leftist Luandabased faction in Angola had achieved a significant victory on the northern front over the weekend, but was still on the defensive elsewhere.

title: Long Contract Demanded by Ex Canadien
description: John Ferguson, the former Montreal Canadiens tough defenseman who turned down the Rangers coaching job this season, is expected to become the new general manager, replacing Emile Francis.

title: Business Briefs
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)Massachusetts soon will have review board to ensure that urban banks grant home mortgages to innercity residents, a state official said today. Lola Dickerman, consumer affairs secretary, said the board would combat alleged redlining in older neighborhoods. Redlining is the practice whereby banks supposedly deny mortgages to residents of older city neighborhoods.

title: Carey's Reasons for Ousting Nadjari Obscured by Furor Over His Decision
description: Partly obscured by the furor over Governor Carey's decision to replace Maurice H. Nadjari as the special state anticorruption prosecutor are the reasons the Governor has given for making this move. At an emotional news conference last week, the Governor said he was convinced that Mr. Nadjari had done poorly and that District Attorney Robert M. Morgerrthau of Manhattan, whore he designated to take over the job, would do better in rooting out corruption in the criminaljustice system.

title: Italy's Socialists Pose Threat to Moro Cabinet
description: ROME, Jan. 6 (Reuters)Italy's Socialist Party is expected to withdraw formally its support from Prime Minister Aldo Moro's 13monthold coalition Cabinet tomorrow, touching oft a government crisis that only early general elections may be able to resolve.

title: Advertising
description: While Forbes Magazine's major competitors for advertising are Business Week and Fortune, the three newsweeklies, Time, Newsweek and U.S. News and World Reports are also considered competition because of the audiences they reach.

title: More Are Seeking Second Degrees in Colleges
description: If Lawrence Noriega's patients call him doctor when he graduates from nursing school at the University of Virginia next year, they won't be wrong.

title: Evidence of Curare Sought in 9 Deaths
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 6The Bergen County Prosecutor has reopened an investigation into whether nine or more patients, including a 4yearold girl and a woman who had just given birth, were murdered over a 10month period in a small osteopathic hospital in Oradell nearly a decade ago.

title: Disabled, Hobbled
description: Early in the twentyyear struggle for civil rights it was established that blacks no longer had to go to the back of the bus. But today in most places in the United States, another minority  the physically handicapped can't even get on.

title: Edmondson Emerges as Heir To Australian Tennis Dynasty
description: Suddenly, Australia has again captured the tennis limelight, with a new heir in sight for the ,Rod LayerKen RosewallJohn Newcombe dynasty.

title: Parsons School Finds New Life in Affiliation
description: Five years ago the Parsons School of Design, a major educational force in the shaping of American design, was faced with a difficult choice either declare bank?? or find new sources of income.

title: Brokerage Taken Over
description: Prescott, Ball & Turben, a Cleveland  based brokerage house, announced yesterday that it had taken over Kinkier, Cantor. Pomboy & Company, New York brokerage firm at 485 Madison Avenue. Both are members of the New York Stock Exchange. Paul S. Cantor, a senior partner of Winkler, which has 26 employes, said the firm felt endangered as small firm, although the company was profitable last year. The acquisition is effective Feb. 2.

title: People and Business
description: Inflation causes problems for a lot of people, including those in the accounting profession. Proposing to meet the matter head on, Russell E. Palmer, managing partner of Touche Ross & Company, a major accounting firm, yesterday began a nationwide campaign for adoption of current value accounting. Mr. Palmer said in a statement:

title: Foreign Exchange
description: NEW YORK (AP) exchange In dollars and dollar, New York prices at Tuesday foreign decimals of 2 p.m.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: DEMOCRATIC GAINS FORESEEN IN SPAIN
description: PARIS, Jan. 6At his first press conference appearance outside Spain, the Spanish labor leader Marcelino Camacho said here today that democratic changes would come in a short time in his country because popular pressures were mounting regardless of the Government's plans.

title: MONTE DANIELS
description: Monte Daniels, president of the Miss America Loungewear and Miss Hollywood Loungewear Corporations, both of New York, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 67 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Food Costs Rose Less. During 75
description: With the weektoweek change in food prices relatively stable again, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs studied the price rise in foods for the family table over the last 12 months yesterday and found it was only a fifth of the rise in 1974.

title: REPORTERS TRAVEL IS EASED BY MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (UPI)The Soviet Union, citing full and strict adherence to the Helsinki agreement on EastWest relations, today formally announced an easing of domestic travel restrictions on foreign correspondents living in Moscow.

title: Trenton Leaders to Seek New Plan to Save Medicaid
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6Governor Byrne and legislative leaders today prepared for an attempt on Thursday to enact a supplemental appropriations bill that would restore Medicaid funds and state employee salary increases that have been cut from the state budget.

title: Murder, Continued
description: Five Roman Catholics are shot to death in their County Armagh homes by masked gunmen, presumably belonging to a Protestant underground force. Next day, ten Protestant workers are ordered off a bus in the same Ulster county and gunned to death with automatic weapons, presumably by a faction of the Irish Republican Army. A day later, the British Government rushes another infantry battalion over from England in an effort to curb the killing.

title: Eat Well And Save
description: THE BUDGET GOURMET, By Sylvia Vaughn Thompson, 302 pages, Random House, paperback, $5.95.

title: Dibbs Beats Mayer by 36, 63, 76
description: MONTERREY, Mexico. Jan. 6 (AP) Eddie Dibbs of Miami Beach eliminated Sandy Mayer of Mendham, N.J., 36, 63, 76, today in the $64,000 Serfin Cup tennis tournament: the first World Championship Tennis circuit event.

title: 5 Plead Guilty in Music Industry Study
description: Three members of the Chi Litesa leading rhythm and blues singing quartetthe ownerpresident of a record distributing company and the former program director of an Atlanta radio station all pleaded guilty yesterday to charges resulting from a Federal investigation Of the record industry.

title: People in Sports
description: Mike Thomas, a rare draft choice in a Washington Redskin organization that stresses trades for veterans, was named the National Football Conference rookie of the year by United Press International yesterday. Thomas, a fifthround choice who was Washington's top pick and the 134th player selected, but the Redskins first, received 20 of a possible 39 votes from the UPI panel (three writers from each N.F.C. city). Steve Bartkowski,. Atlanta quarterback and the first player drafted, was next with 16 votes.

title: WALKER WAY
description: Walker Way, a retired Chrysler Corporation executive, died Sunday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 69 years old.

title: Federal Study to Examine Neighborhoods and Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Justice Department plans to spend 6650,000 to find out why stable neighborhoods have less crime than ones where residents frequently move in and out.

title: Hundreds Line Up To Buy New Stamps At U.S. Post Offices
description: Some walked in and walked back out again. Others reluctantly joined a line. Throughout the city yesterday, post off ices were crowded with people complaining about the wait for stamps.

title: Shaping World Economy
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 6  There are two ways of looking at the series of meetings going on here of finance ministers and central bankers from nations all over the world. One is as an economic puzzle with so many interlocking elements that no economist,Thowever brilliant, can say what it all means and what the consequences will be of particular arrangements. The other is as a political struggle among individual nations and blocks of nations, in which the outcomes must be gross and simple, because politics is the game of reducing infinite complexity to yesorno issues.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Daley Seeking Assurances Of End to 75 Fund Freeze
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (UPI) Mayor Richard J. Daley said today that he would comply with a Federal order to hire, on a minority quota system, about 400 persons for the Chicago Police Department.

title: T.W.A. Appoints Meyer To the Post of President
description: Charles E. Meyer Jr., the 47yearold senior vice presidentfinance for Trans World Airlines, was named yesterday as president of the financially beleaguered carrier.

title: Opera: In Place of Sills
description: When Beverly Sills made her longdelayed debut with the Metropolitan Opera last April, it was in Rossini's The Siege of Corinth. An escteric work of uneven quality, it had obviously been chosen to show off the soprano's talents as well as those of her colleague in the cast, the mezzosoprano Shirley Verrett. The opera depended On them for its success, and they had sung all the performances until Monday night.

title: Passaic Mayor Accuses Colleague of Death Threat
description: PASSAIC, Jan. 6  Mayorl Gerald Goldman has filed crimnal charges against the President of the City Council, accusing him of a telephoned, death threat.

title: Malmquist Takes Ski Jump in Trials
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.. Jan. 6 (AP)  Walter Malmquist of Post Mills, Vt., soared 69 and 73 meters today at the Intervale ski jump to win the second jump competition in the trials for the United States Olympic Nordiccombined ski team. Jim Galanes of Brattleboro. Vt. boasted two. 69meter jumps to finish second today and held a commanding totalpoint lead among the 16 competitors vying for spots on the sixmember

title: CONCORDE DEBATE STIRS 2 CAPITALS
description: PARIS, Jan. 6Debate in the United States over whether or not the Concorde supersonic jet should be given landing rights at two American airports has been shrilly cast in Britain and France into an issue of Atlantic political relations.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An estimated $500,000 in deepsea diving equipment was lost and 13 boats were destroyed or damaged in a threealarm fire on City Island in the Bronx last night. Authorities said the fire, of undetermined origin, began in a storage building of the International Underwater Contractors, Inc., shortly after 6 o'clock and spread to the Clipper Marina before it was brought under control at 8 P.M.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills Boy, 4
description: A 4yearold boy, David Figueroa, died yesterday afternoon in a fire in his home at 15 Lincoln Place. in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Firemen arriving at the scene found the boy's body in the kitchen of his family apartment on the second floor of the threestory structure.

title: OilTank Fire on Brooklyn Waterfront Brought Under Control
description: The blaze that raged through a series of huge oil tanks on the South Brooklyn waterfront was finally extinguished yesterday morning after burning for mare than 36 hours. But the Fire Department took no chances as its units worked through the day to prevent a new flareup.

title: MINTURN SEDGWICK, FINANCIAL ADVISER
description: R. Minturn Sedgwick, a Boston financial counselor, died Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 76 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Trainer s Formula: Claimers to Fame
description: William F. (Doc) Schmitt, the trainer of such 1975 stakes winners as Dr. Emil and General Beauregard, was chewing on a long cigar in the clubhouse at Aqueduct yesterday. The 53yearold, 5foot7inch 170pounder is scheduled to saddle Frances Rosenthat's Forest Stream, a distinct outsider, in this afternoon's $35,000 added Rockaway at the Big

title: Healthy New York
description: Health Commissioner Lowell Beilin reminded New Yorkers the other day that, despite the financial crisis, some facts about this city do point in positive directions.

title: Choice of Rothko Executors in Dispute
description: Now that the two children of the late Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, have succeeded in ousting the three executors of his will, the children's lawyers are locked in a dispute over who shall replace the executors.

title: H.E.W. HELD REMISS ON HOSPITAL STAYS
Christmas in Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, Israelioccupied Jordan (UPI)  The Eastern Orthodox churches marked their Christmas eve today with ceremonies at the Basilita of the Nativity, the traditional birthplace of Jesus. The prayers by priests and followers of the Greek Orthodox, Coptic r:nd Syrian Orthodox churcheswhich follow the Julian Calendarcame 13 days after the Christmas date observed by Western churches.

title: Carter Witness Who Recanted Says Defense Aide Bribed Him
description: Alfred Bello, a major prosecution witness in the triple murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and ?? Artis, said in an affidavit filed yesterday that he had been offered a bribe by a defense investigator if he would recant his testimony.

title: Beame Tells Carey Pollution Control Will Suffer if State Stands Fast on Cuts
description: Mayor Beame told Governor Carey yesterday that the city would start dismantling its airpollution control program and dismiss twothirds of the staff unless the state agreed to retreat from a budget economy that, he said, was endangering Federal aid.

title: Treasury Bills Bow on Futures Market, Sharing a GoldTrading Pit
description: Short  term United States Treasury bills made their debut in futures trading on the International Monetary Market yesterday. The I.M.M., which is a part of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, inaugurated the trading in the new contract at 9 A.M. preceded by a talk by the economist Milton Friedman, a professor at the University of Chicago, who stressed the importance ztfree markets.

title: Music: A Legendarily Effulgent Tone
description: The program that Eugene Ormandy conducted at Carnegio Kall on Monday night could hardly have been better chosen for dramatizing the Philadelphia Orchestra's corporate virtuosity and legendarily effulgent tone.

title: New Jobs in Private Sector to Be Carey Priority
description: ALBANY, Jan. 6  Governor Carey, in his annual message to the Legislature tomorrow, will set the creation of jobs in the private sector as his top priority for the coming year, and will plead with businessmen to remain in the state while it works out its fiscal problems, according to aides familiar with the speech.

title: Rangers Drop Francis
description: The New York Rangers dismissed Emile Francis as general manager yesterday but he will retain his position as the hockey club's vice president. Details, Page 21.

title: Britain Adds Ulster Force After Killings
description: LONDON, Jan. 6The British Government announced today that it was sending more than 600 reinforcements to South Armagh, scene of the slaying of 10 Protestants last night.

title: Whom the Gods Would Destroy...
description: PARISOo returning fronia. lengthy trip I am struck by the spread of international doubts concerning the judgment or resolution of the United States as a world power. The point was recently emphasized by the Paris daily, Le Figaro, a serious, highly reputable paper. A frontpage editorial concluded:

title: Marital Status Held Illegal as a Reason To Reject a Tenant
description: Jay Marans, a Brooklyn salesman whose application rent an apartment was rejected because he was separated from his wife, has been awarded $1,460 in what the city's Commission on Human Rights called the first maritalstatus discrimination case to be decid:d in New York State.

title: Guidebook Tells the Father What He Ought to Know to Share His Wife's Pregnancy
description: LONDON  Some men break out with hives. Some lose sleep. Some don't want to think about it all. Some even have stomach cramps.

title: Deprived, Exhibited
description: For reasons beyond my parents control, I entered a large New York facility for the care of the handicapped at the age of eight. I was 30 when I left. Since I am a quadriplegic, I must be assisted with such daily needs as grooming, dressing, getting into and out of bed and going to the bathroom. For people like me the institution becomes the real world. On my infrequent outings I was a visitor in my parents home.

title: U.S. Attorney Cites I. R. S. Undermining
description: NEWARK, Jan. 5United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein charged today that the internal Revenue Service had undermined the prosecution of political corruption by withdrawing I.R.S. agents from investigations into whitecollar crimes of bribery and extortion.

title: Police DecoyVictim Strategy Takes to Subways
description: A scruffy, apparently drunk man with his arm in a sling slumped on the stairs in the IND subway station at Jay StreetBoro Hall in Brooklyn yesterday, a sheaf of dollar bills peeking from a torn pocket.

title: Needed Uplift
description: For more than ten weeks a strike by 1,300 elevator maintenance mechanics has obliged New Yorkers to trudge up and down stairs in an everlengthening list of apartment and office buildings. Hardship to the aged and handicapped has been particularly severe. Even where elevators have continued to operate, anxiety has grown over the absence of routine inspections and repairs.

title: Market Place
description: The fortunes of mutual funds can change dramatically, A. Michael Lipper observed yesterday in his office roughly a stock certificate's throw from Trinity Church in the Wall Street area.

description: Jay Marans, a Brooklyn Salesman whose application rent an apartment was rejected because he was separated from his wife, has been awarded $1,460 in what the city's Commission on Human Rights called the first maritalstatus discrimination case to he decided in New York State.

description: Directors of White Consolidated Industries Inc. increased the dividend to 2212 cents a share from 20 cents. payable March 19 to shareholders of record March 1.
