description: Politics make strange bedfellows.

title: Squires Win As Nets Get 9 Technicals
CORRECTION
description: The day on which the public may enter the Museum of Modern Art on a payasyouwish basis was reported incorrectly in Tuesday's New York Times. The correct day is Tuesday.

title: India Considering Legislation to Reduce Birth Rate
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 7India's Minister of Health and Family Planning warned in Parliament today that if the Government's birth control program did not achieve greater success, we might have to resort to making it a law."

title: Harborless Harbor Gets a New Master
description: EGG HARBOR CITY, Jan. 7 (UPI)  William Weary, who assumes the office of City Harbor Master here tomorrow, says he will not bother trying to find the city's elusive harbor.

title: The Friendly Lion of Flanders
description: He didn't roar. He didn't even growl. About all the Lion of Flanders did was smile and wink. He winks with his left eye, perhaps with more coordination than he throws his left hook. His name is JeanPierre Coopman, a 29yearold sculptor of religious statues who is the Belgian heavyweight champion. That's not much of a title. Only five licensed Belgian heavyweights exist. He has a 243 wonlost record with 15 knockouts. The numbers are more impressive than the names of his opponents. More impressive than his reputation, too. muhammad Ali even called him Cooperman yesterday in Mama Leone's restaurant at a chaotic promotional luncheon for their world heavyweight title fight in San Juan, P.R., on Feb. 20 unless the zookeepers of the world unite to protect an endangered species. Ali's presence created the chaos, not JeanPierre Coopman's debut. Without fluency in English, the Lion of Flanders smiled and winked throughout the minestrone and roast beef. He's a friendly Lion, quite tame with a mane of wavy Drown hair, a thin mustache, long thick sideburns and a pinkcheeked face. In red tie and brown blazer with a Flemish crest, he resembled a lion who had escaped from a prep school instead a gym. His most encouraging reference is a nose that swerves to the left halfway down.

title: H.E.W. Finds Shift From Jobless Pay To Welfare Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 7 (UPI) A shift from unemployment pay to welfare applications has begun to show up in monthly Government statistics.

title: Miss Hamill Takes Lead In U.S. Figure Skating
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. (AP)Dorothy Hamill, eyeing a spot on the Olympic team, took en early lead in the senior women's competition at the national figure skating championships today. She has won the title twice.

title: Nadjari Jury Investigating 3 Bronx Civil Court Judges
description: A special grand jury is now centering its investigation on how three Civil Court judges elected in 1975 obtained their Bronx judgeships. according to political and law enforcement sources.

title: AN S.L.A. SUSPECT TELLS OF FLIGHT
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP)When Thero M. Wheeler, an escaped convict, was identified as a prime suspect in Patricia Hearst's kidnapping, an electronics technician named Bradley Bruce says he read it in the Houston newspapers.

title: Palestinians and Leftist Factions Open an Offensive in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 7 After a bombardment of Christian positions by rockets and mortars, Palestinian guerrillas and their leftist allies today opened an offensive in the eastern suburbs of Beirut, reportedly seizing sections of one small Christian suburb.

title: Housekeeper Found Slain With Boy, 10
description: A 10yearold boy and a 17year  old housekeeper were found dead yesterday. tied to columns in an abandoned. muchvandalized post office building at Northern Boulevard and 45th Street in Long Island City Queens.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard M. Nixon has joined a conservatively oriented political club in Orange County, Calif., it was disclosed yesterday, but a club spokesman said that did not mean that the former President planned soon to reenter nubile life.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ford Says Budget Will Be Under $395 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 President Ford today told his first Cabinet meeting of the new year that his budget for the next fiscal year would be below his $395billion ceiling.

title: Mrs. Peron Back on Job After Rumors of Illness
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 (AP) President Isabel Martinez de Pern was back in her office today, dispelling rumors that she was ill again.

title: A Glance at Predominant Political Parties in Italy
description: ROME, Jan. 7Italy has been governed by the Christian Democratic Party for three decades, but six other major parties vie in elections, normally held every five years. A few tiny groups, most representing linguistic minorities, also have a seat or two in the 630seat Chamber of Deputies and the 315seat Senate. Following is a profile of the predominant parties, with major figures listed alphabetically:

title: Death and Secrecy
description: BOSTON, Jan. 7The murder of Richard S. Welch, Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Athens. was a piece of cowardly terrorism. No past abuse by the C.I.A. can justify random crimes against its officers.

title: VOTERS CAUTIOUS ON REGAN STANDS
description: PLYMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 7.Ronald Regan may be leading President Ford in the Gallup. Poll's national standings, but in his first campaign tour in this state he ran into problems with the canny. cautious New Hampshire voters.

title: To Increase Police Sensitivity On the Plight of Rape Victims
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., A program to make male police officers more aware of the trauma experienced by rape victims has begun here, following a study that found that most such officers are insensitive to the victims needs.

title: H.U.D. Offers Mortgage Aid To Spur LowCost Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) The Department of Housing and Urban Development says it will soon release $3 billion worth of mortgage money at belowcurrent interest rates to spur construction of about 120,000 multifamily housing units.

title: State School Board Passes New Administrative Code
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7The State Board of Education adopted by a vote of 10 to 2 today a comprehensive new administrative code governing virtually all aspects of education in New Jersey's 607 public school districts and giving the Commissioner of Education the power to force compliance by the districts.

title: Ancil Hoffman Dies at 91; Was Max Baer's Manager
description: Ancil Hoffman, the former manager of Max Baer, onetime world heavyweight boxing champion, died yesterday in his home in Sacramento, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: PrimeRate Cut Helps Raise Dow 7.87 in Growing Volume
description: Stock prices continued their advance in heavy volume yesterday is a cut in the prime rate by the Cleveland Trust Company provided fresh impetus for the string of large market gains in 1976.

title: Strip Mine Mystery
description: Elsewhere on this page an official or the American Electric Power Company complains that our recent praise of the landrehabilitation program of a German coalmining concern implies that American mine operators have not shown similar enlightenment. He points out that his own organization, for one, has done an admirable lob in restoring a mined area in southeastern Ohio.

title: Brown Urges California to End Taxes for Low Income Group
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Jan. 7 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. told a joint legislative session today that California would not require new taxes this year and also recommended legislation that would forgive about $50 million in state taxes for lower income groups.

title: Books of The Times
Beer Prices Rise
description: AnheuserBusch, Pabst and Schlitz announced increases in prices for their major brands of beer, with most changes varving by distribution areas. Page 47.

title: Malone and Spirits Iron Out Problems
description: While Moses Malone was settling his contract differences with the Spirits of St. Louis yesterday, National Basketball Association players and owners were planning to return to the bargaining table today in an effort to reach an outofcourt settlement of the Oscar Robertson law suit.

title: People and Business
description: The three top officers of the American Motors Corporation, got small salary increases in the 1975 fiscal year, but lost their bonuses. The company lost $27 million in the year.

title: Kentucky Governor Bars Funds for Louisville Busing
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 7 (AP)Gov. Julian Carroll says there will be no funds in his proposed budget for the next two fiscal years to finance courtordered busing for desegregation in the LouisvilleJefferson County school system.

title: Personal Finance: Added Pension Plan Benefits
description: For pension plans that operate on a calendar year, as most do, a number of provisions of the Federal pension reform legislation enacted in 1974 became effective with the start of the new year.

title: BlazonFlexible Flyer Sues Citicorp and Unit
description: BlazonFlexible Flyer Inc. announced yesterday that it was suing Citicorp and its subsidiary, the First National City Bank, for $10 million. The sled manufacturer charges that the bank forced it last month into Chapter XI proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act by calling in its $1.7 million debt and by refusing to advance it more money.

title: French Government Closes Cambodia's Paris Embassy
description: PARIS, Jan. 7 (Reuters)The French Government has closed and sealed the Cambodian Embassy in Paris and the Ambassador's residence adjoining the Eiffel Tower, officials said today.

title: DR. FRED R. M'CRUMB JR.
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 (AP)Dr. Fred R. McCrumb Jr. a specialist in infectious diseases and an official at the National Institutes of Health, died Monday at University Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in New Market, Md.

title: Advertising
description: At last spring's commencement of Florida International University, the graduates were urged by the university's president to set their goals high and then work to meet those goals.

title: China Hints at a Manned Space Program
description: China published Yesterday the first clear hint that it might have plans for a manned space program.

title: Former I.R.S. Aide Enters Guilty Plea In Tax Fraud Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP)An expensive home, a private plane and seven foreign cars were bought by a former Internal Revenue Service employee who used his knowledge of the agency to get more than $500,000 in illegal tax refunds, the authorities say.

title: GOVERNOR OPENS '76 LEGISLATURE ON AUSTERE NOTE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7With a grim declaration that we have no future if our budget is not truly in balance, Governor Carey today offered the Legislature a program of more spending cuts, possible further increases in taxes and reduced government services.

title: Carey Pledges New Era of Harmony With Business
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7Governor Carey's promise in the his State of the State message today of a new era of harmony between the state's business interests and Its taxation requirements contained a mixture of business boosterism and a caution that leaders of the state's heavily taxed business would have to be patient until the fiscal crisis was resolved.

title: Ecuador's Cabinet Resigns as Strike Cripples Transport
description: QUITO, Ecuador. Jan. 7 (AP)The cabinet of President Guillermo Rodriguez Lara resigned today in the midst of a transport strike that has partly paralyzed his capital for three days.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: SHIVER DETAILS PLAN ON ECONOMY
description: BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP)Sargent Shriver, maintaining that his number one objective as President would be putting Americans to work, has proposed a public job program similar to that run by the Works Progress Administration of the 1930s.

title: The IdeaKillers
description: WASHINGTONEvery leap year, sinister breed of intellectual hit men step to the fore of opinion leadership. They are the IdeaKillers. Their contract is to riddle with ridicule new ideas from political candidates.

title: Where Young Bookworms Can Browse
description: One of the best things about reading is buying the book, choosing one from thousands. Two places that make it especially nice for youngsters to shop are run by schools of education uptown. One is the Teachers College Bookstore, at West 120th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which has set aside an area in the rear of the first floor devoted exclusively to children's books. There are perhaps 10,000 of them there, and a little reading table with little chairs to make oneself comfortable.

title: Elevator Strike Is Settled With a Compromise Pact
description: The 11  week  old elevator strike here ended yesterday when union electricians and their employers accepted compromise recommendations for a new threeyear contract made by the chairman of the State Mediation Board.

title: C.I.A. AID REPORTS EVOKE FORD ANGER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 President Ford was described today as angry about published reports that the Central Intelligence Agency had begun funneling money to antiCommunist politicians in Italy.

title: ProWest Angolan Group Says It Needs U.S. Arms
description: SILVA PORTO, Angola, Jan. 7 (UPI)Leaders of proWestern forces in Angola's civil war said here today that they desperately needed American weapons to combat a new offensive by troops of the Sovietsupported nationalist move ment based at Luanda.

title: Fireman Is Killed In Brooklyn Blaze
description: Frantic efforts by rescuers succeeded yesterday in saving eight of nine firemen who were trapped for up to two and a half hours when commands to abandon a burning supermarket in Brooklyn Heights apparently went unheard and a collapsing floor plunged them into the burning smokefilled basement.

title: CORRECTION
description: The day on which the public may enter the Museum of Modern Art on a payasyouwish basis was roported incorrectly in Tuesday's New York Times. The correct day is Tuesday.

title: Harris Encouraged by Iowa Support of Campaign
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 7 To many politicians, his candidacy seems to be an impossible dream, but as Fred R. Harris bounced across more than 700 miles of Iowa highway in a rented camper this week he seemed to be increasingly confident that his own plan for events leading to a possible Democratic Presidential nomination might be successful.

title: RATES AGAIN DROP FOR SHORT TERM
description: Shortterm rates continued to decline in the Government market yesterday as the Treasury Department announced plans for its first new year. Elsewhere in the credit markets, prices turned mixed in secondary trading in the corporate sector. The Treasury's financing, which was not unexpected in the money market, will amount to a total of $4.5 billion. Of this figure $2.9 billion will be in new money, with the balance refinancing maturing debt.

Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday:

description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY DE RHAM, 70; INSURANCE LEADER
description: Henry Longfellow de Rham, an insurance executive and descendant of an old New York family, died yesterday in Montclair. N.J. He was 70, years old and lived in Montclair.

title: For the Legislature, End Marks Beginning
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7A tired, already  bored Legislature gathered in the Capitol today, back from a special session that had droned on almost until Christmas, and settled into the familiar routine of long periods of oratory.

title: CAREY TO CHANGE CLEMENCY SYSTEM
description: A new system of yearround executive clemency for prisoners wil soon be adopted by Governor Carey to replace the traditional granting of clemency only at Christmas, one of his aides said yesterday.

title: Congressman Asks Delay In OffshoreOil Leasing
description: WILDWOOD, Jan. 7Representative William J. Hughes said today that he would meet Friday with the Secretary of the Interior, Thomas S. Kleppe, to ask that leasing of offshore tracts of Atlantic Ocean land for oil exploration be postponed.

title: 9 LABOR LEADERS QUIT FORD PANEL
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 8Nine labor leaders withdrew today from President Ford's Collective Bargaining Committee in Construction in the aftermath at Mr. Ford's veto of a bill long sought by labor.

title: General Instrument Offers New PointofSale Units
description: The General Instrument Corporation yesterday introduced what it called a fourth generation of electronic pointofsale terminals, intended for major department stores. The two inew units are being produced as the Series 400 UnitoteRegitel system. Various units are priced at $2,920 and $3,650 a unit.

title: Hofstra 87, Merrimack 73
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., (AP)Rich Laurel, a junior forward, scored 17 of his gamehigh 29 points in the second half and led Hofstra to an 8773 victory over Merrimack tonight. Hofstra led by 3836 before Laurel paced the Flying Dutchmen in their secondhalf rally

title: Football Post to Wilson
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Jan. 8 (UPI)Al Wilson, an assistant football coach at Princeton University, was named today head coach at Delaware Valley College. Wilson replaces Tom Shreiner, who resigned last November.

title: First Sighting of Smew On East Coast Reported
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 8 (AP) A severe European storm may have forced a lone male smew to the United States and made it the first bird of that species ever sighted on the East Coast.

title: Curare Test, expected To Take Several Weeks
description: The tests to determine whether a number of patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, N. J., might have been murdered with curare nearly a decade ago should be completed within several weeks, according to the forensic pathologist who will coordinate the tests.

title: LISBON PLEDGES TO CURB PRICES
description: LISBON, Jan. 8The Portuguese Government pledged today to hold down food prices, punish speculators and hoarders and, if necessary, import essential foods.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 16%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The Department of Commerce said today that retail store sales for the week ended Jan. 3 were an estimated $12.03 billion, up 16 percent from $10.3 billion a year earlier. Department store sales for the same week were an estimated $9.8 billion, up 20 percent from the yearearlier $8.2 billion.

title: Reagan's Budget Plan Becoming Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Ronald Reagan's proposal to transfer power from the Federal Government to state and local governments by reducing Federal budget outlays by $90 billion is emerging as the first major issue of the 1976 campaign.

title: Bangladesh To Establish Defense Groups in Villages
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  The Bangladesh Government has announced plans to set up defense groups in more than 60,000 villages to help the police round up criminals and recover illegally held arms.

title: 9 LABOR LEADERS QUIT FORD PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Nine labor leaders withdrew today from President Ford's Collective Bargaining Committee in Construction in the aftermath of Mr. Ford's veto of a bill long sought by labor.

title: Swiss Wins Ski Race For Women
description: MEIRINGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 8 (AP)Bernadette Zurbriggen of Switzerland won the women's downhill today for the second time in the World Cup competition. The race was marked by falls of some of the favorites on the fast and treacherous track.

title: Official Obituary on the Death of Chou
description: TOKYO. Jan. 8 (AID)Following ig the text of the announcement of the death of Prime Minister Chou Enlai, as distributed in English by Hsinhtia, the official Chinese press agency:

title: C.I.A. Seeking to Find Out Who Told About Italian Aid
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 8The Ford Administration and the Central Intelligence Agency are trying informally to find out who leaked the information that the United States planned to funnel money to Italian political partes, according to sources familiar with the events.

PENSION CONTROL BY PANEL IS ASKED
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8Representatives of two state employee groups told a Republican Assembly task force on pension funds today that they would like to see a broadly based committee, rather than just Comptroller Arthur Levitt, invest the funds assets.

title: Hardees and Butter bean Settle Long Island Dispute,
description: ROCKY MOUNT, N.C., Jan. 8 (UPI)Hardees Inc., the fastfood company, said today that it had reached an outofcourt settlement with the Butterbean Corporation, its former partner on Lone Island.

title: P. S. A. L. Loses Date at Garden
description: Plans to stage the Public Schools Athletic League's basketball finals in Madison Square Garden have been cancelled. The P.S.A.L. had hoped to use the Garden on March 6 for its A league, B league and girl's championshins.

title: thou Regarded as Master Organizer of China's Drive to Become a Great Fower
description: Among statesmen of the second half of the 20th century, Chou Enlai, Prime Minister of China for 26 years, was notable for his grasp of world affairs, his sl: ill as a negotiator and his ability to weather the turmoils of Chinese politics.

title: National Book Critics Circle Gives First Awards
description: The National Book Critics Circle, a twoyearold organization of 300 professional book reviewers and book editors, announced yesterday its first annual awards for books written by Americans and published in 1975.

title: Advertising
description: Four years ago Ramon G. Gaulke was transferred to Marsteller in New York from the Chicago office. I was known as a rahrah guy there. he recalled.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES PLYUSHCH RELEASE
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8, (AP)Soviet officialdom broke its public silence today on the case of Leonid Plyushch, the dissident mathematician who is being released from nearly three years of forced treatment in a mental hospital and will then emigrate.

title: TwoTon Yachts in Spotlight
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 8Last season in ocean racing was the year of the One Ton. Vessels of that class, sloops of 36 to 38 feet, won just about everything on the East Coast, including the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit, which was won by Dennis Conner's Stinger.

title: New Jersey Weekly In The Times Sunday
description: A completely reconstituted New Jersey section of The New York Timesto be known as New Jersey Weekly will appear on Sunday.

title: MIRIAM UNDERHILL, MOUNTAIN CLIMBER
Kissinger Said to Warn All on of Angola Danger
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 8Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has told Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel that his country's security could be more jeopardized in the long run by developments in Angola than by the debate on the Middle East next week in the United Nations Security Council, Israeli sources said today.

title: Further Decline to 6% Predicted
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, responding to the recent downward trend in moneymarket interest rates, reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 7 percent from 7 percent.

title: People and Business
description: Donald M. Johnson, president of Aetna Life and Casualty, the nation's largest publicly held insurer, resigned yesterday from the $200,000ayear post and as a director to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Industrial Indemnity Company of San Francisco, a subsidiary of Crum & Forster, a big commercial insurance underwriter. Mr. Johnson, who is 55, had been with Aetna since 1946.

title: About Real Estate
description: A small boy on a tricycle rounded a corner on Fresh Pond Road in the Ridgewood section of Queens one day last week. Just then, Gerald J. Ardito drove by.

Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Jan. 8United States auto plants are scheduled to build 156,591 cars this week, up 35.4 percent from 115,618 in the comparable week of last year. The auto industry resumed production this week after being closed since Dec. 23 for the holidays.

title: S.E,C. INVESTIGATES FRAUD POSSIBILITY IN CITY BOND SALES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  In an unusual move, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had begun a formal investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities.

title: Tuna Fleet Heading South
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 8 (UPI)The United States Pacific tuna fleet has begun to leave for the fishing grounds off the coast of Central and South America, delayed a week by a price dispute with canneries.

First U.S. Treaty With Indian Tribe Found in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (UPI) Tucked among the civil cases of the Louisiana Supreme Court's 1825 term, historians have found a 1790 document signed by George Washington and Thomas Jefferson that defines the secret terms of the first treaty that the United States signed with an Indian tribe.

title: Concert
description: The earliest American composers, including the celebrated William Billings, are generally regarded as talented tunesmiths who turned out strong hymntunes symbolic of the Pilgrim Fathers Calvinistic faith. To some extent this is true, but a few of them went beyond such elementary works to create anthems of extraordinary power. The form may be small, the style without complexity and sophistication compared with what was going on in Europe, but the music has originality and emotional thrust that make it special.

description: For Period ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise Indicated Restated for change to LIFO

title: Former Owner of Sauna Balks At Questions in Quinlan inquiry
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8Donald Trepiccione, 43yearold former owner of a sauna in Morris County, refused today to testify before a grand jury investigating the bruises found on Karen Anne Quinlan's body when she was admitted to a hospital last April.

title: When Pete Rose Sees His Uniform
description: Pete Rose was chatting with a group in the Terrace Room of the Plaza when a tiny replica of Cincinnati's third baseman leaned over a railing just behind him. When do we cat, the 6yearold asked, putting first things first. What's the young man's name? a man asked. Pete Rose Jr., said Pete Rose Sr. If you met him in the lobby he'd say, I'm Pete Rose, the ballplayer's kid. This is the first time he's come along to see me receive an award and loves it. Not for the award but because he's not in school.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An initial public offering of 500,000 common shares of SBE Inc. at $11 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. SEE, which has its headquarters in Watsonville, Calif., designs and markets twoway citizensband radios and other communications equipment.

title: `Little Magazine Gets a Big Boost At Gotham Mart
description: St. Andrews Review is twiceyearly little magazine sponsored by St. Andrews Presbyterian College of Laurinburg, N. C, The enrollment is 600. Like a number of other magazines, little or large, it is in trouble financially, even though its anmial budget runs to a mere $6,000.

title: CoOp City to Have Some Services Cut
description: The stateappointed directors of CoOp City yesterday ordered the sharp curtailment of maintenance, security and other services at the huge Bronx apartment complex because of the sevenmonths resistance of most residents to a 25 percent increase in carrying charges.

title: Pattison, Stockton Reach Columbus Quarterfinals
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP)Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia and Dick Stockton of Dallas posted upsets today in the second round of competition in a $64,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. The victors moved into the quarterfinals.

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS FACE ADDED CUTS
Reagan BudgetCut Table
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Following is a table submitted by Ronald Reagan. along with his own explanatory comments, under which the Federal budget would be cut and responsibility for the eliminated services would be turned over from the Federal Government to the states and local governments. The proposed cuts, totalling $81.9 billion, were made in the budget proposed by President Ford last January. However, according to Mr. Reagan, because budget growth the cuts would exceed $90 billion if the most recent Congressional Budget Committee estimates are approximately accurate. The following figures are in billions.

title: FUTURES TRADING IN MIXED RESULTS
description: Futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade retreated yesterday from early advances to finish mixed for most commodities.

title: Miss Krupsak Settling Into New Albany Role
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8Despite 14 years of work in Albany as a staff aide and a legislator, Mary Anne Krupsak was regarded as a novelty when she took the oath of office as Lieutenant Governor a year ago.

title: 11 CANDIDATES BACK CODE FOR CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI)Common Cause announced today that 11 Presidential candidates, including President Ford. had pledged themselves to to observe the citizen action group's new campaign standards code.

title: GULF AND WESTERN IN GARDEN OFFER
description: Gulf and Western Industries, which now owns 37 percent of the shares of the Madson Squire Garden Corporation, annopnced, yesterday that it is making a tender offer for 500.

title: UNION BACKS STRIKE; UNUSUAL FOR SPAIN
description: MADRID, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Leaders of a Governmentcontrolled trade union tonight publicly backed striking Madrid subway workers who have Ilefled Government demands for them to return to work. It was believed to be the first time that a Governmentcontrolled union has supported a strike.

description: A surge of Christmas and postholiday consumer buying in New York city lifted December volume of seven of the city's largest department stores 8 percent over the comparable period a year earlier. It was the largest monthly sales increase in 16 months.

Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, on intelligencegathering may constitute a free pass to organized crime figures and others seeking to evade or avoid the payment of Federal taxes.

description: The Del Monte Corporation, the world's largest canner of fruits and vegetables, reported yesterday a decline of 19.3 percent in earnings for the second fiscal quarter.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 President Ford's low standing in public opinion polls reflects a failure to communicate the virtues of his Presidency, Mr. Ford's campaign manager said today.

The broadcast, monitored in Tokyo, did not disclose the route of the new pipeline, which presumably carries crude oil from the Taching field in Manchuria to a North Korean refinery.

title: Market Place

description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP)  Gary Winton scored 21 points, 17 in the first half, as Army trounced Kings Point, 7145, tonight.

title: Johnson of Fairleigh Killed in Car Accident
description: Benjamin W. Johnson Jr., a freshman member of the Fairleigh Dickinson University basketball team, was killed early yesterday morning when the car he was driving crashed into a utility pole on New Jersey Route 17 in Carlstadt.

description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market once again yesterday overcame periodic waves of profit taking and finished higher in slightly slower trading.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 8The State Legislature almost failed to meet today, and perhaps it should not have,

title: Take Away Those Preservatives, and How Do Meats Taste
description: Faced with the current controversy over the relative safety or danger of the food preservatives sodium nitrate and sodium nitrite, a growing number of people are forsaking cured meats such as bacon, ham, frankfurters, bologna and salami, corned beef and pastrami.

title: Egyptian Film Series Scheduled at Bleecher
description: Egyptianmade films, a Comparative rarity here, will be represented by eight features to be shown, starting Jan. 13, at the Bleecker Street Cinema, The series will be presented in doublefeature programs to he screened once each Tuesday through Feb. 3, Each film has English subtitles. The opening double bill is The Sin, a drama made in 1965, and The Postman, a 1968 romantic tragedy. Subsequent dual programs include The Sparrow, a 1973 drama, and The Land, a 1969 historical drama; Night of Counting the Years, another historical drama (1969), and 'My Wile and the Dog (1970), a contemporary domestic drama; Night and Bars, a prison drama (1973), and I Want a Solution drama.

title: 20Foot Shark Caught
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 8 (Reuters)A 20foot white shark, of the maneating species featured in the movie Jaws, has been caught and landed near here. It was believed to be the biggest shark caught at False Bay in 30 years.

description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 8 (AP)Michigan paced by freshman, Phil Hubbard, scored an easy 10681 Big Ten basketball victory over Wisconsin tonight.

description: With the new year a new era has opened in public television. Last week, President Ford signed the fiveyear funding bill for public broadcasting that had long been sought by the industry, and yesterday the board of governors of the Public Broadcasting Service confirmed the appointment of Lawrence K. Grossman, a New York advertising executive, as president. of the system's national organization.

description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 8 (Reuters)South Africa's Defense Minister said today that his Government had no intention of changing its policy on Angola.

title: F.B.I. Drops Plans To Search in Dump For Link to Hoffa
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 3 (AP) The Federal authorities decided today to abandon plans to excavate a New Jersey dump in a search for the body of reputed loanshark linked to the investigation of James R. Hoffa's disappearance.

title: Kazuyoshi Akiyama Leads Philharmonic First Time
description: Kazuyoshi Akiyama, the 31yearold Japanese conductor who has been active in this city as conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, faced the New York Philharmonic for the first time last night. His program consisted of Debussy's Iberia, Chopin's E minor Piano Concerto with Gary Graffman as soloist and Honegger's Liturgique Symphony.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: David Shapiro, a teacher earning a $15,000 salary that supports his wife, who's a student, and his 4yearold son, has just lost his eligibility for subsidized day care and is sure he won't be able to afford $50 a week for private day care. He says the tightened state requirements for eligibility have left him caught in the middleclass crunch, and he's confused and angry.

title: Avalanche of New Accessories for the Boatmen
description: An avalanche of electronic products boasting Space Age circuitry and technology plus, in, some cases, digital readout, has captured the imagination, attention, and the pocketbooks of sport fishing enthusiasts across the iand.

title: 3 POLICEMEN SLAIN IN JAMAICAN UNREST
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 8 (AP)Two gunmen opened fire outside the United States Consulate last night. killing one policeman and critically wounding another in the second attack of the day on the mission, the police said today.

title: U. S. LINKING AID TO VOTES AT U. N
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has formally initiated a policy of selecting for cutbacks in American aid those nations that have sided against the United States in votes in the United Nations. In some cases the cutbacks involve food and humanitarian relief.

title: Lagos Rebuked by Washington For Impugning Angola Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The State Department rebuked the Nigerian Government today, accusing it of making unjustified accusations against the United States and of gratuitously impugning American policy in Angola.

title: U.S. Opposes Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8The State Department repeated today that the United States was opposed to any outside interference in Lebanon and was also against any partition of that country into Moslem and Christian areas.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 8Rejecting a final appeal by Governor Byrne, the Democratic majorities in the New Jersey Legislature refused today to act on an incometax measure or pass a supplemental budget appropriation before adjourning their twoyear session this evening.

title: Inco Will Protect Regular Buyers Prices
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada said yesterday that it would offer longterm customers price protection this year if they maintained their quarterly delivery

title: People in Sports
description: Less than two months after he was discharged as head coach of the Jets, Charley Winner found a new job yesterday. Winner, who was dismissed on Nov. 19 after his team had won only two of nine National Football League games, was hired as coach of defensive backs by the Cincinnati Bengals. The announcement was mane by Paul Brown, the general manager, who gave up his job as coach last week, naming Bill Johnson as his replacement.

title: BlueLaw Prosecution Is Limited in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, Jan. 8The Nassau County District Attorney said today that his office would no longer prosecute the owners of food stores or automobile service stations for the sale of any items on Sundays.

title: Senate Candidacy Declared
description: PROVIDENCE. Jan. 8 (AP)State Representative Earl F. Pasbach, Democrat of East Providence. announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat being vacated by John O. Pastore.

description: Dave DeBusschere, the commissioner of the American Basketball Association. has summoned Kevin Loughery, the New York Nets coach, to his office today for a little talk about a league record Loughery set Wednesday night in Virginia.

description: PEKING, Friday, Jan. 9 Chou Enlai, the Prime Minister of China since the Communists assumed power in 1949, died here yesterday of cancer after along illness, it was announced early today. He was 78 years old.

title: word Sets 60c Dividend
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 8 (AP)The Ford Motor Company declared today a firstquarter dividend of 60 cents a share on its common stock payable, March 1 to shareholders of record on Jan. 29. The dividend is the same as that paid in three previous quarters. Ford redticed the dividend from 80 ants to 60 cents in the second quarter of 1975.

title: Reagan's Budget Plan Becoming Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Ronald Reagan's proposal to transfer power from the Federal Government to state and local governments by reducing Federal budget outlays by $90 billion is emerging as the first major issue of the 1976 campaign.

title: MILK COST TO RISE 2C A GALLON FEB, 1
description: TRENTON. Jan. 8The mini mum retail price of milk in New Jersey will rise another 2 cents a gallon, to S1.46. on Feb. 1. according to Woodson W. Moffett Jr., Director of the State Division of Dairy Indus try.

title: Britain Presses a Dual Effort in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Jan. 8The British Government pressed ahead today with its parallel efforts to control violence in Northern Ireland and to devise a longerrange political solution to the problems of the province.

title: MIRIAM UNDERHILL, MOUNTAIN CLIMBER
YONKERS SCHOOLS FACE ADDED CUTS
description: YONKERS, Jan. 8The Yonkers school system learned today that it would have to operate with $2,296,000 less than previously estimated over the next year and a half. This. school officials said, will mean that an additional 175 teachers will have to he dismised.

title: FULL AGREEMENT ON A MONEY PACT REACHED BY I.M.F.
description: KINGSTON, Jan. 8Finance ministers from rich and poor countries reached full agreement tonight on a broad package of world monetary issues.

title: Brazilian Hotel Bookings Canceled After U.N. Vote
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  North American tourist agencies have begun mass cancellations of Brazilian hotel reservations because of the Brazilian vote in the United Nations supporting a resolution mating Zionism with racism.

title: New Plante, Save H.F.A Under Way
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8An interim solution for rescuing the State Housing Finance Agency from default on its maturing shortterm notes is being worked out for next week in Governor Carey's office, officials disclosed today.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed in order of post position Letter designates OTB listing

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Detectives investigating the slaying of two New York City children and their parents teenaged housekeeper said that they were seeking for questioning a tal, thin man with a bushy mustache who had been seen around the youngsters Queens home before the triple murder. A woman neighbor of the victims told the police that the man had come to her home sometime during the week of Christmas, asking questions in English and Spanish about the whereabouts of the parents, Oscar and Yomaira Toro: theri children, Oscar Jr. 10, and Susanna. 5; and the family's livein housekeeper, Liliana 17.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES FRAUD POSSIBILITY IN CITY BOND SALES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  In an unusual move, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had begun a formal investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities.

title: Gold Price at 15Week Low
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 8The price of gold fell sharply in Zurich and London today in substantial selling brought on by uncertainty over the decision of the International Monetary Fund to eliminate gold from the world monetary system. The dollar rose slightly on most European money markets.

title: Oil Tank Blasts May Cause Shortages
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administrator said yesterday that cleaning up the oil spill caused by the oil tank explosions earlier this week in South Brooklyn might cause spot shortages of fuel In the city but that oil was available from other sources.

title: Pawtucket Racing Off
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 8 (AP)  Today's thoroughbred racing card at Narragansett Park was canceled because of a muddy track. The jockeys refused to ride because it's muddy, said John McCarthy, a track spokesman.

description: MOSCOW. Jan 8The Soviet Union said today that it had no warships off the shores of Angola and termed Western reports of special Soviet movements in the area an invention clearly provocative in character.

description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, facing some of her sharpest critics in Parliament today, delivered a spirited defense against their charges that she had steered India on a totalitarian course.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 8 (UPI)Gihby Gilbert, searching for his first tournament victory in nearly six years, shot a sixunderpar 66 today for a oneshot lead over Tom Weiskopf in the first round of the $200,000 Tucson open. The event opened the $9 million, 44event 1976. Professional Golfers Association Tour.

description: Threemonth Treasury bill rates dipped below 5 percent yesterday morning for the first time since last June, and then the Federal Reserve sold some of these shortterm Government

title: BIG BOARD IS NEAR DEAL ON CARLISLE
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it was near agreement for the purchase of Carlisle De Copp and Company. the nation's last remaining oddlot brokerage house.

title: Stocks Rise Again; Prime Is Cut to 7%
description: The stock market continued its strong advance of the new year yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.29 points, to 907,98, finishing at its highest level in 26 months. In five trading days, the bluechip Dow average has climbed 55 points.

title: Nation's Money Supply Rises $2 Billion in Week
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the nation's money supply climbed $2 billion in the latest statement week, resuming the growth that had been interrupted by an unexpected threeweek decline in December.

title: SmallCar Imports Expected to Rise in 76 Despite Domestic Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8The men who led the successful Japanese invasion of the American auto market predicted today that imported car sales would continue to surge ahead this year but that the proportionate inroads they made last year into the American market would probably decline.

title: Music. A Night of Mahler by Thomas
description: Mahler's Ninth Syrr.phony, most mordant of this deathobsessed composer's masterpieces, would not seem to be the most logical work for an extroverted young conductor such as Michael Tilson Thomas to add to his repertory. It is a grimly resigned last statement, and particularly in its astonishing Adagio finale a work of such economy that in a fine performance one is continually forced to think of what a starkly simple matter death is after all.

title: Curbs on Biomedical Tests on Humans Proposed by Panels at Minority Parley
Sholom Aleichem Stories Staged by Elliot Levine
description: To the names of those actors who have established their own stage personaeHal Holbrook, Emlyn Williams, James Whitmore, among othersadd that of Elliot Levine. whose alter ego is that gentle satirist, Sholom Aleichem. Under the title of From Sholom Meichem With Love, Mr. Levine has gathered a fistful of tales, sketches and characterizations and is presenting them, in English, at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, an attractive interior worth visit its own.

title: A VIOLIN COMEBACK BY BEVERLY SOMACH
description: Beverly Somach, a violinist who made her Town Hall debut at the age of 12 and then concertized regularly for a few years, is now making a comeback as a performer after a 10year retirement for marriage and children. Wednesday night she began a threerecital series of programs devoted to Fritz Kreisler at the newly refurbished Kaufmann Concert Hall in the 92d Street Y.

title: Christians Strike Back in Beirut Area
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 8Despite fierce counterattacks through the night, Palestinian guerrillas and their Lebanese Moslem allies appeared today to retain control of a battered Christian suburb that they seized yesterday.

title: Condolences by Waldheim
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. Jan. 8A spokesman said today that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim had telephoned Huang Hua, China's chief representative at the United Nations. to express his deep sympathy over the death of Chou Enlai and to ask Mr. Huang to convey his condolences to the Chinese Government.

title: The Medical Controversy On Nitrates and Nitrites
description: Among the many suspected cancercausing agents in our food, few have achieved the notoriety of sodium nitrate and sodium nitrite, chemicals used in the preservation of smoked fish, and in most cured meats, such as frankfurters, bacon, ham, bologna and salami, corned beef and pastrami.

title: LIBYANS OCCUPY EMBASSY IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Jan. 8Libyan students from Cairo universities occupied their Government's Embassy here today, saying that Libyan policemen killed as many as 10 students during a demonstration in Benghazi, Libya's second city, on Sunday and Monday.

title: Bridge:
description: All experienced players know that intermediate cards are often of great value. Some systems count tens as a half point, and nines, eights and sevens are not to be sneezed at. One novel with a bridge theme actually described an impractical valuation system in which all the spot cards are added, giving 416 points in the deck.

title: Large Meeting in Peking Held Alter Chou's Death
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 9Foreign diplomats in Peking reported yesterday that there was a large gathering in the Great Hall of the People following the death of Prime Minister Chou Enlai, touching off specillation that China's leaders may have already begun discussions on filling the vacancies created by his death.

title: Italian Takes Downhill; Cindy Nelson Wins Title
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (UPI)Herbert Plank of Italy swept down the icy course at speeds reaching 80 miles an hour today and upset the World Cup champion, Franz Klammer of Austria, by onefifth of a second in the first of two downhill races scheduled at the Lauberhorn track.

title: Anon Ends Talks in U.S. on Preparing Stand for the U.N. Debate on the Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel concluded three days of highlevel consultations with American officials today after having apparently reached agreement on some major principles that should govern next week's debate on the Middle East in the United Nations Security Council.

title: Baseball Giants Sold To Group in Toronto
Bearne Is a Mourner at Fireman's Funeral
description: This poem by the 9yearold son of Charles Sanchez, a 33yearold fireman who was killed last Wednesday in a Brooklyn supermarket fire, was read yesterday at the funeral.

title: Retail Sales in the Nation Soared 3.4% in December
description: The nation's retail sales in December rose 3.4 percent, the largest monthly advance in 29 months, the Commerce Department announced in Washington yesterday.

title: Schools and Seniority
description: In overturning the Board of Education's present seniority guidelines for layoffs dictated by budget cuts, State Supreme Court Justice Frank J. Pino has issued ruling that could throw the school system into turmoil.

title: Dow Pushes Ahead 3.15 Trading Is Active
description: Former glamour issues moved ahead in active trading yesterday as the stock market extended its spectacular gains of the first trading week of 1976 despite the weighty pressures of profit taking.

title: Bomb Threat Shuts Airport
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan.9 A bomb threat forced evacuation of the Albuquerque International Airport and delayed flights for more than an hour. Airport security services and four dogs trained to locate explosives searched the terminal and grounds on Wednesday. No explosives were found.

title: City Offers Incentive Plan To Increase Employment
description: Lower realestate taxes and lower rents on cityowned land were offered by Mayor Beanie yesterday to businessmen who make largescale capital investments creating new jobs in New York.

title: Princeton Stops Harvard, 62 57
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Jan. 9 Harvard's comeback fell short tonight as Armond Hill of Princeton hit two foul shots in the closing seconds to preserve the Tigers 62.57 Ivy League victory.

title: Smallest Cotton Crop Since 67 Expected
description: The cotton harvest, which began Aug. 1, will yield the smallest crop since 1967, the Department of Agriculture said yesterday. The department estimated that the yield would amount to 8.3 million bales, down 2 percent from the forecast made a month ago, and 28 percent below the 1974 harvest.

title: Stage: Runner Stumbles
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Milan Stitt's play The Runner Stumbles, which is having its world premiere with the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford, is an absolutely fascinating play that has had a strange history. It has been done here and there in workshops, it even started as a project at the Yale Drama School, and one wonders whether even now the play has found its final form. No matter, it is still, pretty impressive. Indeed, it is one of the best first plays I have seen in a long time.

title: `Exotic Liberals, UltraElitists Are Wallace Targets in Boston
description: BOSTON Jan. 9  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama brought his 1976 Presidential campaign to Boston today, preaching the old time antiWashington religion in an attempt to exploit this city's strong sentiment against courtordered pupil busing.

title: Honest Pleasure HeadsDream List
description: Kenny Noe, New York's racing secretary, came up with a dead heat of 243 horses yesterday, but he had to assign top weight of 126 Hounds to Honest Pleasure

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TAVERN TIME Three new revivals of works by two famed American playwrights have something in common besides Off Off Broadway: salt air. Tennessee Williams's Small Craft Warnings. one of his more recent ventures, is set in a California coastal bar. The fourth and final segment of Eugene O'Neill's The Long Voyage Home, which has been staged here at least twice in recent seasons, is also set in a bar, sailor's port hangout.

title: Assemblyman Gets 9 Months And Is Fined for Taking Graft
description: ELIZABETH, Jan. 9 (UPI)Assemblyman Arnold D'Ambrosa, Democrat of Union County, was fined $4,000 and sentenced to nine months in the Union County Jail after pleading guilty to charges of embezzlement, bribery, perjury and misconduct.

title: Mrs. Peron Pledges to Defeat Nation's LeftWing Guerrillas
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9President Isabel Martinez de Perdn, in her first major public speech since an Air Force revolt last month, told 700 new military officers today that the Government was committed to the defeat of leftwing subversion in Argentina.

title: F.D.A. AGAIN ASKS FOR A BAN ON DES
Yonkers Will Reinstate Its Listed City Manager,
RECRUITS QUALITY DISTURBS MARINES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The overall quality of the United States Marine Corps has been decreasing, resulting in discipline problems and higher than average rates of drug use and desertion, according to a report the corps has sent to congress. One cause was the end of the draft, the report said.

title: Roche Gets 3Set Shutout
description: HOBART, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP)Tony Roche of Australia equaled the most onesided Davis Cup match on record today when he overwhelmed Atet Wiyono of Indonesia, 60, 60, 60, and helped his country take a 20 lead in the threeoffivematch Eastern Zone tennis semifinal.

title: ILAWYERS REFUSE ROLE IN STUDYING NADJARI CHARGES
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, has been turned down by a dozen prominent lawyers he has asked to investigate assertions by Maurice H. Nadjari that the Governor acted to dismiss the special state prosecutor because of political pressures.

title: 2 UPSTATE MAYORS ENDORSE JACKSON
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 9The Mayors of two major upstate cities endorsed Senator Henry M. Jackson's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomin ation today.

title: London Stocks Boom
description: LONDON, Jan. 9While the New York stock market continued its strong advance, the London stock market, the biggest in Europe and recently the world's most depressed, leaped over an exhilarating peak today.

title: The Forager
description: Nine years ago, I made a trip with Eucil Gibbons, partly by canoe, partly with backpacks, on the Susquehanna River and the Appalachian Trail. The provisions we started off with included no food, except some black walnuts and some hickory nuts. We were gone a week, and what we lived on was Euell's expertise, his extraordinary knowledge of edible wild plants. We killed neither game nor fish. Instead, we ate the riverbank and drank its teasdock, burdock, chicory, chickweed, winter cress, sheep sorrel, peppergrass, catnip, oyster mushrooms, groundnuts, spearmint, pennyroyalnone of which I would have recognized or known how to prepare.

title: Portugal Moves to Appease Farmers
description: LISBON, Jan. 9Portugal's Minister of Agriculture presented new guidelines for the controversial agrarianreform program today in an apparent move to appease the owners of small and medium farms.

title: MixUp in Mailing Sends Consumers To Wrong Parleys
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Several thousand persons invited to attend regional hearings on President Ford's pro posals to make Government departments more responsive to consumers wound up being asked to the wrong meetings.

title: CORRECTION
description: in an Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times of Dec. 18, it was erroneously reported that an oil spill near San Juan, P. R, involved a barge owned by the Sun Oil Company. The barge was owned by Domar Inc, a Mississippi concern, and was being towed by a tugboat of the Port San Juan Towing Company. The barge was carrying Sun Oil products.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 51876, by Triangle Publication. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday, Jan. 9. Seventh day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Court Enjoins Rheingold From Closing Plant Here
description: Justice Frank Composto of Supreme Court in Brooklyn signed a temporary order yesterday restraining the Rheingold brewery and the Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation from doing anything to close down their Brooklyn plant I pending a hearing next Tuesday.

title: Cleaver's Bail Set at $100,000; Case Is Continued for 30 Days
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 9Eldridge Cleaver, the former Black Panther Party leader,p made his first court appearance here today since his return to the United States last November after seven years abroad as a fugitive.

title: Gov. Grasso Rules Out Funds For Ramps to Dog Track
description: HARTFORD (UPI)Gov. Ella T. Grasso says Connecticut's taxpayers will not be asked to pay for highway ramps connecting the Plainfield dog track with part of the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: Thomas Paine, Radical of 1776, Honored Belatedly by City Fathers

title: Cliacometti's Work on View at Sidney Janis Gallery
description: There was a peculiar poignancy about the death (10 years ago tomorrow) of Alberto Giacometti. That he had not long to live was well known; he was loved not only for his art but also for the purity and integrity that he brought to human dealings. Giacometti was so patently not out for himself, not out for money, not out for celebrity, not out for anything but the right to carry on with his work in the conditions that he had always known. Those conditions comprised a lodging that was barely more than a hovel, a mode of life that was absolutely private and a lifelong belief that in art the artist is dealt a losing hand and must get on with it as best he

title: Books of The Times
description: The engineer in our culture, says Samuel C. Florman, has been demoted from hero to scapegoat. It seems only yesterday that he was delivering workers and housewives from drudgery with laborsaving machines. He designed trains, ocean liners and airplanes that enabled evergreater numbers of people to see the world. He provided inexpensive cars for picnics, sightseeing and weekend trips to the country. In 1895, a leading engineer described the men of his profession as the priests of a new epoch, without superstition. Engineers were magicians who brought fertility to arid areas, who built breathtaking bridges and skyscrapers, who put man on the moon.

SANFORD TAKES REST IN DURHAM HOSPITAL
Lina Wertmuller's Comedy of Foibles
description: It is late at night in the Milan tenement. Adelina, a pretty, conventional country girl newly moved to the city and quickly urbanized, finds herself fighting off the advances of her Sicilian fianc, Carletto. Carletto wants to marry Adelina but she thinks they should wait. After all, she has told him on more than one occasion, they haven't enough money for all those things he doesn't even know they need yet, like plastic flowers.On this particular night, Carletto, a good sort really, has let his passion overcome his patience. He attacks. Frontally. They wrestle. He tugs at her bodystocking. She cries and kicks. He gets hopelessly tangled in underclothes. Finally they topple over in such a way that Adelina must decide  very quicklywhether to save her virginity or her new TV set.It's a crucial, hilarious moment, and one that is integral to the kind of social-political-sexual comedies that Lina Wertmuller, the brilliant Italian director, seems to have a corner on these days.The scene is from "All Screwed Up," Miss Wertmuller's 1973 comedy that opened yesterday at the Eastside Cinema. "All Screwed Up," a witlessly slangy reworking of the Italian title (which is literally translated as "All in Order, Nothing in Place"), was made just after "Love and Anarchy" and just before "Swept Away."In many details it seems less polished, less cohesive than either of those two films, but that may simply be because its narrative scope is broader and its concerns less delicately expressed. It's a noisy, angry, relentlessly paced comedy that leaves one exhausted. Miss Wertmuller is a risk-taker, which creates a certain amount of tension in the audience. Will she or won't she pull it off?She sometimes underscores her points in blunt ways that would be avoided by a director more conscious  or more fearfulof the refinements of film criticism. She appears to be saying to hell with all that, as long as the point is effectively made. Watching "All Screwed Up" is to be witness to a giant talent that won't be cut down to size by apprehensions of whether or not something is in good taste."All Screwed Up" is the often exuberantly funny tale about the often tragic adventures of a group of young country people who have come to Milan to make their fortunes. In addition to Adelina and Carletto there are Gigi, who drifts into a life of small crime (he becomes the sort of burglar who neatly folds the shirts as he ransacks a bureau drawer), Isotta, who becomes a street walker, and Sante and Mariuccia, who marry in bliss and, in two years, are something less than blessed with seven children (one set of twins followed by quintuplets).Though the characters in the forefront are fully realized, Miss Wertmuller's fundamental interest is obviously in the society they inhabit, in the endless and usually fruitless pursuit of work and money and appliances. The film is not a polemic, however. It recognizes that there are no easy answers to social, political and sexual questions. Instead the film is fascinated and amazed that, given the odds against them, these people manage to survive at all."All Screwed Up" juxtaposes contradictory scenes with occasionally breathtaking effect, as when Miss Wertmuller cuts from the silly, self-absorbed conversation of two young women to what amounts to a ballet by the workers in a slaughter-house as they skin and grade sides of beef.At her best, Miss Wertmuller combines these contradictory effects in a single scene: the beggars outside a butcher shop, when told they are disturbing the customers, answer logically that the meat is disturbing them. It is both too funny and too harsh. Sometimes the hysteria of the characters  so broadly acted they resist easy criticismappears to envelop the film itself, but that, too, is part of the fascination of the film and what the director is up to.There's no doubt about it now: Lina Wertmuller has become one of the major film talents of our day.

Film: Niven as Dracula:Showcase Theaters Get Screen Farce
description: At the end of "Old Dracula," David Niven turns black. To explain why he turns black would give away the machinery of the plot. Probably the makers of "Old Dracula" care about the machinery, since they don't give us much else.We do have David Niven as Count Dracula, proprietor of an up-to-date horror castle into which tours are booked. Besides paying for the castle's upkeep, the tourists are examined in their sleep to see if any has a particularly rare blood type. Dracula's wife died 50 years earlier of anemia, and a transfusion would bring her back. As Mr. Niven explains, it's no fun going to bed each morning in an empty crypt, especially one equipped with a matrimonial double coffin.Does this seem funny? If so, "Old Dracula" will seem funny. If not, it will quickly turn tedious, although I liked the Mark Cross-style portable leather coffin that Dracula takes with him on his travels. It is hard not to have some affection for Mr. Niven: He is beginning to resemble a haunted house himself, but his lineaments remind us of better times even if his lines do not.

'Maisie' and 'Sub Rosa' Shown at Whitney
description: The Whitney Museum's new film program, Babette Mangolte's 58-minute "What Maisie Knew" and Michael Harvey's 12-minute "Sub Rosa," are the sort of works designed to convince you that films are essentially a parasitic art.Miss Mangolte displays a lot of nerve by invoking Henry James's subtle scrupulously complex novel about a rotten world as seen through the eyes of a resilient little girl. If Miss Mangolte's Maisie is the camera, as the director pretends in her program notes, then this little girl is prematurely bent. She sees the world through the viewfinder of an especially dull, film-school student whose friends don't mind making idiots of themselves. The film has nothing to do with James and everything to do with someone wanting to make a film but having no dependably talented impulse."Sub Rosa" is a not unendurable rip-off of Matisse's "Harmony in Red." A female model, in a red dress and red hat, sits in a red room, while the camera slowly moves around her as she quotes some of the master's musings about color ("Do you suppose red has a particular taste?"). I won't give away the ending.

Sketch of Huck Finn Returning to Twain's Home
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 18  Edward Windsor Kemble's original penandink drawing of the character Huckleberry Finn, long given up as lost by Mark Twain enthuSiasts. has turned up in Chappaqua, N. Y., and is being donated to the Mark Twain Memorial in Hartford, where ii will he displayed in the extravagant old house the author built here a hundred years ago.

title: Soviet Press View of U.S. Life Is a Mosaic
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18On an inside page of Pravda several weeks ago, well below such headlines as The Evolution of Socialism and Steadily Along the Leninist Path, there appeared a long article titled, Disillusioned Society. It was not about the Soviet Union, of course. It was about the United States.

title: Fairness for Schools ...
description: At a time when the painful question is not whether municipal spending has been reduced too drastically but rather how much more needs to be cut, it may seem frivolous to discuss legislation in Albany which may any way stay the hand that wields the ax.

title: Arizona Asks High Court Relief  From New Mexico Energy Tax
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18Arizona and New Mexico are engaged in a bitter legal and legislative battle on the question of whether one state has the constitutional right to levy an energy tax on the citizens of another.

title: CARTER AND BAYH FAVORED IN IOWA
description: FORT DODGE, Iowa, Jan. 18 Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia and Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, two country boys grown into Presidential candidates, appeared to hold the lead today on the eve of Iowa's Democratic precinct caucuses.

title: EgyptSyria Feud Blocks Role in Beirut
description: CAIRO, Jan. 18The bitter dispute between Egypt and Syria over the Americansponsored IsraeliEgyptian disengagement agreement of last September is regarded by Arab diplomats as the principal obstacle that prevents Arab governments from taking a concerted stand on the Lebanese crisis and in the United Nations Security Council.

title: City's Rent Rises Outpace Tenant Income Increases
description: A major new Federal study finds that despite rent control and rentstablization programs covering New York City apartments, rents generally have risen here more than three times as fast as tenant incomes over the last five years.

title: Miss Evert Is Upset By Miss Navratilova
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)  Martina Navratilova upset a mistakeprone Chris Evert tonight, 63. 64, and won the first tournament on the 1976 Virginia Slims women's tennis tour.

title: PRIME MINISTER QUITS IN LEBANON; CRISIS INTENSIFIES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Monday, Jan. 19  Prime Minister Rashid Karami, whose latest attempt at a ceasefire in the factional fighting between Moslems and Christians collapsed yesterday, announced last night that he had resigned.

title: Tighter Rule of Economy Is Debated by Canadians
description: OTTAWA. Jan. 18Inflation, Canada's first peacetime wageprice controls, publicservice strikes and remarks by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau have sparked debate among Canadians about the future of the free enterprise system and whether the central Government should wield more power over the economy.

title: Israel Fights Leaks
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved a proposal by Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin that unauthorized publication of diplomatic communications or diplomatic contacts be made punishable by prison terms both for persons who supply the information and for those who report it. Page 9.

description: PARIS, Jan. 18Hitherto unknown compositions by Johann Sebastian Bach have been acquired by the French National Library.

title: WOMAN'S DEATH IS LINKED TO GAG
description: The Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that the cause of an 84yearold woman's death during what the police believe was a holdup attempt was asphyxiation from a gag a robber had placed over her mouth.

title: TV: A FastPaced Super Bowl on CBS
description: Conceding that professional sports have become little more than elaborate television productions. CBS has deliberately moved toward transforming its presentations into entertainments. Robert Wussler, chief of CBS Sports, is convinced that sports fans, like most TV watchers, really want a little glamour in the form of a superstar or big event. His basic prescriptions were on clear display yesterday in the coverage of Super Bowl X.

title: Cunningham at the Crossroads
description: With the investigation of the Democratic state chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, expected to drag on for months, even after such side issues as the validity of Maurice H. Nad jari's subpoena are decided, Democrats are looking to Governor Carey as the final arbiter of Mr. Cunningham's future as state chairman. Some Cunningham supporters are privately fearful that the Governor, who is not known for blind loyalty to subordinates with problems, will ask Mr. Cunningham to step aside either temporarily or permanently to spare the party and the Governor further embarrassment.

title: U.S. Negotiators Seeking New Bases Pact With Spain
description: MADRID, Jan. 18 (AP)An American negotiating team arrived here today for talks with Spanish officials on the continued use of United States military bases in Spain.

title: Cowboy Reputation Worried Rooney
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18 (UPI)Art Rooney, the 74yearold owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers, accepted his second National Football League championship as quietly and gratefully as he did his first a year ago.

title: Cancer Clues Found in HighRisk Study
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 18 Some persons have an extra risk of developing cancer because of their genes, scientists believe, and others because of lifestyle. occupation or even the Place they live.

title: Lottie Lett. 90 Years. Alabama. Never Bed Sick. Gone Now.
description: SMONTGOMERV, Ala. HE DIED. That's what they told me at the country store down the road from the empty house. Four years ago I was driving north on the strip of highway in rural Wilcox County in south Alabama when I saw smoke billowing up into the gray sky. As I passed I saw black woman dipping clothes into black pot under which a fire was smoldering. Within a hundred yards I stopped, turned around, and returned to her.

title: Attack Led by Cubans In Angola Said to Fail
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 18 (AP)ProWestern forces of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola have repulsed an attack north of Luso by leftist forces led by Cuban troops and backed by Soviet tanks and artillery, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Convention Center
description: The arguments about the Convention Center siteand it is an encouraging sign for the city that the project is alive enough to be argued aboutnow focus on location: whether it should be built at Battery Park City or over the Penn Central 34th Street yards. It boils down to money versus merits.

description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 18The overall quality of the nation's environment declined slightly in 1975 despite progress on some fronts, in the judgment of the nation's largest conservation organization.

title: Federal Officials Checking Charges of Substandard Grain on Polish Ship Immobilized in the Mississippi
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18A huge vessel sits idly at anchor about 20 miles up the Mississippi River today, immobilized by charges that her holds contain large amounts of substandard grain that was misgraded by a private inspection agency as No. 3 yellow corn.

title: Louis Resnick, Lawyer, 66, Assistant to V.A. Director
description: Louis H. Resnick, a lawyer and a staff assistant to the director of the Veterans Administration from 1962 until his retirement in 1972, died Friday in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 66 years old and formerly lived in Brooklyn.

title: Article 1  No Title
Youth Found Frozen Upstate
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., .Tan. 18The body of a 17yearold former Eagle Scout was found in the snow in this Buffalo suburb today. The Orchard Park Police Chief, Robert Henning, said that foul play was not suspected and that the teenager, J. Gregory Bray, might have died of exposure. An overnight low of 2 was recorded in the area.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph S. Portash, a former Ocean County Freeholder who earlier this month was reelected Mayor of Manchester Township, is scheduled to go on trial today in Toms River on charges of misconduct in office and unlawfully accepting fees for the performance of his duty. Mr. Portash, former Ocean County Republican chairman, was indicted with the late Robert J. Schmertz. the president of the Boston Celtics basketball team. A New Jersey grand jury accused Mr. Schmertz and the multimilliondollar building concern he headed of paying $31,750 to Mr. Portash between July 1, 1971, and Dec. 31, 1972.

title: Friedrich Hollander, Writer Of Dietrich Love Song, Dies
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Jan. 18 (AP)Friedrich Hollander, composer of Falling in Love Again, the song Marlene Dietrich made famous in the film The Blue Angel, died here today. He was 79 years old.

title: Screen: French 'Slap':Daughter Grows Away From Her Father
description: There are sparks of humor and style in this new French film, but they gutter out like short birthday candles in thick frosting.Like many weak movies whose virtues exist without redeeming them, "The Slap" starts out well. A study of an unquiet father and a daughter who is growing up and away from him, it quickly establishes its characters, their wry if unoriginal predicament and our interest in what happens to them. Unfortunately, nothing much does.The father is a professor, a man whose considerable fire is banked by a determined conformity. His wife has left him years before; he keeps a respectable mistress, plays vigorous soccer on weekends, and takes care of his 18-year-old daughter.Both father and daughter have the crises appropriate to their seasons. The father's repressed rebelliousness flares up when he sees a student beaten by two policemen. He scuffles with them, is arrested and threatened with disciplinary action by the education authorities, and submits his resignation.His daughter wants to leave home and move in with her boyfriend, is forbidden to, rebels, submits, fails her exams, runs off with a new boyfriend. As the film plods along, with endless coming and going and telephoning and arguing and changing of minds, the two crises gradually erode.The daughter's rebelliousness matures into real independence. The father's professional difficulties blow over, and by the end he has left his mistress and seems likely to take up again with his wife.The director, Claude Pinoteau, has chosen two strong actors for his protagonists. As the professor, Lino Ventura manages stiffness dourness and moments of sudden sweetness that illuminate his complexity. His sour love for his daughterhe shouts her to her room in one flare-up, and the next morning brings her a solicitous cup of coffee in bedis held firmly this side of sentimentality.As the gawky, quicksilver, funny, fidgety daughter, Isabelle Adjaniwho was the star of Franois Truffaut's "Adle H."also plays her part for what it is worth.Neither of the parts is worth a great deal, however. The characters are established, but they have remarkably little to do. About halfway through, the movie's slim vitality flickers out and never recovers. Mr. Pinoteau has set out pinwheels but failed to find a wind.

title: MADRID ARRESTS LABOR LAWYERS
description: MADRID, Jan. 18The Spanish Government gave further evidence of a stiffened attitude toward its leftist opposition by breaking up a private gathering in a suburban villa early this morning and arresting 22 lawyers and 33 other professional people with their wives.

title: WOODWIND QUINTET IN CARNEGIE DEBUT
description: The Juilliard School has long been a spawning ground for chamber ensembles, and among the more recent arrivals is the American Woodwind Quintet, founded by students in 1974. The quintet gave a spirited debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night, introducing Wendy HecklerDenbaum, flute; Roger Cole, oboe; Theodore Lane, clarinet; Michael Olesak, bassoon, and Kazimierz Machala. horn.

title: Concert
description: It must be an illusion, stimulated by the hardening of one's own arteries, but it does seem that as Andres Segovia grows older his audiences grow younger. The Andalusian guitarist, who will he 83 next month, returned to Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon for the first of his two recitals here this season and one was struck as in the past by the phenomenon: this looked less like an audience than an assembly of the student body.

description: An Oregon State basketball news release last summer read: The pros have signed our star, Lonnie Shelton. It has really hurt our chances, so delete his name from the roster. We'll have a respectable team, but will be lacking board strength.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 18 (AP)The New Jersey Turnpike compiled its best safety record in history in 1975 with a fatality rate of one death for each 100 million miles of travel, officials said.

title: 350,000 Said to Leave Saigon for the Countryside
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Jan. 18 (Reuters)More than 350,000 people have left Saigon for the countryside since the communist victory last April. informed sources said here.

title: 1,300 Turn Out in Chinatown For a Memorial Tribute to Chou
description: More than 1,300 people, most of them residents of Chinatown, filled the seats and aisles of a Grand Street auditorium yesterday for a memorial tribute to Chou Enlai.

title: Ballet: D'Antuono and Bortoluzzi in Hoffmann
description: It was a varied weekend for Broadway dance, with the Paul Taylor Dance Company ending its season at the Mark Hellinger Theater, American Ballet Theater continuing across the street at the Uris, and the New York City Ballet still in occupation of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center.
