title: Lazar Berman. Russian Pianist, Heard
description: Lazar Berman, billed as the legendary Russian pianist, made his local debut Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He played, with the Brooklyn Philharmonia under Lukas Foss, the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Piano Concerto. Legendary? That remains to be seen. But the big Russian is indeed a pianist.

title: PHELPS BARNUM, 84, ARCHITECT, IS DEAD
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 18 Phelps Barnum, an architect whose designs included the rebuilt Stoa of Attalos in the Agora, or marketplace, of ancient Athens, died yesterday at his home on Chapman Lane. He was 84 years old.

title: Gromyko's Tokyo Rebuff
description: Tokyo's rejection of a heavyhanded Soviet effort prevent completion of the Japanese peace treaty with China reflects a shift in the Asian power balance that Moscow evidently has been slow in recognizing, but can no longer ignore. Lacking significant military force, but protected by the American nuclear umbrella, Japan has emerged as a major political as well as economic factor in Asia, able to pursue its own policies regardless of the wishes of its powerful Soviet neighbor.

title: Returning Congress Hears Address by Ford Tonight

description: TRENTON, Jan. 18 (AP)The head of the New Jersey Department of Higher Education says budget cuts he will announce this week could lead to enrollment cuts, tuition increases and substantial faculty layoffs at the state colleges and at Rutgers University be,ginning in September.

title: Police Say Subway Crime Peaks From 2 to 4 A.M.
description: The most dangerous time to ride the subways, according to an analysis of transit police statistics, is between 2 and 4 A.M., when the ratio of felonies to passengers is at its highest.

title: A Basque in Idaho Urges Inquiry Into a C.I.A. Role
description: BOISE, Idaho. Jan. 18 (AP)Idaho's Secretary of State, a BasqueAmerican. said today that he had asked Senator Frank Church to investigate whether the Central intelligence Agency was involved in any attempt by the Spanish Government to split the Basque groups in northwestern Spain.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 18Secretary General Kurt Waldheim appealed today for a haft to the civil strife in Lebanon and warned that the fighting could lead to disastrous developments in the Middle East as a whole.

description: Edward A. Willner, who retired in 1974 as assistant vice president of the Imperial Reading Corporation, makers of garments, died Saturday of heart attack in Hempstead (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Bellmore. L.I.

title: Vatican Document Protested
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 18 (AP)  Women and homosexuals marched in front of the cathedrals of Florence and Turin today to protest a Vatican document on sexual ethnics that opposed sex outside of marriage, masturbation and homosexuality. The police said that the marches involved a score of demonstrators in each city.

title: U.S. Is Sued in Jailing of By Pacific Company Police
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 18 (UPI)Five former employees of the Kwajalein missile range in the Marshall Islands, asserting that their civil rights had been violated many times following their arrest by police of Global Associates at a marijuana party, have filed a $200,000 suit against the Government.

title: Gilder, a Tour Rookie, Golf Victor on 67268
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 (AP)Bob Gilder, a longshot rookie playing in his second pro tour event, ignored the growing pressure, carded a fourunderpar 67 and scored an upset, twostroke victory today in the Phoenix open golf tournament.

DE GUSTIBUS
description: A few columns back we spoke of the varieties and techniques for using bouquets garnis. A bouquet garni is simply an assortment of herbs and/or spices, tied together and added to soups, sauces, stews and so on to give flavor. A basic bouquet garni might consist of simply a few sprigs of parsley tied together or, in a more complicated sense, a few sprigs of parsley tied with thyme sprigs (when available), whole or broken bay leaves and so on.

Most who went outside bundled up carefully, as did the group, above, on Fifth Avenue at 47th Street. title: Tighter Rule of Economy Is Debated by Canadians
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 18Inflation, Canada's first peacetime wageprice controls, publicservice strikes and remarks by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau have sparked debate among Canadians about the future of the free enterprise system and whether the central Government should wield more power over the economy.

description: LISBON, Jan. 18A leftist campaign against soaring food prices backfired today with street market that promised too much and offered too little.

description: Flora PittConrey, a phatographer, died Wednesday at the Hutton Nursing Home in Kingston, N.Y. She was 88 years old.

description: Sharif Khan regained the North American open squash racquets championship yesterday with a 153, 157, 155 victory over Victor Niederhoffer at the University Club. Khan, from Toronto, ran off 10 striaght points in the first game and had little trouble with the New Yorker thereafter.

title: U.S. Stocks Are Attracting More Investors in Europe.

description: MIAMI; Jan. 18The Super Bowl justified its existence today. The Pittsburgh Steelers won, 2117.

title: Books of The Times
description: There are times, says R. D. Laing, when people need to go mad. Reminding us that schizophrenia literally means brokeu hearted, he suggests that feelings of terror and despair are often the result of 'doublebinds, in which, without conscious malice, one person is repeatedly subjected to simultaneous, absolutely contradictory injunctions and attributions about who he is, or how he feels or what he thinks, until he can no longer tell who he is, or what he feels or thinks.

title: Fire Destroys 25 Yachts
description: GLOUCESTER. Mass., Jan. 18 (AN  A fire destroyed 23 yachts and heavily damaged 10 others early today with losses estimated at up to $400,090. the police reported. No injuries were reported. The fire was in a boat storage area at the Cape Anni Marina on the Annisquam River.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18If the experiences of B'nai B'rith, the Jewish service organization, are any barometer, there are a lot more Americans joining in volunteer community aid proerams these days.

description: To this listener's ears, ?? sare Siepi's recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night sounded like that of a singer in transition, moving from one repertory to ai.other, from one vocal technique to another and, if all continues well. from one kind of performing success to another.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP)Up to 5,000 football fans came to South Florida on package tours that promised Super Bowl tickets, but there were no tickets and the tour company officials have disappeared, the police said tonight.

description: HOUSTON, Jan. 18A week of violence involving laidoff union construction workers subsided this weekend in Houston and Lake Charles, La., after one man was killed and five others were wounded by gunfire. and rampaging workers caused an estimated million dollars in fire damage at a refinery construction site.

description: TOKYO. Jan. 18 (Reulers)The first international exposition devoted to the world's oceans closed today in Okinawa after visits from about 3.5 million people during six months.

description: MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP)Joe Namath said today would like to be traded to the Los Angeles Rams. The Jets quarterback, here for the Super Bowl, was interviewed on the CBS 90minute pregame television show.

Y., and is being donated to the Mark Twain Memorial in Hartford, where it will he displayed in the extravagant old house the author built here a hundred years ago.

The Dallas Cowboys, who lost to the Steelers, 2117, thought the victors were overly and unnecessarily aggressive, especially Mel Blount, the cornerback.

description: Joan Grant, Somerville Frazee, an account executive with William Estey Company Inc., the advertising concern, died Sunday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Officials of the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency may have intentionally permitted Greek militants to engineer a coup against Archbishop Makarios in Cyprus, according to a report prepared by the staff of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: How Do You Price Art Works? Let the Dealers Count the Ways
description: The subject of art prices, a delicate one that dealers don't like to discuss and everyone else in the art world does, has lately heated up. The interest stems from such factors as the recession, which has caused a thinning of art buyers, and a slowdown in the contemporary auction market, plus the recent case of Mark Rothko, the late. Abstract Expressionist.

description: OTTAWA, Jan. 19Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, defending himself against charges of socialism and authoritarianism, asked Canadian business and labor tonight to collaborate with the Government in programs to cure the nation's economic ills.

title: Chess:
description: The winner of the seventh world correspondence championship, which ran from 1972 to 1975, was Yakob Estrin of the Soviet Union. He scored 12 points in the 16man final, to top Josef Boey of Belgium, who took second prize a half point behind. Third prize was shared by V. Zagorovsky of the Soviet Union, and Richardson of England, each with 11 points.

title: High Court Rejects Wilmington 10 Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) The United States Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by the Rev. Ben Chavis, a civil rights activist, and nine other defendants of arson and conspiracy convictions stemming from racial violence at Wilmington, N.C., in 1971.

title: Bowie Triple Pays $39,160
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 19 (AP) The $3 triple in the ninth race at Bowie Race Course today paid $39,160.80, providing the largest payoff of the meeting. There were two tickets on the 3116 combination. The winner was Soda Pop, paying $14.20, $6.80 and $5; second was Real Guy, $13.80 and $10; third was Roanesian, $14.

title: Rockets' Shooting Tops Bullets, 11596
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Houston Rockets used perfect firsthalf shooting by Kevin Kunnert and Ed Ratleff to build a 25point lead in the second quarter and trounced the Washington Bullets, 11596, tonight.

title: Byrne Suggests Raising Gasoline Tax 2 Cents
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19With the spectre of a possible strike by several thousand state workers for bonuses that they were promised last year but did not get, Governor Byrne today suggested that the Legislature consider raising New Jersey gasoline taxes by 2 cents a gallon to finance bonuses for state employees and to restore cuts in the state Medicaid program.

title: Market Place
description: While trading on the New York Stock Exchange has been averaging a hefty 28.4 million shares a day lately, the American Stock Exchange has meandered through an average daily turnover of 2.7 million shares, not even beginning to reach the traditional ratio of 25 to 40 percent of Big Board volume.

title: House Committee Report Finds C.I.A. Understated Prices of Angolan Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Central, Intelligence Agency has systematically undervalued, in some cases by half, the military equipment supplied to warring factions in Angola, according to evidence obtained by the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Diane Rosenberg, 37, Dies; Housing Authority Lawyer
description: Diane Stricof Rosenberg, a lawyer who was a hearing officer with the Housing Authority and a referee with the Parking Violations Bureau, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 37 years old and lived at 84 St. John's Avenue in Yonkers.

title: OCCIDENTAL EXPECTS A DECLINE IN PROFITS
description: The Occidental Petroluem Corporation said yesterday that on the basis of preliminary estimates, it expected 1975 net income to decline to between $165 million and $170 million from 1974's restated total of $277.2 million.

title: College Presidents Lead Move to Gain Greater Control of N. C.A.A. Policies
description: Dr. Ross Pritchard, president of Arkansas. State University, told delegates at last week's National Collegiate Athletic Association convention to review and focus more carefully on what is essential in intercollegiate athletics. Notes He rocked the boat during the usually dull annual N.C.A.A. awards luncheon last Thursday.

title: FLORENCE L. WHITFIELD
description: Florence Levenson Whitfield, a former lawyer who had been active in the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in West Orange, N. J., and philanthropies in New Jersey, died Saturday of cancer at her home in Washington. She was 71 years old and formerly lived in Montclair, N. J.

title: Gold at 2Year Low; Dollar Is Still Weak As U.S. Rates Ease
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 19 (UPI)The price of gold dropped to its lowest rate in two years today as the dollar, undermined by lower interest rates in the United States, also fell on European money markets.

title: 14 FOOD PLACES GET WARNING OF CLOSING
description: The Health Department has named 14 more food businesses for failing a health code inspection and warned that they faced closing orders if violations persisted on a second and final inspection. The names of the establishments cited and the actions follow:

title: SPAIN CONSCRIPTS 70,000 RUMEN
description: MADRID, Jan. 19The Government today drafted some 70,000. railroad workers after one of Spain's biggest waves of strikes in 40 years began to disrupt train service.

title: Last of the Dynamic Duo Near End of Police Trail
description: Batman has quit the Police Department, and Robin fears that he will soon be forced out.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SOCIAL HISTORY OF THE MACHINE GUN. By John Ellis. 186 pages. Illustrated Pantheon. $12.95; paperback, $4.95.

title: Amex Options List Grows
description: The American Stock Exchange said today it had added Eli Lilly, the Tandy Corporation and TRW Inc. to the list of options it now traded as well as 68 debenture issues of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae. The Amex said it now traded 51 option issues and all Treasury bonds and notes and major Federal agency securities as part of its oddlot Government market.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Transportation Commissioner, Raymond Schuler, has rejected fare increases requested by three bus companies in Westchester County. He turned down the applications submitted by the Westchester Street Transportation Company, Liberty Coaches Inc. and Club Transportation Company. The three companies carry about million passengers a year95 percent of the bus riders Westchester County. In denying the application, Mr. Schuler said that state subsidy funds, matching county funds and Federal money would allow continuation of the present fare at this time.

title: STATE OF UNION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19President Ford, declaring that 'common sense dictated a selfdisciplined course at the outset of the third American century, zalled tonight on Congress to act with restraint in meeting the immediate needs and expectations of the nation.

title: Thailand's Democracy
description: The fall of Thailand's first democratically chosen Government less than one year after the elections that brought it to power is less surprising than Prime Minister Kukrit Pramoj's decision to dissolve Parliament and call new elections for April rather than leave office.

title: New Hearst Hearing Is Set In Fight With Psychiatrist
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19Paticia Hearst's defense lawyers obtained today a new court hearing on an assertion that they had newly diseovered evidence relating to evaluation of the government psychiatrists.

title: S.E.C. Deadline Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that it is extending until March 31 a transition period for brokers and dealers before they must comply fully with new financial responsibility and reporting requirements on municipal securities transactions. The transition period, which offered brokers and dealers certain variances, was originally to expire last Thursday.

title: Only Syria Could Cause Intervention, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Jan, 20 Israeli officials expressed deep concern yesterday over the intensified fighting and political chaos in Lebanon, but both civilian and military sources contended that Israel would not intervene unless Syria did so first.

title: Kennedy & Cohen Starting To Close 17 of 25 Units
description: Kennedy & Cohen Inc., a large majorappliance chain operating in the South and Midwest, announced yesterday that it had started to close 17 of its 25 stores and would probably file under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: F.D.A. Replies to Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Responding to the G.A.O. re port, the Food and Drug Admin., istration said today that its conflict of interest regulations exceed statutory requirements, are more comprehensive than those of other agencies and are vigilantly enforced.

title: City Basks In 25 Heat (Up From 7)
description: The temperature of 7 in Central Park at 7:20 A.M. yesterday didn't break the record low for the date (1, in 1875), but it was still cold enough to make 25 at 3 P.M. feel like break in the weather.

title: LAWYER ALLEGES L.I. POLICE DEAL
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 19  A lawyer for Roger Barry Peterson charged today that the Suffolk County Police Commissioner and other police officials had promised Mr. Peterson that he would never have to spend a day in jail on burglary and forgery charges if he signed statement accusing Henry F. O'Brien, the Suffolk District Attorney, of an act of sodomy.

title: Super Bowl Marks
description: RECORDS BROKEN

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MELODY LAND The. choice of Betty Allen, the meuo soprano, to begin Town Hall's four Tuesday evening programs of a Sing Out. America series seems a practical one. since this Bicentennial salute is designed to include the best in American music. Commenting on a recital by Miss Allen three years ago. Harold C. Schonberg, music critic of The New York Times. wrote that the singer was marvelous. When is she not?

title: DR. KURT BLOCH DIES; BARRON'S EDITOR, 75
description: Or. Kurt Bloch, an associate editor of Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly since 1950, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Chad Mitchell Conviction Is Reversed
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has reserved the 1974 conviction of Chad Mitchell, the the singer, for possession of 400 pounds of marijuana with intent to distribute.

title: Housing Starts Show Dip In Last Month of Bad Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Housing starts declined slightly in December for the second consecutive month but re mained well above the depressed levels of late 1974 and early 1975, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Indiana Gets 32 Points From May and Holds Off Purdue, 7167
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 19 (AP)Topranked Indiana, led by Scott May's 32 points, survived a Purdue rally tonight and beat the Boilermakers, 7167, to take the Big Ten basketball lead.

title: CHARLES E. HALLENBORG
description: Charles E. Hallenborg, former executive vice president of the Dictaphone Corporation and former president of the Copease Corporation, a pioneer in photocopying died here yesterday. He was 77 years old and lived at 50 East 77th Street.

title: 1,000 Join The Festivities at Sutton FundRaising
description: Don't Nobody Bring Me No Bad News, was not billed as the theme of the fundraising party thrown last night by Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan.

title: ExDean John Gallen, 70, Of Villanova Engineering
description: Dr. John James Gallen, who retired in September as dean of the. College of Engineering of Villanova University, died Saturday at his home in Havertown, Pa., near Ardmore. He was 70 years old.

title: Nadjari and Sandler Confer on Calendar
description: Leonard H. Sandler, the newly appointed special justice hearing cases brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, spent part of his first day on the job yesterday conferring with the special state prosecutor about pending prosecutions.

title: Super Bowl NoShows
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)The National Football League said today there were 3,305 noshows for yesterday's Super Bowl game. The league said the actual attendance at the Orange Bowl was 76,882.

title: Article 1  No Title
Helping New York
description: Recently, the New School for Social Research announced that it would hold an open public forum i one of its auditoriums at lunchtime entitled Alive and Loving New York. The discussion was to be on the need for selfhelp in New York and the panel members were to include six citizens who had organized civic activities ranging from volunteer ambulance corps to a citywide greening program.

title: America's Political Malaise
description: WASHINGTON  As chairman of the Democratic Party I travel a great deal around this country and everywhere I find a negativism, a pessiism, a lack of faithfor which there is admittedly some justification. But to acknowledge that this mood exists and that there may be cause for it, does not justify the tendency of some political leaders to fall prey to the same malaise.

title: Vote in 2 Vietnams For Joint Assembly To Be Held April 25
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 19 (AP)  North Vietnam and South Vietnam will elect a joint national assembly on April 25 with jurisdiction in both parts or the country, the Saigon radio announced today.

title: Supreme Court Upholds the WinnerTakeAll Rule for California's Republican Presidential Primary
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of the winnertakeall rule of California's Republican Presidential primary.

title: Beame Orders BreakUp Of Transit and Youth Units
description: Mayor Beame yesterday announced the abolition pf the Transportation Administration and the Youth Services Agency, and the division of their functions among new city agencies, a reorganization that he said would result in the layoff of 90 city workers and a savings of $3.9 million a year.

title: Transit Secrecy
description: Upper Broadway has become the latest beneficiary of bus shelters which are at long last springing up sporadically in various locations around town. Since they are provided by a commercial enterprise, the shelters add nothing to the city's strained budget. The new structures are attractive and appear welldesigned, except for one incredible omission: Their ample transparent wall space is unencumbered by any legend that might inform passengers of the numbers and destinations the buses which stop there.

title: Beirut ExPremier Balks At Return Without Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Jan. 20With Lebanon caught up in a constitutional crisis and continued factional warfare, President Suleiman Franjieh reportedly appealed yesterday to the Moslem leader Rashid Karami to reconsider his resignation as Prime Minister.

title: ODEN MEEKER, 57, A TRAVEL WRITER
description: Oden Meeker, author, travel writer and a former executive of CARE, died yesterday of pneumonia and complications of multiple sclerosis in St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived here and in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: 4 YOUTHS SEIZED AS TRAIN VANDALS
description: Four youths, all students at Chelsea Vocational High School, were arrested yesterday on charges ranging from sexual abuse, to criminal mischief after an IND subway train was vandalized near the West Fourth Street station.

title: Rizzo Forms Own Democratic Machine
PAINE WEBBER'S NET IS OFF NEARLY 19%
description: Paine Webber Inc., parent company of the brokerage firm of Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis, reported yesterday that profits for its December quarter fell nearly 19 percent despite a 16 nercent rise in revenues.

title: MAN FREED ON BAIL IN MADISON BOMBING
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 19A former University of Wisconsin student, charged with firstdegree murder in a fatal campus bombing in 1970, has been released from jail for the second time within three days.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Judge Orders Halt in Sales  Of Alleged Cancer Cure
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19 Judge Vincent Biunno of Federal District Court has ordered two companies based in Summit to stop selling a drug alleged to be a cancer cure and to recall the item from the market. The drug, known alternatively as amygdalin laetrile or Vitamin B 17, has not been approved by the Federal Drug Administra tion, according to Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Congress Democrats Cool To Ford Budget Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Democratic senators and representatives indicated tonight that President Ford's proposals to hold the line on the Federal budget would not fare too well in the electionyear Congress.

title: State Buying Farm Rights in 4 Places
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19  The state will pay $5 million for development rights on 10,000 or more acres of southern New Jersey farmland, officials said today.

title: Other Company Reports
Venezuela Oil Output Off
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 19 (AP)Slower sales abroad and the government's oil conservation policy have resulted in a decline of more than 1.2 million barrelsaday in Venezuela's oil production this year, according to Venezuelan Government officials.

title: GRAIN INSPECTORS INDICTED BY U. S.
description: BATON ROUGE, La.. Jan. 19  Three grain inspectors employed by a Louisiana government agency were indicted by Federal grand jury here today on charges that they conspired to mise rade soybeans in return for $67.130 in bribes.

title: A New Realism
description: In an election year, a President usually takes a benign view of the state of the union. President Ford last evening was no exception to this custom.

title: Advertising
description: There are some 40 to 45 weekly community newspapers in this city making their money from local advertisers who generally can't afford the rates of the big metropolitan dailies.

title: Goliath, 2din World, Loses a Chess Game To British David, 10
description: LONDON, Jan. 19Viktor Korchnoi, the Russian grandmaster who is the world's secondranking chesa player, lost a game here over the weekend to a 10yearold boy.

title: CASINO GAMBLING IS URGED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19Governor Byrne today proposed that New Jersey adopt a constitutional amendment that would legalize casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: MINISTER GUILTY IN PLANT BOMBING
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19The Rev. David N. Bubar, the Fundamentalist minister who claims psychic powers, was convicted here today of charges that he masterminded the bombing last year of a sponge rubber factory in Shelton, Conn.

title: Ford Says Policy Abroad Is Weakened by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19President Ford told Congress tonight that its hasty actions in blocking activities of the Administration in Angola and elsewhere abroad were very shortsighted and had raised questions about the United States in the minds of allies and adversaries.

title: FORMULA IS SOUGHT IN DOCTORS PROTEST
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) With renewed possibilities for negotiatinp, state help, two committees of Southern California doctors began meetings today aimed at ending their 19day slowdown.

title: SOUTHLAND RAISES OFFER FOR AZTEC
description: The Southland Royalty Company announced in Fort Worth yesterday that it had raised its cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of the Aztec Oil and Gas Company from $27 a share to $32 a share.

title: Laos Reports Clashes
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 19 (Agence FrancePresse) Laotian troops clashed with traitorous reactionaries in the southern part of the country on Jan. 10 and 11, the Government radio reported today. It said two of the reactionaries had been killed in the fighting in two villages in Champassak Province. A number of clashes between Government forces and dissident groups have been reported in that area recently.

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Tighten Fiscal Monitoring of City
description: Concerned with the city's ability to monitor its own attempt at fiscal recovery, United States Treasury officials have decided to seek tighter, more coordinated procedures next week at a meeting with representatives of the General Accounting Office and the state's Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: F.D.A. Outlaws Dye Used in Drugs, Food And Cosmetic Items
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was banning Red No. 2, the nation's most widely used dye in foods, drugs and cosmetics, because of new concern that it might be a cancercausing agent.

title: Election Agency to Get a Report On Roles of Morton in New Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) President Ford's top lawyer promised the Federal Election Commission today a detailed breakdown of Rogers C. B. Morton's activities as a White House adviser to help the commission decide if Mr. Morton should remain on the Federal payroll.

title: Quake Hits Three States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) An earthquake of intermediate magnitude struck portions of Kentucky, West Virginia and North Carolina early today, the United States Geological Survey said. There were no injuries or damage reported.

title: WagePrice Unit Opposes Postal Service Monopoly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The President's Council on Wage and Price Stability recommended today that the United States Postal Service lose its monopoly of firstclass letter service and face competition from private deliveries.

title: A.T.&T. Gets $225 Million LongDistance Rise
description: Commission approved yesterday an increase in the longdistance telephone rates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that is expected to cost its customers an additional $225 million year.

title: Trenton Convict Is Killed, 4 Men Hurt in Uprising
description: TRENTON, Tuesday, Jan. 20 Otie prisoner was killed and three guards and another inmate were wounded last evening during an attempted takeover of a maximum security wing of Trenton State Prison.

title: 8 Freight Cars Derailed
description: CHARLEMONT, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP) Eight cars of an 18car Boston & Maine freight train derailed here today put: ting the freight line out of service until tomorrow morning; railroad officials said. The traM was headed from Boston, to Mechanicsville, N.Y.

title: Beirut ExPremier Balks At Return Without Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Jan. 20With Lebanon caught up in a constitutional crisis and continued factional warfare, President Suleiman Franjieh reportedly appealed yesterday to the Moslem leader Rashid Karami to reconsider his resigbation as Prime Minister.

title: Music: Some Rare Duets
Rutgers, St. John's In Tots 10
description: Rutgers and St. John's are restoring the lost prestige of New York college basketball. Each team was in the Top 10 in the weekly United Press International's board of coaches ratings released yesterday. The biggest jump was made by Oregon State.

title: In a Greek Village, a Need for Dowries Leads to Prosperous Weaving Business
description: LINDOS, RhodesIn 1961, Mary North got off the bus in this small island village, a footloose British woman who was spending her savings on a tour of Greece. A small boy took her by the hand and led her to a house, where she rented a room for 50 cents a day.

title: Canadian Paper Workers Union Sets Vote on a New Wage Offer
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (UPI)Members of the Striking Canadian Paper Workers Union will vote later this week on a new Wage offer aimed at ending a threemonth strike at four mills in Quebec.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Soybean prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade under the impact of some new speculative buying handled through leading commission houses.

title: CANADAU.S. PLAN FOR GAS DELAYED
description: TORONTO, Jan. 17  Delays in Ottawa and Washington have set back by a year or more the proposed pipeline to deliver natural gas from Alaska and the Canadian Arctic, according to officials planning the multibilliondollar project.

title: Panel Finds City Schools Severely Hurt by Cuts
description: A panel of educators appointed by the American Federation of Teachers declared yesterday that last fall's budget cuts had stripped the city schools of vital programs and services and were turning them into mere custodial institutions.

title: Only Syria Could Cause Intervention, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM. Tuesday, Jan. 20  Israeli officials expressed deep concern yesterday over the intensified fighting and political chaos in Lebanon, but both civilian and military sources contended that Israel would not intervene unless Syria did so first.

title: KISSINGER DOUBTS REPORTS ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he cannot believe that President Nixon denied that he had personally selected the targets for F.B.I. wiretapping in a search for information leaks in 1969.

title: Storms in Turkey Kill 5
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 19 (AP)Heavy snow and cold engulfed almost half of Turkey today, causing at least five deaths. Airline flights to and from Istanbul were canceled.

title: N.B.A. Steps Up TrustSuit Talks
description: Five executives of National Basketball Association teams, the advisory committee seeking an outofcourt settlement of the Oscar Robertson antitrust suit, turned salesmen last week. They spread out all over the nation in a series of meetings to sell and brief owners of the other 13 franchises on the progress of the sensitive negotiations that took place on Jan. 7 and 8 with the N.B.A. Players Association in New York.

title: EARNINGS RISE 10.8% AT BIG CHICAGO BANK
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, parent of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, reported yesterday increased earnings before securities transactions for both the fourth quarter of last year and for the entire year.

title: Colleague of Mrs. Javits Says She Is Considering Resigning
description: Marion Jay its, wife of Senator Jacob K. Davits, is considering resigning the $67,500 consultant work on an Iranian public relations account that stirred controversy last week, her immediate superior said yesterday.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: More Message Units For L.I. Jail Inmates
description: A Suffolk County spokesman conceded yesterday that giving inmates of the Suffolk County jail a free telephone call a day could help avert trouble there, but he said the plan, ordered last June by Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, was proving too costly.

title: Chess:
description: The winner of the seventh world correspondence championship, which ran from 1972 to 1975, was Yakob Estrin of the Soviet Uniorr. He scored 12 points in the 16man final, to top Josef Boey of Belgium, who took second prize a half point behind. Third prize was shared by V. Zagorovsky of the Soviet Union, and Richardson of England, each with 11 points.

title: BOOK STIRS FUROR ON LEFT IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 19Leftist politicians in France are angrily trying to rebut the central thesis of a widely discussed new book by a political philosopher, JeanFrancois Revel, which argues that Socialists are committing suicide when they work together with Communists because the essence of communism is Stalinism.

title: Assembly Will Try Again To Use Machine Counts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19  The Assembly, which made a rather controversial false start into the machine age in 1966, is going to try once again to institute a sound and lasting electronic voting system. The first one fell into misuse and disuse and became a laughing matter for most legislators.

title: EDWARD M. POPOVITS
description: Edward M. Popovits of Forest Hills, Queens, principal emeritus of the YeshiVa Rims Chaim of South Shore and past. president of the Yeshiva Day Schools Principals Association, died Saturday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: THUNDER BAY, Ontario, Jan. 19 (UPI)Terry Kern, a 21yearold from Duluth, Minn., soared 88.5 and meters yesterday and showed almost perfect form in winning the final competition of the United States Olympic ski jumping tryouts.

title: STATE OF UNION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Ford, declaring that common sense dictated a selfdisciplined course at the outset of the third American century, called tonight on Congress to act with restraint in meeting the immediate needs and expectations of the nation.

title: Bridge:
description: The fourday Tristate Regional championships ended at Grossinger's, N. Y., Sunday, with Leon St. Jean of Newton, Conn., leading his squad to victory in a field of 168 in the Swiss teams event. The others on the winning team were Steve Earl, Waterbury, Conn.. Larry Bausher, New Haven, and Jeff Horowitz, Bethany, Conn.

title: SUIT DIRECTS NO TO GIVE 11P E.S.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today to force the InternaItional Nickel Company of CanaIda Ltd. and its United States subsidiary to divest themselves of E.S.B. Inc, a Philadelphia company. which is the largest battery manufacturer in the: United States.

title: FORD IS SAID TO ASK USERY TO TAKE POST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19President Ford has asked W. J. Usery, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to take over the post of Secretary of Labor, succeeding John T. Dunlop, who resigned last week, an informed White House official reported tonight.

title: Edward Abbey, Voice of Southwest Wilds
description: PAGE, Ariz.If the Glen Canyon Darn here on the Colorado River were suddenly blown up by saboteurs, Edward Abbey, the novelist. might have to take a bit of the blameor the credit.

title: Sir Ronald Edwards, 62, Dead; Chief of British Leyland Motors
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)Sir Ronald Edwards, chairman since last October of the restructured British Leyland car and truck manufacturing company and president of the Beecham pharmaceutical group. died in a hospital here last night. He was 62 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Ralph M. Parsons Company announced yesterday that it had received a letter of intent from the Oil Service Company of Iran, a privately held business, for construction work estimated at $500 million on a major gas processing project in southern Iran. Parsons, based in Pasadena, Calif., will provide process design and construction management services for the project, which is part of Iran's nationwide resource development and utilization program.

title: Exchange Proposes Remedy For Ticker Tape Lateness
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday what it called a partial remedy for the lateness of the exchange's ticker tape on heavy trading days.

title: Judge Orders Milwaukee To Desegregate Schools
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 19A Federal judge ruled here today that Milwaukee schools were segregated, and ordered immediate steps for integration.

title: Tenafly Faces a Deadline on Acquiring Scenic Tract
Pittsburgh Citizens Unit Urges Higher Pay Offer for Teachers
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19A citizens factfinding panel recommended with one dissent today that the Board of Public Education increase the salary offer it has made to the Pittsburgh Federation of Teachers, which has been on strike since Dec. 1.MADISON, Wis., Jan. 19 (AP) Teachers returned to work at Madison's 50 public schools today as classes resumed after a twoweek walkout.

title: Securities Proposal Would Defer Taxes On Money Invested
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19President Ford proposed tonight the enactment of a new type of tax benefit designed to encourage more people to buy common stocks.

title: Minister Guilty
description: A Fundamentalist minister who ciaims psychic powers was convicted of Federal charges of having mastrrminded the bombing that devastated a sponge rubber factory in Shelton, Conn., last March 1. Page 13.

title: Oil Found in British North Sea
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The Continental Oil Company announced today confirmation of an apparently significant oilfield in the British North Sea sector. The company's British subsidiary, Conoco North Sea Inc., has a onethird share in the field 125 miles northeast of the Shetland Islands, together with Britain's National Coal Board and the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: REHIRING OF POLICE AND FIREMEN URGED
description: Citing what he said were declines in police and fire protection, Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, a Queens Democrat, yesterday proposed the rehiring of laidoff police officers and firemen by using $615 million in rainyday city taxes over the next three years.

title: Giants Add 2 Assistants
description: Bill Arnsparger, who has survived a disappointing second season on his threeyear contract with the Giants, reorganized his coaching staff yesterday. Arnsparger added Hunter Enis as his quarterback coach and named Jay Fry defensive line coach.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Viking Is Halfway to Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI)The Viking 1 spacecraft has reached the halfway point on its voyage to Mars and is in excellent operating condition, scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said today. Viking 1, now 50 million miles from earth, was launched on Aug. 20, and is scheduled to go into orbit around Mars on June 19 and to be put on the planet surface on or close to July 4. Its sister ship, Viking 2. is functioning perfectly some 3.7 million miles behind Viking 1. It was launched Sept. 9 and is expected to enter orbit around Mars on Aug. 2.

title: City Fire Prevention: A Maze for Experts
description: The fire last month at the Blue Angel night club on East 54th Street, which claimed seven lives, has prompted concern about the adequacy of the city's building and fire

title: Paris Magazine Names Two As Soviet Intelligence Men
description: PARIS, Jan. 19 (UPI)Two Soviet Embassy officials today were identified as intelligence agents by the leftwing magazine Le Nouvel Observateur.

title: City Ballet Revels in an Evening of Robbins
description: A decade agobefore the days of Michael Bennett, Harold Prince or even, in a way, Bob Fossethe leading Broadway director in the musical theater was Jerome Robbins. And, in absentia, he still is. Most producers with a musical on their hands routinely, if with bleak hope, offer it to Mr. Robbins first. But Mr. Robbins has found his own theater in the sky; it is called the New York City Ballet and it keeps him content. Moreover, if anyone thinks Pacific Overtures is innovative and imaginative, iliCh it most certainly is, he should see Watermill. Still, that is hardly the point.

title: Thunder Out of Lebanon
description: The sense of despair with which Lebanon's courageous Prime Minister Karami resigned Sunday must be shared by everyone concerned with the stability of the entire Middle East. The only remaining hope rests on still another shaky truce worked out late yesterday which could conceivably permit Mr. Karami to regain his post and his stabilizing influence. As the hour of ceasefire passed, the fighting scarcely paused.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976. by Triangle PublicatIont Inc. (The Daily Raclin Form)

title: Steelers Carson a Prime Jet Candidate
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19Bud Carson, the talented defensive coordinator of the twotime champion Pittsburgh Steelers, became a leading candidate today for the New York Jets coaching job.

title: After the Assenter
description: Last Thursday, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. would have celebrated his 47th birthday. Next April he will have been dead eight years. As the sixties recede, the significance of his life becomes much clearer and the impact of his absence becomes almost tangible. Before he was murdered, he embodied the hope of the vast majority of blacks and of many whites as well. In contrast, his death and the circumstances surrounding it not only symbolize a dramatic decline of faith once firmly held in the black community; they actually fuel and accelerate that decline.

title: High Court Bars Appeal Of 2 New York Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters)  The Supreme Court declined today to review the dismissal of one of the principal antitrust claims brought against the Standard Oil Company of California, Texaco Inc, and the Mobil Oil Corporation by two major New York area utilities.

title: Trenton Convict Killed
description: A prisoner was killed and three guards and a prisoner were wounded during an up rising at Trenton State Prison when convicts tried to seize a maximumsecurity wing with smuggled weapons. Details on Page 28.

title: Jankunis: High Jumper, Artist
description: Bill Jankunis gets out of bed at 6 A.M. every day and runs about three miles on the beaches of Midland Beach, Staten Island. Then, on weekdays, he heads for Manhattan to work from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. as a clerk in a brokerage firm. In his spare time, he enjoys scrutinizing the works of such artists as Dali, Picasso, Van Gogh and Monet at museums.

title: William N. Chace, 67, Dies; ExGreenwood Mills Officer
description: William N. Chace, a past president of the National Federation of Textiles who retired in 1965 as president of Greenwood Mills Inc. to administer the Fort Church Properties Company, a family real estate concern in Tiverton. R.I., died yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: The Press and the Campaign
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 19Eight years ago, at about the comparable stage of the 1968 Presidential campaigna month before the first primarythe candidacy of Senator Eugene McCarthy was considered poor joke by most of the political press.

title: Heirs of 4 Get $1.8 Million In Plane Crash Fatal to 72
description: CHARLESTON, S. C. Jan. 19 (AP)Federal District Judge Charles E. Simons announced damage awards today ranging from $315,000 to $550,000 to the families of four persons killed in 1974 in the crash of an Eastern Airlines jet at Charlotte, N.C., that claimed 72 lives.

title: New Hampshire Held Liable On All Welfare Abortions
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 19 (AP) United States District Court United States Ditrict Court clarified an earlier ruling today and said that the State of New Hampshire must pay the cost of abortions for welfare recipients during all stages of pregnancy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rizzo Forms Own Democratic Machine
description: The Mayor now controls virtually all Philadelphia patronage, and with that, he has come to dominate Philadelphia's daytoday politics. Those opposed to him, in or out of office, are impotent, Those who have supported him in the past, in or out of office, are now part of his bailiwick.

title: Newest Icebreaker Freed After Running Aground
description: PORT ORCHARD, Wash., Jan. 19 (AP)The $53 million Polar Star, the Coast Guard's newest and most powerful icebreaker, was floated free late today after running aground on her first cruise.

title: U.S. Export Ban on Nuclear Equipment Urged by Former Atomic Energy Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said today that the impending disaster of the rapid international spread of nuclear bombs required that the United States immediately and unilaterally end the shipment of nuclear equipment to all foreign countries.

title: MEANY IS CRITICAL OF FORD AND BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., portrayed President Ford as a political candidate whose word could not be trusted and the Federal Reserve Chairman, Arthur F. Burns, as someone who would be a good servant for a fascist society.

title: Bridge:
description: The fourday Tristate Regional championships ended at Grossinger's, N. Y., Sunday, with Leon St. Jean of Newton, Conn., leading his squad to victory in a field of 168 in the Swiss teams event. The others op the winning team were Steve Earl, Waterbury, Conn., Larry Bausher. New Haven, and Jeff Horowitz, Bethany, Conn.

title: Lutine Bell at Lloyd's Signals Costly Wreck
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The Lutine Bell was rung at Lloyd's of London today to notify insurance brokers of what could prove the costliest shipwreck in history.

title: HIGH FILING FEES FOR SUITS UPHELD
description: WASHINGTQN, Jan. 19The Supreme Court upheld today, without comment, the system of New York State Supreme Court filing fees that makes it more expensive to bring suit in New York City than elsewhere in the state.

title: Let Them Find Bread
description: Former Gov. Ronald Reagan's plan to transfer the state governments the bulk of existing Federal human welfare programs throws light on his brand conservatism. It should do much to take the ideological hokum out of currently fashionable calls for emancipation from Washington. When asked what might happen to the poor who live in states whose lagging means and social conscience might allow former Federal subsidies to go unreplaced, Mr. Reagan said: You can vote with your feet in this country. If a state is mismanaged, you can move elsewhere.

title: Shooting Victim Testifies at Sonny Carson Trial
description: A man who had been shot in the head and reportedly left for dead on a street corner in Roosevelt, L.I., took the witness stand yesterday at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson.

title: City Puerto Ricans Lag in Income Gains
description: Despite significant gains in education, work experience and language skills, Puerto Ricans in New York City suffered a decline in their relative income position between 1960 and 1970, according to a new Federal report issued here. The report compared Puerto Ricans here with other New Yorkers, residents of Puerto Rico, or Puerto Ricans living in other mainland cities.

title: Wood,Field&Stream
description: The account in this newspaper a few days ago that several rare sea animals dredged from the depths of the Gulf of Mexico are now on display at the New York Aquarium reminds one that Oceans Festival 76, called the largest marine fair ever planned, will be held at the Aquarium next June.

title: SPAIN CONSCRIPTS 70,000 RAILMEN
description: MADRID, Jan. 19The Government today drafted some 70,000 railroad workers after one of Spain's biggest waves, of strikes in 40 years began to disrupt train service.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19When Mean Joe Greene reported the Pittsburgh Steelers training camp in 1974, their defensive line coach, George Perles, told higi, We've got rookie who's so mean, he doesn't even like himself. The rookie was Jack Lambert, the middle linebacker who has now been a central character on two Super Bowl championship teams in two years. It's no accident, says Steeler official. He put the finishing touch on our defensive unit. Opponents prefer to think of Jack Lambert as the finishing forearm. After the Steelers 2117 victory in Super Bowl X, some of the Sports Dallas Cowboys did not nominate Jack of Lambert for the Nobel Peace Prize. They The Times accused him of hitting late and big mouthing and taking cheap shots. But aggressiveness, like beauty, is in the eyes of the beholder. Or, at least, in the eyes of the Steelers head coach.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: In a move to take advantage of its vast Wall Street computer capability, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. disclosed yesterday that it would handle backoffice operations for other Wall Street brokers.

title: Socialists Split on Working With Reds
description: HELSINGOR, Denmark, Jan. 19European Socialist leaders concluded a twoday meeting today sharply divided over political links with Communists and uncertain about what tactics to use to counter Communist influence in Italy and Portugal.

title: Byrne Proposes Raising Gasoline Tax by 2 Cents
Appellate Division W eighs Challenge to Gag on Press
description: After hearing oral arguments, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn said yesterday it would rule by Friday on whether to vacate a gag order against the press issued by the presiding judge in the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants.

title: F.D.A. Officials Are Criticized on Stocks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Congressional auditors charged today that more than 150 officials of the Food and Drug Administration had violated Federal conflict of interest rules by owning stock in companies that F.D.A. regulates.

title: Accountants Board Clears Stans of Ethics Charge
description: A trial board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has found Maurice H. Stans, former Secretary of Commerce and chief fund raiser for Richard M. Nixon's 1972 Presidential campaign, not guilty of bringing discredit on the accounting profession.

title: Race Quota for Principals Here Voided by U. S. Appeals Court
description: A courtordered racial quota for school principals here was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court that called it constitutionally forbidden reverse discrimination.

title: A.T.&T. Gets $225 Million LongDistance Rise
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved yesterday an increase in the longdistance telephone rates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that is expected to rota its customers an additional $225 million a year.

title: CORPORATE BONDS ADVANCE IN YIELD
description: Yields on new corporate bond issues were raised yesterday for the first time since early December as investment bankers abandoned last week's effort to persuade investors to

title: Barnett Lambert, Director Of Associated Camps, Dies
description: Barnett Lambert, executive director of Associated Camps Inc. and associate general director of the Associated Young Men's Young Women's Hebrew Associations of Greater New York, died Thursday on a visit to Jerusalem. He was 64 years bid and lived in Eastchester, N.Y.

title: REPORTS ON AZORES DRAW U.S. PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The State Department said today that it had made strong representations to the Azores for allowing Cuban planes hound for Angola to refuel there.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Looking for a gift or an accessory to add a fillip to that tired winter wardrobe, or a little pizazz to your dcor? You may very well find what you want in your own neighborhood, for the city is rich in offbeat shops offering merchandise that is out of the ordinary.

title: How Do You Price Art Works? Let the Dealers Count the Ways
description: The subject of art prices, a delicate one that dealers don't like to discuss and everyone else in the art world does, has lately heated up. The interest stems from such factors as the recession, which has caused a thinning of art buyers, and a slowdown in the contemporary auction market, plus the recent case of Mark Rothko, the late Abstract Expressionist.

title: 8 Held in Seizing of Cultist, 19
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y., Jan. 19A motorist helped to balk an apparent attempt yesterday by Ted Patrick to deprogram a 19yearold member of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church,

title: Nuclear Power Study Set
description: The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a oneyear, $874,000 program of studies of nuclear power, covering present knowledge and critical issues in what the foundation's president, McGeorge Bundy, called a confusing and often acrimonious debate. The studies will be organized through the Mitre Corporation; Princeton University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: U.S. Warns U.N. Against Bids to Change Basis of Mideast Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19The United States warned in the Security Council today against any attempts to impose any changes in the basis for Middle East negotiations that the Council laid down in 1967 and 1973.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Organ Concerto in F, Brixi; Symphony No. 38, Mozart; A Midsummer Night's .Dream, Mendelssohn.

title: Victors Greeted By 100,000 on Return Home
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19A crowd estimated by the police at 100,000 welcomed the Pittsburgh Steelers back from Miami today.

title: JOHN J. MOORE DIES; STATE SENATOR, 55
description: State Senator John J. Moore, a Democrat representing the 14th district in Queens, died Sunday night after apparently suffering a heart attack at his home, 2248 80th Street, Jackson Height's. He was 55 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Nine persons, including the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan and his brother, Philip, a former priest, began serving jail sentences of 30 to 60 days in Washington yesterday rather than pay fines for digging a hole in the White House lawn Nov. 26. The defendants received the choice after explaining why they had turned to civil disobedience to protest the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Philip Berri gan stated their position they could not pay a fine for an act of conscience. The others sentenced were Jim McNeill and Mike Dunham of Baltimore, Lee Griffith of Washington: Bob Smith, Beth Centz and Brian Widelitz of Philadelphia and Joe Maynes of Seattle. Present in court was Philip Berrigan's wife, Elizabeth McAllister, a former nun. She and the Berrigans, with 16 other members of the Community For Nonviolent Action, received fiveday suspended sentences last Friday for attempting to dig a mock grave at the Pentagon.

title: Race Quota for Principals Voided by U.S. CourtHere
description: A courtordered racial quota for school principals here was overturned yesterday hya Federal appeals court that called it constitutionally forbidden reverse discrimination.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The newly appointed head of the New Jersey Division of Criminal Justice believes that certain types of crime, including the possession of marijuana, prostitution and gambling, should be decriminalized to ease the strain on overcrowded prisons. Robert Del Tufo, who took office two weeks ago, also believes that the Legislature should enact law to make it illegal for New Jersey residents to own handguns.

title: Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (UPI)The California and Hawaiian Sugar Company was fined the maximum $100,000 in Federal court today on a no contest plea to fixing sugar prices. The sugar company was among six companies indicted in 1974 for price fixing in the Midwest and CaliforniaArizona markets.WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)The Justice Department filed a proposed consent order today that would settle a civil antitrust suit against four manufacturers of plumbing supplies and the parent corporation of one of the companies. The companies involved are the BorgWarner Corporation of Chicago, the Celanese Corporation of New York City, Plastiline Inc. of Pompano Beach, Fla., the R. & G. Sloane Manufacturing Company of Sun Valley, Calif., and Sloane's parent company, the Susquehanna Corporation of Alexandria, Va.

title: U.S. STILL SUPPORTS KARAMI IN LEBANON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The United States, seeking to prevent a worsening of the situation in Lebanon, said today that it continued to support Prime Minister Rashid Karami's efforts to end the fighting and told all parties that it opposed any partition of the country into Christian and Moslem regions.

title: jersey Set For Night Flat Racing
description: EAST WINDSOR, N. J., Jan. 19  An agreement reached today at the State Racing Commisssion offices here paved the way for the introduction of night thor ougnorea racing on a major level in the East this year. Night rac ing will make its

title: London Agrees to Withdraw From 200Mile Zone After Ultimatum by Reykjavik
description: BRITISH WARSHIPS LEAVING ICELANDBRUSSELS, Jan. 19Foreign Secretary James Callaghan announced today that Britain would withdraw its naval vessels from the 200mile fishing zone proclaimed by Iceland in an effort to avoid a break in diplomatic relations between the two countries.

description: To the Editor:

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold Prices Monday.

title: Nastase Defeats Borowiak, 62, 64
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (UPI)Ilia Nastase, the temperamental Rumanian who had said he might not play in the final without a change of officials, coasted to a 62, 64 victory over Jeff Borowiak tonight and won the W.C.T. Phoenix Cup tennis chamnionshin.

title: Market Gains 14.09; Volume High Again
description: Stock prices surged upward on heavy volume again yesterday as buyers entered the market aggressively after a bit of profit taking inthe morning. The Dow Jones industrial average, gaining 14.09 points to 943.72, closed at its best level of the day and established another 26month high on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: City Will Resubmit RentLaw Changes to Albany
description: The Beame administration will ask the Legislature this year to approve basically the same proposal for reforming the city's complex and controversioal rent laws that the city proposed, unsuccessfully, last Year.

title: Europe Alarmed by U.S. Plan on Steel
description: PARIS, Jan. 19Common Market officials said today that they intended to make representations to the United States to emphasize the dangers that American protectionist measures on imports of specialty steels would have for international trade.

title: Fashion: Casual Clothes Are Alive and Well
description: Nailing down fashion firsts is often a tricky business. For one thing, someone is sure to say he got there even earlier. For another, what matters more than being first in line is how well the idea executed.

Dividends
description: DIVIDENDS DECLARED ... ...

title: Securities Proposal Would Defer Taxes On Money Invested
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19President Ford proposed tonight the enactment of a new type of tax benefit designed to encourage more people to buy common stocks.

description: Alan R. Gruber has been appointed president of the Equity Funding Corporation of Amerlica, Robert M. Loeffler, trustee of the company, Robert M. Loeffler, trustee of the cornloony. announced yesterday.

title: Joseph L. Delafield, Headed Nassau Water Conditioning
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 19Joseph Livingston Delafield, who retired in 1972 as head of the Nassau Water Conditioning Company, distributor of watersoftening products, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 65 years old.

CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Dec. 31 said incorrectly that corruption cases involving American business in 1975 also involved the National Maritime Union.

description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's State of the Union Message delivered last night before a Joint session of Congress, as recorded by The New York Ttmes:

title: Prices for Mink Soar as Supplies Dwindle
description: Charies Reich, one of the largest mink dealers in New York raised his hand yesterday at the Emba mutation mink auctions at the liudson's Bay Company and bought a bundle of mink skins at $44 a skin.

title: STOCK PRICES GAIN ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Buoyed by ravorable economic news, prices on the American. Stock Exchange and in the over  the  counter market advanced yesterday in active trading despite some early profit taking.

title: Saharan Guerrilla War Is Predicted by Algerians
description: ALGIERS. Jan. 14A protracted guerrilla war in Spanish Sahara is foreseen by Algerian officials and Saharan dissidents who refuse to accept the agreement under which Spain in effect is handing over the territory to Morocco and Mauritania.

title: The Adams Chronicles: American TV at Its Best
description: More than five years in the snaking, a total budget of about $7 million, stalled by a Writers Guild Strike, the source of much nervous pride and some bitter criticism within the halls of the producer, WNET/13  The Adams Chronicles finally begins its 13week run on public television tonight at 9 o'clock. If the first hours can be considered representative, the series gives every indication of being a Bicentennial jewel, a splendid achievement in a major anniversary year that, so far, seems to be drenched in kitsch and mediocre tribute.

title: The Big Town
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19One comes from New York to Washington these days with a genuine sense of humility. This is rare in Washingtona genuine sense of humility. All politicians here are humble, of course, and seldom let you forget it. They go around the country boasting about their humility. They are proud of their humility. Many are downright arrogant about their humility and insist that it qualifies them to be President.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Met Opera's Lavish Sets Win Applause for Benois
description: This is in an operatic age in which films and mixed media are all the rage, as the New York City Opera has proved so well. But audiences still respond warmly to triedandtrue traditional sets. too, as the applause accorded Nicola Benois's decor for the Metropolitan Opera's current production of The Siege of Corinth has proved.

title: 2 GUARDS SHOT IN TRENTON RIOT
description: TRENTON, Jan. 19  Two guards were reported shot and wounded by inmates at the Trenton State Prison tonight after prisoners in a highsecurity wing obtains guns and opened fire in a sudden uprising that drew scores of policemen and state troopers.

title: Gerald A. Brissman Dies; N.L.R.B. Associate Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Gerald A. Brissman, an associate general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, died yesterday at Fairfax Hospital in suburban Virginia. He was 55 years old.

title: Goliath, 2din World, Loses a Chess Game To British David, 10
description: LONDON, Jan. 19Viktor Korchnoi, the Russian grandmaster who is the world's secondranking chess player, lost a game here over the weekend to a 10yearold boy.

title: Helping New York
description: Recently, the New School for Social Research announced that it would hold an open public forum in one of its auditoriums at lunchtime entitled Alive and Loving New York. The discussion was to be on the need for selfhelp in New York and the panel members were to include six citizens who had organized civic activities ranging from a volunteer ambulance corps to a city wide greening program.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon reportedly appealed yesterday to Rashid Karami to reconsider his resignation as Prime Minister, which has brought about constitutional crisis. Mr. Karami appeared to be insisting that there be a ceasefire first between the Christian and Moslem factions. A new ceasefire, the 22d in three and half months, was declared last night and, according to some accounts, Mr. Karami agreed to reconsider his resignation if this truce held. But there were reports of continued fighting. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: DAN THORNTON, 64, OF COLORADO DIES
description: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)Dan Thornton, a cattle rancher who became a twoterm Governor of Colorado, died yesterday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Kidney Is Transplanted In 3MonthOld Baby
description: Doctors at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn said yesterday that they had successfully transplanted kidney in a 3monthold baby boy who weighed only pounds 2 ounces. The infant, Alexander Kelly, was believed to he the youngest and probably the smallest child ever to receive a transplanted kidney.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The winds of change are swirling over tennis again, this time in the area of the Davis Cup.

title: State Medicaid Cuts Leaving the Sick Without Care
description: NEWARK, Jan. 19Medicaid cuts in New Jersey began taking their physical and emotional toll among the poor in this city today.

title: Centennial Safe Is Opened for Public View
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Memorabilia collected by a New York publisher nearly 100 years ago went on display todaymore or lessas the outer doors of a large safe were thrown open in the Capitol.

title: Bid Raised for Aztec
description: The Southland Royalty Company announced that it had raised its tender offer for the common shares outstanding of the Aztec Oil and Gas Company to $32 a share from $27. Page 49.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was banning Red No. 2, the nation's most widely used dye in foods, drugs and cosmetics, because of new concern that it might be cancercausing agent.

description: BASEBALL

title: Hiker Dies of Exposure
description: CRAWFORD NOTCH, N. H.,I Jan. 19 (AP)A 27yearold New York City man died yesterday in a mountainous area near here after becoming ill Saturday while he and two companions were hiking. Local medical officials said that William Kilker of Manhattan died of exposure during his rescue.

title: Basketball Scoring
description: WEEKEND BOXING

title: Railroads Seek to Lift Freight Rates by 4.7%
description: The nation's railroads filed yesterday a request with the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase freight rates by 7 percent, effective Feb. 18. After allowing for various commodities on which the carriers would not apply the higher rates, the increase would work out to about 4.7 percent.

title: Chamber Group at New Museum Hall
description: There is a new concert shall in New Yorknestled among the secondfloor galdefies at the Jewish Museum and an interesting new echamber series incorporating elements of the statesupported Meet the Composers programs.

title: Open Interest
Judge Seeks To Speed Up Baseball Suit
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 19 (AP)Attorneys for major league baseball owners and players huddled today, attempting to speed up the court battle that could determine the future of the reserve clause.
