title: Planning in Queens
description: The first tests of the city's planning vision against its hard economic realities are beginning to appear. The temptationand the needto encourage construction, as an investment act of faith and source of city revenue, are clearly great. So great, in fact, that projects may look good now that, in ordinary times, would surely look bad; and measuring them against longterm goals beginning to be considered a luxury that the city cannot afford. That is an attitude certain to sell New York short and create problems for the future.

title: A.T.&;T. President to Retire
description: In a surprise action, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a series of executive cnanges, including the early retirement of its president, Robert D. Lilley. and the election of two vice chairmen.

title: Chess: Here We Go Again! (Guess Who's Likely to Be Absent)
description: The European Zonal B Tournament in Barcelona was won by Genna Sosonko of the Netherlands, who finished a half point ahead of Jesus Diez del Corral of Spain, the secondprize winner. These two players thus qualified for berths in the twin Interzonal Tournaments to be held this summer in Switzerland and the Philippines.

title: Ford Shuffles SpeechWriting Staff, Reportedly in Anger Over Its Quality
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Ford, reportedly unhappy with the quality of his speeches, has reshuffled his speechwriting staff, the White House disclosed today.

title: Colonels Rally to Beat Nets
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 21 (UPI)Artis Gilmore and Maurice Lucas sparked a winning Kentucky surge in the final 3 minutes tonight that produced a 10091 Colonels victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game.

title: The House of Faussner Judges Rottweilers Here
description: For more than half a century the name of Faussner has been associated with Rottweilers in Germany. :My father, who is 72 years old, is one of the oldest members of the German Rottweiler Club, said Willi Faussner. As long as I can remember we had one or two in the house. In every photo of me as a child, there's always a Rottweiler in the picture.

title: Needed Surgery

title: Colson Tells of a Midnight Phone Call From Nixon
description: A midnight telephone call in December 1973 by President Nixonworried that he might be wiped out financially if he fought an impeachment, fearful also of possible jailingis described in a forthcoming book by his former special counsel. Charles W. Colson.

title: Personal Finance

description: Laurence Olivier will be the artistic director and host of a series of dramas by 20thcentury American playwrights to be produced by Granada Television of Britain and carried here by NBCTV as A Tribute to American Theater.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 21 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors defeated Sid Ball of Australia, 63, 6.1, in a secondround match tonight in the Birmingham indoor tennis tournament.

title: CONCORDES BEGIN SUPERSONIC RUNS
description: BAHRAIN, Jan. 21  Two Concorde jets, taking off simultaneously from London and Paris, today inaugurated the world's first scheduled supersonic passenger services.

title: City Begins New RentSubsidy Program
description: The City Housing Authority announced yesterday that, effective immediately, it would begin receiving applications for rent subsidies to be given to lowincome and moderateincome families in privately owned housing.

title: 3 Lancia Stratos in Monte Carlo Lead
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 21 (AP)Three Italian Lancia Stratos cars held a solid lead in the 44th Monte Carlo rally today. A wrong decision on tires had cost Italy's Sandro Munari and Silvio Maiga the lead they had held throughout the event. But Munari, the 1975 winner, fought back into the lead again on the next speed test.

title: People and Business:
description: Mitchell P. Kobelinski, who is President Ford's choice to head the Small Business Administration, said yesterday that he would refuse the nomination if he had to sell his stock in two Chicago banks, as a Senate committee may demand.

title: Musselman Is Victim of Policy
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 21 (AP)Bill Musselman's nineweek stint as coach of the Virginia Squires has ended after differences with both the players and the front office.

title: FLUTES BRIGHTEN CHAMBER CONCERT
description: Tuesday evening's concert of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall concentrated on music for two flutes. The flutists were JeanPierre Rampal, the reigning international idol of the instrument, and Eugenia Zuker man; Paula Robison, the society's regular flutist, was nowhere to be seen or heard.

title: Inquiry on a Dannemora Suicide Calls Guard Action Inexcusable
description: ALBANY, Jan, 21The State Commission of Correction, in an investigation made public today, concluded that an inmate who hanged himself three months ago at the Clinton State Correctional facility in Dannemora had tried unsuccessfully to kill himself moments earlier and had been left without supervision even after he told; guards that he would try to kill himself again.

title: Article 3  No Title
Books of The Times
description: Monday, Jan. 19, 1976, NoonBrighl bracing, cold winter dtty. House toasay warm. Stock market moving up. Knicks doing well. Things seem in place. And here's Otto Friedrich's Going Crazy. An Inquiry Into Madness in Our Time to read. Grim subject, maybe. One we used to argue about endlessly and fruitlessly on dateless Saturday nights m the dormitory. What is sanity, insanity? Who knew? But Otto Friedrich. novrsenior editor at Time magazine, lively, inquisitive reporter. Liked Decline and Fall, about the death of The Saturday Evening Post. Didn't mind Before the Deluge, about Berlin in the 1920's. Besides, nothing so titillating as reading about other people's troubles. Looks interesting.

title: Self-Indulgence Is Triumphant in '92 in the Shade'
description: Thomas McGuane's "92 in the Shade" is subtle and lively. Parts of its are overbrilliant, if anything, in that they compel our pleasure almost to the point of distracting. By the time it ends, we have unmistakably been entertained. Perhaps we have been mildly poisoned, as well.Mr. McGuane, a novelist turned screen writer and director, has set his movie in the charter-boat, fishing-guide world of Key West, Fla. The blues and greens, the heat, the wilting paint hint at corruption. Under the film's humor and momentum there is also corruption. But the whole thing is so finely tuned, so edgily balanced that it's hard to say whether corruption is merely the theme or shades over into the viewpoint as well.The film, which opened yesterday at Showcase theaters, uses a disarrayed and drifting child of plenty as its protagonist. Peter Fonda plays him as a human desert planted with expensive flowers. He is self-indulgent and cold, disconnected and rich.His name is Tom Skelton. His grandfather owns the bank, the police force and a vast supply of earthness. His father has retreated semi-permanently into a kind of outdoor crib  shades of "Baby Doll"set out on the front porch. Tom takes a candlelit bath with a braless schoolteacher and suddenly decides that he is going to find something to do.What he does is move his cloudy self-indulgence into a rough and real world, that of the boat captains who take tourists out fishing. They are hard, self-made men, at once competitive and clannish, and with no liking for a rich kid who tries to break into their business.It is in its portrayal of these men that the movie moves from languid wit into something stronger. There is Nicholas Dance, a violent, primitive man with a rough code of honor that consists, as he puts it, in maintaining his "credence." There is Carter, cleverer, and quicker to see the threat to his struggling lifestyle posed by Tom.Dance and Carter, in an act of half-playful, half-serious hazing, steal Tom's first client. Tom's detachment dissolves totally. He's never reacted to anything; now he overreacts viciously by burning Dance's boat.Dance, played with marvelous strength and a kind of baffled sweetness by Warren Oates, tries to puzzle out the rights and wrongs. Egged on by Carteranother splendid performance by Harry Dean Stantonhe decides that even though he likes Tom and has wronged him, the reprisal is out of all measure.To maintain his "credence," he warns Tom, he will shoot him if he continues to work as a fishing guide. Tom ignores him. He gets money from his grandfather and orders a boat built that is far grander than anything Carter or Dance have been able to buy. He takes out a touristsent to him by Carter, who wants to see him deadand there is a showdown.The showdown is more ironic than tragic. Quite coldly, in fact, this pseudo flower-child has used the old weapons of money and positionhis grandfather'sto get his way. It is an ending with uneasy implications. Tom has been portrayed with charm as well as irony and there is an overwhelming desire not to see him shot dead. But it is he, fundamentally, who is the aggressor and the bully.As in "Rancho DeLuxe," which he wrote, although he didn't direct it, Mr. McGuane captures the speech and style of young people who are funny and charming and empty and mean. "92" maintains some of the disquieting ambiguity of viewpoint that weakened "Rancho." But it's a more satisfying picture.The authenticity of Carter and Dance sets off the emptiness at the center of Tom, and gives us a focus to sense it. So does a line by Tom's invalid father who warns his son that, for Dance, the showdown is a matter of honor. "It's a matter of who gets to fish and who gets to cut bait," says Tom, shrugging the notion off. "You and your generation have a depraved sense of language," says his father.

title: Iberia Curtails Flights
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Iberia Air Lines of Spain, citing reduced passenger revenues and increasing fuel prices, will close its operations at Logan. International Airport on Feb. 1. A spokesman said the airline's operation in Washington also would close, and all flights would be to and from New York.

title: Taft Winding. Up. A Success Story
description: Taft's first step in defending its Public Schools Athletic League basketball title is almost complete. The Blue Devils seem certain of capturing the Bronx Division II crown and gain High ing a spot in the playoffs. With all School five of last sea, Sports son's starters having been graduated, Taft's success is sure prising. The Blue Devils have met with some failure (they lost their first league. game in two years), but they have won nine games and lost one in the league and lead secondplace Stevenson by two games.

title: Medicare
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The new Administration proposal to help ease the burden of catastrophic illness for the elderly and the disabled may benefit about three million persons at an extra cost to several million others.

title: Sing Out, America
description: Since song, in its various manifestations, is one of the most direct expressions of a people and its culture, the Town Hall series called Sing Out, America, which opened on Tuesday night, is one of the more valuable local salutes to the Bicentennial. The

title: MARCOS PUTS OFF PHILIPPINES VOTING
description: MANILA, Jan. 21President Ferdinand E. Marcos today created a national people's council to advise him on legislative matters under his martial. law rule and announced that there would be no elections in the immediate future.

title: 92 Wardlaw Takes Dash; Iron Bit 2d
description: The snow had covered the slush in the parking lots by the third race. By the fifth, horses running down the backstretch had disappeared from view behind a winter's scene. It was only At the the third Wednesday of January Race at Aqueduct yesTracks terday and the talk was already of that first Saturday in May at Churchill Downs.

title: Ford and Truman Briefings on Budget: How a President Takes a Case to Public
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 When President Ford conducted his press briefing yesterday on the new budget, he was the first President to do so since Harry S. Truman, and the event put into focus some changes that have occurred in 23 years.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP; OTC SHOWS RISE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday, while those in the overthecounter market closed higher.

title: Same System of Rating Banks Used by Fed and Comptroller
description: The Federal Reserve System and the Comptroller the Currency employ an identical system of rating banks, using an intricate code that consists of two digits and two letters. The highest possible code rating for a bank would be 1AS/1. The lowest would be 4DP/4.

title: St. John's Maryland Upset
description: NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 21 (UPI)Beaver Smith hit a 15foot. jump shot in the final two minutes of play tonight to give St. John's a 5351 basketball victory over Boston College.

description: You could have knocked me down with a bridge girdereven demolished me with a feather. Here was Andre Gregory's experimental theater company, the Manhattan Project, resident at Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival's Lafayette Street complex, presenting a poor 1930'sstyle comedy today. Well, at least last nightand its home in Mr. Papp's Martinson Theater.

title: Budget Book Holds the Line
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI)  President Ford outlined a holdtheline budget for the fiscal year 1977 today, and the budget book itself reflected that. The price for this year's detailed budget hook is $19.20, same as a year ago.

title: ITALY IS SHOWING STRAIN OF CRISIS
description: Rome. Jan. 21The political crisis here, now three weeks old, is generating new economic and social tensions and shows no signs of easing.

title: New Massachusetts Justice
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP)Gov. Michael S. Dukakis swore in Edward F. Hennessey as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court today. Justice Hennessey, associate justice since 1971 replaces G. Joseph Tauro, who retired Jan. 10.

title: Soviet Reported to Let 5 Study for Rabbinate Here
description: The leader of an interfaith foundation reported yesterday that the Soviet Union had agreed to allow five Soviet Jews to study for the rabbinate at Yeshiva University here.

title: WHITE HOUSE FUNDS REFLECT STAFF CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Ford's proposed budget indicates he is making good on his promise to cut the size of the White House staff.

title: The Kid Brother at Super Bowl III
description: When the New York Jets won Super Bowl III, none enjoyed the victory more than Paul (Rocky) Rochester, 250pound defensive tackle with a quick laugh. But the 167 upset of the Baltimore Colts had provided only share of his happiness. In the days before the game, he had glowed because of the companionship of his kid brother Phil, then 17 years old. Slim, with a thin mustache, Phil Rochester had a shy, somewhat lost look about him. He had run away from his Grand Rapids, Mich., home several weeks earlier. But among the Jets he Sports appeared to realize that he needed a purpose in his life. After that, he attended colof lege briefly, served in Vietnam, worked The Time farm, then moved with his wife and daughter to a Job on the Alaskan pipeline. But last Sunday, when the Pittsburgh Stealers won Super Bowl X, he was found dead, a suicide, in a lonely cabin in Glenalien, Alaska, not far from Anchorage.

title: Monsanto Earnings Rise 70.6% in 4th Quarter
description: The Monsanto Company, producers of chemicals, textiles and consumer products, reported yesterday that fourthquarter earnings were up 70.6 percent, but that the net for all of last year was down 5.4 percent, reflecting declines in the second and third quarters.

title: MARY A. BROOKS
description: Mary A. Brooks, the mother of George A. Brooks, retired Secretary of the General Motors Corporation, died Tuesday t her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. she was 99 years old.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect, The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

description: Leon Greenberg, who was president of Monticello Raceway, was fined $9,000 yesterday for fraudulently using $4,856 of the raceway's money to pay for his son's har mitzvah at Grossinger's the resort hotel in the Catskils.

description: Outgoing

The name of the holding company's lead bank has also been added.

title: Cancer Unit Gets No Fund Rise For the First Time Since 1965
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21For the first time in more than a decade, a new proposed Federal budget contains no increase in appropriation for the National Cancer Institute, the agency that manages the nation's research war against cancer.

title: Defendant Testifies in Slaying of L.I. Court Aide
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 21Taking the stand in her own defense, Jo Anne Brown startled the courtroom today when she replied yes and no, when asked if she had killed Burr Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived in Uniondale.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan 21Following is the text of a working paper prepared by nonaligned countries and others and circulated today to members of the Security Council by the Council, President:

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Boafd, charged today that the nation's banking system could be damaged if Congress subpoenaed hank examiners reports on the Chase Manhattan and First National City Banks.

title: Elizabeth Police and Firemen Fighting Cutbacks
description: ELIZABETH, Jan. 21The heads of the police and firemen s unions said today that they would circulate petitions among registered voters herein an effort to defeat four ordinances calling for the laying off of 16 patrolmen and nine firemen and for the demotion of 26 superior officers in the two departments.

title: GRAIN INQUIRY CHIEF WARNS OF PENALTIES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21Under Secretary of Agriculture John A. Knebel says that the department is considering stripping a Louisiana government agency of its authority to inspect grain.

title: Democrats Will Fix Acceptance Timing
description: Determined to avoid a repetition of 1972, when squabbling on the convention floor pushed their Presidential candidate's speech into the early morning hours, Democratic Party officials have decided to put that Rey speech into prime television time this year no matter what else has to be postponed.

title: STATE HAS UNITS IN FIVE COUNTRIES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21New York State maintains an official presence in five foreign countries through offices that develop educational materials, promote tourism and economic development in the state, boost state businesses to potential overseas companies or examine foreign branches of state banks.

title: Swiss Girl, 17, Takes Downhill in World Cup
description: BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 21 (UPI)Doris De Agostini surprised the favorites by winning a World Cup downhill ski race on what looked like a tourists powder slope rather than a racing course.

title: Bridge:
description: For the first time in its long history, the oldest and most famous bridge club in the world, New York's Cavendish Club, has elected a woman as an honorary member. Rose Loewenthal, wife of a New York expert, Ed Loewenthal, was honored last month at a meeting of the club's board of directors in recognition of her notable service as president of the Cavendish Ladies Duplicate Club.

title: Edward Wallace, Trial Lawyer, Weil, Gotshal Partner, Is Dead,
description: Edward Corbett Wallace, trial lawyer here for more than 40 years and a partner in Weil, Gotshal & Manges, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: Opera: Barber of Met
description: Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia, which had its fifth performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera or Tuesday night, is one of the supreme challenges of sny company's ensemble nlaying. Like some Mozart operas, the Barber requires extraordinary cohesion and group orecision, as well as individual talent and hounding vitality from the entire cast.

title: 2D JUDGE IS ADDED TO HAMMER'S TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) A second Federal judge has been assigned the task of deciding if Armand Hammer, the inoustrialist, is sincere in pleading guilty to campaign law violations, it was disclosed today.

title: Plan to Drill for Oil in Park Creates Dispute in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 21What would happen if a big oil company announced plans to drill some wildcat oil wells in New York's Central Park? Well, the roadshow version of just such a saga is trying out in Houston.

title: 75 Prices Up 7% For Smallest Rise Over Last 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Consumer Price Index rose again in December but at a slower rate than in the two preceding months, making an overall rise of 7 percent for 1975, the Labor Department reported today. This was the smallest annual increase since 1972, when prices rose 3.4 percent.

title: MIDEAST PROPOSAL IN U.N. IS SOFTENED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 22Some Security Council members headed by Tanzania today circulated a softened proposal for a Middle East resolution that would call for Israel's withdrawal from all occupied Arab territories and affirm Palestinian rights to an inde, pendent state in Palestine.

title: Boycotting Parents Want Funds Used For Private Schools
description: A group of parents who have kept 11 children out of city schools since September in the belief the education provided there is harmful and destructive, pressed the Board of Education yesterday to give the money it would have spent on the children to schools of the parents choice.

title: WAR IN LEBANON SPREADS AS SYRIA SEEKS A SOLUTION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Jan. 22Palestinian guerrillas and their Lebanese Moslem and leftist allies pressed their offensive in several parts of the country yesterday as a highlevel Syrian mediation mission arrived in Beirut.

title: W .T.Grant Is Planning New Outlook for Stores
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which has still to propose formally a repayment plan for its $1 billion debts under its Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings, is laying the ground work for a new Grant's, which its management hopes will put it into the black in 1977.

description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 21 President Ford's budget and accompanying documents indicated today that whatever the deficit in the budget for fiscal 1977 finally turns out to be, the Treasury will have to borrow about $10 billion more than that amount in the market to finance various offbudget expenses of the Government.

The correct figure is $8,395, 17 percent higher than reported in the 1970 census.

description: Dr. S. Evans Ganz, an ear, nose and throat surgeon and teacher, died Monday evening at Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 300 East 74th Street.

description: LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP)The dollar gained strength today in Europe, aided by weakness in the Italian lira and French franc. Gold inched up a bit on European bullion exchanges but was far from recouping yesterday's sharp losses.

title: GOLD CONTRACTS DECLINE AGAIN
description: After a sharp twoday decline in gold futures, the February delivery closed yesterday at $123 7!10 an ounce, off only 40 cents for the day on the Commodity Exchange. On Monday and Tuesday the price decline totaled $7 an ounce.

title: F.D.A. Chief Suspicious of Estrogens
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 21 Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Alexander M. Schmidt told a Senate subcommittee today that he believed there was very strong evidence linking the estrogen compounds prescribed for millions of postmenopausal women to cases of cancer of the lining of the uterus.

title: Australia Reinstates God Save the Queen
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP)  Australia's new Liberal Party Government today restored God Save the Queen as an Australian national anthem.

title: DYE MANUFACTURER TO FIGHT F.D.A. BAN
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21 (AP)A major producer of the red food dye banned by the Food and Drug Administration has challenged a Government contention that the dye might be cancer causing agent.

title: Sanford Is Leaving Presidential Race; Realities Are Citec
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21  Terry Sanford, president of Duke University and former Governor of North Carolina, has decided to drop out of the race for the Democratic nomination for President. The decision, disclosed by a source close to Mr. Sanford, was described as based on the political realities

title: M'GOVERN ASSERTS VIETNAM WANTS TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (Reu ters)Senator George McGovern, back from trips to Saigon and Hanoi, said today that Vietnamese leaders appeared eager to open peaceful relations with the United States, and otter countries.

title: Market Place
description: On Tuesday, while 315 issues on the New York Stock Exchange ranging from Air Products to Woolworth were posting their best prices of 197576, only one stock sank to its low for that period. It was Rosario Resources, a producer of silver and gold.

title: HEATING OIL STOCKS SHOW A SHARP DROP
description: Stocks of distillate oil fell sharply in the latest week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Screen: Placid Studies
description: Art sometimes may be the end result of devotion to a specific style. And, the three short silent films by Barry Gerson, which began a week's run yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, are stamped by a distinctly personal point of view on the interplay of images, color and movement. But if the manmade and natural subjects he lovingly focuses on do not have a shattering impact, they are notable for an unflagging concentration on familiar objects that eventually, if somewhat tediously, emerge as artful compositions.

title: 4 News Agencies of India Agree to Plan for Merger
description: NEW DELHI. Jan. 21 (Reutors)India's four news agencies have reached agreement in principle on government plans for them to merge into a single national news agency, reportedly within six months.

title: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: UPPER NYACK, N.Y.Their shiny new fire engine arrived just before Thanksgiving, and the people. of this community of 850 could hardly believe their eyes.

title: Many Fail to Claim T heir $30 Tax Credit And Second Benefit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Many taxpayers throughout the country are apparently failing to claim the special $30 tax credit per family member that they are entitled to on the 1975 tax returns.

title: Protection for Buyers Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) The House voted 369 to 18 today to impose prison terms on anyone convicted of tampering with the mileage recording devices on automobiles. The measure, which was sent to the Senate. would provide for one year in prison or a maximum $50,000 fine, or both, on conviction of altering a car's odometer to deceive a prospective buyer.

title: FRANK N. IRWIN, 73, TIMES REWRITEMAN
description: Frank N. Irwin, who retired as a rewriteman for The New York Times in January 1970 after 45 years service, died yesterday in the Sands Point Nursing Home, Port Washington., L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: International Paper Lifts Newsprint
description: The International Paper Company, the country's largest paper producer and a major source of newsprint, announced yesterday an increase of $25 a ton in newsprint, effective March 1 The new price will be $285 per ton. In midDecember, the Great Northern Nekoose Company of Stamford, Connn, raised its newsprint prices by $20 a ton, making its new price $280, also effective March 1.

title: Open Interest
Syria and Arafat, in Arabs Eyes, Are Real Winners in Lebanon
description: CAIRO, Jan. 22Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization are emerging as the real winners in the Lebanese civil war, in the view of most Arab diplomats and other informed sources. Syria, in this view, has greatly enhanced its poli

title: RAY B. WALKER
description: Ray B. Walker, retired principal of the Pocantico Hills School in North Tarrytown, N.Y., died Wednesday at his home in South Salem. N.Y. He was 96 years'old.

title: Luanda Confident
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 22 This is now a selfconfident city.

title: Court to Review Death Penalty Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The Supreme Court opened the way today for a broad and historic ruling on when, if ever, it is constitutional to impose the death penalty.

title: SHOP TALK
description: On an offbeat sidestreet of Manhattan's Upper East Side a quiet artist is creating imaginative jewelry at reasonable prices and, what is more, is making pieces to order, in consultation with customers who want to be involved with the designing.

title: Twin's 1975 Losses Are Put at $136,000
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 22 (UPI) The Minnesota Twins lost $136,000 in 1975, less than half the loss predicted at season's end by Calvin Griffith, the club president. Griffith had projected a loss of $400,000 on home attendance of 737,000.

title: Schaefer, the Last of City's Breweries, To Close Its Plant Here as Too Costly
description: The F and M Schaefer Brewing Company, the last brewery in New York, announced yesterday that it would close its plant here, a move that will bring a loss of 850 jobs.

title: Miss Evert 3Set Victor; Dates Ford's Son Again
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 22 (UPI)Topseeded Chris Evert outlasted Betty Stove of the Netherlands, 62, 46, 61, tonight and advanced to the quarterfinals of a $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternate  side  of  the  street regulations are normally in effect. The regulations have been suspended because of snow. However, other park. ing and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Beanie Raises Poisibility Of Fresh Cuts in Budget
description: Mayor Beame raised the possibility of fresh budget cuts for the city yesterday as he estimated that the twomonthold emergency financial plan was already running significantly behind in revenues and ahead in expenses.

Ford's Labor Choice
description: In recent labor negotiations that were being mediated by W. J. Usery Jr., the union negotiators were advised before a session, Watch out for Usery. He's

title: Durable Orders Dip Again,
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods drifted downward in December and have shown no real strength since August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CARSON JURY TOLD OF 74 TESTIMONY
description: The prosecutor at the murder trial of Robert C. [Sonny] Carson told the jury yesterday that five of the six defendants had previously admitted being involved in events that led to the murder of a 34yearold Brooklyn man.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Potvins Score 5 Goals As Islanders Win, 81
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 22 When Jean Potvin's wife, Lorraine, asked him this afternoon how long it had been since he had scored a goal, Jean's answer was, Don't ask. It had been a month and a half.

title: Vatican Paper Says Article Assailing Israel Was Error
description: ROME. Jan. 22 (AP) The deputy director of the Vatican's paper, L'Osservatore Romano, said the paper's publication of an article critical of Jerusalem city authorities and their town planning had been a staffer's mistake.

title: G.A.O Is Expected to Ask Federal Grain Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The General Accounting Office, in an investigative report to Congress. will urge creation of an allFederal grain inspection system, saying that nothing short of complete reform can prevent scandals of the kind exposed recently in a broad investigation of corruption in the industry.

title: Depression Among Women Is Found Rising
description: CHERRY HILL, Jan. 22 A new study for the National Institute of Mental Health has found that depression among women is rising rapidly in the United States compared with depression among men.

title: GEORGE W. EMLEN
description: George W. Emlen, who in 1922 founded Emlen & Co., a major Philadelphia real estate concern, died Wednesday in Philadelphia, He was 88 years old and lived there.

title: Lake Survey Unit to Close
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP)The Detroitbased United States Lake Survey Center will close June 30 after more than 135 years of providing charts and maps to Great Lakes sailors, the agency said today.

title: Seychelles to Gain Freedom in June
description: LONDON, Jan. 22 (UPI)Britain agreed today to grant independence to one of its last remaining colonial possessionsthe tiny but strategically important Seychelles Islands group in the Indian Ocean.

title: U.C.L.A. Scores on 2dHalf Rally
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (UPI)Richard Washington scored 19 of his 27 points in the second half tonight as seventh  ranked U.C.L.A. overcame a halftime deficit and defeated the University of California, Santa Barbara, 6450, in a nonconference basketball game.

title: ITALY SEEKS HELP TO BOLSTER LIRA
description: ROME; Jan. 22In dramatic moves to bolster the sinking lira, Italy sought help today from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and West Germany.

title: Lisbon Resumes Airlift of Refugees From Angola
description: LISBON, Jan. 22Portugal resumed today its airlift to evacuate refugees fleeing the guerilla war in its former colony of Angola.

title: Cold and High Winds Beset the City Area
description: A bitter cold wave high wind swept through the metropolitan area last night and early this morning with temperatures near zero.

title: Two RightHanders for Cooperstown
description: Two righthanders were voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame yesterday on their credentials as competitors, but they both deserve to be advertisements for the preservation of a pitching arm until it and the head attached to it have matured. Robin Roberts went to Michigan State as a basketball player and was thinking about becoming a basketball coach until the Philadelphia Phillies signed him for a $25,000 bonus. If you start pitching at too young an age, he says, you can develop hangups. Bob Lemon thought he could play third base for the Cleveland Indians until I saw Kenny Keltner play it, Men he thought he was a center fielder until he saw his batting average skid to .180. But he doesn't regret being 27 years old before he concentrated on pitching, You never know, he says. if I pitched in the minor leagues, I might've come up with a sore arm. Their thinking is as positive as their career total of victories286 for Robin Roberts over 19 seasons, 207 for Bob Lemon over 13 seasons.

title: Bond Rater Says Exclusion Of City May Last 20 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)The bond market may be reopened to New York State this spring while remaining closed to New York City for possibly as long as 20 years, the head of a major bond rating service told Congress today.

title: Carter in Iowa
description: As long as racial segregation and discrimination were primarily a Southern regional problem, the rest of the nation exercised a silent veto against a white Southerner in the Presidency. The strong showing of former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter in the Iowa Democratic caucuses is a significant event because it demonstrates that this invisible barrier has now fallen.

title: FOREIGN COMPANIES CUT SPENDING PLANS
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that foreign companies sharply reduced their plans in 1975 to invest in manufacturing in the United States

description: Las Vegas, Nev.  Antonio Leyva, 145 pounds. Tucson, Ariz., outpointed Rocky DiFazio, 149 Chicago, 10 rounds.

title: S.E.C. Subpoenas Officials in Study Of City Bond Sales
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed two New York City officials and a number of other persons, including bankers and brokers, in its Investigation of possible fraud in the sale of the city's securities, industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Family Doctors Joining Coast Malpractice Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (AP) Some family doctors began a twoday strike today in sympathy with surgeons and other specialists in the Los Angeles area who are in the 22d day of a slowdown protesting spiraling malpractice insurance, rates.

title: CITY UNIVERSITY FACES JOB ACTION
description: The delegate assembly of the City University faculty, angered by the university's plan to place all employees on a fourweek payless furlough, voted 43 to 6 last night in favor of a leadership recommendation that all members stay away from work after the furlough to make up for any reductions in their paychecks.

title: MESSAGE BY FORD DROPS 2 ATTACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Language attacking the effectiveness of Federal programs aimed at reducing pollution and improving the health and safety of workers has been deleted from President Ford's Economic Message, which is scheduled to be sent to Congress early next week.

description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials for the latest week was 191.4, unchanged from last week.

title: Electric Company Is Fined
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP)Probate Judge Ralph Locher fined the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company $7,400 yesterday for contemptofcourt and ordered the utility to replace 15 trees in the Cuyahoga Valley National Park. The Ohio Department of Natural Resources said the company had cleared land and installed utillity poles.

title: 5 Listed as C.I.A. Agents By British Socialist Paper
description: LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)The Socialist Worker, a small leftwing newspaper, published the names and addresses yesterday of five men it said were Central Intelligence Agency employees working in London. The report said one of the men was the C.I.A. chief of station.

description: Forget, for a moment, the buzzing confusion that greets infants at birth, and consider instead the rude awakening some parents experiencewhen they learn what childbirth costs.

title: Rabin to Address Congress
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 22 (AP) Prime Minister Titzhak Rabin of Israel is scheduled to address a joint session of Congress next Wednesday, the Speaker's office announced today. President Anwar alSadat of Egypt spoke before a joint session of Congress late last year.

title: A Pig's Heart Is Used In Surgery on Boy, 8
description: An 8yearold Queens boy born with less than a full heart was released from Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center, New Hyde Park Division, after doctors there had rebuilt the organ with parts of a pig's heart.

title: House Will Call Witnesses On Interception of Cables
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) The House Government Operations Committeee voted today to subpoena three major telegraphic companies and four former or present F.B.I. agents to testify on interception of cables by Federal intelligence agencies.

title: BEIRUT ANNOUNCES PEACE AGREEMENT IN FACTIONAL WAR
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22A political and military agreement, underwritten by Syria, to bring an end to Lebanon's ninemonth civil war was announced today as fighting continued, in many parts of the country.

title: Pro Bowl Will Go On As Planned
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP)A threat that the National Football League players would boycott the Pro Bowl on Monday night was removed tonight when about 50 players voted not to take a strike vote.

title: Rise in City Convention Business Held Periled by Cutback in Fund
description: New York did good convention business in 1975 and can expect to do even better this year. the Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday, but it warned that prospects for 1977 through 1980 were imperiled by a sharp cut in city financing for the bureau's promotional activities.

description: Another reduction in the prime lending rate of commercial banks is expected to spread across the country within the next few days, based on money market trends confirmed in the weekly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: TEXACO'S PROFITS ARE OFF SHARPLY
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday sharply, lower profits for the final quarter of 1975 and for the entire year while the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported an improvement in profits for the last threemonth period but a decline for the year.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The economists of various persuasions are now producing their mystifying clarifications of President Ford's State of the Union address and budget, but the politicians of both parties seem to agree that he has produced a couple of fairly effective campaign documents.

title: EXECUTIVE IS HELD IN A PLOT IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Jan. 22A tale of corporate intrigue involving theft, kidnapping, an explosion and apparent plots in the board room is unfolding at the biggest recorddistribution company in France.

description: MADRID, Jan. 22Spanish and American negotiators were believed to have reached virtual agreement today on a new defense accord that would allow continued United States use of military bases here in return for increased military and other credits.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan 22Security Council members began intensive private consultations today on a revised resolution affirming the Palestinians right to an independent state and also advocating that the security of all states in the areaIsrael ob viously one of thembe guaranteed.

description: UNION CITY, San. 22The Federal Bureau of Investigation today join the inquiry into the shooting of a former municipal magistrate who was attacked yesterday as he entered his law office on Bergenline Avenue between 48th and 49th Streets.

title: Bridge:

I. The veteran expert Morrie Elis of Oceanside, L. I, reports that it took place at the Federal Savings Bank of Long Beach.

title: Sanford Expected to Announce Withdrawal From Race Today
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 22Terry Sanford, the former Governor of North Carolina, has called a news conference for 1 P.M. tomorrow at which he is expected to withdraw formally as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: You don't have to be a restaurant reporter with a mailbag full of letters from readers telling of horrible times they have had in restaurants you have liked, or beautiful experiences in restaurants whose names make you shudder, to know that consistency of performance is the rarest of restaurant virtues. Dozens of variables, with the number and character of the diners as a major one, affect the personality of a restaurant at any given meal.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Profit taking weakened many issues yesterday as prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished mixed.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The number of state  chartered problem banks selected for closer supervision by the Feder al Reserve Board increased by onethird from 1973 to 1974.

description: Sales and earnings of the General Electric Company, reached new highs in the fourth quarter of 1975, Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the company, reported yesterday.

description: Soybean oil futures dropped the daily limit in most deliveries on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, dragging soybean prices sharply lower.

title: BACHE TO RESCIND TRADES IN GEICO
description: In the wake of stunning losses reported by the Government Employees. Insurance, Company. Bache & Company, has wired clients who participated in its recent offering of 100.000 Geico shares that it is willing to rescind the trades.

description: ENGLEWOOD. Jan. 22Assemblyman Byron M. Baer is happy.

title: 2 CHILDREN'S BOOKS CAPTURE TOP PRIZES
description: The American Library Association announced yesterday at its midwinter meeting in Chicago that a Brooklyn couple and an expatriate Englishwoman have won the association's principal prizes for children's literature published in 1975.

title: Kraftco Net a Record Others Report
description: The Kraftco Corporation, the world's largest processor of packaged food products, yesterday reported record profits that were up 79.8 percent and 47.51 percent for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, respectively.

title: Senators Urge That Ford Play a Beirut Peace Role
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (Reuters)The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations adopted a resolution today urging President Ford to use his good offices to try to end the civil strife in Lebanon.

title: Nicklaus, Morley Tied at 67
Huambo Gloomy
description: HUAMBO, Angola, Jan. 21 The streets are nearly deserted, except for a few cars racing recklessly, their tires squealing. Most shops are closed; those that occasionally open have little to sell.

title: Straits of New York
description: CHICAGOThe true New York metropolitan area should include not only New York City as delineated by its political boundaries but also adjoining New York counties, areas in northeastern New Jersey and those parts of Connecticut covered by railroad commutation tickets.

title: Prof. C. W. Barlow of Clark; Classicist and Geneologist
description: Claude W. Barlow. professor of classics at Clark University from 1947 to 1972, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Worcester, Mass. He was 68 years old.

title: Meeting on Hospital Cuts Is Disrupted
description: Angry, shouting protesters brushed past police barriers, kicked a hole in a door and stormed into an executive session of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which was considering the closing of hospitals in the deepening fiscal crisis.

title: Weekend Outlook for Skiers: Warmer
description: weather experts had good news for skiers yesterday. Although the thermometer in the metropolitan New York region last night was around the zero mark and the windchill factor at such exposed elevations as New Hampshire's Tuckerman Ravine was estimated at 69 below, forecasters were predicting a Warmer weekend.

title: Press Group in Congress Elects Two to Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Richard L. Madden of The New York Times and Leonard Larsen of The Denver Post were elected today to the Standing Committee of Correspondents, the governing body of the Senate and House press galleries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Estimate delayed zoning approval for a proposed $150 million, privately financed complex of condominiums, stores, offices and parking space in Rego Park, Queens. The development, to be known as the Galleria at Forest Gardens, had received a 4 to 3 favorable vote in the City Planning Commission last month, While it is favored in principle by most Rego Park community groups, a strong campaign against the project has been mounted by businessmen and civic leaders representing nearby Jamaica, supported by the Regional Plan Association. The Jamaica interests are concerned because their own business district is badly languishing.

title: LongDelayed Chicago Civil Suit On Black Panther Raid Is Begun
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22After more than five years of legal disputes, a civil suit against Edward V. Hanrahan, former Cook County State's Attorney, and other county and Federal officials involved in a raid on a Black Panther headquarters in 1969 was finally under way here today.

title: Market Place
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, which stunned its shareholders (and investors in utility stocks generally) in April 1974 when it omitted its 45cent quarterly dividend, now appears to be on the comeback trail.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
Plant Costs Termed Underestimated
description: BOSTON, Jan. 22  Utility companies and Federal agencies have consistently underestimated the costs of building, nuclear energy plants, according to a Massachusetts state study released today.

title: Tiebreaker Is Rejected By N.C.A.A.
description: NASHVILLE. Tenn., Jan. 22 (UPI)The football rules committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tightened today the rules on spearing (punitive use of the helmet) liberalized rules on blocking and defeated a proposal to break tie games.

title: The Ballet
description: American Ballet Theater offered a surprisingly dull performance of La Sylphide Wednesday night at the Uris Theater as the season's first view of what is one of 19thcentury Romantic ballet's most poetic signature works.

title: About Real Estate
description: DALLAS  Builders from all over the country were here this week, hearing a fundamentally optimistic account of the prospects for housing production in the next two years.

title: Tenafly Group Is Fighting Woodland Preservation
description: TENAFLY, Jan. 22A group of residents, contending they represented a majority of Tenafly's population, has mounted a campaign opposing the borough's attempt to purchase 274 acres of Palisades woodland to preserve it in its natural state.

title: FOUNDATION HEAD INDICTED IN THEFTS
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22Harry A. Lowther Jr., head of the Phillips Research Foundation, was indicted today by a Du Page County grand jury on charges of stealing more than $160,000 from the defunct Lincoln Open University in suburban Lombard.

title: LILCO IS ACCUSED OF HIDING FACTS
description: The State Consumer Protection Board charged the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday with deliberately frustrating the board's inquiry into its productivity, efficiency and economy.

title: Chicago U. Chairman Retiring
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22Gaylord Donnelley, 65 years old, has announced that he plans to resign as chairman of the University of Chicago Board of Trustees this June. Mr. Donnelley, who retired last May as chairman of the hoard of the publishing concern R. I. Donnelley and Sons Company, has held the university post since 1970.

description: FRANKLIN, N. H., Jan. 21A burly old Hampshireman driving through the Franklin business district slowed his car today, leaned out the window and called to a town policeman trying to direct traffic in front of Raffaelly's Market on slushy Central Avenue: Hey, Bob! Better hold on to your walletthere's a politician in town!

title: Stage: A Papp Winner
