Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center, where it is being produced by Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, can be assured of an absorbing evening of theater.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday. London: Morning fixing $124.00, down $0.90; afternoon fixing $126.15, up $1.25. Paris: Afternoon market quotation $129.72, up $1.86.

title: Separation Is No License For Adultery, Judge Says
description: A. separation agreement between a husband and wife is no license for license, Justice Louis B. Heller ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Music: Previn Conducts
description: It seems de rigueur these days for conductors who are pianists to make at least one appearance conducting from the keyboard. It is a little ego trip that does not hurt anybody very badly except, once in a while, the composer. Last night Andre Previn, taking over the New York Philharmonic as guest conductor, did the honors from the keyboard in Mozart's C minor Piano Concerto.

title: The State of the City
description: Mayor Beame confirmed yesterday what close observers of the city's fiscal crisis have long suspectedthat the threeyear plan for restoring New York to solvency, which was approved by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board only last October, is already in deep trouble.

title: No  Title
Grumet to Investigate Nadjari's Charge Against Carey
description: Justice Jacob B. Grumet or State Supreme Conrt was appointed yesterday as a specia deputy attorney general to in vestigate allegations by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, that Governor Carey had acted to dismiss him because of political pres sures.

title: JACKSON PUSHES HEALTH PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Pledging to make health care a dominant issue in his campaign for the Presidency, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat, of Washington, called today for a national health insurance plan, extension of Medicare benefits, and Federal malpractice insurance for doctors.

title: Chief of Complaint Unit Moves to Keep It Alive
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 22The director of the city's Public Information and Complaints Office said today that he was willing to take a $5,500 cut in pay to keep his office functioning.

title: RALLY DEMANDS BAN ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22A crowd that the police estimated at 65,000 persons rallied outside the Capitol today in bitter cold weather to protest the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, and then went indoors to lobby for a constitutional amendment that would ban abortion.

title: Owner of Shelton Plant Acquitted in Arson Case
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 22Charles D. Moeller, the Ohio millionaire who was accused of arranging to have his own ailing factory in Shelton, Conn., blown up to collect the insurance on it, was acquitted today by a jury in United States District Court in New Haven.

title: Port Authority to Consider 34th St. Convention Center
description: The Port. Authority of New York and New Jersey will meet next week with the Trump Organization, which is seeking to develop the site of the Penn Central's 34th Street yards in conjunction with the. railroad, to study plans for building the New York City Convention Center there.

title: U.S.SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS ENDED; MODEST GAIN SEEN
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22  The United States and the Soviet Union concluded their highlevel arms control negotiations tonight with an American official asserting that there had been a considerable degree of progress, but acknowledging that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had failed to achieve his maximum goalan agreement in principle to cover all outstanding issues.

title: House Sets Hearing On Irving Loan Role
description: The House and Senate Banking Committees both announced yesterday that they would hold hearings in the near future on the involvement of the Irving Trust Company in a bid by the General Cable Corporation to take over Microdot Inc.

title: COURT VINDICATES A NUCLEAR PLANT
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that authority for the regulation of nuclear power plants was vested solely in the Federal Government and could not be superseded by the state.

title: Jersey Moves Up Night Racing
Grumet, an ExProsecutor, Reenters the Inquiry Field
description: No stranger to tough cases, Jacob B. Grumet helped to prosecute Waxey Gordon and Louis (Lepke) Buchalter when he worked on Thomas E. Dewey's rackets investigations in the 1930's.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS TO RISE 4% IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22American auto plants are scheduled to, build 175,338 cars this week, up 4 percent from last week's 168,616 and 62 percent ahead of the 108,232 cars built in the corresponding week last year.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 22The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest weel: totalled an estimated 14.5 billion tonmiles, 0.7 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 432,991 cars, 0.6 percent below last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 7.1 percent above last year.

title: TEAMSTER HEARD IN HOFFA INQUIRY
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22Stephen Andretta, a New Jersey teamster, appeared today before a Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and reportedly began to answer the jury's questions.

title: Julian B. Claff, 79. Owned Beekman Place Bookshop
description: Julian B. Claff, a bookseller who for more than 33 years operated the Beekman Place Bakeshop, 936 First Avenue, died Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 865 First Avenue.

title: About New York
description: New York is a city of separate tables. New York is a big bar mitzvah, where the relatives sit one place, the neighbors another place and the old friends and people from the office someplace else. No one is sure who's at any other table, although everyone feels more or less safe at his own.

title: GRUMET TO STUDY NADJARI'S CHARGE
description: Justice Jacob B. Grumet of the State Supreme Court was appointed yesterday as a special deputy attorney general to investigate allegations by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, that Governor Carey had acted to dismiss him because of political pressures.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 23, 1976

title: Helipad, Anybody? One Goes Begging On a Nixon Estate
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 22 (UPI)The General Services Administration sags it sold Richard M. Nixon's guardhouse to a Miami parking lot, but cannot find a buyer for the former President's $418,000 helicopter landing pad.

title: SHORT INTEREST RISES TO RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced that the short interest position in its listed shares totaled 27,142,200 shares as of Jan. 15, up 1,551,000 shares for the month. The total is a record high for the short interest.

title: Prosecuting for Leaks Difficult, Merola Says
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx testified yesterday that it was virtually impossible to prosecute indi viduals who unlawfully leaked grandjury information as long as journalists who published the leaks were not required to divulge their sources.

title: New Ownership of The Star Is Approved in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) Joe L. Allbritton has received final permision from the Federal Communications Commission for his takeover of The Washington Star and its parent company, the Washington Star Communications Inc.

title: Activity Is Limited
description: The credit market went into, a holding pattern yesterday as it waited for the Federal Reserve's financial data that is customarily released every Thursday afternoon and as it drew nearer to the Treasury's announcement of its February financing plans. Fixed  in come prices bounced up and down within narrow limits and closed with small declines

title: Phased State TakeOver Of Court Costs Is Urged
description: A breach of faith by the Federal Government has compounded New York City's fiscal problems and should be corrected, a panel headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: BEIRUT ANNOUNCES PEACE AGREEMENT IN FACTIONAL WAR
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22A political and military agreement, underwritten by Syria, to bring an end to Lebanon's ninemonth civil war was announced today as fighting continued in many parts of the country.

title: NEWS MEDIA PLAN ATTITUDE POLLS
description: A number of news organizations are once again using public opinion polls this election year to keep their readers, viewers and listeners informed.

title: A BUSY DAY AT PIANO FOR MISS CARROLL
description: Barbara Carroll, the jazz pianist, had a busy day on Wednesday. Late in the afternoon she performed in Town Hall's Interludes series, and in the evening she did her regular stint in the Bemelmans Bar of the Carlyle Hotel. In the process, she revealed two slightly different Barbara Carrolls.

title: Wasting Diplomacy
description: The Syrian peace initiative against Israel at the United Nations Security Council is foundering, overwhelmed not only by the acute crisis in Lebanon but also by the internal dynamics of interArab diplomacy.

title: U.S.SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS ENDED; MODEST GAIN SEEN
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22  The United States and the Soviet Union concluded their highlevel arms control negotiations tonight with an American official asserting that there had been a considerable degree of progress, but acknowledging that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had failed to achieve his maximum goalan agreement in principle to cover all outstanding issues.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: First of U.S. Team Assigned to Sinai Reach Their Station
description: TEL AVIV. Jan. 22  The vanguard of a United States mission that is to operate electronic listening posts between the Israeli and Egyptian lines in Sinai reached its station today.

title: Advertising:
description: It is genuinely a miracle, said David R. Altman, the nattily dressed chairman of Altman, Stoller, Weiss, as his doorknobsize cuff links glittered.

title: Business Briefs
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 22 (UPI)The historic role of the Bahamas as a corporate tax haven is coming an end as scores of locally incorporated companies announce their intention of shutting down before they are due to be taxed Feb. 1.

title: Conferees Agree On $6.4 Billion Aid For Rail industry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 House and Senate conferees approved today a $6.4 billion measure to aid the nation's railroad industry.

title: Parliament in India Gives Government, Wider Arrest Rights
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 22 (AP)The Indian parliament today gave the Government power to detain political prisoners without having to disclose reasons to anyone, including the judiciary.

title: Wallace Could Be Hurt By Mississippi Caucuses
description: VICKSBURG, Miss., Jan. 22There is scarcely a politician in Mississippi who believes that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama could be beaten if the state were conducting a primary erection among Mr. Wallace and his four active Democratic rivals here.

title: Memphis and N.F.L.: Door's Not Shut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)Tennessee's two senators said today after a meeting with Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, that they were encouraged about the prospects of Memphis's getting a pro football team but that no decision could be made until litigation over N.F.L. expansion was settled.

title: ECOL IN DIRECT DEAL TO BUY KUWAIT OIL
description: Northeast Petroleum Industries Inc. said yesterday that its 50 percentowned New Orleans refinery subsidiary has signed a contract with Kuwait to buy 50,000 barrels of crude oil a day for five years.

title: F.D.A. DRUG TESTS CALLED LACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The Food and Drug Administration has not adequately monitored the testing of new drugs to insure the accuracy and reliability of the data on which these drugs are approved for general use, an officer of the General Accounting Office said today.

title: AntiAmericanism in Greece
description: ATHENSThe murder of the Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Athens, Richard S. Welch, in December, is an indirect result of the poisonous antiAmericanism advocated by the Greek press. Listening today to the extreme protestations against the United States and all its institutionsincluding multinationals and charitable foundationsone would not guess that tens of thousands died at the hands of the Communists thirty years ago, and that a ruined country and shattered economy were rebuilt from scratch mostly through American aid.

title: Charles Reznikoff, Poet, Dead; A Founder of Objectivist School
description: Charles Reznikoff, a founding member of the Objectivist school of poetry, died yesterday morning. He was 81 years

title: Notes on People
description: Reports circulated in Washington and Kansas City yesterday that Ruth Lewis Farkas, Ambassador to Luxembourg since 1973, is being replaced by Rosemary Ginn, Republican National Committeewoman from Missouri since 1960. White House sources were cited but the press office there, like the State Department, said there was nothing to announce. Dr. Fakas was said to have returned to Luxembourg after holidays here.

title: New Chinese Dictionary Tells It Like It Is
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 22Western music may have been banned in China as decadent, but if Chinese students want to freak out they can try a new unexpurgated EnglishChinese dictionary published in Shanghai.

title: Lina Wertmuller, Torrent of Paradox
description: Lina Wertmuller was looking for fog. Fog is one of the significant figures in her beautiful and terrifying new movie, Seven Beauties. It denotes the abstract, inhuman and sentimental North. It pervades the German forest where soldiers machine gun Jews as casually and irritably as if they were burying garbage. It pervades the concentration, camp where the living and the dead inhabit the same shade of gray.

title: Population Shift Study Gives Sunbelt House Majority After
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20For the first lime in United States history, the Southern and Western states will hold a majority of seats in the House of Representatives after the next census ifas seems likelythe population continues to shift in its current pattern and at its current pace.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW AND THEN Nostalgic sheet music  songs like Rainbow Round My Shoulder, At the Balalaika and Love Walked In papers the foyer wall at Jolson's (8386154) at 303 East 53d Street, just east of Second Avenue. But the piano sounds you hear, drawing you to the, far end of the bar, are uptodate.

title: Volunteer Prober
description: After vainly trying to persuade a score of New York City's most prominent lawyers to accept the assignment, Attorney ,General Lefkowitz has finally found a volunteer to assess the charge that Governor Carey's abortive attempt to oust Special Prosecutor Nadjari last month was designed to protect top Democrats against possible indictment.

title: San Francisco Terrorists Call a ThreeWeek Truce
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 (UPI)The New World Liberation Front has ordered a threeweek truce in its campaign against the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, the target of to bombs that failed to go off.

title: Doubts Are Raised on Why Sun Shines
description: Until recently scientists confidently believed they knew why the sun shines. The energy source, they said, was the fusion of hydrogen nuclei in the sun's core.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 13%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Department of Commerce reported today that retail store sales last week totaled an estimated $11.71 billion, up 13 percent from the yearearlier figure of $10.37 billion. Department store sales were about $906 million, up 24 percent from last year's total of $731 million.

title: Prof. Konstantin Reichardt, Germanic Expert at Yale, 71
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 22Prof. Konstantin Reichardt, Leavenworth Professor Emeritus of Germanic Languages and Literature at Yale University died Monday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: Pose as Journalists Laid to 11 in C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The House Intelligence Committee has obtained evidence that, as of last year, 11 fulltime officers of the Central Intelligence Agency were posing as journalists overseas in connection with their intelligence  gathering work, an authoritative source said today.

title: 10 Cents Postage Found Good on FirstClass Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)  The United States Postal Service is still delivering firstclass mail bearing only 10 cents postage and making no effort to collect a recent three cents minimum increase for such letters, the ScrippsHoward News Service reported today.

title: People and Business:
description: Charles F. Robinson. UnderSecretary of State for Economic Affairs, said yesterday that a Soviet delegation would arrive in Washington this weekend to resume talks Monday on an oil agreement with the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: When Georges Simenon writes about the middle class, his suspense stories might be described as novels of manners that include a murder. The killer is punished for having violated the conventions of a respectable literary genre. Like a supererogating editor, Chief Superintendent Maigret reviews the behavior of his characters until he arrives at an inconsistency, a flaw in the pattern of wellregulated civilization. This flaw is the clue to the crime.

title: Dividends
Reilly Youth Could Not Have Slain His Mother, According to Dr. Helpern
G.A.O. Is Expected to Ask Federal Grain Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The General Accounting Office, in an investigative report to Congress, will urge creation of an allFederal grain inspection system, saying that nothing short of complete reform can prevent scandals of the kind exposed recently in a broad investigation of corruption in the industry.

title: Improved Earnings Slow Profit Taking
description: A number of stocks responded favorably to improved earnings yesterday, although profit taking caused a slight retreat in the general market.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Federal Reserve Statement
U.S. Yacht Takes Cup Series Opener
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 22, (Reuters)  The American yacht Saint Francis VI defeated Australia's Prince Alfred by 2 minutes 18 seconds today in the first race of the AmericanAustralian 6Meter Class Challenge Cup off Palm Beach. Saint Francis VI, designed by Gary Mull, outperformed the Australian yacht on most sections of the 24mile race a, ter David Forbes, the Australian helmsman, had clearly won a close fought start.

title: Cooke, on Anniversary of Ruling, Scores Court's Abortion Position
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke sharply criticized yesterday groups and individuals supporting the Supreme Court's decision liberalizing abortion.

title: Special Slalom Won By Miss Mittermaier
A Portuguese SocialistBibliophile Discovers Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 22'In Lisbon, not even big professors at the end of their careers have such apartments, Mario Soares was saying last night.

title: FORD CALLS 8 FIT TO RUN WITH HIM
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 President Ford, turning his attention from statecraft to state political primaries, discussed potential campaign running mates today.

title: Seeks to Aid the Thousands Who Have Fled ExColony to Neighboring Nations
description: Government's refugee agency, Maj. Fernando Cardoso Amaral, warned that the country would be unable to absorb the 350,000 refugees already here if their friends and relatives did not help out.

title: Big Amtrak Service Cut Seen Without New Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) The country's national passenger train system would be reduced to a skeleton unless President Ford's budget for Amtrak is increased, according to a letter from Paul Reistrup, Amtrak president, to the Transportation Department.

title: This Skater's Day Never Ends
People in Sports
description: President Ford considered quitting the University of Michigan football team in 1934 when a black teammate was benched because of his race.

title: A HEBREW WORD HELPS NEEDIEST
description: A number of checks in the amounts of $18 and $36 have been received by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and the gifts have a traditional significance for Jews.

title: 2D BODY IS EXHUMED IN CURARE INQUIRY
description: The second of five bodie. that were ordered exhumed a part of a new investigation o. suspicious deaths at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, N.J. wa reautopsied yesterday.

title: CoalFired Facilities  Seen as Alternative
description: A major review of the place of nuclear power in future United States energy supplies began here yesterday with the first of five public. hearings in large cities before a committee of the National Research Council.

title: Death Sentences for 10 Upheld by Iranian Court
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 (AP) A military appeals court today upheld death sentences for 10 guerrillas convicted of killing eight persons, including three American colonels.

title: Schaefer to Close Its Brewery Here
description: The F & M Schaefer Brewing Company, the last brewery in New York, announced that it would close its plant here as soon as possible, a move that will bring a loss of 850 fobs.

title: CUNNINGHAM TIED TO TERMINAL DEAL
description: Ken Patton, the former Economic Development Administrator here, said yesterday that Patrick J. Cunningham and his law firm had directly participated in a 1973 lease negotiation that is under investigation by several agencies.

title: Hunter to Pilot Oilers
description: EDMONTON, Alberta. Jan. 22 Bill Hunter, general manager of the Edmonton Oilers, will coach the team for the remainder of the season. Hunter, a vice president and part owner of the World Hockey Association club, takes over from Clare Drake.

title: HERB REIS
description: Herb Reis, a music publisher who headed the Herb Reis Music corporation at 15 East 48th Street, died of cancer Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 401 East 86th Street,

title: Levine Is Resigning State Industrial Job For G.H.I. Position
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22The State Industrial Commissioner, Louis L. Levine, one of the few holdovers from previous Republican state administrations, said today that he would resign within 30 days.

title: Hartford Responds To Plight of Puppy Thrown Off Bridge
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Jan. 22 (UPI)A nameless female pup that suffered two broken legs when thrown from a bridge has generated an outpouring of concern from hundreds of residents of the Hartford area.

title: U.S. Audit Indicates Waste  In Rural Home Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 (AP) Preliminary findings of a Department of Agriculture audit indicate that about $43 million in Federal funds has been wasted in the last two years in the subsidized rural home ownership loan program, two Senators said today.

title: 2 Injured in Paris in Bombing Of Residence of the Moon Sect
description: PARIS, Jan. 22Two young people were seriously injured today when a bomb exploded outside a mansion being used by a religious sect that is becoming the object of increasing public indignation here.

title: Strauss Wants Pay Of Morton Labeled A Political Expense
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National Chairman, called on the Federal Election Commission today to treat Rogers C. B. Morton's White House salary as an expense of President Ford's election campaign.

title: Robinson Leads Bullets In 10986 Rout of Jazz
Excerpts From Beame's Address on State of the City
description: My fellow New Yorkers:

title: MICHAEL M'GRATH
description: Michael McGrath, a stage and screen actor, died of pneumonia last Friday at the Medical Arts Center Hospital, 57 West 57th Street. He lived at 280 Riverside Drive.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Superior Court jury in Paterson yesterday acquitted Patrick Napatano of charges of assaulting five Bergen County Sheriff's officers and wounding two of them with a pistol in a courtroom fight on Feb. 3, 1973, in Hackensack. Mr. Napatano was also wounded in the fight.

title: A Retrial in Abortion Case Is Ordered in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 22Canada's Justice Minister today ordered a retrial of a Montreal physician on a charge of having performed an illegal abortion.

title: Huambo Gloomy
description: HUAMBO, Angola, Jan. 21 The streets are nearly deserted, except for a few cars racing recklessly, their tires squealing. Most shops are closed; those that occasionally open have little to sell.

title: ITALY SEEKS HELP TO BOLSTER LIRA
description: ROME, Jan. 22In dramatic moves to bolster the sinking lira, Italy sought help today from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and West Germany.

title: Assembly's New Payroll Doesn't Reflect Austerity
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22The Assembly today made public its first payroll for the new legislative session.

title: M.T.A. Seeks a Subsidy From State
description: Fearful of a new cash crisis by June because of a problem in obtaining Federal aid, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority urged the Legislature yesterday to enact a threepoint subsidy program to provide 5770 million a year.

title: Lebanon at a Glance
description: Vital StatisticsLebanon is the most Westernized country in the Arab world and its people are the most cosmopolitan. It is a nation of 3,927 square miles, double the size of Delaware. Its population of nearly 3 million 93 percent Arab. Arabic is the official language, but French is widely spoken. No official census has been taken since 1932, but it is believed that Moslems now outnumber Christians. Nonetheless, the Christians have dominated the country politically, economically and culturally.

title: NEWSMEN WARY ON PRIVACY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) New Federal laws and regulations designed to protect individual rights to privacy were described today as a dangerous step toward the wholesale conversion of public records to private records.

title: Bridge:
description: A bridge tournament with cash prizes and no entry fees might seem about as likely to be offered as a genuine gold brick, free, on the streets of Manhattan, but it happened recently in Long Beach, L. I. The veteran expert Morrie Elis of Oceanside, L. I., reports that it took place at the Federal Savings Bank of Long Beach.

title: $1.7 Million TaxBilling Error Pits Towns Against Town
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., .lan. 22The struggleClarkstown vs. the Restbegan in late December 1973 when a Rockland County official called the town to say that its share of the next year's county tax would be $5,800,772.84.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: ATOMARMED SUBS MAY LEAVE SPAIN
description: MADRID, Jan. 23  The United States, under Spanish pressure, is reported to have agreed to remove submarines with atomic weapons from the Rota naval base in southern Spain some time before the termination of a new fouryear agreement on the American use of bases here.

title: Bridge:
description: The knockout stage of the Grand National Teams, the world's bigest team event, begins here today, when 79 teams, qualifiers from games in many New York City clubs, start matches at the New York Hilton Hotel at 2 P.M., playing two rounds that will reduce the field to 16.

title: Peak Stock Volume
description: Stock prices rose briskly yesterday, closing out a record week of trading volume 161.68 million shares. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 10.47 points yesterday to 953.95. Volume was 33.64 million shares. Page 37.

title: Miss America Rule To Ban Pregnancy In Past or Present
description: Young women who are or have been pregnant are to be barred from competing for the crown in the annual Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City.

title: NOW Still Growing But It's Still White and MiddleClass
description: The National Organization for Women is now in its 10th year, and some of the more gloomy are expressing great reservations about its future. Its last national convention was followed by the formation of a significant splinter group. Criticism has been leveled from various quarters at the organization's alleged failure to reach or represent large segments of women in society.

title: Floating Lira Shows Little Change Against the Dollar
description: LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP)The lira was little changed today against the dollar and European currencies on its third day of free floating

title: MIDMONTH SALES OF NEW CARS RISE
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23Without a rebate program, domestic new car sales rose 31.1 percent in midJanuary over sales of the same period a year earlier, which were spurred by rebates.

title: December Redemptions of Funds Exceeded Sales by $53.5 Million
description: Redemptions of mutual funds in December exceeded sales by $53.5 million, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The trade association noted that sales of all mutual funds in last year's final month totaled $1.039.7 million, while redemptions reached $1.093.2 million.

title: Paul Robeson Dead at 77; Singer, Actor and Activist
description: Paul Robeson, the singer, actor and black activist, died yesterday at the age of 77 in Philadelphia.

title: 2 Unions Threaten To Start a Boycott Of Schaefer Beer
description: Two unions representing some 850 workers who are about to lose their jobs at the Schaefer brewery in Brooklyn said that they planned to open a campaign to boycott the beer unless Schaefer fully documented its claim that it was losing money.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of weather conditions. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Coop City Residents Get Deadline From ConEd
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has notified residents of Coop City that gas and electric bills totaling more than $700,000 would have to be paid by. Feb. 9 if service was to continue.

title: 5 Nuns in Glen Ridge Face Fines on Zoning Charges
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J. Jan. 23Five Roman Catholic nuns must appear in Municipal Court on Feb. 18 to face charges that they are illegally living together in their $65,000 rented home and illegally parking too many cars on the property in violation of a zoning ordinance that rermits only singlefamily residences.

title: In the Center of Lebanon, Palestinian Guerrillas Deploy for a Long Stay
description: CIITAURA, Lebanon, Jan. 23 Palestinian guerrilas deployed here in east central Lebanon declared today that they would not withdraw until the political demands of Lebanese leftists and Moslems were met in full.

title: Coffee Price Lifted By General Foods
description: The General Foods Corporation, the country's largest coffee wholesaler, increased wholesale prices yesterday by 15 cents a pound on ground coffees and 2 cents an ounce, on instant coffee.

title: POSTCHOU DANGER IS SEEN BY MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (Reuters) A Soviet commentator said today that leftist extremists in Peking were seeking to take over the post of the late Prime Minister, Chou Enlal and two other vacancies in the Chinese Leadership.

title: A Parking Lot Is to Replace the Tree of Life in Harlem
description: The state has decreed that one of Harlem's younger but more popular institutionsthe Tree of Lifewill have to make way for a parking lot.

title: Head of Grain Concern Disputes Charges of Misgraded Corn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The chairman of one of the country's largest grain corporations opened a counterattack today against charges that corn loaded by his company aboard a Polish supertanker had been misgraded.

title: U.S. IS SUING HERE ON SCHOOL RIGHTS
description: The Federal Government has filed suit to require the school board of District 21 in the Gravesend and Coney Island sections of Brooklyn to cooperate with representatives of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in conducting a civilrights investigation into possible discrimination in the city's schools.

title: Art: Fritz Bultman Restates His Metaphors
description: Styles and the emotions that inspire them have their cycles. In the 1940's and well into the 1950's, a significant number of American artists were drawn to a mode of imagery that, while remaining abstract, was nonetheless totemic or otherwise primitive in feeling. A disposition to invest abstraction with something of the archetypal resonance of myth and ritual was widespread. It seemed at times as if The Golden Bough was everywhere being ransacked for appropriate titles, if not for actual ideas.

title: UPSTATE G.O.P. CHIEF GIVEN 6MONTH TERM
description: William E. Doulin, the 72yearold Republican Party chairman of Orange County, was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and two years of probation for committing perjury when he denied using his influence to obtain a suspended sentence for a defendant in a 1971 criminal case.

title: SOVIET DROPS TALKS IN COMMUNIST SPLIT
description: EAST BERLIN, ran. 23Moscow has shelved its plans for a conference of Europe's Communist parties as a result of deep differences that became apparent once again at a preparatory session here.

title: Loan Delinquencies Trend Is Showing Improvement
description: A Government survey on national banks shows that the trend in loan delinquencies stabilized or improved somewhat in the second half of 1975, reflecting the general improvement in the economy.

title: People in Sports
description: The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association named 35yearold Zelmo Beaty coach yesterday.

title: Separatism Posing Challenges for Wilson
description: LONDON, Jan. 23One of the sadderlooking guests at a farewell reception given the other evening by the departing American Ambassador, Elliot L. Richardson, was a short, portly man with drooping eyes who stood near the door clutching a small glass of brandy and talking distractedly to anyone bold. enough to push forward and say

title: Luanda Is Reporting Gains In a Drive on Rival Capital
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 23The army of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola has crossed a strategic bridge on the road to Huambo, the capital of the rival Angolan government, and, in a separate action, has captured the coastal town of Novo Redondo, according to a military spokesman here.

title: News Summary and Index
Ballet
description: Amercian Ballet Theater's production of La Sylphide came to life vibrantly and poetically at the Uris Theater Thursday night, when a superlative cast headed by Carla Fracci, Ivan Nagy and Erik Bruhn took over the leading roles.

title: CITIBANK CHANGES FORMULA ON RATE
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it had changed the formula it uses to determine the interest rate it charges corporate borrowers.

title: Connors, Tanner Reach Semifinals
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 23 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors and Roscoe Tanner, the only seeded players left in the $50,000 Birmingham international indoor tennis tournament, earned places tonight in the semifinal round.

title: Celtics Win, 10891; Cowens Dominates
House Unit on Intelligence Votes, 94, to Issue Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The House Select Committee on Intelligence, after making what a committee source termed a small number of minor changes in the initial draft, voted 9 to 4 today to approve the publication of a final report summarizing its yearlong investigation of the Federal intelligence agencies.

title: Lebanon CeaseFire Gains But Looters Roam Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23A ceasefire negotiated by a Syrian civilian and military delegation appeared to be taking hold in Beirut and parts of the country tonight, although scattered fighting and widespread lawlessness and looting continued in the capital.

title: Peak Stock Volume
description: Stock prices rose briskly yesterday, closing out a record week of trading volume 161.68 million shares. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 10.47 points yesterday to 053.95. Volume was 33.64 million shares. Page 37.

title: NoFault Insurance Failing to Cut Rates
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23Nofault automobile insurance, which was heralded as a costsaver for consumers when it began to spread across the country five years ago, is failing to bring down the price of automobile insurance,

title: Some TV Stations Resist Political Ads of 5 Minutes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Presidential candidates who want to buy political commercials on television lasting longer than the 30second and 60second spots that prevail in the TV marketplace are meeting stiff resistance from network affiliates in major. cities.

title: Market Place
description: Over the years, investors have come to view the nation's casualty insurance companies as investments that provided an excellent means of participating in the nation's longterm economic growth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday said incorrectly that The Los Angeles Times prematurely made public a Gallup poll that showed President Ford leading Ronald Reagan among Republican voters. The poll was scheduled for release Sunday. but the Gallup organization had authorized release of a portion of it for Thursday morning newspapers.

title: A Slot Machine Pays $113,232 to Canadians
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 23 (AP) A British Columbia couple has won $113,232 from a Nevada slot machine.

title: Mercury Drops to an 8Year Low of 1
description: The harshest cold in eight yearsa withering 1 degree below zero in Central Park shortly after dawnput New York into a deep freeze yesterday. It was even colder in the suburbs, and record lows were set in several upstate cities.

title: For WorkingClass Women, Own Organization and Goals
description: Ann Giordano is a 43yearold Brooklyn woman who is married to a transit worker. She has worked outside her home for most of her 16year marriage. She believes, In individual identity and in equal pay and opportunities for women.

title: Masked Riders Battle Cold
description: Suddenly a new fashion note is toning up Aqueduct's jockey colony. The trend was much in evidence yesterday as a number of riders kept appearing in the saddling enclosure sporting woolen face gear. The opening contest was held in subteen temperatures and the At the Race Tracks weather got only slightly warmer as the afternoon progressed, Many in the slim crowd of 7,731 arrived wearing Arcticthemed accessories ranging from earmuffs to galoshes.

title: Lebanon CeaseFire Gains But Looters Roam Beirut

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23 (Reuters) Sonatrach, Algeria's national oil and gas company, has concluded a multimilliondollar costplus contract with Bechtel International Inc. for completion of the liquefied natural gas project in Arzew, Sonatrach announced here yesterday. A spokesman said the contract was signed Wednesday in Algiers.

title: Draft Lottery Ends; System Staff Cut, Enrollment Halted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) The draft, which for nearly three decades haunted the lives of young men and provided the nation with a continuous pool of soldiers, went out of business today.

title: Pentagon Admonishes 38 On Northrop Lodge Visits
Polar Bear Dies in Hospital
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (UPI)A nineweekold polar bear, rejected by her mother and attempting to survive in the polluted environment of a big city. died yesterday in a hospital.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES FINISH DAY MIXED
description: A surplus of dried milk in Europe had an impact on soybean and soybean product prices in Chicago yesterday. Traders reasoned that news about how the European Community planned to use part of the surplus would have brought about price declines for soybeans and soybean meal and oil, except for a report issued by the Department of Agriculture about good domestic usage. As a result, prices were virtually unchanged.

title: Spain's Council Reported Barring Electoral Change
description: MADRID, Jan. 23  The strongly rightist Council of the Realm, the highest consultative body in Spain, was reported today to be blocking a key Government move to make the Parliament more representative.

title: In Memoriam
description: ADELAAREmil. So lovingly remembered, so Sadly missed. BELOVED WIFE Sandra.

title: Testing System Is Found For Integrated Circuits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23A scientist of the RCA Corporation has developed a technique for testing the little devices called Integrated circuits, much as a biologist

title: ATOMARMED SUBS MAY LEAVE SPAIN
description: MADRID, Jan. 23  The United States, under Spanish pressure, is reported to have agreed to remove submarines with atomic weapons from the Rota naval base in southern Spain some time before the termination of a new fouryear agreement on the American use of bases here.

title: 123 Sweep For Lancias At Monaco
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 23 (AP)Sandro Munari and Silvio Maiga of Italy, overcoming a bad 15 minutes when their gearbox locked up, led the Lancia Stratos team to a threecar sweep of the 44th Monte Carlo rally today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: To Abbie Hoffman, Wherever He's Hiding Out
description: Dear Abbie:

title: Murder Charges Against Officer Upset Over Speedy Trial Issue
description: RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 23 (AP)A Federal appeals court dismissed today murder charges against a former Army captain accused of killing his wife and two daughters.

title: Sanford, Quitting Race, Cites Ordeal of Campaigning
description: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 23Before Terry Sanford walked to a lectern at Duke University today to make official his withdrawal as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, Barbara Morgan, the black woman who is his national campaign treasurer, turned to him and said, Oh, Terry, I'm so sad about this.

title: Pittsburgh Teachers Union Is Fined $30,000 Additional
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan 23 (UPI)Judge Donald Ziegler fined the Pittsburgh Federation of Teachers $30,000 additional today but deferred a decision on possible jail sentences because of the possibility of a settlement this weekend to the eightweek school strike.

title: Dave Hill Takes 2Shot Lead In Crosby Golf on 65 for 136
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23Dave Hill, who cheerfully nurtures his image as the curmudgeon of the golf world, shot a 65 today and took a twoshot lead in the second round of the Bing Crosby National ProAm. He stayed in character after doing it.

title: ISRAELI SAYS STAND CONSTRAINED SYRIA
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 23Defense Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israeli warnings to Syria had saved the Lebanese Christians from direct Syrian military intervention in the recent fighting.

title: The Casts
description: THE STEADFAST TIN SOLDIER (New York premiere), music, Georges Bizet; choreography, George Balanchine; scenery and costumes, David Mitchell; lighting, Ronald Bates; conductor, Robert Irving. Presented by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater

title: Community Board Member Suspended
description: A member of Community Board 5 in midtown, Carl J. Abraham, was suspended yesterday following an allegation that he sought a bribe from the company that has begun installing shelters at bus stops in Manhattan but has been barred from the territory of Board 5.

title: But Year Was Off 22%
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation reported yesterday a 41 percent increase in net income for the fourth quarter but a 22 percent decline for the full year 1975.

title: Concert
description: In recent years there has been a great deal of talk about the need to break down the traditional separation between performers and audiences, a separation generally assumed by the talkers to be a bad thing. But what if, instead, the existence of a dividing line between reality and fantasy were in fact a precondition for the perception and enjoyment of art?

title: Portugal's Communists
description: A Portuguese military commission investigating the abortive leftwing putsch of last Nov. 25 has directly implicated the Communist Party and Maj. Gen. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, the flamboyant former security chief, among the conspirators. These are highly significant charges both in terms of fixing responsibility for a coup that came close to succeeding and with respect to Portugal's political future.

title: Opera: Versatile Scotto
description: The three heroines of Puc??'s Il Trittico are not usually, sung by the same soprano, but they were all taken by Renata Scotto on Thursday night in the Metropolitan Opera's seventh presentation of the trilogy this season. Since she, is one of the finest Puccini interpreters around, the evening was something of a triumph for her as well as giving the production, largely new, a special glow.

title: Critic's Notebook: Being And Knottiness on the Air
description: Only 15 years ago, whenever something interesting happened in this country it was called existential. Existentialism seemed to be a fastfood chain, opening up a new franchise on a new corner every day. There were existential Presidents, existential prize fights, existential murders, even existential architecture. Kierkegaard and Sartre would not have approved. Their existentialism had been solemn. Ours was feisty and promiscuous. The absurd, to us, was a pep pill. It was as though anyone who unzipped the stitches of a scar and spilled his beings were instantly authentic, a selfmade hero.

title: Paige Upholds Villanova Pace
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23Three generations of Coach Jim (Jumbo) Elliott's dynasty of middle distance runners from Villanova scored four easy victories and dominated the racing at the Philadelphia Track Classic on the Spectrum's 11lap track tonight.

title: Magazine Lists 5 Russians In Rome as Agents of K.G.B.
description: ROME. Jan. 23 (Reuters)The political weekly L'Europeo today named a Soviet Embassy counselor as the head of the Soviet secret service K.G.B. in Italy.

title: A Double Standard in Reporting News From Portugal
description: ITHACA, N.Y.When reporting on Portugal, the United States news media have displayed little of that pluralism and diversity of opinion they deem so essential for Portuguese democracy.

title: A Portuguese Communist Urges End to Rising AntiRed Attacks
description: LISBON, Jan. 23The leader of the Portuguese Communist Party demanded today that the authorities take urgent measures to end the increasing antiCommunist violence in the country.

title: Numb's the Word for Weather Here
description: NEWARK, Jan. 23This was the kind of day when water pipes froze, cars refused to start and every other person you met asked the same question: Cold enough for you?

title: S.E.C. OVERRULED IN MERGER CASE
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals here reversed today a decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission that would have permitted the proposed merger of the Christiana Securities Company E. I. and du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money ratest or Friday.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES PLAN TO RESOLVE ARMS PACT SNAG
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23  The Soviet Union has proposed to the United States a new approach to resolve the issues still holding up a treaty limiting each side's strategic bomber and missile forces, American officials said today.

title: Death in the Name of God
description: THE HAGUE, the NetherlandsIt is a dismal truth that probably half or more of the wars now being fought around the world are either openly religious conflicts or involved with religious disputes. And, since virtually all formally organized creeds are monotheistic, this means that at this very instant men are killing other men in the name of an identical, if variously named, God.

title: Dispute Flowers Over Garden in Village
description: A halfacre plot in Greenwich Village that in summer is ablaze with roses, zinnias, marigolds and a variety of cool, green bushes has become caught in a tugofwar between the Community, which wants it preserved as a neighborhood amenity, and St. Vincent's Hospital, which wants to build a parking lot on it for the use of its staff.

title: Tass Praises Robeson As Singer and Leader
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (AP)The official Soviet press agency Tags paid tribute today to Paul Robeson as an outstanding black singer and prominent public leader of the United States.

title: Nastase, Solomon Advance in Tennis
description: CATONSVILLE, Md., Jan. 23 (AP)Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania and three Americans advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Baltimore international tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Foreman Favored Over Lyle Today
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 23George Foreman weighed in at 226 pounds today and Ron Lyle at 220 in preparation for their heavyweight fight, which will be televised live tomorrow (at 4:30 P.M. New York time, on Channel 7) from the Sports Pavilion at Caesars Palace Hotel.

title: Growth of Nuclear Power Slowed Sharply Last Year
The Ballet: Two Local Premieres by Balanchine
description: George Balanchine is quite ridiculously unexpected. It probably adds to his slightly perverse charm, and it is also indicative of his special artistic diffidence. On Thursday night at the New York State Theater, his New York City Ballet gave two New York premieres. Now why two premieres on the same night? But who is counting? Obviously not Mr. Balanchine when it comes to press coverage!

title: Man Accused of a Threat To Reagan Is Out on Bail
description: MIAMI, Jan. 23 (AP)Michael L. Carvin, charged with seeking to intimidate Ronald Reagan by pointing what turned out to be a toy gun at him, has been freed from jail under a $7,500 surety bond.

title: New Trends for Old Things At Winter Antiques Show
description: Some things have changed subtly, others dramatically at the Winter Antiques Show. It opens today for a nineday run at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street.

title: Kings Hospital Unit Quits in a Dispute With City Agency
description: The medical board of Kings County Hospital, the city's largest municipal hospital has voted to resign in a dispute with the Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Columbia Scores in 2 Overtimes
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP) Elmer Love's 15foot jump shot with a minute left in the second overtime tonight gave Columbia an 8988 basketball victory over Cornell.

title: Thomas F. Pyle, Baritone, Soloist and Choral Singer
description: Thomas F. Pyle, a baritone soloist and choral singer, who was a contractor to find choral singers for leading music groups, died of a heart attack Thursday at his office, 711 West End Avenue. He was 58 years old and lived at 801 West End Avenue.

title: HEARST LAWYERS ASSAILED IN COURT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23Prosecutors accused Patricia Hearst's lawyers today of trying to drive a psychiatrist out of the Hearst bank robbery case after he was hired by the Government to testify about the defendant's mental condition.

title: Winning U.S. Attorney
description: When playing hockey or coaching youngsters in the rugged sport, which he enjoys with enthusiasm, Robert Bishop Fiske Jr. works hard to win. He works even harder to win his cases as a lawyer. I really want to win, he says, but not at the expense of fair ness.

title: EARNINGS CLIMB AT BANKAMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corporation reported yesterday an in crease in net operating earnings for both the fourth quarter of 1975 and the full year.

title: Peterson Crashes in Drill
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 23 (AP)Ronnie Peterson of Sweden escaped unharmed today after his Lotus77 car crashed into a protection wall on a curve during the first official training session for Sunday's Grand Prix of Brazil, the first Formula One event of the year.

title: Peru Executes Slayer
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 23 (AP)Peru today held its first execution since capital punishment was reinstituted in 1974. A 27yearold man was shot by a firing squad for having killed a policeman in a store holdup, prison authorities said.

title: PRICES SHOW RISE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Volume Is Heavy as 2 Days of Profit Taking End

title: Public Jobs Increase as Others. Decline in State
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23  Government employment in the state increased substantially last year, according to statistics issued today by the New Jersey Department of Labor and Industry, although overall employment dropped by 125,000.

title: 45 Are Reported Dead In China Airline Crash
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 23 (AP)A Chinesee airliner crashed on a domestic flight near Shanghai, killing 45 persons, the Danish Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Executives Here Wary of an Import Tax
description: Thirty business leaders met here yesterday to discuss the implications of a United States Supreme Court decision expanding the right of states and cities to tax imported goods, and they agreed that imposition of such a tax here could only hurt the city's economy and lead to new job losses.

title: Edwin D. Wolf, 37, Lawyer In Legal Aid and Civil Rights
description: Edwin D. Wolf, a Philadelphia lawyer who specialized in legal aid and civil rights cases, died Wednesday of cancer in the University of Pennsylvania. Hospital. He was 37 years old.

title: Senate Overrides Ford on Enlarging His Security Panel
Graceful Young Fish and Flying Plugs
description: FLAMINGO, Fla., Jan. 23A female wolf of a wind bared her fangs as Clint Jones steered his skiff up Buttonwood Canal and across choppy Coot Bay. According Sandy Bain, this is the southernmost settlement on the mainland of the United States, but in this year of grace mere proximity to the tropics is no guarantee of warmth.

description: Suspect in Wright Murder Surrenders

description: WASHINGTON

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23The Soviet fishing fleet, along with other East European craft, has returned in force, prompting new demands that Congress give the United States jurisdiction over waters 200 mites off the coast rather than 12 miles.

title: Vatican Releases 43 Documents On Handling of Jewish Problems
description: ROME, Jan. 23The Vatican released documents today on its controversial role in World War II and insisted that its policy of public silence on the plight of the Jews was calculated to avoid endangering its quiet diplomacy on their behalf.

title: Nets Erase Deficit, Top Colonels
Man Seized at La Guardia With a Gun and $172,695
description: A 29yearold Coral Springs, Fla., man was arrested here after he allegedly tried to board an Eastern Airlines flight at La Guardia with a loaded antique gun.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23The Soviet fishing fleet, along with other East European craft, has returned in force, prompting new demands that Congress give the United States jurisdiction over waters 200 miles off the coast rather than 12 miles.

title: GOVERNOR ORDERS REVISION IN PLAN ON CITY'S DEFICIT
description: Governor Carey yesterday ordered a revision of the city's emergency financial plan to take into account new deficit factors, even as city officials argued that Mr. Carey's own proposed cuts in city aid should not be included because they would not pass the Legislature.

title: 13 Injured in L.I. Luncheonette Blast
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Jan. 23Thirteen persons were injured this morning, when a gas explosion and fire erupted in a luncheonette on the ground floor of a twostory brick building.

title: A Democratic Reply
description: It is an awkward assignment for a member of Congress to reply on behalf of his party to a Presidential State of the Union address. Such a speech may have the air of a Presidential address but it lacks the substance of power to give it credibility. If a President has difficulty leading his party in the direction he wants to go, an individual member of Congress has much greater difficulty.

title: State Set to Bill Polluters For Oil Cleanup in Hudson
description: New York State plans to use a 1973 law for the first time and require those responsible for a recent Hudson River oil spill to pay for the cost of cleaning it up.

title: NoFault Insurance Failing to Cut Rates
About Half Termed by Wille as in Serious State
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation currently has close to 350 state and national banks on its problem list, Frank Wille, the agency's chairman, disclosed today.

title: Canadian Minister Found in Contempt
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (AP) Canada's Consumer Affairs Minister, Andre Ouellet, was found in contempt of court today, given a threemonth suspended sentence and ordered to pay $500 court costs.

title: Correspondent From U.S. Is Ordered to Leave India
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 (AP)Lawrence S. Lifschultz, correspondent of the Far Eastern Economic Review, has been ordered to leave India, official sources said.

title: Memorial for Frank Irwin
description: A meeting in memory of Frank N. Irwin, who retired as a rewriteman for The New York Times in 1970 after 45 years of service, will be held at the Newspaper Guild of New York, 133 West 44th Street, next Friday at 1 P.M. Mr. Irwin died Thursday in Port Washington, L. I., at the age of 73.

title: Victory Ends 25Game Drought
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 23The team that the hapless Washington Capitals had been waiting for all seaon finally showed up tonight; the hapless New York Rangers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: New Resolution Backing Palestinian Nationhood Is Submitted to the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Jan. 23Six members of the Security Council submitted today a Middle East resolution affirming the Palestinians right to independent nationhood but also advocating security guarantees for all nations in the area, including Israel.

title: Shriver Evokes Warm Memory For Poor Blacks in Mississippi
description: McCOMB, Miss., Jan. 23The limousine carrying Sargent Shriver swept past the tinroofed .shacks propped on cement blocks. The people, leaning against the refrigerators and broken furniture piled on the porches, just stared.

title: Sudan Executes Six
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23 (AP)Six Sudanese, including three army officers, were executed by a firing squad today for attempting to overthrow President Gaafar alNimeiry last September, the Sudanese military command announced in Khartoum.

title: Lechner Resigns as Budget Director
description: Melvin N. Lechner, the city's Budget Director since Mayor Beanie took office in 1974, resigned yesterday to accept an unspecified opportunity to return to the private sector.

title: Bolshoi Does Romeo and Juliet for TV
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 23The Bolshoi Theater tonight presented a special performance of the ballet Romeo and Juliet that was taped for television viewing later this year in 112 countries, according to the project's. West German producer.

title: MORTON SEES EBB IN REAGAN'S DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Secretary of Commerce Rogers C. B. Morton professed confidence today that Ronald Reagan's challenge to President Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination was on the wane.

title: Proposed U.N. Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23Following is the text of a draft resolution on the Middle East submitted to the Security Council today by Benin, Guyana, Pakistan, Panama, Rumania and Tanzania:

title: Five Nuns Face Fines On Zoning
Carey Delays Order Permitting Nadjari to Expand Bronx Role
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would delay signing an order permitting Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, to go into the Bronx to investigate political corruption because of reservations raised by Mario Merola, the District Attorney there.

title: Iran Sets $100 Million In Eurocurrency Loan
description: LONDON, Jan. 23 (Reuters) The Agricultural Development Bank of Iran is borrowing $100 million in the Eurocurrency market, the Iran Overseas Investment Bank Ltd. said today.

title: No Welfare Reform
description: More than six years have passed since President Nixon sent to Congress his program for reforming welfare by putting a floor under family income. That program, by far the most imaginative social proposal to come out the Nixon Administration, has been recognized ever since as the essential foundation for any constructive effort to reduce the human and fiscal waste that makes welfare a national disgrace.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Stricken Ibis to Take Jet to Florida Vacation
description: A lonely, glossy ibis that somehow missed out on the fall's migration and was found Dec. 20 lying on its back and starving in a marsh in Jamaica Bay will now get a free flight South, thanks to the help of a few friends.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: MADRID, Jan. 23  The United States, under Spanish pressure, is reported to have agreed to remove submarines with atomic weapons from the Rota naval base in southern Spain some time before the termination of a new fouryear agreement on the American use of bases here.

title: Paul Robeson
description: The magnificent voice in its prime filled the concert hall; it spoke in dramatic power and In passion; it spoke of gentleness and the warmth of humankind. Whether conveying the tragedy of Othello or the compassion the spiritual, the voice of Paul Robeson enriched the culture from which it grew and the lives of all who heard it.

title: Senate to Examine Role Of Bank in Microdot Bid
description: The Senate Banking Committee announced yesterday that it would hold hearings Feb. 16 on the involvement of the Irving Trust Company in a bid by the General Cable Corporation to take over Microdot Inc.

title: Books of The Times
description: War, unfortunately, is part of the human condition. Of all war's guises the least understood is the guerrilla, the little war. From the Persian Empire onward, great powersthe United States is the most recent examplehave been unable to understand guerrilla war and consequently have suffered losses in men and position in circumstances in which, with proper understanding, they could have won.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SAME VEIN American audiences fortunate enough to have seen the monologue programs by the late Ruth Draper, who created a memorable gallery of characters on stage, may derive the same kind of enjoyment from Peggy Cowles.

title: Portugal Denies Pressure By U.S. Over Cuban Flights
description: LISBON, Jan. 23The Portuguese Government has expressed displeasure over a State Department announcement that the United States had exerted pressure to get Portugal to bar Cuban aircraft bound for Angola from refueling in the Azores.

title: Kennecott Halts Smelting Because of Utah Weather
description: MAGNA, Utah, Jan. 23 (UPI) Kennecott Copper Corporation, saying it was worried about exceeding emission standards during a heavy temperature inversion, indefinitely suspended its smelting operations here last night.

title: Spain's Council Reported Barring Electoral Change
description: MADRID, Jan. 23  The strongly rightist Council of the Realm, the highest consultative body in Spain, was reported today to be blocking a key Government move to make the Parliament more representative.

description: International

title: Citibank and Merrill Subpoenaed by S.E.C.
description: The First National City Bank and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the brokerage house, said here yesterday that they were among a group of leading ban:,:s, and brokerage firms that had been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: For One Rye Resident, a Closed Street Means Tough Sledding
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 23While laughing children on sleds and toboggans skimmed down the unplowed Reymont Avenue hill today, Tevfik Yalim lay in bed, suffering from a severe pain in his back, which, he said, he had injured in a fall on his icy street.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday said incorrectly that The Los Angeles Times pematurely made public a Gallup poll that showed President Ford leading Ronald Reagan among Republican voters. The poll was scheduled for release Sunday, but the Gallup organization had authorized release of a portion of it for Thursday morning newspapers.

title: Notes on People
description: In a tradition that began in 1794 with Edmund Randolph, a portrait of Richard G. Kleindienst, a former Attorney General, was unveiled in a corridor of the Department of Justice yesterday. Mr. Kleindienst resigned in 1973, after less than a year, citing the involvement of many close associates in the Watergate situation. A year later he pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor for refusing to testify fully in the I.T.T. antitrust suit. His onemonth sentence and $100 fine were suspended.

title: Consumer Notes
description: A Burlington County newspaperman who challenged New Jersey Bell Telephone to put meters on customers telephones has been waging a oneman war against the company on several fronts.

title: Glamour Stocks Lead Rise; Week's Volume Is a Record
description: With a number of glamour issues showing multipoint gains, stock prices surged ahead yesterday to close out a strong week that also marked the heaviest trading in New York Stock Exchange history.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES PLAN TO RESOLVE ARMS PACT SNAG
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 23  The Soviet Union has proposesd to the United States a new approach to resolve the issues still holding up a treaty limiting each side's strategic bomber and missile forces, American officials said today.

title: JESS MATTHEWS
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 23 (AP)Jess Matthews, principal of Little Rock Central High School during the integration crisis of 1957, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 75 years old.

title: Scott Urges a Utility Rule For Cutting Off Services
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, today urged the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to require utilities to make personal contact with delinquent customers before cutting off services.

title: Investing in Children
description: The State Board of Social Welfare has developed a plan to meet the severe shortcomings, identified in its earlier report released last June, in the foster care system in New York City. Though the board's plan clearly tends in the right direction, the remedies proposed are unduly optimistic, considering the availability of funding for remedial efforts and the intractability of a system in which inappropriate placement, particularly of black and Hispanic children, has reached staggering proportions.

title: Bridge:
description: The knockout stage of the Grand National. Teams, the world's bigest team event, begins here today, when 79 teams, qualifiers from games in many New York City clubs, start matches at the New York Hilton Hotel at 2 P.M., playing two rounds that will reduce the field to 16.

title: Drawing Now, One of the Modern's Best
description: One of the best and most useful exhibitions ever mounted at the Museum of Modern Art is Drawing Now, which was directed by Bernice Rose, is on view at the museum through March 9 and will subsequently travel abroad.

title: PARKING
description: Motorists will be able to park their cars today on both sides of those streets where alternatesideofthestreet regulations are normally in effect. The rules have been suspended because of weather conditions. However, other parking and standing restrictions still apply.

title: Pentagon Admonishes 38 On Northrop Lodge Visits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23The Defense Department announced today that 38 Pentagon civilian officials and officers including 9 admirals and 17 Air Force generals, had been admonished for accepting entertainment at a Maryland hunting lodge maintained by the Northrop Corporation, a major defense contractor.

title: Paul Robeson Dead at 77; Singer, Actor and Activist
description: Paul Robeson, the singer, actor and black activist, died yesterday at the age of 77 in Philadelphia.

title: Sanford Can Apply U.S. Funds to Campaign Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Terry Sanford received more than $240,000 in Federal subsidies to help him finance his abortive Presidential campaign, but he will have to give some of it hack to the Treasury if there is any surplus left when his political accounts are settled.

title: No Airliner Used As Military Target, Coleman Declares
description: A Government inquiry has found no evidence whatMeyer to substantiate a recent charge by Jacksonville air traffic controllers that military jets have been intercepting commercial airliners in practice maneuvers, according to Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr.

title: ECLECTIC DISPLAY OF DANCE AND SONG
description: Bill Vanaver and Livia Drapkin are a team of mostly song and a little dance, who practice eclecticism to an extreme degree, Their program at the Theater of Riverside Church on Thursday started with a Bulgarian folk song and concluded with a farm workers protest ballad, but only intermittently struck genuinely entertaining sparks.

title: Symington Denies Collusion in 1973 To Protect Helms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Senator Stuart Symington said today that he and Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, privately discussed covert operations in Chile and other problems Mr. Helms faced before his Senate hearings in 1973. But Mr. Symington denied rumors that he had been involved in collusion to protect Mr. Helms.

title: Woman's Body Found In the Americana Hotel
description: The body of a young woman who had apparently been strangled was found last night in a 55gallon garbage drum on the 18th floor of the Americana Hotel at 52d Street and Seventh Avenue, the police reported.

title: People and Business
description: A lawyer for Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Company, said that Dr. Hammer was hospitalized in Los Angeles and unable to appear at a hearing yesterday before a Federal judge in Washington to restate his guilty. plea involving an illegal 1972 campaign donation.

title: EARNINGS RISE 17% AT BRISTOLMYERS
description: The BristolMyers Company has reported profit increases of 17 percent for the fourth quarter and 18 percent for all of of 1975, setting records for any quarter or year.

title: FORD TERMED LOW ON MEDICARE COST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)  President Ford's plan to protect 25 million Medicare patients against catastrophic illness could cost double the $538 million stated in his new budget, informed sources said today.

title: EDGAR LESLIE, 90, SONG WRITER, DIES
description: Edgar Leslie, who wrote the lyrics for Moon Over Miami and a multitude of other highly popular American songs and who also helped to found the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died here Thursday at Doctors Hospital of a heart ailment.

title: House Panel Scores U.S. Agency. For an Exchange With Rockwell
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) A Government agency violated the intent of the law when it gave Rockwell International Corporation $19.5 million worth of Air Force property in exchange for a building that is now used in part to house the records of former President Richard M. Nixon, the House Government Operations Committee said today.

title: COURT'S GAG RULE PRESSED BY STATE
description: The State Attorney General's office said yesterday that the gag order issued against the press in the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants was necessary to preserve the integrity of the trial.

title: Hair Dye Cited in Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) Janet C. Eliott yesterday filed a lawsuit against Clairol Inc. seeking $5 million in damages after a hair dye product allegedly caused physical injuries and illness. She contended that the use of Loving Care ColorFoam Instant FoamIn Hair Color caused abdominal pains and injuries to her nervous system.

title: Italian Socialist Party Invited to Join Coalition
GOVERNOR ORDERS REVISION IN PLAN ON CITY'S DEFICIT
description: Governor Carey yesterday ordered a revision of the city's emergency financial plan to take into account new deficit factors, even as city officials argued that Mr. Carey's own proposed cuts in city aid should not be included because they would not pass the Legislature.

title: Past Due Bank Loans
description: The five regions with the largest percentage of bank loans past due in various categories. The nation's banks are divided into 14 regions for a survey made by the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: CITY HELD LAGGING ON LOAN CRITERIA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23A high Treasury Department official told Congress today that New York City was not meeting Federal criteria for getting its fiscal house in order, and he issued a veiled warning that Federal loans might be withheld as provided by law if the situation was not improved.

title: Symington Denies Collusion in 1973 To Protect Helms

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Transportation Department drafted proposals for transit cutbacks and fare increases to make up a $4.2 million subsidy shortage expected by March 1.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENBertram F. Sr., of Port Washington, L.I., on January 22, 1976. Beloved husband of the late Blanche, loving father of Bette Merrified and Bertram F., Jr., also survived by one grandson. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc., Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington. Visiting hours Saturday, 7.9 P.M., Sunday 2.4 and 7.9 P.M. Religious services Monday 2 P.M. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Sant'Angelo: Something for Everybody's Man
description: I'm O.K., Giorgio Sant'Angelo said the other morning. More relaxed.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 23A most unlikely college course to be taught in New York City will begin early next montha lecture series on New Jersey government.

title: Interest Rates Off Slightly On Certificates of Deposit
description: The shortterm money market, where the $82 billion of outstanding bank certificates of deposit may be traded, so far has shown little, if any, reaction to the disclosure that 35 banks a year ago were put on a Federal Reserve Board list of hanks with problems.

title: District School Superintendents Ask Payless Holiday on Feb. 13
description: The city's local school superintendents have asked the Board of Education to close the entire system for one day next monthand pay no employee for that dayto save an estimated $8million and avoid new reductions in educational services.

description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 19The Cambodian Communists are bad credit risks.
