description: FINN SAILOR (Finn), Helsinki Feb. 10; sails from Port Newark, N.J.

title: Coin Phones
description: The 10 cent phone call is going the way of the 10 cent stamp.

title: Fueling the Arts, Or, Exxon as a Medici
description: Corporate support for the arts last year totaled about $150million compared to only $22million in 1965. This increase of almost 600 percent over the past decademuch greater than the increase in corporate profitsraises several interesting questions: Is what the corporations are doing really giving, or is it advertising? What are their criteria in the selection of recipients? And, why are they doing it, anyhow?

title: Eulogy to a Dead Battery?
description: Longer life is the battleground in a war in the auto battery business. The stakes are big; last year 40 million were produced.

title: Last. Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area
description: 1. Vote on bill to provide that the Secretary of the Treasury be a member of the National Security Council, which had been vetoed by the President and required a twothirds vote of those present for passage. Veto overridden, 72 to 16, Jan. 22.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, was strolling on East New York Avenue in Brooklyn in June 1973 when, he says, he stepped off a curb into a 1footby5inchdeep hole in a city street. He filed a claim against the city, charging that through its negligence he had suffered a broken toe and other injuries.

title: SPRATLY ISLANDS CAUSING CONCERN
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 24  In a series of recent moves that concern analysts here, China, Taiwan, Vietnam and the Philippines have all taken actions apparently designed to reassert their claims to the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

title: Bribery Dilemma Grows
description: DISCLOSURES last year of bribery and payoffs by United States corporations to foreign officials triggered a series of investigations and reform movements around the world.

title: Imports Brace For U.S. Challenge
description: LOS ANGELES  From France, there's a new small car that the French hope can make Americasts forget the last French small car.

title: Nightmare
description: Our long national nightmare is over, declared Gerald Ford on assuming the Presidency. So saying, he helped to bury the memory of his predecessor's abuse of Presidential powers and to encourage the belief, which has now become an article of national faith, that Watergate constituted no more than a regrettable interlude in American politicsa minor spasm from which the body politic has fully recovered.

title: Headliners
description: Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona says that the Senate Committee on Intelligence, of which he is a member, has spent too much time investigating the Central Intelligence Agency and not enough time investigating the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He said in an interview last week that the inquiry had damaged the C.I.A., and that he had urged the committee chairman to limit the investigation. I begged Frank Church not to get into political assassinations abroad, said Senator Goldwater, because, It's going to end up in only one place, and that's the White House. On the other hand, said the Senator, not enough was found nut about abuses of Americans by institutions like the F.B.I. On another matter, when asked whether he thought former President Nixon was an honest man, the Senator replied, No, I don't think so, and I think that was his trouble. He said he had once asked Mr. Nixon to tell the truth about Watergate, and that Mr. Nixon then got kind of mad at me

title: Labor Is Refocusing on Goals
description: With joblessness growing and company profits generally being eroded by continuing recession and inflation, organized labor scarcely holds the whip hand in neuotiations this year.

title: PEOPLE
description: Remember when Julie Andrews didn't get to star in the movie version of My Fair Lady? And when Carol Charming was passed over in favor of Barbra Streisand for the Hollywood version of Hello, Dolly!? Well, take the case of Englewood's Jim Bouton. That's right, the former 20game winner for the New York Yankees of championship days. The fellow responsible for exposing some of baseball's hilariously zany seaminess in the bestseller, Ball Four. The nap who garnered some nice reviewes for his acting in the The Long Goodbye, a 1973 Robert Altman film. The WCBSTV broadcaster. The one who leaves every now and then to try to make a comeback as a pitcher.

title: A G.M. View: The Controls Are Working
description: A lot of people have very definite opinions about automobiles and air pollution. Some tell us:

title: Lisa Peters Sets Bridal To Peter Schiff In June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Turner Peters of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Peters, to Peter Grenville Schiff, younger son of John Mortimer Schiff of Oyster Bay, L. I., and the late Mrs. Schiff.

title: Events Today
description: Peter Pan Game: musical marionette show; 11 A.M., I and 3:30 P.M., Swedish Cottage, Central Park West off 81st Street, near the Delacorte Theater. (Call 9889093 for free reservations.)

title: A playful storm of sculpture
description: For over two months now, the city of New Yorknot only the island of Manhattan, the traditional locus of trendsetting cultural developments, but all five boroughshas been the scene of an extraordinary artistic event. The work of an American sculptor, still in his early 40's and little known to the vast majority of people who do not follow the arguments and opinions of the international art world, has been respiencientty installed in the public parks and other workaday outdoor locations at the same time that the Whitney Museum of American Art has been housing a retrospective exhibition of his smaller and more manageable creations. From a lakeside meadow in Prospect Park in Brooklyn to the neighborly reaches of Astoria Park on Ditmars Boulevard in Queens to the plaza of the elegant Seagram Building in midtown Manhattan, mammoth openform constructionscompletely abstract in design, yet unexpectedly friendly and encompassable in feelinghave delighted, baffled, and otherwise engaged the interest of passersby who, in most cases, have never set foot in a 57th Street art gallery. At the same time, in a gaily colored room at the Whitney Museum children clamber over smaller. similar works as if they were the commonplace facilities of a public playground. (The exhibition the Whitney remains on view through Feb. 8; the outdoor installations will be gradually dismantled during the late winter.)

title: Italy's Government Crisis Is Really Different This Time
description: ROMEAn Italian political crisis, because it is one of so many, normally generates a minimum of excitement, but the current one is different.

title: Reports from the Moscow bureaus
description: It is amazingworse, it is alarming to realize how little one knows about the Soviet Union. For 30 years the U.S.S.R. and the West have been locked into an apparently never ending arms race. Yet It is only now that we have an opportunity to learn something of what one of these excellent books calls the human quotient, the texture and fabric of the personal lives of the Russians as people.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Andrew York, who wrote The Dominator, The Predator The Expurgator and about a halfdozen more books with titles, ending in or, all dealing with the secret agent Jonas Wilde, has turned to new fields. With DARK PASSAGE (Doubleday, $5.95) he has dropped Wilde and introduced Tommy Angel. Angel is a big man, 6 feet inches tall. With that height comes corresponding strength, a keen enough intelligence and an innate honesty. In short, the man of one's dreams. York is a great one for supplying fantasy figures.

title: Stingers Top Whalers
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 24 (AP)Rich Dudley had two goals and the Sohchuck brothers, Dennis and Gene, had one each, to lead the Cincinnati Stingers to a 63 victory over the New England Whalers in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Games Security Guards to Outnumber Athletes, 2 to 1
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP)Nearly 5,000 specially trained Austrian policemen and troops will be assigned here during the upcoming Winter Olympice to insure no terrorist attacks occur during the Games.

title: Those Old Mechanical Banks: Pop Goes the Penny
description: Once upon a time it was fun to save money. A dog would jump through a hoop. Horses would race around a track. A football player would kick a ball. An eagle would feed her babies. And the minimum deposit was only a penny.

title: Monica Spence Fiancee
description: The engagement of Monica Elaine Spence to James Eugene Santelli Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Santelli of Oyster Bay, LI., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dexter Spence of Baldwinsville, N.Y. Miss Spence is studying for a Master of Arts degree at the State University at Binghamton. Here fianc is a student at the Temple University School of Dentistry.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices paused a bit during the middle of last week to absorb profittaking and then pushed ahead to continue the dazzling rally that has prevailed during the opening month of 1976.

title: Detroit Recovering in a Chastened Mood
description: DETROITk is over. The automobile industry's most troubled and unsettled period in postwar history has ended.

title: Few Savings in Car Rentals
description: Rentacar companies have just emerged from a price war of sorts, a phenomenon ??? is not uncommon in the industry. Extensive advertising campaigns have proclaimed simplified and reduced rates for the last three months, but benefits to the consumer are hard to discern.

title: New Test of Auto Industry's Standing in Congress Is Imminent
description: WASHINGTON  Just last month the automobile, which is already regulated bumper to bumper, became the subject of new controls with a law setting fuel efficiency standards. And the resolution of House and Senate versions of clean air standardsproposals known to have made industry officials extremely unhappywill provide another test in coming weeks of how many friends Detroit has on Capitol Hill.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynExhibition of works by six cooperative art galleries on Atlantic Avenue, beginning Tuesday through Feb. 3; Sundays, 1 to P.M. and Mondays through Saturdays, 7 P.M. to midnight, Lepercq Space, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue.

title: STUDY FINDS RISE IN ABORTIONS HERE
description: One in five New York City women of reproductive age has obtained a legal abortion here since the state's abortion law was liberalized in 1970, according to a report by three City Health Department officials.

title: Editors Choice
description: GUERRILLAS, by V.A. Naipaul. (Knopf, $7.95.) Artful. Conradian tale of futile revolutionaries on a Third World island smoldering with violence.

title: Trudeau Sees Echeverria
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Prime Minister Trudeau visited Mexico's petroleum research laboratories today and had further talks with President Luis Echeverria Alvarez on oil and other enegy matters on the second day of his fourday visit here.

title: Births
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wa?er J. Casey of Garden City, New York joytully announced the arrival ofKaren Marie on Mannar, December 29, 1975, in North Shore University HOSPital, Manhasset, Now York. Mrs. Casey, the former Veronica K. D?ng, is an ins?ucior in nursing at the Oueensborough Community Coliege. title: Rosalind F. Dobrin Is Fiancee of Editor
description: Mrs. Lionel Dobrin of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Rosalind F. Dobrin, to Richard M. Warshauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Warshauer of Tenafly, N. J. The wedding is planned for March 28.

title: Composer Draws on His Wartime Experiences
description: In 1944, when Hugo Weisgall, now a Great Neck resident who is a composer, conductor and educator, was serving as an assistant military attach with the United States Embassy in London, he came across an anthology of war poetry that spanned many conflicts.

title: African Development Hopes Dashed
description: ACCRA, GhanaAfricans realize their continent is not doing so well these days. The relentless burdens of recession and inflation, aggravated by trade deficits, have put a tremendous strain on the slim financial resources of many countries. And growing political uncertainties have added to the economic problems. Development suffered a sharp setback last year, and African hopes for progress are generally at the lowest ebb since 1960, when much of the continent gained independence.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: GOVERNOR Byrne, who thinks he rules the most in New Jersey, has been pecked at by the stabs Senate, the Speaker of the Assembly and the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

title: A Skiing Novice on a Skiing Weekend
description: MCAFES The Great Gorge Resort Hotel is rather like the Concord of New Jersey.

title: Five Years of Progress Following the Corrective Movement
description: In the economic, political and social fields, Syria has made an impressive number of achievements during the last five years which can be matched by only a few other developing countries. This point should be emphasized because over the past two decades Syria had acquired the reputation of a country rich in political turmoil and in hatred for foreign aid or investments. This is also responsible for the impression abroad of Syrian. economy being in a state of stagnation.

description: At the entrance of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, a plaque reads:

title: A Student Eyes Princeton's Chief
description: IN nearly three years as a student at Princeton, I have seen him perhaps 20 times and had dinner wan him once. But I know the thing I'll remember most vividly about William G. Bowen, president of the universityhis tennis shoes.

title: 26 Women Are Now Serving As Chaplains at Hillel Centers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22It was once an almost exclusive domain of the rabbi. Now, more and more women are becoming campus chaplains of B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundations.

title: Korea Girds For Economic Fray
description: One of the key factors contributing to the development of the economy in. Korea is effective utilization of foreign capital.

title: Leonard, Unrated Miler, Gets Chance, Wins Race
description: Kevin Leonard of Albertus Magnus went to the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday to compete in the unseeded section of the onemile run at the 27th annual Cardinal Hayes Games. He did the same thing a few weeks ago at the St. Francis meet, won his section bu went unplaced on a time basis in the final standing.

description: CAIROHafez alAssad, the tough but quietspoken and, even after more than five years in power. still enigmatic President of Syria has won a major personal and political triumph by persuading the opposing factions in the Lebanese civil war to agree to a ceasefire.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Forman of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy L. Forman, to Dr. Andrew LeaderCramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney LeaderCramer of London.

title: TV: A Blurry
description: TV stations in towns as small as Ottumwa, Iowa, endlessly celebrate the locality. Beautiful Ottumwa, Growing Ottumwa, Happy Ottumwa, the stationidentification slides say, usually against a picturepostcard background.

title: Dance: Erick Hawkins
description: The label of revolutionary is pinned rather easily these days on any fashionable choreographer. Unfortunately, there is a basic confusion between the original contribution any choreographer makes to his or her art (especially in modern dance) and those few dance figures who have radically changed the way we look at dance itself.

title: Hopes to Further Canada's Independent Course
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 24Prime; Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has begun an 11day tour of three Latin American countries; in which he hopes to en1 hance the Canadian image lands where Canada has been, screened from their view by the colossus of the United States, as an aid to Mr. Trudeau put it.

title: The Region
description: New York City still is in financial trouble of a serious kind. State officials say it has been slow to impose the restraints required of it in return for New'York State and Federal Government aid to avoid default, and now both the state and Washingtonseeking to curtail their own expenditures are proposing to cut the normal flow of funds to the city.

description: Cousin Joe, the foxy old New Orleans blues singer, was hanging around Jersey City with me some years ego when it occurred to him that he needed a haircut.

title: Canadian Paper Strike Proves Long and Costly
description: MONTREALThe sixthmonth strike in the Eastern Canada pulp and paper industry, which has cost several hundred million dollars in lost production and wages and forced cutbacks in size for some smaller American newspapers, is on the way to settlement.

title: Vancouver Old Handat China Trade
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaAs the major North American port closest to mainland China, Vancouver has more than its share of interest in the prospects of Chinese trade.

title: Judith Glixon Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Glixon, of. West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Miriam Glixon, to Peter Kutt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Kutt of West Brookfield, Mass. A May 23 wedding is planned. Miss Glixon's father is the editor and art director of Limited Editions Club and Heritage Press of Avon, Conn.

title: Poets and Politicians
description: When you begin a picture, said Picasso, you often make some pretty discoveries. You must be on guard against these. Destroy the thing, do it over several times. In each destroying of beautiful discovery the artist does not really suppress it, but rather transforms it, condenses it, makes it more substantial. What comes out in the end is the result of discarded finds. Otherwise, you become your own connoisseur. sell myself nothing!

title: David Sullivan, 71, Dead; ExHead of Service Union
description: David Sullivan, who retired in 1971 as president of the Service Enployees International Union, died Friday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 71 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

description: ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISEMENT

title: In Dacca, Life Is Precarious
description: DACCA, BangladeshThe boatmen of Bangladesh are an adventurous lot. For a taka or twoless than a dimethey will risk their boats, their lives and yours too.

title: American Victor In Speed Skating
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 24 (AP)  Peter Mueller of Mequon, Wis., won an international speedskating event at 1,000 meters today in a tuneup for next month's Winter Olympics.

title: The Nation
description: The health of the nation's banking industry has come under examination in Congress, but the Federal officials who regulate banks are reluctant to supply the information that members of Congress say they need.

title: The BelowDecks Loneliness of a LongDistance Cruise
description: FAR below the gaiety of the Promenade Deck, separated by caste and cash from the Pucci gowns and VanCleef & Arpels jewelry, are the people who feed and nurture the engineroom boilers, wash the laundry, cook the tons of food and clean the mountains of dishes. For themand for the abovedecks personnel, from waiter to captainthe cruise ship means hard work and, often, loneliness.

title: The Right to Own a Cadillac
description: DETROITOwners of luxury cars regard the ability to own a car of their own choice, and to drive it when and where they please, almost as an inalienable right.

title: Presidential Primaries Here Are Crowded
description: Long Island is shaping up as a major battleground in the Democratic Presidential primary April 6 but the Republican Presidential primary in the two counties will be relatively peaceful.

title: Steinke Honored Again
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 24 (AP)  For the second straight year, Gil Steinke of Texas A. and I. has been named football coach of the year by the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: Marty Robbins Back in Racing
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. (AP)Marty Robbins; the countrymusic singer has decided to return to stock car racing, a sport he gave up last summer because of its danger.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Arms Cheating May Be A Matter of Interpretation
description: WASHINGTON  Between Initial ambiguities in draftsmanship, overselling by the Administration and political rivalries, the initial euphoria over the 1972 strategic arms agreements has disintegrated into a debate over whether the Soviet Union is cheating the United States.

title: What Was This Opera Doing in the Rubble of the Roxy?
description: The music world learned recently that a manuscript of the unknown but seminal 18thcentury opera Metaxis in Accidie, by Imbroglio Valpolicella, had been unearthed at the site of the old Roxy Theater. The composer's own synopsis of his libretto, which follows, is remarkable for its purity of line, absence of melodrama, profundity of characterization and avoidance of contrived situations.

title: Miss Bigelow Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. D. Hardwick Bigelow of West Newton and Marshfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marion Ayer Bigelow, to Philip Wilkes Bianchi, son of Mrs. Arthur B. Marvin of New York and East Hampton, L. I., and the late Albert W. Bianchi.

title: Katherine Duffy To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Duffy of Wilton, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katherine HarlanDuffy, to Richard Blair McKeough Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKeough of Stamford, Conn. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Nader Group Urges the Federal Chartering of Big Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Ralph Nader, long a critic of alledged corporate abuses, called today for the Federal chartering of 700 giant corporations as a way of making them more democratic, efficient and lawabiding.

title: 9 Are Executed in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 (AP) A firing squad today executed nine guerrillas convicted of having killed several person, including three American colonels.

title: encounter: A Lesson in Hitchhiking From a Scottish Grande Dame
description: WHEN a fairytale witch suddenly stepped in front of our car on a narrow hack road in Scotland, we were forced to recbnsider our usual ban on hitchhikers.

title: NOBUKO IMAI HEARD IN RECITAL ON VIOLA
description: Nobuko Imai, a violist who made her solo debut here in 1968 as a Young Concert Artists Audition winner and has made several appearances in New York since then, gave recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon.

title: President and Candidate Ford Says Retrench
description: President Ford has delivered his state of the union message and his new budget, statements which together describe his proposed course for both the Government and his Presidential campaign. Most of his plans have little chance of being enacted in their original form. Those that are acted on at all will probably represent compromises between the President and the Democratic Congress, which like him will be strongly influenced by the political demands of an election year.

title: Thousands of Refugees Trying to Return to Angola
description: LISBON, Jan. 24Not this time, maybe next time, an Angolan woman told a 31yearold Portuguese store manager who has been waiting a month and a half to return to Angola.

title: Letters
description: With reference to Leslie H. Gelb's article (Should we play dirty tricks in the world? Dec. 21), C.I.A. should stand for Cancer in America, and we'd better cut it out before it kills us.

title: In Scandinavia, Norway Alone Sees Big Gains
description: COPENHAGEN, DenmarkA single ray of sunshine pierces the Scandinavian winter, illuminating Norway's North Sea oil fields, which promise the country it can weather the current recession better than any country in Europe.

title: A Rebuilt Track Awaits Millrose
description: The Madison Square Garden track season opens Friday night with the Wanamaker Millrose Games, and there is more than the normal amount of excitement in the air for the occasion. Not only does Millrose have its usual complement of top athletes, but it will also be the first meet for a reconstructed Garden track that arena officials believe will produce faster times.

title: U.S. and Spain Sign Pact For Defense Cooperation
description: MADRID, Jan. 24 The United States and Spain signed a fiveyear Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation today that marked a rise in status for Spain in the Western defense community.

title: Vail, Harrelson Sign Mets Contracts
description: Mike Vail, an outfielder and an instant success last year when he tied a National League record for a rookie by hitting in 23 consecutive games, and Bud Harrelson, the experienced shortstop, signed 1976 contracts yesterday with the New York Mets.

title: HOUSE UNIT SCORES POVERTY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) The Federal antipoverty agency should be reorganized because of job abuses and executive mismanagement, a Congressional committee recommended today.

title: Britain, in Spirit of 76, Sending Artists to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 About onethird of the $1 million that Britain has allocated to mark the loss of its American colonies will be spent on the arts, under the direction of a dapper Yorkshireman whose plans include the export of some of Britain's lessknown cultural enterprises.

title: CORRECTION
description: The dates of the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements at Vancouver were incorrectly given in The New York Times last Sunday. The correct dates are May 31 to June 11.

title: Power in the Levant
description: The worst has been averted in Lebanon, at least temporarily. A new distribution of power among forces inside and outside the divided country has now taken place.

title: Mexico's Industry Now More Confident
description: NIZAICO CITYAfter severe years tribulation over inflation and recession and life under an essentially antibusiness administration Mexican businessmen are looking forward to better days.

title: The World
description: Secretary of State Henry Kissinger went to Moscow last week to try to further progress on a new agreement on limiting nuclear arms, and also to try to define how dtente, applies to such areas of conflict as Angolan civil war.

title: Virginia Rogers and Lawyer to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dwight L. Rogers Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia B. Rogers, to Jeffrey V. McCormick, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Stanley McCormick of Manchester, Conn.

title: Pursuit of Sounder Economic Basic
description: The year 1975 was a period when Korea had to endure economic difficulties amidst persisting worldwide recession and inflationary trends. The difficulties were acute, especially in the sectors of international payments position and import commodity prices.

title: From Paris La Guerre duVin
description: ROMEA few weeks ago, several thousand small winegrowers in southern France converged on the Mediterranean port of Sete, set up roadblocks on the main roads, and then tore up half mile of railway track with the help of bulldozers and axes.

title: Small Cars Mean Big Gain in Sales
description: DETROITAlmost 15 percent of all cars now being sold in the United States are subcompacts, and the demand has yet to peak, according to one Chevrolet estimate.

title: Briton to Sail Atlantic to Show Irish Could Have Discovered America
description: CROSSHAVEN. Ireland, Jan. 24A strangelooking boat, made of leather stretched over wooden ribs, was launched here today for a voyage into the past.

title: Egypt Counts on Canal and Oil To Bolster SelfSufficiency
description: CAIROIn 1975, possibly, the Egyptian economy ceased to be a bottomless barrel in which huge gifts from the oilrich Arabs and lowinterest loans from Western governments disappeared without a trace.

title: NinetoFive Philodendra
description: A new growth industry: rentaplant.

title: Gratovich,Violinist, In Debut Program
description: Eugne Gratovich, a Ukrainianborn, largely Americantrained violinist who teaches at San Francisco State University, played an unorthodox program for his debut here last Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. To open it, he made the ironic juxtaposition of sonatas by John Alden Carpenter and Charles Ives.

title: Pamphleteering About 76
description: Most Jerseyans do not have to be told that their state was a crossroads for the armies fighting the War of Independence. If nothing else, they are acquainted with the desperate winter that General Washington spent at Morristown and the crucial importance of his victory at Trenton.

title: Leprosy in Cameroon
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon. Jan. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Cameroon has 43.816 lepers. or seven of every thousand citizens, according to figures published here. Specialists here hope leprosy can be eradicated by the end or the century.

title: Endpaper
description: Here are some questions and answers explaining the origins of the crisis, its current dimensions, and how widespread the effects are likely to be.

title: Marquette Vanquishes Fordham
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (AP) Marquette routed Fordham tonight, 9264, giving the highranked Warriors their 10th straight basketball victory.

title: CHICAGO SCHOOLS MORE SEGREGATED
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24The new academic year is half finished, and Chicago's public schools have grown even more tightly segregated.

title: National economic planning will arrive when businessmen demand it and demand it they will, to save the capitalist system.
description: America is drifting into economic planning. One may deplore the tactHerbert Stein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Nixon, tells us that planning will make the economy more inflationary, less free, and less efficient. One may denounce itThomas Murphy, chairman of General Motors, predicts that national planning will be a prescription for national chaos, or, at best, national stagnation. One may dread itWalter Wriston, chairman of First National City Bank, warns us that planning will destroy our personal liberties.

title: College At Westbury Is Given High Marks
description: The State University college at Old Westbury has received generally high marks from a national team reviewing the school's application for accreditation. A formal report is expected to be issued late next month.

title: Mayor Appoints Hornstein To Planning Commission
description: Howard D. Hornstein, a commissioner on the Board of Standards and Appeals, has been appointed by Mayor Beame to the City Planning Commission.

title: Black Businessman Abducted, But Alabama Ransom Bid Fails
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 24 (AP)A. G. Gaston, one of the nation's wealthiest black men, was kidnapped today in what the police said was a ransom attempt that fell apart at the seams.

title: The Banks: In the Fed's Own Words
description: Last week, the nation got a rare inside look at how Federal regulators view some of America's largest banking institutions.

title: L.I. Officials Assail Carey's Budget Cuts
description: Governor Carey's $10.8 billion nonewtaxes budget, in which he proposed sharp cutbacks in various forms of state aid, has drawn concern from Long Island officials and residents who say that the longrange impact on Nassau and Suffolk would be severe.

title: Hunter Title To Slice O'Life
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Jan. 24Slice O'Life, owned and ridden by Nora Goodhue, scored in all three classes to capture the junior working championship today at the opening session of the twoday The Hill Horse Show.

title: Sara Petersen, Jeffrey R. Buell Wed in Suburb
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Sara Elizabeth Petersen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E.. Petersen of Bronxville, became the bride of Jeffery Richard Buell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Buell of Naugatuck, Conn.

title: ART VIEW
description: The question is often asked: Whatever happened to painting? Meaning, of course: Whatever happened to the kind of painting that is representational, that addresses itself to subjects, that is firmly based on the depiction of people, places and the other observable things of this world? The underlying assumption in this question is that the art of painting, in order to remain a viable form of art, long ago abandoned these venerable interests in favor of more abstract, more tironical or more transcendent modes of expression. As a resultso this assumption goeswe are obliged to resign ourselves to the absence of something that once delighted us but now no longer exists.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ONCE ONE becomes a regular user of New Jersey's commuter buses, it isn't at all difficult to spot other practiced riders. As a group, we just don't ride on buses as New Yorkers do; we seek comfort in them, nestle into them, sleep in them and, although it is admittedly hard to manage, after a day's work we try to find solitude in them.

title: Shah of Iran Uses Oman to Train Armed Forces
description: SALALA, OmanThe Shah of Iran, who has never fought a major war, has been seen using this remote Arabian sultanate as a practice field for his armed forces.

title: A Machine Reduces Postoperative Clotting of Blood
description: A machine that lets a patient's legs float on air has helped prevent a common and potentially fatal complication of routine surgery, according to preliminary test results reported at a medical meeting here last week.

title: Many Nigerian Workers Quitting Neighbor State
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Nearly 25,000 Nigerians are estimated to have returned from Equatorial Guinea since the Government charged that Nigerians working, on plantations there had received barbaric treatment.

title: State Gives Hampton Jitney GoAhead
description: Despite opposition from the Long Island Rail Road, an express bus that operates between the South Fork and New York City has been given the goahead from the state Department of Transportation.

title: An Asian Common Market May Be Far Away, but Five Nations Work Toward
description: JAKARTAFor years, the economic visionaries of Southeast Asia have alked wistfully of the advantages and future of a Southeast Asian Common Market.

title: The Automobile Through Children's Eyes
description: In children's eyes, a car becomes more than a vehicle. It becomes a rounded igloo with windows on the world, or a home on wheels, or a fantasy machine. These drawings are by children who were asked what cars looked like to them. In their unique way, the drawings may be insights to the consumers of tomorrow.

title: How Yuri Maximovich Isakovsky survived
description: Ask an American to name three living poets and you can bet the rent money one of them will be Yevtushenko, shorn of his Christian name perhaps, but Yevtushenko. Yet should be clear by now that the popularity of this Kahlil Gibran of the literature of dtente owes less to poetry than to publicity, bumptious charm, playacting and safe mischief. He reads aloud theatrically, with voice trained to convey ginger or saccharine, and a manner both boyishly ingratiating and grave. He has snookered many a critic into dealing with him on a seriousnot to say etherealplane. Here's one, Delbert Phillips, writing about Yevtushenko a couple of years ago: Filled with hope and bitterness, he seeks to establish the meaning of life while examining the nature of injustice in the world.

title: Fire Kills 13,000 Chickens
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Jan. 24 (UPI)More than 13,000 chickens were killed last week in a fire that destroyed their coop in nearby Lower Milford Township.

title: E. J. DeCastro Fiance Of Mary Lou Magrino
description: Allan J. Magrino, deputy inspector of the New York Police Department, and Mrs. Magrino of Pearl River, N.Y., have made known the engagdment of their daughter, Mary Lou Magrino, to Edward 3. DeCastro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony G. DeCastro of Woodhaven, Queens. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Caracas Now Its Own Boss
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaShortly before Venezuela nationalized its vital oil industry on New Year's Day, a newspaper poll here found almost all its readers viewed the action as the opening of a huge cornucopia of wealth.

title: Saigon Movies Free for Tet
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 21 (Agence France Presse)  The people of Saigon and its environs can go to the movies free of charge next Saturday on Tet, the first day of the lunar new year, the Saigon radio has reported.

title: Patchwork of History At Greenfield Village
description: DEARBORN, Mich.John Nyers, in striped overalls and railroad cap, reaches. up to ring the bell on the Torch Lake, and the train pulls away from the Main Street station through its own steam:

title: The Geniuses Who Shaped an Industry
description: Agenius, as defined by Webster, has a single strongly marked capacity or aptitude, or extroardinary power as shown in creative activity. Genius, according to Thomas A. Edison, is 1 percent inspiration, 99 percent perspiration. By either yardstick, the auto industry, spawning ground of some of the nation's most creative, hardworking men, has produced its share of geniuses.

title: Saw Pen's Potential
description: The son of a salesman, Milton Reynolds made it to the pinnacle of that calling, having won and lost several fortunes before the ball point pen wrote his ticket for success andfor a spellpublic attention.

title: Some Help From Debussy For the Hassled Driver
description: It's 5:45 on a Friday afternoon and you're stuck with hundreds of others on the West Side Highway trying to get out of town. But instead of leaning on your horn and raising the din outside. you slide a cassette into your tape deck and listen to Debussy's Suite Bergamasque.

title: Shapp Plan Sets Limit on Campaigning
description: MIAMI, Jan. 22Governor MiRod J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, regarded as an underdog in the Democratic Presidential contest, is trying to turn that fact into an advantage that could win him the nomination at the party's convention next July.

title: Montauk Benefit
description: MONTAUKThe East End musical community will hold a Red Mending party today at 2 P.M. at the Montauk Yacht Club on Star Island here to raise funds for Jon Tooker, a local musician who was seriously injured in a car accident recently. Among those appearing at the benefit will be Tom Paxton, Athena Hendrickson, Christian Johnson and Winter Sky.

title: GARDENING
description: FOR VARIETY in winter bulbs, try the uncommon, but easy, Clivia miniata (or one of its hybrids) and the Amazon lily (Eucharis grandiflora). Both belong to the Amaryllis family, both are beautiful and they have other characteristics in commons.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT ROSE 5.4 percent to $1,217.4 billion in the fourth quarter in terms of 1972 dollars, and in current dollars was up 12 percent to $1,573.2 billion. For all of 1975, however, G.N.P. was down 2 percent in real dollars. The Consumer Price Index in December rose 0.5 percent, as against a rise of 0.7 percent in November. For 1975 the C.F.I. went up 7 percent, the smallest annual Increase since 1972. The Federal Budget for the year to end June 30, 1977, sent to Congress by President Ford proposes expenditures of $394.2 billion and a deficit of $43 billion.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Threat and Reaction
description: The chief danger is not in the sale of giant billiondollar nuclear power reactors to produce electricity; weapons grade fissionable material is never present most of these reactors. It lies in the GermanBrazilian and FrenchKorean sales of pilot reprocessing plants to extract weaponsgrade plutonium from spent reactor fuel rods.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE DOZEN stores at Historic Murray Hill Square, a Colonialstyled shopping village in New Providence, are housed in reproductions of buildings that once existed in this town.

title: Sarah Koehrie, Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Koehne of Sutton, Vt., formerly of Lawrence, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah M. Koehne, to Mark Scharfenaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wulimb Joseph Scharfenaker of Dearborn, Mich. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Critics at the Wheel
description: PHILADELPHIAI visited some automobile dealers showrooms recently for the first time in 20 years, and it was like opening a time capsule. For in all those years while we have been sending men to the moon, and discovering women on earth, the auto industry has merely moved from the tail fin to the opera window.

title: The Disinformation Game
description: BRUSSELSAll rival intelligence services practice private propaganda wars against each other. These feature smear campaigns, efforts to discredit each other's agents, blackmail, traps designed to have opponents declared persona non grata in foreign countries, et cetera.

title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
description: I would appreciate your having your Mr. Richard Reeves, who wrote the article on the 15 most powerful people in New Jersey, advise me as to where I can locate all those houses in Summit that sell for $125,000 and have a property tax of $1,400.

title: Not Only Drought Hurts Soviet Crops
description: MOSCOWWhen the Soviet Union suffered its worst harvest in a decade last year, the Kremlin blamed the weather. But the prolonged drought of 1975 was not solely responsible for the sad yield that officials implied was only 135 million tons, or more than onethird below plan.

title: Islamic Leader Sentenced To 8 Years on Drug Charge
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 24 (UPI)Nathaniel Muhammad, leader of the temple of the nation of Islam here, was senitenced yesterday to eight years in prison for a drug conviction.

title: MAYOR BIDS STATE MT 9 HOSPITALS
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday that the state order the closing of nine voluntary and proprietary hospitals with more than 1,100 beds here as unessential or out of compliance with codes, saying it would make the overall healthcare system more efficient and economical.

title: V.I.P. Rides in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  The chauffeured ego trips of nearto 800 Federal officials hero may be in danger.Senator William Proxmire, who for years has tried to force all but toplevel Government officials out of their chauffeured limousines, may be geting support this year from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Guatemala Drills for Big Find
description: GUATEMALA CITY, GuatemalaIn the wild rain forests up north near the elbow in the Mexican border, brawny, barechested men are working around the clock in hopes of finding a fortune in oil.

title: Parking Ban Aims For Cleaner City
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations were not designed to hound the motorist or to raise more revenue for the city. They were devised to help, workmen clean the city's streets, and originated under the opals of the Departrnent of Sanitation.

title: Fort Lee: Suburb of Japan
description: THE children of Tojuro Nishi remove their shoes before entering their balconied apartment on 15th Street. in Fort Lee, observing without question the Japanese tradition.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The number and intensity of complaints from collectors about Bicentennial coins and medals have increased with each new issue. Dissatisfaction has been expressed concerning prices, selling methods, deliveries  with the heaviest accent on high prices. A new peak of collector resentment has apparently been aroused by the pricing of the various types of the official National Bicentennial Medal. As reported in this column Dec. 21, the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration is offering the medal in seven combinations of sizes and metals: a threeinch gold version of the medal, priced at $4,000; a 1 5/16inch gold medal at $400; a .906inch gold jewelrysize version at $100; a threeinch sterling silver medal at $150; a 1inch sterling silver version at $25; a. 1inch goldplated bronze medal at $15, and a 1inch bronze version of the medal at $5. These medals went on sale Jan. 1 and will continue to be available through July 31. They are being struck for the A.R.B.A. by the U.S. Mint. The ire of collectors is being directed at both of these organizations.

title: Cuba, Swallowing Promises, Now Shapes Modest Aims
description: MIAMI  In the early 1960's, Premier Fidel Castro used to say that by 1980 every Cuban family would ??? a houase, an automobile (or at least a motorcycle) and a large refrigerator full of the most varied, countrygrown foodstuffs.

title: Finnish Skater Scores
description: INZELL, West, Germany, Jan, 24 (UPI)Paula Halonen of Finland won the 500Meter run today at an international sprint speed skating match. Miss Halonen was clocked in 43.61 seconds. John Granath of Sweden won the men's 500 meters in 39.49.

title: Foreman, Down Twice, Knocks Out Lyle in 5th
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.. Jan. 24 George Foreman, beginning serious pursuit of the heavyweight championship he lost to Muhammad Ali 15 months ago, knocked out Ron Lyle in the fifth round today in wildswinging brawl that resembled an old Hollywood movie.

title: Iowa High Court Upholds State Ban on Prostitution
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 24 (UPI)The Iowa Supreme Court has ruled that state law prohibiting prostitution constitutional and does not discriminate against women.

title: A Bigger Slice of a Smaller Pie
description: DETROIT  A recessionbred quest for security has emerged as the underlying theme as the United Automobile Workers unionthe nation's largest industrial union begins to gird itself for the negotiations with the auto companies that begin in the fall.

title: Puns and twists
description: DOWN

title: ARMS SALES STIR DISPUTE IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Jan. 24A moral and political controversy over France's lucrative sale of arms abroad is being stirred by the Archbishop of Paris, Franois Cardinal Marty, and by prominent leftists.

title: FOOD
description: When Gilbert Reynolds went into the catering business, he ran into at least one hazard he had not foreseen.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Well, the theater still has its poets, with or without words. I'm not necessarily thinking of serious poetry at the moment: nothing demanding, nothing profound, not even anythins rhetorical enough to mole drafts in the auditorium. Just a gift for imagery tliat may be prickly enoughor possibly goofy enoughto make you stop whatever you're doing (taking notes, ordering coffee in cabarets, dodging the rumbling tumbrils that charge directly through the standing audience at La Mama) and cling to the unexpected sound or sight, unwaveringly, until it's had its odd will of you.

title: Hunting for Leonardo's Lost Masterpiece
description: In a contract signed by Machiavelli, Leonardo da Vinci was awarded in 1504 what he considered the most important artistic commission of his career: a huge, heroic mural for Florence's Palazzo Vecchio, seat of the Florentine government. Art historians have long believed that the mural, which was only partially completed, was destroyed about 50 years after Leonardo began working on it. But now there seems reason to believe that the mural might still exist, after all; and an intensive search combining artistic expertise and scientific ingenuity, is under way to find it.

title: For First Time, China Reports Air Disaster
description: PEKING, Jan. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Chinese Government announced today that a Chinese airliner crashed this week, killing all persons aboard. It was the first official announcement of a Chinese airline disaster.

title: Picture credits
description: 1DESIGN BY SEYMOUR CHWAST, PUSH PIN STUDIO 1720PAT WARNER 2627BLACK STAR/BOB BENYAS 30UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL 34SLACK STAR/BOB SENYAS 3840ERIK HILGEROT 50HANS NAMUTH 57OGILVY, DENSON AND MATHER, INC., DOYLE DANE SERNSACH; SCALI, MCCABE. SLOVES. INC. 58JILL FREEDMAN

title: POINTS OF VIEW.
description: As the race for the Presidency begins to pick up steam, an interesting question to consider is whether economic issues are likely to help or hurt the Republican chances of keeping control of the White House. The standard economic forecast for 1976 is for a real growth rate of about 6 percent and for an unemployment rate of slightly over 7.5 percent. Both of these numbers are high by historical standards. In 1976 expectations are that the level of economic activity will be below average, but the change in the level will be above average.

title: Suzanne C. Rinfret Is Affianced. To Donald Ashton Moore Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Pierre A. Rinfret of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Chartrand Rinfret, to Donald Ashton Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of San Marino and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: A Book
description: The book is, as Desi Arnaz puts it, written my way, with my own not too good knowledge of the English language. His way Includes a lot of notsofunny sexual jokes, some good ragstoriches tales about making it in the Latincombo night club belt, some homey I Love Lucy anecdotes and a lot of sentiment about family and country. His way offers no felicitous phrases and few insights into Cuba, television or his tumultuous marriage to Lucille Ball. What the book comes down to is the force of his presence.

title: Britons Hopeful as Belt Tightens
description: LONDON  The British people, who read dire warnings almost daily of economic storms ahead, are being encouraged to look beyond the bleak foreground to the far horizon.

title: Benefit at Paper Mill
description: The New Jersey Historical Society will benefit from Wednesday night's performance of the Cole Porter musical You Never Know at the Paper Mill Playhouse, in. Millburn, N. J. Tickets at $20, $35 and $50 are available from society headquarters at 230 Broadway, Newark.

title: President, Worldwatch Institute
description: The principal surprise of the last decade was that the food scarcity emerging during the midseventies did not prove temporary as so many had assumed. Rather, it became more or less chronic, even worsening for a period in the late seventies.

title: Rip van Winkle Jrs. Describe 1985
description: At Home (Circa December 1985) SHE: Did you finally see the doctor about your headaches?

title: Leslie Megear,Fashion Editor, Fiancee of Crandall S. Connors
description: The engagement of Leslie Randolph Megear to Crandall Saville Connors has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Harrison Megear of Brookville, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Connors is the son of Mrs. Victor N. Connors of New York and the late Mr. Connors.

title: NEW! IMPROVED!
description: Uncle Sam belched. He was munching on his eighth Hebrew National hot dog. A little more movement, said director Steve Horn (handlebar mustache and white suspenders). You're anticipating by a hair. A production assistant picked the lint off Uncle Sam's satin suit, fluffed his long white beard and handed him another hot dog.

title: Conservation Unit Party
description: A theater party is planned at Tuesday's performance of A Chorus Line at the Shubert Theater to raise funds for the Fire Island Pines Conservation Society. Tickets at $10 to $40 can be obtained from the Islanders Club, 322 East 34th Street.

title: Hocuspocus and HoHoKus
description: In addition to the authentic history of place names, there is a pseudoscience variety of toponymy that specializes either in placename jokes and puns (a bit like the ethnic jokes that are so much deplored in certain circles) or in popular and obviously false etymologies of the names themselves.

title: FILM VIEW
description: At a crucial point in Seven Beauties, Lina Wertmuller's epic new film about an Italian soldier's efforts to survive in a German concentration camp near the end of World War II, Pasqualino (Giancarlo Giannini), the soldier, determines that he might be able save himself if he makes love to the camp's particularly ferocious female officer. As played by Shirley Stoler, the American actress (The Honeymoon Killers), this woman is a kind of Superbitch of Belseri..She's so large, so fleshy, so pinkskinned, so smalleyed, so utterly implacable, and so apparently without conventional sexual needs (it would seem to anyone in his right mind), that only a very desperate man would undertake such a doomed campaign. But Pasqualino is that desperate as well as slightly lunatic.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor: It is quite obvious that Martin Garbus did not do his homework as a good lawyer should, because as far as my series Petrocelli is concerned, h;s article The Case Against Perry Mason [Dec. 28] was full of errors that any jury could see right through. If Mr. Garbus had take??? the time to look at the evidence, i.e., watch my series, he would have seen that Petrocelli: (1) doesn't win every case; (2) doesn't have only white clients; (3) doesn't always prove his clients totally innocent; (4) does charge fees to his clients who can afford them.

title: Mexico Fears an Increase in Heroin Addiction Among Its, Young People
description: MEXICO CITY. Jan. 24The Government is fearful that the increased production of Mexican heroin for smuggling into the United States may lead to a wave of heroin addiction hare.

title: Asian Bank Pressed by Need
description: MANILAThe daily auction at the fishing port in suburban Navotas reaches its peak at noon, when the boats anchored at Manila bay have finished unloading their catch of tuna and anchovies and the wholesale buyers from inland markets have arrived.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Cup Slalom Event Won by Stenmark
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 24  Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, the World Cup leader, rallied with the fastest second heat today and overcame Gustavo Thoeni and Piero Gros of Italy to win the Olympic Preview special slalom ski race, highlighted by the United States's strongest showing ever in this World Cup event.

title: An Impressive Debut for Dance in America
description: As a professional dancegoer, I am not. naive enough to believe that when I turn on the telly to see a dance program. I am going to have the smne. experience as at a live perronnance in a theater. But I do expect television's ps tsentation of dance to remain true to the spirit of a dance work as I remember it on stage or to the intent of its choreographer. These are, of course, Great Expectations.

title: A First Lady of the Dance
description: Mondays are her day off, but tomorrow Audree Estey will be putting in a full day's work, as she does each week. She is not complaining.

title: Mexico Bars S. Africa
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 (UPI)Mexico will not meet South Africa in the Davis Cup North American tennis final, and will seek to ban South Africa from the competition permanently. Thus, an old cup controversy has been revived.

title: Trial of Patricia Hearst for Robbery to Open Tuesday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24Patricia Hearst, uprooted by kidnappers two years ago from a comfortable life, goes on trial Tuesday for a bank robbery she has said she took part in to save herself, when society was powerless to help her.

title: A Youth Who Loves Cars and the Bigger the Better
description: Cars are a passion of mine. This undoubtedly comes from my grandfather, who has been a car buff since he learned to drive on a 1919 Moon.

title: Men's Designers Show They Have a Way With Women,Too
description: It's easier to go from designing women's clothes to men's clothes than the reverse, observes Ralph Lauren.

title: Pinhas Lavon, Defense Minister Of Israel in Sabotage Case, Dies
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 24Pinhas Lavon, the key figure in the affair that clouded Israel's political life for a decade, died this morning after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Mideast Sales Sought to Avert Trade Deficits
description: Under prodding from top Government officials anxious to avoid disastrous trade deficits, businessmen have been beating paths to the Middle Eastern oil exporters. And often they have been coming back with some of the most lucrative contracts they have ever landed.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TomorrowWestchester Corvette Association meeting at Canada Lounge, Mamaroneck Avenue and Grand Street, Mamaroneck, N. Y., 8 P.M. Information: Ron Schwartz, phone (914) 9370818.

title: American Art to 1920 at a Gallery on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEYThe Country Art Gallery has been one of the mainstays of the Long Island art community. Ever since it was opened in 1953 by Clarissa Watson, it has offered Long Islanders a rich diversity of art exhibitions and collectors with some choice items that have become part of distinguished Long Island collections.

title: Convention Centers: Another Kind of Show Business
description: The shelving of plans to build a convention and exhibition center along the Hudson River between 43d and 47th Streets has raised anew the whole issue where such a facility should be located and how can be financed.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States was accused yesterday by Prime Minister Pinnock Eduardo of the proWestern Angolan government of failing to establish a diplomatic or military balance in the struggle for control of the country, and of harming the proWestern coalition. He said that the United States had neither attained its goal of persuading the Soviet Union to moderate its influence in the conflict, nor had it armed antiCommunist forces to enable them to confront successfully the Sovietarmed Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola and its Cuban allies. The declarations of Ford and Kissinger even do us harm, Mr. Eduardo said. Whenever they bang their fists on the table against our enemies, the Russians take them seriously and increase military aid to the M.P.L.A. The Americans don't match this by aid to us. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Politically Subtle
description: CARACASAgainst the expectation of many, Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte is still supreme in Chile. Twentyeight months after a military coup overthrew the Allende administration, General Pinochet wields greater power than all but a few Presidents have had in the country's century and a half of indenendence.

title: CORRECTION
description: The dates of the United Nations Conference on Human Settlements at Vancouver were incorrectly given in The New York Times last Sunday. The correct dates are May 31 to June 11.

title: Theater Notes: MillerWilliams DoubleBill At the Phoenix
description: We felt this was a good year to provide an overview of what went on in our past. There's something special about the theater's way of givihg you a look at the way things were. T. Edward Hambleton, the managing director of the Phoenix repertory company, was responding to a question about the allAmerican program that the Phoenix is bringing to Broadway, starting tomorrow night at the Playhouse Theater on West 48th Street. The Phoenix hunches its 23d season with a doublebill of oneact plays by Arthur Miller (A Memory of Two Mondays) and Tennessee Williams (27 Wagons Full of Cotton), Tuesday night, Sidney Howard's They Knew What They Wanted Joins the MillerWilliams duo in repertory for six weeks. Come April 12 and 13, the program changes to William Gillette's Secret Service and Bella and Samuel Spewack's Boy Meets Girl.

title: Lawyers Proliferate and Prosper
description: Ten years ago J. C. Penney Corporation had 25 lawyers on its payroll. By 1973 the number had risen to 66. Today it's 94.

title: Dr. Denise Michelle Nagel Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Nagel of Grantham, N. H., and Pompano Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Denise Michelle Nagel, to Michael H. Wald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lee Wald of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Lovers and other Irishmen
description: From the early masterpiece, Midsummer Night Madness, set in the era of the AngloIrish War of 191921, to Lovers of the Lake, a story about adulterous lovers going on pilgrimage to St. Patrick's Eurgatory in Lough Derg, O'Faolain's fiction has been remarkable, in an Irish context, tor the attention n gives to passionate love and sexuality along with the more familiar Irish literary obsessions of religion, politics, family and autobiography. In Lovers of the Lake the man, an agnostic Dublin surgeon, follows his mistress around the torturous sequence of stations on the grim penitential island as a sort of lover's compliment. The woman, on the other hand, is a true believer, although she has scarcely less expectation of giving up her lover than she has of divorcing a husband who has ceased to appeal to her. Add that both these people are affluent, welleducated, urbane and welltraveled, genuinely representative of the Roman Catholic middleclass elite which has been running things in the Republic for the last generation or so, and one will understand why this story has been called by some critics the first modern Irish story.

title: CITY FISCAL AIMS SEEN IN REACH
description: Although New York city is within reach of its current financial objective, a Federal Treasury official said yesterday, the city needs to make more progress in controlling its spending and in generating more of its own revenue.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman proposed yesterday abolishing state and local cigarette taxes and replacing them with a uniform Federal tax to help wipe out cigarette bootlegging. The RepublicanLiberal legislator proposed that the Federal Government establish a nationwide price of 40 cents per pack, including a 21cent tax, and reimburse state and localities for lost revenues. The price would exclude sales taxes. In a speech to the Wholesale Tobacco Distributors of New York, he said cigarette bootlegging had grown rapidly in recent years because of illegal profits made possible by wide disparity in cigarette taxes.

title: Sports Today
description: Queens at Hunter, 5 P.M. (Radio WNYCAM. 5 P.M.)

title: Concerning pain and beauty
description: In her first book, The Gift Horse, autobiographical as is The Verdict, Hildegard Knef said, I busied myself with a fresh outbreak of dysentefy and the only thing I ever learned: survival. She recounted her survival in Germany through World War II: malnutrition, the terrors of bombing and occupation, detention in a Russian prison camp, illnesses and operations; survival at war's end through the theater (she became an actress at 16) and the world of movies in Europe and America; her survival as a singer. It was written with such urgency for life, such steelyeyed observation, with the wit and comic sense of a Berliner loosed on an everexpanding stage, and with generosity, too, that, reading it, one is swept along, enlarged in understanding, touched with respect and affection.

title: State joins Fight for a Pond
description: For most of the last 15,000 years, winter transformed Potamogeton Pond in Queens Village into a downy wonderland of snow before spring warmed it back to a pastoral oasis bristling with animal and plant life. Now civilization has entered the scene and environmentalists are fighting to make sure nature is not disturbed.

title: ANGOLAN LEADER SEES U.S. HARMING HIS SIDE'S EFFORTS
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 24Pinnock Eduardo, Prime Minister of the government set up by proWestern factions in part of Angola, accused the United States today of harming his coalition and failing to establish a diplomatic or military balance in the struggle for the former Portuguese colony.

title: Around the world people still find the time and the money for the best things in
description: IN a generally somber world economic outlook, with catastrophe, if not economic cataclysm, seeming lurk round every corner, a diligent search has uncovered some cheerful aspects of economic developments in a number of countries.

title: Why Humphrey Endures
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The latest bulletin from George Gallup is that Hubert Humphrey is leading the Democratic poll and running almost even with President Ford in a nationwide test of preference for the Presidency. Which raises the question of how Mr. Humphrey manages to survive.

title: Running the Trenton Blockade
description: The loudspeakers at the rear of the State Assembly chamber were turned off when Governor Byrne delivered his State of the State address earlier this month, but it didn't matter. The Governor was talking to those in the chamber but his speech was really pitched toward the public, and his message was simply, Trust me.

title: Hunger Still Haunts the World
description: Hunger Still Haunts the World

title: Breaking Up the Oil Industry
description: WASHINGTON This country does not have an energy policy. The President wants a noncompetitive private sector to make basic energy decisions. The Congress supports Government regulation. Neither side has the power to impose its will. The result is the confused energy bill that passed Congress last year.

title: Computer Will Keep Tabs Suffolk Legislation
description: HAUPPAUGEComputerization has come to the Suffolk County Legislature, bringing with it a promise of greater public access and savings in time.

title: Squires Take Replay; Then Nets Win, 9485
description: NORFOLK, Va., jan. 24 (UPI)The box score wound up different but the result was unchanged when the Virginia Squires beat the New York Nets tonight, 107100, in a partial replay of their Jan. 7 game.

title: Bruins Rout Wings, 61, As Bucyk Scores Twice
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)John Bucyk's hockey gets better with age. The 40yearold left wing, in his 22d National Hockey League season, scored two goals in the first Boston Bruins to a 61 rout 10 minutes to lead the hot of the Detroit Red Wings today.

title: Fashion
description: This winter in the cold climates every other girl and boy from 13 to 22 will be wearing a down jacket 2nd Frye boots. They were coronated as fashion fad sometime last winter, but it takes a while for the word to get back to the older generations, the buyers at department stores and the weary parents who have to replace perfectly good, once adored, now ignored ski jackets, pea coats, Eskiloos, Wallabees and other common clothing.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: I wish to thank you for the great honor you did to Chinese poetry by featuring Sunflower Splendor on the front page (Dec. 21), and of course David Lattimore for his erudite and discerning review.

title: Impoverished Demanding Others Help
description: PANAMA CITY, PanamaFor the hungry and impoverished peoples of the third and fourth worlds. 1975 was not a year for meditating or inquiring about their economic condition, which shows little chance of improving.

title: Dr. Wallace Gordon Dies; An Official of du Pont, 68
description: Dr. Wallace E. Gordon, a director, former vice president and member of the executive committee of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died yesterday at his home in Greenville, Del. He was 68 years old.

title: New Day Dawns for the Bar
description: A 17th century pamphleteer, G. Thomas, was one of the first to identify the phenomenon. Writing his Historical and Geographical Account of Pennsylvania and West Jersey in 1698. he advised wouldbe colonists that New Jersey was a paradise on earth because, among its other virtues, it was free of doctors, ministers and lawyers.

title: GREATER NEW YORK AUTOMOBILE SHOW
description: The show runs now through Feb. 1. All the major American auto manufacturers and most Epropean and Japanese makers will be represented. The show features economy and compact cars as well as new intermediate luxury and sports cars.

title: Mary Tuttle To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Tuttle of Hancock, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Wright Tuttle, to David Morris Lemonick, son of Aaron Lemonick, dean of the faculty at Princeton University, and Mrs. Lemonick of Princeton, N. J.

title: At a Democratic Caucus in Mississippi, the Message Is Spelled in Black and White: All of You Come
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 24 In 1959, Hodding Cuter 3d came home from the Marine Corps to this pleasant Mississippi river town, where his father, a Pulitzer Prizewinning editor and writer, had built The Delta DemocratTimes into one of the leading Southern advocates of racial justice.

title: A Bicentennial Salute
description: TRENTON THE EXHIBIT that opened at the State Museum last week is truly aBicentennial one in the grand manner. It pays full tribute to the American heritage, and is allencompassing in its attempt to dramatize the historical, social and cultural foundations and developments of a nascent nation.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: New Devices to Help Skiers Keep Warm on Cold Slopes
description: When recreational skiing began making an impact in the United States 40 years ago, a major objection by those hesitant to try the sport was the fear of frost New Devices to Help Skiers Keep Warm on Cold Slopes bitten net ana hands. I was one of the early birds who began skiing even before the depression years, says Lowell Thomas. The fact that people in those early days had to Climb hills in order to ski down them didn't seem nearly so great a deterrent as did the cold.

title: Cheryl Toussaint At the Crossroads
description: Until a few years ago, Cheryl Toussaint, an Olympic silvermedal winner in 1972, was a carefree girl from Brooklyn who enjoyed running.

title: Knicks Topple Pistons For 6th in Row, 117100
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 The New York Knickerbockers, playing well in spurts and experiencing occasional lapses, ran their National Basketball Association winning streak to six games tonight with a 117100 victory over the undermanned Detroit Pistons before a crowd of 8,643 at Cobo Arena.

title: Four Norwegians Lead in Skating
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Four Norwegian skaters, Kay Stenshjemmet, Jan Erik Storholt, Sten Stensen and Amund Sjoebrend, took the first four positions in the overall standing after the 500 and 5,000 meters of the European speedskating championships today.

title: U.S.Soviet Arms Accord Tied to Brezhnev's Health
description: MADRID, Jan. 24United States officials, fresh from negotiations just concluded in Moscow, said today that an early SovietAmerican agreement on limiting longrange bombers and missiles might hinge on whether Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, retained his political and physical health in the months ahead.

title: His First State of the Union Address, He Felt, Did Not Suit Him
description: President Ford began preparations for this year's State of the Union message almost as soon as he finished delivering last year's. As his predecessors have done, he began early last winter to gather material and ideas from the executive branch of the Government.

title: Vice Adm. Andrew Bisset Dies; Led Construction in the Pacific
description: Vice Adm. Andrew G. Bisset, retired, who in World War II commanded 100,000 Army and Navy construction troops on islands in the Pacific, died Friday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 82 years old and lived in Madison, N. H.

title: Fiscal Policies Skewed by Inflation
description: For the world's industrialized nations, 1975 marked the first signs of success in the fight against inflation, but often at the cost of large budget deficits. And governments, still wary of inflation, continued to be cautious in their efforts to spur their economies.

title: L. H. Jacobson Fiance Of Cynthia Lipschutz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Lipschutz of Paughkeepsie, N. Y.. have announced the engagement of their daughter. Cynthia Lipschutz, to Lawrence Howard Jacobson. son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jacobson of Chicago.

title: In Sports, Few Big Scores on Pay Day
description: The rise of the millionaire professional superstar is primarily an American phenomenom. There are few Catfish Hunters in Western Europe, no Joe Namaths in the Soviet Union, no Jimmy Connorses in China and no Chris Everts in Australia, once the dominant force in tennis.

title: FREEDOMS ASKED BY POLISH GROUP
description: An appeal by prominent Polish intellectuals for constitutionally guaranteed civil liberties has been published by a Polishlanguage paper in London and was circulated here by Polish exiles last week.

title: Canada Faces Crisis
description: EDMONTON, AlbertaThe intown Edmonton Industrial Airport is the rear base and jumpingoff point for the vast mineral and petroleum developments of the Canadian North. Business is so heavy on the provincial government's airline, Pacific Western, that a glossy new terminal has been built to serve such destinations as Rainbow Lake (conventional oil), Fort McMurray (Athabasca tar sands, Induvik (Mackenzie Delta and Beaufort Sea oil and gas) and the Arctic Islands.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Green, local and maiden working hunters; open jumpers. 8:30 A.M.

title: Ecuadorean Junta Frees Former Minister From Jail
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 24 (AP) Former Gen. Ral Puma, who opposed one of the leaders of a bloodless coup against the Government Jan. 11, has been released from jail, the Government announced.

title: Robards Returns to O'Neill's Journey
description: WASHINGTON, D. C. Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night is to me the greatest American play because, among other reasons, it is the least pleasant. O'Neill saw America as the greatest failure in the world, the country where everyone tried to put a pleasant face on things while, beneath their smiles, their souls were slipping away. And in Long Day's Journey he faced the subject head on, without being lured away from it by the grandeur of myth, or the uptodateness of Expressionism, or any of the other forms of fakery that had rotted and despoiled most of his earlier work (to the point where virtually none of it seems playable today). To face the reality of America's failure, O'Neill came home, to the failure of his own family, and created the perfect Bicentennial play out of the bickerings and evasions he had heard in his home for most of his childhood and youth, and in his head for most of his life thereafter.

title: 4Alarm Fire Damages 5 Brooklyn Row Houses
description: A fouralarm fire caused heavy damage to a row of five threestory frame houses in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn last night, the Fire Department reported. About 100 firemen fought the blaze for nearly two hours before bringing it under control.

title: Latins Apply Shock Policy
description: S ANTIAGO, ChileFor most of Latin America's 300 million people last year, the economic bottom line was deepening poverty. Hunger grew with food prices and unemployment, while those still working found their living standards eroded by inflation.

title: Tighter Brownstone Loans
description: Buying a brownstone in New York City usually depends on two major factors: a desire to live in such an old row house and an opportunity to obtain financing for purchase and rehabilitation. But while many may have the desire to participate in the brownstone movement, not too many are now getting the opportunity to gain the financing necessary to carry it out.

title: For young readers: science fiction
description: All anthologies of sports stories run up against the same problem: It's hard to find any reader, even a young reader, who is passionately interested in baseball and football and golf and boxing and hunting and chess, etc. And when the sports stories are science fiction stories as well the reaaer, in addition to wading through detailed descriptions of sports that he is not interested in, is also expected to wade through detailed descriptions of sports that don't even exist yet, like Combat Football and Foci. But anyone with a taste for sports and S.F.and an open mindwill find this a surprisingly entertaining collection. The game of Foci (which resembles an amalgam of basketball, hockey and soccer played under low gravity conditions) turns out to be just the thing for countering boredom on long interstellar flights. Combat Football (which combines the worst aspects of football, professional wrestling and street fighting) turns out to be the new National Pastime. A twobit fight manager who is foolhardy enough to stand in for his broken robotboxer turns out to be a hero of sorts in a losing cause. And fishing for leviathan in the murky seas of Venus turns out to be a job for human bait.

title: The Budget Goes to Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe attempt by Congress to gain control of the Federal budget, which began with some success last year, is facing its toughest test in this year of Presidential election politics and an improving, but not robust, economy.

title: Aid for the Divorced
description: Several New Jersey organizations offering aid to women on their rights in marriage and divorce are joining together in a coaliiton that they hope will make Path of them more effective. Following publication of an article in The New York Times last Sunday, organizations throughout the state received many phone calls from women with marital difficulties who did not know that sources of help existed.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: What is it that Martha Graham did to all those people? It is quite extraordinary how many contemporary choreographers have, served an apprenticeship in the Graham company; one could literally list dozens. The influence of this woman, simply through her disciples, dissidents, followers, malcontents and other friends, is remarkable. The other week, for example, we had two major New York premieres,, Paul Taylor's Runes and John Butler's Medea, and a revival of a longlost work by Jerome Robbins, Fanfare. True, Robbins never actually worked with Graham, but he has been influenced to some extent. by people who have, such as Agnes de Mille, and, of course, Butler and Taylor were, at different times, longserving members of Graham's company. And, like Merce Cunningham, Erick Hawkins, Pearl Lang, Jean Erdman, Bertram Ross; Robert Cohan, Anna Sokolow, Glen Tetley, William Louther, Donald McKayle, Dan Wagoner, Richard.. Ruch and others, they turned to their own choreography. The sheer inspiration that Graham has been to a generation,._ indeed, even two or three generations of American dancers is really incalculable. Mind you, they do not, luckily for them, just follow her slavishly. She has always sparked off creativity rather than merely inspired imitation.

title: Notre Dame Tops U.C.L.A. by 9585
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 24 (UPI)Notre Dame checked a rally by the University of California, Los Angeles, with 10 minutes to play today, then went into a stall for the final 5% minutes to preserve a 9585 upset of the Bruins.

title: POLITICS
