description: NEW JERSEY Republicans have just issued the latest bulletin soliciting candidates for the G.O.P. nomination to run for the United States Senate against Democratic Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. Republican leaders have sized up the prospects and are notifying applicants to bring their own money, since they can expect no funds from a party that can barely pay its telephone bills. And they are telling them to expect a defeat.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 24Thorbjorn Ryen captured the Telemark skijumping tourney trophy in a jumpoff today with a standing leap of 153 feet, good for 103.4 points. The winning performance came after the Staten Island carpenter had captured Class B in the regular competition with trips of 151 and 154 feet for 204.8 points.

title: Letters: Reflections On Touring in Russia
description: The Letters Column this week is devoted entirely to correspondence addressed to the Travel Editor in response to the story. Group Travel to Russia: A Collective Triumph. in the Jan. 11 issue of the Travel Section.

title: Switzerland's Watchmakers Fall Behind Time
description: GENEVAThe Swiss watch industry is falling behind time.

title: Marsha Susan Berkowitz Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Berkowitz of Great Neck. L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Susan Berkowitz, to Wayne Stuart Kabak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kabak of White Plains.

title: Harrington Says U.S. Aid Goes to Chile Despite Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Representative Michael Harrington, a Massachusetts Democrat, said today that Chile ranks as a major Latin American recipient of economic and military aid from the United States despite limitations imposed by Congress.

title: Setback in Eastern Europe
description: BELGRADE, TougoslaviaEastern Europe, where the stability of Communist regimes is nearly as dependent on local prosperity as it is on the backing of Soviet tanks, faces an uncertain year.

title: Response Loses Its Urgency
description: FOOD. Like the weather, which affects it so much, everybody talks about it. Some people, who lack it, agonize over it and die from its absence. Starvation and malnutrition still kill millions each year. Others, who may possess it in abundance but foresee its absence on an immense scale, perhaps within a decade, theorize about it.

title: CAREY DISMISSES AIR GUARD CHIEF;
description: Maj. Gen. Raymond L. George, commander of the New York Air National Guard, has been dismissed by Governor Carey, effective Jan. 31. No replacement has been named.

title: Ambush Among the Slots
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 24It was a dreadfully twosided fight, the most twosided battle of heavyweights in recent memory. George Foreman, who used to be heavyweight champion of the world and would be again, was slugged stupid in the first round and smashed to the floor twice in the fourth. He got up.

title: P.A.F. Playhouse. Shifts to Original Works
description: HUNTINGTON STATIONFive years after it opened as a theater dedicated to bringing the classics and nearclassics to suburbia, the Performing Arts Foundation Playhouse is alive and well and trying to establish itself as one of the handful of inventive regional theaters that dot the wayoff Broadway map.

title: Ellen Boates Engaged
description: The engagement of Ellen Boates, a senior at Wellesley College, to Donald C. Clark Jr.. a senior at Williams College. has been announced by the Rev. and Mrs. T. Thomas Boates Jr. of Floral Park, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance Is the on of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Wilmette, III. Mr. Boates is an area minister for the United Church of Christ. Mr. Clark's father is a senior vice president of the Household Flstance Corporation.

title: The Search for Auto Safety
description: DETROIT  How hard a blow can the human body withstand without serious injury? The importance of the answer to autmobi'e safety has led researchers to pursue it trough not just laboratory tests but also such diverse means as the work of high divers and prize fighters.

title: Sahel, Striving to Recover, Adapts After Killing Drought
description: DAKAR,SenegalWithout any flocks, the nomad has no reason to roam. With this remark, an American relief official here recently summed up a lasting effect of the great drought that ravaged West Africa's Sahel region three years agoa sharp decline in the region's traditional nomadic life.

title: Saigon Plans Drive On Unemployment And Bureaucracy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 24 (Reuters)The new civilian administration of Saigon plans a series of legal measures to cope with bureaucracy, unemployment, hoarding and drug abuse.

title: Fords Both Given Clean Bill of Health After Examinations.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) President Ford declared, I fell fit as a fiddle toady after undergoing a threehour annual physical checkup at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Those who are learning the fine art of rooting cuttings have probably already found out that the best results come when plant cuttings are rooted in sterile media such as perlite, vermiculite, sand, or peat and sand or combinations of any of these. The rooting media hold moisture well without making stem ends soggy, the cuttings take hold fast and roots are strong.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Some Subsidized Coops Far From Pioneers Ideal
description: The housing cooperatives that the late Abraham Eli Kazan pioneered halfcentury ago differ dramatically from those Roberto Nazario envisions today.

title: Are the Times AChangin Too Much for Dylan?
description: There can be no doubt about itBob Dylan is back. His recently concluded Rolling Thunder Revue tour and his new album, Desire, have capped a twoyear career renaissance. The folkpoet of the 1960's, lapsed into relative obscurity between 1966 and 1974, has reemerged as a vital force in both contemporary pop music and, perhaps, in contemporary culture in general. More of the public at large knows about Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the imprisoned boxer, through Dylan's harshly insistent protest song than through the efforts of a small army of investigative reporters. Anybody who listens to popular music on the radio can't avoid Desire and that Instantly recognizable, husky, snarling baritone with its punching folkrock accompaniment and the eerily exotic accompaniment of a gypsy violin.

title: A Former Coach Tells of the Evils of College Recruiting
description: The president of Notre Dame, the Rev, Theodore Hesburgh, has pointed out that the money made by Notre Dame football teams pays for the entire Notre Dame athletic programevery varsity sport. And there is money left, over to pay for some academic programs. Without football, obviously, those other sports and those academic programs would be in trouble.

title: Elizabeth Vickery Tufts Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Chapman Tufts of New York hive announced thg engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Vickery Tufts, to David Warren Swanson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Swanson of Brooklyn Heights and Williamstown, Mass. The couple plan to be married in July.

title: j. Lesley Varner Plays Tuba Recital
description: J. Lesley, Varner, the sixth in the parade of fine tuba players who have been enlivening Carnegie Recital Hall evenings this season, has extensive ensemble credits. He is performer in residence with the Da Camera Brass Quintet at Ball State University in Indiana; he is a member of the Midwest Tuba Trio and the Muncie Symphony, and he: conducts the Ball State Brass Choir.

title: The image of an imagist
description: According to Jean Gould's biography, the world of Amy Lowell, governed by an illustrious family of clergymen, judges, statesmen and manufacturers, at once encouraged new ideas and demanded adherence to tradition. Often the Lowells wavered between intellectual enlightenment and established beliefs: Amy's father Augustus, for example, was a founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an official of the American Academy of Sciences who nevertheless rejected Darwin's theory and refused to allow a book by that atheist Shelley in his home.

title: Surging Bankruptcies Bring. State Into Industry
description: The law of the economic jungle isn't so clearcut as survival of the fittest. Mdre often, it's the bestprotected that survive, although often as wards of the state.

title: CHINA ANNOUNCES A NUCLEAR BLAST
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24 (AP)The Peking radio announced today that. China had carried out anfi other nuclear test in. line with) its policy of developing atomic weapons for defense and for breaking the nuclear monopoly of the superpowers.

title: Cities, Worldwide, Can Vie With New York for Urban Problems
description: ACAPULCOPerhaps New York started a fashion for the world's cities. This one, renowned for almost permanent sunshine and freedom from care, went bankrupt last summer. Between July and October public employees missed three paydays.

title: E.P.A. View: There's Still a Considerable Way to Go
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued air quality standards for six pervasive air pollutants. The air quality problems of four of these pollutants  carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, nitrogen dioxide, and photochemical oxidants  have been in large measure a result of pollution from mobile sources. Control over automotive emissions is therefore fundamental to the attainment of ambient air quality which is protective of public health. Air quality for hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide has improved over the course of the last few years.

title: Unequal Justice
description: How in God's name could so many lawyers get involved in something like this? asked John Dean about Watergate. In this remarkable book about America's elite lawyers and their quest for power and profit, Jerold S. Auerbacha Wellesley history professor and a former Fellow in Law and History Harvard Law Schoolgoes a long way toward explanning Why lawyers have played such central roles in perpetuating so many injustices, ranging from racial and religious discrimination, to McCarthyism to the denial of legal representation to the poor. This not to deny that some lawyers have also played significant roles in helping to secure justice and equality, but that is a familiar story celebrated in Law Day speeches, at bar association banquets and in the authorized histories of the bench and bar.

title: Suburban Theater Lights the Nights
description: I F New Jersey were a nation (And why not? It's bigger than some!), there is no doubt whatsoever who would be its national playwright. Neil Simon is New Jersey's Shakespeare. A recent rundown on what was playing in New Jersey showed that out of 14 listed theaters fewer than three were playing Mr. Simon.

title: Vermont University Wins Ski Carnival
description: CANTON, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP)Doug Bruce and Joe Lamb won the slalom and jumping events today to lead the University of Vermont to a team victory in the winter carnival ski competitions at St. Lawrence University. Bruce turned in a tworun time of 47.53 seconds, followed by Andy Mike!! of Williams College, Mass., with a time of 47.69, and Bill Rathbone of Vermont with 47:89.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: As part of the search for clues to the causes of cancer, the National Cancer Institute has issued a report on what is known and suspected concerning high risk factors that apparently make some persons abnormally vulnerable to various forms of the disease.

title: White Sox Sign 9, Silvestri as Coach
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP)The Chicago White Sox signed Wilbur Wood and eight other players today and also announced the completion of their coaching staff with the addition of Ken Silvestri, a former major league catcher who spent most of his career with the New York Yankees and Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Seton Hall's Trackmen Win Jersey Indoor Title
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 Orlando Greene of Seton Hall upset Craig Masback of Princeton in the 1,000yard run to lead the Pirates to the team title in the New Jersey State collegiate indoor championships tonight. Seton Hall scored 100 points to Princeton's 71, with Rutgers third at 52. The result broke a string of five straight team victories by Princeton.

title: Traffic Jam Recalls Old Days
description: Rush hour is generally an unhappy blend of long trips and short tempers. So when computercontrolled traffic signal system broke down in Queens one morning last week, it could have been hard to find a bright spot in the gloom.

title: If You Co
description: to Vald'Isere, fly to the Geneva airport, which straddles the SwissFrench border. You go out through the French side. A oneweek excursion flight from New York costs $351 for the round trip. Buses, taxis and car rentals are available at the Geneva airport. It takes about four hours by bus from Geneva to Vald'Isere and the fare is about $15 one way. You don't really need a car to get around the village. The local bus goes everywhere you'll want to go, and the bus fare is a bonus that comes with your week's skilift ticket. For further information contact the French Government Tourist Office, 610 Fifth Avenue, New York 10020 (tel: 2127571125).

title: Inflation Turns Buenos Aires Into a Bazaar
description: BUENOS AIRES  Many middle  class Argentines bought summer places last year, or un/country as they are known here, while monied Chileans favored the stock market. Uruguayans simply kept buying dollars.

title: Notes: On Celebrating America's 3Billionth
description: THE creation of the land mass that now parades under the name United States of America ??? place at most 3 ??? years ago. The United States Travel Service has the word of the Smithsonian Institution for that fact, and it has inspired U.S.T.S. to suggest that Americans take time this year to celebrate their nation's 3billionth birthday along with its 200th.

title: MILWAUKEE APPEAL ON INTEGRATION SET
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (AP)The Milwaukee School Board voted 11 to 3 today to appeal an order that it begin at once to prepare an integration plan.

title: A Fugitive Leader Of Indian Movement Captured by F.B.I.
description: EL CERRITO, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP)Dennis Banks, the fugitive leader of the American Indian Movement, was arrested today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who surrounded a college instructor's home in this San Francisco suburb.

title: Japan: the Land of the Rising Fad Football for Now
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24Tomoya Kanemura is a 13yearold Japanese lad who is nuts about the National Football League. The walls of his room are covered with N.F.L. posters and pictures of N.F.L. players. His pencils and school notebooks are marked with N.F.L. team emblems. He wears N.F.L. socks and N.F.L. shoes.

title: Portugal Facing Economic Crisis
description: LISBON Ze is a metal worker and, comes the revolution, ha is told life will change for the workers because now we're working for ourselves. But there are so manypolitical rallies, union meetings and mobilizations of workers that Ze doesn't get any work done and in the end he is purged from his job for being a raactionary.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: JAZZAt 68 years of age, Joe Turner describes himself as the last of the stride pianists of the old era. Currently established at the big black Steinway at The Cookery, and looking like a cross between Duke Ellington and Mr. Magoo, he calls stride, which is a successor to ragtime, a swingin thing. More descriptively, it is a method by which the left hand plays mostly single notes in the basea duty that was later taken up by a bassist or guitaristwhile the right hand carries the melody and improvisation. Turner, who was nurtured in the twenties by Fats Waller, Willie The Lion Smith and James P. Johnson, has spent most of his time since then in Europe.

title: A. Look at the Record on Catalytic Converters
description: DETROIT  The catalytic converter, which enabled the automobile industry to meet last year's Federal antipollution standards while providing a timely increase in fuel economy, has survived its first year on the road without major difficulties.

title: Brighter Payments Position
description: Bright prospects for the nation's international payments position have been forecast as the government has embarked on determined efforts to improve the payments position.

title: David Le Winter, 61, Leader Of Orchestra and Composer
description: David Le Winter, who had led the orchestra in the Pump Room of the Ambassador Hotel in Chicago for 18 years, died Thursday in Biscayne Medical Center in Miami. He was 61 years old, and lived in Hollywood, Fla., just north of Miami.

title: Going After People
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.  Fresh from his victory in the Iowa caucuses, Jimmy Carter sparred amiably the other day with an interviewer who wanted to know whether the former Governor of Georgia considered himself a liberal, a conservative, a moderate or what. Mr. Carter did not consider himself any of those things, and the only description he and the reporter could agree on was that he was just Jimmy Carter going after people.

title: Briggs Advances In Squash Racquets,
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 24Peter Briggs of the Field Club of Greenwich, Conn., led'the ad vaned of the top four seeded players into the semifinals of the 34th Apawarnis Club invitation squash racquets tournament today.

title: Japanese Striving to Catch Up With Westerners in Mideastern Deals
description: TOKYOJapan has been making strides in developing its prospects in the lucrative Middle East market, but Tokyo is keenly aware of its shortcomings In competing with Western nations for Arab business.

title: Ernst Rothe, Exporter, to Marry Nancy L. Eberhart Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. Waiter Mark Eberhart of New Yogk have announced the entagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Eberhart, to Ernst Rothe, son of Tyge Ernst Rothe of Greenwich, Conn., and Espergaerde, Denmark, and the late Delight Hall Rothe.

title: Convention Events Envisioned As Way to Put Spirit Into City
description: Manhattan streets and store windows would bloom with Welcome, Democrats decorations. Museums would open for special sessions. Theater matinees would be rescheduled from Wednesday, or perhaps extra matinees would be given.

title: Cilcinda Childs Dance Company Presents Three New Works
description: The process of change quiet, unceasing and slightly mysterious like natural growth, is the matter of Lucinda Childs dances. They are fascinating demonstrations of geometric order in their structure but are touched with visual poetry.I Miss Childs presented a program of new and reputtory works at Washington Square Methodist Church Friday evening.

title: Councilman Wright's Son. 3 Companions Arrested
description: Four Brooklyn persons, including 24yearold Robert Wright, son of Councilman Samuel D. Wright, were arrested Friday night in the Bushwick section on a variety of charges, including possession of a weapon, attempted robbery and possession of drugs.

title: Memory lane
Orange Juice Futures Soured by Winter's Balm
description: Every autumn, speculators in frozen orange juice concentrate flock to the New York Cotton Exchange to stock up on future contracts for winter, and pray quietly for a devastatingly cold winterin Florida.

title: In Albany, an Echo from Carey
description: As with President Ford so with Governor Carey. Like the conservative Republican in the White House, the libcral Democrat, in the statehouse last week declared this was the time of retrenchment. Mr. Carey even used the same language: Mr. Ford spoke of a new realism, Mr. Carey urged reality again.

title: Three Candidates And Their Day
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson danced the sirtaki at a GreekAmerican gathering in Newton, Mass., after addressing the crowd. In photo at right, Morris K. Udall held a news conference in Boston at which he was endorsed by Archibald Cox, exWatergate prosecutor. Next to Mr. Udall is his brother, Stewart, with hand raised. Meanwhile, in Bethesda, Md., President Ford underwent his annual medical checkup. [Details, Page 51.] With Mr. Ford is Rear Adm. Earl Brown, naval hospital's chief.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The case of Henriette Bran
description: By Georges Simenon. Translated by Ralph Manheim. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. 96 pp. New York: Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich. $5.95.

title: New Stock Issues Stir Again
description: More common stock financing is coming investment bankers say and they can point to a few signs.

title: State Offers to Help Antidrug Programs
description: The state has offered to advance money to the city to break a bureaucratic jam that has threatened to shut down some of the 156 local programs to combat drug abuse.

title: Experts Seek Ethical Guidelines for Sex Research and Therapy
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24A proliferation of selfstyled sex therapists and growing challenges to sexrelated research have prompted 32 experts from various disciplines to take the first steps here toward establishing ethical guidelines for research and therapy in human sexuality.

title: Dachshund Best in Va. Show
description: FISHERSVILLE, Va., Jan. 24A Sunday dog found Saturday to his liking and scored his fourth best in show of the month today. He is Ch. Spartan's Sloe Gin Fizz, a red miniature wirehaired, dachshund owned by Mrs. Christy GordonCreed of Camden, S. C., and handled by Jerry Rieden.

title: An Unspoiled World
description: THE Henry Hudson Drive, one of New Jersey's loveliest roads, cuts and twists for seven miles down the sharp, dark cliffs of the Palisades and carves graceful path through an unspoiled world of nature.

title: Brazil, After the Boom, Is Trimming Its Economic Sails as Foreign Debts Soar
description: RIODE JANEIROMinister of Finance Mario Henrique Simonsen ordered zero growth for Brazil's Gross National Product this year after the economy sailed into the Roaring Forties of foreign Indebtedness and imports late in 1975.

title: Pachman could have been a contender
description: Until 1969 the name of Ludek Pachman was known in the West primarily to the chess fraternity. Born in 1924, Pachman was a Czech grandmaster. a feared competitor, a chess journalist and author. In his own country he was something of a national hero. He also was active in Communist Harold C. Schonberg, music critic of The Times, is the author of Grandmasters of Chess.

title: GreggHaywood Team Split Up
description: For the first time in live years, the United States most successful longdistance racing team will not be paired for America's longest motor racethe 24 Hours of Daytona. Peter ciregg and Hurley Haywood, the overall winners in 1973 and 1975, will be in different cars with different codrivers when the grind begins next Saturday. Gregg will be leading the B.M.W. factory team and his codriver will be an Englishman, Brian Redman. Haywood will be in a Porsche Carrera with Jim Busby of Laguna Seca, Calif., as his codriver.

title: Aussie Designer Hopeful
description: Lean and tanned with a shock of graying black hair topping his tall frame, Alan Payne sat at the tiller of his beamy new boat, peering over the bow at the sea of people. You can see over the stem quite nicely, said the 54yearold Australian designer. inspecting the topsides that Columbia Yacht had placed on his hull design for the 8.7 Meter. Payne paced through the interior and roamed the deck,; checking fittings and layout, just as any other visitor to the recent National Boat Show might. Then he scrambled down for another close look at the flatbottom which narrows into a long, thin keel.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Boost for Soccer/SmokeFilled Garden
description: I was happy to see that Alex Yannis, in his Jan. 4 News of Soccer column, brought into the 1,open the intention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to maintain socce as a minor collegiate sport.

title: NoFault Effect on Lawyers Seems Slight
description: From the beginning, groups of negligence lawyers frantically and often successfully lobbied against the passage of nofault automobile insurance laws in state legislatures.

title: YUGOSLAVS BUILD WORLD NEWS UNIT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21As the main organizer of a newsgathering pool depending on contributions from the nations of the third world, Yugoslavia is seeking to undercut the influence of major Western news agencies.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Moses Isquith of Brooklyn. N.Y. and South Fallshore, N.Y. announce the engagement of their daughter, Lenore Cynthia, to Dr. Bruce Behr of Miami, Fla. Dr. Behr is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving S. Behr of Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: DoItYourself Gasoline Stations
description: A New York couple vacationing in Florida recently drove into a gasoline station on Route 1, about 80 miles north of Miami, and waited for an attendant.

title: Economic Curbs Stir Trudeau's Foes
description: OTTAWA  Controversial restraints instituted by Prima Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government to cope with a drastic turnaround in the oncebooming Canadian economy have brought calls for a new national election.

title: Writing Test for College Is Urged
description: A major new sign of the mounting concern over what seems to be crumbling achievement in the nation's schools is that the College Entrance Examination Board, which has relied on multiplechoice tests, appears likely to start testing the writing ability of students.

title: Book Sales Make. a Varied Reading
description: Book publishers and sellers around the world are reading these days  reading their 1976 lists, their 1975 income statements, and the tea leaves that spell out what's ahead for the year just begun.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Paul T. Lanyhow is running for President and won't give his right name, or so says the Federal Election Commission, which recently published a list of 62 persons who have told it they are after the big job. Lanyhow, according to the Associated Press, is the alias of a man who wants to stay anonymous lest the campaign be debased by factors of personality and charisma.

title: Road Back Strictly Uphill for Yogi Behr
description: In auto racing it's called a ride, and without one a driver is as naked as a hitter without a bat, as empty as a singer without a song.

title: A Meeting at Elsinore
description: ELSINORE, DenmarkBy the end of the twoday drama at Elsinore, it seemed appropriate, even ironic, that Europe's leading Socialists had gathered within the shadow of Hamlet's Kronborg Castle. They squabbled, they postured, they disagreed, they publicly smiled behind masks of resentment.

title: 1977 Cars: Shorter, Lighter
description: DETROIT  The American automobile industry will be going only part of the way toward meeting the demand for smaller, more economical cars in its 1977 models.

title: Oil: A LongRange Viewpoint
description: PARIS He was an oil strategist for the Hapsburg Emperor Francis Joseph in the war of the Central Powers against the France of Clemenceau, the Britain of Lloyd George and.the United States of Woodrow Wilson.

title: Results in British Football
CONDON'S OFFERS FRIDAY NOON JAZZ
description: Eddie Condon's is serving up jazz on Fridays from noon until 3 P.M. with a band that is an interesting variant of the group that plays at the club's regular nightly sessions. It includes two musicians who are daylighting from nonmusical jobsDick Rath, a trombonist who is editor of Boating magazane, and Bob Sparkman, a clarinetist who sells marine insuranceand Bobby Pratt, the regular trombonist at Jimmy Ryan's. a few doors up West 54th Street from Condon's,who is pianist in Condon's lunchtime band.

title: TV Notes: New Entries Will Premiere Later Next Season
description: Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, was jeered at by his rivals a year ago when he proposed that the three networks start the TV season a few weeks later than usual in order to give the production studios adequate lead time to prepare the fall series. Pierce was a firstterm president with a thirdplace networkthus a bit short on credentials for making industry proposals. If he's got problems, that's his tough luck. We don't have his kind of problems, a competitor said, indicating where he stood on the Pierce plan.

title: MILTON REYNOLDS, PEN MAKER, DEAD
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 (AP) The body of Milton Reynolds, retired board chairman of they Reynolds International Pen Company, who was known as the father of the ballpoint pen has been returned to Mexico for burial, the. family said today.

title: INVESTING
description: The roaring bull market of the past three weeks has reverberated noisily in the options exchanges, devastating many of those who sold naked calls, sobering most of the rest of the sellers and providing smart profits for speculators who bought these rights to call (buy) shares of stocks at predetermined prices.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Two related events: on Wednesday, Rudolf Serkin's recital in Carnegie Hall will celebrate the 40th anniversary of his debut there; and Young Audiences, Inc., will be starting the celebration of its 25th anniversary. The relation? Rudolf Serkin, himself an educator, has been greatly interested in Young Audiences through the years. Currently he is a vice president on the board of directors and also a member of the national advisory committee. His Carnegie Hall concert this week is a benefit for Young Audiences.

title: Iowa Wrestlers Win
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 24 (AP)Iowa's wrestling team extended its unbeaten string to 30 meets today with a 276 triumph over Northwestern. The victory gave the Hawkeyes a 90 wonlost record for the season. The Hawkeyes captured eight of the events.

title: Rutgers Trounces Lafayette
description: EASTON, Pa., Jan. 24Rutgers, one of the most potent college basketball teams in the nation, routed Lafayette, 11379 today before a capacity crowd of 4,200 in Kirby Field House. The triumph was the 15th in a row for the undefeated Scarlet team.

title: Its Own Procedures Prevent It From Doing Much Deliberating
description: WASHINGTONVisitors to the Capitol during the bicentennial year expecting to see the Senate at work are likely to be disappointed. The very procedures designed to make the United States Senate the world's greatest deliberative body now prevent that body from actually deliberating much at all, a situation that has led to the appointment of a group charged by the Senate with recommending changes in its operations.

title: China Emerging as an Oil. Power
description: HONG KONGWith another 20 percent increase in Its oil output last year, and with oil  exploration work going on from the icy north?rn waters of the Po Hai Gulf to the suburbs of Can, ton, China has emerged as one of the world's leading oil producers.

title: It's Not Who Will Speak, but Who Will Listen
description: Joanne Stevensivrote on this page (Who Speaks on Behalf of the Children? Jan. 4) that children are often exploited in sports, that no one speaks for them. I do not think it is a matter of who will speak, but rather who will listen.

title: Greg Cluess Is Dead at 26; St. John's Basketball Star
description: Greg Cluess, captain of the St. Johns University basketball team during the 197273 season, died Friday of cancer at the SloanKettering Institute. He was 26 years old and lived in Floral Park, Queens.

title: SYRIA: An Invitation To Tourists
description: Historians have traditionally described Syria as a Octure of world history On the banks of the Orontes Syria witnessed the birth of humanity, while the hills and dales of Yabrud and Palmyra provided the Cave Man with shelter. The first alphabet was vented in Ras Shamra on the Syrian coast, and Damascus, the capital of Syria, is the oldest continuously inhabited city in the world. Truely, Syria was born at the beginning of history and offers tourist and archeologist samples from every era of human civilization.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As one who has been in the business of selling and managing cooperatives for more than 45 years, I feel I must take real exception to the first three of your series of articles on cooperatives and condominiums which have given a distorted impression of the state of the market and of the functioning and integrity of coop boards of directors, as well as their managing agents.

title: Beth Wladis, Librarian, Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Wladis of Elmira, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Elaine Wladis, to Paul Richard Himmeistein, son of Mrs. Leonard Weinroth of New York and the late Dr. Aaron Himmelstein. A May wedding is planned.

title: Short reviews
description: Anyone who has visited the seaandforest villages of the Northwest Coast Indians, seen examples of their great outpouring of art in museums and galleries, or gazed in wonder at E. S. Curtis's sepia photographs of their totem poles and wood carvings, rituals and masked dancers has at least an inkling of the majestic native culture of that often fogenshrouded part of the continent.

title: Miss Evert Wins
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 24 (UPI)  Chris Evert outsteadied Britain's 19yearold Sue Barker, 64, 64, in a baseline battle today and advanced to the final of the $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: 4 Candidates Sit Down to Dinner With 1,000 Nevv Hampshirites
description: ??? N.H., Jan. 24Morris K. Udall has privately been telling a story about the time he asked a New Hampshire woman to give him her vote in next month's Democratic Presidential primary election.

description: Dr. and Mrs. Sol Rodbart of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Della Rodhart, to Morton A. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cohen of Lynbrook, L. I.

title: Snow: Where Has It Gone?
description: WHEN I was a youngster growing up in the New Jersey suburbs, winter brought snowand plenty of it. Enough to make an army of snowmen at any time. Enough to make a fort with two rooms.

title: Greece and Turkey Battle Austerity
description: ATHENS  In a recent speech, Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis chastised Greek farmers for demanding higher price subsidies for their crops. It is absurd, he said, to ask the state to give more than it has.

description: An auction for the benefit of the Huntington Arts Council will be held at the Harbor Arts Center on Brown's Road in Huntington today at 4:30 P.M.

title: Most Boston Schools Held Lagging on Racial Guideline
description: BOSTON, Jan, 24 (UPI)Eightyfive percent of Boston's 162 schools do not comply with a Federal court's guidelines on racial mixture and widespread changes could result next fall. The Boston Globe reported today.

title: BRIDGE
description: There are situations in which everything is suddenly topsyturvy, and an advantage turns into a disadvantage. The chess expert may find the right to move becomes a liability in rare situations called zugzwang. And a bridge defender sometimes discovers that the right use for an honor is to cover a small card, and that to cover an honor with it would be an error.

title: Margaret Cunningham Engaged to Bradley W. Smith.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Beams Smith of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter, Margaret Riker Henry Cunningham, to Bradley W. Smith of New York.

description: At least three slates of Rea ganforPresident delegates will seek to get on New York's primaryelection ballot, an aim that could scramble what Republican leaders had hoped would be a placid, uncontested election resulting in an uncommitted delegation of party professionals.

title: New Labor Secretary
description: When the TaftHartley Act was passed nearly three decades ago, one of its major reforms was to separate the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service from the Department of Labor. That line of demarcation, which never made too much sense, has been eroding ever since.

title: Winter Night
description: The winter night is as long as the summer day, but if there is snow on the ground it isn't fourteen hours or more of darkness. With a moon it can be as bright as early twilight, and even without the moon it has enough reflected starglow to create a special world quite apart from the world of daylight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States was accused yesterday by Prime Minister Pinnock Eduardo of the proWestern Angolan government of failing to establish a diplomatic or military balance in the struggle for control of the country, and of harming the proWestern coalition. He said that the United States had neither attained its goal of persuading the Soviet Union to moderate its influence in the conflict, nor had it armed antiCommunist forces to enable them to confront successfully the Sovietarmed Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola and its Cuban allies. The declarations of Ford and Kissinger even do us harm, Mr. Eduardo said. Whenever they bang their fists on the table against our enemies, the Russians take them seriously and increase military aid to the M.P.L.A. The Americans don't match this by aid to us. (Page 1, Column 8.]

description: 1 breast of veal with bones, about 4 pounds

title: Spain Fears Tortugalized Economy
description: MADRIDIs Iberian history repeating itself? Portugal's revolution in 1974 began in the midst of an economic recession that has bedevilled it ever since. Now Spain is getting off to fresh political start and, while not a revolution, it, too, is hampered by the worst economic downturn in years.

Ernest Hemingway and Adam Clayton Powell made the island of Bimini their home. Richard M. Nixon used to visit Grand Cay, owned by his millionaire friend Robert Abplanalp. Once playground for the very rich and the famous, the Bahamas in the last decade have become a popular eacation ??? for the notorich Aoid the sotatallfamous. but although the style of visitors has ??? he yearound warm weather, clear waters and sandy b aches ??? unchanged. The 700 Bahamian islands dot tht. blue Atlantic and the emeraldgreen shallows of the Great and Little Bahama Banks, forming a 750mile arc that begins 50 miles east of Palm Beach, Fla., and extends to within 50 miles of Haiti.

title: South Africa Gives Strong Indications Of Angola Pullout
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 24 (AP)South Africa gave strong indications today that it was prepared to withdraw some of its troops fighting in Angola, where Soviet  hacked forces are reported to be making broad advances.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 24 Sandra Lil, the only female pacer in the field of eight, did it the hard way tonight and won the richest winter race in Roosevelt Raceway's history.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Fordham's basketball team is at home on its Rose Hill campus in the Bronx for three 8 P.M. games this weektomorrow night against Columbia (to be televised on Channel 9), Wednesday against City College and Saturday against Boston College. In another local rivalry tomorrow, Manhattan is at St. John's Alumni gym in Jamaica, Queens, at 8 P.M.

title: New York's AlternateSide Ritual Dance: CutIns Frowned On
description: East Side, West Side and all across the town, hordes of car ownersmany of them housewivesstream out of their homes in the predawn darkness to begin the daily routine of moving the car before the 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations go into effect.

title: Floyd Braun to Wed Yvonne Drouillard
description: The engagement of Yvonne Drouillard and Floyd C. Braun has been announced by Lawrence P. King, associate clean of the Mew York University School of Law, and Mrs. King, uncle and aunt of the prospective bride. Mr. Braun is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Braun of Yonkers.

title: Trying to Like Those Saturday TV Kid Shows
description: I have never had enough righteous indignation to become more than slightly annoyed about Saturday morning children's television. Of course, when my kids were younger (they are ten and seven now), I hated the commercials (a corner of my daughter's bedroom is Barbie brothel). And I dutifully put in my time on park benches lamenting, with the other mothers, the disgraceful state of the vast wasteland's back 40.

title: Nastase Turns Back Solomon and Official
description: CATONSVILLE, Md., Jan. 24 (AP)Topseeded Ilie Nastase battled Harold Solomon, three linesmen and the chair umpire before gaining a role in the final of the $50,000 Baltimore international tennis tournament.

title: Spirits' Aide Resigns
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP)The Spirits of St. Louis announced today that their assistant coach, John Morrison, had resigned from the American Basketball Association team. Morrison said his reasons for leaving were personal and have nothing to do with the ball club.

title: Ambitious Trade Talks Persevere
description: Business Grapples With Shifting ProblemsGENEVAWorld recession notwithstanding, the 90 nations engaged in the most complex trade negotiations ever tackled hope to complete their widening and deepening of the channels of international trade by 1977.

title: All Greece Hails a 90YearOld Woman Who Saved an Island for Her Country
description: ATHENS, Jan. 24  For more than 20 years Despina Achladiotou kept the Greek flag flying over a tiny chunk of rock in the eastern Aegean Sea. Now the 90yearold woman's story has reached the Athens media and she is being hailed as a national heroine.

title: Punjabi Official Slain
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Jan. 24 (UPI)  A young worker burst into a Pakistani courtroom yesterday and shot to death a member of Punjab's provincial assembly, the police said. No motive was given.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Duck Hunting in Winter Cold
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., Jan. 24When you plan to hunt scaup during the bonus season for them on Long Island, the weather becomes an adversary.

title: Princeton Defeats Redmen
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24 Princeton indicated that it. is not only the best team in a rather weak Ivy League this season but also one of the best in the East as the Tigers upset St. John's, 5855, today in overtime at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Design
description: Moving gave Dr. and Mrs. Mato Marinovich not only an extra bedroom but also a chance to change their decorating scheme from strictly traditional to a blend of traditional and modern. Although the doctor and his wife threw out some of their old furniture and bought a few new pieces, they worked mostly with what they already had. The contemporary feeling in their fourbedroom apartment comes, for the most part, from changes to walls and doors and windows. Working with architect John Bedenkapp, the couple stripped off moldings and baseboards; changed doublehung, multipaned windows in the living and dining rooms to single sheets of glass in pivoting frames; and installed two sets of floortoceiling double doors in the living room. They also merged the old pantry and kitchen and put in new cabinets and appliances. Once these changes were made, the couple began arranging the furniture. In many cases. pieces that had lived in one place in the old apartment found different resting places in the new. For instance, the dining table was cut down and lacquered oxblood and is now a console table in the foyer. A Spanish tooled leather screen from the foyer became the headboard in the master bedroom. Dining chairs and a sofa for the living room were new purchases. As for color, the couple decided on melon orange for the walls in their living and dining rooms. It was close enough to the yellow of their old living room to keep them from having to reupholster their furniture.

title: SOCIALISTS PLAN MORE AID IN SPAIN
description: COPENHAGEN,Denmark,Jan. 23Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen of Denmark said this week that Socialist parties and trade unions in Europe had decided to step up support for the dissident Socialist Party in Snain.

title: Smith and Islanders Conquer Kings, 50
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 24 Contributions from recent benchwarmers and lessheralded players propelled the New York Islanders to a 50 National Hockey League victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight before a sellout crowd of 14,865 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Theodore Faunce, ExTeacher, Planning to Marry Anna Lorca
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Valentine Lorca of Paris of the engagement of her granddaughter, Anna Lorca, to Theodore Swift Faunce, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Faunce 3d of Rye, N. Y.

title: Gun at Airport Leads to Arrest Of Suspect in $530,000 Holdup
description: A Florida man who was picked up at La Guardia Airport last Thursday night on a routine security inspection was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday on charges of robbing a rabbi and his two daughters of $530,000 in cash last October on a Brooklyn street.

title: PLAN ON LAYOFFS MODIFIED BY H.R.A.
description: The city's Human Resources Administration has modified a complicated layoff plan that would have removed a fifth of its childprotection force, and instead will leave the force with about the same number of caseworkers that it had before.

title: Barbara J. Sonn Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Sonn of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean Sonn, to Joseph Thanhauser 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thanhauser Jr. of Philadelphia and Harvey Cedars, N. J.

title: 250 at Rally Seeking to Save Morningside Heights Library
description: More than 250 people crammed into the small Harkness Theater at Columbia University yesterday for a rally to save the Morningside Heights Community Library at 535 West 114th Street.

title: Missouri Hires Lawrence
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Jan. 24 (Ap)Don Lawrence, former Notre Dame and Washington Redskin tackle who once was head coach at Virginia, has been hired as an assistant football coach at Missouri. For the last two years, Lawrence had been defensive coordinator at Texas Christian.

title: Chapot Triple Winner
description: POTTERSVILLE, N.J., Jan. 24  Frank Chapot rode the winners of all three working hunter divisions today at the Tewksbury Horse Show. The fivetime Olympian was up on Mrs: E. Miles Valentine's Gutsy and Please James, victors in the limitopen and novice sections, respectively, and Unicorn Ventures's Nachez, winner of the Maiden Division.

title: St. Lucia: Empty Beaches, Lush Junglesand a Bubbling Volcano
description: IAWOKE to the sickening screech of brakes. The taxi had been meandcring along the serpentine Caribbean coast road from St. Lucia's capital of Castries to the Soufriere volcano. We wound through thick groves of mango, breadfruit, coconut and banana, past, stands of frail immortelle trees with their shimmering orange blossoms. The late afternoon sun filtered through the leaves and vines and the air was heavy with the scent of fruits and flowers. I dozed.

title: Outlook for Affluence
description: Divided Korea is an unfortunate and unintended legacy of the Second World War and subsequent developments in the Cold War. The initial division was externally imposed, against the wishes of the Korean people. According to a prearranged agreement, the country which had been under Japanese colonial rule for thirtyfive years, was divided along the 38th parallel, with the Soviet Union taking military control in the north and the United States in the south.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe Iceman Cometh. Thursday, 7:30 P.M.; Friday and Saturday, 8:30 P.M. Opens Thursday (through March 6). S3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, 62.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Carlie Butcher, Neal S. Garonzik Marry in Wilton
description: Sarah Carlisle Butcher, daughter of Willard Carlisle Butcher, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank. and Mrs. Butcher of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Neal Stuart Garonzik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Henry Garonzik of Gloversville, N. Y.

title: DINING OUT
description: OLDTIMERS will remember Chateau Roberto Dot's Kitchen and a couple of other things, all them vaguely rustic or roadhouse style. The present owners have transformed the old place into something resembling the set for a road company of II Trovatore. Everywhere are crenelated walls, fashioned from plastic stone and iron grillwork; all that is lacking is moat with plastic monsters.

title: Better Power Plant Remains Elusive Goal for Engineers
description: DETROITIn the 100 years since it was patented, the internal combustion gasoline engine has overcome various automotive challenges: steam and electricity in the early years; the gas turbine, the rotary piston and, again, electricity in recent times.

title: Tuition Raised in Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 24 (AP)Tuition for outofstate students at two of the five Vermont state colleges was increased by Vermont State Colleges trustees yesterday. Tuition for outofstate students at Castleton College will rise from $1,950 to $2,100; at Vermont Technical College in Randolph Center it will go up from $1,750 to $1,050.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: INDIA LACKS SPACE FOR FOOD STORAGE
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23India is facing a special kind of food problem this year, the problem of storage.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS OF EMILY DICKINSON, edited by Thomas H. Johnson. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) Every one of the 1,775 poems written by the quiet lady of Amherst; although the author's punctuational peculiarities are preserved, this is an excellent reading text.

title: California Suspect Indicted in Killings Of 11 By Slashing
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI) Vaughn Greenwood was indicted yesterday for 11 murders, mostly of Skid Row derelicts.

title: New & Novel
description: A young man named Tom Pinto is privileged to attend his own funeral. Hovering close to the casket, his spirit gets an earful of family squabbling. Once again, the departed is reminded of the differences between his weak father and his tough mother and between his wife and himself. And of the hostility of his patriarchal grandfather toward his son and daughter  in  law, the ethnic conflicts within the family, the ambivalent status of his Aunt Agnes and his whole rotten, wasted life. All of this lugubrious raking over of the blithering coals may have some value for Tom, although he isn't quite sure. But for the reader, it is a dead loss.

title: Solutions to last week's puzzles
description: (JUDITH S.) NEAMAN: SUGGESTION OF THE DEVIL  Perhaps the  truest clich about the Middle Ages is that it was a period obsessed with order. Despite the  variations and innovations in medieval schemes of the universe, a prevailing sense of system and pattern is always discernible.

title: W.T.A. Policy Said to Foster Further Service Cuts
description: Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, head of the Council's Mass Transit Committee, accused the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday of fostering a reducedservice policy that kept riders from using buses and subways.

title: No Boom for the Many Mansions of Somerset
description: For almost 10 years, the ???prawling Field Farm estate ???ere has been caught be en opposing forces, one ??? would preserve the man???n and its 375acre proper??? as a distinguished res???ence and one that would ???bandon it as an uneconomi??? relic.

title: TV VIEW
description: In the sense that all traces of a discernible personality seem to have been successfully obliterated, Steve Austin mays be prime. time television's first truly pornographic figure. He is, of course, ABC's Six Million Dollar Man and, as monotonously activated by Lee Majors, is the supreme electronic lummox. Devoting precisely the same degree of blankfaced attention to all activitieseating, flirting, killing for the OSI, his governmentagency employerSteve could be the ideal symbol for the 1970's. In any case, the series is one of very few on ABC to make the Top 20 popularity chart. And it is, reported that the program attracts TV's highest percentage of children viewers.

title: Terrorists Alarm Latins
description: BOGOTA, Colombia Terrorism has long been a tool of those seeking power in South America. But 1975 saw a frightening increase in a different form of terrorthe kidnapping of The Talk men, women and of children by cornSouth mon thugs. Quite America often the ransom demanded by the kidnappers was less than $100. Not all business people in Colombia can afford to send their children to school in Miami and hire hodyguards to protect themselves, one textile salesman noted last month. He added:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: FINN SAILOR (Finn), Helsinki Feb. 10; salts from port Newark, N.J.

title: The Nation
description: The political year has been inaugurated by the first expression of voter sentiment, and the very tentative results in Iowa appear to affirm one of the current beliefs about the Democratic race for the nomination: Jimmy Carter alone has so far separated himself from the group whose campaigns were considered hopeless.

title: U.S. Seeks the Return of Accused Bomber
description: MIAMI, Jan. 24The United States will use all possible legal and diplomatic means to obtain the return of a Cuban American, now believed to be in Venezuela, who. has been charged with six bombings here last year, according to Robert W. Rust. United States Attorney In Miami.

title: Carey and Nadjari Clash On Bronx Inquiry Order
description: Governor Carey and Maurice H. Nadjari clashed yesterday over the special state prosecutor's request for an executive order that would allow him to expand his investigation into political corruption in the Bronx.

title: Questions in Short Hills
description: It is said that problems stay away from Short Hills because they cannot afford the rent.

title: PACIFIC REGIONS WORRY PENTAGON
description: Pentagon planners are concerned over the. ability of the United States to project military force into the Western Pacific and Indian Oceans in the postVietnam era, according to a study circulated in the Defense Department.

title: Rhode Island Overtime Ban Of Gov. Noel Invalidated
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Jan. 24 (AP) A Superior Court judge has struck down Gov. Philip W. Noel's ban on overtime for state employees, calling it an unfair labor practice. Judge Thomas H, Needham upheld an arbitrator's ruling against Governor Noel's ban and ordered the state togive overtime opportunities to state prison guards who have been genied them.

title: Far From the Madding Recession
description: FAR from the madding recession, the discerning Paris queued before Fauchon for their holiday season foie gras at $28.64 to $43 a pound and truffles at a trifling $66.49 a pound.

title: Mideast Oil Riches Flow Unevenly
description: TEHERANPeople in Teheran are growing accustomed to that modern wonder the revolving door. In the United Arab Emirates, fishermen have been using fine new nets made of metal wire. But in Northern Syria, the peasants are still building their traditional beehiveshaped huts.

title: Banks Also a Casualty in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThrough the raging ninemonth civil war here, Lebanese had hopes but few expectationsthat Arab oil money would help rebuild their economy, once the business and financial center of the Mideast and now a shambles.

title: Connors, Tanner in Final
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 24 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors and secondseeded Roscoe Tanner reached the final tonight in the Birmingham international indoor tennis tournament.

title: Rights and Remedies
description: A Supreme Court majority, in an opinion written by Justice Rehnquist, may have wiped out citizens remedies for a whole range of abuses of their constitutional rights.

title: Mary Wiesen To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Guy Wiesen of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Wiesen, to Timothy G. Kalliches. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Kalliches of Englewood Cliffs, N. J.

title: Consumer Leaders Join Council Named To Advise P.S.C.
description: Fourteen leaders in the consumer movement in the state, some of them activists also on behalf of environmental protection, have agreed to serve on the Public Service Commission's new citizenadvisory council, Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.

title: D. A. R. Aids Families in Tracing Genealogy
description: OLD FIELDA while ago, Mrs. George Thomas came across a Bible that had been in her husband's family for generations. Armed with that Bible and envelopes filled with other documents accumulated by the famly, Mrs.

title: American Stars in Ghana
description: ACCRA, GhanaAs United States Ambassador to Ghana, Mrs. Shirley Temple Black, the former child film star, is enthusiastically playing a new and serious rolethat of promoting greater American business interest in Africa.

title: Students Upheld in Protest
description: PROVIDENCE, Jan. 24 (AP) A threejudge Federal panel has ruled that Charles Coor and Donily Ranns, student protesters at the University of Rhode Island, had been unfairly denied financial aid as a result of an antiwar demonstration. The judges ordered the aid reinstated this week and criticized university officials for failing to provide fundamental fairness in dealing with the students.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Gucci Shops Inc., has purchased the 16story office building at 685 Fifth Avenue and 54th Street from Stanley E. Stern. The purchase price was $4 million.

title: Electronic Alarm
description: Although there are a number of different burglar and intruder alarms available which the do  it  yourselfer can buy, the new Circle of Safety alarm system is probably the easiest to install in any home or apartment. It requires no wiring at all, and only the ability to press selfadhesive sensors in place on the windows and doors being protected.

title: 800 in Bolivia Dismissed For Not Returning To Work
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 24 (Reuters)More than 800 Bolivian workers have been dismissed for not obeying a Government order to return to work, it was officially announced here.

title: The Crosby
description: It's remembered as Palmer on the rocks, which sounds as if it should be a drink. But instead, Arnold Palmer was in the drink. On the 218yard 17th hole at Pebble Beach during the 1964 Bing Crosby National ProAm, his tee shot had sailed over the green and bounced down into shallow water among the rocks. As he stood there on the edge of Carmel Bay that opens into the Pacific Ocean, he was accompanied by a stray dog and by Jimmy Demaret, the threetime Masters champion who was employed as a TV commentator. Demaret was explaining that Palmer was entitled to lift his ball and drop it no nearer the hole as long as he maintained the line behind the position of the ball.

title: PALESTINE ARMY PATROLS BEIRUT TO UPHOLD TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24Patrols of thi Palestine Liberation Army kept order in western Beirut today as a Syriannegotiated ceasefire continued to hold for the most part in this capital and other sections of Lebanon.

title: Cutting Back Is All the Vogue; The Issues Are How and Where
description: WASHINGTONThe politician's familiar face, creased by lines suggesting firm resolve, stared out from the television set. He pledged a tough spending ceiling. He talked of balancing the budget soon. He urged abandonment of wasteful, ineffective programs. He admonished against the delusion that problems could be solved by simply throwing Federal dollars at them.

title: Israel Seeks Niche in Special Exports
description: TEL AVIVAt a recent metals trade fair here, overseas buyers, salesmen and potential investors streamed to a section where the latest Israeli inventions and innovations were displayed.
