title: Queens Class Carnival Nets $115 for Neediest
description: Sixthgrade pupils in Queens held a carnival; girl campers at Camp Dunmore in Salisbury, Vt., had a campout here, and members of the Honor Society at Herricks Junior High School in New Hyde Park, L.I., gave more than half of its organization's treasury.

title: BALTIMORE
description: The Official American League Baseball Schedule for the 1976 Season

title: Quintet by Taxin In Local Premiere
description: I was interested in creating a mostly dramatic and aggressive piece that captured the essence of brass quintet playing. Thus Ira Taxin describes his quintet, written in 1973 for the Empire Brass Quintet, and, unwittingly, the general tone of the ensemble's Carnegie Recital Hall debut last Sunday afternoon at which the score received its local premiere. Virtually all the music was tense and anguished: the performances were etched with flaring colors.

title: It Is Possible More Than a Million Did Not Even Register
description: WASHINGTON  The war was unpopular with many Americans and seemed interminable to most. As it dragged on, year after year, thousands of young men resisted military service; many fled to Canada and even Europe. Opponents of the war were vilified and some imprisorred.

title: Theater
Music Notes: Inspiration From The Colonies
description: A Decent Entertainment is what Pulitzer Prize winning composer John La Montaine calls his Bicentennial opera Be Glad Then America, which is to be given its premiere on Feb. 6 at Pennsylvania State University at University Park. He is not being prim, he is sunply being consistent: the desmiptive phrase is an 18thcentury designation, and every word of Be Glad Then America has been drawn from authentic 18thcentury documentsjournals, letters, broadsides and the like. Mr. La Montaine spent two years reading every article, every ad, every announcement of a slave sale in newspapers covering the period 17641776. He also digested 12 volumes of letters and speeches of King George III a feat which leaves him, in his own estimation, an idiot historian. I'm also a thief, stealing whatever suits me from all this material. Nothing, though, is taken from history books.

title: Miss Gonzalez, Mezzo, Sings
description: New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on  Thursday night in the Concert Artists of Mexico series presented by the Carnegie Hall Corporation through an arrangement with the cultural counselor of Mexico in New York.

title: Scientists Are Updating Cherished Ideas
description: At the age of 5, Walter Bowers was paralyzed on the right side, wracked by frequent grand mal seizures, showed severely disturbed speech and was found on testing have a mental age of 4. After medication failed to stop the seizures, Walter's doctors reluctantly carried out a drastic operation: the removal of the whole left hemisphere of Walter's brain. Today, 21 years later, Walter Bowers is an industrial executive and parttime student carrying simultaneous majors in sociology and business administration. On neuropsychological testing he demonstrates above normal language and intelligence.

title: Common Market at Halfway House
description: PARIS Britain is insular, maritime, bound by her trade, her markets, her supplies to countries that arc very diverse and often far away, said the bulbous, bellied man in a blue suit one historic afternoon 13 years ago.

title: Meg Rice Is Fiancee Of James Campbell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rice of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Jean Rice, to James Glen Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Campbell of Buffalo and Rosehill, Ontario.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: Today  CharlottesvilleAlbemarle K.C. allbreed and obedience. U. of Virginia, Charlottesville: 1,394 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Small Businesses Survive in Algeria
description: ALGIERS  To survive in Socialist Algeria, private business must stay small and as inconspicuous as possible.

title: Bettors Get Reward
description: When Nassau Downs Offtrack Betting observes its first anniversary on Saturday, it will offer a novel promotion as a way of saying thanks to its customers.

title: It's Confidence That Counts
description: NOT surprisingly, there were varied views from various points of the political spectrum last week after President Ford gave his assessment on the State of the Union and offered his budget blueprint for the coming fiscal year.

title: How to Find 4 Peaks, 89 Trails, 105 Lifts. Pick Vald'Isere.
description: IT takes a while to grasp Vald'Isere, the highest and most massive French ski resort, which sits near the Italian border, 125 miles from Geneva. Maybe it is the sheer scope of the place: four separate and distinct lift areas whereon, locals insist, one can ski for two weeks and never ski the same run twice. Or the size and contrasts of the jumbled village itself: a sprawl of hotels and enticing restaurants to sample and an elaborate health center (the churning hot water is laced with seaweed) to work off the weight.

title: Regional Government Has Been Suggested for New York
description: With New York City newly chastened by economic realities, some lessons might be learned from, other cities experiments with regional government, These experiments represent possible solutions to an endemic central city problem that is particularly acute in New York: the cost of city services keeps rising while the tax base keeps shrinking. Regional governments spread the cost of urban services across a greater metropolitan area or broaden a city's tax base to include more affluent suburban areas.

title: Suffolk Jockey Takes 6 Races
description: BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Gonzalo Prosper, the hottest jockey at Suffolk Downs winter meeting, booted home six winners today, including Nurse's Cap in the featured $5,200 allowance race before a crowd of 6,789.

title: Traffic cop in Slaughter Alley
description: In his second season as a referee in the National Basketball Association, Darell Garretson found himself paired with Eddie Rush, just beginning his third year. Two officials with so little working time in the N.B.A. seldom officiate together. Usually a veteran referee teams with an inexperienced referee.

title: Cold Snap Evokes Era Of Icy Bridge on Hudson
description: The presence of floe ice in the port last week has raised again the old question of when the last time was when people were able to cross the Hudson here on foot. It was just about 101 years ago, or to be more specific, in early February of 1875. An editorial in The New York Times of Feb. 16 that year, entitled A Severe Winter, noted that persorrs have crossed to Hoboken from New York and recrossed the same day.

title: Skyline K.C. Chief Award's
description: TERRIER (Mrs. Lydia Hutchinson, Judge)I, Mrs. Elizabeth Holsington's Airedale, Ch. Eden's Sal Sorbus; 2, Carl and Barbara Pew's colored bull terrier, Ch. Monkery Sea Boots; 3, Constance Jones's wire tox terrier, Ch. Briartex Tavern; 4, Gene Simmonds's smooth fox terrier, Newmaidiey Jacko.

title: The Palisades: Beauty and the Beast
description: SIX stories was a highrise on our side of the river when I was growing up in New Jersey. They belong in New York, I remember thinking, and in fact I don't think I ever rode an elevator until I went visiting in the big city.

title: Auto Worker Survives and Plans New Career
description: DETROITIt's no longer $5 a day which lured workers to Henry Ford's assembly lines, but $5.20 an hour at the Chrysler Corporation's auto plant in Hamtramck, ???

title: Nuptials in Spring For Dianne Bailey
description: Diannb Elizabeth Bailey and Dr. Gilbert Steven Jody, a surgical resident at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, plan to be married in the spring.

title: Trading With the Enemy
description: In the arcane discipline of China watching, making much of a nuance is the way of things. But if there is much to be made of the latest trade figures emanating from the world's most populous country, it seems to be escaping the experts.

title: Senate and House Inquiries Are Not the Usual Investigative Procedures
description: WASHINGTONThe name A. Seed Field has not become a household word. Nor have the names William B. Miller, Mitchell Rogovin, James Wilderotter, Michael Duval, F. A. 0. Schwartz 3d, and Aaron Donner. Yet these men, and a dozen or so others even less well known, have had more to do with the conduct of the Congressional investigations of United States intelligence agencies than the Senators, Congressmen, agency chiefs and President they resnectively serve.

title: No Confirmation, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  A senior State Department official in the Bureau of African Affairs said today that the United States Government had no confirmation that South Africa was withdrawing its forces from Angola.

title: Nigeria Reviews Its Plans
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThe new military Government is reviewing Nigeria's ambitious $48.9billion fiveyear development program with the evident aim of drastically trimming such extravagances as a dozen luxury residences that had been planned for state governors.

title: Senegal Project Marks Iran's First Big Move Into Africa
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Most visits by heads of state produce little more than banquet toasts. But the recent official visit by President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal to Iran has brought an agreement under which the oilrich Mideastern country will join with this literally peanutpoor West African country in $500 million of petroleumrefining and phosphatemining developments.

title: Choir Specializes In Unusual Music
description: HUNTINGTON  The warmly polyphonic sounds of a Renaissance mass filled the United Methodist Church here last Sunday as members of the Cantare da Camera, a new chamber choir dedicated to music which is unique and seldom performed, according to one chorister, prepared for their premiere performance this evening.

title: Answers/ Questions
description: A:S.L:, a Worcester, Mass, reader wondered why her twoyearold bougainvillea has only al flowered once. It grows rapidly in a south bay. In its natural climatee, bougainvillea blooms in summer, but in the greenhouse or plaint room, the display appears in late fall or early spring. As with poinsettias, the brightly colored bracts, not the true flowers, provide the colorfid bougainvillea show. The plant should be pruned back hard after flowering. A short dry rest period is sometimes recommended. Start growth again by watering and feeding every two to three weeks. Some greenhouse gardeners manage their bougainvillea successfuly by starting fresh cuttings annually rather than maintain the large older. jaulants. Ed.

title: Postal Problems Mounting
description: Once upon a time, when it came to mail, the postage stamp was the only thing that took a licking.

title: D. M. Sullivan Fiance. Of Margaret Murray
description: Henry L. Murray of New York and East Hampton, L. I., and Mrs. Alexander B. Slater of New York. and Quogue, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Louise Murray, to David M. Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs Frank Sullivan of Lancaster Pa.

title: Wallace Does Well In Mississippi Test; Carter and 3 Trail
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 24Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama built a solid lead over former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia today in Mississippi's Democratic precinct caucuses, the first contest between the two Southern Presidential candidates.

title: South Korea Faces Slackening Growth
description: SEOUL, Smith KoreaAfter a decade of remarkable progress, the South Korean economy has run into troubles that make questionable its continued expansion at the same pace.

title: Brazil's Economic Miracle Appears of Little Benefit to Workers
description: GUAIANAZES, Brazil, Jan. 19During the last seven years there has been a spectacular economic surge in Brazil that has outpaced growth in virtually every other developing nation other than the oilproducing. countries.

title: Nuclear Spread
description: I'm glad I'm not a young man and I'm sorry for my grandchildren, the first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said last week in commenting on the rapid and terrifying spread of nuclear explosives around the globe. To avoid impending disaster, David Lilienthal called for an immediate, unilateral American embargo on exports of nuclear reactors, technology and fissionable materials until effective international controls are achieved to impede proliferation of atomic weapons.

title: Cunningham Makes Plea for Suspending of Judgment on Charges
description: Politics has been good to Patrick J. Cunningham. It has brought him power, prestige and affluence.

title: The Perils and Delights of Walking a Dog
description: HAVING a dog is not all bad. There are serendipitous benefits. It was because we moved to Leonia and acquired Bingo that I came to know and be a part of the Feminist Movement.

title: DEEPSEA TROUGH TO BE EXPLORED
description: GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West Indies, Jan. 24Tomorrow three research vessels sail from here on a venture that, in a series of dives, will carry a half dozen scientists into a colossal canyon that humans have never seen.

title: Recycling, Peking Style
description: Heaps of household and industrial waste accumulate daily in Peking proper, and garbage alone reaches 2,700 tons a day. But these materials are really not waste. Garbage is carted or trucked to the fertilizer pits of the people's communes in the suburbs and processed into organic fertilizer. This is a great support to these areas. Other items of household waste such as rags, wornout shoes and paper are recycled by the state purchasing department for multipurpose use.

title: Moreland Unit Proposal Called A Windfall for Nursing Homes
description: A committee of the State Public Health Council estimated yesterday that a Medicaid revision proposed by the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes would at least quintuple payments to owners for the use of their land.

title: Soviet Buying Technology Despite U.S. Trade Curb
description: MOSCOWThe collapse of the SovietAmerican trade agreement a year ago, over the issue of emigration, does not appear to have hampered the Soviet Union's ability to buy modern technology from American and other Western companies.

title: Sri Lanka Nationalizes Estates to Aid the Poor
description: COLOMBO, Sri LankaIn a little village near Kandy. 72 miles from Sri Lanka's capital, 89 peasant families live huddled together on a quarter acre of land. They are the dispossessed.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: The Bicentennial has riveted attention on local history projects. Photography is playing an important role in telling us where we have been, who we are and where this nation is going.

title: No Greeting Cards in Japanese Bookstores
description: Kamome no Jonasan (Jonathan Livingston Seagull) has given place to Jaws and Agatha Christie's Curtain on the national best seller lists, but well behind Ryotaro Shiba's latest samuraiera historical novel (in three volumes) and pessimistic local best sellers like Multiple Pollution (Fukugo Osen), the woman novelist Sawako Ariyoshi's alarming documentary of Japan's environment problems. Sakyo Komatsu's Sinking of Japan (Nihon Chimbotsu) is also still currenta description in almost accurate seismological terms of how the Japanese islands could sink in a series of volcanic explosions. Other historical epics about 12th or 16thcentury warriors gallop ahead of the everpopular zenshu (collected works) of various modern authors (Tanizaki, Mishima and Kawabata among them), endless series of world classics, Japanese literary masterpieces, business success stories and howtobehave etiquette books about funerals, weddings and the proper use of knives and forks when traveling abroad.

title: Beat the Mob, Don't Breathe
description: EVERY morning when I wake up, my first thought is: have I done anything to upset the mob today?

title: Briggs Advances In Squash Racquets,
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 24Peter Briggs of the Field Club of Greenwich, Conn., led'the ad vaned of the top four seeded players into the semifinals of the 34th Apawarnis Club invitation squash racquets tournament today.

title: Sliffolk's First and Only Ombudsman Makes rouble Her Business
description: ISLIPGloria N. Davids has no qualms about it. I'm not an ombudswoman or an ombudsperson, she says emphatically. I'm the ombudsman for the Town of Islip and I've got much more important things to do than worry about titles.

title: Australians Struggle to Preserve Cattle
description: SYDNEY, Australia Across the vast scrub land of the state of Queensland millions of beef cattle that were worth a fortune two years ago are running wild. Left untended, many will sicken and die.

title: Plan for an Adviser to the President Likely to Pass Congress in Six Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A law establishing a White House office of science, engineering and technology policy, an urgent goal of American scientists since 1973, appears likely *0 be a reality within about sa weeks.

title: Janet L. Guerci Married in Rumson
description: Janet Lynn Guard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Guerci of Rumson, N. J., and Gregory Michael Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Henderson 2d, also of Rumson, were married there yesterday in St. George'sbytheRiver Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. George J. Willis Jr., and the Rev. William Kokoszka, pastor of the Holy Cross Catholic Church, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: Labor's Voice Heard in West Germany
description: BONN  West Germany's 25yearold codetermination laws, giving labor a voice in corporate decision making, are expected to be broadened later this year to give workers nearly half the seats on the toplevel board of any company with more than 2,000 employees. The key word is nearly.

title: Rip van Winkle irs. Describe What They See in 1985
description: At the end of 1975 the population of the world was about 4 billion. At the end of 1985 the likelihood is that it will be about 20 percent larger, or 4.8 billion. Depending upon what happens to. birth and death rates in the interimand absent a great (nuclear) catastropheit can hardly be less than 4.7 billion or more than 4.9 billion.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters published here pose questions similar to those sent in by other readers whose actual letters may not appear here, but who will, nevertheless, find their answers printed below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: Millrose Entries
description: 60Yard DashHouston Meter, Henry Crawford, Steve Riddick, Ivory Crockett, Reggie Jones, Dr. Delano Meriwethern Cliff Outlin, JeanClaude Amoureux.

title: Bangladesh Fishermen Lost
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 24 (Reuters)About 800 fishermen were feared drowned and 100 fishing boats were missing after tidal wave from the Bay of Bengal struck the Bangladub coast on Monday night, press report said today. The fishermen were swept away by waves in the Barisal district south of Dacca, a Government official was quoted as saying.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Julie Christie looks so old in this picture, one suburban matron said to another at the exhibition of celebrity portraits by Pepe Diniz at the French Institute/Alliance Francaise. She needs to comb her hair, said the second matron. What the ladies said was true: Christie looks awful, at least by suburban standards. But so do nearly all the other celebrated actors, directors, photographers and writers whose portraits are included in this show. From Diniz's dark, dramatic prints, they gaze out at ordinary mortals as if from another worlda world where they have gained a more profound understanding of the human condition than you or I have, but only at the cost of terrible suffering. Christie looks like a survivor of a concentration camp, or at least of an embattled underground. So do Brassai, Alain Delon, Ken Russell, Lotte Lenya, Ursula Andress and Milton Glaser. It was hard to realize that they are, as a group, among the most talented, accomplished and privileged people in the world.

Herewith, then, from my private stock is a selection of moments which Woody Allen, Mel Brooks and Gene Wilder have yet to equal:

title: The arbiters of taste in England
description: There are critics who have a positive genius for choosing their subjects, and Martin Green is one of them. This was immediately evident in his first book, A Mirror for AngloSaxons, which appeared in 1960, and it has been abundantly confirmed in the books he has written sinceamong them, Science aria the Snappy Curate of Poetry (1965), The Problem of Boston (1966), and, most recently, The von Richthofen Sisters (1974). Now, in Children of the Sun, his narrative of the dandyesthete sensibility that held so much of English life and letters in thrall for some four decades in this century, shaping not only its characteristic literary styles but crucial constituents of its sexual ethos, its political destiny and the very idea of what England is or should be, he has produced another workin some respects, his most importantthat illuminates a large area of modern cultural history.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 26, 1976

title: Hedda on Film Is All Glenda Jackson
description: When we first see Glenda Jackson's Hedda Gabler in the opening credit sequence of the new film, "Hedda," she is standing on the deck of a Norwegian coastal steamer, her body straight and lean, her jaw firm and her eyes betraying no interest whatever. Hedda tolerates scenery. Fjords, mountains, autumn foliage are landscapes to be passed through as quickly as possible. That's all.Standing on the deck, she is the steamer's figurehead. She could slice through a polar icecap without receiving a scratch. It's a striking image, and one that sets the style for the bright, clean-edge performance that follows."Hedda," which opened at the Fine Arts Theater yesterday, is Trevor Nunn's screen adaptation of the Royal Shakespeare Company stage production that he directed and toured in this country and Australia last year. It is very much a film, though, with a few exceptions at the beginning, it sticks to the single interior set of the Ibsen play.Not having seen the stage production, in which Miss Jackson's interpretation caused a certain amount of controversy, I have no idea to what extent that interpretation has been modified, if at all. Her screen performance could hardly be called controversial, though it is certainly lively andif you're like methank heaven for that. The pleasures of "Hedda Gabler" are not inexhaustible, especially when Hedda is played with the more conventional gestures of despair.Miss Jackson's Hedda comes on with low-key fury, her manner so abrasive and openly sarcastic that it's difficult to see why men have tried to conquer her, unless it was simply the game and not the prize that was fascinating. She is intelligent. She's well-born. She's also lethal, which is so apparent from the start of Miss Jackson's performance that the interest is not in why she wrecks the lives around her, but how. This version of "Hedda Gabler" is all Miss Jackson's Hedda and, I must say, great fun to watch, though I don't think that I was moved for a minute.Miss Jackson's technical virtuosity is particularly suited to a character like Hedda. Her command of her voice and her body, as well as the Jackson mannerisms, have the effect of separating the actress from the character in a very curious way. It's as if one were reviewing the other with rueful self-awareness. It's the drama critic in Hedda who describes as "a grotesque farce" her marriage to a dull pedant who doesn't come up to her ankles. Hedda is a terrific roleand Hedda knows it. She is willful, insatiable, articulate, but no more demanding of others than she is of herself.One of the problems with the film is that none of the actors seem to have the resources needed to balance Miss Jackson's performance. Some of this is in Ibsen's play, of course. It's no contest from the beginning, when Hedda and her husband return from their honeymoon and she sets about goading her former lover into "a positive act" (suicide) and sparring with her husband's best friend, who could possibly become a lover.Most effective is Timothy West, as the possible lover who is almost as ruthless as Hedda is. But both Peter Eyre, as her husband, and Patrick Stewart, as the former lover whose life and work she destroys, haven't the weight to make the contest with Miss Jackson especially interesting.In this "Hedda," the women have the best moments. Jennie Linden is fine as the deceptively defenseless Mrs. Elvsted, who originally comes to Hedda's house for help and stays on to replace her. Miss Linden succeeds in uncovering the smugness underneath Mrs. Elvsted's helplessness, which then becomes a weapon as lethal as Hedda's arrogant demand for perfection.The physical production is handsome, and Mr. Nunn is most successful in preserving the claustrophobic nature of the play without creating a static film. "Hedda" is an imaginative, intelligent film version of a play that I wasn't breathlessly waiting to see at this moment.

title: Film: Gassman in 'Scent of a Woman'
description: "Scent of a Woman" is about a journey and a destination. The journey is funny, acid and intriguing. The destination is mawkish, melodramatic and interminable.A young soldier is called to present himself at a house in Turin and place himself for seven days at the service of a retired captain, blinded in an explosion. The captain, played by Vittorio Gassman, is a handsome, vigorous man whose aristocratic arrogance suffers horribly not so much from the deprivation as the humiliation of his blindness.He is bitter, sarcastic, domineering, and his handicap has inflated his native lechery to satyriasis. All these qualities are fully displayed in the curious train trip he sets out upon with his hapless traveling companion. The destination is Naples; they stop at Genoa and Rome.The captain continually makes scenes. In the train, drunk, he insists on pressing whisky on a starchy old gentleman. When the latter only pretends to drink, the captain  whose other senses are almost sharp enough to compensate for blindness  slaps him and drives him from the compartment.In Genoa, the captain embarks on a hilarious search for a prostitute. He can smell women, he tells Ciccio, his companion, but for proper choice needs a description as well. So he goes through Genoa sniffing and considering Ciccio's thumbnail descriptions until he meets a woman who seems to suit.He requires assistance  hence Ciccio  but won't admit it. When he sits in a cafe he demands a newspaper as well as coffee. In Genoa, when a woman asks directions, he insists on giving them even though he can't see and doesn't know the city.These things work well, and the relationship between the tormented captain and the good natured, though sometimes rebellious Ciccio has humor and bite. It helps that the purpose of the journey is a mystery: Ciccio discovers a pistol and a portrait of a girl in the captain's suitcase.The Rome sequence is a heavier replay of the adventures in Genoa. And finally they arrive in Naples. The journey is over, but the movie has a long, long way to go.The captain is meeting another blinded officer, with whom he has a suicide pact. At the same time, there is the girl in the portrait who loves him, and whom he loves, but whose lovebecause of his blindnesshe is too proud to accept. Love, pride and death contend, but the real struggle is between bathos and tedium."Scent" was well liked at last year's Cannes Festival, and Mr. Gassman won the Best Actor prize. In retrospect it is hard to see why. His performance has force, but his role is paper-thin. He is a comic Iion in the early scenes When matters become serious he is nothing but roaring.

Western  supported opponents in the north and turn its back southward after the departure of the South African forces.

title: Fulbright to Represent Arab Sheikdoms in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)J. William Fulbright, former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, registered today as an agent of a group of Arab sheikdoms.

title: Panel Says C.I.A. Lets 85% of Its Contracts Without Bidding
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 More than eight of every 10 contracts awarded to private industry by the Central Intelligence Agency are let without competitive bidding by contractors, the House Select Committee on Intelligence has found.

title: ROUSE UNIT SCORES F.C.C. ON CABLE TV
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A Congressional staff report charged today that the Federal Communications Commission has provided broadcasters an improper, unconstitutional and illegal umbrella against competition and recommended the creation of a Federal program to encourage the growth of cable television.

title: Jersey High Court Gets Quinlan Case
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Attorneys for the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan asked the State Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court decision and authorize the removal of a mechanical respirator from the comatose woman so her natural processes may take over and she may die with grace and dignity.

title: Nessen and Colby Say Agreements Have Been Violated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Ford Administration and the Director of Central Intelligence charged today that leaks of House committee report on in, telligence activities violated an agreement between the committee and the executive branch.

title: Prices of Soybeans, Along With Grains, Decline Daily Limit
description: Prices of grains and soybeans plunged the daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as speculators sold in disappointment over the Department of Agriculture's largerthanexpected estimates of stocks on hand of wheat, corn and soybeans. The report was issued Friday.

title: EUROPE GOLD PRICE DROPS $3 AN OUNCE
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 (UPI)The price of gold fell more than $3 an ounce on European money markets today, while the dollar suffered marginal losses.

title: U.S. PLANT SEIZED IN LISBON DISPUTE
description: CHARNECA, Portugal, Jan. 26Hundreds of Portuguese workers occupied the Timex factory here today, accusing the company of a lockout and calling for Government intervention.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report in The New York Times of Jan. 19 on legal action involving the Subversive Activities Unit of the Michigan State Police, it was incorrectly reported that two lawyers of the American Civil Liberties Union were preparing an appeal. The lawyers involved are not affiliated with the A.C.L.U.

title: Hermit Gives Up Shack in the Woods For Comfort of an Old Folks' Home
description: MARLBOROUGH, Conn., Jan. 26After 30 years alone with the animals, birds and flowers of the Connecticut woods, Albert Teatreault has given up his serene life in a handbuilt shack for a place in a rest home.

title: F.D.A. IS CRITICIZED  IN A HOUSE REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Food and Drug Administration makes Illegal, excessive use of advisory committees and has abdicated its responsibility to protect the consumer against unapproved new drugs, according to a Congressional study issued today.

title: Helping New York
description: An elementary school in Flushing, Queens, needed people to help its immigrant pupils learn English. Those who came included a retired United Nations translator.

title: SOCIALIST SUPPORT OF ISRAEL WANING
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Meetings of European Socialist leaders, including a restricted session in Paris last weekend, have disclosed a broad and growing loss of traditional sympathy for Israel that reaches almost open support for the Palestinians in some cases.

title: Chess:
description: Ljubomir Ljubojevic, a 25 yearold Yugoslavia grandmaster, got off to a terrific start in the 38th Hoogoven International Tournament in WijkaanZee, the Netherlands, by winning his first three games.

title: Life Goes On in Dachau, but Always With a Memory
description: DACHAU, West Germany Thirtyone years after the American liberation of the inmates of the Nazi concentration camp here, the people of the city of Dachau are trying to lead normal lives, something they found easier after they accepted the fact that the camp would never be forgotten.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS ARRESTS IN PUBLIC WITH NO WARRANT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Over the harsh dissent of its two most liberal Justices, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution does not require law enforcement officials to get warrants before they make arrests in public places, even when there is adequate opportunity to obtain a warrant.

title: News Articles on Banks Are Scored by Volcker
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday warned that recent press articles based on fragments of bank examination reports lend a sensationalized air to bank problem areas.

title: Recovery From Low'74 Level
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday a strong earnings recovery in the fourth quarter from the depressed levels of a year ago. Sales rose by 19.6 percent. However, the substantial gain of the final quarter was not sufficient to overcome the declines in earnings in the first three quarters and the company wound up with a decline of 32.6 percent in earnings for 1975 as sales edged ahead by 4.5 percent.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976, by Trlacle PublIcations. Inc. (The Dally Racinz Forrn) Monday, Jan. 26. 21st day. Weather cloudy, track sloppy.

title: Lebanon Is Calm as Gunmen Withdraw
description: BEIRUT, Jan. 26As rival gunmen began warily pulling back from their sandbagged positions in Beirut today, the future of the Syriannegotiated ceasefire and proposed political settlement of Lebanon's civil war appeared to turn on the attitudes of the nation's Maronite Catholic leadership.

title: Shock Ads Criticized By Foote's President
description: Shock advertising as typified by Air France's Have you ever done it the French way, and the Mennen's antiperspirant ad that says Get off your can. Get on the stick, comes under fire in the latest house memo of John E. O'Toole, president of Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: Detroit Peaceful as Pupil Busing Begins
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26  The sparkling new yellow bus rolled to a stop this morning in front of Clark Elementary School, an old yellowbrick fortress sur!rounded by the Tudors and Colonials of the middle and uppermiddle class white families of Northeast Detroit, where busing for integration is not exactly a popular cause.

title: College Art Gallery Is Paysons Gift
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan 26The son and daughterinlaw of the late Joan Whitney Payson have announced they would build an art gallery for Westbrook College here in memory of Mrs. Payson, owner of the New York Mets and a patron of the arts, and lend it an art collection for an extended period of time.

title: Article 4  No Title
Simnson's Hand Injured
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP)  O. J. Simpson, the Buffalo Bills allpro running back, was taken to a hosiptal for Xrays of his left hand tonight after a freak accident as be was leaving the field after the Pro Bawl. Simpson siad a fan tried to snatch his chin strap for a souvenir, and that he injured his hand trying to protect it.

title: Books of The Times
description: What I find striking today is the radical disjunction between the social structure (the technoeconomic border) ana the culture. The former is rule by an economic principle defined in terms of efficiency and functional rationality, the organization of production through the ordering of things, including men as things. The latter is prodigal, promiscuous, dominating by an antirational, antiintellectual temper in which the self is taken as the touchstone of cultural judgments, and the effect on the self is the measure of the aesthetic worth of the experience.

title: Exxon and Shell Off Du Pont Gains
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Shell Oil Company reported yesterday lower net income for the last quarter and all of 1975 while the Sun Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of California showed a gain in earnings for the quarter but a drop for the year.

title: PARKING
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will he back in effect today. The regulations had been suspended during the snow alert, which ended with yesterday's rising temperatures.

title: 12 Colombians Convicted, in Drug Traffic
description: Twelve defendants have been convicted here of conspiracy to distribute large amounts of cocaine and marijuana smuggled from Colombia in what Federal prosecutors described as the biggest Colombian narcotics organization ever uncovered.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Article 3  No Title
Highest 75 Jobless Rate Revised Down, to 8.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The statistical section of President Ford's economic report to Congress disclosed today that the regular annual revisions of the nation's unemployment figures had reduced the recession's peak unemployment rate, reached last May, from 9.2 per cent to 8.9 per cent of the labor force.

title: Asphalt Plant Into Gymnasium
description: Except for the traffic, probably nothing on the East River Drive has caused as much comment over the years as the Municipal Asphalt Plant. Its enormous parabolic arch of reinforced concrate soars over the bend in the road at 91st Street, a powerful, stark form if there ever was one.

title: Panel Says C.I.A. Lets 85% of Its Contracts Without Bidding
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 More than eight of every 10 contracts awarded to private industry by the Central Intelligence Agency are let without competitive bidding by contractors, the House Select Committee on Intelligence has found.

title: Yorkville Group Plans to Convert
description: A battle for preservation has been won on the playing fields of Yorkville.

title: Sunshine Boys Sets a Record
description: The Sunshine Boys made more money than any other film in the 43year history of the Radio City Music Hall, with 834,719 persons paying a total of $3,164,929 over an 11week engagement that ended last week. These receipts top the previous high of $3,096,635, set in 1968 by another Neil Simon comedy, The Odd Couple, over a 14week period, the longest run recorded at the 6,000seat showcase.

title: BARRON COLLIER JR., REALESTATE LEADER
description: Barron Collier Jr., a realestate developer and newspaper publisher in southwest Florida, died Thursday in New Orleans. He was 67 years old.

title: Burke Says State Aid Cut Will Raise Realty Taxes
description: UNION, Jan. 26Dr. Fred G. Burke, State Commissioner of Education, told local school officials today that they faced a reduction of $122 million in state aid for public education under Governor Byrne's proposed budget. and warned them that the result could be higher local property taxes.

title: Mrs. Nixon Meets Rebozo On a Trip to Key Biscayne
description: MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP)Pat Nixon flew to Miami today and went immediately to the former Nixon compound on Key Biscayne, where she was met by C. G. Rebozo, a close friend of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Some Hints for Wary. Patients: A Shopper's Guide to Surgery
description: To combat the millions of unnecessary or questionable operations being performed each year at a cost of billions of dollars and thousands of lives, Herbert S. Denenberg, a former Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner, has prepared a booklet called A Shopper's Guide to Surgery.

title: Palisade Woodland
description: Within the next few days, an agonizing question affecting a major area of open space atop the Palisades will be settled: whether an unusually large tract of privatelyowned woodland in the immediate metropolitan region will remain untouched forever, as a park  or be lost forever to building lots and possibly to highrise apartments. The strip of potential parkland lies in the Borough of Tenafly above the Hudson River and about six miles north of the George Washington Bridge. The borough and the State of New Jersey, through the GreenAcres fund, long ago earmarked what had been thought to be sufficient money to conclude the purchase of this property of 274 acres, known as East Hill.

title: Schools Maintenance Chief Urges Custodial Cutbacks
description: The official in charge of school buildings has proposed a $21 million reduction in cleaning and maintenance sevices to meet a current budget deficit.

title: Miss Morerod Captures 2d Cup Race in 2 Days
LEFTIST ANGOLANS APPROACH HUAMBO
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 26 A column of at least 52 Sovietmade tanks is reported to be leading an offensive by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola into the heartland of territory held by proWestern Angolans.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CUT 1977 AID TO ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26The Ford Administration has decided to submit to Congress a request for $1.8 billion in military and economic aid for Israel in the next fiscal year, nearly $500 million less than Israel will probably receive from the United States in the fiscal year that ends June 30.

title: Bonn Reports Sharp Drop In ForeignTrade Surplus
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Jan. 26, (UPI)West Germany's 1975 foreigntrade surplus dropped sharply from the previous year, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: TV: Laverne and Shirley, Spinoff With Surprise
description: In television's hallowed tradition of the spinoff, Happy Days, one of the more successful series on the ABCTV schedule, now has spawned Laverne and Shirley, which will immediately follow Happy Days on Tuesdays at 8:30 P.M. The surprise is that the new show, or at least tonight's premiere, is one of the best production efforts of the midseason sweepstakes.

title: Microdot Offer Is Made By Northwest Industries
description: After vigorously battling an unwanted tender offer by the General Cable Corporation for nearly two months, Microdot Inc. announced yesterday that a better offer had been found for its stockholders.

title: U.S. Retains Sailing Cup
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The American yacht St. Francis VI retained the AmericanAustralian Challenge Cup for sixMeter yachts today. The San Francisco based yacht, sailed by Tom Blackaller, beat Prince Alfred, the Australian challenger, by 1 minute 7 seconds in the fourth race of the series and won 40.

title: Dungan Is Pelted With Eggs as He Tells Of Budget Trims in Higher Education
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 26  Ralph A. Dungan, the State Chancellor of Higher Education was pelted with eggs today at the Douglas College Student Union after he outlined a series of planning tuition increases, enrollment cuts and faculty layoffs in state colleges. His announcement also elicited threats from faculty bargaining representatives and students.

title: Israel Views Beirut Agreement as Expansion by Syria
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26The ceasefire and political compromise reached last week in Lebanon represents, in the opinion of Israeli officials and analysts, a thinly camouflaged move by Syria to expand its influence over Lebanon.

title: PRESIDENT URGES MODERATE POLICY TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Ford and his Council of Economic Advisers today advocated policies aimed at achieving a moderate recovery pace rather than the rapid return to full employment favored by many Democrats.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Rear Adm. Andrew McKee Dies; Expert on Navy Construction
description: Rear Adm. Andrew I. McKee, retired, who served with the Navy construction corps in both World Wars, died Saturday in the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was 79 years old and lived in New London. Conn.

title: Pentagon Drops Bid For 600Ship Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Defense Department, largely for budgetary reasons, has quietly abandoned the longstanding goal of expanding the Navy's diminished fleet to 600 ships by the mid1980's.

title: Texts of Merola Letter to Carey and Governor's to Lefkowitz
description: Following are the texts of a letter sent on Jan. 14 by District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx to Governor Carey, and the Governor's letter of Jan. 26 to State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz:

title: STATE AIDE SCORES ENVIRONMENT ACT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26The State Commerce Commissioner, Thomas Dyson, called today for an 18month delay in implementing a proposed requirement for environmentalimpact statements on publicly approved and financed development.

title: The Vetoed U.N. Resolution on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26Following is the text of the resolution on the Middle East vetoed in the Security Council tonight by the United States.

title: Adam Smith. Adam Who
description: It is strange that so little attention has been paid so far to the fact that 1976 is the Bicentennial not only of the United States but also of Adam Smith's classic, The Wealth of Nations. Smith's masterwork provided the ideology for traditional capitalism in much the same way as Karl Marx's Capital did for Soviet socialism. But no one can imagine Moscow being as indifferent to the Bicentennial of Capital as Washington has been to that anniversary of The Wealth of Nations.

title: DELAY IS DENIED IN ATTICA TRIALS
description: A justice in State Supreme Court in Buffalo yesterday rejected a request by Alfred T. Scotti, the special state Attica prosecutor, that the delay the trial of 10 former Attica inmates charged with kidnapping guards during the 1971 prison revolt.

title: Canadian Physician. Jailed In Abortion Case, Is Freed
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (UPI)Dr. Henry Morgenthaler was released without bail today after spending 10 months in prison on a charge of having performed an illegal abortion.

title: HOUSE UNIT SCORES F.C.C. ON CABLE TV
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A Congressional staff report charged today that the Federal Communications Commission has provided broadcasters an improper, unconstitutional and illegal umbrella against competition and recommended the creation of a Federal program to encourage the growth of cable television.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CUT 1977 AID TO ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Ford Administration has decided to submit to Congress a request for $1.8 billion in military and economic aid for Israel in the next fiscal year, nearly $500 million less than Israel will probably receive from the United States in the fiscal year that ends June 30.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1976

title: Gerulaitis on Team
description: World Team Tennis named the Wimbledon doubles champions, Sandy Mayer of the New York Sets and Vitas Gerulaitis of the Pittsburgh Triangles to the league contingent that will play a fivematch series with the Soviet Union.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS STAYING IN ANGOLA
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Defense Minister Pieter W. Botha said in a statement today that South African soldiers would remain in the area of Angola's border with SouthWest Africa until the Government received a guarantee that the frontier was safe.

title: Fordham Defeats Columbia 6557
description: Too bad Fordham isn't in the Ivy League. If the Rams were, they could be in first place. The Rams defeated Columbia, 6557, last night before 1,200 fans at Rose Hill Gym.

title: Clifford A. Prevost, 77, Dies; ExNewsman in Washington
description: Clifford A. Prevost, a former Washington correspondent for The Detroit Free Press and the Knight Newspapers, died yesterday in Mount Kisco (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and had been living recently with a daughter, Mrs. Elie Abel, at 13 Banksville Road in Armonk, N.Y.

title: U.S. CASTS VETO ON MIDEAST PLAN IN U.N.'S COUNCIL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 26The United States vetoed a Middle East resolution in the Security Council tonight, asserting that it would set new and onesided conditions for negotiating an ArabIsraeli peace settlement.

title: 2 Killed on Carolina Road
description: RIDGELAND. S. C., Jan. 26 (AP)A car caught fire in a collision on foggy Interstate 95 today, burning two occupants to death and touching off chainreaction crashes that involved 15 cars and two trailer trucks In all A highway patrolmen said the victims were women from Rhode island.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: S. Dakota Five Invited to Cuba
description: VERMILLION, S. D., Jan. 26 (UPI)The University of South Dakota's basketball team has been invited to play two games in Cuba against the University of Havana. The invitation was extended through the office of Senator James Abourezk, South Dakota Democrat, with the games to be played the first week in March when the university is on its spring break.

title: City's New Budget Director
description: Donald David Kummerfeld, already confirmed as the city's newest Budget Director, was preparing for his obligatory City Hall news conference yesterday when, according to mayoral aides, he asked: What should I wear? I don't want to look like a banker.

title: Michigan State May Go to Court
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 26 (AP)  Michigan State's president, Clifton Wharton, charged today that penalties given to the university by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for recruiting violations were unduly harsh. Some charges, he said, are factually incorrect and a court fight is being discussed.

title: City's New Budget Director
description: Donald David Kummerfeld, already confirmed as the city's newest Budget Director, was preparing for his obligatory City Hall news conference yesterday when, according to mayoral aides, he asked: What should I wear? I don't want to look like a banker.

title: Canada's Ski Team to Be Disciplined
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 26 (UPI)Canada's skijumping team will be disbanded after the Winter Olympics because drinking and swearing by some of its members, Keith Nesbitt, executive director of the Canadian Ski Association: said today. A couple or three members of the team have been rather undisciplined in the recent training camp held in Europe, Nesbitt said. The problem, he said, was the drinking and swearing and that kind of thing.

title: Stocks Rise in Heavy Trading; Dow Gains by 7.56 to 961.51
description: Buoyed by reports of improved earnings, stock prices continued to surge ahead on heavy trading volume yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, showing strength from the opening bell, rose 7.56 points to close at 961.51, bringing its total advance in January to more than 109 points, or 12.9 percent.

description: STOCK

description: The Major Events of the Day

title: BlackLung Benefits Cost Rises; A New Liberalization Is Sought
description: LOGAN, W. Va.Jay Conley felt his way along the downtown buildings, trudging the sidewalk with his outstretched right hand barely touching the grimy bricks.

title: Next to Good Rhyme, Coda Proves Poet's Best Friend
description: Did you know that when sending material through the mail for copywright registration, the postage is free?

description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

description: Alternatesideofthe street parking regulations will he hack in effect today. The regulations had been suspended during the snow alert, which ended with yesterday's rising temperatures.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26The United States vetoed a Middle East resolution in the Security Council tonight, objecting that it would alter the existing peacenegotiating framework and be seriously harmful to the future of the process.

title: Excerpt From Report of Economic Council
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26Following is an excerpt from the Annual Report or the Council of Economic Advisers. which, together with the President's Annual Economic Report, was submitted to Congress today:

title: Births
description: POLANSKY Dr. & Mrs. Sleven Polansky joy July announce the birth of Jonathan & Jennifer's sister Pobln Ellse, 9 its 112 oz. on January 26, 1976, in Carmlchael Calf.

title: Notes on People
description: With his head bowed, John B. Swainson, former Governor of Michigan and state Supreme Court judge, heard himself sentenced in Detroit yesterday to serve at least 60 days on a perjury conviction. The rest of three concurrent yearandaday sentences were suspended. He had faced a possible 15year sentence and $15,000 fine.

title: Article 2  No Title
Summary of Actions Taken by U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: A BRIGHT DANCE DUO FOR HARLEQUINADE
description: In its oldfashioned, rainbowhued way, Harlequinade might be voted the ballet least likely to succeed in the lean New York City Ballet repertory. However, it has proven quite durable and enjoyable since its premiere 11 years ago, and if nothting else is an eyedazzling rebuff to the idea that the company's only costume colors are black and white. It received a bouncy, bright performance by Patricia McBride and John Clifford, guest artist, in its first appearance this season on Sunday at the State Theater.

title: LowIncome Englewood Project Is Hailed as a Success
description: ENGLEWOOD, Jan. 26A low  income, predominantly black housing development that was forcefed into a white residential neighborhood here four years ago is producing none of the horrors that Its opponents feared.

title: CAREY CAMPAIGNS FOR HIS BUDGET
description: UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 26Governor Carey campaigned upstate today for a candidate he clearly believes to be a winner his 197677 budget, which calls for deep spending cuts and no new taxes.

title: No Evidence
description: A Connecticut judge, sitting as a special oneman grand jury, has found no evidence approaching even a minimal standard of credibility to indicate that the late John M. Bailey, long the state's Democratic boss, ever accepted any money to use his influence in behalf of a promoter seeking a license for a jai alai fronton. While we were wrong in our original assumption that Mr. Bailey had indeed received a $250,000 payment, and have already said so, we are glad to make special note of the final report by Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey exonerating Mr. Bailey.

title: Article 7  No Title
MillTown Basketball, Or Life in the Minors
description: Last month the Long Island Sounds of the Eastern Basketball Association were on the first road trip of their struggling career when they stopped to eat outside one the Pennsylvania mill towns that make up most of the league.

title: Strike by Pittsburgh Teachers Ends With $19 Million in Raises
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 26 Striking schoolteachers ended an eightweek walkout today, by ratifying a new contract, that will bring the top maximum for teachers with masters degrees to $20,300 a year on March 1. 1978.

title: Helping New York
description: An elementary school in Flushing, Queens, needed people to help its immigrant pupils learn English. Those who came included a retired United Nations translator.

title: ISSAR UNTERIVIAN, ASHKENAZI RABBI
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 26Issar Yehuda Unterman, dean of the Israeli rabbinate, died yesterday in Jerusalem, Israel. He was 90 years old. He occupied the highest offices in the Jewish religious establishment when he served from 1964 to 1972 as Chief Rabbi of the Ashkenazi, or Western community, and president of the Rabbinical High Court.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 26  The sparkling new yellow bus rolled to a stop this morning in front of Clark Elementary School, an old yellowbrick fortress surrounded by the Tudor and Colonialstyle houses of the middle and uppermiddleclass white families of Northeast Detroit, where busing for integration is not exactly a popular cause.
