title: Quinlan Coma Case Heard By Highest Jersey Court
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26Attorneys for the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan asked the State Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court decision and authorize the removal of a mechanical respirator from the comatose woman so her natural processes may take over and she may die with grace and dignity.

title: Fashion: Paris Is Alive and Well, but Different
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Inching up the curving marble staircase, past the fitting rooms on the second floor to the grand salon of the House of Dior on the third, it is almost possible to believe the couture is back in its glory days.

title: W. T. Grant Faced a $300 Million Loss Before Reorganization Step
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which has closed 712 stores and dismissed 50,000 employees since filing for Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings last October, faded a loss of about $300 million in the current fiscal year had it not undertaken its massive program of surgery, it was learned yesterday.

title: Merola Questions Legality Of Investigation by Nadjari
description: Governor Carey yesterday released a letter from Mario Merola in which the Bronx District Attorney, reversing his previous position, raised questions about the legitimacy of Maurice H. Nadjari's investigations into alleged political corruption in the Bronx.

title: BEAME FILLS JOB OF BUDGET CHIEF
description: Acting quickly and without consulting the city:s fiscal overseers, Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Donald D. Kummerfeld, a 41yearold vice president of the First Boston Corporation, as the city's new Budget Director.

title: L.I. Man in O'Brien Case Gets Prison for Burglary
New Jersey Briefs
description: $350,000 Insurance Fraud Admitted

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE GOOD EARTH Sidney Howard's 1924 drama, of a triangle in California's Napa Valley, They Knew What They Wanted, is rarely staged these days, possibly because of the popularity of Frank Loesser's musical version, The Most Happy Fella, which arrived on Broadway in 1957 and was reprised twice by the City Center Light Opera Company. The original play, which won the Pulitzer Prize, also had two revivals, in 1939 and 1949 (with Paul Muni). And there was a nearforgotten Hollywood version teaming Charles Laughton, Carole Lombard and William Gargan in 1940 and directed by a young Hollywood newcomer, Garson Kanin.

title: New Bond Issues
HENRY S. SANDERS
description: Henry S. Sanders, who retired in 1965 as a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 969 Park Avenue.

title: Coyote Freed by Vandals Bites a Jersey Boy, 12
description: A 75pound coyote that was released from a small zoo by vandals attacked and hit a 12yearold boy on the left arm and thigh yesterday morning as the boy walked to school in Westfield. N.J.

title: A.B.A. Owners Confident
description: DENVER, Jan. 26Putting the best possible face on an uncertain situation, Commissioner Dave DeBusschere and the American Basketball Association owners declared today that they were confident of the stability of their depleted league.

title: State Court Upholds Layoffs by Cities
description: The Appelate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a municipality could dismiss Civil Service em ployees for economic reasons, despite job guarantees in its contracts with unions.

title: Los Angeles Council Ends Inquiry in Kennedy Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) The City Council voted today to end its investigation into police handling of the 1968 assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES SCORE CAREY PLAN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  The state's principal association of private colleges and universities charged today that Governor Carey's proposed 197677 budget would weaken its members ability to compete with the lowcost public colleges, rather than helping them attract new students, as the Governor has asserted.

title: Lots of Lettuce Leaves The City a Little Ahead
description: Every bit of lettuce the city can save these days brings salad days closer to reality, so the city jumped at the chance yesterday to pick up 637 cases of iceberg lettuce from the Army at a saving of almost $4,000.

title: LILCO RATE CHANGE ASKED FOR L.I. POOR
description: The State Consumer Protection Board asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to take account of deteriorating economic conditions in the NassauSuffolk area in revising the electric rate structure of the Long Island Lighting Co. and in increasing rates to meet the utility's revenue requirements.

title: Dr. John Hastings Is Dead; C.C.N.Y. Professor, 100
description: Dr. John Hastings, professor emeritus of anthropological and economic geography at City College and a renowned cartographer, died Saturday at the Isabella Geriatric Center here at the age of 100.

title: Legislature Puts Off Vote On 2c Gasoline Tax Rise
description: TRENTON, Jan. 26The Legislature deferred action today on Governor Byrne's request for a 2centagallon gasoline tax increase and adjourned after a routine session to await the Governor's budget message and tax proposals a week from tomorrow.

title: Wisdom Of the Sages
description: WASHINGTONHaving soaked for seven days and seven nights in the clichs of the world's most awesome political reporters, I am ready to take questions about the national political situation. Do I hear a question?

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The National Institute of Arts and Letters has elected two writers, an architect, a composer and four painters to membership. Those chosen were:

title: Bulova Accepts Study
description: GENEVA, Jan. 26As part of a settlement of a 10day sitin strike by its workers, the Swiss subsidiary of the Bulova Watch Company has agreed to cooperate with an independent study to determine whether its decision to close a plant was justified.

title: Return to Washington
description: When the Prime Minister of Israel arrives in Washington today, he will find the mood and preoccupations of the United States Government somewhat different from those which he encountered as Israel's Ambassador in the heady days after the SixDay War of 1967.

title: Going Through the Mill
description: When Terry Sanford, the president of Duke University, got off a plane in North Carolina last week, after four days in a Massachusetts hospital with chest pains, his wife Margaret Rose told reporters at the airport: Terry's a strong person. But the primaries are killing the candidates.

title: Note to Readers
description: Starting today, the table for stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange will reflect the final prices, volumes and highs and lows of all those stocks on the regional exchanges and all offboard trading as well.

title: St. John's Wins; 17 for Indiana
description: IOWA CITY, Jan. 26 (AP) Topranked Indiana used a poised pressure defense and 32 points from Scott May to defeat Iowa, 8873, in a Big Ten Conference basketball game tonight.

title: Barry, Smith Pace Warriors' Victory
Indians Hoping Election Today Will Result in Peace at Pine Ridge
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Jan. 26. Residents of this strifetorn Indian reservation go to the polls tomorrow for a tribal election that they hope will bring them their first real peace since the Wounded Knee takeover three years ago.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Pentagon Drops Bid For 600Ship Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Defense Department, largely for budgetary reasons, has quietly abandoned the longstanding goal of expanding the Navy's diminished fleet to 600 ships by the mid1980's.

title: DAVID GRAHAM DIES; INVESTMENT EXPERT
description: David Graham, who retired in 1969 as a partner and chairman of the corporate finance department of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, Inc., investments, died Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 70 years old and formerly lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Millrose Meet Loaded in Talent, But Will Bayi Show Up to Run?
description: A galloping case of Olympic fever was building in New York yesterday as the French track team arrived and joined the rush of international athletes headed for the first major meet of the season here, the Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: Av Westin Resigns as ABC News Officer
description: Av Westin, the 46yearold executive producer in charge of news and documentaries for ABCTV, resigned yesterday. No successor was named immediately.

title: People and Business
description: Barbara A. Simpson, an economist and utility regulator, in in iine for a vacant Republican seat on the Federal Power Commission, according to highlevel sources in the commission. If nominated by President Ford and confirmed by the Senate, she would be the first woman of the fivemember agency whose principal task is setting natural gas prices.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division

title: Market Place
description: The president of the Conrac Corporation, a company whose shares are believed to have been manipulated late last year, regards the alleged attempt as almost ludicrous.

title: Yale Restricts Campus Entry Alter New Assault on a Coed
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26The assault on a woman student last week at Yale University has brought new security added to the security plan introduced only 10 days earlier.

title: Incompetent Surgery Is Found Not Isolated
description: A middleaged man entered a leading New York hospital for the replacement of a heart valve that had been damaged by rheumatic fever. When he was taken off the heartlung machine after his operation, his circulation failed and he died minutes later. An autopsy revealed that the surgeon had put the artificial valve in backward, preventing blood from flowing through the heart.

title: A Race For the Top 3
description: The more forehanded of the Democratic Presidential candidates have laid down the organizational bases of their campaigns in New Hampshire and shaken hands all the way to the Canadian border. But with a month to go until the primary on Feb. 24, all the voters see is four or five obscure guys saying more or less the same thing.

title: Urban Groups Say U.S. Budget Gives Inadequate Aid to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Two leading urban lobbying organizations said today that the Administration's proposed budget offers mayors and city councils little solace.

title: Orthodox Rabbis Hail Papal Stand On Sexual Morals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26A major body of Orthodox Judaism's rabbinate lauded today the Vatican's recent reaffirmation of a document urging sexual morality, terming the statement an act of courage and statesmanship.

title: ENGINES OF DC10'S WILL BE MODIFIED
description: As a result of the destruction of a DC10 jet in New York last fall and two other cases of hazardous damage from collisions with birds, a decision has been made to reinforce key parts of all DC10 engines.

title: HEARST TRIAL SET TO SELECT JURORS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26Patricia Hearst's defense lost motions today designed to limit evidence against her, while the Government lost its fight for an order barring outofcourt statements by lawyers in the case.

title: IRWIN B. GOODMAN
description: Irwin B. Goodman, founder and board chairman of the I. B. Goodman Manufacturing Company, jewelry maker, died Sunday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Nadjari's Jurisdiction
description: By instructing Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to review Maurice H. Nadjari's investigation of alleged influencepeddling and selling of political jobs in the Bronx, Governor Carey has directly challenged the jurisdiction of the special state prosecutor. That is one of the rare points of agreement between the prosecutor and the Governor, who have been openly feuding since the Governor attempted to dismiss Mr. Nadjari last month.

title: Hey, Mister! Wayne Marks First 50 Years
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.A man sits on horseback by the draw of a stream in Jack's Valley, silhouetted against the snowcapped Sierra Nevadas, a gray Stetson on his head, a red bandanna around his neck, a rifle jutting out from under his saddle.

title: Urban Groups Say U.S. Budget Gives Inadequate Aid to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Two leading urban lobbying organizations said today that the Administration's proposed budget offers mayors and city councils little solace.

title: VW Authorized to Begin U.S. Plant Talks Again
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Jan. 26 (Reuters) The management of the Volkswagen car works here has been authorized by the company's supervisory board to reopen negotiations on establishing an assembly plant in the United States, company spokesman said today.

title: Article 6  No Title
The People Beneath the. Bottom Line
description: The financial records of New York City are undergoing unprecedented surveying and studying. On any given day, record numbers of auditors pore over city books for the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Emergency Financial Control Board, our comptroller, our comptroller's comptroller, and for an everincreasing host of watchdogs and. watchdogs watchdogs who now oversee New York's fiscal affairs.

title: Judge Acts to Curb The LegalAid Arm Of Antiunion Group
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today, in a major victory for organized labor, that the legalaid arm of the National Right to Work Committee operates as front for employers who are trying to weaken unions.

title: PROPOSAL IS BACKED IN GASDEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The House Democrat who is leading forces opposed to general deregulation of natural gas prices described today as eminently sensible a proposal to end regulation for up to 7,000 small independent producers, those who do not sell more than 100 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year while extending Federal jurisdiction over large producers to sales within intrastate commerce.

title: Advertising:
description: During the 1960's a lot of little retail shopsboutiques came into being and did their own things in both the shops and in the communications for them.

title: ISRAELIS GET REPORT OF SOVIET HIJACKING
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 26 (AP)Reports circulated at Israel's international airport today of a possible attempted air hijacking in the Soviet Union. There was no immediate comment from officials in Moscow.

title: GARBAGE CLEANUP BEGINS IN YONKERS
2 Races Canceled After Big A Spill
description: It was Weather Unclear, Track Missing yesterday at Aqueduct. Part of the Big A's surface, near the rail at the end of the backstretch, was drenched after a springlike thaw, causing a three  horse spill in the fogshrouded seventh race. Horses and jockeys came up covered in mud, but escaped without serious injury. After stewards examined the scene of the grime, the last two races, including the $25,000 feature, were canceled.

title: More Obstruction
description: Everyone prominent in New York State Democratic politics, from Governor Carey down, is filling the air with assurances of eagerness to see Special Prosecutor Nadjari's anticorruption investigation proceed with maximum speed and without political interference.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
Pistons Drop Ray Scott As Coach
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Detroit Pistons dismissed Coach Ray Scott today and named the assistant coach, Herb Brown, to replace him.

title: Nigeria, Citing Cruelty, Recalls 45,000 From Equatorial Guinea
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 26 (AP) Nigeria is evacuating 45,000 contract laborers from Equatorial Guinea because of what it calls a long history of brutal ill treatment of its citizens there.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report In The New York Times of Jan. 19 on legal action involving the Subversive Activities Unit of the Michigan State Police, it was incorrectly reported that two lawyers of the American Civil Liberties Union were preparing an appeal. The lawyers involved are not affiliated with the A.C.L.U.

title: PitneyBowes Cuts Prices On Paper Copier Rentals
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 26 (UPI)PitneyBowes Inc., reduced today rental prices on its plainpaper copier effective March 1 and announced discount plans to give it a significant price advantage in the office copying market. The basic monthly rental for a customer making 10,000 copies is 5.7 percent lower under the new rate structure, The rental rate for the same monthly volume over a sixmonth period is 5.1 percent cheaper.

title: 3YEAR PRICE PLAN SET BY F.EA. ON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26In an ambitious attempt at economic planning, the Federal Energy Administration is preparing to publish a tentative schedule of the domestic crude oil prices it will let producers charge for the next three years.

title: People in Sports
description: Shula Tries to Grant Scott's Trade Wish

title: OPEC Meets in Paris
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting under tight security in Paris, worked on details of a $1 billion aid program for poor nations. Page 61.

title: Security Tight as OPEC Meets In Paris on Aid to Poor Lands.
description: PARIS, Jan. 26Amid tight security precautions, finance ministers of the Organization of Petroleun Exporting Countries met here today to work out details of a $1 billion aid fund for poor countries. Final approval was expected tomorrow.

title: Quake in Northern Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (UPI)A weak earthquake shook Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan's main Islands, tonight but there were no reports of casualties or damage, the Meteorological Agency reported.

title: PRICES ARE EASIER IN BOND MARKETS
description: Prices in the credit markets drifted lower yesterday as traders and investors awaited the Treasury's announcement of its refinancing plans, expected this afternoon, and the terms of this week's major corporate and taxexempt bond sales. Rates on threemonth Treasury bills, nevertheless, moved down slightly, enabling the Federal Government to incur the lowest rate in selling these shortterm securities since November, 1972.

title: 2 Prosecution Witnesses at Trial Of Carson Admit Lying on Stand
description: Two key prosecution witnesses at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson admitted yesterday that they had given false testimony. Their admissions were the final testimony heard before the prosecution rested its case.

title: British Order Halt, Then a Resumption, Of Iceland Fishing
description: LONDON, Jan. 26 (Reuters) Prime Minister Harold Wilson tonight told British trawlers off Iceland they could resume fishing after earlier ordering them to stop.

title: FORD'S AIDES SEE WORLD RECOVERY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The recession In the rest of the industrial world reached bottom sometime during the summer of 1975 and a policy aimed at faster growth in the United States would have negligible effects in spurring the rebound of other countries, President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

title: Incompetent Surgery Is Found Not Isolated
description: A middleaged man entered, a leading New York hospital, for the replacement of a heart valve that had been damaged by rheumatic fever. When he was taken off the heartlung machine after his operation, his circulation failed and he died minutes later. An autopsy revealed that the surgeon had put the artificial valve in backward, preventing blood from flowing through the heart.

title: Some Hints for Wary. Patients: A Shopper's Guide to Surgery
description: To combat the millions of unnecessary or questionable operations being performed each year at a cost of billions of dollars and thousands of lives, Herbert S. Denenberg, a former Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner, has prepared a booklet called A Shopper's Guide to Surgery.

title: Egypt Seems Worried That Syria Has Cut Sadat's Role in Mideast
description: CAIRO, Jan. 26  Western diplomats here feel that Syria's demonstrated ability to assert power over the Lebanese and the Palestinians has further weakened President Anwar elSadat's power to influence, events in the Middle East in coming months.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Bush Named Scouts Pilot
description: Ed Bush has been called a wild man, a taskmaster and one of the toughest guys going. His tempestuous nature has propelled him from one hockey coaching Job to another in the American Hockey League and in Ontario Junior B hockey. Now the 57yearold former defenseman who is said to have punched players during games will coach the Kansas City Scouts of the National Hockey League, his first N.H.L. coaching assignment. He's been one of the premier coaches in the Ontario Hockey Association for years, said Sid Abel, the

title: Steel Production Rose 0.8% in Week To 2,253,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 24 edged ahead to its highest level of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Article 8  No Title
U.S. Explains Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  The United States said tonight that it had vetoed the Security Council resolution to prevent the current negotiating framework in the Middle East from being destroyed.

title: Merola Questions Legality Of Investigation by Nadjari
description: Governor Carey yesterday released a letter from Mario Merola in which the Bronx District Attorney, reversing his previous position, raised questions about the legitimacy of Maurice H. Nadjari's investigations into alleged political corruption in the Bronx.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS ARRESTS IN PUBLIC WITH NO WARRANT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Over the harsh dissent of its two most liberal Justices, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution does not require law enforcement officials to get warrants before they make arrests in public places, even when there is adequate opportunity to obtain a warrant.

title: Music: Songs of Darzins
description: The local Latvian community turned out in force late Sunday afternoon when Janis Klavins offered the complete songs of Emils Darzins at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: A 12Month School Year Supported in State Senate
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26The State Senate today approved a bill authorizing the Commissioner of Education to permit 12month school years in up to three community school districts in the statea measure designed by its sponsors to ease the districts budget difficulties.

title: Article 1  No Title
Gulf Is Ordered to Refund $2 Million in Overcharges
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (UPI)  The Federal Energy Adminisration ordered the Gulf Oil Corporation today to refund $2.2 million in power plant fuel overcharges to the Virginia Electric and Power Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: C. Julius Hoffmann, director of the German Information Center here since 1970, has been awarded the Founders Medal by the New School for Social Research for his contribution to international understanding that exists the shared mission of scholars in Germany and the United States.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SUPS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday, while those in the overthecounter market closed mixed.

title: 2 CHILDREN KILLED IN FIRE IN BROOKLYN
description: Despite a perilous rescue effort by firemen who carried al 135pound ladder through al burning Brooklyn tenement, two children died yesterday after a fire allegedly set by an arsonist swept through the threestory frame building, trapping the children on the top floor.

title: Banking Secrecy
description: How much should the public know about the condition and management of banks? That question has been sharply raised by reports that many banks, including twelve the nation's fifty largest bank holding companies, were put on a confidential problem list by the Federal Reserve Board a year ago and by the more recent disclosure that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has 350 state and rational banks on its own problem list.

title: SENATOR CLARK SEES U.S. RISKS IN ANGOLA
description: Senator Dick Clark. chairman of the Foreign Relations subcommittee on African affairs, warned last night that a United States attempt to counter Soviet. and Cuban involvement in the Angolan civil war might entail a commitment far heavier than the American people or Congress would he likely to support.

title: PHASEOUT IS SET OF PCBS CHENICIAL
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Monsanto Company announced today that it plans to phase out the manufacture of a toxic group of chemicals known as PCBs, which environmentalists contend are threatening public health and the nation's rivers and lakes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: London Pledges Steps to Lower Unemployment
description: LONDON, Jan. 26  In an effort to avert a threatened parliamentary challenge to its economic strategy, the British Government today pledged to introduce new measures to curb the sharplyrising unemployment rate.

title: Money
Riessen, Roche Victors at Philadelphia
FourYear Moratorium On Coal Leases Is Ended
description: DENVER, Jan. 26 (AP)Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe ended today a fouryear moratorium on Federal coal leases, pledging to allow mining of coal that is needed. but only when it is needed.

title: Beame Picks Budget Chief Without Help of Advisers
description: Acting quickly and without consulting the city's fiscal overseers, Mayor Beame yesterday, appointed Donald D. Kummerfeld, a 41yearold vice president of the First Boston Corporation, as the city's new Budget Director.

title: Mourners, at the Chapel, Go Tell It to Robeson
description: As if to stir the memories, there were tapes of Paul Robeson singing Amazing Grace, Ol Man River and Go Tell It on the Mountain.

title: GROWTH OUTLOOK FOR ITALY BLEAK
description: PARIS, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Growth prospects this year for the Italian economy are poor, Italy's external payments balance will remain fragile, and inflation and unemployment may worsen, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development contended today.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Piano Concerto No. 9, Mozart; Symphony No. 2. Borodin; Elegy for Strings, Elgar.

title: East Germany Jails a Refugee Smuggler
description: EAST BERLIN, Jan. 26A 29yearold West Berliner was sentenced here today to 15 years in prison for having helped 86 East Germans and a Czech to flee to the West.

title: Civil Rights Parley Assails Ford on Domestic Policis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Participants in the 27th annual (board meeting of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights condemned today the Ford Administration's domestic policies and strongly implied that the group of 120 organizations would oppose Mr. Ford at the polls in November.

title: Nessen and Colby Say Agreements Have Been Violated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Ford Administration and the Director of Central Intelligence charged today that leaks of House committee report on in telligence activites violated an agreement between the committee and the executive branch:

title: For an Envoy, A Gala Date To Remember
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26Alejandro Orfila looked as if he were fit to burst with pride last night.

title: Rise in Mental Illness Linked to Economy
description: The current unstable economic conditions have led to a sharp rise in treatment for mental illness in this country, particularly among 45to60yearold men, thus adding to the overall costs of inflation and recession, according to a report published yesterday by two psychiatrists at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda. Md.

title: AROUSTAMIAN PLAYS MUSIC OF CAUCASUS
description: Andranik Aroustamian, former conductor of the Yerevan Armenian State Philharmonic's Ensemble of Folkloristic Instruments, gave a recital of kemanje music from the Caucasus on Sunday at Asia House.

title: New Marijuana Studies Find No Adverse Effect
description: Several recent studies of chronic marijuana users, conducted independently in half a dozen countries, indicate that the drug has no apparent significant adverse effect on the, human body or brain or on their functions.

title: An Old Party Takes On a New Look
description: These are not the days in which new charity parties are born, but there's nothing against a face lift that gives a new look to an old gala. And not only a new look but a new name. And not only a new name but a new location.

title: People and Business
description: Atelegram from Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's Ambassador to Iran, to the British Foreign Office apparently was the decisive factor in persuading the British Government to rescue the Chrysler Corporation's ailing British subsidiary last month.

title: Islanders Rally Tops North Stars, 4 to 3
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 27 Jean Potvin, New York Islander team historian, shook his head. I don't want to do that too often, he said. That wasn't in the game plan at all. The last time that happened was an exhibition game against the Rangers last season.

title: Merola Says Nadjari Has Ability toSmear
description: District Attorney Mario Merola snapped his fingers and said that Maurice H. Nadjari could ruin an individual's reputation just like that. Of course, he can smear me, the Bronx prosecutor said yesterday. He can ruin people in public office.

title: Business Briefs
description: United Brands Consents to Injunction

title: Orthodox Rabbis Rebuke Jews Who Back Permissive Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Leaders of American Orthodox Judaism criticized Jewish groups today for projecting what they held was a false image to the general public that Judaism sanctions abortion.

title: Stony Brook Triumphs
description: GREENVALE. L. I., Jan. 27 Earl Keith sank two free throws with 3 seconds remaining to clinch a 6662 victory for Stony Brook over C. W. Post tonight.

title: HOUSE OVERRIDES A VETO OF FUNDS FOR SOCIAL PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Democraticcontrolled Congress won today its first skirmish of the year with President Ford over Federal spending for social programs.

title: A Chateau Country With No Castles but Plenty of Wine
description: TARADALE, New ZealandThey call the Hawke's Bay area the chateau country of New Zealandnot because there are any castles, but because of the names that appear on the 10 million or so bottles of wine that are turned out here each year.

title: TEAMSTER FUNDS UNDER NEW AUDIT
description: The United States Labor Department has sent a team to Chicago to audit and investigate the Central States pension funds of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Cambodian Schools Remain Shut and Mood Is Hostile to Education
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Jan. 27 Lor Voeung Say has not gone to school since last April, the week before the Cambodian Communist forces entered Phnom Penh and the engineering school he was attending was closed.

title: Right Questions to Ask About Your Prescription
description: Nearly everyone has at some time left a doctor's office, prescription in hand, wondering about the medication he or she is about to take. What is it for? Exactly when should it be taken and for how long? What side effects might it cause? By asking the right questions when drugs are prescribed, the patient can do a great deal to protect his own be41th.

description: (Cont'd)

title: Quake Felt Off Oregon
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI)A strong earthquake centered off the coast of Oregon was recorded today by the University of California. It was centered 450 miles northwest of Berkeley about 180 miles offshore.

title: About Real Estate
description: There was a seminar on rent control in Washington two weeks ago at which one of the speakers was a youthful lawyer from California. A national tenants rights and reform movement is under way, he said, and rent controls are increasingly a part of it.

title: JUDGE IS INDICTED ON A BRIBE CHARGE
description: Ludwig G. Glowa, a Criminal Court judge for 24 years, was indicted yesterday on a charge of accepting a $500 payoff to fix a criminal court case. It was the first bribery indictment brought against a judge by a special grand jury hearing corruption cases developed by Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Roosevelt Entries
Moynihan Says State Department Fails To Back Policy Against U.S. Foes in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States representative at the United Nations, has sent a cablegram to the Secretary of State and all United States embassies saying that he is succeeding in breaking up the antiAmerican voting bloc in the United Nations but that the State Department does not realize this and is not supporting him.

title: A Christian Village in Lebanon Escapes Violence, but Inhabitants Are Wary
description: RMAILE, Lebanon, Jan. 27 At night, people in this largely Christian village get out their guns and wait in their living rooms or orchards for the looters.

title: Democrats Say Inquiry on Cunningham Hamstrings the Party's Organization
description: The special state prosecutor's investigation of Patrick J. Cunningham is casting a pall over Governor Carey and the state Democratic Party, in the view of Democratic politicians. They say it is jeopardizing the Governor's chances for the national ticket and embarrassing and hamstringing the party in the months before it plays host here to the Democratic National Convention.

title: People in Sports
description: Hal Wissel, coach of a Fordham five struggling with a 711 wonlost record, and Tom Penders, coach of also struggling Columbia (49), showed up at the basketball writers luncheon at Mamma Leone's yesterday and buried the hatchet. Both said they were sorry about the firsthalf brawl and nearbrawl in the second half that marred their Monday night game at the Rams Rose Hill gym, won by Fordham, 6557.

description: Theater

title: Note to Readers
description: The table for stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange now reflects the final prices, volumes and highs and lows of all those stocks on the regional exchanges and all offboard trading as well.

title: Open Interest
3 in Jewish Defense League Halt Soviet Pianist Here
description: Several members of the Jewish Defense League interrupted a recital by the Soviet pianist Arkadii Sevidov in Carnegie Hall last night by shouting, blowing noisemakers and releasing mice on the stage, the police reported.

title: Portuguese Caldo Verde
description: The same combination of kale. potatoes and sausages that make up the thick and hearty Dutch stew known as Stamppot van Boerenkool met Worst, also appears in Portugal in the lighter and more elegant soup. Caldo Verde. Plenty of pepper and spicy garlic sausage offset the soothing. blandness of potato and kale. 6 mediumsized boiling potatoes, about 2 pounds, peeled

title: Basic Instructions for Cooking Kale
description: Break stalks apart, discarding leaves that are brown, yellow, faded or bruised. Strip leafy portions from stems and ribs. Discard stems and ribs. Follow instructions in individual recipes as to whether the kale should be chopped or shredded before being cooked, or chopped after cooking.

title: Ford Meets With Rabin and Assures Him of Aid
HUMORTINGED LOGIC IN SOLOMONS DANCES
description: Words, motion, systems, scraps of music and welltrained dancers are Gus Solomons Jr.'s preoccupations. He combines them into structures that are tinged with emotion or humor but are always stringently ordered. At its best a work also allows a touch of the irrational to leaven the rigorous logic of its making. The company presented a selection of new and repertory pieces Monday evening at the the Cubiculo.

title: N.A.B. ASSAILS STUDY ON F.C.C. AND CABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) A Congressional report on cable television was attacked by the National Association of Broadcasters today as an effort to make the public pay for ententainment it now gets free.

title: AID TO ANGOLANS ENDED BY HOUSE IN REBUFF TO FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Brushing aside a lastminute plea from President Ford, the House gave final approval today to a Congressional cutoff of aid for two Westernsupported factions in the Angolan civil war. The vote was 323 to 99.

title: $1,776 Weekly Won For Life by Man, 26, In Jersey Lottery
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. A 26yearold North Arlington hair stylist today won the richest prize in any lottery in the nation's history.

title: Senate Confirms Bush as C.I.A. Director
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 27The Senate confirmed today President Ford's nomination of George Bush, now the chief American representative in China, to he Director of Central Intelligence.

title: ELLIOTT D. SMITH, 85, CARNEGIE PROFESSOR
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 Elliott Dunlap Smith, former provost and Falk Professor of Social Relations at CarnegieMellon University, died yesterday lat his home in New Haven. He was 85 years old.

title: Defeat on Angolan Aid
description: Defying a lastminute plea from President Ford, couched in global coldwar terms, the House of Representatives has voted even more emphatically than the Senate did last month to end covert American arms aid to two factions in Angola's civil war. The message from Capitol Hill seems clear: Congress will no longer sanction what might become an openended commitment to remote conflict where no United States interest has been established except that of thwarting the Soviet Union.

title: Patricia Hearst Faces 74 Being Screened for Jury
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27Patricia Hearst, apparent heiress to one of the world's great publishing fortunes, rose silently in a Federal courtroom here; today to face the 74 persons) from whom a jury will be chosen to decide her fate on bank robbery charges.

title: Thai Army Repels an Attack On Power Plant and Office
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Helicopter gunships of the Thai Army drove off 100 Communist supported guerrillas who staged a fivehour attack on a power plant and a district office in the northern province of Udon, the police there said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (UPI)The Soviet Union defeated the United States tonight, 43, in an amateur boxing match, the second straight Soviet victory of the fourmatch series. In the heavyweight feature, Yevgeny Gorshov defeated Woody Clark of the United States when the referee stopped the bout in the first round.

title: 2D JACKSON LINK TO C.I.A. REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Senator Henry M. Jackson advised Richard Helms, former director of central intelligence, on how to respond to Congressional questions on Watergate at a dinner meetig with Senator Stuart Symington early in 1973, according to Congressional sources.

title: Amex Prices Rise In Slowing Volume; OTC Ends Mixed
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished higher yesterday in active trading. Prices in the overthecounter market closed mixed.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: ALL ABOARD There's very little wrong with China Seas now except that this 1935 movie is usually run on television toward midnight or much later. You can see it tonight at 6:15 o'clock, with no commercial intrusions, aboard an anchored vessel, the St. John's Guild Hospital Ship, at the South Street Seaport's Pier 15, South and John Streets on the East River. The pieture is the third of 12 films with a briny theme being presented each Wednesday a program organized by the Seaport Museum.

title: Ford Nominates Two
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) President Ford announced today that he would nominate Richard G. Darman of Wellesley, Mass., to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Policy and Joseph B. Kasputys of Jamaica, Queens. to he Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Administration.

title: Nordiques 91 Victors
description: QUEBEC, Jan. 27 (AP)Tom Serviss scored three goals and had an assist while Marc Tardif added two goals and two assists to pace the Quebec Nordiques 01 rout of the Cincinnati Stingers in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: REP. HAYS CHIDES ELECTION AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Representative Wayne L. Hays threatened today to cut the guts out of the Federal El,iction Commission's budget if the agency continued to investigate anonymous complaints of campaign violations by members of Congress that occured before the commission was created.

title: Presidential Rivals Found in Good Health
description: This year's Presidential candidates, according to a survey or their medical records and physician statements, are generally in good health for men of their age, a national medical magazine reported yesterday.

title: Theater: Mamet's American Buffalo
description: David Ma met has a feeling for the contradictions that make up everyday conversaion, and, as a playwright, he knows how to convert what he hears into stage speech. His dialogue is not simply overheard, but it has the glow of reality.

title: Moynihan Says State Department Fails To Back Policy Against U.S. Foesin U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States representative at the United Nations, has sent a cablegram to the Secretary of State and all United States embassies saying that he is succeeding in breaking up the antiAmerican voting bloc in the United Nations but that the State Department does not realize this and is not supporting him.

title: March of Generations Assured on Suffolk Land Held Since 1661
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  There were no fireworks, no special merriment, when Vernon Wells Jr. observed the tricentennial of his family farm here 15 years ago.

title: CORRECTION

The Times regrets any adverse effects arising from the story.

title: About Education
description: The City Board of Education will seek changes in the state law on teacher seniority that could end some of the confusion and inequities that have plagued the school system ever since the city's fiscal crisis forced major cutbacks in educational programs and services.

title: Mazowsze Makes Folk Dance a Spectator Sport
description: When Mazowsze, the Polish State Song and Dance Company, finished its opening program last night at the Felt Forum, young women in different parts of the audience stood up and whirled their headscarves in the air in response to the dancers who were doing the same onstage.

title: U.S. Judge Blocks The Proposed Ban On a Food Coloring
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) A Federal judge, at the request of manufacturers, blocked today for 10 days the Food and Drug Administration's proposed ban on the nation's most widely used food coloring. Red No. 2.

title: LEGISLATURE GETS CONSUMER BILLS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27New York City sent its annual package of consumer protection legislation to the Legislature today, asking for 36 bills that would, among other things, permit lawyers, druggists and opticians to advertise the cost of their services and enlarge the rights of localities to enforce, consumer protection laws.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday it planned a public offering of common shares with additional details to be provided when it files a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Revolution Predated By 32 Farms in State
description: Following is a list of familyrun farms of New York that were founded before the Revolution. The list includes the location, the date founded and the present owners.

title: RICHARD CONGLETON, INSURANCE OFFICIAL
description: Richard J. Congleton, a for mer Essex County prosecutor and a retired insurance executive, died Monday at Tarpon (Springs, Florida. He was 70 years old and lived in Arlington. Va.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN AND SOYBEANS UP
description: Grain and soybean prices managed to show slight gains at the close of trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Birdmen of the Everglades
description: A recent report in this space told how four fugitives from Super Bowl X had stealthily made their way through the watery wilds of Everglades National Park to Flamingo at the southernmost tip of mainland Florida, there to commune with nature and forget Roman numerals, the Dallas flex defense and the fleshpots of Miami Beach. On the first communing day, the party divided in Whitewater Bay. Ludwig Johnson guided Tom Callahan of Cincinnati and Sandy Bain of New York up Shark River to Tarpon Bay, where they surprised and murdered several redfish and weakfish, known as speckled trout in Florida. Clint Jones took Jack Murphy of San Diego and his companion up near the headwaters of Roberts River to fight it out handtofin with the baby tarpon native those brackish waters. At the start of this century, when Flamingo was a nest of moonshiners, smugglers and fishermen, two families named Roberts occupied shacks on stilts there. Chances are the river was named for Uncle Billy Roberts, who was famous for his indifference to the bloodthirsty Everglades mosquitoes, which in summer are thick enough to plow. His tolerance of the critters was attributed to his habit of eating half a plug of Brown's Mule chewing tobacco at breakfast.

title: Princeton Beats Penn Again On Way to Ivy Title, 6952
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27Princeton probably won the Ivy League basketball title tonight when the Tigers beat Pennsylvania, 6952, even though the Men of Old Nassau have played only four of their 14 Ivy games.

title: Police Exam Is Found To Be Unfair to Women
description: NEWARK, Jan. 27 (UPI)The State Division of Civil Rights ruled today that a police examination that asks, Does your wife approve of you being a policeman? discriminated against women applicants.

title: CAREY APPROVES NADJARI INQUIRY INTO BRONX CASES
description: Governor Carey signed an order yesterday clearing the way for the promised investigation by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, of alleged political corruption in the Bronx.

title: City Cites 45 for Public Service
description: Their names read like a roster of the melting pot that is New YorkSpinelli, Ruiz, Chieng. Hill, Schildkraut and 40 others and yesterday they were honored by Mayor Beame and the Police Department for distinguished acts of public service.

description: 87:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Violin Concerto in A minor, Dvorak; Symphony No. 26, Haydn; Romeo and Juliet, Tchaikovsky.

title: BUSINESS GROUP URGES JOBS CODE
description: EVANSTON, III., Jan. 27A coalition of three dozen major business organizations called yesterday for adoption of a set of uniform Federal guidelines against job discrimination with some modifications.

title: Cook to Retire From American Electric
description: Donald C. Cook, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Electric Power Company, second only to the Governmentowned Tennessee Valley Authority as the largest producer of electricity in the country, announced yesterday that he would retire effective Feb. 19.

title: Record U. S. Trade Surplus Tops $11 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The United States recorded its largest surplus of exports over imports in history last year despite a drop in the monthly surplus in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Tashi, a Classical Success at Bottom Line
description: Tashi's twonight run at the Bottom Line that began Monday was, by and large, a nice musical success. More important, it was about as sensible an instance yet of a classical group reaching out to expand its appeal to a young audience primarily interested in rock.

title: For Cold Nights, Kale Dishes Like Those the Norsemen Eat
description: Kale weather, greengrocers say with a shiver as the mercury drops below freezing and they prepare to take in all fruit and vegetables from outdoor stands. All vegetables, that is, save this heartiest member of the cabbage family, with its winter green curly, ruffled leaves that not only. can withstand freezing temperatures but absolutely requires them. Kale, in fact, should not be cooked unless it has frozen at least once since that process tenderizes its otherwise tough leaves and mellows their sometimes bitter flavor.

title: Palestinians Assure Lebanon of Respect For Its Sovereignty
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it respected the sovereignty of the Lebanese, state throughout all Lebanon without exception.

title: Article 4  No Title
C.I.A. Ties to Journalists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27A draft copy of a report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence last week said that 11 fulltime officers of the Central Intelligence Agency were posing as journalists overseas in connection with their intelligence work. The report said further that until 1978 live agents posed as fulltime correspondents with organizations that have major general news impact. Moreover, the report said, some 15 news organizations had cooperated with the C.I.A. in providing cover for C.I.A. operatives.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Just by residing in the United States, the average person is exposed to a certain amount of unavoidable background radiation from naturl soaurces. But there are sources of radiation that can be avoided. among them unnecessary dental Xrays, which, not incidentally, also add to your bill.

title: H.E.W. IS TERMED SUBJECT TO FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27A House subcommittee said today that the 300 or so programs of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare were vulnerable to fraud and abuse because the department lacks the ability to investigate.

title: Rutgers Gets 16th in Row, Routs Pitt
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 27It took Rutgers's nationally ranked basketball team about 10 minutes to solve Pittsburgh's rugged pressing defense tonight in its home. Once that was done, the Scarlet Knights took off for a 10271 victory.

title: MADRID COUNCIL YIELDS ON VOTING
description: MADRID, Jan. 27The highly conservative Council of the Realm is reported to have reversed itself and given its approval to a Government move toward making the Spanish Parliament more representative.

description: The 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $900,000 mark with the receipt of $5,441 from 162 contributors. The total now stands at $901,510.09.

title: German Pinkelwurst Mit Braunkohl
description: Pinkelwurst, the special winter sausage favored in the SchleswigHolstein area of north Germany, includes onion, celery. whole grain oats, ground pork, fat, and all the seasonings necessary to flavor a pot of kale. Available at German sausage shops in Yorkville, the best in town is sold at Karl Ehmer, 230 West 86th Street and at several other locations around the city. It is one of those homey, homely. soulsatisfying dishes best reserved for family dinners.

title: Detroit Busing Plan Complete; Pupil Attendance Near Normal
description: DETROIT. Jan. 27 (UPI)More students came back to school today as Detroit completed a twostep busing inte2ration plan.

title: Sidney Howard Play Is Staged by Phoenix
description: This 23d season of the Phoenix Theater is being devoted, in this Bicentennial year, to revivals of American plays. At the most agreeable 500seat Playhouse Theater on 48th Street we had the opening of this repertory season with a double bill by Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller. Last night Sidney Howard's They Knew What They Wanted was introduced into the repertory. Later there will he productions of William Gillette's Secret Service and Boy Meets Girl by Bella and Sam Spewack:

title: ... Sanford Withdrawal
description: Former North Carolina Governor Terry Sanford meanwhile has withdrawn from the Democratic Presidential contest because his candidacy also failed to take hold. Those who know his record are understandably disappointed because Mr. Sanford is an executive of demonstrated competence, a serious man who understands national problems, and one whose qualities of character and imagination suggest that he would make a good Presidentif he could be elected.

title: Byrne May Bar Oil Equipment From Shore Areas
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Jan. 27Governor Byrne said today that New Jersey might bar from coastal counties the pipeline terminals and other onshore development that would accompany offshore drilling for oil.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Following is the text of a cablegram from Daniel P. Moynihan. the United States delegate at the United Nations, to Secretary of State Kenry A. Kissinger. and all American embassies.

title: 5,000 at Robeson's Funeral in Harlem
description: The themes of strength and struggle as expressed in this old black spiritual, Oh, When I Come to the End of My Journey sung by Delores Ivory Davis, were chosen by friends and relatives who paid their last respects last night at a funeral celebration for Paul Robeson.

title: Dr. Fannie Tomson Kogel. 71, ExCity Health Aide, Dies
description: Dr. Fannie Irene Tomson Kogel, a former assistant city health commissioner and associate professor of public health at New York Medical College, died yesterday at the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. She was 71 years old and lived in Wading River. L. I.

title: GrandJury Press Leaks Are Denied by Nadjari
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, turned up unexpectedly at the hearing of the State Commission of Investigation on grand  jury leaks yesterday and testified under oath that he had never leaked anything to the press.

description: ABC News, which has been striving for parity with the other networks for many years, on Monday forced the resignation of the executive who had been credited with revitalizing the Evening News with Harry Reasoner and with creating for the network a respected documentary unit.

title: Marion Javits Quits Role As a Consultant for Iran
description: Marion Javits, wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits, yesterday gave up her $67,500 consultant role on an Iranian public relations account and resigned her twoweekold salaried post as a senior vice president of the company involved, Ruder & Finn.

title: Lulu's Back
description: The daya of wine and roses may be over for state civil servants, who face a pay freeze and force reductions; for state agencies, most of which will receive reduced appropriations in Governor Carey's new balanced budget; for local governments throughout New York which have to learn to live with less state aid. But not apparently for members of the nation's highestpaid state Legislature.

title: Unfinished Hunts Point Pier Project Raises Questions
description: In the bottom of the East River at Hunts Point there is a 40foot hole that cost the city more than a million dollars.

title: Stenmark, 19, Captures Cup Giant Slalom Race
description: ZWIESEL, West Germany, Jan. 27 (AP)Ingemar Stenmark, a 19yearold frecklefaced Swede, turned in a brilliant second run today and won the final World Cup giant slalom race before the Winter Olympics and solidified his standing as a slalom favorite for the Innsbruck Games.

description: STAMFORD, Conn.  we first heard of Joseph Macaluso a few weeks ago pursuant to a column we wrote on Italian cookery, one that included a recipe for preparing a consummately good vegetable, a leafy green that is available but little known in America and much prized by Italians.

title: Today's Entries at Hialeah
To Courrges, It's Always 1963
description: PARIS, Jan. 27Some 15 years ago, when couture was couture, Andre Courrges and Emanuel Ungaro were .both plugging away at Balenciaga's place. You know about Balenciaga. One year he won the fashion Super Bowl, The next year it was Dior. Both always made the playoffs.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Treasury estimated today that its borrowing needs in the first six months o this year would be $38 billion to $43 billion and called this amount large but readily manageable.

description: Every year perhaps 30,000 Americans accept the drugs their doctors prescribe for them and die as a direct result. Perhaps 10 times as many patients suffer lifethreatening and sometimes permanent side effects, such as kidney failure, mental depression, internal bleeding and loss of hearing or vision.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The United States Postal Service, which drew strong criticism when it shut down photocopying services in hundreds of post offices around the nation at the end of the year, said today the decision had been wrong and that the service would be resumed.

title: INTERSTATE STORES LIFTS EARNINGS 17%
description: Interstate Stores Inc., which entered Chapter X proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act on June 13, 1974, announced yesterday 17 percent higher sales and 173 percent higher earnings for 11 months through Dec. 28, 1975 compared to the same to the same period in 1974.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was named yesterday tits chairman of the Office of Technology Assessment's advisory council. He succeeds Dr. Arnold Brown, president of the Caliifornia Institute of Technology.

description: Adamo lived up to his billing as the International Singer on Monday evening by filling Carnegie Hall with a heterogeneous crowd of avid fans.

title: Bridge:
description: An interesting initiative last year by the American Contract Bridge League seems to have ended in failure. Teams playing on the national level were encouraged to choose a team name, and pay a small fee for registering the name and using it in major contests.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Democraticcontrolled Congress won today its first skirmish of the year with President Ford over Federal spending for social programs.

title: Ford Meets With Rabin and Assures Him of Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Ford today assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel of continued American support, but he said it was urgent that further steps be taken to advance peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: Merola Says Nadjari Has Ability to Smear
description: District Attorney Mario Merola snapped his fingers and said that Maurice H. Nadjari could ruin an individual's ,reputation just like that. Of course, he can smear me, the Bronx prosecutor said yesterday. He can ruin people in public office.

description: Record earnings were reported yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1975 by the Union Pacific Corporation and the Southern Railway.

title: The Ik, Staged by Brook In London, Puzzles Many
description: LONDON, Jan. 27  The six actors thread over a stage covered with sand and broken stones and with wooden hut. They weep and chant. They laugh and gasp and play vicious games.

title: Pesticide Peril: Inaction and Ills
description: HOPEWELL, Va., Jan. 27In one of the more bizarre chapters in the annals of toxicology, 30 persons here have been hospitalized in recent months with tremors, .blurred vision, loss of memory and an as yet medically uncertain threat of sterility or liver cancer.

title: TV Review

Mounted superbly by New York's Negro Ensemble Company, the play was first produced Off Broadway, where it was very successful at the box office, and then on Broadway, where it failed within the cavernous recesses of the Palace Theater.

title: Food Prices Here Rise Again
description: For the second consecutive week food prices rose again last week in New York City, the cost of feeding a family of four increasing 1.1 percent after a 1.3 percent advance the week before ended a long period of compartive stability.

title: Article 2  No Title
Southern Exposure ...
description: Governor George C. Wallace's success in winning about 44 per cent of the delegates chosen in Mississippi's precinct caucuses hardly constitutes a significant triumph. If Mr. Wallace could not make a sizable showing in Mississippi with its barelyfaded heritage of racial repression and violence, he could not hope to do well anywhere.

title: CERRO HOLDERS SET TO VOTE ON MERGER
description: Stockholders of the Cerro Corporation will vote Feb. 24 on the proposed merger of their company with the Marmon Group Inc., which already holds 45 percent of Cerro. In announcing the special meeting in Chicago, Cerro said that proxy statements for the meetling are being mailed to stockholders of record on Jan. 22, 1976.

title: Quality and Cost of Car Repair Are Debated at Albany Hearing
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27The Senate Committees on Insurance Transportation and Consumer Protection heard charges and counter charges from representatives of the autorepair industry and auto insurers today, with each blaming the other for consumer complaints of shoddy repairs and high costs.

title: Gorman, Healthy, Is Winning Again
description: People can now stop asking, What happened to Torn Gorman?

title: WINE TALK
description: Books about wine usually are timed to arrive on the retail shelves in the fall because the assumption is that no one buys them, except as Christmas presents.

title: AID TO ANGOLANS ENDED BY HOUSE IN REBUFF TO FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Brushing aside a lastminute plea from President Ford, the House gave final approval today to a Congressional cutoff of aid for two Westernsupported factions in the Angolan civil war. The vote was 323 to 99.

title: City Council Disbands Parks Administration
description: Restructuring the first of the city's nine superagencies, the City Council passed legislation yesterday breaking up the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration into two separate departments.

title: Charges of Overpayment and Kickback In Buying Park Land Are Under Inquiry
description: TRENTON. Jan. 27  The State Commission of Investigation today began looking into charges that Middlesex County taxpayers had paid double the fair market value for parkland acquired in 1974 and that a county official had received kickbacks for awarding realestate appraisal contracts.

title: Con Ed Net Up 41%; Higher Rates Cited
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, the nation's largest investorowned utility, reported yesterday a 41 percent increase in fourthquarter operating earnings and increased its dividend almost to the level of two years ago.

description: Net income of the Gulf Oil Corporation fell 8.1 percent in the fourth quarter and 36.4 percent in the full year 1975, Jerry McAfee, Gulf's recently elected chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday.

title: Low Library Displaying Authors Letters to Cerf
description: Which paragraphs in James Joyce's Ulysses did a United States Attorney mark as obscene? What did William Faulkner think about journalistic invasions of his privacy? How did Ralph Ellison succinctly sum up the black experience in America? Do authors care how their books look? And how did many famous writers feel about their publisher, Bennett Cerf, and his company, Random House?

title: Books of The Times
description: As someone who makes his living by putting words together, I cannot finally fault these two guides to writing betterone of them, Simple & Direct, a quasitextbook by Jacques Barzun, who last year retired from a distinguished teaching career at Columbia University; the other, On Writing Well, based on a course taught at Yale by the popular journalist William Zinsser. Each of the books pro vides a useful checklist of warnings and prescriptionsstop usinab the illogical form of the adverb hopefully in such a sentence as Hopefully, he will undertake the project hopefully look up the true meaning of such words as escalate and preempt before you misuse them in any more sentences: learn to distinguish between repel and repulse, precipitate and precipitous, and compose and comprise.

title: U.S. Productivity Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Productivity in the American economy increased in the fourth quarter of 1975, but at a sharply reduced rate from the thirdquarter gain, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Algerians and Moroccans Said to Battle in Sahara
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 22 (AP)Algerian and Moroccan troops clashed today in their dispute dyer Spanish Sahara, and Moroccan officials said apparently there are many dead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Economics for People
description: The economic model of a nation is an abstraction with no particular virtue of its own. The economy must function to serve people; the needs of people cannot be manipulated to serve the interests of an abstract economic model. The only reason for restating these truisms is that the Ford Administration's economic policy skirts dangerously close to turning a seemingly obvious priority on its head.

title: Lilco Told to Aid Insulation
description: The Public Service Commission ordered the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday to submit a program of interestfree loans that would enable electricheat customers who converted from another fuel to insulate their homes to maximum efficiency and thus reduce their heating bills.

title: Equal Time for Voters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27In an appeal to the networks in this corner recently, it was suggested that they help raise the level of discussion in the Presidential campaign by submitting the major candidates to thoughtful and extended questioning on the major issues before the nation.

title: Last U.S. Ambassador in Saigon Defends Handling of Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Graham A. Martin, the last United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, said today that in the long run the final American evacuation of Saigon before it fell to the Communists would be judged as, a hell of a good job.

title: About New York
description: The only thing you can say about Staten Island is that it's there, an island sticking out into the Atlantic, a neocolonial outpost with only 4 percent of the city's population, a place where people from Brooklyn settle down.

title: TETLEY RESIGNS AS BALLET'S HEAD
description: BONN, Jan. 27Glen Tetley resigned yesterday as director of the Stuttgart Ballet, West Germany's most important company, after nearly two years of dwindling audiences and unfavorable critical comparison with his predecessor, the late John Cranko.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Prison Priority
description: Judge Morris E. Lasker recently ordered an end to the practice of keeping two inmates in a single cell the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island. Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm said he was shocked that the court did not give the city more time to provide single  cell occupancy. But the singlecell order coula certainly have come as no shock since a similar order had been entered in a Brooklyn case by Judge Orrin G. Judd eighteen months ago. The handwriting was even more clearly etched on the wall when the Court of Appeals for this circuit affirmed that ruling last summer, making it the law in this jurisdiction.

title: Burton to Join Equus Prices Will Be Raised
description: When Richard Burton begins a 10week engagement in Equus on Feb. 16 the top price for orchestra seats will he raised to $15 from $13.50. Other tickets will also go up.

title: $500,000 Awarded in Suit Against Doctor Who Died
description: A 32yearold Detroit woman was awarded $500,000 yesterday by a sixmember jury in State Supreme Court in Riverhead, L.I., in a malpractice suit against a physician who died in 1972. The suit was brought by Joanne Ward against the late Dr. Joseph L. Kovacs of Fire Island. L.I., for Si million, charging negligence in treating a hand, infection that ultimately required the amputation of four fingers on her right hand.

title: ProWest Angolan Units Leave Their Capital as Foe Advances
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 27 (UPI)  Angola's hardpressed proWestern forces have abandoned their administrative capital of Huambo in the center of the country, reports from the group said today.

title: Notes on People
description: California's state Supreme Court suspended Donald H. Segretti from law practice in the state for two years yesterday, rejecting his contention that his political tricks during the Nixon reelection campaign in 1972 did not involve moral turpitude. The court order, originally calling for a fiveyear suspension, was modified and Mr. Segretti was put on probation for the final three years. He was also ordered to pass the state bar's professionalresponsibility examination before resuming law practice.

title: LICE AM SCABIES ON RISE OVER U.S.
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 27 (AP)Head lice and scabies are afflicting more persons in the United States than at any other time since the end of World War II, the Center for Disease Control says.

title: S.E.C. DEFENDING ITS BANK POWERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Commissioner Philip A. Loomis Jr. of the Securities and Exchange Commission argued strongly to a House subcommittee today that the S.E.C. should retain its present jurisdiction over bank holding companies, banks and other financial institutions.

Although the U.S.S.R. is still a relatively weak economic force, especially in agriculture, its industrial, military and technological vigor are impressive.

description: NEW YORK AP) ( Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Stolle, 37, Nearly Upsets Ache
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27Tennis stars like to declare that any one of them on any given day can beat anybody In the world. For a while at the United States professional indoor championships, Fred Stolle might have thought that this was his day.

title: Italian Gang Gets $200,000
description: ROME, Jan. 27 (Reuters)Bandits firings machine guns seized 600 pay envelopes for postal employees containing nearly $200,000 at a Rome post office early today, the police said.

title: ICELAND AND BRITAIN END FISHING TALKS
description: LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Talks between Prime Ministers Harold Wilson and Geir Hallgrimsson on the fishing dispute between Britain no land ended here tonight and informed British sources the two leaders had reached the makings of a possible solution.

title: Grossi Ending 40Year Career
description: NEWARK, Jan. 27Anthony J. Grossi, president of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners who is ending four decades of political life and public service on Friday, said goodbye today to a handful of reporters in his office here.

title: GULF REDUCES PRICE OF GASOLINE 1 CENT
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it was lowering the price of it; gasoline by 1 cent a gallon because of market conditions.

title: CARSON TESTIFIES IN OWN DEFENSE
description: Robert C. (Sonny) Carson testified at his murder trial here yesterday that he did not order the slaying of two Brooklyn men and that he did not even learn they had been shot until he read a newspaper.

title: Nets Get Eakins; Trade 2
description: DENVER, Jan. 27  The New York Nets traded Swen Neter and Billy Schaeffer to the Virginia Squires today for Jim Eakins, a sevenyear veteran of the American Basketball Association who has done most of his playing as a reserve center.

title: U.S. General in Iran Ousted; Reportedly Too Abrasive
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The head of the United States military mission to Iran has been removed because he was too abrasive, accord ing to Defense Department sources.

title: Con Ed Net Up 41%; Higher Rates Cited
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, the nation's largest investorowned utility, reported yesterday a 41 percent increase in fourthquarter operating earnings and increased its dividend almost to the level of two years ago.

title: British Rental Car Ran 2 Years With Hidden I.R.A. Explosives
description: LONDON, Jan. 27For two years a rental car with explosives and ammunition hidden in door panels and intended for Irish Republican Army guerrillas was driven about unwittingly by 60 or more customers.

title: Alampi Says Processors of Food Can Be Rescued
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27New Jersey's $100millionayear vegetableprocessing industry remains in danger but can possibly be saved, State Agriculture Secretary Philip Alampi told delegates to the annual State Agriculture Convention here today.

title: U.S. STEEL PROFIT DECLINES BY 33.8%
description: The nation's largest steelmaker, the United States Steel Corporation, reported yesterday a 33.8 percent decline in net income for the fourth quarter and a drop of 11.2 percent for the full year 1975.

title: AIRPORT SECURITY STUDIED BY F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The Federal Aviation Administration is studying procedures for airport baggage security that could delay passengers for as much as three hours, John L. McLucas, the agency's administrator, said at a news conference today.

title: TAXFREE BONDS SHOW STRENGTH
description: The tax  exempt bond market, which has been moving toward lower interest rates almost without interruption since early November, showed substantial strength yesterday. Florida sold a big issue of bonds that underwriters priced generally to yield half a point, less than New Jersey bonds marketed early in January, and two Long Island communities found Wall Street firms much more eager to bid for their bonds.

title: St. Peter's Five Notches No. 500
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27St. Peter's College posted its 500th victory by taking an 8367 decision over East Carolina tonight.

title: $1,776 Weekly Won For Life by Man, 26, In Jersey Lottery
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 27A 26yearold North Arlington hair stylist today won the richest prize in any lottery in the nation's history.

title: Music: Dominant Cello
description: Nathaniel Rosen is a virtuoso cellist of a sort audiences love to idolize and other cellists gather around to hear in mingled appreciation and envy.

title: Japanese First on Games Scene
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 27 (AP)The Olympic Village opened its doors to athletes and Games officials today, and word spread quickly that visiting rules for men and women competitors were not nearly so strict as the.Austrian hosts initially said.

title: Alice Crimmins Works As a Private Secretary
description: Alice Crimmins, who is serving a 5to20year sentence in state prison for the murder of her 4yearold daughter in 1965, is working as a secretary for private concern in Queens as part of a prison workrelease program. She will be eligible for parole this fall.

title: BIG POPULATION CUT PLANNED FOR SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (UPI)The new civilian ad: ministration here, in what it says is a program to improve the lot of Saigon's residents, plans to reduce the city's three million population by onethird this year.

title: Article 1  No Title
Market Place
description: Mutual funds have never been set up for the purpose of investing in municipal bonds, but the Investment Company Institute is pressing for a change in the tax law to make it possible.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Woman, 70, Last of Her Family on Farm Dating to 1671
description: KINDERHOOK, N.Y.Jans Martense Van Aelsteyn and his wife, the former Dircke Harmense, bought several thousand acres along the Kinderhook Creek here in 1671 for 70 good and whole and merchandable beaver skins.

title: Lebanon: The Flourishing Cedar Splintered
description: NZARETH, IsraelI doubt if Lebanon has ever occupied so much of our thoughts here in Galilee as it does today.

title: Ford's Steady Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27The economic report of the President, in spelling out the case against policies to promote a more rapid recovery despite the persistence of what Mr. Ford himself calls too high unemployment, has posed what is likely to be the major issue of the 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: Argentina Gives Civil Workers a 40% Pay Increase
South Africa Invites U.N. Angola Inquiry
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27South Africa proposed today that'the Security Council send representatives to Angola to determine whether a threat to peace there was caused by South Africa or by Soviet and Cuban intervention.

title: Marion Javits Quits Role As a Consultant for Iran
description: Marion Javits, wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits, yesterday gave up her $67,500 consultant role on an Iranian public relations account and resigned her twoweekold salaried post as a senior vice president of the company involved, Ruder & Finn.

title: Rumsfeld Calls for More Funds, Citing Increasing Soviet Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27Donald H. Rumsfeld opened his case today for a $100 billion defense budget with the argument that this country must increase its military spending to offset the growing military strength of the Soviet Union.

title: MAX DAETWYLER. 89, SWISS PACIFIST, DIES
description: ZITMIKON, Switzerland, Jan. 27 (AP)Max Daetwyler, the swiss pence apostle who preached against war in Red Square and marched from New York to Washington in a crusade for disarmament. died yesterday of pneumonia. He was 89 years old.

title: Italian Cavolo Riccio Affogato
description: Although the authoritative Italian dictionary published by Garzanti calls kale cavolo riccio (curly cabbage), it is also known as verdura riccia (curly greens) or as verza, a name that in some provinces of Italy is also used for Savoy cabbage. By any name, it is cooked affogatoliterally suffocatedin a bath of garlicperfumed Olive oil.

title: Beware The Meter
description: Nov, there is not the least reason to believe that electricity exerts any better moral influence than gas, and we know that when a number of reasonably Christian men form themselves into a gas company they immediately become pirates of the most merciless and extortionate character.

title: Beanie Deplores Albany's School Bill
description: Mayor Beame warned state legislative leaders yesterday, that the basis of the city's threeyear austerity plan would be destroyed by a billnow moving swiftly toward passage mandating that a fixed proportion of the city budget funds must be allocated to education.

title: Award Recipients
Ballot Changes Sought in State Primary
description: A suit has been filed in Fed eral District Court here to require the state's April 6 primary ballot to list the Presidential preferences of candidates seeking to be delegates at the Democratic National Convention.

title: Dorothy Gatchell. 71. Dies; Designed Air Force Flag
description: CAMDEN, Me., Jan. 27Dorothy Glendenning Gatchell. an artist who desgined the Air Force flag. died in a nursing home here Sunday. Miss Gatchell, who was 71 years old, retired from the Air Force in 1957 as heraldic consultant after 26 years of service.

title: Deaths
Integration Plan Is Ruled Valid at Forest Hills High
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the legality of the Central Board of Education's zoning plan for Forest Hills High School in Oueens.

title: The Pop Life
description: The American tour of the Who begins its second leg March 9 in Boston, continues the next night to Madison Square Garden, and winds up March 27 and 28 in the 5,100scat Winterland Auditorium in San Francisco.

title: Jewish Veterans Keep Ban on Mexico Trips
description: The Jewish War Veterans, disagreeing with 31 other American Jewish organizations, reaffirmed yesterday their boycott on travel to Mexico because of the Mexican Government's support last Nov. 10 of a United Nations General Assembly resolution linking Zionism with racism.

title: V. W.  Henderson Dead; Economist and Educator
