description: Vivian Wilson Henderson, president of Clark College in Atlanta and one of the country's few black economists, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Infirmary in Atlanta during open heart surgery. He was 52 years old.

title: NURSES IN HAWAII STRIKE OVER PAY
description: HONOLULU. Jan. 28All except one of Honolulu's seven ;major hospitals were picketed today by registered nurses who walked out after rejecting increases in wages and fringe benefits that management said were worth $420 a month.

title: Fewer in the City Working As Job Total Mounts Here
description: The number of jobs in New York City increased slightly in December, although fewer city residents worked here or elsewhere, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

title: Carey Opposes, Beame Supports Jersey Offshore Drilling Leases
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 28Governor Carey of New York today urged postponement of Federal plans to lease land off New Jersey to oil companies that want to drill, while Mayor Beame of New York City urged prompt offshore oil production.

title: Ford Acts to Overcome Problems in Primary Campaign in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Ford, responding to severe organizational problems in his Florida campaign, made tentative plans today to stump the conservative state twice before a crucial contest March 9 with Ronald Reagan in the Republican Presidential primary.

title: Chess
description: Ljubomir Ljubojevic held the lead with 3 points after five rounds of the 38th Hoogoven International Tournament in WijkaanZee, the Netherlands. After three straight victories, the Yugoslav grandmaster's pace was slowed in the fourth round by a draw with Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland in a 16move Queen's Gambit. Ljubojevic adjourned his fifthround contest with the United States champion, Walter

title: A Rocket Orbits 8 Cosmos
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today used a single rocket to put into orbit a cluster of eight satellites believed to be for use in naval communications. The press agency Tass said that the new satellites, Cosmos 791 to 798, were circling the earth every 115.6 minutes at an altitude of Up to 956 miles.

title: NYQUIST ASSAILS EDUCATION TRIMS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, predicted today that many school districts would face awful hard times if Governor Carey's proposed $110 million cut in education spending went through the legislature.

title: Esposito Backing Jackson, A Major Boost for Senator
description: Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, endorsed Senator Henry M. Jackson's Presidential candidacy yesterday and gave the Senator a major boost in New York State, which he has labeled a key to his aspirations.

title: Lord &
description: Lord & Taylor, one of New York's major stores, will spend $3 million to $5 million in the next eight months to remodel its main floor and renovate four upper floors in its 60  year  old Fifth Avenue store. Lord & Taylor, which has 21 stores, is the largest division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

title: Job Reversal Urged
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, former Federal Reserve Board Governor, called for reversal of the trend that finds blacks to a greater extent than whites, dependent on public jobs. Page 53.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate confirmed Anne L. Armstrong unanimously yesterday as the nation's first woman Ambassador to Britain and Northern Ireland. The action was by voice vote after Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Democratic majority leader, spoke to commend President Ford for an excellent appointment.

title: Oil Producer Listed 20.4% Fall in  75
description: Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California fell 24.3 percent in the fourth quarter and 20.4 percent for the full year of 1975.

title: 2 PARTIES ASSAILED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The executive director of the National Urban League said today that although President Ford had not mentioned the plight of minorities in his State of the Union Message, the state of black Americans is worse. in many ways a lot worse, than before.

title: MoscowSupported Force in Angola Reported Poised Before Key Targets
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 28Forces of the Sovietsupported Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola are reportedly within striking distance of two critical positions held by the rival Angolan factions.

title: James F. Donnelly, Lawyer, Former Official of Port, 67
description: James F. Donnelly of 160 Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, L. I., a senior partner in the New York and Washington law firm of Barnes, Richardson & Colburn, died Monday while. vacationing in Sydney, Australia. He was 67 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD BLOCKS AID FOR SUBURBS
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 28In a case brought by the City of Hartford, a Federal judge here today enjoined the Federal Government from giving approximately $4 million in community development funds to seven of Hartford's relatively affluent suburbs.

title: Geneva Arms Talks Reopen With Reports of Progress
Late Score Tops Leafs, 32
Washington Post Dissidents Seek to Replace Guild With Own Union
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 More than 400 members of the Newspaper Guild at the Washington Post, who have stayed at their jobs in defiance of threatened disciplinary action by their union during a fourmonth strike by mechanical workers, moved today to quit the Guild and form an independent union.

title: 8 Satellites Launched
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Soviet Union has launched eight satellites in the cosmos series aboard a single rocket, the Tess press agency said. It said that the satellites. Cosmos 791 to 798, would be used in outer space research.

title: RECREATION PARK ON S.I. IS DROPPED
description: Faced with nearunanimous community opposition, the developer of a proposed $40 million amusement park in the Bulls Head section of Staten Island abandoned their plans yesterday and began looking for another site, most likely, in New Jersey.

title: Essex Judge Gavels Down the Old JuryDuty Excuses
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28You are hereby summoned to appear at the Superior Court of New Jersey, at the Essex County Courts Building, Room 410, Newark, New Jersey, to serve as a petit juror.

title: 73 City School Buildings Face Closing by Next Fall
description: Eight schools that were built before the turn of the century and 33 others that are more than 50 years old are among 73 city school buildings that face possible closing next fail by the Board of Education.

title: 400 Choristers Sing in Tribute To Thomas Pyle at a Memorial
description: Thomas Pyle was a man whose name was unknown to most concertgoers, but yesterday afternoon some 400 of his friends came together in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine to sing Brahms's A German Requiem at a memorial service for him.

title: Weyerhaeuser Earnings Rose 35.8% Other Concerns Report
description: The Weyherheauser Company, the largest factor in lumber and wood products, and major producers of pulp, paper and containers, reported yesterday an increase of 36.8 percent in fourthquarter earnings, the first gain in a year and a half. Annual earnings were down 31 percent from 1974 on a 4 percent dip in sales.

title: Carey Opposes, Beame Supports Jersey Offshore Drilling Leases
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan, 28Governor Carey of New York today urged postponement of Federal plans to lease land off New Jersey to oil companies that want to drill, while Mayor Beame of New York City urged prompt offshore oil production.

title: Bodies of 3 Women and Girl, 4, Found In West 49th St. Tenement Apartment
description: The decomposed bodies of three women and that of young girl were discovered by the police yesterday along with two starving German shepherd dogs in an apartment at 438 West 49th Street.

title: Dr. Simon Pasternack. 61. Physicist. Journalist. Dies
description: Dr. Simon Pasternack, a physicist who served for many years on the editorial staff of Physical Review, a scholarly journal, died Monday of heart attack at his home, 8 Namkee Road, Blue Point, L.I. He was 61 years old.

title: TEXACO RAISES PPICF FOR RESIDUAL FUELS
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it had increased the prices of residual fuels to all classes of trade in varying amounts ranging from 10 cents to 45 cents a barrel, depending on sulfur content. A company spokesman said the increases ranged from less than 1 percent to about 3 percent.

title: Defense Gets Help
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28In an unusual action today, Judge Oliver J. Carter of Federal District Court moved selection of the jury in the Patricia Hearst trial into a locked courtroom, where the only witnesses besides prosecution and defense attorneys were her parents, a sister and the wife of F. Lee Bailey, Miss Hearst's chief defense counsel.

title: Celtics Turn Back Hawks by 11099
description: BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP)John Havlicek and Charlie Scott led a balanced Boston attack tonight with 17 points each and the Celtics erupted for 69 points in the second half to defeat the Atlanta Hawks, 11099, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: ANNA BAUM SKANE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 28 (UPIAnna Baum Skane, president of the Bridgeport Board of Education and a member of the Swimmers Hall of Fame, died yesterday of cancer. She was G8 years old.

title: Concert
description: The Juilliard String Quartet, which celebrates its 30th birthday this year, has changed personnel gradually but completely since being founded as the school's chambergroupinresidence. Yet, the streamlined performance style and standard of excellence that were noted early in its history continue to prevail.

title: Churches, Angered by Disclosures, Seek to Bar Further C.I.A. Use of Missionaries in Intelligence Work
description: American churches and mission boards, reacting indignantly to admissions last fall by the White House and the Central Intelligence Agency that overseas missionaries have been regularly used in information gathering, are mounting a drive to stop such practices through governmental action and improved internal safe guards.

title: Morocco and Algeria Continue Battle in Sahara
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Moroccan and Algerian troops were engaged in. heavy fighting in Spanish Sahara today for the second day, a Government communiqu said tonight.

title: Aqueduct to Dash Into Action
description: Operation Mudpack was in full progress at Aqueduct yesterday as New York Racing Association officials continued with their plans to reopen the Queens County thoroughbred track with a ninerace program this afternoon.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The World Bank announced today its first loans under the newly established third window, which provides loans at a subsidized interest rate.

title: Indian Museum, Under State Orders, Is Taking Inventory
description: Gina Laczko, until two week ago a theatrical costumer taking courses in anthropology at the New School, and Gary Galante, an undergraduate anthropology student at Hofstra University, began counting granite arrowheads, rawhide Blackfoot war shirts, Cheyenne moccasins, Ecuadorian pottery shards, Kiowa buckskin drums and feathered Commanche war shields yesterday as the Museum of the American Indian started an inventory of its fourmillionpiece collection.

title: Speculators Move cocoa Futures Up, Potato Pacts Down
description: For the third time this week speculators trading moved two markets by the daily limits in opposite directions. Cocoa futures for March delivery jumped up 2 cents to close at 69.35 a pound on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Potato futures dropped by the limit of cent a pound to close at 15.15 in terms of the May delivery, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: TV Review
description: The time may have arrived for the Norman Lear factory to close down and take serious stock of its product. The machine may be overworked. No matter how well One Day at a Time may be doing for CBSTV in the ratings, the character of he older daughter is an abrasive drag. No matter how many sophisticated excuses are proffered for the deadpan monotony of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, the syndicated series is tedious in extended doses. And now, on NBCTV at 9:30 on Wednesdays, the hastily concocted product is The Dumplings.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He arrived in New York nearly a decade ago as Walt Frazier, from Southern Illinois, a guard who would grow in stature as the Knicks did. Soon his stature included a lifestyle that befitted his nickname of Clyde, bestowed because he wore flashy clothes that resembled those in the Bonnie and Clyde motion picture. And he lived flashily, a millionaire bachelor in an East Side pad with a big round bed and a mirror on the ceiling and a RollsRoyce in the garage. He even rented two parking spaces so the Rolls wouldn't he scratched. Now that's cool. He was cool on the basketball court, too, never changing expression. Clyde Cool, some people called him. And when Willis Reed and Dave DeBusschere retired, he emerged as the symbol of the Knicks and the captain. Earl Monroe was the magician, Bill Bradley was the mind and when Spencer Haywood was acquired this season, he was the muscle. But there was nobody quite like Clyde, who had scored more points than anybody in the Knicks history. Not that it meant much now because last month the Knicks had an 819 record. But that's when Clyde reverted to being Walt, as Spencer Haywood says. And of all the explanations for the Knicks turnaround as a 500 team now with a 2424 record, that is the most descriptive and the most discerning.

title: Cuts in State and U.S. Aid Scored by Caso and Klein
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Jan. 28The County Executives of Nassau and Suffolk agreed today that costs mandated by the Federal and state governments and cuts in aid had contributed greatly to the adverse economic plight of residents of Lone Island.

title: Ford and Kissinger Give Assurances to Moynihan
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28The White House and the State Department today publicly reassured Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the United States representative at the United Nations, of their support and approval.

title: Sabres Tied by Rangers, 33; Islanders Win on Stewart Goal
description: Playing with a sort of nervous desperation, the Rangers gained a 33 tie last night with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Senate Panel Endorses Usery for Labor Office
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) President Ford's nomination of W. J. Usery Jr. as Secretary of Labor was approved overwhelmingly today by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.

title: Beame Asks Law to Aid Investments in the Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mayor Beame told the Senate Foreign. Relations Committee today that Federal tax laws, which he said favored foreign investments, should be changed to encourage domestic investments, particularly in our central cities.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: ... and Campus Inflation
description: In his budgetary approach to higher education, Governor Carey proposes to place greater emphasis on opportunities for individual students and less on institutional support and to narrow the tuition gap between public and private institutions. Unfortunately, the measures by which those goals are to be achieved directly contradict one another.

title: Byrne Details His Reorganization Plans
description: TRENTON, Jan, 28Governor Byrne's plan to reorganize the state government would place enormous economic power in four of his subordinates and would give the Governor More direct control of the state's 55,000 employees, according to details of the plan that he unveiled today.

title: HARTFORD BLOCKS AID FOR SUBURBS
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 28In a case brought by the City of Hartford, a Federal judge here today enjoined the Federal Government from giving approximately $4 million in community development funds to seven of Hartford's relatively affluent suburbs.

title: Books of The Times
description: One million children run away every year, according to informed sources, and Christine Chapman, an English teacher and mother of two teenage sons, spent three years trying to find out why. She traveled around the country interviewing runaways, their families, their friends, the police, and various public and private agencies. In America's Runaways, she tells us what she found. She also tells us what she feels, and sometimes the two are difficult to separate.

title: Middlesex Paid Too Much For Land, Appraisers Say
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28  Two realestate appraisers hired by the State Commission of Investigation to review appraisal reports that allegedly led to the payment of double the fair market price for parkland in Middlesex County, testified today that the reports were patently defective and did not accurately describe the properties.

title: All in the Family: II
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In our last episode, readers were left breathless by revelations of an interlocking directorate of Old Kennedy Hands who set up the Church committee staff. in way that makes easy the rover up of abuses of power in the sixties.

title: Simon and Wall Streeters Try to Block Antitrust Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In response to complaints from key Wall Street figures, the Administration is considering withdrawing support for a major section of antitrust legislation pending in the Senate.

title: Riders Get Timetables for D Trains
description: Where is that D train anyhow? Now there's an answer. IND subway riders on the D line hetween Coney Island and 205th Street in the Bronx are the first to receive pocketsized time tables with maps designed to show when D trains can he expected at any of the 41 stops along the line.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Newark Board of Education unanimously appointed Stanley Taylor to a threeyear term as the first ,executive superintendent of New Jersey's largest school system. The new position, which carries an annual salary of $47,000, is part of a reorganization plan mandated by a bill signed into law by Governor Byrne last Aug. 4. It replaces the longstanding tripartite administration of the school system, which was formerly run by a superintendent, business manager and secretary. Mr. Taylor, a former Brooklyn school superintendent, was named head of the Newark school system in May 1973, and has served as acting executive superintendent since the new law took effect. Since that time, his policies have frequently been at odds with those of the Board of Education.

title: DUBLIN TAXES RISE ON CONSUMER ITEMS
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 28 (Reuters)The severest Irish budget in years was presented today. It sharply increased taxes in the republic on gasoline, cigarettes, beer. wines and liquor.

title: Article 79752171 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4 30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI.DAY: NEW JLRSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO (515) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800, CONNECTICUT (203) 3417767.

title: Enlarging the Dial
description: The tough report on the suppression of cable television by the Federal Communications Commission, which has just been issued by the staff of the House Subcommittee on Communications, contends that the F.C.C. hasn't caught up with the new cable technology and continues to favor conventional overtheair broadcasting.

title: Sandvik of Sweden to Buy 2 MIlion Disston Shares
description: Disston Inc. of Pittsburgh, a manufacturer of hand and garden tools, said yesterday that it had been advised by the Swedish steel company, Sandvik A.B., that the Swedish concern planned to buy about 2 million of Disston shares at $13 a share.

title: Leading Indicators Index Rose 0.4% for December
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4 percent in December and was virtually unchanged for the final quarter of 1975, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Red Cross Drive Director Is Named
description: A former Ford Motor Company executive and onetime head of the United States Bureau of the Census has been named chairman of the 1976 community appeal of the American Red Cross in Greater New York. The drive seeks to raise $7.8 million.

title: Bethlehem Net Off 37.8%; Socal Profit Drops 24.3%
description: The nation's second and ninth largest steelmakers reported yesterday declines in sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and for 1975.

title: Kaunda Assumes Emergency Powers, Citing Threats to Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 28 (Renters)  President Kenneth D. Kaunda declared tonight that his Government was assuming widespread emergency powers to counter any moves to destroy our country.

title: Ford Ousts a Housing Aide In Interest Conflict Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Ford has asked for and received the resignation of H. R. Crawford, assistant Secretary for Housing Management, who is the subject of an inquiry by the Justice Department into possible conflict of interest violations, the White House disclosed today.

title: Esposito Backing Jackson, A Major Boost for Senator
description: Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, endorsed Senator Henry M. Jackson's Presidential candidacy yesterday and gave the Senator a major boost in New York State, which he has labeled a key to his aspirations.

title: Trainers Prefer A Southern View
description: MIAMI, Jan. 28The travails encountered by New York racing this week have elicited little sympathy from trainers at Hialeah.

title: Soaked Pollution Records Sent for a FreezeDrying
description: The bulk of the city's airpollution control records were shipped by refrigerator truck to Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon in what Ethan C. Eldon. Commissioner of Air Resources. said was a race against timewe're right up to the danger point.

title: Reagan for Economic Slowdown As a Method of Curing Inflation
description: TILTON, N. H., Jan. 28Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, campaigning for the Republican nomination for President, told a small audience at the Town Hall here today that the remedy for inflation was an economic slowdown.

title: Prices for Bonds Rebound On Demand for U.S. Notes
description: The credit markets reacted yesterday to news that the Treasury would borrow $2.5 billion next weekan amount larger than generally expected, and most fixedincome prices declined early in the day. As deal ers discovered heavy demand for the Treasury's new sevenyear 8 percent notes, however, bond prices rebounded and some corporate bond issues closed higher than they last traded on Tuesday.

title: Slain Kennedys Called Most Dangerous Men
description: DALLAS, Jan. 28 (AP)John and Robert Kennedy were two of the most dangerous men America ever produced, William M. Kunstler, the radical lawyer, said yesterday, adding that he was not entirely upset by their assassination.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF; OPTIONS DECLINE
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished lower yesterday as profit taking weakened both lists.

title: Brimmer Urges Reversal On Job Trend by Blacks
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, a former member of the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors, yesterday called for a reversal of the trend that finds blacks, to a much greater extent than whites, dependent on the public sector for lobs.

title: SENATE APPROVES A 200MILE LIE ON FISHING RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Senate voted 77 to 19 today to broaden the United States fishing jurisdiction to a distance of 200 miles of the coasts beginning in July 1977.

title: State Drug Chief Who Quit Is Retained for Transition
description: Anthony Cagliostro, who resigned last month as head of the state's Office of Drug Abuse Service following criticism, is continuing on the payroll as a consultant to the agency at or near his old salary, according to a spokesman for Governor Carey.

title: 6 IN RULING COUNCIL HELD IN ETHIOPIA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Six members of Ethiopia's governing military council have been arrested, the state radio said today.

title: DEALERS RELEASE EMERGENCY FUEL
description: NEWARK, Jan. 28The State Energy Office announced today that the recent period of extreme cold and lowerthannormal temperatures for the month had necessitated the release of about onethird of the 15 million gallons of heating oil held for emergency purposes.

title: India's Legislature Moves to End Council Setting Press Standards
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 (AP)The lower house of Parliament adopted legislation today abol abolishing Indian's 10yearold Press Council and ?? immunity for persons reporting, on Parliamentary proceedings.

title: Open Interest
Notre Dame Studying Problems Remaining After Vietnam War
description: A study of continuing problems of Vietnam war veterans, deserters and draft evaders is under way by the University of Notre Dame's Center for Civil Rights with a $225,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: 4 to 5% Economic Growth Is Seen in West Germany
description: BONN, Jan. 28West Germany is now in economic recovery and will achieve a to 5 percent real economic growth rate in 1976, according to a Government report published today.

title: Simon and Wall Streeters Try to Block Antitrust Bill
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28In response to complaints from key Wall Street figures, the Administration is considering withdrawing support for a major section of antitrust legislation pending in the Senate.

title: House Rules Unit Votes to Block Release of a Report on the C.I.A
description: WASHNIGTON. Jan. 28 (UPI) The House Rules Committee, In a stormy session, voted to 7 today to block release of the House Intelligence Committee's report on the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence agencies until President Ford could see if the report contained unauthorized security material.

title: Sutton Tells Jury Carson Has Excellent Reputation
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan testified yesterday at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson that Mr. Carson's reputation for integrity was excellent.

title: 2 Stone Age Factory Sites Are Uncovered in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Tan. 28 (Reuters)British archeologists have found the remains of Stone Age factories at two sites along the Indus River in Pakistan's southeastern Sind Province, the newspaper Dawn has reported.

title: The Randolph Hearsts Are Bitter and Angry at Outside World
description: bitterness and anger at the outside world that they feel has betrayed them by failing to understand or sympathize with the plight of their daughter. They also are apparently resentful of the power structure to which they belong because, in the echelon of wealth and authority where they have lived their lives, they suspect Patty is now viewed as a criminal instead of a kidnapping victim.

title: Gerulaitis Bows at Net
Costly School Politics ...
description: Despite all denials, Governor Carey's proposed $110 million cut in operating aid to local school districts sounds suspiciously like a bargaining card for higher state taxes. For those districts already at or near the austerity level of school financing, the reduction in state aid makes higher local property taxes the only alternative to curtailed educational services. The threat of such local tax rises may well be intended to make higher state taxes more palatable.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
Thomas French of Chicago Led Psychoanalytic Institute
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) Dr. Thomas M. French, director of the Chicago Institute of Psychoanalysis, died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: A Changed Family
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan, 28The Hearst family here is very different now from what it was in the days before Patricia Campbell Hearst was kidnapped on the night of Feb. 4, 1974.

title: Full Schedule Planned By Botanical Garden
description: The New York Botanical Garden, dosed to the public Mondays through Fridays this month as an economy measure, will return to its sevendayaweek schedule Monday with a lull calendar of events.

title: 57 BEST FILM LISTSMORE THAN ANY OTHER MOVIE!
GOLD
description: Solected world gold prices Wodnesday.

title: Veterinarian Accused ha a Malpractice Case
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28 (AP)A Yardville veterinarian has been charged with malpractice for allegedly refusing to treat a kitten because its young owner had no money.

title: Uninsured Jobless
description: The State of New Jersey's intention to borrow $:100 million from the Federal Government this year keep its overstrained unemployment insurance fund from going broke is dramatic evidence of the crushing burden joblessness is putting on employers, who pay the taxes to support the Federalstate job benefit system.

title: Advertising
description: Using television to reach chief executives and chief operating officers of major corporations may seem like a terribly wasteful exercise, but that is exactly what Chemical Bank is planning with Marsteller Inc., its new agency for corporate and international advertising.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Piano Concerto No. 1, Beethoven; Sintonia for Flute. Oboe, Cello and Harpsichord, Fux; Iberia, Debussy.

title: CUNNINGHAM WRIT BACK IN SPOTLIGHT
description: The focus of the question of alleged political corruption in the Bronx swung back yesterday to the effort by Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, to quash subpoena ordering him to testify before a grand jury.

title: MRS. OLCOTT H. DEMING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Louise MacPherson Deming. wife of Olcott H. Deming, a retired diplomat, (lied Monday, apparently of a heart attack at her home here. She was 59 years old.

title: MunicipalState Relationship Returns to an Old Issue: The City U.
description: The new. chronically desperate. relationship between the city and state governments, while oriented for the last year around revenue notes, credit ratings and other arcane elements of the fiscal crisis, has be gun to return to such encrusted traditional issues as state aid and the City University. Now pending before the Emergency Financial Control Board, the state panel, headed by Governor Carey, that supervises the city's fiscal reform, are the questions how to cut the budget of the resistant City University by $34 million and who should wield the ax.

title: How to Report a Doctor
description: To report a doctor who may be unfit to practice medicine, complaints should he sent to the following state licensing agencies:

title: Market Place
description: Some observers believe that this omnth's bill market, the strength of which has surprised many Wall Street veterans, may be getting an undue assist from stock exchange specialists.

title: Audits Reducing Shortcomings of Hospitals
description: Nearly half the nation's hospitals have begun systematically to review their surgical cases to improve the quality of patient care, detect incompetence and decrease the number of unnecessary operations.

title: Bridge:
description: The defender who knows when to play the wrong card at the right time is an exponent of a difficult artlying. He has to be careful not to deceive his partner, and sometimes an illjudged lie will give more help to the declarer than an honest card would be.

title: Tribal Leader Is Defeated in Election On Troubled Pine Ridge Reservation
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D., Jan. 28The president of the Oglala Sioux Indian Tribe was defeated in a federally supervised election yesterday by a career administrator who has promised to bring peace to the troubled Pine Ridge Reservation.

title: Press Club Bomb Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (Reuters)Several thousand people were evacuated for an hour today from the National Press Building, headquarters of most of the capital's major news bureaus, because of a bomb threat. A search failed to turn up any sign of a bomb in the 13flor building.

title: ARMY CHIEF BALKS AT OFFICER RECALL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffman refused to day to recall to active duty thousands of career officers who had been dismissed from service as a result of improperly convened military promotion boards.

title: TV Review
description: The time may have arrived for the Norman Lear factory to close down and take serious stock of its product. The machine may be overworked. No matter how well One Day at a Time may be doing for CBSTV in the ratings, the character of the older daughter is an abrasive drag. No matter how many sophisticated excuses are proffered for the deadpan monotony of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, the syndicated series is tedious in extended doses. And now, on NBCTV at 9:30 on Wednesdays, the hastily concocted product is The Dumplings.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: GILBERT KINGAN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 28 Gilbert Kingan, retired Unit eel States manager of the London and Lancashire Insurance Company of Liverpool. England, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at I Putnam Hill.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Agents of the State Department of Taxation seized 3.000 cartons of cigarettes lacking state tax stamps and arrested three men at a store at 1404 Zerega Avenue, the Bronx. Alfred Donati, director of the department's Special Investigation Bureau, idenutied those arrested on charges of possessing contraband as Thomas Consagra, 65, of 11866 Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens; Anthony Speranza. 19. of 3739 59th Street, Woodside, and David Tobin, 20, of 4433 41st Street, Sunnyside, all in Queens.

title: DeepDiving Submersible Prepares to Explore Submarine Cliff
description: ABOARD THE RESEARCH VESSEL LULU IN THE CARIBBEAN, Jan. 28'Our business is going under says a motto on the deepdiving submersible Alvin for whom the catamaran Lulu is mother ship. But a test dive has confirmed the principle that to go down deep it is sometimes necessary to take a leaf from those who go very high.

title: People in Sports
description: Jim Peterson, the Georgetown University sophomore who ran a sensational 4:00.9 mile at Dartmouth two weeks ago, has been added to the Wanamaker mile field in the 69th annual Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. Peterson's, time was the best in Georgetown history.

title: Westinghouse Reports Profit in Quarter
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation. one of the nation's major manufacturers of electrical equipment, reported a 1975 fourth quarter profit of $54 million, or 62 cents a share. in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $76.1 million. During the latter period the company, which is the nation's leading maker of nuclear reactors, recorded a $90 million loss on disposition of discontinued businesses and operations of discontinued businesses.

title: Music: Sevidov's Debut
description: Arkadi Sevidov, a very gifted 27yearold Soviet pianist, made his New York debut on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall under difficult circumstances. Three times, people identifying themselves as members of the Jewish Defense League attempted to disrupt the recital to protest the Soviet Union's treatment of Jews. Three demonstrators were arrested.

title: ASSEMBLY MOVES ON POLICE BADGES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28A bill that would allow municipalities to issue official replicas of policemen's shields to retired policemen passed the Assembly today despite warnings from several legislators from New York City that the replicas could fall into the wrong hands and be abused.

title: Ford and Kissinger Give Assurances to Moynihan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The White House and the State Department today publicly reassured Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the United States representative at the United Nations, of their support and approval.

title: F. D. A. Issues Two Recall's and Rescinds a Third
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration, in a series of actions, announced today the recall of nearly 2,000 dental Xray machines and more than 7,800 cases of canned chilies, but reversed itself on the largest recall of television sets in history.

title: Dress Union Threatens Strike If There Is No Pact by Monday
description: The president of the Interna tional Ladies Garment Workers Union, Sol C. Chaikin, said yesterday that employers in the dress industry had failed to make any wage offer to the union in current negotiations and warned that there would be a strike next Monday if there were no settlement.

title: LEBANON ORDERS A RETURN TO JOBS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 28The Government today ordered all civil servants to report to work tomorrow as the ceasefire held, and the Lebanese Army began taking up positions in the charred seafront hotel district, the ruined downtown sections and the port.

title: Argentine Policeman Slain
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  A policeman was killed and another wounded in a guerrilla attack in a suburb of Buenos Aires today, the police said. Three passersby, two of them children, were wounded in the attack in which guerrillas fired on a police car from a moving pickup truck.

title: RABIN RULES OUT ANY NEGOTIATION WITH P.L.O. HEADS
description: WASHINGTON, Jun. 28Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel told a joint session of Congress today that while his Government was ready for further negotiations with any Arab state, it would not drop its refusal in cooperate in our national suicide by meeting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: STRATFORD, CONN., MAY LOSE STAGE
description: The American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., one of the country's largest theatrical institutions, says that it will have to close its doors April 1 if $300,000 is not raised in the next 10 weeks.

title: Article 3  No Title
The Bennett Mystery
description: First, a little Watergate quiz: Who was Howard Hunt's employer at the time of the Watergate breakin?

title: Cooperation Breeds Optimism for A.B.A.
description: DENVER, Jan. 28  The American Basketball Association owners and players disbanded today after their ninth annual AllStar break, trailing plans and optimism for the future of the league.

title: ... and Communist Gains
description: The most critical issue, however, is the political future of Italy, where the Communists made extraordinary gains last year, corning within two percentage points of the ruling Christian Democrats. Under Enrico Berlinguer, the Italian Communists not only claim to be democratic and independent of Moscow, but have criticized the power drive of Portugal's Communists and expressed sympathy for the Soares Socialists.

title: Long Day's Journey Into Greatness
description: Of all the playwrights of the 20th century it seemsnow that the clouds are clearingthat Eugene O'Neill is so far very possibly the greatest. Such evaluations are not all that meaningfulafter all what is your favorite flower?  yet, as time goes on, the reputation of O'Neill obviously expands rather than diminishes.

title: Europes Socialist Split...
description: Gains by Communist parties in southern Europe from Portugal to Greece and their steppedup drive for governmental role in Italy, France and possibly Spain, find West Europe's powerful Socialist movement deeply divided over what to do. Few problems facing the member states of the Atlantic alliance are more urgent or perplexing.

title: Defense Gets Help
Yesterday's Results at Hialeah
description: MIAMI

title: COST OF POTATOES SOARING IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, Jan. 28The price of Europe's ubiquitous staple, the humble potato, has been soaring.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Piano Concerto No. 1, Beethoven; Sinfonia for Flute, Oboe. Cello and Harpsichord, Fux; Iberia, Debussy.

title: Pulp Mill Plan Splits New Hampshire Town
description: WALPOLE, N. H., Jan. 25Should a huge, $200 million paper pulp mill be built on farm land in this quiet, picturesque village along the Connecticut River?

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: SMILE AWHILE New Yorkers will have a chance starting tonight to see three performances of The National Lampoon Show, a comedyrevue with a cast of five young people, written by the editors of the humor magazine. The show began a tour of the United States and Canada last fall and so far has played more than 100 onenight dates at colleges and universities.

title: CHILE SETS RIGHTS FOR THOSE ARRESTED
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 28, (AP)Chile's ruling military; junta, which has been under international pressure for alleged violations of human rights, issued a law tonight establishing legal guarantees for persons arrested by security forces.

title: People and Business
description: A Chicago banker said yesterday that the nation:s banks have worked with their troubled customers instead of calling loans and setting off a chain of foreclosures and bankruptcies that would have plunged the country into a major depression.

title: Congress Approves Billto Aid Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Congress overwhelmingly passed today a compromise $6.4 billion railroad aid bill and sent it to the White House where it is expected to get a friendly reception.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: FORD ECONOMISTS BACK JOB POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The opening hearings by the Congressional Joint Economic Committee into the state of the economy and the Government's program produced today mainly a partisan dispute over the problem of unemployment.

title: Games Construction Can't Finish in Time
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP) Construction of the main stadium and adjoining swim hall for the 1976 Olympics will not he completed by the scheduled opening of the Summer Games, but officials said today they would be able to hold competition in the two facilities.

title: SENATE MOVES A 200MILE LIMIT ON FISHING RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Senate voted 77 to 19 today to broaden the United States fishing jurisdiction to a distance of 200 miles off the coasts beginning in July 1977.

title: 160 Feared Dead in Burma
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 28 (AP)About 160 people were believed drowned in the sinking of a ferryboat after it and fishing trawler collided in the Andaman Sea off southern Burma Monday night, the Government newspaper, Working People's Daily, reported today.

title: LISBON RESTORES PAPER TO OWNERS
description: LISBON, Jan. 28It wasn't much of a newspaper and couldn't say very much, but for almost half a century the little tabloid Republica stood as a symbol of opposition to Portugal's rightwing dictatorship.

title: Madrid Outlines Reforms, But the Reception Is Cool
description: MADRID, Jan. 28Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro outlined today his Government's longawaited program of political and other change for postFranco Spain, promising to move toward a Spanish democracy that copied no others.

title: Madrid Outlines Reforms, But the Reception Is Cool
description: MADRID, Jan. 28Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro outlined today his Government's longawaited program of political and other change for postFranco Spain, promising to move toward a Spanish democracy that copied no others.

title: Elderly in Arizona Town Fight to Keep Children Out
description: YOUNGTOWN, Ariz., Jan. 23  The Welcome sign that greets newcomers here says Youngtown.

title: All States Drop Smallpox Vaccinations
description: Smallpox vaccination is now almost as extinct as the disease the immunization was designed to prevent.

title: Slopes Dripping With Promise Despite Heavy Rains
description: Almost all of the Northeast's ski areas were taking steps yesterday to repair the damage done by the recent heavy rains that drenched slopes and trails in Pennsylvania's Poconos and most of New York and New England. Maintenance crews at such northern Vermont retreats as Jay Peak, Stowe and Middlebury, however, had the task eased by a sizable snowstorm early yesterday that deposited up to a dozen inches.

title: Farmingdale Center Cuts His Recruiting Whirl Short
description: When the recruiting season blooms in early spring, Jim Graziano should be an observer, not a participant. The 6foot9inch center from Farmingdale, L.I., has signed a scholarship letter with the University of South Carolina and vows that the Gamecocks are his final choice.

title: CANCER TOLL RISE IN 75 A MISTAKE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The apparent dramatic increase in the nation's cancer death rate Is the first seven months of 1975 resulted from vagaries of data and does not reflect a real disease trend, Government experts said today.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES
Police Lieutenant Here Accused Of Altering Test to Aid Brother
description: A police lieutenant and his brother, a police sergeant, and a newsstand they bought are the subjects of an investigation growing out of a 1973 Civil Service test for lieutenant.

title: Saint Laurent: The Theme Is Mannish
description: PARIS, Jan. 28  Quietly, without hijinks, Yves Saint Laurent had himself another of his nice little triumphs today. Almost effortlessly, it seemed. He simply tunes into the mood of the times and reflects it in uncomplicated clothes. Mostly separates.

title: Dance: Loving Giselle
description: Each performance of Giselle serves only to further Natalia Makarova's status as the premier interpreter of the role currently. Her happy partnership with Mikhail Baryshnikov at American Ballet Theater on Tuesday evening provided a performance that will be hoarded in memory and taken out from time to time for loving reexamination.

title: SUPPLIES SHRINK IN HOMEFUEL OILS
description: Supplies of distillate oil, which are chiefly used for home heating, dropped sharply last week, the second consecutive significant decline. Severely cold weather in many sections of the nation was the principal reason for the drop. Distillate stocks fell to 183.44 million barrels in the week ended Jan. 23 from 193.2 million barrels in the Jan. 16 week and 212.89 million barrels in the Jan. 24 week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: FRESNO, Calif.  Bobby Chacon, 133 pounds, Sylmar, Calif., knocked out Gene Prado, 131, Mexico, 5 rounds.

title: Schaefer Tells Why It's Leaving City
description: High labor and energy costs and a long list of taxes that are either unique to New York City or higher here than elsewhere were cited by the F. & M. Schaefer Corporation yesterday at a City Council committee hearing into why the company is moving its brewing operations from Brooklyn to Pennsylvania.

title: Richardson Says He Does Not Think Nixon Pardon Was Right
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Elliot L. Richardson, who resigned as Attorney General rather than obey President NixIon's order to discharge Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox, said today that he did not believe that Mr. Nixon should have been pardoned.

title: RABIN RULES OUT ANY NEGOTIATION WITH P.L.O. HEADS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel told a joint session of Congress today that while his Government was ready for further negotiations with any Arab state, it would not drop its refusal to cooperate in our national suicide by meeting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Texas Company Is Speeding Monitors to Sinai
description: DALLAS, Jan. 28On Jan. 16, a $16.5 million contract was awarded to the Dallasbased electronics and aircraft systems company, ESystems Inc., to install and maintain the sensoring devices that will monitor the Sinai buffer zone between the Egyptian and Israeli forces.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Highways Commissioner Anthony R. Ameruso declared a pothole emergency in New York City following a threeday weather cycle that ranged from belowfreezing temperatures to the mid50's on Tuesday, and ordered repairs made.

title: OPEC SETS UP AID OF $800 MILLION
description: PARIS, Jan. 28Finance Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to establish an $800 million fund, less than had been expected, to aid poor countries.

title: 7 CITY FOOD PLACES TERMED VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department cited seven food establishments yesterday as violators of the Health Code, It also released the results of final inspections at nine previously cited places. including four that were closed because of failure to correct violations. All are restaurants. The list follows:

title: Jobless Rolls at 12.6% In State in December
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28Joseph A. Hoffman, Commissioner of the Department of Labor and Industry, announced today that the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for New Jersey dropped to 12.6 percent of the labor force in December from 13.4 percent in November.

title: Marjorie Greenbie Dead at 84; Wrote About American History
description: Marjorie Barstow Greenbie, a popular author of books one the art of living and American history and an early advocate of equal rights, died yesterday lat the Westgate Manor Nursling Home in Bangor, Me. She was 84 years old and lived in Castine, Me.

title: ORTHODOX RABBIS INVITE THE YOUNG
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The American Orthodox rabbinate expressed sharp concern today that young Jewish intellectualsparticularly those of Orthodox persuasionhad isolated themselves from the mainstream of the organized Jewish community.

title: MARKET ORDERLY IN PROFIT TAKING
description: Orderly profit taking continued in the stock market yesterday, sending prices lower for the second straight session. Meanwhile, corporations continued to report generally, favorable profits for 1975, exceeding Wall Street estimates in some instances.

title: CORE Director Will Urge Veterans to Fight in Angola
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  A black American civil rights leader said today that he was returning home to encourage black American veterans of Vietnam to go to Angola to fight on behalf of the Westernbacked National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

title: Pakistan. Under Bhutto's Strong Rule, Shows Signs of Progress
description: ISLAMABAD. Pakistan, Jan. 24Four years after its humiliating defeat and dismemberment, Pakistan is showing surprising signs of recovery.

title: A Changed Family
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan, 28The Hearst family here is very different now from what it was in the days before Patricia Campbell Hearst was kidnapped on the night of Feb. 4, 1974.

title: SENATE OVEIRIDES SOCIAL FUND VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Senate followed the House today in voting to override President Ford's veto of a $45 billion social funds measure for two Federal departments in the first election year test of Republican support for the Administration's economy drive.

title: PARTY POLL PACED BY MISS MYERSON
description: Only Bess Myerson could defeat Ramsey Clark, according to a series of hypothetical matchups for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York. The matchups were made in a poll commissioned by the Democratic State committee, according to politicians who say they are familiar with the results.

title: State U. Trustees Delay Action Against Nyquist
description: The trustees of the State University of New York decided yesterday to delay legal action that had been threatened against Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist in a dispute over efforts to close clown two doctoral programs at the State University Center at Albany.

title: Jersey's Battle Royal
description: Princeton's basketball team has developed into one of the best long fieldgoal shooting teams in recent seasons, and Rutgers into one of the fastest and most durable. When the Tigers and Scarlet Knights meet Monday night at Princeton it may be something like the artillery on the hill vs. waves of cavalry riding up from the valley

title: USE OF MARIJUANA IN TEST IS QUERIED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Justice Department has asked the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to review its decision to sponsor a study of the effect of marijuana upon human sexual response.

title: Teamster Evades Questions
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28 (UPI)A reluctant Teamster witness ducked in and out of a Federal grand jury room 117 times today. The government prosecutors have been attempting to get him to talk about the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, former head of the Teamster Union. After the last appearance, Marshals returned Stephen A. Andretta of Little Ferry, N. J., to the prison cell he has occupied for 48days after being cited for contempt. Most times, he has remained inside the jury room for one minute or less.

title: Daytona Defender Has New Problem
SENATE OVERRIDES SOCIAL FUND VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The Senate followed the House today in voting to override President Ford's veto of a $45 billion social funds measure for two Federal departments in the first election year test of Republican support for the Administration's economy drive.

title: Two Nations Withdraw
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 28 (AP)Denmark and Andorra have pulled out of the 1976 Winter Olympics, reducing to 36 the number of participating nations, Austrian organizers said today.

title: Open Season on Potholes Is Declared
description: The city's Highways Commissioner. Anthony R. Ameruso, declared a pothole emergency yesterday lowing a threeday weather cycle that ranged from belowfreezing temperatures to the mid30 on Tuesday.

title: Columbia Wins Swim
description: The Columbia swimming team beat St. John's yesterday for the first time in five years, turning back the Redmen, 7043. Although the Lions captured the Metropolitan Conference Division I championship last year hey had never defeated St. John's in a dual meet since joining the conference.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Bird Dogs Follow in Path Of PoliceTaught Owners
description: What does a policeman do in his spare time?

title: Personal Finance: Estate Planning
description: Owners, partners and stockholders of closely held business, particularly small businesses, are often concerned about estate taxes after death. In many instances, the bulk of a businessman's or investor's assets is comprised of his interest in the business, which cannot or should not be quickly liquidated.

title: Harry Blumenstein Dead; Demanded the 7th Precinct
description: Deputy Inspector Harry Blumenstein, commanding officer of the Seventh Precinct on the Lower East Side, died of pneumonia yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J. He was 57 years old and lived at 2755 West Fifth Street, Brooklyn.

title: Critic's Notebook: Arts And Attitudes in Canada
description: OTTAWA  The Chteau Laurier is a fine old hotel in the heart of this capital city, with big rooms, big beds, big desks for visiting journalists to slump on while embroidering generalizations about the Canadian mind, and ice machines that work if you need any ice when the temperature outside is 15 degrees below zero. One view is of the river. Another is of the new National Arts Center. which cost the Canadian Government $46.5 million to create, and which receives an annual federal subsidy of more than $7 million.

title: Spain's South Talks of Poverty, Not Politics, but Communists Make Gain.
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Jan. 28Unusually cold winter winds are blowing across the dusty, droughtstricken fields of southern Spain, and the destitute tenant farmers and day laborers of the region are paying little attention to Madrid politics.

title: Frustration
description: WASHINGTONRecent disclosures of our yearlong involvement in the Angolan civil war raise serious questions about Congressional oversight of foreign policy, particularly, the conduct of covert operations.

title: Memorial Srruires
description: HOPPERVincent F. Memorial service will be held Feb. 3, 5.30 P.M. at N.Y. University Maison, Francaise, 16 Washington Mews.

title: In Pursuit Of Folly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28In recent weeks the Ford Administration has been arguing, in all possible forums, that a President must have broad discretion to use the Central Intelligence Agency for covert operations. It has argued with particular emphasis that the operations must be kept secret.

title: Reilly's Lawyers Bring Three Brothers Into Case
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn.. Jan. 28 Lawyers seeking a new trial for 20yearold Peter Reilly began presenting evidence here today that they contend will link three brothers to the brutal murder of Mr. Reilly's mother, Barbara Gibbons.

title: Stereo TV Is Urged as Aid to Sound and Language
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) Home television sets could provide stereo sound and multichannel sound for nonEnglish speaking viewers and other services if manufacturers, broadcasters and transmission suppliers worked together, the acting head of the White House Office of Telecommunications policy said today.

title: Few Doctors Ever Report Colleagues Incompetence
description: Although incidents of careless and incompetent medical treatment are known to almost every physician, officials of medical societies and state licensing agencies say that relatively few doctors ever report them to the appropriate regulatory body.

title: Elderly in Arizona Town Fight to Keep Children Out
description: YOUNGTOWN, Ariz., Jan. 23  The Welcome sign that greets newcomers here says Youngtown.

title: U.S. Has Little Influence On How Doctors Practice
description: Although many people assume that the Federal Government plays a major role in regulating healthcare delivery, Washington actually has very little influence over doctors and the way they practice.

title: U.S. Initials Treaty With Canadaon Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Officials of Canada and the United States initialed today a draft treaty that would commit each government not to impede the flow through pipelines of oil and natural gas destined for the other country.

title: Clippers Name Reardon
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP) Terry Reardon, who coached the Baltimore Clippers to their first American Hockey League division title In 1971, took over the team's coaching chores again today. Reardon, also the Clippers general manager, replaced Kent Douglas, playercoach for the first 46 games of the season. Douglas will remain as assistant coach and defenscman.

title: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST

title: Special to The New York Them
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29A Public Service Commission examiner has recommended a temporary increase in the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity rates to help the company sell at least $60 million in bonds late this year.

title: HOUSE PREVENTS RELEASING REPORT ON INTELLIGENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The House of Representatives acceded tonight to the wishes of President Ford and the intelligence agencies and voted to withhold the final report of its Select Committee on Intelligence until it had been censored by the executive branch.

title: SALES GAINS HOLD AT CHAIN STORES
description: December's high volume of retail sales has continued into the new year, according to figures released yesterday by the country's leading chain store organizations.

title: Rep. Jones is Guilty of Failing To Report Receipt of Donation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In the second criminal conviction of a member of Congress this week, Representative James R. Jones, Democrat of Oklahoma, pleaded guilty in Federal court here today to a misdemeanor charge of failing to report receipt in late 1972 of a cash contribution of between $1,000 and $2.000.

title: What the Initials Mean
description: In addition to M.D., for Doctor of Medicine, a physician may list one or more of the following abbreviations after his name indicating that he has satisfied the professional requirements of a specialty college.

title: 13 STRIKE BLAMED IN 20 DEATHS HERE
description: As many as 20 persons died as a result of a nursinghome strike here in November 1973, according to a report released yesterday by the City Health Department.

title: U.S. Weighs Aid to Lisbon
description: LISBON, Jan. 29The United States is studying an aid package to Portugal that could total $200 million over the next 18 to 20 months, it was announced here today. The aid would be for social projects, particularly health, housing and education.

title: A DELAY IS SOUGHT IN HAMMER'S PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Two heart specialists reported today that the millionaire industrialist, Armand Hammer, would be unable to plead guilty to Federal campaign law violations for at least six weeks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP)Peter Gregg, plagued by mechanical trouble throughout practice, solved his problems today long enough to win the pole position for the $100,000 24 Hours of Daytona endurance race, which starts Saturday at 3 P.M. Gregg, a Jacksonville (Fla.) Porsche dealer codriving a factorybacked B.M.W with Brian Redman, lapped the 3.84mile Daytona International Speedway road course in 1 minute 56.55 seconds for an average speed of 118.61 miles an hour.

title: Bennington College President and Husband Resign
description: The Bennington College trustees last night accepted the resignations of the school's 32yearold president and her husband as vice president, ending months of controversy over the couple's efforts to restructure the small, innovative Vermont college.

title: Homelite Moves Account To a Carolina Agency
description: The Homelite division of Textron, which is very big in chain saws, recently moved its corporate headquarters to the Carolinas. Now it's moving its advertising down there as well.

title: Senate Vote to Extend Fishing Limit to 200 Miles Could Bring Global Changes
description: A wide continental shelf that extends for as much as 500 miles off the North Atlantic coast of the United States is the latest staging ground for a jurisdictional battle that is enveloping the world fishing industry.

title: KATHARINE DUFFIELD
description: Katharine Duffield, who retired in 1955 as campus representative of the Student Christian Movement of the Episcopal Church, died yesterday at her home in Orange, N. J. She was 87 years old.

title: DOCTORS ON COAST RENEW INSURANCE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29Facing the dilemma of risking, costly lawsuits or paying malpractice insurance premiums 327 percent higher than last year's, most southern California doctors decided to be safe and renewed their policies at the higher rate before the midnight deadline.

title: Births
description: PILO??? Michelle, In Greenville, 5.C., on January. 28, 1976 to Jacauelynne Z. and Mervin R. Pilo.

title: GOVERNOR EASES STAND ON PCB'S
description: Governor Carey, overruling his Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, has decided not to force the General Electric Company to stop completely its discharge of the toxic chemicals called PCB's into the Hudson River.

title: Staley Talks With Esmark On Buying Soybean Interest
description: A.E. Staley & Company of Decatur, Ill., reported yesterday that it was in a meaningful stage of talks with Esmark Inc regarding possible acquisition of Swift & Company's soybean processing interests. Swift is a subsidiary of Esmark.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Front Page 3  No Title

title: What About Moynihan?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Ford Administration is in a pickle about how to handle Daniel Patrick Moynihan, its ambassador at the United Nations, but it has nobody to blame but itself.

title: Carey Assails Lefkowitz For Decision on Nadjari
description: Governor Carey charged yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz had failed to check closely the justification for Maurice H. Nadjari's expanded investigation of corruption in the Bronx and had thus opened the investigation to legal challenge.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS U. S. IS WEIGHING OPEN ANGOLAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the Ford Administration is now seriously considering open financial aid totwo Angolan factions fighting a Sovietsupported nationalist movement.

title: McDonnell Douglas Lifts 4th Quarter Profit But Year Falls
MOROCCO REPORTS VICTORY IN SAHARA
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 29Morocco said tonight that it had achieved a victory in its campaign against Algerianbacked guerrillas in Spanish Sahara and Algeria reported it Was withdrawing all its own tloops from the area.

title: Advertising
description: Integration  the integration of account people with creative peopleis coming soon to the New York office of J. Walter Thompson.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Bayh Accuses Carter of Raising False Hopes of Abortion Foes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.29Senator Birch Bayh charged today that Jimmy Carter, the former Georgia Governor who is also seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, was raising false hopes among opponents of abortion by suggesting that there was a legislative solution to the problem.

title: EDWARD M. FURNESS
description: Edward M. Furness, president of the Reserve Mining Company, a producer of taconite, a lowgrade iron ore, from 1967 until his retirement last year, died Wednesday in Silver Bay, Minn. He was 64 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Ford's coolness about the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) for what he views as its costliness to industry and its relative ineffectiveness could easily have come from an Orwellian world of government.

title: Plaza Hotel Seeks to Open Basement Movie Theater
description: Donald Rugoff, the theater operator, and the Plaza Hotel have requested permission from the Landmarks Preservation Commission to open a 212seat movie theater in the basement of the landmark hotel on Central Park South.

title: Refugees Report Chaos in North Angola
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 29Portuguese settlers fleeing to this city report chaotic conditions and a mass exodus from a small corner of northwesternmost Angola that remains in the hands of the Westernsupported National Front for the Liberation of Angola.

title: About New york
description: Meade H. Esposito was in Tiro a Segno, a private club on MacDougal Street, addressing himself to cherrystone clams and old recollections. These are generally bad times for political bosses in New York, but Mr. Esposito, who says he fears no man, was feeling expansive. Mr. Esposito runs Brooklyn.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State. Henry A. Kissinger testified before the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Africa yesterday and said that the Administration is now seriously considering open financial aid to two Angolan factions fighting a Sovietsupported nationalist movement. He said the overt assistance would have to be considerably larger than the $32 million sent the two groups covertly by the United States last year. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: PRISONER AT R1KERS IS 2D SUICIDE IN 76
description: A 30yearold prisoner hanged himself with a bedsheet in his room at the Mental Health Center on Rikers Island yesterday afternobn, according to the Department of Correction. It said the man was transferred to the special facility last week because of bizarre behavior.

title: State Prohibits M.T.A. From Making More Cuts in Bus and Subway Service
description: The State Transportation Commissioner, Raymond T. Schuler, told the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to desist immediately from any further reductions in bus and subway service here.

title: Boat in Bangladesh Sinks
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  A river boat with 300 people on board sank today after striking a submerged wreck on the Meghna River. The number of casualties was not immediately known.

title: Coast Guard Chief Retires
description: Capt. James L. Fleishelb took over as new Coast Guard ??? mander for New York's busy harbor, replacing Capt. Frank Oliver, who retired, at ceremonies on Governors Island.

title: Rome Rules Tango Obscene
description: ROME, Jan. 29 (UPI)Last Tango in Paris was ruled obscene today and its producer, director and stars were sentented to two months each int prison. The ruling from the high court was the final verdict in a case that began almost three years ago against the movie, its producer, Alberto Grimaldi; director, Bernardo Bertolucci, and stars; Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider. They will be subject to arrest Id they show up in Italy. Each was fined $40 and assessed $132 in court costs.

title: FORD DISAPPOINTS MAYORS ON FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29More than 100 Mayors chine here today, most of them to tell President Ford what they needed and to react to his recent budget proposals, which some Mayors said offered little that was new and dramatic for cities.

title: Common Market Endorses Greeks on Tentative Basis:
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 29 (Reuters) The European Common Market Commission today endorsed a request from Greece to join the community, but proposed preparatory period before full membership.

title: REAGAN ENDS TOUR IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 29Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, winding up a campaign swing throngh New Hampshire in his quest for the Republican nomination for President, said today that a Presidential nominee had the duty to select as a running mate a man who shared his political philosophy.

title: Spouses of Judges Free to Participate In Political Activity
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  The State Supreme Court agreed yesterday to let the spouses of New Jersey judges partictpate in politics, thereby reversing a 28yearold sale intrpduced as part of 4. statewiaa judicial reform.

title: A Vico Sampler
description: It is a matter for astonishment that there should be so many ignorant persons when ignorance or being misled or falling into error is as repugnant to the mind as smoke is to the eyes, or a foul stench to the nose.

title: A Hearst Jury This Week Held Unlikely
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29United States Attorney James L. Browning Jr predicted today that Patricia Hearst's trial jury would not be finally chosen until Monday.

title: FORD AND RABIN END DISCUSSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel wound up his talks with President Ford today with a reported understanding that the United States would try to see if the Geneva conference on the Middle East could be reconvened without the direct participation of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Ruling May Speed Fed Data Release
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29A ruling by a Federal judge raised the possibility today that the monthly decisions on monetary policy of the Federal Reserve System's key Open Market Committee might have to he made public on the day of the committee's meetings instead of 45 days later, as is now the practice.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: COMMUNITY SERVICE SOCIETY OF NEW YORK. 105 East 22d Street, New York, N.Y. 10010.

title: Market Place
description: Most discussions of mutualfund sales charges speak routinely of an 8 percent rate. Robert Weston, a vice president at Hugh Johnson & Company, a New York Stock Exchange Member firm, believes that this is misleading.

title: TV: Danny Thomas Stars in The Practice on NBC
description: The star is Danny Thomas. The producer is Danny Thomas Productions in association with M TV and the NBCTV network. The Practice. therefore, a new weekly series beginning on NBC tonight at 8:30, requires some tolerance for the Danny Thomas brand of lovablesticky humor. But once beyond the stickiness, which is wisely kept to a minimum.

title: Car Output Cut for Quarter But Is 66% Over 1974
description: DETROIT, Jan. 29The United States auto industry has cut 37,000 cars from first quarter production schedules but output will still be 860,000 units ahead of the recession levels of last year, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

title: A FARKAS WITNESS IS GIVEN IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) A key figure in an investigation of the selling of ambassadorships was granted immunity against his wishes today and was taken before a Federal grand jury.

title: Leftist Party and Union Offices Are Bombed in North Portugal
description: LISBON, Jan. 29Offices of extreme leftist parties and Communistled labor unions were destroyed in two northern Portuguese towns today as an eightmonthold wave of bombings and other violent incidents continued.

title: How Educated Patients Get Proper Health Care
description: Healthcare experts say there is much that patients can do to protect themselves against incompetent and negli. gent medical care.

title: Goggles Called Skiing Necessity
description: Morton L. Rosenthal, who spends almost every winter weekend at Mount Snow in Vermont with his family, was seen lunching in that ski area's base lodge. As soon as he had finished dining, he took out goggles, wrapped them around his ski hat, and headed for the slopes. I wouldn't think of going out there without goggles  rain, sun or snow, he said. Continual exposure to wind and sun can cause chronic redness and irritation of the eyes and although not serious is troublesome. Since this skiier sounded like an expert on goggles, he was asked how he Could sound so authoritative. He hesitated a moment and. then confessed to being an ophthalmologist with offices in Manhattan. He was then asked other questions. Some of his answers.

title: 2 in Legislature Score Restaurant At Trade Center
description: A report Issued yesterday by two legislators criticized the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for wasteful and lavish expenditures on their semiprivate restaurant facilities in the World Trade Center.

title: Nurse's Aide is Convicted Of Assaulting Patient, 84
description: A jury in Queens Criminal Court yesterday found a nurse's aide guilty of assault on an 84yearold woman patient in a Rockaway Beach nursing home.

title: The Moynihan Affair
description: President Ford completely approves of Daniel Patrick Moynihan's conduct as United States Representative to the United Nations. So, apparently, does Secretary of State Kissinger, who says Ambassador Moynihan has the full support of the President and the Secretary of State and the Department of State.

title: HOUSE PREVENTS RELEASING REPORT ON INTELLIGENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The House of Representatives acceded tonight to the wishes of President Ford and the intelligence agencies and voted to withhold the final report of its Select Committee on Intelligence until it had been censored by the executive branch.

title: Stock Prices Advance
description: Stock prices pushed higher yesterday, after profit taking, to reach their best levels in 27 months. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.40 points to 968.75. Volume for all Nevi York Stock Exchange issues totaled 34.29 million shares. Details on Page 37.

title: Bridge:
description: Exactly a century and a half ago, members of the Stratford Club in London were afflicted by the presence of one most obnoxious member, and the club constitution had no provision for expulsion.

title: Buttons on Their Minds
description: LONDON, Jan. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)Readers of The Guardian are engaged in an intense debate through the London newspaper's correspondence column on why women have buttons on the left side of their garments while men have them on the right.

title: Books of The Times
description: Not surprisingly, it turns out again that what Henry Fairlie has to say is very much worth hearing. So I wish there were some way of putting in a nutshell the argument of his latest book, The Spoiled Child of the Western World: The Miscarriage of the American Idea in Our Time. If there were, the nutshell would contain something like this The Upheavals that began the 1960's  particularly those symptomized by the squalling of Jerry Rubin and Abbie Hoffman  are a sign that America has become a spoiled child. This regression would not matter if America were just another country in the world. But even in its infantile state this country embodies an ideal that has improved the hopes of all Western civilization. Therefore it is essential that America rediscover and embrace again the principles on which was founded. In order to do so, the country must cast off the reactionary influences that are now threatening to keep its development arrested.

title: Pope Says Priests Betray Church on Sex Statement
description: ROME, aJn. 29 (AP)Replying to criticism of the Vatican's condemnation of sex outside marriage Pope Paul VI has denounced what he called betrayal by clerics in his own church.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Hockey, Basketball Standings

title: Hawks Thwart Knicks, 112109
Little Penn National Clicks in the Sticks
description: While thoroughbred racing people were congratulating themselves yesterday because attendance was up per cent last year across the United States, the head of a vestpocket race track with a post office box as mailing address was smiling.

title: Police Conference Plans Political Bloc To Back P.B.A.Endorsed Candidates
description: The Metropolitan Police Conference, which represents 65,000 police officers in New York City and five metropolitanarea counties, announced last night a major campaign to form a political bloc to support candidates endorsed by police associations.

title: INQUIRY ON GRAIN SOUGHT IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Five members of the House Agriculture Committee called today for a Congressional inquiry into evidence that they said indicated everything from massive benign neglect to specific incidents of attempted coverup of grain scandals.

title: Newspaper Guild Bars Punishing of Washington Post Dissidents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In a move to head off the loss of the 500member unit of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post, the union's international executive board voted tonight to block union charges of strikebreaking against Post guildsmen who have crossed picket lines during bitter fourmonth strike by craft union.local union's threatened disciplinary actions by promising to dismiss, on appeal, any convictions handed down by a local union trial board. The trial board has the nominal power to impose suspension, expulsion or heavy fines against those convicted.

title: U.S. Paid $800,000 To Italian General; C.I.A. Fought Move
description: ROME, Jan. 29Over the strong objections of the Central Intelligence Agency in 1972, Graham A. Martin, then the United States Ambassador to Italy, won approval to pay $800,000 to a prominent rightist general who headed Italy's military intelligence agency.

title: Jailing for Alimony Debt Voided by a Judge Here
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said yesterday that as a result of a Federal Court decision this month he could no longer send anyone to jail for not paying alimony.
