title: BRITAIN SETS PLANS TO CURB JOBLESSNESS
description: LONDON, Jan. 29Denis Healey, Chancellor of the Exchequer, outlined plans in the House of Commons today to alleviate Britain's growing unemployment.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Philip W. Noel of Rhode Island, who began in politics as an interne in the Washington office of Senator John O. Pastore, announced in Providence yesterday that he would enter the race for the seat his mentor is vacating after 25 years. The 44yearold former Mayor of Warwick is chairman of the Democratic Governors Conference and head of the Platform Committee for he 1976 National Convention. He said he was not ruling out a possible VicePresidential offer.

title: Dissolve Upper Volta Cabinet
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Jan. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Sangoule Lamizana dissolved the cabinet here today. The ministers will continue to carry out their duties until a new cabinet has been formed.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: CEASEFIRE HOLDS IN LEBANON: A street vender In Beirut sells oranges while carrying an automatic rifle, defying a Palestine Liberation Army call for civilians not United Press International to carry weapons on the street. The Syrianbacked Palestinian army is enforcing the ceasefire between Christians and Moslems, which has lasted one week.

title: Spanish Refugees: Waiting
description: King Juan Carlos I of Spain and his Government are eager to join the Common Market and end Spain's isolation from Europe. The time has therefore come for Spain to give unconditional restitution to the thousands of Spanish political exiles living all over the world today. These people lost their homes, jobs and country when the fascist rebel generals, supported by Hitler and Mussolini, defeated the legitimate Government of Spain after almost three years of war. And, like their most eminent countryman, the late Pablo Casais, they have refused to return until Spain is free of fascism.

title: Nadjari Turns Over Material On Carey Dispute to Grumet
description: State Supreme Court Justice Jacob B. Grumet, who was named last week to look into Maurice H. Nadjari's charge that Governor Carey had tried to dismiss him to stymie his investigation of alleged political corruption in the Bronx, met yesterday with the special state prosecutor.

title: RollsRoyce, 5 Years After Bankruptcy, Is Regaining Confidence
description: LONDON, Jan. 29With the fifth anniversary of the RollsRoyce bankruptcy coming up next week, the chairman of the resuscitated company offered a confident view today of its longterm survivability, along with a complaint about the erratic flow of Government capital support.

title: CANADA UPDATING RAILWAY SYSTEM
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 29The Canadian Government announced plans today to reform the nation's ailing railway system, which has been running at a loss of $167 million a year.

title: ALIMONY JAILING VOIDED BY JUDGE
description: District on Jan. 8. That case involved three nonalimony debtors from Poughkeepsie who had challenged the constitutionality of a state law allowling debtors to be arrested for contempt if they did not pay.

title: Memorial Seruies
description: RICHARDSONJohn, of Canton, Mass., Jan. 24, 1976, in his 90th year. Memorial Service 12 noon, Saturday, Jan. 31, et First Parish Church (Unitarian) In Milton, Mass. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be sent to Harvard Univeroily Treasurers Office, 70 Federal St., ??? ??? ???

title: Study of Islands' Problems Proposed by Rep. Eilberg
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Representative Joshua Eilberg suggested today that a commission be formed to consider whether four American areas needed special immigration laws taking account of their problems with resources and labor supply.

title: Newark Will Disband Mounted Police
description: NEWARK, Jan. 29Justice and Honesty will no longer walk the streets of Newark. Neither will Mayor, Director, Chief, Tex, Rocky or Hughie.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger testified before the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Africa yesterday and said that the Administration is now seriously considering open financial aid to two Angolan factions fighting a Sovietsupported nationalist movement. He said the overt assistance would have to be considerably larger than the $32 million sent the two groups covertly by the United States last year. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Ford Panel Urges Ban on Concorde At 2 U.S. Airports
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 29 (Reuters)President Ford's Council on Environmental Quality has recommended that the AngloFrench Concorae supersonic jet be denied landing rights at KenInedy Airport in New York and Dulles Airport near Washington.

title: Stocks Rise 17.40 to 968.75, Their Best Level in 27 Months
description: A reduction in the prime interest rate on loans to the biggest and most creditworthy corporate borrowers will be considered today by the First National City Bank of New York, which often leads the rest of the banking community in rate changes.

title: Sanford Keeps His Options Open On Resuming Presidential Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.29Terry Sanford may have withdrawn from active competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but he has not given up the politician's practice of trying to have it both ways.

title: TricentennialPlus8 Sunders A Savant's Veil of Obscurity
description: It is no trick at all these days to organize conference on the Bicentennial or even the defense of the Western world, but it takes uncommon skill, bravado and three parts of gall to unfold the chairs and wire the lectern for Giambattista Vico.

title: Disclosure of Grandjury Data
description: The State Commission of Investigation hearing on grandjury news leaks has raised a number of ethical and practical questions for the press and, the public. Should the press, for instance, withhold information News obtained from Analysis grand juries to protect the reputations of individuals? If not, when should it, publish such information? Should grand jury testimony about private individuals be treated differently by the press than testimony about public officials?

title: How Educated Patients Get Proper Health Care
description: Healthcare experts say there is much that patients can do to protect themselves against incompetent and negligent medical care.

title: SATELLITE PLACED OVER THE EQUATOR
description: The Communications Technology Satellite, a harbinger of direct broadcasting from space to rooftop antennas on earth, was sent to its assigned station 22,300 miles above the Equator yesterday, in preparation for two years of medical, educational and data transmission tests.

title: Bill for Legal Casinos Gets Conflicting Views
description: Speakers attacked and defended a bill to amend the State Constitution to allow gainbling in stateoperated casinos and parimutuel betting on jal alai and dog racing at the first public hearing on the measure, which was held here yesterday.

title: But Report is Challenged by NursingHome Union
description: As many as 20 persons died as a result of a nursinghome strike here in November 1973, according to a report released yesterday by the City Health Department.

title: Manhattan, Seton Hall Garden Victors
description: Manhattan and Seton Hall, two local teams that believe they are better than their records indicate, were good enough to win their openinground games in the second annual Madison Square Garden classic last night.

title: On Classified Loans
description: Like all other industries, banking is a business. It moves money from where it is available to where it is needed and provides whatever services are required to get it there. The banking business also has a larger responsibility and that is to assure the functioning of our economy when other markets falter.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 34yearold city police officer was indicted on two counts of manslaughter yesterday in the fatal shootings of two men the officer contended were attempting to rob him in a gypsy cab last month on Staten Island.

title: Undersea Phone Cables Expand
description: Undersea Phone Cables Expand

title: FORD'S AIDES SEEK HEALTH FUND CUT
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 29Administration officials were working today on new proposals for cuts in the health programs in the $45 billion appropriation bill Congress passed yesterday over the President's veto.

title: INTEREST RATES ON BONDS DECLINE
description: Interest rates on state and city bonds yesterday reached their lowest levels since last June. Even so, major bond issues marketed this week achieved a fair degree of success in attracting investors. Florida, North Carolina and Illinois sold a total of $311 million of highgrade taxexempt bonds this week and twothirds of them appeared to have been sold to investors by late afternoon yesterday.

title: Reporters Vie for Seats at Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 The Germans have come, the French, the Spanish, the English, the Swedes and the Australians. The Italians are not here, nor are the Mexicans nor Asians nor representatives from the Middle East. But here is someone from The National Courier, a semimonthly publication in Plainfield, N.J., and someone from a weekly in Idaho.

title: Finnish Six Routs United States, 92
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 29 (UPI)Finland defeated the United States National Hockey Team, 92, tonight in a violent game which a brawl halted for five minutes in the final period.

title: STOCKHOLDERS SUE 1ST PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) A group of stockholders of the First Pennsylvania Corporation filed a $3 million suit, today against the giant bank, alleging it had made risky loans, held inadequate loan reserves and misrepresented its financial condition.

title: Greek Officers Face Inquiry
description: ATHENS, Jan. 29 (AP)  A military prosecutor today ordered an investigation of 89 active and retired Greek officers for alleged collaboration with the former military junta, in establishing the dictatorship. in 1967. The prosecutor called the 89 secondary to the 21 main conspirators, who have already been sentenced to prison.

title: Business Records
description: Petition filed by; SHARON ANN MORRIS, 20 E. 11 St., N.Y. Liabilities $7,120; assets $700.

title: Singer Plans Phase Out Of a West Coast Facility
description: The Singer Company announced here yesterday that it planned to phase out virtually all manufacturing operations at its business machines division facility at San Leandro, Calif., by the end of March. The company said some 300 employees would be affected by the action although a small manufacturing group will be retained to support ongoing research and engineering funcworkers would remain at San Leandro.

title: 1,036 Athletes Entered In Olympics in Austria
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria (AP) A total of 1,036 athletes has been entered in the Winter Olympic Games opening next Wednesday, Innsbruck organizers said today.

title: Style, Not Substance
description: The argument between Mr. Moynihan and his critics, in and outside the State Department, is about manner and style, not about the substance of policy, on which there is wide agreement. Change comes but slowly at the State Department and many career officers undoubtedly are strongly opposed to the Moynihan style. Some may, as he charges, have carried their hostility to the point of obstructionism or of leaking criticism of the ambassador to the press.

title: Chapter XI Filed by Peden
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Peden Industries Inc of Houston has filed a voluntary petition in Federal court for debt arrangement under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy law. The manufacturer and wholesale supplier of iron and steel products, listed assets of $22.4 million and liabilitie of $18.3 million as of Nov. 30.

title: Millions of XRays Found Unneeded And Radiation is Often Excessive
description: About twothirds of the American people receive Xray examinations each year, with an average of five Xray films taken per person examined. But several radiation experts maintain that many of the millions of medical and dental Xray examinations done are unnecessary and that the average dose of radiation per Xray is much higher than it need be.

title: Oil Cleanup Coop Set Up For Offshore Jersey Spills
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29Oil executives, who have testified for the last three days here that New Jersey beaches would not be fouled by spills from offshore drilling, said at a public hearing today that they had formed a cooperative to clean up spills.

title: Biology Program Seeks Black Doctor Increase
description: A program to bolster the teaching of biology in black colleges and to help prepare more black and other minority group students to become doctors was announced this week by the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation here.

title: Curl's 64 Sets Pace By Stroke
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 29 (AP) Rod Curl, who packs a hardhitting game in a tiny frame, overpowered the 7.219yard Waialae Country Club course today with an eightunderpar 64. It staked him to a onestroke lead in the firstround of the $230,000 Hawaiian open.

title: Rangers Win, 63, Ending a Drought
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29The New York Rangers, without a victory in their previous seven games, got a pair of secondperiod goals from Rod Gilbert tonight and went on to defeat the St. Louis Blues, 63, in a National Hockey League game.

title: B. DEMBLIN, AUTHOR OF YIDDISH NOVELS
description: B. Demblin, an winning Yiddish novelist who depicted the social changes in modern Jewish life, died Tuesday in Miami Beach, where he had been living. He was 78 years old and also lived at 264 East Broadway.

title: People and Business
description: I really am a troubled fellow, Paul Newman said yesterday in Washington by way of explaining what an actor was doing before television cameras in the New Senate Office Building.

title: Fassbinder 'American Soldier' Is Bold and Interesting
description: "The American Soldier," which opened at the Film Forum yesterday, is an early (1970) film by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the prolific and prodigiously talented young German director whose works are turning up in this country out of their chronological order. This is not necessarily a bad thing. It keeps all of us, including critics, on edge since it's not easy to categorize his work.In the later Fassbinder films to be seen here, including "AliFear Eats the Soul" and "Fist-Right of Freedom" (now being called "Fox"), Mr. Fassbinder appears to have settledfor the time being, anywayon a rather rigorous style that is both understated in the way of cinema and exaggerated in the manner of epic theater.His interiors are cages with walls instead of bars. His landscapes, even in a city, are eerily empty, which has the effect of foreshortening perspectives, making them seem unreal. His characters, including the ulcer-ridden Moroccan worker in "Ali" and the put-upon homosexual in "Fist-Right" have tumultuous private lives, but those private lives are always political parables  if you care to read them."The American Soldier" is not so ambitious a film, but it is extremely interesting and often bold. The great thing about Mr. Fassbinder is that he makes films quickly and moves on (more than 20 features in less than 10 years, I'm told). He doesn't fret about mistakes or rewriting. His late films, as well as the early ones like "The American Soldier," give the impression of having been created in a single burst of energy, not shot in bits and pieces over a period of time and then fitted together."The American Soldier" is a flamboyant but finally solemn joke that recalls early Jean-Luc Godard. Photographed in intentionally overlit black-and-white, it's the deadpan tale of a German-born gangster who returns home from America to make a couple of "hits" on a contract from what appears to be the police.The story is about as important as the name of the unit publicity man on your average, run-of-the-mill American disaster movie. "The American Soldier" is about people living lives styled after the highlights of American gangster movies, under the direction of a man who finds such movies both fascinating and funny. It's virtually an anthology of movielearned attitudes and gestures that, in the world of this particular movie, give life meaning.Ricky, the gangster, played by Karl Scheydt (who looks like a soft version of Charles Bronson), moves impassively through the film, knocking off assignments in the fashion of a distilled Alan Ladd, making love perfunctorily to women who go suddenly limp in his arms as if shot with curare, finally to be double-crossed by his employers.The film has the cold eye of the political cartoonist, as well as the political cartoonist's eye for outrageous detail: Ricky's mom and brother, who are apparently conventional middle class types, have a pinball machine in the living room and swig their morning whiskies directly from the bottle of Ballantine's.Mr. Fassbinder's achievement here is in avoiding obvious camp. The film has a languorous, dreamlike pace, a feeling of slow motion. "The American Soldier is notas was the Warhol-Morrisey "Heat"a parody of a familiar subject, but a contemplation of one. It could be called "The American Gangster Movie, Theme and Variations."

title: Sports Today
description: Columbia at Yale, 8 P.M. (Radio WKCR, 7:55 P.M.); New York State Maritime at New York Poly, 8 P.M.; Binghamton at Pratt, 8 P.M.; Barrington at Nyack, 8 P.M.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 2.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 188.7 from 191.4 last week.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 11%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $857 million, up 22 percent from the yearearlier total of $704 million. Total retail store sales were about $11.69 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $10.58 billion.

title: Soviet Indicates it Favors Angola. Political Solution
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29The Soviet Union is willing to accept a political settlement in Angola, a position shared by the Sovietbacked faction there, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: Salvation Army's Favorite Customer
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Sweeping off the snow in front of his bright red door, Pablo Manzoni looks like a Norman Rockwell illustration in his knitted cap and striped muffler. Being a New England householder with a Yankee sense of thrift is one of his personalities the newest one and the one he enjoys the most.

title: Millrose: On Road to Olympics
description: Dan Ripley, a pole vaulter started the track and field season of 1975 by clearing 18 feet 1 inch. No other human who isn't paid openly for vaulting has attained that altitude under a roof, though Steve Smith did 18.5 last year and accepted a check. Ripley hurt a shoulder and faded from the championship scene until the 1976 indoor season began, when he vaulted 18 feet 1 inch. Where, a man asked Tom Jennings of the Pacific Coast Club, had he been meanwhile? Well, it seemed he finished San Jose State and his wife said now it was time to get a job. A job? he said, he was a pole vaulter. So what happened? the man asked. Oh, Jennings said, they got divorced. And that's the way it is in an Olympic year.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: La Mangeoire, a small restaurant on the east side of Second Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets, has become so popular since it opened last spring that when we cast off our anonymity after four meals there and told the management that we planned a favorable review, the news was greeted with yelps of distress. The room seats about 40 at tables very close together, with no waiting space to speak of except Second Avenue, not the best place in town for queuing up in midwinter, and we were asked to hold off, at least until new space, now being remodeled next door, was put into operation.

title: 17 Jamaicans Dead Of Flour Poisoning; 78 Others Left Ill
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 29 At least 17 Jamaicans have died of poisoning and 78 are ill after using contaminated flour, health officials said today.

title: Long Beach is Making Intricate Preparations for Street Race: U.S Grand Prix West
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 29Long Beach, a prosperous oil town with offshore rigs camouflaged to look like highrise apartment and office buildings, is about 6,000 miles from Monte Carlo. Like Monte Carlo it has a pleasant harborCalifornia's busiest.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday about Marion Davits raising the issue of feminism stated that Carl Byoir & Associates had been replaced as public relations representative for Iran Air. The firm is still the major public relations agency for Iran Air in North America.

title: South Korea Drops Plan to Buy A Nuclear Plant From France
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The State Department said today that South Korea had canceled plans to buy a nuclear processing plant from France that experts believe would have enabled it to build its own atomic bombs.

title: A Profile in Hockey: Tough, Hard and 8
description: A Profile in Hockey: Tough, Hard and 8They are tough, hardskating hockey players. They know the corners, where many games are won. They take their injuries in stride. They are between 7 and 9 years old.

title: Influenza Outbreak Is Reported Here; Pupil Absences Up
description: An outbreak of influenza has hit the city, Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, Health Commissioner, said yesterday. One man has died from what was presumed to be influenza.

title: A Very Pretty Bicentennial at the Met
description: Until quite recently the Metropolitan Museum had no plans for a Bicentennial exhibition. The subject was by general consent vast, gaseous and likely to be overdone. The museum had enough on its hands already. Was it not the act of a wise man to sit back and let the others fall on their faces?

title: RATERISE DETAILS FILED BY A.T.&T.
description: Rates that would increase twothirds of the nation's interstate long distance telephone charges and most of its long distance privateline services, were filed yesterday in Washington with the Federal Communications Commission by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Price Surge is Laid to Buying Activity by Institutions
description: The stock market, after declining two days on profit taking, resumed its upward march yesterday and staged its second best gain of a spectacular January.

title: Grain Futures Rise On Report of Buying By the Soviet Union
description: Grain futures prices rose on higher cash prices at Gulf porta resulting mostly from farmer withholding of crops. During the trading session there were reports of Soviet buying mostly centered on coconut oil and soybean oil.

title: Aqueduct Returning To Normal
description: It was businessalmost as usualat Aqueduct yesterday as the thoroughbreds returned to action before a crowd of 13,658. The ninerace program, held under overcast skies and in chilly weather, was Race staged without unusual incident. The routine session provided a sharp contrast to the fogshrouded, spillpunctuated Big A proceedings last Monday and Tuesday. It was this backdrop, plus an unusually sloppy track, that caused track officials to cancel Tuesday's last seven races and Wednesday's program.

title: PARENTS / CHILDREN Young Victims Of Alcoholics
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.There are an estimated 10 million alcoholics in the United States, and many of them are parents.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: cause of death in the Queens and Manhattan incidents had been chemical pneumonia resulting from tear gas.

title: Amex and Counter Advance Strongly; Options Trading Up
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market snapped out of their twosession spell of profit taking with a strong advance yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: City and State Pledge to Rebuild West Side Road
description: Governor Carey and Mayor B???ame sought to reassure the Federal Government yesterday that they strongly favored reconstruction of the West Side Highway and had no intention of diverting the requested highway funds to mass  transit projects.

title: $62 BILLION VOTED FOR PUBLIC WORKS BY DEFIANT HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Setting up another veto confrontation with President Ford, the House overwhelmingly approved today a $6.2 billion measure for state and local public works.
