title: Pentagon Reports That Russian Navy Has Been Stabilized in Size
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Defense Department has coneluded that the Soviet Navy, while continuing to be modernized, has been stabilized in size.

title: 8 Sunders A Savant's Veil of Obscurity
description: It is no trick at all these days to organize a conference on the Bicentennial or even the defense of the Western world, but it takes uncommon skill, bravado and three parts of gall to unfold the chairs and wire the lectern for Giambattista Vico.

title: The Budget Battle
description: January brought snow to New England, a dry spell to the West and a blizzard to Washington. The blizzarrd, was a paper stormhundreds of pages of budget and economic policy proposals. They were spewed forth by a Perspective weary White House, where economists and others worked long nights to produce they logic and the documents on which President Ford's chances for reelection may rest.

title: A Vico Sampler
description: It is a matter for astonishment that there should be so many ignorant persons when ignorance or being misled or falling into error is as repugnant to the mind as smoke.is to.the.eyes, or a foul stench to the nose.

title: About Real Estate
description: Where but in New York City would 11 commercial banks and 23 savings banks get together to form a nonyrofit housing corporation? Nowhere.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Clarence Reisen, president of the board of trustees of Symphony Hall in Newark, said yesterday that the 50yearold auditorium would close today because its operators could not afford to spend the $250,000 needed to repair an electrical system that had recently been found in violation of the city's building code. The 3,400seat auditorium served in past decades as a springboard to stardom for a number of entertainers. In recent years, the concert hall served as the home of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: Council Reverses Raise
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (UPI) In a surprise vote yesterday, the City Council reversed the tentative approval it gave last week and turned down a proposed twostep pay raise for council members and three other officials. The raise would have pushed councilmen's salaries from $30,000 to $33,000 a year.

title: WALLACE BEGINS ATTACK ON BUSING
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., Jan. 29Two things are happening to George C. Wallace's Presidential campaign in Massachusetts.

title: REBELS IN ARGENTINA KILL 2 AT U.S. PLANT
description: BUENOS AIRES, Tan, 29 (AP) Terrorists assassinated two Argentine executives and killed a policeman at the American owned Bendix Corporation plant today, officials said.

title: Sir Gyles Isham, Baronet and Shakespearean Actor
description: NORTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 29 (AP)Sir Gyles Isham, a baronet and Shakespearean actor who appeared with Greta Garbo in the film Anna Karenina, died in a nursing home here today. He was 72 years old.

title: Carey Assails Lefkowitz For Decision on Nadjari
description: Governor Carey charged yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz had failed to check closely the justification for Maurice H. Nadjari's expanded investigation of corruption in the Bronx and had thus opened the investigation to legal challenge.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday about Marion Javits raising the issue of feminism stated that Carl Byoir & Associates had been replaced as public relations representative for Iran Air. The firm is still the major public relations agency for Iran Air in North America.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Daily Averages for the weeks ended.

title: 3 Deaths From Tear Gas Reported in a City Study
description: The city's Board of Correction said yesterday that two prison inmates and a man resisting arrest died last year after being heavily teargassed.

title: Ecuador Welcomes U.S. Steps on Fishing Limit
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 29 (AP) The Ecuadorean Government, which has collected fines and license fees of nearly $5.5 million from American fishermen since 1971 for operating off its coast, today welcomed a United States Senate vote to extend American fishing jurisdiction to 200 miles out to sea.

title: Gorman Upsets Ashe
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29The first shocker of the United States pro indoor tennis championships occurred late tonight. Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion and seeded No. 3 in men's singles. was eliminated by unseeded Tom Gorman, 63, 36, 63. Th loss ended Ashe's winning streak at 12 matches.

title: Testimony of 2 Reilly Witnesses Conflicts on a Key Point in Case
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 29 Two major witnesses called to help Peter Reilly overturn his 1974 manslaughter conviction and obtain a new trial gave directly contradictory testimony in Superior Court here today on a key point.

title: Soviet Indicates it Favors Angola Political Solution
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 29The Soviet Union is willing to accept a political settlement in Angola, a position shared by the Sovietbacked faction there, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE 10 27MONTH HIGH
description: PORT NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 29A sleek, 511foot ship sailed from Port Newark last night to begin the final phase of a multinational protect to expand transAtlantic communications by undersea cable.

title: Stock Prices Advance
description: Stock prices pushed higher yesterday, after profit'taking, to reach their best levels in 27 months. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.40 points to 968.75. Volume for all New York Stock Exchange issues totaled 34.29 million shares. Details on Page 37.

title: ln Memoriam
description: DREZNERRose. January 30th your birthday darling. Love you always.

title: Cheap Shot at Transit
description: State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler's blunt demand that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority desist immediately from further service cuts is a political cheap shot that can do nothing to improve the condition of the foundering M.T.A. or the lot of its hapless passengers.

title: Soviet Criticism Helps Mrs. Thatcher
description: LONDON, Jan. 29Any opposition leader has trouble getting on the front page, especially in times of economic crisis when newspapers and ordinary citizens are preoccupied with the decisions of whoever happens to be in charge. But Margaret Thatcher has a way of getting help from unlikely quarters.

title: Theater: Fire of Flowers Presented
description: Jacques Brel is not precisely alive and well, nor, for that sad matter, even living at the Provincetown Playhouse. Last night, there opened a fourhanded show called Peter Copani's Fire of Flowers. It is difficult to know exactly what the title meansthink of it: Fire of.

title: Mailers Ratify Contract With The Times and News
description: Members of Mailers Union No. 6 voted 548 to 134 yesterday to accept a threeyear contract with The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: Pictorial Salute to 75 Shubert Years Set for 9Month Run
description: In identical top hats and white gloves, Fred and Adele Astaire are dancing. Carmen Miranda balances a stack of tiny umbrellas (rather than bananas) on her head. Fanny Brice is grinning impishly. Jimmy Savo and Fred Allen are standing glumly next to each other. Bert Williams is strutting. Irving Berlin in shirtsleeves is crouched over a piano; he seems to be listening. Over a loudspeaker comes the voice of Al Jolson singing I'm Always Chasing Rainbows. And peeping over the entrance to the room are four madcap Marx Brothers.

title: PATRICIA TOBIN COOPER
description: Patricia Tobin Cooper, a granddaughter of the late M. H. deYoung, founder of The San Francisco Chronicle, died of cancer Wednesday at the University of California Hospital in San Francisco. She was 64 years old and lived in nearby Hillsborough.

title: MOROCCO REPORTS VICTORY IN SAHARA
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 29Morocco said tonight that it had achieved a victory in its campaign against Algerianbacked guerrillas in Spanish Sahara and Algeria reported it was withdrawing all its own troops from the area.

title: Railroad Volume Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 14.6 billion tonmiles, 1.9 per cent below a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 433,277 cars, 3.6 per cent below last year.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC LIFTS PROFIT 37%
description: Following the pattern of railroads that have already reported, the Southern Pacific Company yesterday announced that fourthquarter net income rose 37 percent, while profits for the year fell 33 percent from 1974's record level.

title: F.T.C. EXPANDING STUDY OF PRICING
description: The Federal Trade Commission, after announcing two weeks ago a nationwide investigation of alleged price fixing in the women's apparel industry, is now surveying a variety of other consumer product industries in New Jersey and New York for the possibility of general price collusion between producers and retailers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SUPPORTS CASTRO: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada, right, at farewell ceremonies at Havana yesterday. His wife, Margaret, held their son, Michel CharlesEmile. Prime Minister Fidel Castro, meanwhile, adjusted his cuffs. At left is Mrs. Raul Castro, the wife of Mr. Castro's brother. Mr. Trudeau said that Mr. Castro was a leader of world stature who sent Cuban combat troops to Angola with a great deal of thought and feeling for the situation. The Cuban Prime Minister said earlier he might send reinforcements to Angola.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Their innocence is tainted, but their guilt is not established.Governor Carey, discussing victims investigative abuses. [57:1.]

title: U.S. Paid $800,000 To Italian General; C.I.A. Fought Move
description: ROME, Jan. 29Over the strong objections of the Central Intelligence Agency in 1972, Graham A. Martin, then the United States Ambassador to Italy, won approval to pay $800,000 to a prominent rightist general who headed Italy's military intelligence agency.

title: Beware, Rangers! Here Come The Mites!
description: Beware, Rangers! Here Come The Mites

title: Ray Nance, 62, Jazz Musician, Long With Ellington Band, Dies
description: Ray Nance, a star in Duke Ellington's band for 23 years, died Wednesday at his home, 88 Charles Street. He was 62 years old. Although he had been ill, off and on, for several years, he had continued to perform until the beginning of this month.

title: Bank Sued on Loans
description: The parent corporation of the First Pennsylvania Bank was accused yesterday in a $3 million classaction suit of making risky loans, holding inadequate loan reserves and misrepresenting its financial condition. The company had no comment. Page 39.

title: Officer is Held for Manslaughter In Slaying of 2 Men in Gypsy Cab
description: A 34yearold city police officer was indicted on two counts of manslaughter yesterday in the fatal shootings of two men the officer said attempted to rob him after he accepted a ride last month in their gypsy cab on Staten Island.

title: Flyers Tie Sabres On Bladon Goal,11
Jackson, in Shift, Decides To Step Up Florida Drive
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29A belated decision by Senator Henry M. Jackson to campaign heavily in Florida has placed a new obstacle in the path of the effort by former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia to win or finish a strong second in the primary here on March 9.

title: 'Mary Hartman' Series is Doing Well
description: Mary Hartman Series is Doing WellMary Hartman, Mary Hartman is doing very nicely, very nicely.

title: Aerosol Blast Toll Up 2
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 29 (AP) Two men died from burns yesterday, raising to three the number of victims in the Jan. 17 explosions and fire that ripped through the PetersonPuritan Inc., aerosol plant in Cumberland. Gerard Latour, 24 years old, of Woonsocket and William T. Crossley, 18, of Chepachet died at Rhode Island Hospital. Seven persons remained hospitalized.

title: 5 MEN ARE INDICTED FOR MEDICAID FRAUD
description: Federal indictments were filed here yesterday against two physicians, two chiropractors and a podiatrist, charging them with filing fradulent Medicaid claims for services they had not performed.

title: SENATE VOTES AID FOR CHILD DAY CARE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Senate approved today a bill giving child daycare centers more time to meet specific staffing requirements to qualify for Federal assistance.

title: House Unit Tries to Show Holdback in Gas Supplies
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 29A House subcommittee sought to show today that some natural gas producers have been holding production below maximum rates and could reap big profits from enactment of a natural gas deregulation bill that comes before the House next week.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GOING OUT Guide
description: ONE BY TWO Sarah Vaughan's reputation as a pop and jazz singer should be sufficient inducement for George Gershwin fans to head for Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock, when Miss Vaughan joins Michael Tilson Thomas as her keyboard accompanist in a Gershwin program ranging from the composer's ballads to more ambitious offerings such as the Cuban Overture, An American in Paris and the Second Rhapsody.

title: Dr. Bernard StiHerman, Psychiatrist, 61, Is Dead
description: Dr. Bernard Stillerman, former supervising psychiatrist at the PostGraduate Center for Psychotherapy here and earlier at Rockland State Hospital, Orangeburg, N. Y., died yesterday of multiple myeloma at his home in Closter, N. J. He was 61 years old.

title: Music: Clarion Presents John Messana, Falsettist
description: The operas of Handel and other Baroque composers are difficult to revive satisfactorily because of the virtual disappearance of the virtuoso male soprano and contralto, a breed of singer idolized in past centuries. Nowadays, these key roles are taken by women or countertenors, or in some instances, by tenors for whom the music has been. transposed.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29(Reuters)The United States International Trade Commission charged today that Canada has not lived up to terms of the 11yearold agreement on automobile exports and imports. Treasury Secretary William E. Simon disputed the contention.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: New York  Walter Seely, 131 pounds, Saiville, L.I., knocked out Carlos Dupree, 129, North Philadelphia, Pa.. 8 rounds. Philadelphia Willie Monroe, 160, Philadelphia, outpointed Carlos Marks, 159, New York City, 10.

title: Gas Ruling Issued
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29, (AP) A United States Court of Appeals has ruled that the Federal Power Commission can allow old natural gas to command the higher Incentive price set for new gas when the old gas is sold under a new contract.

title: BEAME CITES LOSS IN FORD'S BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Mayor Beanie told the New York State Congressional delegation today that President Ford's proposed budget would cost the city $160 million.

title: Hoffman Says That the State's Economy Is Showing Some Signs of Improvement
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  Last month's drop in unemployment in New Jersey and other promising economic signs are reenforcing a judgment that the state's economy may be on the brink of an upturn, the state's Commissioner of Industry and Labor, Joseph A. Hoffman, said today.

title: ExSaigon Troops May Vote
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan, 29 (Agence FrancePresse) Soldiers and oficials of the former South Vietnamese regime will be allowed to vote in general elections scheduled for April 25 if they have completed reeducation courses, according to an official statement issued here today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, JAN. 30 LEONARDO DA VINCI, Italian. Left St. Thomas, Jan. 27; this 3 P.M. at W. 30th St. TOMORROW, JAN. 31 QUEEN ELIZABETH ii, Cunard. Left Nassau Jan. 28; due 9 A.M. at W. 48 St.

title: Cliburn and Previn Warm Up for the Live TV Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic goes public this week,. with a live telecast of tonight's concert, an event for which last night's regular subscription performance served as a rather tedious preview. For the leadingcharacters, the night offered two famous musiciansno, better than that, two celebrities. Van Cliburn appeared as soloist in the Grieg Concerto and Andre Previn conducted. A real onetwo publicity punch.

title: Recital
description: Alexis Weissenberg is presenting a series of three piano recitals at Kaufmann Concert Hall this season; the first of them was on Wednesday night. It was devoted to music by Schumann and the works presented were the Scenes from Childhood, the Fantasy in C and Carnaval.

title: Jailing for Alimony Debt Voided by a Judge Here
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said yesterday that as a result of a Federal Court decision this month he could no longer send anyone to jail for not paying alimony.

title: Sure Bet at Las Vegas: Put Your Money on Five
description: A recent visitor to Las Vegas asked a cab driver for the best show in town.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four of the five remaining defendants in the arson case concerning the Sponge Rubber Products Company in Shelton, Conn., were found guilty on two counts each by a jury in United States District Court in New Haven. Peter and Ronald Betres of Butler, Pa.; Anthony A. Just of Greensburg, Pa., and Albert P. Coffey of Cleveland, were convicted of traveling between states to commit arson and of conspiring to do the same, in the spectacular explosion and fire in Shelton last March 1. On its 10th day of deliberation, the jury said it still had not come to an agreement an all four charges that still face the last remaining defendant, Michael J. Tiche of Boyer, Pa.

title: Chance Meeting on Bus Aids the Neediest
description: A chance meeting on a bus with an elderly man on his wayto the hospital for further treatment of a hip injury made a young man decide not to buy holiday gifts, but instead contribute to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Permanent Censorship Approved in Indian Parliament
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29The lower house of Parliament today approved sweeping legislation expected to insure that Government censorship of India's newspapers remained a permanent feature of the society.

title: Beleagured Fleet Tells Tale of Foreign Fishing off New England
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 29When Harry Swain landed the dragger Shamrock at this fishing port on Feb. 3, 1969, after a week at sea, he had 61,000 pounds of fish aboard, mostly yellowtail flounder.

title: Mr. Ford and Angola
description: Gerald Ford should take care lest his premature announcements of the decline of the United States should teed toward selffulfilling prophecy. Now that the House has joined the Senate in refusing to finance further military assistance to a socalled proWestern coalition in Angola, President Ford has virtually invited the world to regard this as evidence that the United States is no longer willing or able to protect its interests or those of its allies.

title: $62 BILLION VOTED FOR PUBLIC WORKS BY DEFIANT HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Setting up another veto confrontation with President Ford, the House overwhelmingly approved today a $6.2 billion measure for state and local public works.

title: Bonds Team Takes BestBall ProAm
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)Bobby Bonds, the California Angels outfielder, and three amateur partners carded a bestball score of 53 today and captured the proam prelude to the 10th annual American Airlines golf tournament.

title: C.A.B. Approves 1% Rise On Domestic Fares Feb. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (Ap) The Civil Aeronautic Board approved today a 1 percent rate increased in all scheduled domestic air fares affective Feb. 1.

title: Beame Asks U.S. Funds To Reopen 7 Libraries
description: Mayor Beame, citing the possible use of Federal funds, raised hopes yesterday for the temporary reopening of seven branch libraries closed last Jan. 17 because of budget cutbacks.

title: Carey Offers Bill to Cut Medicaid Cost
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29Governor Carey today introduced legislation to cut back on state Medicaid expenditures.

title: People in Sports
description: Lynn Swann, the Pittsburgh wide receiver who caught four passes for a record 161 yards in the Steelers 2117 victory over Dallas in Super Bowl X, was honored yesterday as the 18th winner of Sport magazine's most valuable player awardan automobile.

title: Plan to Deepen Channels In Harbor is Supported
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29Representatives of business, shipping, public transportation and municipal development agencies expressed their strong support here today for a $215.38 million plan by the Army Corps of. Engineers to widen and deepen the navigable channels of Newark Bay and the Kill Van Kull.

title: S.C.I. Attacks Use of 'Tribute' In Getting Government Contract
description: S.C.I. Attacks Use of  Tribute In Getting Government Contract TRENTON, Jan. 29  The State Commission of Investigation said today that it is time to put an end to the proposition that you have to pay monetary tribute to get government work in New Jersey and that it might recommend a law to end such practices.

title: Spanish Use the Press to Discuss Government's Plans for Reform
description: MADRID, Jan. 29  Debate opened today on the reform program outlined to Parliament by Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro yesterday, but the discussion took place in the nation's press, not on the floor of the chamber.

title: South Korea Drops Plan to Buy A Nuclear Plant From France
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The State Department said today that South Korea had canceled plans to buy a nuclear processing plant from France that experts believe would have enabled it to build its own tnmin hnmbs.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS U. S. IS WEIGHING OPEN ANGOLAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the Ford Administration is now seriously considering open financial aid to two Angolan factions fighting a Sovietsupported nationalist movement.

title: Depressed Puerto Ricans
description: The greatest concentration of human misery in this troublebeset metropolis is among the millionmember Puerto Rican community. They represent only about oneeighth of the total population, yet they constitute between a third and a half of New York City's welfare recipients. Thirty percent live below the poverty line in terms of family income.

title: C.A.B. Says Country's Airlines Can Raise Fares 1% Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that airlines, in the UnitedStates would be allowed to raise their ticket prices 1 percent next month on all mainland routes in this country to offset rising fuel and other economic costs.

title: The Ballet: Robbins's Mere L'Oye
description: At its premiere last spring at the New York City Ballet's Ravel Festival, Jerome Robbins's ballet to the French composer's Mother Goose Suite seemed to be very much one big in joke for the balletomane.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: I.L.G.W.U. Seeking Pact Covering Entire Industry
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has started a drive in its current negotiations with the dress industry aimed at eventually achieving an agreement covering the entire outerwear industry instead of separate contracts for dress, sportswear and cloakandsuit workers.

title: How to Reform C.I.A.
description: For far too many years, Congress blithely played the role of the Central Intelligence Agency's subservient protector. The legacy of the cold war impelled those few members of Congress who were privy to the agency's mysteries to act as its rubber stamps and apologists.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Two former fashion models, Sondra Lipton and Clare Geiman, have designed a new line of table linens called DiningIn that are meant to offer an opportunity to create one's own look by mixing and matching items within a given framework.

title: Union Carbide to Raise Prices of Polyethylenes
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday announced that effective March 1 it would increase prices of most lowdensity polyethylene products by 2.5 cents per pound with highdensity product prices moving up 2 cents a pound for most types.

title: JOSEPH HARRISON, EXJERSEY JUDGE
description: Mr. Harrison, a Republican, had held a wide variety of state offices. He had been a state deputy attorney general assigned to the board of Public Utility Commissioners, 52; deputy state rationing commissioner for the Office of Price Administration, 194142, and state rationing attorney, 194244.

title: JUDGE ADAMANT ON NEARBY JURY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 30Federal District Judge Oliver J. Carter disregarded a plea today by the American Civil Liberties Union to open up to public view the jury selection process in Patricia Hearst's trial by the admission of at least a small pool of reporters.

title: Beame Proposes $1.46 Billion Capital Budget, With No Funds for Any New Construction
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday what he called unquestionably the tightest capital budget in the city's recent historyan outlay of $1.467 billion for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 that envisions not a single new construction project of any kind.

title: No. 94 Is Bowling Strikes Again
description: Dick Battista's wife, Jean, was waiting outside the intensive care unit of New York Hospital last September when a nurse appeared.

title: STOUFFER ENDS PACT WITH LABOR OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 After seven days of picketing of the Labor Department, a dispute involving unionization of cafeteria employees of a private foodservice company has been ended with the company terminating its contract with the department.

title: Dividends
Deaths
Britain Threatens Cutoff Of Funds to Chrysler Unit;
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (UPI)The government threatened today to cut off rescue funds for Chrysler's ailing British subsidiary if workers at the Linwood, Scotland, plant continue their strike.

title: Right Mind Heads Stymie Handicap Field
description: Right Mind and General Beauregard, who finished a head apart in the recent Aqueduct Handicap, renew their rivalry at Aqueduct today in the $50,000 added Stymie Handicap at 1 miles. Off his first stakes victory, in the Aqueduct Deronjo Stable's 5yearold Right Mind has been established the 21 morningline favorite against eight rivals.

title: Highlights of the Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Following are the highlights of today's Supreme Court decision on the Federal campaign law:

title: U.N. COUNCIL ASSAILS THE SOUTH AFRICANS
description: United NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 31The Security Council unaaiimously approved a resolution today, calling for United Nationssupervised elections in SouthWest Africa and condemning South Africa's use of The territory as a base for attacks on neighboring countries.

title: SCHOOL EQUALITY UPHELD IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON. Jan. 30In a decision that displeased Governor Byrne and state school officials, the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today in principle a law entitling each of the state's 1.5 million public school pupils to a thorough and efficient education and gave the Legislature until April 6 to devise a method to nay for it.

title: Leafs' Kelly Sinks No Roots
description: TORONTO, Jan. 30Not a photograph, framed document or chart interrupts the sweep of wood paneling in Red Kelly's windowless Maple Leaf Gardens office.

title: Rochester Votes Inquiry Into Offtrack Betting Unit
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 29 (UPI)Legislators from this city and Monroe county have voted to conduct investigations of the management of the Western Regional Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: RICHARD C. KREUSLER
description: Richard G. Kreusler, former marketing executive with the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and labor relations counsel to the Sperry Gyroscope Company of New York, a division of the SperryRand Corporation died Thursday in Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 47 years old and lived in Palm Beach. He formerly lived on Long Island.

title: I.B.M. SCRUTINIZED ON TYPEWRITERS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation disclosed yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission is beginning an investigation to determine whether I.B.M. monopolizes or has attempted to monopolize or has engaged in unfair meth??? of competition in the of??? typewriter market.

title: Nursing Home Fire In Chicago Kills 13; 30 Suffer Injuries
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP)A fire raced through the top floor of a nursing home and into a chapel where elderly residents were attending mass today, killing 13 patients and injuring more than 30 persons. Most of the victims were in the chapel.

title: CBS, Cutting Down On Sports Bidding, To Lose Preakness
description: A CBS executive, referring to the wild escalation in bidding among television networks for the right to cover some sports events, announced yesterday that CBS was dropping out of the bidding for the right to televise the Preakness Stakes, an annual thoroughbred horse race that CBS has carried since 1948.

title: Con Ed 1974 Rates Held Highest in U.S By Survey of F.P.C
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Consolidated Edison Company of New York charged higher residential electricity rates in 1974 than all other privately owned utilities in the country, a Federal Power Commission survey showed today.

title: Dancemobile in Series on Harlem Stage
description: Dancemobile, which has made its reputation traveling about and performing in the streets, has come inside for the winter but is no less active. This Thursday it began a weeklong series at the Wirlem Performance Centv, displaying a quartet of dhoreographic talents ranging from the ethnological work of Pearl Primus to the vigorous movement structures of Gus Solomons Jr.

title: Art: The Cat in American Folk Painting and Sculpture
description: Great painters do better with dogs than with cats. If we think of the dog in Titian's portrait of Charles V, or of the King Charles spaniels to whom Van Dyck gave such an unforgettable elegance, or of the hounds to whom Courbet brought the dignity of antique sculpture, then we can really ask ourselves, What happened to cats?

title: HAROLD W. GOFF, 87, BELL LABS INVENTOR
description: Harold Wheeler Goff, who held more than 50 patents on telephone improvements developed in 36 years with the Bell Telephone Laboratories, died Wednesday evening in Huntington, L. I. He was 87 years old and live din Lloyd Harbor. L.I.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Gag Order in Carson Case
description: The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously struck down a gag order issued against the press in the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants.

title: In Memnriam
description: STUARTCharles, III. The King across the water. January 31, 1788.

title: Funds for Education Law Held Assured
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke said today that he would certify to local school districts that full financing was available for the law that mandates thorough and efficient education despite the fact that the Legislature must still come up with the money.

title: HARRY GITTLESON
description: Harry Gittleson, since 1961 general sales manager of the R.K.O. Radio Pictures division of R.K.O. General Inc., died Thursday at the French and Polyclinic Health Center. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: Ford Vetoes Milk Bill
description: President Ford vetoed a bill to raise Federal price supports for milk, saying it would mean unnecessarily high consumer prices and huge surpluses. Page 18.

title: A Shiny New Capital Emerging Slowly in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 24In a scrubby, windswept valley at the edge of the Himalayas, Pakistan is building itself a capitala shiny symbol of national pride in a nation more accustomed to feeling downtrodden. Fourteen years after the dry earth here was turned for the first construction, Islamabad now has a population of 100,000, and the look and feel of a real city, with shopping centers, office towers and row upon row of neat, flatroofed stucco Government houses stretching off into the grasslands that surround it.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Manila Troops Seize 200 In Crackdown on Strikers
description: MANILA, Jan. 30Philippine Army troops detained more than 200 striking workers today as part of one of the biggest crackdowns since President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law over three years ago, eyewitnesses reported.

title: The Hartford Lesson
description: The victory of the City of Hartford over the Department of Housing and Urban Development and seven affluent suburbs in a Federal court in Connecticut is a victory for realism in the nation's urban policies.

title: People in Sports
description: Abe Pollin, owner of the Washington Capitals, took out a halfpage newspaper advertisement yesterday to take the blame for his team's 5415 wonlosttied recordthe worst in the National Hockey League.

title: LEBANESE BANKS LOOK TO EUROPE
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Once prosperous Lebanese banks, many of which have been forced to close during months of civil strife, are moving to expand in Western Europepursuing clients and clients cash.

title: People and Business
description: J. K. Jamieson and Sir Eric Drake, two prominent figures in the oil world, have joined the WorldWide Shipping Group, headed by Y. K. Pao, the largest independent operator of tankers.

title: LANDIARK RUING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  In a landmark ruling on how political campaigns are to be waged, the Supreme Court today upheld public financing for Presidential contests, limits on how much individuals may contribute directly to a candidate in any Federal election race, and strict requirements for reporting both contributions and expenditures.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The Justice Department said it would appeal a Federal.judge's ruling that the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee might no longer wait several weeks before disclosing its decisions to buy sell Government bonds.

title: Lebanon Banks Move
description: Many Lebanese banks, forced to close during months of civil strife are moving to expand in Western Europe. Three are seeking branch offices in Paris. P. 31.

title: Muaic: World Premiere
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which is nothing if not eclectic, was sponsor to a world premiere at its Alice Tully Hall concert last night. In the past, the society has commissioned music from such avantgarde composers as Pierre Boulez. In commissioning a Quintet for Piano and Winds from Sir Lennox Berkeley, quite the opposite end of the musical spectrum was approached.

title: Japanese Car Exports Up
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 (UPI)Japan's automobile exports hit & record monthly high in December, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. The association said Japan exported 309,226 cars last month, topping the previous record of 249,654 units last October and up 37.2 percent over December 1974. Japan's total car exports last year were a record 2,677,612 units, up 2.3 percent over 1974.

title: Moroccan Sees Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)King Hassan II of Morocco sent a special representative to meet Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger yesterday to express his concern ??? the risk of armed contn???t With Algeria in Spanish Sahara, it was announced today.

title: Indonesia Offers Some Nations Oil for Less Than OPEC Price
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 30 Indonesia, faced with dwindling markets and a sharp decline in demand for its oil, has begun to negotiate governmenttogovernment oil sales at substantially lower prices than the current levels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to oilcompany executives and Western diplomats reached by telephone in Jakarta.

title: NATO Chief to Visit
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  Secretary General Joseph, M.A.H. Luns of the North AtMantic Treaty Organization, will visit Washington and Ottawa next month for talks with Presiident Ford and with Premier Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canlada, the alliance said today.

title: IMPACT THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Supreme Court decision today on campaign financing will probably not have a great deal of effect on the 1976 Presidential election, in the view of politicians and political observers here.

title: Highlights of the Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Following are the highlights of today's Supreme Court decision on the Federal campaign law:

title: EGBERT WHITE, 81, OF YANK IS DEAD
description: Egbert White, a former advertisirig executive and magazine publisher, who was a founder of Yank magazine and editor of Mediterranean editions of Stars and Stripes, the service newspaper, in World War II, died Thursday in Hartford Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in New Milford, Conn.

title: Farm Prices Received Decline OneHalf of 1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 30 (AP) Prices farmers get for raw agricultural products declined onehalf of 1 percent from Dec, 15 to Jan. 15 but averaged 8 percent higher than they did a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 18 Oil Consumer Nations Agree On Plan to Develop Own Energy
description: PARIS, Jan. 31 Eighteen leading Western oil consumer countries agreed today on a longterm program of energy development to lessen dependence on foreign oil. The agreement includes a minimum price of $7 a barrel for oil to protect new investment.

title: Chinatown Saluting the Auspicious Year of the Dragon
description: Dragon dancing to ward off evil spirits is as authentically Chinese as the fried noodle, but 20yearold Cheung Sang had to make a journey of 10,000 milesfrom Canton in South China to Mott Street in New York's Chinatownto see a fullblown version of a rite that was known before Confucius was born.

title: For Mrs. Keyes, It Was a Capitol Job
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 It is more than 44 years since Charlotte Morse Keyes went to work as a junior stenographer for the assistant secretary to Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt. Today, seven Governors and untold political lifetimes later, Mrs. Keyes, who has been confidential secretary to every Governor's press secretary since James C. Hagerty, left her desk in the executive chamber and retired to an apartment three blocks from the Capitol she knows better than almost anyone in the state's history.

title: The 19th Century is Just a Bend of the River Away
description: PIERMONTONHUDSON, N.Y.Even those New Yorkers who are inveterate explorers of the five boroughs are wont to overlook exciting melds of architecture, history, twisting river views and odd and interesting snops that lie only slightly further afield.

title: New Rail TV System Keeps Roving Eyes on Business Operations
description: WASHINGTON. 30A store surveillance system called Rail TV is being marketed nationally and abroad by the American District Telegraph Company.

title: WILLIAM EYERS, FARM EXPERT, 84
description: William I. Meyers, who organized the Federal Farm Credit Administration in the Depression, died yesterday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Britain Condemns Recruiting
description: NORWICH, England, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The British Government tonight strongly condemned the recruitment in Britain of mercenaries for Angola.

title: A Threat to Blacks In Higher Education
description: QUIET REVOLUTION is taking place withiri Congress that if successful could spell disaster for blacks in higher education.

title: WILLIAM P. SEARS JR., EDUCATOR AT N.Y.U.
description: William Paul Sears Jr., professor emeritus of education and former head of the department of vocational education at New York University, died Thursday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 73 years old and hired at 7 Washington Square North.

title: MILK PRICE BILL VETOED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) President Ford vetoed today a bill to raise Federal price supports for milk, saying the legislation would result in unnecessary high consumer prices and lead to huge and costly sur pluses.

title: Clay Gets Football Post
description: HATTIESBURG. Miss., Jan. 30 (AP)Bill Clay was named assistant defensive coach today at the University of Southern Mississippi. Clay replaces Buddy Nix, who resigned recently to loin the couching staff at Auburn.

title: Lesbian Fights to Get Son Back; Seeks Funds Here for an Appeal,
description: Mary Jo Risher, the lesbian mother who recently lost custody of her 9yearold son to her former husband in a jury trial in Dallas, vowed here yesterday that she would fight the decision in the courts.

title: Stock Cars Face Mileage Test
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30In two weeks Confederate flags will fly again atop the motor homes in the infield and there will be more people in the stands than in the pits at Daytona International Raceway.

title: When Life Began at 58
description: At the age of 58, William Randolph Hearst began courting a pretty pony girl in the Follies chorus. The courtship lasted some 30 years. The girl, Marion Davies, became a pampered, highly paid movie star (her MGM contract with Irving Thaiberg called for $500,000 a yearthis in the untaxing 20's). The romance between the press tycoon (a married man) and the Hollywood beauty fed gossip columns and scandalmongers around the world, until Mr. Hearst's death in 1951.

title: Bizarre Italian Episode
description: Few recently disclosed American covert adventures abroad are as disturbing as Ambassador Graharn A. Martin's alleged payment of $800,000 to an Italian general who now faces charges of complicity in rightwing plots to overthrow his Government. This was no C.I.A. caper butif the story is accuratean operation demanded by a career Foreign Service officer over C.I.A. protests and sanctioned by the Forty Committee of the National Security Council, then headed by Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Market Place
description: Drug  company stocks, which for years seemed singularly resistant to bear markets, finally appear to have encountered a measure of investor apathy.

title: Cummings Takes 3:57.6 Mile; McTear Wins Millrose Dash
description: More than 600 athletes and a record indoortrack crowd of 18,142 watched the road to the Olympic wind through Madison Square Garden last last night, and they were repaid when Paul Cummings broke the meet record for the onemile run in the Wanamaker Millrose Games.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Monay roles for Friday.

title: FUTURES OF WHEAT ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Wheat futures dominated the market in light trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with final prices up about 7 cents a bushel. The March delivery closed at $3.50 a bushel, up from $3.43. Corn and soybeans were virtually unchanged.

title: U.S. Skiers Arrive at Innsbruck
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 30 (AP)The eightmember United States men's Alpine ski team moved into the Olympic Village earlier than expected today, scrapping plans for a preGames training camp.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 54311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M, IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRI DAY: NEVI ???RSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW, YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (514) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: REAGAN SAYS PLAN WOULD CUT H.E.W.
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., Jan. 30Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said in an interview in his Florida campaign) today that implementation of his plan to shift responsibility for a halfdozen Federal programs to the states would mean a great reduction in the size of giant Federal departments, notably the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: ROSENTHAL WARNS ON CURBING PRESS
description: A. M. Rosenthal, the managing editor of The New York Times, warned yesterday that recent judicial rulings restricting the press constitute the latest and perhaps most dangerous threat to the existence of the free press.

title: Loans to South Africa Being Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Administration is under pressure from business interests, Congressmen and some of its own officials to allow the resumption of direct loans to South Africa by the ExportImport Bank. Such loans were banned 12 years ago.

title: Murphy, Jacobs, Irwin Tied at 135
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 30 (AP) Hale Irwin, Bob Murphy and John Jacobs overcame shifting, gusty winds today and tied for the secondround lead in the $230.000 Hawaiian open golf tournament with 135 totals.

title: Music: From St. Louis
description: The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night to offer Mozart's Symphony No. 34; Ravel's Shehdrazade and Schumann's Symphony No. 2 under the direction of Georg Semkow.

title: Singer Deficits Widen for Fourth Quarter
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. Restated for change to LIFO

title: Verrazzano College Liveson Paper
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.In the early 1960's, Gilbert DeLucia, a Greenwich Village businessman, conceived the idea of a new college based on Italian culture and values. He named his hypothetical school Verrazzano College, after the explorer who first found New York harbor.

title: IMPACT THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Supreme Court decision today on campaign financing will probably not have a great deal of effect on the 1976 Presidential election, in the view of politicians and political observers here.

title: Connors, Stockton, Borg, Okker Gain
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30A Swede, a Dutchman and two Americans battled their way into the semifinals of the United States pro indoor tennis championships tonight. The top prize for the men's singles event is $20,000.

title: FOLKROCK PROGRAM BY DAN FOGELBERG
description: Dan Fogelberg reminds one of the Eagleswhich isn't too surprising, because he has the same manager and opened for the popular Los Angeles countryrock band on its last tour.

title: Judge Says Lawyers for Reilly Have Met 2 of the 3 Prerequisites for a New Trial
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 30 Judge John A. Speziale ruled today in Superior Court that the identification of a fingerprint found on the screen door of Barbara Gibbons's cottage the day after she was murdered met two of the three criteria needed to win a new trial for her 20yearold son, Peter Reilly.

title: Health Veto Loses
description: Congress has now overridden President Ford's veto of the appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfarea measure that he, described as a classic example of unchecked spending.

title: SINGER DEFICITS WIDEN BROADLY
description: The Singer Company reported; yesterday that it lost $414.6 million in the fourth quarter and $452 million in all of last year. The threemonth deficit is believed to be the biggest suffered by any company in a single quarter.

title: Ford Denies Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Ford declared this evening that Mr. Reagan's accusation of dirty tricks by the Ford campaign organization was without foundation.

title: Jersey Court Upholds a Statute On Thorough Schooling for All
description: TRENTON. Jan. 30In a decision that displeased Governor Byrne and state school officials. the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today in principl??? a law entitling each of the state's 1.5 million public school pupils to a thorough and efficient education and gave the Legislature until April 6 to devise a method to pay for it.

title: Verrazzano College Lives on Paper
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.In the early 1960's, Gilbert DeLucia, a Greenwich Village businessman, conceived the idea of a new college based on Italian culture and values. He named his hypothetical school Verrazzano College, after the explorer who first found New York harbor.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Rossini's it Barbiere di sivigha, 2; Beethoven's Fidelin, 8.

title: JEAN PAUL LAMIRANDE
description: BELLEVILLE, Ont., Jan. 30 (AP)Jean Paul Lamirande, a defenseman with the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League in the 1940's, died today in a hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CAVALCADE Today, before or after a concert, ballet or opera matinee at Lincoln Center, might be a good time to look in on a dew display of more than 100 scene and costume sketches by Yale University stage designers. It is on view in the main gallery of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at 111 Amsterdam Avenue through March 26.

title: Unions Termed Key in Sunday Racing
description: The future of Sunday horse racing is tremendous, an expert said yesterday. But, like most people around race tracks, he hedged his prediction.

title: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, Campaigner
description: QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 30Eunice Kennedy Shriver stood alone outside the transit turnstiles, a stack of campaign leaflets under her arm, as the rushhour masses swarmed home from Boston the other night. In a palebrown, fur  collared Saks Fifth Avenue coat, she presented the figure of a college girl and the lined face of a 55yearold woman who has lived with triumph and tragedy in the 30 years since she canvassed the tenements of Charlestown and East Boston in her brother John F. Kennedy's first Congressional race. My husband's running for PresidentShriver thanks so mucn, she said over and over.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William H. Steinman, a former chief aide in the State Comptroller's Department, pleaded guilty to grand larceny yesterday for allegedly receiving $10,000 in 1973 to attempt to fix a criminal case staged in a Federalstate inquiry into judicial corruption in Brooklyn.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 30 (UPI)Rod Thorn was dismissed tonight as coach of the Spirits of St. Louis of the American Basketball Association and Joe Mullaney, a longtime college and pro coach, was hired to replace him. Thorn had been the Spirits coach since the beginning of this season after two years as assistant to Coach Kevin Loughery of the New York Nets. Thorn was offered another job with the Spirits organization, but a spokesman said details of the offer have not been completed, and Thorn has not yet agreed to remain with the club.

title: Soviet Georgian Condemns Corruption
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30The head of the Communist Party in Soviet Georgia has issued a pubiic denunciation of corruption, theft, inefficiency and poor workmanship in his republic.

title: A New School to Be Shut
description: Angry parents, their representatives on the Community School Board of District 32, teacher spokesmen and officials, at Intermediate School 291 in Brooklyn announced yesterday that they were gradually going to pull students out of their brand new school and close it because of unsafe and hazardous conditions caused by unfinished construction.

title: Art: Avery's Seascapes and the Masters
description: All esthetic experience is, directly or indirectly, comparative experience. The response we bring to individual works of art is shaped by our personal inventory of earlier responses and what we call taste is a kind of natural selection that results from this cumulative esthetic experience. In this sense, at least, comparisons are anything but odious; they are. in fact, fundamental to all artistic understanding and perception.

title: Theft of Bank Data From Comptroller Reported in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The police reported tonight that confidential papers had been stolen early this morning from the offices of the Comptroller of the Currency here and that a Deputy Comptroller had identified the file cabinet broken into as containing data which was extracted from examination reportsbank by bankon particular banks.

title: KimberlyClark Lifts Price On Newsprint by $25 a Ton
description: The KimberlyClark Company announced yesterday a price increase of $25 a ton to $265 a ton on the 32 pound basis weight newsprint, effective April 1. It follows the same higher rate also announced recently by the Canadian division of the international Paper Company to $285 a ton, and Great Northern Nekoosa Company of Stamford, Conn. to. $280 a ton, both effective march 1.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed into law three bills that forbid medical practitioners to charge their patients for filling out medical insurance claim forms. The three bills together affect physicians, dentists, podiatrists, optometrists and psychologists. The Governor also signed a bill to appropriate $678,620 for transportation expenses from Feb. 1 to June 30 for students at the Marie H. Katzenbach School for the Deaf, a state institution in Trenton.

title: C.I.A. Tried in 50's to Recruit Times Man
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Central Intelligence Agency attempted in the early 1950's to recruit a reporter for The New York Times as an undercover operative abroad, according to C.I.A. documents obtained by the Times.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1976. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday, Jan. 30. 24th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Kissinger Says Angola Issue Has Ended Plans to Seek a Review by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger told a Senate committee today that because of Soviet military involvement in Angola the Ford Administration had dropped plans to ask Congress to reconsider lifting trade restrictions against the Soviet Union.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Encouraged by another prime rate cut by the trendsetting First National City Bank, prices on the American Stock Exchange and overthecounter Market made a broad advance in active tradina.

title: Notes on People
description: With 50 years of diplomatic and government service behind him, David K. E. Bruce stepped down in Brussels yesterday as Ambassador to NATO and will retire to his Virginia estate. The 78yearold dean of the Foreign Service, former Ambassador to Great Britain, France and West Germany, had retired in 1971, but returned in 1973 to become the nation's first envoy to China. He had held Washington appointments in the State Department and Commerce Department and represented the United States at the Vietnam peace talks.

title: Ford Promises Effort to Restore Confidence in C.I.A.
description: McLEAN, Va., Jan. 30President Ford promised officials of the Central Intelligence Agency today that he would work to restore public confidence in the intelligence community without compromising its effectiveness or secrets.

title: Teachers Union Unable to Bar Recall From Sabbatical Leaves
description: The United Federation of Teachers lost a court effort yesterday to stop the Board of Education from recalling about 1,100 teachers from sabbatical leaves when the spring school term begins Monday.

title: 18 Oil Consumer Nations Agree On Plan to Develop Own Energy
description: PARIS, Jan. 31 Eighteen leading Western oil consumer countries agreed today on a longterm program of energy development to lessen dependence on foreign oil. The agreement includes a minimum price of $7 a barrel for oil to protect new investment.

title: Papers in Agnew Inquiry Are Turned Over to Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Justice Department said today it had complied with the order of a judge to turn over for her private inspection documents from the 1973 investigation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Ford Promises Effort to Restore Confidence in C.I.A.
description: McLEAN, Va., Jan. 30President Ford promised officials of the Central Intelligence Agency today that he would work to restore public confidence in the intelligence community without compromising its effectiveness or secrets.

title: MARGARET I. CARMAN
description: Margaret I. Carman, a teacher of history and other subjects at Flushing High School from 1915 to 1960, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Canada's Man in Havana
description: In a brief visit to Cuba, Pierre Elliott Trudeau discovered that Fidel Castro is a man of world stature, one very well informed about Africa, who sent 10,000 Cuban soldiers to fight in Angola's civil war only after a great deal of thought and feeling for the situation.

title: Ford Vetoes Milk Bill
description: President Ford vetoed a bill to raise Federal price supports for milk, saying it would mean unnecessarily high consumer prices and huge surpluses. Page 18.

title: Blurry Hot Dog in Sky Is Identified as Saturn
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 30 (UPI)  Researchers of unidentified flying objects say there is nothing phenomenal about a strange hot clogshaped object photographed recently over Clovis, N.M. They say it is only a blurred picture of the planet Saturn.

title: Nuclear Controls Called No Bar to Making Bombs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Congressional investigators testified today that there was no available evidence that international controls had prevented nations from transferring nuclear materials for their power reactors to military programs to construct atomic bombs.

title: Issue and Debate
description: New York City has lost 25,000 to 30,000 housing units in each of the last five years. In the 1974 fiscal year, 7.4 percent of all realestate taxes due on residential properties went unpaid, a total of $66 million.

title: Jersey Court Upholds a Statute On Thorough Schooling for All
description: TRENTON. Jan. 30In a decision that displeased Governor Byrne and state school officials. the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today in principl a law entitling each of the state's 1.5 million public school pupils to a thorough and efficient education and gave the Legislature until April 6 to devise a method to pay for it.

title: Spread of Crime Alarms French
description: VILLENEUVE  LES  SA BLONS, France. Jan. 25Every night for the last six weeks, small bands of unarmed but robust civilians have been patrolling the main road and narrow lanes in this village of 450 people in Picardy.

title: UNIVERSITY CUTS SOUGHT BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that the State Emergency Financial Control Board would mount an aggressive campaign to get the City University and other semiindependent agencies to stop balking at the city's austerity mandates.

title: State Campaign Fund Law Now Faces Sharp Revision
description: Campaign finance law in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and 32 other states will require drastic revision in the wake of yesterday's Supreme Court decision that struck down nearly all limits on campaign spending by candidates for Federal office.

title: Tax Returns Sought
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Slate Secretary Paul H. Guzzi is asking Presidential candidates to file with him their Federal income tax returns for the last four years. His letters to candidates were mailed today.

title: TV: Live From Lincoln Center With Cliburn
description: With an understandable touch of breathlessness (there was a predictable reference to the Super Bowl), Live From Lincoln Center had its debut on public television last night with a New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall. The guest conductor was Andre Previn.

title: The Renaissance of Paris Couture: A Mood of Glorious Simplicity
description: PARIS. Jan. 30The couture here has obviously renewed itself this season. Why?

title: Ruder & Finn Answers Aerosol Antitrust Suit
description: Ruder & Finn Inc., the public relations concern that figured prominently in the news last week when Marion Javits, wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, resigned her $67,500 consultant position in an Iranian National Airlines account she had steered to the company, filed its answer yesterday to a $6 million antitrust suit by a Connecticut aerosol manufacturer.

title: Ford Campaign Offering to Pay Part of Salary for Morton's Job
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The White House said today that President Ford's campaign committee would pay part of the salary of the new Presidential counselor, Rogers C.B. Morton, if the Federal Election Commission rules that Mr. Morton's salary is covered by campaign, spending limits.

title: Ballet: Miss Makarova in Le Corsaire
description: Injuries and sickness are still playing a large role in the casting of our ballet repertory. Last night at the Uris Theater, where American Ballet Theater is just rounding off this weekned its highly successful sixweek engagement, Natalia Makarova was the victim.

title: Brothers Die in Fire
description: WOOSTER, Ohio, Jan. 30 (UPI)Two young brothers died and three other family members were injured last, night in fire that destroyed their home at nearby Madisonburg. The dead were 8yearod Raymond Hamilton and his brother, Douglas, 10. The fire apparently started in the attie.

title: Moves to Bar Oil Drilling Off Jersey Head to Court
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30A fourday public hearing on Federal plans to permit oil drilling off New Jersey ended today, and efforts to block the plansl shifted to Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Texts of Opinions Striking Down Gag Order by Judge in Carson Murder Case
description: The respondent, a justice of the Supreme Court. Kings County, is presiding at a criminal trial which commenced on Jan. 13, 1976. The defendant Carson, and five codefendants, are on trial, charged with the alleged murder of one Philip Williams on May 23, 1973. The defendants are also charged with kidnapping, robbery and burglary. On Jan. 13, 1976, the first day of the trial, the respondent admonished petitioner [Dena] Kleiman a reporter for petitioner The New York Times and [Irving] Lieberman, a reporter for The New York Post, not to report anything about the case, except what transpired in the courtroom. The respondent advised petitioner Kleiman and Lieberman not to go into any background at all.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Gag Order in Carson Case
description: The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously struck down a gag order issued against the press in the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants.

title: Walker Challenges N.B.A. Option Rule
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP)The reserve clause of the National Basketball Association was challenged today in United States District Court by Chet Walker, who is seeking to be declared free from the Chicago Bulls so he can play with another club of his own choosing.

title: 'Thorough Education Statute Upheld
description: Education experts had estimated that it would take another $375 million for the state to implement the new law fully. that the law was constitutional if it is funded.

title: Books of The Times
description: MaximilienFrangoisMarieIsadore de Robespierre died at an early ageand many say it should have been earlier. He was 36 years old when he put his neck under the guillotine on July 28, 1794, and since then his reputation as a revolutionary, as a theorist and as a person has fluctuated wildly, depending to a marked degree on the politics of the writer. To some in the early years after Thermidor the date of his executionhe was an execrable tyrant, totally without virtue in his bloodthirstiness. Somewhat later this view was slightly modified, and now, almost 200 years after the French Revolution, Robespierre is again examined, this time by George Rude, an able writer on the period and a distinguished professor of history at Concordia University in Montreal.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II, Cunard. Left Nassau Jan. 28; due 9 A.M. at W. 48th St.

title: Life in a Slum in Luanda is Bustling and Regulated
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 30 The place is called Rangel, a sprawl of tinroofed mud shacks without running water or electricity in which 40,000 people live. It is one of the 15 Luanda slums that ring the modern center of this city and that together house some 300,000 people.

title: New Jersey Convict Is Called Informer On Hoff a Suspects
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30Ralph Picardo, a 32yearold member of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who is serving 17 to 20 years in Trenton State Prison in New Jersey on a seconddegree murder conviction, has been identified by a lawyer here as the informer who had named three other New Jersey teamsters has having kidnapped and killed James R. Hoffa on July 30.

title: Pacers End Jinx Of Nets, 127107
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 30 The New York Nets, wellrested but erratic, could do little right tonight and suffered their first defeat of the season to the Indiana Pacers, 127107.

title: $450,000 Awarded For Hospital Death Of Mother of Four
description: A State Supreme Court jury, in Brooklyn, finding that a 26year old mother of four children had been given improper anesthesia during surgery at the Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital and died as a result, awarded her husband $450,000 in compensation yesterday.

title: Undermanned Knicks Routed by Jazz
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30A Case, of the flu for Spencer Haywood and an ailing foot for, Earl Monroe helped send the, Knicks to their third straight loss tonight, a 11997 rout by the New Orleans Jazz in the Louisiana Superdome.

title: Screen:'Manson,' Full-Length Documentary, Opens
description: "Manson," the feature-length documentary now playing at theaters around town, is one of those rip-off movies that tut-tuts with shock at all the unpleasant details it feels it must give us in the interests of higher sociolog and the fast buck.As its title indicates, the film is more or less about Charles T. Manson, one of the four convicted in what became known as the Tate-La-Bianca murders in California in 1969. There are bits and pieces of interviews with Manson, with some of the Manson "family" members who were not arrested in the two murder cases (including Lynette Fromme, who later gained her own notoriety) and with Vincent T. Bugliosi, the prosecuting attorney and author of the best-selling book about the Manson trial, "Helter-Skelter."The producers attempt unsuccessfully to enliven the film by the use of split screens and kaleidoscopic effects, apparently meant to stimulate acid trips recollected in tranquillity, but none of it creates a point of view. This is old-fashioned Sunday-supplement journalism transplanted to the screen for no purpose I can think of, other than money.

title: British Skippers Are Paid To Resume Iceland Fishing,
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) British trawlermen resumed fishing today inside Iceland's disputed 200mile limit after the Government agreed to pay them up to $200,000 for interruptions in fishing during delicate negotiations.

title: Some Budget Figures Compared
description: Following is a summery of the 19761977 capital budget in comparison with the current fiscal year.

title: Press, TV and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30On the night of Iowa's precinot caucuses, as 90 per cent of the state's Democrats were preparing to go bowling or settle in front of their television sets and only 10 percent to go out and vote, Walter Cronkite raised the question on the CBS evening news of what the caucus results would finally mean.

title: Progress Reported By Garment Union In Contract Talks
description: The garment workers union reported some progress in dressindustry negotiations yes terday as the two skies intensified their efforts to reach agreement and avert a strike threatened for Monday.

title: Egg on Their Faces
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The Southeastern Poultry and Egg Association, in convention here this week, voted to give its annual recognition award to the McDonald fastfood chain for its breakfast item. egg mcmuffin. McDonald's however, was quick to decline.

title: ROBERT HAWKINS, 54, ART HISTORIAN, DIES
description: Robert Bradshaw Hawkins, art historian and distinguished professor at the University of Colorado, died last Saturday at his home in Boulder, Colo., apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

title: BUENOS AIRES
Cancer Along The Edges
description: BRUSSELSThe most significant recent trend in Western Europe has not been an advance toward economic and political unity after two decades of faltering along that road but the perceptible crumbling along the edges of the NATO allfance without which European safety and prosperity cannot long endure.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Saigon Reported Calling Holiday Victorious Tet
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The people of Saigon have given the lunar new year a new name, Victorious Tet, the North Vietnam press agency reported today.

title: !Byrne Widens Insurance Role In Medical Malpractice Cases
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 (AP)All companies writing liability insurance in New Jersey may be required to finance medical malpractice insurance under a bill signed into law today by Governor Byrne.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30A fourday public hearing on Federal plans to permit oil drilling off New Jersey ended today, and efforts to block the plans shifted to Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Made by African Villagers
description: Appliqud hangings in crayonbox colors will shortly be brightening the eighthfloor art gallery at Altman's. The simple, primitive looking cotton hangings (they're washable, incidentally) are made by the male villagers of Abomey, the ancient capital of Benin, formerly Dahomey. The hangings, which would work well in a country home or a child's room, depict stylized birds, fish, animals, plants, ships and some mysterious little shapes, all symbols of the old kings of Dahomey. The pieces come in various sizes. They average about. 2 by 4 feet, but there are also Some long skinny vertical banners, as well as narrow horizontal ones that could be used as runners, Prices are $35 to $100. The hangings will be on display from Feb. 7 to 21, and will continue to he available after that, but tucked away. LISA HAMMEL

title: Adoptions of Disabled Children Sought
description: EAST ORANGE, Jan. 30Spaulding for Children, a private, nonprofit adoption agency, opened an office today in this suburban community with hopes of spurring the placement of older, disabled minoritygroup children.

description: Wall Street traded a record volume of shares yesterday in a fitting windup to the most spectacular month in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 30Despite a continuing political uproar over skirmishes between Moroccan forces and Algerianbacked guerrillas in Spanish Sahara, the dispute seems to have become mostly a matter of bark without bite.

description: Governor Carey urged last night that the State Bar Association take a more active role in disciplining errant prosecutors.

title: Exxon's Study of Payoffs in Italy Finds No Basis for Action Against Its Officers
description: The special committee of three directors of the Exxon Corporation investigating the company's political activities and contributions in Italy reported yesterday that evidence did not warrant a suit against any present or former direttors or officers of the company.

title: Divided Judgment
description: A divided Supreme Court has reached a compromise judgment on the difficult issues posed by the farreaching and complex provisions of the Federal Campaign Reform Law. Though much of the decision was affirmative, some elements can prove damaging, even destructive, to the elimination of money as a dominant factor in national elections.

title: Vorster Says Troops Went Long Way in Angola
description: CAPE TOWN, Jan. 30 (AP)Prime Minister John Vorster said today that South African troops had penetrated a very long way into Angola in recent months but said they had not been a party to the civil war there.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday. London: Morning fixing $128.00, down $0.60; afternoon fixing $128.15, down $0.45. Parts: Afternoon market quotation $131.31, down $0.99.

title: CANADA WARNS CUBA ON ANGOLA FLIGHTS
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 30 (UPI)The Canadian Government has advised Cuba against using Gander air base in Newfoundland as a refuelling stop for its military planes to and from Angola.

title: Antiques: A Nautical History of the City
description: To many New Yorkers born since World War II, ships are what sailed on Central Park's artificial ponds each Sunday. And to older Manhattanites, the marine traditions of this island have been increasingly obscured as the roar of jet aircraft replaced the husky blasts of boat whistles.

title: Columbia Five Tops Yale, 7057
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 30Larry Collins of Columbia scored 18 points, his career high, tonight in leading the Lions to a 7057 Ivy League basketball victory over Yale.

title: Summaries of Millrose Games

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  In a landmark ruling on how political campaigns are to be waged, the Supreme Court today upheld public financing for Presidential contests, limits on how much individuals may contribute directly to a candidate in any Federal election race, and strict requirements for reporting both contributions and expenditures.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Ford Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Commitee have agreed on a formula that if approved by Congress would have the effect of giving Israel an additional $556 million in military and economic aid this year.

description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 19 editorials Fairness for Schools and in Schools represent once again The Times contusion concerning education in our city.

title: Elusive Group in Britain Is Recruiting for Angola
description: CAMBERLEY, England, Jan. 30The man in his 20's, shivering in the icy winds, placed a sheet of paper beneath the locked doors of two homes in this pleasant army town. The papers contained the youth's name, his telephone number and the date of his army discharge.

title: CITY WON'T MAKE USE OF A TAX ON IMPORTS
description: New taxes on business operations is not the way to solve our city's fiscal problems, Mayor Beame said yesterday in announcing that the city would not take advantage of a recent United States Supreme Court ruling permitting cities and states to tax inventories of imported goods.

title: Default Pays City Hall a Call
description: A black and white mutt  apparently lost, obviously hungry and shivering with cold  turned up at City Hall yesterday and ran into the president and executive vice president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on the Randolph Hearst family that appeared in The New York Times on Thursday, David Hearst was incorrectly identified in some editions as head of The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer. He is former publisher of The Los Angeles HeraldExpress, a predecessor of The HeraldExaminer. The publisher of The HeraldExaminer is George R. Hearst Jr.

title: Japan to Extend Sea Limit
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30 (AP)The Government announced today that it would extend Japan's territorial sea limits from the present three nautical miles to 12, but it did not say when. A decision on timing awaits the next session of the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea, which begins on March 15 in New York.

title: Equality in Britain: Envy and Bourgeois Guilt
description: WHAT EXTENT is more equality desired in Great Britairt today? Statistical myths lead directly to the claim that there is a widespread sense of resentment and injustice over the current degree of inequality in our society and great enthusiasm for its elimination. This political judgment is closely linked in many commentators eyes with, the quite separate proposition that class divisions in Britain are severe and reinforced by economic inequality.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Administration is planning fewer trade concessions for the Soviet Union in retaliation against its military involvement in Angola. Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, testifying on trade policies, told the Senate Finance Committee yesterday that the Administration had dropped plans to reconsider lifting trade restrictions against the Soviet Union and that recent Soviet actions such as that in Angola had caused him to oppose the joint SovietAmerican multibilliondollar deals that had been proposed to exploit natural gas and other resources. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: A Bennington Group is Meeting To Replace President Who Quit
description: A group of trustees and faculty members of Bennington College will meet here today to try to reach areement on the choice of an acting president to replace Dr. Gail T. Parker.
